title: Plus/Minus in the N.B.A., a Plus or Minus?
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology IT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference is regarded as a gathering of like-minded sports dorks pushing basketball statistics away from traditional measures, such as points and assists, and toward more advanced measures, including hockey-style plus/minus. But at this years conference in March a debate continued over whether plus/minus is relevant when evaluating individual players in basketball. Some critics contend it might work better in measuring the effectiveness of five-man lineups.

title: What Were Reading: Slacker U.
After 158 Weeks, a New Womens No. 1
description: Lorena Ochoas goal was to retire at the top and she did, but barely. Ochoas reign as the No. 1 player in the world was like a long putt that ekes into the hole; it expired at the very end of her full-time career.

title: Bjork DJs in Brooklyn: Pleated Burgundy, Questlove and More
description: Bjork plays a parking garage sounds like a dreamy Michel Gondry video pitch, but this weekend, it was a sweaty reality. Above the Auto Parts is an accurately named space: literally above an auto parts store in Bushwick, Brooklyn, it is a parking garage for much of the week thats lately doubled as a DIY club. Bjork liked it enough to DJ a show there on Sunday night, a benefit for the Haiti relief group Partners in Health. (She checked out another venue, the Market Hotel, which has since been shut down, but preferred Above the Auto Parts because it was rougher, said the promoter, Todd Patrick.) The other DJs were also a whos who of the New York music scene: Dave Longstreth of the art-rock favorites the Dirty Projectors, Tyondai Braxton of the math rock-y Battles, Alex Ross of The New Yorker and Brandon Stosuy, an editor at the music blog Stereogum, who helped organize the event, all took turns or buddied up at the decks to play a mix of obscure tunes and pop hits. The crowd was mostly Brooklyners who turned out to dance despite the fact that the unventilated space had them sweating even when standing still.

title: Point Counterpoint: How to Use (and Avoid Misusing) PowerPoint
description: Overview | Is PowerPoint a valuable tool, or does it stifle critical thinking and innovative presentation of material? How can information be presented visually using PowerPoint without falling into the trap of simplistic bullet-point prose? In this lesson, students examine perspectives on effective and ineffective uses of PowerPoint, then develop a set of rules for effective use of this tool for their class projects and presentations. They then create PowerPoint slides and a prose narrative on the same subject and compare the impact of each on the intended audience.

title: Awards Night | Not Afraid of Color
description: This week, the paint company Benjamin Moore will present its Hue Awards for the best use of color in architecture and interiors, and the lifetime achievement award will go to the New York design team of William Diamond and Anthony Baratta, whose sophisticated, bold, and vividly-colored interiors have been featured in The New York Times Magazine. Although the choice of Diamond Baratta would seem a no-brainer, this is the first time that the award has gone to interior designers; past winners were the architects Steven Holl, Ettore Sottsass, and Ricardo Legorreta. Diamond Baratta is known for custom-designing everything from fabrics to braided rugs, and paint colors are no exception. But in an odd coincidence, the designers have always used Benjamin Moore paint bases. And when they told told the company that they were donating their $5000 prize money to the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, which provides specialized care to people with HIV and AIDS, Benjamin Moore matched Diamond Barattas donation. Baratta credits Diamond with being the firms color maven. Bill is really the maestro of color selection, he said. Its like musicyou have to have perfect pitch. Above, a few of the firms colorful interiors.

title: Germany Clears Rescue for Greece

Although he later recanted that confession, it was captured on video and broadcast on Indian television.

I have collected cockroaches from many different places, Mr. Pea said. From Cuba, Mexico, Miami, Houston, everywhere I travel.

Rhiannon Giddens, the bands singer and banjo player, quickly described the connection between banjos and West African stringed instruments, then produced an akonting, a three-stringed ancestor of the banjo from Gambia. She played it for about two minutes, down-stroking it, claw-hammer style, as she had the American instrument, and sang in that regions Jola language.

title: Broadway Box Office Declines; Link to Bomb Scare Unclear
description: Almost all Broadway plays and musicals lost money at the box office last week, with some of the biggest declines occurring at theaters near the car that was found to contain a defective bomb on Saturday evening. The ensuing evacuation of Times Square could have been a factor in some of the box office declines, theater industry executives acknowledged, but they said they had no data to confirm such a correlation.

description: What: The Art of Elysium Second Annual New York fundraiser with Donatella Versace and Christopher Kane for Versus.

title: Stravinsky, That Teller of Russian Fables
description: Avery Fisher Hall was more fully packed for the Sunday afternoon installment of the New York Philharmonics Russian Stravinsky festival than it had been for several of the orchestras recent subscription concerts. Part of the draw, no doubt, was Valery Gergiev, whose high-energy Stravinsky recordings held out the promise that this festival would be among the highlights of the season. Certainly the works at hand  two of Stravinskys enduring, acid-tinged fables, Renard (1916) and LHistoire du Soldat (1918)  have ample partisans. And it probably did not hurt that the orchestra invited its new best friend from the world of popular culture, the actor Alec Baldwin, to narrate Histoire.

title: Much Movie Title Meshugas
description: LOS ANGELES  It might take the reasoning powers, not to mention the vocabulary, of a Talmudic scholar to figure out what Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks are trying to say with the title of their new Steve Carell comedy.

description: BEACON, N.Y.  To watch Trisha Browns best dances, particularly the early ones, is to be aware of how little a choreographer has to do to hold the stage: a single idea, developed with rigor and presented with clarity, is often all it takes.

description: Harry Winsor, an 8-year-old from Boulder, Colo., loves airplanes. He flies with his father, John Winsor, the chief executive of the ad agency Victors & Spoils, to places like Europe and Africa regularly. Recently, he began designing his own airplanes, and decided to send one such drawing to Boeing with the suggestion that they manufacture his plane.

title: When It Comes to Sex, Chimps Need Help, Too
description: The human ego has never been quite the same since the day in 1960 that Jane Goodall observed a chimpanzee feasting on termites near Lake Tanganyika. After carefully trimming a blade of grass, the chimpanzee poked it into a passage in the termite mound to extract his meal. No longer could humans claim to be the only tool-making species.

title: Emotion, Spectacle and Songs Writ Large
description: Peter Gabriel has never shied away from grandeur or paused at the threshold of spectacle. But restraint is part of the package too: few figures in pop are as adept with dynamics, at building pressure in a song. On Sunday night, in his first of two sold-out concerts at Radio City Music Hall, Mr. Gabriel made some interior sentiments feel momentous, practically seismic, and kept others small but mesmerizing, like lightning bugs in a jar.

title: We Three Things | Bird Braids
description: I hear more birds than I see. Neither my patience nor my neighborhood seem conducive to watching birds and their enigmatic nesting rituals. With springs arrival, I hear them calling and chirping outside my window, but I rarely turn around to look. Instead my eye is drawn to designers and artists producing their own versions of ornithology.

title: When East and West Collided, but Commingled to Make Music
description: The once constricted world of Western early music has opened to new  O.K., old  and exotic vistas in recent years as it explores the fertile ground it shares with Eastern, especially Middle Eastern, performance styles. And no one has played a more pivotal role in this exploration than Jordi Savall, the Catalan string virtuoso who now seems fully at home in the motley musical precincts of Jerusalem.

title: That Continuing Radical, Balanchine
description: The ads for New York City Ballets season announce Architecture of Dance  New Choreography and Music Festival  7 New Ballets, 4 Commissioned Scores, 1 Renowned Architect. You might assume  wrongly  that the season contained nothing but new works.

title: It Started More Than One Revolution
description: The birth control pill has been called the most important scientific advance of the 20th century, and no wonder. Fifty years after its approval by the Food and Drug Administration, it is still one of the leading methods of contraception, in the United States and around the world.

title: Its Reopening Night at the Jane Ballroom
description: After months of back-and-forth with city officials, the Jane Ballroom is finally reopening tonight, according to one of the owners who declined to be named but emphasized the new quiet (shhh!) and private nature of the place.

title: Tune In for the Tony Nominations
description: Will any Broadway show approach the record-tying 15 Tony Award nominations of last years Billy Elliot: The Musical? Will the cavalcade of Hollywood stars on the boards dominate the Tony acting nominations announced Tuesday morning, or will lesser-known theater veterans receive their fair share for critically acclaimed work? Will plays and musicals that opened and closed earlier in the 2009-10 theater season  like Finians Rainbow, Ragtime, The Royal Family, Superior Donuts, and Time Stands Still  receive much recognition compared to shows that are still running? Which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed? Were live-blogging the Tony nominations starting at 8:30 a.m. here.

title: Russian Orphanage Offers Love, but Not Families
description: MOSCOW  There is nothing dreary about Orphanage No. 11. It has rooms filled with enough dolls and trains and stuffed animals to make any child giggly. It has speech therapists and round-the-clock nurses and cooks who delight in covertly slipping a treat into a tiny hand. It has the feel of a place where love abounds.

title: Second Stages Season
description: Off Broadways Second Stage Theater announced on Monday that its 2010-11 season would include productions of new plays by Lynn Nottage (below; the winner of the 2009 Pulitzer Prize in drama for Ruined) and Rajiv Joseph (Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo) as well as a revival of Arthur Kopits 1978 drama, Wings. Ms. Nottages play, a world premiere called By the Way, Meet Vera Stark, is scheduled to begin performances in April 2011. Second Stage described the work as a 70-year journey into the life of Vera Stark, a headstrong African-American maid and budding actress, and her tangled relationship with her boss, a white Hollywood star desperately grasping to hold on to her career. The director is to be announced. The Second Stage season will begin in the fall with the Kopit drama, about a female aviators recovery from a stroke; the work was nominated for the Tony Award for best play in 1979. It will be directed by John Doyle, who won the 2006 Tony for best direction of a musical for Sweeney Todd, and is scheduled to begin previews in early October, with an opening night to be announced. After Wings will be the New York premiere of Mr. Josephs new play, Gruesome Playground Injuries, described as a dark romantic saga about two childhood friends whose lives intersect over 30 years in damaging ways. The director will be Scott Ellis, with previews scheduled to begin in early January 2011. A fourth production for the 2010-11 season will be announced later.

title: Car Bomb a Possible Factor in Broadway Declines
description: Almost all Broadway plays and musicals lost money at the box office last week, with some of the biggest declines occurring at theaters near a car that was found to contain a bomb on Saturday evening. The ensuing evacuation of Times Square could have been a factor in some of the declines, theater industry executives acknowledged, but they said they had no data to confirm such a correlation. The car with the bomb was found on West 45th Street, just west of Seventh Avenue and right outside the Minskoff Theater, where The Lion King is playing. Last week The Lion King had one of the biggest declines, of $113,440, although the hit show still grossed $1.3 million, third behind Wicked and The Addams Family. The largest week-to-week decline was for Mary Poppins at the New Amsterdam Theater on West 42nd Street, close to Seventh Avenue and some of the most heavily trafficked subway stops in Times Square; some theatergoers said they did not reach their shows on Saturday night because of subway delays and were exchanging their tickets. Mary Poppins was down $180,251 from the previous week, to a total of $704,541. No Broadway shows canceled performances because of the bomb scare and evacuation. Over all, Broadway box offices grossed $20.7 million, down from $22.1 million the previous week  but up from the $19.9 million for the same week last season.

title: Little Miss Sunshine Heads to La Jolla
description: While Abigail Breslins Broadway debut in The Miracle Worker did not meet with much success, a stage adaptation of the movie that helped put her on the map (and earned her an Academy Award nomination at age 10) is inching ever closer to Broadway. The musical version of Little Miss Sunshine will be presented next year at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, Variety reported. The film, which also starred Greg Kinnear, Steve Carell, Toni Collette and Alan Arkin, centered on a precocious young performer (Ms. Breslin) and her eccentric familys do-or-die efforts to get her into a beauty pageant. It was a breakout hit at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and went on to earn more than $100 million at the box office worldwide. A version of the musical was presented last year at the Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak in Yulee, Fla. The La Jolla production, which will run from Feb. 15 through March 27, 2011, features music and lyrics by William Finn and a book and direction by James Lapine. No casting has been announced.

title: Columbia Receives Gorey Drawings
description: A large group of drawings, etchings, posters and more by the macabre master illustrator and writer Edward Gorey has been given to Columbia University Libraries. Andrew Alpern, an architectural historian and lawyer who published a collection of ephemera by Gorey in 1980, donated the more than 700 items, which include nearly every edition of every work that Gorey published. Gorey (above in a self-portrait), who died in 2000, ranged over a wide field, drawing the animated opening sequence for PBSs television series Mystery!, designing costumes and sets on Broadway, writing more than 100 books and illustrating more than 60 others by authors that included Samuel Beckett and Edward Lear. He won a Tony Award for best costume and set design for the 1977 production of Dracula. When asked why he spent his time on murder and other violence, he answered: Well, I dont know. I guess Im interested in real life.

title: $22.5. Million Gift For Kennedy Center
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has received a $22.5 million gift from Betsy and Dick DeVos for its Institute of Arts Management, which will now be called the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center, the center announced. It also announced that David M. Rubenstein had been appointed the Kennedy Centers chairman, succeeding Stephen A. Schwarzman. The arts management institute was created in 2001 by Michael M. Kaiser, president of the Kennedy Center. In addition to offering 10 full-time fellowships for arts managers annually, it brings 42 arts managers from around the world to Washington for a summer fellowship program. The Kennedy Center said Mr. Kaiser would remain as president through 2014 and then lead the DeVos Institute for another three years. The DeVoses gift will create an endowment that will support the institute indefinitely, the center said. Ms. DeVos, who is a Kennedy Center trustee, said in a telephone interview that while donating money to train administrators might seem less sexy than directly financing artistic creation, having good managers leverages the creative talents of thousands of artists.

title: On 60 Minutes, Conan Is No. 1
description: There were no ratings problems for Conan OBrien on Sunday night as an episode of 60 Minutes featuring his first television interview since departing The Tonight Show was the nights most-watched program, according to Nielsens estimates. The broadcast, in which Mr. OBrien said he got very depressed at times after NBC reinstated Jay Leno at 11:35 p.m. and he left the network, drew 13.3 million viewers. CBS was No. 1 for the night over all with a lineup that included The Amazing Race (10.5 million) and back-to-back episodes of Cold Case at 9 (9.6 million) and 10 (10.1 million). ABC was runner-up on the night with Desperate Housewives (12 million), and NBC was third with Dateline (5.2 million), Minute to Win It (5.6 million) and The Celebrity Apprentice (7 million). Fox placed fourth with its comedy lineup, including an hourlong Family Guy (7.3 million) to mark the shows 150th episode.

title: Poll Shows Most in U.S. Want Overhaul of Immigration Laws
description: LOS ANGELES  The overwhelming majority of Americans think the countrys immigration policies need to be seriously overhauled. And despite protests against Arizonas stringent new immigration enforcement law, a majority of Americans support it, even though they say it may lead to racial profiling.

title: The Buzz Is All About BP at Oil Drillers Conference
description: 7:35 p.m. | Updated  Added information on BPs presence at the conference.

title: Readers Dont Like Being Shortchanged
description: The copper-plated cousin of the more expensive dime and nickel is sometimes seen as a castaway in the change circle. How often have you shed yours in the Take a penny, leave a penny tray at the 7-11 counter?

title: Mets Play It Safe and Send Pelfrey for M.R.I.
description: CINCINNATI  Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey had a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder Monday, but it revealed no structural damage and Pelfrey is expected to make his next start Friday against the Giants.

title: Slide Show: Four Decades of New Orleans Tradition and a Whole Lot of Jazz
description: The 41st annual New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival began on April 23 and ended Sunday with performances by Maze, with Frankie Beverly, above, and others.

title: In Darwin Family, Evidence of Inbreedings Ill Effects
description: Charles Darwin, the author of the theory of evolution, may have been right to worry that his childrens health had been affected by the inbreeding in his own family, especially that of his wife, Emma Wedgwood, who was his first cousin.

title: By the Architects, for the People: A Trend for the 2010s
description: NEWARK  Last week, when the city planning board here voted to approve construction of a four-block-long mixed-use development, the decision was barely noticed outside a small circle of civic boosters. But it was a turning point in the career of the projects architect, Richard Meier.

title: A New Poll Finds Support for Arizonas Immigration Law
description: In the wake of Arizonas new immigration law, a poll released today by The Times and CBS News finds that a slim majority of Americans support the legislation. An overwhelming majority of respondents also believe the nations immigration laws should undergo an extensive overhaul.

title: A Rapid Security Check Could Be Revived at Airports
description: The idea of a monthly subscription service that allows people to jump to the head of airport security lines by submitting to a fingerprint or iris scan may be getting another chance.

title: Watercress, as Fresh as a Gurgling Spring
description: WATERCRESS does not incite the kind of frenzy generated by ramps, those spindly wild onions that nobody bothered to pick until a few chefs began trumpeting their arrival as a major springtime event. But it is starting to show up in farmers markets, too, and those who know it, love it.

description: Salt

description: For the first time in 43,000 years, a woolly mammoth has breathed again on earth.

description: Updated, 8:55 a.m. |  Jeffrey Rosen, a law professor and author of The Naked Crowd, joins the discussion.

title: Grant Achatz To Open a Restaurant and a Bar
description: How many forthcoming restaurants are announced, Hollywood-style, with a trailer? Alinea, opened in Chicago by Grant Achatz and Nick Kokonas five years ago this week, featured a short coming soon film on its website many months before its kitchen was built. Today, Mr. Achatz and Mr. Kokonas did it again, releasing a trailer for Next Restaurant and a cocktail lounge called Aviary, both projected to open in Chicago this fall. (The exact addresses have not been announced.)

title: Particle Detector Shows Promise, if Nothing Else
description: A new widely anticipated experiment underneath a mountain in Italy designed to detect a sea of dark particles that allegedly constitute a quarter of creation did not see anything during a test run last fall, scientists reported Saturday.

title: Tax Break for Erotica? A Museum Favors It
description: A few years ago, when Ann Marie Coughlin, a New York dominatrix also known as Domina M., donated her brushed-steel bondage machine to be shown at the Museum of Sex, many people benefited.

title: Hertz May Have Rival in Bid for Dollar Thrifty
description: The Avis Budget Group signaled on Monday a potential bidding war for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, saying it was considering a bid that would top the $1.2 billion offer by Hertz Global Holdings.

title: A Faded Relic of Christendom Reappears
description: TURIN, Italy  The Roman Catholic Church is weathering another sex scandal, but it is impossible to tell here, where the faint image of a bearded man on a yellowing linen sheet provides the moment, if brief, for pilgrims to declare and reaffirm their faith. For some, it does not matter if the Shroud of Turin is authentic. It is the shared spiritual experience that counts most.

title: Push to Insulate Deaf Students From Dissimilar School
description: The students at Public School 347 in Manhattan sit at round tables when they eat lunch  the better to see one anothers hands when they chat using sign language.

title: Carrots Share Trait With Tiny Pea Aphid
description: Theres a reason your parents kept after you to eat your carrots. The vegetables (and lots of others, too) supply carotenoids, compounds that are good for vision and overall health. Animals, humans included, cannot manufacture them.

description: What the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times took notice of Monday:

title: Cavaliers Ask: Whats a Foul?
description: Some thought the fourth-quarter play Saturday on which Clevelands Shaquille ONeal sent Bostons Rajon Rondo sprawling to the courts floor in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series constituted a flagrant foul. So it was odd when Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown acknowledged that he sent tape of the foul to N.B.A. headquarters for clarification.

title: Where Weedkiller Wont Work
description: Farmers wide use of Roundup, also known as glyphosate, a popular herbicide, has led to the spread of Roundup-resistant weeds across the country. At least 10 species of Roundup-resistant weeds have infested millions of acres in more than 22 states since 2000.

title: Toxin Tied to Illness Is Found in Baltic Sea
description: In the 1950s, the Chamorro people of Guam had a very high incidence of a neurodegenerative illness similar to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S. A neurotoxin called BMAA, which is produced by cyanobacteria found in the seeds of an edible plant and accumulates in the food chain, has long been suspected as the cause.

title: And You Thought Iceland Was a Problem
description: One thing is clear from Tuesdays Nova on PBS: Mount St. Helens is messing with us.

title: Famine Persists in Niger, but Denial Is Past
description: NIAMEY, Niger  Outside the state food warehouses here, women sift in the dirt for spilled grains of rice. Seven hundred miles to the east, mothers pluck bitter green berries and boil them for hours in an attempt to feed their children. In urban slums and desert villages, one word is on all lips: famine.

title: A Quandary in Restoring Bald Eagle Populations
description: For three decades, scientists have been trying with only limited success to re-establish breeding populations of bald eagles on the Channel Islands off the Southern California coast. The eagles disappeared from the islands in the 1960s, victims, like many other birds, of DDT, which affected their ability to reproduce.

title: Why So Blue?
description: Q. Why do Martha Stewart chickens produce blue and green eggs?

description: An advocacy group is defending one of its advertisements following criticism about how the spot claims a Senate candidate in Arkansas helped outsource jobs to India.

description: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, did a series of illustrations of Ms. Redgrave in her theater productions.

title: Lynn Redgrave, Actress and Playwright, Dies at 67
description: Lynn Redgrave, who as an actress upheld the tradition of her theatrically royal family on stage and on screen and as a playwright wrote about her family with probing affection and equally probing anguish, died on Sunday at her home in Kent, Conn. She was 67.

title: Militia Members Released Until Trial in Michigan Plot
description: DETROIT  A federal judge on Monday ordered that nine members of an extremist militia accused of plotting to kill police officers be freed on bond until their trial, saying that prosecutors did not demonstrate that the defendants would pose a danger if released.

title: Auto Businessmen Briefly at Bomb Inquirys Focus
description: In every terror inquiry, there are the investigators, the persons of interest and the targets of suspicion. Then there are the Wayne LeBlancs, who get rousted out of their beds by federal agents because of some connective tissue  tenuous or not  linking them to the culprits.

title: Helpful Tips From Locals for New No. 2
description: Stephen Goldsmith, a former mayor of Indianapolis, has been named New Yorks new deputy mayor for operations, which makes him the fellow who, figuratively speaking, is supposed to make the trains run on time. Mr. Goldsmith is said to be good at that.

title: Saints Accused of Mishandling Prescription Drug
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration is investigating allegations made in a lawsuit by a former employee of the New Orleans Saints that the club tried to cover up the theft of Vicodin pills from its training facility by a senior member of the teams staff.

title: U.S. to Send Trainers to Afghanistan as Stopgap
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has signed an order sending 850 more American military personnel to Afghanistan as a stopgap measure to fill vacancies in the high-priority effort to train local security forces, Pentagon officials said Monday.

title: No Place Like This for Soothing Care
description: NORWICH, Vt.  The renovated barn next to the family house was always one of Kevin Pearces favorite places. There is a skateboard ramp out back and a giant recreation room inside, with three loftlike bedrooms above.

title: Iraqi Sunnis Frustrated as Awakening Loses Clout
description: FALLUJA, Iraq  Sheik Aiffan Saadoun al-Aiffan stepped across a scorched patch of farmland, raised his shotgun and fired once. A bird fell to the ground.

title: New Paterson Policy May Reduce Deportations
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Monday that the state would accelerate consideration and granting of pardons to legal immigrants for old or minor criminal convictions, in an effort to prevent them from being deported.

title: Selig Can Send Message on Arizona Immigration Law
description: In 18 years as the head of Major League Baseball, Bud Selig has been fed a steady stream of fastballs. There have been labor fastballs and steroid fastballs, pitches he has learned how to hit. Lately, he has been taking his hacks at human growth hormone fastballs.

title: Fast Start Surprises Even the Red Bulls
description: The play and decision-making of Red Bulls midfielder Dane Richards often can run hot and cold  but he always runs fast.

title: When Is a Cross a Cross?
description: Also, when is a menorah a menorah, and when is a crche a crche, and when are the Ten Commandments directives given to the Jews by God on Mt. Sinai? These questions, which might seem peculiar in the real world, are perfectly ordinary in the wild and wacky world of Establishment Clause jurisprudence, where in one case (Lynch v. Donnelly, 1984) the Supreme Court declared, with a straight judicial face, that a display featuring the baby Jesus, Mary, Joseph and the wise men conveyed a secular, not a religious message.

title: City Cuts Ties to Catholic Agency That Provides Foster Care
description: New York Citys child welfare agency said Monday that it would sever its foster care contracts with Little Flower Children and Family Services of New York, an 80-year-old Roman Catholic agency that has been troubled in recent years.

title: Marea, Boulud, Colicchio and McNally Win Beard Awards
description: Monday nights 21st running of the Beard awards, the annual anointing of chefs and restaurateurs by the James Beard Foundation, followed the pattern of most years: restaurants and chefs in New York under the umbrellas of Daniel Boulud, Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Danny Meyer, again took home awards.

title: Army Examines Units Treating Injured Soldiers
description: A high-ranking general said Monday that the Army wanted to learn more about shortcomings at its Warrior Transition Units, which treat soldiers with physical injuries and severe psychological trauma and have come under criticism from service members and their families.

title: Extra Security and Raised Alerts: You Get Used to It, but Youre Not Used to It
description: The acrid smell meant something was wrong, maybe dangerously wrong, and John Schneider, sitting at his superintendents desk on Monday in an office building on West 40th Street, just off Times Square, immediately looked outside. Flames from an open manhole shot three stories into the air.

title: Googles Venture Fund Steps Up the Pace
description: Google has been throwing money around the last few days. It bought a start-up called BumpTop, invested in wind farms and, on Monday, announced its 10th venture investment and some details about its year-old venture capital fund.

title: Gulf Oil Spill Is Bad, but How Bad?
description: WASHINGTON  The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is bad  no one would dispute it. But just how bad?

title: Unexploded Car Bomb Left Trove of Evidence
description: Among the enduring images left by car bombings, overseas or in the United States, is investigators on their hands and knees, crawling through the wreckage searching for clues: a blasting cap or a timing device, a piece of the explosives casing or a trace of the chemicals used.

title: Canadiens Goalie May Not Be Familiar, but Theme Is
description: MONTREAL  When it comes to the Canadiens, there is always a proud tradition of one kind or another, like that of a young, relatively green goalie rising from obscurity to lead them on a surprising run through the playoffs.

title: Weather Hampers Efforts to Burn Some of Oil Spill
description: ROBERT, La.  While a controlled burn of petroleum in the Gulf of Mexico was judged successful last week, strong winds and rain have hampered efforts to conduct additional ones to contain the spill.

title: Ochoa Loses No. 1 Ranking Day After She Retires
description: Lorena Ochoas goal was to retire at the top, and she did, but barely. Ochoas reign as the No. 1 player in the world was like a long putt that ekes into the hole; it expired at the very end of her full-time career.

title: Justices Agree on Detainee Death Case
description: WASHINGTON  A man who received what the government concedes was negligent medical treatment while held by immigration authorities may not sue the personnel who failed to treat him, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a unanimous decision.

title: The Way Out
description: President Obama made a convincing case last December for sending an additional 30,000 American troops to Afghanistan. Most of those new forces, plus 58,000 already in country, would fight the Taliban. A smaller number would mold Afghan recruits into an indigenous Army and National Police force that could in time assume responsibility for protecting their country so the Americans and NATO allies could go home.

title: Step Away From the Courthouse Doors
description: WASHINGTON  In a decision ripe with symbolism about access to justice in the age of terror, the Supreme Court announced on Monday that visitors to its courthouse will no longer be allowed to enter through the front door.

title: Whats in a Name?
description: We are skeptical that merging with Continental Airlines can solve the perennial woes of United Airlines, which has reported billions of dollars in losses and spent three of the last 10 years in bankruptcy proceedings. Continental also reported losses during most of the last decade. Leaving aside any business rationale, what worries us about the proposed merger is what it could mean for harried travelers.

title: The Supreme Courts Doors
description: In a sad bow to security concerns, visitors to the Supreme Court will no longer enter the Cass Gilbert building by climbing its marble steps and passing through its bronze doors and underneath the words that define the courts mission: Equal Justice Under Law. The court announced on Monday that the public will now have to enter through a new reinforced area at the plaza level.

title: Luck and Vigilance
description: New York City was lucky this time. The bomb-laden vehicle that pulled into Times Square Saturday night smoldered but didnt ignite. Two nearby vendors warned a policeman. Officers quickly cleared the area and alerted bomb-squad specialists and investigators.

title: Critics' Picks: 'High and Low'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Akira Kurosawa's film about a kidnapping in postwar Japan.

title: Bloggingheads:  Is Obama a Socialist?
description: David Frum, left, of FrumForum and Jonah Goldberg of National Review debate whether the president is a socialist.

title: Farmers Cope With Roundup-Resistant Weeds
description: DYERSBURG, Tenn.  For 15 years, Eddie Anderson, a farmer, has been a strict adherent of no-till agriculture, an environmentally friendly technique that all but eliminates plowing to curb erosion and the harmful runoff of fertilizers and pesticides.

title: France: Synagogue Defaced and Jewish Man Is Attacked
description: Three attackers defaced a synagogue in Nmes on Sunday, then threw tear gas at a 78-year-old Jewish man, the local police said Monday. Word of the attack came as 300 people gathered Monday in front of the Strasbourg synagogue in eastern France to express solidarity with the victim of another anti-Semitic assault, on Friday in downtown Strasbourg. There, a Jewish man was repeatedly stabbed. Two suspects were charged Sunday, the police said.

title: France: Sentence Is Suspended for Former Interior Minister
description: A one-year prison sentence for corruption has been suspended against a former French senator and onetime close ally of former President Jacques Chirac, according to a court document released Monday. The Justice Court of the Republic last week found Charles Pasqua, 83, guilty of complicity in embezzling public funds when he was interior minister, but suspended his sentence on the basis of his age and his past in service of France. The case involved kickbacks paid to Mr. Pasquas son and other close associates in 1993 and 1994 in connection with sales of French police equipment abroad.

title: Turkey: Parliament Rejects Plan to Protect Political Parties
description: In a surprise blow to the government and its plans to change Turkeys Constitution, Parliament rejected a proposal on Monday that would have made it harder to ban political parties. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said, however, that he would press on with the plan, which opponents see as a bid to expand his partys grip on state institutions and undermine the countrys secular principles. More than 20 parties, have been closed on charges that they were linked to terrorist groups or had antisecular tendencies. Mr. Erdogans party, AK, which has roots in political Islam but denies ambitions to create an Islamic state, says the changes are needed to bring Turkey closer to European Union democratic norms.

title: The Limits of Policy
description: Roughly a century ago, many Swedes immigrated to America. Theyve done very well here. Only about 6.7 percent of Swedish-Americans live in poverty. Also a century ago, many Swedes decided to remain in Sweden. Theyve done well there, too. When two economists calculated Swedish poverty rates according to the American standard, they found that 6.7 percent of the Swedes in Sweden were living in poverty.

title: A Moment Kent State Wont Forget
description: KENT, Ohio  Black pillars mark four sites on the east side of Kent State University  each memorializing one of the four college students killed by the Ohio National Guard during antiwar protests on May 4, 1970.

title: Top New York Judge Urges Greater Legal Rights for the Poor
description: New Yorks chief judge called on Monday for a new guarantee of a lawyer for poor people in civil cases, like suits over eviction and other disputes where basic needs are at stake, pushing the state to the forefront of a national effort to expand the right to representation for the indigent.

title: Yankees Want to Fix Vazquez, but Not at Fenway
description: The Yankees would have almost nothing to lose by starting Javier Vazquez this weekend at Fenway Park. If the Boston Red Sox were to beat up Vazquez, it would be nothing new for him. But if Vazquez pitched well, it could be a springboard to recovery from an abysmal start to the season.

title: For Obama, a Nonstop Juggling Act
description: President Obamas spokesman promised for a second day on Monday that the administration would keep our boot on the throat of BP to get the company to resolve the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Yet, hours later, the president was hosting dinner at the White House with executives of the Business Council. Among the companies represented by the corporate club: BP.

title: Rutgers Hires Coach From Robert Morris
description: Mike Rice, who coached a Robert Morris team that took second-seeded Villanova to overtime before losing, 73-70, in the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, has agreed to become the next coach at Rutgers.

title: Christie, Shunning Precedent, Drops Justice From Court
description: Once again showing that he means to shake up Trenton, Gov. Christopher J. Christie declined on Monday to reappoint a sitting justice to the New Jersey Supreme Court, instead appointing someone who he said would show the restraint that was missing from the court.

title: In His 10th Season, Crawford Is Finally Enjoying the Playoffs
description: The last player to reach the interview podium Sunday at Philips Arena in Atlanta was the one who treasured the opportunity the most. And not just because Jamal Crawford likes to talk.

title: No Charges for Ex-Head of Housing Under Bush
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has decided not to file charges against Alphonso R. Jackson, the former secretary of housing and urban development in the Bush administration, over allegations that he improperly steered federal contracts to friends, his lawyers said Monday.

title: Jean-Louis Dumas, Chief of Herms, Dies at 72
description: Jean-Louis Dumas, who revived the flagging fortunes of Herms in the late 1970s and in his nearly 30 years as the companys chief executive transformed it into one of the worlds most successful luxury brands, died Saturday at his home in Paris. He was 72.

title: After an M.R.I. on His Shoulder, Pelfrey Is Set to Make His Next Start
description: CINCINNATI  Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey is expected to make his next start Friday against the San Francisco Giants after a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder Monday revealed no structural damage.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,385 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,040 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Patricia Rico, Proponent of Womens Track and Field, Dies at 76
description: Patricia Rico, a central figure in womens track and field for more than 50 years and the first woman to be the president of USA Track and Field, the sports governing body, died Sunday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. She was 76 and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Hired to Bring Order, Kings Adviser Brings Peace

title: Vain Glorious | How to Get Pampered in Paris

In Paris, nail salons are few and far between, and when you do find one, Madam must make an appointment! Walk-ins are unheard of. And forget having your cuticles cut. It is simply not done! But if you know where to look, the French are extremely good at lavishing you with care. And thats where Pampered in Paris: A Guide to the Best Spas, Salons and Beauty Books (The Little Bookroom, New York; available May 11 for $16.95 at littlebookroom.com) comes in. The author, Kim Horton Levesque, has scoured the boulevards and the back alleys. Shes soaked in hammams and had had her corns and calluses attended by a Chinese chiropodist. Shes been lathered and creamed, exfoliated and scrubbed to an inch of her life. This, so you can enjoy chocolate facials and bask in some of the most wonderfully designed spas on earth. title: The Man Who Saved American Catholicism
description: His name is David Spotanski, and in the early 2000s he was the chancellor of the diocese of Belleville, in Illinois, where Wilton Gregory was bishop. Gregory was elected president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops in the autumn of 2001, just as the wave of sex abuse revelations began breaking over the American church. Four months later, Spotanski wrote his bishop a 10-page memo on the abuse crisis, which he read aloud to Gregory in the bishops private study. In part, the memo was a blistering attack on the American hierarchy, from Bostons Bernard Law on down, for their dreadful negligence, cover-ups and excuse-making. In part, it was a blueprint for action: To have any chance of restoring their credibility, Spotanski wrote, the American bishops needed to invite victims from decades past to come forward and act swiftly on their claims, adopt strict nationwide standards for handling new allegations of sex abuse, and then turn over as much responsibility as possible for implementing the rules to an independent board of laypeople (and parents), who could issue annual reports and hold recalcitrant bishops feet to the fire.

Her name, because she was born during a June downpour, is Summer Rayne Oakes. When I first went to a modeling agency, they thought I was a stripper, she says of her two given names, which she prefers to be said in unison. Oakes is just 25, but shes already written a book (Style, Naturally), contributed to an eco-art magazine (Above), served as a correspondent on Discoverys Planet Green channel, and co-founded a business (S4 Style). title: Fairey Mural Gets Thumbs Down From Buildings Department
description: The street artist Shepard Fairey, who is no stranger to legal trouble, has now run afoul of the New York City Department of Buildings. The Department issued a stop-work order and an Environment Control Board violation this weekend to Elizabeth Houston Associates, the owner of a building on Houston Street near the Bowery on which Mr. Fairey recently installed a mural connected with his show at Deitch Projects in Soho. The mural was pasted onto a structure built on top of the original wall, preserving another mural by the Brazilian brothers known as Os Gemeos. According to Ryan Fitzgibbon, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings, the violation was issued for installing the structure and the mural without a permit. She said the Environmental Control Board court would hold a hearing soon on the violation; if it stands, it could carry a penalty of up to $25,000. She added that the Department was also considering issuing a violation for illegal advertising on the grounds that the mural constituted an advertisement for the Deitch Projects show. But Daniel Killinger, a managing director of Goldman Properties, an affiliate of Elizabeth Houston Associates, said that Goldman did not see the mural as an advertisement. We see it as a continuation of the history of the art thats always been on that site, he said, referring to the Os Gemeos mural and a previous mural designed by Keith Haring. The Department of Buildings action was reported by the blog animalnewyork.com.
