title: In Costa Rica, a Home Without Walls
description: PUNTA UVA, Costa Rica  One day in February 2002 Manuel Pinto and his real estate agent were hacking through the jungle here in southeast Costa Rica, near the surf town of Puerto Viejo, looking for a property for sale within the Gandoca-Manzanillo Wildlife refuge.

title: Ex-Lehman Official Denies Secret Barclays Discount
description: Barclays did not receive a secret $5 billion discount on a portfolio of securities when it bought the brokerage operations of Lehman Brothers after the firm collapsed, a former Lehman executive said Tuesday, Bloomberg News reports.

title: BlogTalk: Miranda Rights for Terrorists
description: Just a few hours after Faisal Shahzad, a naturalized American citizen from Pakistan, was arrested this morning in connection with the attempted bombing in Times Square, politicians and bloggers were debating whether investigators were obligated to extend Miranda rights to Mr. Shahzad.

title: One Mans Hard Road, From Existing to Living
description: Wilbert Rideau was in eighth grade when, in the mid-1950s, he committed his first real crime. He robbed a Piggly Wiggly near his home in Lawtell, La. That went pretty well (he took $40, and some costume jewelry to give the girls at his school), so he tried it again. This time he was caught. So begins Mr. Rideaus sprawling and hard-headed new prison memoir, In the Place of Justice.

title: A Renewed Debate Over Suspect Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The arrest of a suspect in the attempted Times Square car bombing revived the volatile political debate over terrorism policy on Tuesday, as President Obamas supporters and critics squared off over how the nation should handle those plotting against it.

title: Latter-Day Stockhausen, Seen in a Different Light
description: Has any major composer disappeared from public view in the United States more completely than Karlheinz Stockhausen did during the last decades of his life? Once a seminal figure in the international avant-garde, Stockhausen all but reduced himself to a historical footnote in the decades before his death in 2007, through his increasingly esoteric output and with an ill-conceived statement ascribing aesthetic value to the 9/11 World Trade Center attack.

title: Agency Told Tylenol Maker of Many Quality Concerns
description: The Johnson & Johnson unit that voluntarily recalled certain lots of childrens liquid Tylenol and Motrin over the weekend had numerous and wide-ranging quality control problems at the plant that made the products, according to a federal inspection report released Tuesday.

title: Consumer Reports Offers Tips for Hotel Deals
description: Haggling for a lower room rate works about 80 percent of the time, and the walk-up rate at a hotels is about $20 less than advance bookings.

title: Palestinians Emotions Run High After a Fire Destroys a Mosque in the West Bank
description: LUBAN AL SHARQIYA, West Bank  A fire swept through a mosque in this Palestinian village early Tuesday, angering Palestinians who said they were certain that extremist Israeli settlers were to blame, although investigators have found no proof. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, echoed those sentiments and warned that the blaze represented a threat to the efforts to revive the peace process.

title: New Death in Moscow Jail Renews Calls for Reform
description: MOSCOW  For months family members, lawyers and doctors of Vera V. Trifonova pleaded with officials to grant her furlough from prison to seek medical help. Suffering from severe diabetes, Ms. Trifonova, a businesswoman in jail awaiting trial on fraud charges, had only one working kidney, and her lungs were filled with so much liquid that there was a danger she could drown in her sleep, her lawyers said.

title: At the Track I Pray
description: I cant pray when I am visiting a church.The problem is that I am a singer and choir director. I find myself analyzing the hymnal while fantasy conducting the choir. I generally end up having a great time but I do not achieve a quiet prayerful solace and comfort that church provides for the masses. But take me to a racetrack and its another story. At Santa Anita, there is a golden sunrise in the early morning when the horses are training on the track. It is quiet and ethereally beautiful as the San Gabriel Mountains provide a glorious backdrop. I climb the stairs and sit by myself. I am quiet and thoughtful. I empty my mind and let the images drift in front of me. Horses and exercise riders, trainers and jockeys, laughter and camaraderie.

title: Trying Out Delivered Diet Meals
description: PAST 50 and pushing 230 pounds, I decided that this spring I would try to get down to a healthier 200.

title: Remembering an Omnipresent Force at a Brooklyn School
description: If there was one person who didnt need to wear a name tag at Edward R. Murrow High School, it was Saul Bruckner, Murrows founding principal, who guided the school in Midwood, Brooklyn, to national prominence over 30 years, from 1974 to 2004.

title: A Chance to Trade Toasts With Champions
description: Though Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion, may face an uphill fight in his bid to be elected president of the World Chess Federation, his campaign is coming together.

title: For Sushi at Home, Skip the Fish
description: YOU can make sushi at home, and easily. Just forget about fish.

title: Majority of Americans Post Risky Information Online, Study Says
description: 6:30 P.M. Updated with response from Facebook.

title: New World Symphony to Open in January
description: The New World Symphony, a Miami Beach-based training orchestra, said on Tuesday that it would celebrate the opening of its new home on Jan. 25. Six days of special programs will include the premiere of a piece composed for the occasion by Thomas Ads and videos by Tal Rosner, a filmmaker, and Casey Reas, a video artist. The building, designed by Frank Gehry, includes a concert hall, practice rooms, an outdoor wall for video projections and a music library.

title: Cameras on Your Back
description: If youre planning a summer vacation and need a new way to (lightly) pack and protect your camera gear, you might consider the new Bumblebee Ultra-Light 222 backpack from Kata. Every aspect of this $275 bag is meticulously engineered for durability, protection and economy of weight.

title: Trailer: 'Metropolis'
description: A trailer for the restoration of Fritz Lang's "Metropolis," now on DVD.

title: Debate Flares on Goldmans Role as Market Maker
description: Goldman Sachs insists that it did nothing wrong and was just acting as a middleman when it sold billions of dollars of securities that are at the center of the Securities and Exchange Commissions fraud case against the firm. But John C. Coffee Jr., a professor of securities law at Columbia University, told a Senate hearing on Tuesday that Goldman was much more than a middleman and that it therefore had a duty to its clients that went beyond just filling orders.

title: Players Is a Haas Family Reunion
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Jay Haas is competing this week in his 29th Players Championship, the arc of his career so majestic he is about to claim a piece of history smaller than the 17th green at TPC Sawgrass.

title: Obama Interviews Judge Wood
description: Another potential Supreme Court nominee  Judge Diane P. Wood of the federal appeals court in Chicago  was interviewed Tuesday at the White House by President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Shiite Alliance in Iraq May Push Allawi Aside
description: BAGHDAD  The electoral coalitions of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and the other major Shiite bloc in Iraq announced a postelection alliance on Tuesday night that cleared the way for a Shiite-dominated government for the next four years.

title: Footage Restored to Fritz Lang's Metropolis
description: For fans and scholars of the silent-film era, the search for a copy of the original version of Fritz Langs Metropolis has become a sort of holy grail. One of the most celebrated movies in cinema history, Metropolis had not been viewed at its full length  roughly two and a half hours  since shortly after its premiere in Berlin in 1927, when it was withdrawn from circulation and about an hour of its footage was amputated and presumed destroyed.

title: Ghent Altarpiece to Undergo Restoration
description: In the nearly six centuries since its completion in 1432, the Ghent Altarpiece, one of the worlds most renowned works of art, has not exactly been a stay-at-home kind of masterpiece. It was taken apart and hidden twice in the 16th century to protect it from iconoclasts and Calvinists. It was hauled to Paris two centuries later as a war trophy. In 1934 thieves stole two of its panels, and during World War II it was seized by the Nazis and kept in a salt mine.

title: Speed Bumps and Potholes on the Road to Recovery
description: I want to go home. Its no fun here. This cri de coeur erupting from an antsy teenager is likely to fall on receptive ears at the Lucille Lortel Theater, where the Beth Henley play Family Week opened on Tuesday night. Lighthearted diversions are definitely not on the menu at the treatment center where this wan, ineffectual comedy-drama is set.

title: Dollar Thrifty Says It Will Consider an Avis Offer
description: 7:30 p.m. | Updated One day after the Avis Budget Group said it was prepared to offer a substantially higher offer for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group than the $1.2 billion proposal it had accepted from Hertz Global Holdings, Dollar Thrifty says its willing to listen.

title: Ethics for Extraterrestrials
description: Remember the episode of The Twilight Zone where the earthlings discover only too late that a book brandished by extraterrestrial visitors, titled To Serve Man, is not, in fact, a philanthropic manifesto  but, sadly, a cookbook?

title: Finalists Named For Turner Prize
description: Susan Philipsz, an artist whose installations explore the relationships between structures and sound, and whose works have used her own recordings of songs by Radiohead, Nirvana and the Velvet Underground, was among the finalists announced on Tuesday for the Turner Prize, the Tate Britain said. Ms. Philipsz was nominated for this prestigious award, presented annually to a British artist under the age of 50, for works presented at the International Festival of Visual Art in Glasgow and in the Mirrors exhibition at the Museo de Arte Contemporanea de Vigo in Spain. The other finalists are the painter Dexter Dalwood, nominated for a solo exhibition at Tate St Ives, and whose works (like The Brighton Bomb, above right) have focused on ominous landscapes and portraits of famous writers; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation After at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films, for a series of exhibitions called A Long Time Between Suns. Finalists will have their works presented at a Tate Britain exhibition that opens on Oct. 4, and a winner, who receives about $38,000, will be announced on Dec. 6.

title: Nashville Sites Are Closed By Flood
description: The flooding in Tennessee has damaged some of Nashvilles most prominent music institutions, including the Grand Ole Opry House, at bottom of photo above, and the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. Tuesdays Grand Ole Opry show was moved to the War Memorial Auditorium, and this weekends shows will be playing at the Ryman Auditorium, former home of the Opry. While we ourselves are shaken by the impact of the flooding of the Opry House and throughout the area, it is important that Nashvilles most treasured tradition continues with this weeks shows, Pete Fisher, vice president of the Grand Ole Opry, said on the organizations Web site, opry.com. Lisaann Dupont, a spokeswoman for the Ryman, said it was not known how long the Opry acts would perform at Ryman. She said that parts of the Hall of Fame had been flooded but none of the memorabilia had been damaged, and that the Nashville Municipal Auditorium had also closed. Many of the citys honky tonks have fared better, said Rebecca Jones, owner of Roberts Western World, one of the smaller clubs along Broadway. Were up and running, Ms. Jones said. The only part of our business affected is that fewer people are coming downtown.

title: Perfection for Dancing
description: Evan Lysaceks tango with his dancing partner, Anna Trebunskaya, earned the first perfect score of the season on Dancing With the Stars, capping a near-perfect Monday night for ABC. An average of 19.3 million viewers tuned in for Dancing, followed by the new comedy Romantically Challenged (10.6 million) and the crime series Castle (10.8 million). Fox placed second for the night with House (9.7 million) and 24 (9.1 million). CBS was third and NBC ranked fourth.

title: Jimmy Fallon to Host Emmy Show
description: The comedian Jimmy Fallon, right, will be the host of the Emmy Awards broadcast this summer, NBC announced Tuesday. It is the first Emmy hosting gig for Mr. Fallon, of NBCs Late Night. John Shaffner, the chairman and chief executive of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, said Mr. Fallon is a bright, insightful and energetic entertainer who made his name performing on live television, and we welcome him to host our annual celebration of great television as the show returns to broadcasting live coast to coast. The prime-time Emmy show will be broadcast live on Aug. 29. The nominations will be announced on July 8.

title: Summerstage Lineup
description: For its 25th season SummerStage is expanding beyond Central Park into parks throughout New York City. In Central Park, where SummerStage began in 1986, the season of free performances opens on June 1 with the New York Pops and Melody Gardot. It continues through September with highlights including the African singer Baaba Maal (June 14), Meshell Ndegeocello with Martha Wash (June 19), McCoy Tyner and others for George Weins CareFusion Jazz Festival (June 23), Gil Scott-Heron (June 27), Jimmy Cliff (July 11), a comedy night with stars from The Daily Show (July 21), the singer St. Vincent (Aug. 1), the British band the XX (Aug. 8), Public Enemy (Aug. 15) and the reunited ska band the Specials (Aug. 22). Benefit concerts, which are not free, include the Flaming Lips on July 26, the Black Keys on July 27 and 28, and one of Pavements four concerts there, on Sept. 21. The City Parks Foundation, which presents SummerStage, has for years also put on a separate series of free summer concerts in parks throughout the city but this year those shows are coming under the SummerStage aegis. They begin on June 1 with Jay Electronica in Red Hook Park in Brooklyn.

title: From a Clan That Lives by Its Own Rules, a Tale Made for the Movies
description: The unruly extended family at the heart of The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia might have been the subject of an earnest, hand-wringing social-problem documentary. Or else an entire season of Cops, since the Whites propensity for violence, drug use and general cussedness makes plenty of work for the authorities in Boone County, W.Va.

title: The Encores! Season
description: Encores!, the annual series at New York City Center that stages revivals of overlooked and underappreciated musicals from bygone eras, has announced the lineup for its 2010-11 season. It will begin with Bells Are Ringing, the musical by Jule Styne, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, which will run from Nov. 18 through 21. Judy Holliday starred in the original 1956 Broadway production, about a phone-answering service employee who gets involved in the lives of her clients. The next production will be Lost in the Stars, the musical version of the Alan Paton novel Cry, the Beloved Country, with music by Kurt Weill and book and lyrics by Maxwell Anderson. It was first presented on Broadway in 1949 and briefly revived in 1972; this version will run at City Center from Feb. 3 to Feb. 6, 2011. Finally, Encores! will present Wheres Charley?, the farcical George Abbott musical adapted from the Brandon Thomas comedy Charleys Aunt, from March 17 to 20, 2011. The original 1948 Broadway production, directed by Mr. Abbott and choreographed by George Balanchine, starred Ray Bolger.

title: At Italys Operas, Fat Ladies Are Quiet
description: No barber schemed in Turin; Butterfly stayed alive in Trieste; and Carmen remained chaste in Bologna.

title: Moonshine Finds New Craftsmen and Enthusiasts
description: IN early April, Kris Comstock, a representative for the Buffalo Trace distillery in Kentucky, conducted a seminar on bourbon at Char No. 4, a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that offers 150 kinds of American whiskey.

title: Treats for Mom to Nibble on Her Day
description: High-heeled pumps or a picture hat for Mother on her day? Perhaps, if you select the stylish edible versions by Christophe Toury, the new pastry chef at Jacques Torres Chocolates, or Sbastien Rouxel, the baker at Bouchon Bakery. The shoe, one of three styles, is all chocolate. The pink bonnet, on a hazelnut cookie, is topped with chocolate hazelnut cake, frosted with dark chocolate and covered with pink fondant. The white bonnet has an almond cookie base, white cake infused with yuzu, strawberry filling and a coating of strawberry butter cream and white fondant. The flowers are not edible.

title: Battle for New York Skies
description: All the major airlines have been looking for ways to regain the upper hand as air travel begins to rebound. And New York City is a major focus of their attention.

title: An Eccentric Life, From Polio to Punk
description: Great musicians have uniquely fascinating lives, but their film biographies are all alike. The latest illustration of this paradox  definitively mocked in Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story a few years back  is Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll, a dutiful and admiring film about Ian Dury, one of the more eccentric stars of British punk rock. The film, directed by Mat Whitecross and written by Paul Viragh, hits the usual narrative marks: childhood trauma, artistic struggle and triumph, family upheaval and substance abuse. Its flashes of style are sometimes lively but more often seem, like the slavish period dcor, to be desperate attempts to overcome the built-in inertia of the genre.

title: US Airways C.E.O.: Were Not the Ugly Girl
description: In his exuberance at sealing a merger with United Airlines on Monday, Continental Airlines chief executive got a little too colorful.

title: The Vanderbilt and Kaz an Nou
description: THE service was slick, the room was handsome and the food reliably good at the Vanderbilt, a well-groomed gastropub that opened last fall in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. But something was missing.

title: In Chicago, the Chef Grant Achatz Is Selling Tickets to His New Restaurant
description: BY this point, nearly everyone agrees that dining out has replaced going to the theater and that chefs are rock stars. So why dont restaurants sell tickets?

title: The Limelight Nightclub Becomes a Marketplace
description: Though its the sweet tooth that will get the most attention at this shiny new marketplace in the once notorious neo-Gothic Limelight, there are savories, too, including Peak Season, a farmers market in what used to be a churchyard, with 8 to 10 stands from nearby growers.

title: Obama Tries to Mend Fences With American Jews
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had lunch on Tuesday with Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate and Holocaust survivor, as part of an effort to mend fences with American Jews upset by the administrations stance against the Israeli governments construction of Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem.

title: For New York, Summer on a Stick
description: Last summer it was artisanal ice cream from carts and trucks. This summer your frozen treats will be on a stick. You cannot do much better than the frozen gelato and sorbetto at Popbar, an Italian import in Greenwich Village. Small batches are made on the premises in more than a dozen flavors, with the suavest of textures. The coffee has the intensity of espresso, and mixed berry suggests mid-July. Embellishments include chocolate dips (below, on strawberry sorbetto). Drizzles and coatings of chopped nuts, coconut or granola are also available, some already applied to the pops, others for custom combinations. Popbar is the American franchise of Stick House, based in Turin.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: At the James Beard Awards, Marea Takes a Top Prize
description: Marea, on Central Park South, was named best new restaurant at the James Beard awards on Monday night. Timothy Hollingsworth, chef de cuisine of the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., won the Rising Star Chef of the Year honor at the James Beard Foundations ceremony at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: The Lion in Greenwich Village Returns as a Tavern
description: Back in the 1960s, the Lion was a popular Greenwich Village hangout where Bette Midler and Barbra Streisand performed. Eventually this town house space, with its soaring ceiling and domed skylight, became Village, a bistro. Now, John DeLucie, on leave from the kitchen at Waverly Inn, is turning it into a tavern and restaurant.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Hail Native Plants

title: Senate President Vows to Block New Jersey Court Nominee
description: The New Jersey Senate will block Gov. Christopher J. Christies appointment of a State Supreme Court justice by refusing to vote on whether to confirm the nominee, the Senate president said Tuesday, escalating a partisan clash between the governor and the Legislature.

title: Commerce and Art Slug It Out
description: Broadway producers banked more than ever this theater season that stars onstage would fill seats, and in many cases were proved right. On Tuesday, though, the 2010 Tony Award nominations drew a sharp distinction between commercial interests and artistic success, with recognition going to several shows with few, if any, stars and small audiences.

title: Art, and the Line to Get in, Take to the Streets
description: Jeffrey Deitch, SoHo gallery owner, gets a splashy send-off.

title: Pam Griers Collection of Lessons Learned
description: Pam Grier, who manages to exude toughness and sensuality in equal measure, has also managed to embody many of the cultural shifts of the last 40 years.

title: Another Opening: Cue the Crowds
description: FREUD said cultural achievement and sensual pleasure pull in opposite directions. He never met Keith McNally, who just introduced the insanely crowded Pulinos Bar & Pizzeria on a formerly moribund corner of the Bowery and East Houston Street.

title: Michigan High School Snags Obama as Speaker
description: WASHINGTON  Proving they have more to boast of than just their alumnus Derek Jeter, the graduating Giants of Kalamazoo Central High School in Michigan have beaten more than 1,000 public high schools in a national contest of academic self-promotion. The prize: President Obama as commencement speaker.

title: McNallyland: A Review of Pulinos Bar & Pizzeria
A Few More Moments, Please
description: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the Moment in Time interactive gallery by the name given in the photographers credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). Youll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasnt posted, we urge you to give this a try.

title: A Muslim Who Just May Be Jewish
description: Sometimes the best way to approach an inflammatory or scary subject  death, for instance, or corporate malfeasance  is through humor. That is what The Infidel, an amusing little film from Britain, does with one of the touchiest subjects of them all, the animosity between Jews and Muslims.

title: A Teenage Canadian Bolshevik
description: The typical American high school comedy is more concerned with sex than with socialism, but leave it to Canada to reverse that balance. In The Trotsky, a study of teenage dementia set in Montreal, a privileged 17-year-old named Leon Bronstein (Jay Baruchel) is convinced hes the reincarnation of Leon Trotsky.

title: Who Benefits When Airlines Merge?
description: United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed Sunday to a $3 billion merger that would create the worlds biggest airline, with 10 major hubs, dominating in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. If the deal wins antitrust approval from the Justice Department, the new company would replace Delta as the largest carrier after it merged with Northwest Airlines in 2008.

title: Malaysian Talent Show Contestants With Problems
description: Even the Disney folks wouldnt pile as much baggage onto a school talent show as the Malaysian director Yasmin Ahmad did in Talentime, her final film before her death last year. The young competitors not only have puppy love and dying relatives to worry about, they also have to be conduits for Ms. Ahmads commentary on the prejudices  religious, racial and otherwise  in her multicultural country.

title: Enron to End Broadway Run on Sunday
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated With the field of Tony Award nominees sown this morning, the first underperforming show of the post-season has been claimed by the Grim Reaper this evening: Enron, the play by Lucy Prebble about the rise and fall of that notorious Texas energy company, will close on Sunday, according to a statement on the shows official Web site. The Broadway production of the play, which opened last week after transferring from Londons West End, collapsed almost as rapidly as its namesake: though its cast included Norbert Leo Butz (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, Speed-the-Plow) and Gregory Itzin (24) as the Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth Lay, as well as Marin Mazzie (Kiss Me, Kate) as a composite Enron employee, it was shut out of most major categories. Stephen Kunken was nominated as a featured actor in a play, but its lack of a nomination for best play likely sealed its fate. Enron could still be the rare play to win the Tony for best original score, another category in which it is also nominated.

title: A Souk for Trust-Fund Hobbits
description: JADE JAGGER might shop here  that is, if she could tear herself away from her whitewashed finca at the north end of Ibiza. So might India Hicks, wafting in from Harbour Island to pad barefoot, as is her habit, across the expanse of rough-hewn herringbone parquet.

title: Traveling an Indian Highway to Adventure
description: The open road. In American fiction and film, it stands for freedom, romance, escape from quotidian woes. In Road, Movie, an occasionally lyrical, occasionally confused indie, the director Dev Benegal translates those themes to modern India. His hero, Vishnu (the excellent Abhay Deol, not afraid to be unlikable), hits the road in a rattling antique of a truck, a Chevy with a traveling cinema (projectors, films) in back. Vishnu, a cool jerk in aviator shades and tight jeans, escapes his family, small city and fate  to sell Atma hair oil for his dad  for a week, driving from Rajasthan to the sea.

title: Chicago Wins Prize as Home of Big Carrier
description: CHICAGO  Mayor Richard M. Daley and other politicians stood with the leaders of United and Continental airlines in downtown Chicago on Tuesday, proudly underscoring plans that the proposed merged airline  to be the largest in the world  will have its headquarters here.

title: Picasso Sells at Auction for $106.5 Million, a Record for a Work of Art
description: 8:27 p.m. | Updated A painting that Picasso created in a single day in March 1932, Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust), sold for $106.5 million, a world record auction price for a work of art, at Christies Tuesday night. The painting, more than 5 feet by 4 feet, shows Picassos mistress Marie-Thrse Walter, both reclining and as a bust. Picassos profile can be discerned in the blue background.

title: If Parliament Hangs, Queen Could Veto Fresh Election
description: She makes no speeches on the hustings; she remains aloof from the political fray. She admits no party affiliation and is not permitted to vote or stand for office. Yet, she addresses Parliament with bejeweled and regular fanfare; for more than half a century, she has held secret conversations with a cavalcade of 11 prime ministers; and, in a peculiarly British way, she could be cast in a central, yet largely powerless, role if Britains elections on Thursday stray into the gray zone known as a hung Parliament.

title: Flyers Carcillo Plans to Get More Physical Against Bruins
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Less than 18 hours after he claimed that Boston Bruins forward Marc Savard bit his finger, Dan Carcillo stood in the Philadelphia Flyers dressing room Tuesday and said he felt fine. He would not make a big deal of the incident.

title: Celtics Expose Cracks in Cavaliers Facade
description: Cavaliers Coach Mike Browns demeanor after two games of the Eastern Conference semifinals reflected two different results, a transformation from relief to regret.

title: E.P.A.s Plan to Regulate Coal Ash Draws Criticism
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued a long-awaited proposal Tuesday to regulate coal ash, the toxic byproduct of burning coal to produce power. But the agency deferred a decision on whether to treat it as hazardous waste, drawing criticism from environmentalists who had hoped for a stronger stance.

title: A Coachs Mistake, a Teaching Moment
description: Education comes in different forms, at all hours.

title: Catholics Criticize Pope on Abuse Scandal, but See Some Hope
description: A majority of Roman Catholics in the United States are critical of the way Pope Benedict XVI and the Vatican have handled the reports of sexual abuse by priests, but have confidence in the Vatican to make changes to prevent abuse in the future, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll released Tuesday.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 28 through May 2 with 1,079 adults throughout the United States.

title: For Homemade Sushi, Its All About the Rice
description: I have not had as much fun doing a story as this one on making sushi at home in a long time. Cooking the rice itself is foolproof; the proportions in my recipe will work for you, and if you taste as youre mixing the rice with sweetened vinegar, you cant go wrong.

title: Del Potro Sidelined by Surgery on Wrist
description: In September, Juan Martn del Potro won the United States Open, pounding his huge, flat forehand as he put a surprising end to Roger Federers five-year winning streak at Flushing Meadows.

title: Who is the Baron?
description: Baron Ambrosia, the star of "Bronx Flavor," on Jamaican-style cow foot and more.

title: Experts, Conflicts and the F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration relies on 49 expert committees to advise it on policy matters and on whether particular drugs or other medical products are safe and effective. The agency has made substantial progress in reducing conflicts of interest among members, and it is now pledging to search far and wide for neutral experts and to make more information public about any waivers it grants.

title: And the Magic Number Is ...
description: Finally, the truth can be told. The United States has officially announced that it has 5,113 nuclear weapons in its arsenal, plus several thousand more waiting to be dismantled. The totals are so close to the unofficial estimates that have been publicly circulating for years, you might wonder what all the excitement is about.

title: News Sessions With Woods Are Tenser
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Pretournament news conferences with Tiger Woods used to be fairly sedate, predictable events. No more. On Tuesday at the Players Championship, the general atmosphere and the questions and answers were in stark contrast to a year ago.

title: Kyrgyzstan Opens an Inquiry Into Fuel Sales to a U.S. Base
description: MOSCOW  Prosecutors in Kyrgyzstan have opened a criminal investigation into whether, for the second time in a decade, a son of a president of this small Central Asian country illegally profited from contracts supplying jet fuel to an American air base.

title: Pelfrey Has M.R.I.; Mets Say All Is Well
description: CINCINNATI  Mike Pelfrey said his shoulder felt fine, and the Mets said Pelfrey was still expected to make his appointed start Friday against the San Francisco Giants at Citi Field. That is good news for the Mets, considering he has been their best starter this season.

title: No Fooling Mother Nature
description: There is only one meaningful response to the horrific oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and that is for America to stop messing around when it comes to designing its energy and environmental future. The only meaningful response to this man-made disaster is a man-made energy bill that would finally put in place an American clean-energy infrastructure that would set our country on a real, long-term path to ending our addiction to oil.

title: An Electrifying Start for the Rockies Jimenez
description: SAN DIEGO  As Colorado Manager Jim Tracy took a seat in the dugout late Monday afternoon to meet with reporters, he unfolded a piece of paper with handwritten notes detailing the latest developments concerning the Rockies long list of injured players, most of whom are pitchers.

title: Giants Zito Living Up to the Expectations of His $126 Million Contract
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Barry Zito said something Tuesday that baseball players are not supposed to say.

title: Lessons From the Lost
description: In Virginia, law enforcement officers are learning how to search for missing persons who may not know they are lost.

title: Rumblings in the New York Skies
description: The combination of United and Continental Airlines would upend the balance of power at New Yorks airports.

title: Why Charter Schools Fail the Test
description: Burkittsville, Md.

title: More With Dementia Wander From Home
description: ASHBURN, Va.  For generations, the prototypical search-and-rescue case in America was Timmy in the well, with Lassie barking insistently to summon help. Lost children and adolescents  from the woods to the mall  generally outnumbered all others.

title: Liberal Democrat Relishes Central Role in Race
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Chris Garlick arrived a skeptic, but departed a convert.

For only thus can the load of prejudice by which this subject is overwhelmed be removed.

title: Sampler: District Attorney in Hot Seat; Tonga Room in Preservation Fight

Ms. Harris fired back that Mr. Adachis comments were irresponsible. The district attorneys office failed to research and disclose the criminal and misconduct histories ofabout 80 police officers who testified in trials, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. By law, the officers histories should have been revealed to defense lawyers, who could have used the information to challenge their credibility as witnesses in court. Ms. Harris called Mr. Adachis assertion that hundreds of convictions could be in jeopardy wild speculation and playing politics with public safety. Meanwhile, the SF Weekly reports that Ms. Harris now has the lowest felony trial conviction rate of any big-city district attorney in the state. She is the front-runner to become the Democratic Party nominee in the race for California attorney general.[The San Francisco Chronicle, SF Weekly]

title: The Moral Life of Babies
description: Not long ago, a team of researchers watched a 1-year-old boy take justice into his own hands. The boy had just seen a puppet show in which one puppet played with a ball while interacting with two other puppets. The center puppet would slide the ball to the puppet on the right, who would pass it back. And the center puppet would slide the ball to the puppet on the left . . . who would run away with it. Then the two puppets on the ends were brought down from the stage and set before the toddler. Each was placed next to a pile of treats. At this point, the toddler was asked to take a treat away from one puppet. Like most children in this situation, the boy took it from the pile of the naughty one. But this punishment wasnt enough  he then leaned over and smacked the puppet in the head.

title: Going to the Mountain
description: We finally left Tana on May 2, fully loaded with all our equipment and supplies.The packing is always high stress, as the omission of a single item can have terrible consequences in the field, when resupply is not an option. For example, no formalin or alcohol (perhaps due to a leaking bottle top), or no spare flashlight bulbs, can bring research to a complete stop. I had hoped we could have departed the previous afternoon, but my driver, Nicholas, was nervous about nighttime attacks on vehicles between Tana and Antsohihy, so we left at first light.

What great timing, too, I thought, as American sportswear is having a moment right now in fashion  especially in the European collections. title: How Serious Is Raynauds Phenomenon?
description: Millions of people, more women than men, suffer from a feeling of extreme coldness in the fingers and toes, a problem called Raynauds phenomenon. For some, the discomfort extends into the summer months, and even holding a cold drink or being in an air conditioned room can be unbearable. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School responds to readers concerned about whether they have Raynauds, how serious it might be and what can be done to ease the discomfort. For more information, see Dr. Wigleys earlier responses in Ask the Expert: Raynauds Phenomenon and The Times Health Guide: Raynauds Phenomenon.

title: An Unusual Gift for Bloomberg
description: At its spring gala on Tuesday night, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts paid tribute to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with an unusual gift. The center will move its Calder sculpture, Le Guichet (The Box Office), to any place in New York City the mayor chooses for a period of 90 days. In his remarks, Mr. Bloomberg said his deputy mayor Patricia E. Harris would find a good place for it. Ms. Harris said on Wednesday a site had yet to be determined. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, sits on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It was presented to Lincoln Center in 1965. The philanthropist David M. Rubenstein, a Lincoln Center trustee, was honored at the gala.

title: The Best Money Sites on the Web
description: The annual Webby Awards were announced on Tuesday and there were two categories that caught our eye here at Bucks, Banking/Bill Paying and Financial Services.For the second year in a row, Mint won for Best Financial Services Web site, and for the third year in a row it won the Peoples Voice award. Mint, a personal finance Web site, beat CBS Moneywatch, which features video interviews with Jill Schlesinger; MicroPlace, a microfinance Web site; StockMapper, a site that specializes in stock heat maps; and wikinvest, an investment research portal.In the Banking/Bill Paying category, a money management site, moneyStrands, took the Webby, knocking last years winner Xero out of the category. The London-based online lender Wonga won the Peoples Voice Award, which also went to Xero last year. The nominees in the category included The Morris Code, an interactive personal finance Web site sponsored by Bank of America and geared toward college students; Billeo, a bill paying site; and BillShrink.com, a Web site that scours the Internet for better deals on things like credit cards and cellphone plans.One additional note was in the Education category which nominated the Your Life, Your Money project. The project was produced by WNET-TV and Working Dog Productions and ran on the Public Broadcasting Service Web site.

description: Bob Woodward, the prominent investigative reporter, will have a new book on the Obama presidency in September, just two months before the midterm elections. The book will be released by Simon & Schuster, Mr. Woodwards longtime publisher. Tracey Guest, a spokesperson for the publisher, said she had no other information about the content, and that it did not yet have a title. Mr. Woodward, whose reporting with Carl Bernstein on Watergate for The Washington Post first brought him prominence, is one of the few writers in recent years whose political books have consistently altered the talking points in Washington. The storyline in his four books about President George W. Bushs administration changed dramatically, as the first one, Bush at War, described Mr. Bush as a strong leader and the third, State of Denial, described the administrations troubles in handling the war in Iraq, a story continued in The War Within, the final Bush installment.

title: Smartphones to Travel With
description: Here are three smart handsets that make good traveling companions:

title: Where Kosher Beckons the Cool Crowd
description: Imagine kashrut  Jewish dietary law  as a kid in an elementary school. It would probably take on the role of hall monitor, enforcing restrictive rules that may or may not be important to the authorities: Sayonara, shrimp! Ciao, cheeseburgers! And for the love of G-d, stay away from pork!

title: Has Apple Lost Its Cool?
description: On Tuesday I talked with John Berman, an ABC News correspondent, about Apples current image in the media, and with its fans and customers.

title: Extra Innings and the Road Prove to Be Unfriendly Territory for the Mets
description: CINCINNATI  Extra-inning games have been treacherous for the Mets this season. The only one they won lasted 20 innings and left them exhausted. On Wednesday, they made it to the bottom of the 10th when Orlando Cabrera hit a solo shot off Pedro Feliciano to give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-4 victory and a second game-winning home run in extra innings in this three-game series.

title: Would You Like Accessories With That iPad?
description: When Apple began selling the first iPods, millions of people were delighted with its ease of use. Youd pay for the songs you downloaded from iTunes and what else would you need?

title: Look What I Bought (or Got Free)
description: MELISSA ROSE PONCE DE LEON, a 19-year-old bartender from the Bronx, had just gone shopping. When she got home she sat in her tiny peach-colored room, leaned into her Web cam and held up her swag: a few MAC lipsticks, a glittery black V-neck top, a snake bracelet and a new pair of Ugg boots.

title: Another Auction, Another Trophy
description: Whatever the state of the global economy, theres always a ton of discretionary cash floating around looking for someplace to land. Tuesday night at Christies a chunk of it  $106.5 million to be exact  landed on a Picasso painting called Nude, Green Leaves and Bust, setting a record for art sold at auction.

title: Suspect Was Tracked Through Phone Numbers
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators discovered the name of the suspect in the failed Times Square bombing because of a telephone number he provided when he returned to the United States from Pakistan in February, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

title: Submit Your Photos of Election Day in the U.K.
description: The Lede will be live-blogging the vote count in the United Kingdom on Thursday and we would like to hear from readers who will be taking part in the election. Please send us your thoughts or, better yet, submit a photograph documenting your experience of the day, by e-mailing it to pix@nyt.com.

title: Another Victory, and Another Injury
description: Aside from the struggles of Javier Vazquez, little has troubled the Yankees starting pitchers this season.

title: Providing Loans Based on Cash Flow, Not Credit Score
description: With the recession having left many banks reluctant to lend, small businesses have struggled to find other sources of credit. One intriguing alternative is On Deck Capital, which promises to revolutionize lending to small businesses.

title: Pictures of the Day: Athens and Elsewhere
description: Aris Messinis of Agence France-Presse, whose photograph from Athens begins Wednesdays report, has been published frequently in Pictures of the Day recently.

title: Is This the Way to Get Credit to Small Businesses?
description: In a small-business conversation weve just published, Mitch Jacobs, founder and chief executive of On Deck Capital, talks about what he hopes will be a revolutionary new approach to getting credit to small businesses. Among those who believe in the approach are James D. Robinson III, former chairman and chief executive of American Express, and Alan Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, both of whom serve on On Decks board.

title: The Way We Were
description: Mike Konczal has an interesting post on how Wall Street and the role of the SEC were perceived in the late 1970s: back then, the securities abuses of the pre-New-Deal era were viewed as archaic evils, no longer part of the modern world thanks to effective regulation. Today, of course, regulation has been degraded, and the abuses are back in earnest.

title: Answers About Etiquette in New York
description: Following is the first set of responses from Lyudmila Bloch, an international etiquette expert, protocol consultant and author of The Golden Rules of Etiquette at the Plaza.

title: G.M. Recruits Marketing Executive From Nissan
description: After only a couple of months with Nissan North America, the marketing executive Joel Ewanick is headed for Detroit to help with the rebuilding of General Motors brands. Mr. Ewanick has been named vice president for United States marketing, effective May 24, and will report directly to G.M. North Americas president, Mark Reuss.

title: Some Are Partying Like Its 2006
description: The year was 2006. That summer, Fidel Castro relinquished his control (temporarily) over Cuba. The Da Vinci Code was captivating audiences around the globe. And Kevin Richardson broke a million hearts by leaving the Backstreet Boys.

title: Borats Designer Redresses Art
description: Its fitting that Jason Alpers first art show opened just blocks from the Dolce & Gabbana boutique on West Hollywoods Robertson Boulevard. As the costume designer for the movie Bruno, (as well the Sacha Baron Cohen characters, Ali G and Borat), the London-based Alper has put the comedian in all sorts of outrageous get-ups including a velcro suit for the Milan runway as well as accessorizing a National Guard uniform with a D & G belt, claiming the look on its own is just too matchy-matchy.

title: House Republicans Criticize Response to Oil Spill
description: House Republicans pointedly questioned the speed of the Obama administrations response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the day after British Petroleum executives said the ruptured well could spew sweet crude into the surrounding water 10 times faster than initially estimated.

title: At Hotels, Making Wi-Fi as Standard as a Bed
description: FOR Yael Smadja and business travelers like her, a Wi-Fi connection in a hotel is nonnegotiable.

title: Senate Voting on Regulation Amendments
description: The Senate has finally started voting on amendments to the financial regulatory legislation.

title: U.C. Berkeley Drops Charges Against Some Students
description: After months of pursuing charges against students involved in the large-scale campus demonstrations last fall, the University of California, Berkeley has dropped charges against dozens of them. At the same time, it is undertaking an extensive review of its procedure for investigating and charging students.

title: Pastor Involved in Job Scheme Is Back in New York
description: The Rev. Isidro Bolaos, a Brooklyn pastor who persuaded hundreds of people to hand over copies of their personal records through false offers of employment at an apparently nonexistent social service agency, has returned to New York, according to three men who say they confronted him this week.

title: Shrimpers, Not Oil? A Dead Turtle Inquiry
description: About 35 endangered sea turtles have washed up dead on beaches along the Gulf of Mexico since Sunday, sowing fears that they were done in by the growing oil spill.

title: Newsweek: Between The Week, Slate, and The Economist, Not Much Room for a Storied Brand
description: What do the Brits know that we dont about publishing weeklies in America? The Week and The Economist, both owned by British publishing companies, continue to grow even as it was announced today that Newsweek is up for sale with very meager prospects.

title: Greek End Game
description: Many commentators now believe that Greece will end up restructuring its debt  a euphemism for partial repudiation. I agree. But the reasoning seems to stop there, which is wrong. In effect, the consensus that Greece will end up defaulting is probably too optimistic. Im growing increasingly convinced that Greece will end up leaving the euro, too.

title: Nascar Rolls Out a Museum
description: How do you take a car race and make it interesting as a museum? Let the people drive.

title: Shortcuts Define Self-Service Travel
description: TRAVELERS have accepted a trade-off in the do-it-yourself era: embracing the self-service technologies that airlines, hotels and car rental companies have developed in exchange for lower prices.

title: Back on the Road, but on a Shoestring
description: BUSINESS travel has often been depicted with a dash of style and adventure. Think of Eva Marie Saint in North by Northwest, the various James Bond movies, or George Clooney in Up in the Air.

title: Need a Little Nap in the Terminal? Get a Room!
description: NEVER have so many travelers needed a collective nap as they did in April when the ill winds blew across Europe from a spewing Icelandic volcano.

title: Downward-Facing Dogs Life
description: WHEN the world of the business traveler turns upside down  whether because of a missed connecting flight, lost luggage or an uncooperative volcano  Steve Boerema knows just what to do.

title: Apps That Remove Bumps in the Road
description: THE smartphone can be a nearly perfect travel companion, a chum that is helpful, entertaining and knowledgeable, does not complain and, incidentally, fits in your pocket.

title: Packing Tips From Travel Pros
description: From the archives: Heres one of our favorite stories with helpful tips for Smarter Living.

title: Air Security Gets Faster, but at Price of Privacy
description: WASHINGTON

title: For Some Plying the Road, Two Wheels Are Plenty
description: PICTURE a Hollywood agent powering to a power lunch. Entourage has done it for us: an expensive convertible, an iPhone and dialogue devoted equally to schmoozing and screaming.

title: Beaming Into the Big Meeting
description: FALLOUT from a recession and ash from a volcano drove more companies than ever to try videoconferencing. Once the skies clear on both fronts, will it be time to plan more business trips or will virtual meetings continue to get the job done?

title: Food to Grab and Go, With Flair
description: WITH a Javits Center trade show scheduled to take up the majority of his day last month, Allen Marko, director of technical and plant operations for Obagi Medical Products, had no time to stop for a bite.

title: A Swiss Secret, Tucked Away in the Alps
description: IMAGINE a mountain landscape speckled with rustic villages whose residents speak an ancient, isolated language. Centuries-old stone dwellings with mysterious renderings of wild men and mountain goats are etched into white facades. Panoramic views are so clear and stunning you have to rub your eyes to make sure youre not in a Hollywood epic.

title: Help in Shaving Minutes Off Your Underground Commute
description: A question for New Yorkers: How much would you pay for another 10 minutes with your family after work?

title: Update on an Addicted Child
description: Last June, I ran a guest post from Janice Lynn Schuster, about her daughters drug addiction and her own despair at not being able to help. After following Katie Granjus vigil by her son, who was critically injured after an overdose and a drug-related assault, it seemed a good time to check in with Schuster for a look at life farther down the recovery road.

title: The Echoes of an Execution Reverberate Loud and Clear
description: In a small Southern town during the Jim Crow era, a black man is accused of raping a white woman. During his stormy trial there are threats of lynching, as well as intimations that the white woman had been the sexual aggressor.

title: New Woe for Goldman as Blankfein Defends Firm
description: Another day, another bit of bad news for Goldman Sachs  even as Lloyd C. Blankfein, its chief executive, tried to shore up the firms reputation.

title: My Mannequin, Myself: What Talking Heads Say
description: IN 1936, a glamour girl named Cynthia became a minor toast of the town. She went around with a guy named Lester, who took her to all the showoff places  the opera, El Morocco  and the next year she made the cover of Life. Cynthia would get fan mail, but if anyone ever got a reply, it was guaranteed to come from Lester.

title: Rahm Emanuel Is Losing a Key Aide
description: Despite his reputation for hard-charging and profanity-spiced intensity, Rahm Emanuel has long kept a circle of loyal aides, both as a congressman and now as White House chief of staff. But he is about to lose the adviser who has been closest to him: Sarah Feinberg is leaving to join Bloomberg L.P. as a communications strategist.

title: CUNY Imposes Cutoff for Freshmen Applications
description: Faced with record enrollments, the City University of New York has decided to place prospective freshmen whose applications arrive after Friday on a waiting list. It is the first time in memory that CUNY will impose an across-the-board cutoff for applications to its 11 senior colleges and six community colleges.

title: Financial Tuneup: Spend Your Gift Cards
description: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, weve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

title: Bangs Like Justins (but Dont Say So)
description: WHEN a boy of a certain age asks Cozy Friedman, the owner of Cozys Cuts for Kids in Manhattan, for a haircut with long, side-combed bangs, she is careful not to ask, like Justin Biebers?

title: Bears Ex-Bosses Shocked by Firms Collapse
description: The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big to manage and that they were shocked when it suddenly collapsed in March 2008.

title: Works Made on the Wings of Inspiration
description: Deadlines, poverty and ambition have long been motivating factors for composers, as for many artists. But according to the program book for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, the featured works were not driven by prosaic concerns but composed on wings of pure inspiration.

title: Trying to Keep Up as the World Turns
description: It seemed that all but one in Tuesday nights audience at the Baryshnikov Arts Center greeted Gaff Aff, the American debut of the Swiss duo Zimmermann & de Perrot, with rapt attention and ardent applause. I was, alas, the exception.

title: Haim Saban Goes Into Brand Management
description: The media investor Haim Saban is moving into brand management and licensing. The Saban Capital Group will plow $500 million into Saban Brands, a new company dedicated to acquiring entertainment and consumer brands and exploiting them through retail, television and film channels.

title: Flying Low, but Staying on Folks Radar
description: Josh Ritter has a way with metaphor. Its one of the literary touches in his music that have established him among the cream of the young singer-songwriter crop, and it is all over his albums: romantic diplomacy in a missile silo; Columbuss doomed fourth ship; a mummy whose curse is the realization that love is mortal.

title: F.C.C. Push to Regulate Broadband Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will try to regulate broadband Internet service despite a recent court ruling that the commission had limited powers to do so.

title: Russo & Steele Sues Tent Company
description: Classic cars werent the only things damaged when storms blew down the tents at the Russo& Steele auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., in January. The president of Russo& Steele, Drew Alcazar, said his company sustained serious damage  financially and to its image  and has filed a lawsuit against the tent provider, Tri-Rentals, in an effort to recoup at least the financial portion of those losses.

title: Bon Apptit! Yelp Goes to France.
description: Expect to see more reviews of baguettes with brie and Bordeaux wine bars on Yelp. The site for local business ratings and reviews has opened in France at Yelp.fr.

title: Shopping With Anna Sui
description: The fashion designer, who has put butterflies on her clothing, jewelry and cosmetics packaging, shopped for furnishings with a butterfly motif.

title: A Drive for All Seasons
description: For computer users, Seagate has taken the concept of mix and match to a higher level.

title: Who Was the High-Rolling Picasso Buyer?
description: Its hard to ignore the $106.5 million price tag attached to the Picasso piece whose sale on Tuesday is the biggest-ever price tag for a work of art sold at auction.

title: A Spirited Mood Conveyed by Both Soloist and Ensemble
description: The path to success as a classical musician is often narrow, with intense study from early childhood through conservatory training. Ryu Goto, a 21-year-old Japanese-American violinist and the younger brother of the violinist Midori, is taking a broader approach, balancing a busy performing career with full-time undergraduate studies at Harvard, where he is a physics major.

title: Heres the Dash... Hold On, Whats a Dash?
description: As the barrage of advertising should make quite clear, the new Sony Dash is here.

title: Honoring a Mentor, Muse and Colleague All in One
description: The four composers who started Red Light New Music in 2005 intended the organization, with its resident ensemble, to be an outlet for works of their own and of like-minded colleagues. But its concert on Tuesday evening at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space was a 60th birthday tribute to Nils Vigeland. All four Red Light founders were composition students of Mr. Vigeland, who supported their endeavor from the start and has composed several works for it.

title: Two Days, Two Field-Running Fans, No Trend Yet
description: Despite consecutive incidents at Philadelphias Citizen Bank Park involving fans who ran onto the playing field during Phillies games, Major League Baseball is not yet reconsidering game security.

title: Notebook: Yankees Ready to Take to the Rails
description: The Yankees are off Thursday before opening a three-game series in Boston on Friday night. They will travel Thursday by railroad  in a private three-car train  from New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Greek Protests Claim First Fatalities
description: Three people were reported to have died inside a bank building set ablaze by protesters during demonstrations against tough new austerity measures in Greece.

title: How to Move Your Own Documents to Kindle
2 Votes Break Logjam on Financial Overhaul Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill that both Democrats and Republicans claimed would end the prospect of taxpayer-financed bailouts for companies deemed too big to fail.

title: Balmy Microsoft Commercial
description: Video | From a PC World collection of funny old tech ads and promos:

title: Song Visions, Large Scale and Small
description: Since founding the New York Festival of Song in 1988 the pianists Steven Blier and Michael Barrett have mostly avoided presenting complete song cycles. They prefer to mix and match diverse selections in imaginatively themed programs.

title: Eco Labels and Dietary Advice
description: THIS has been the spring for looking back on American fashion, from the American Beauty show at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology that closed last month to the American Woman and American High Style companion exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Brooklyn Museum. Amid this jingoist spirit, it would be easy to overlook a tiny show that opened Wednesday at Scandinavia House in Midtown to cheer the fashions of Sweden.

title: 2 Votes Break Logjam on Financial Overhaul Bill
description: The Senate on Wednesday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill that both Democrats and Republicans claimed would end the prospect of taxpayer-financed bailouts for companies deemed too big to fail.

title: Hopscotching the World in Headlines
description: On an epochal day in 2007 the newspaper staff in The Imperfectionists must deal with a huge story. Thankfully, Tom Rachman writes, most of the editorial staffers are occupied piecing together copy on a shooting at Virginia Tech when the other story, the really big one, breaks.

title: A Pitch-Perfect Trip From Folk Days to 9/11
description: Her silver-blonde hair cascading around a face whose wide blue eyes inspired Crosby, Stills and Nashs famous Suite: Judy Blue Eyes, Judy Collins cut a resplendent figure on Tuesday evening at the Caf Carlyle, where she began her fourth season. Ms. Collins turned 71 on Saturday, but you would never know it from the unalloyed purity of her soprano. Her slightly unworldly voice is still an instrument that evokes angelic visions in an imaginary cathedral or a shaft of moonlight settling on a lake whose waters are barely quivering.

title: Captured Leader Offers Insight Into the Taliban
description: WASHINGTON  Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, the most senior Afghan Taliban leader in custody in Pakistan, is providing important information to American officials on the inner workings of the Taliban, pivotal insights as the United States looks ahead to negotiations to end the war in Afghanistan, according to senior American intelligence and military officials.

title: France Wont Extradite Iranian Sought by U.S.
description: PARIS  A French court on Wednesday refused an American request to extradite an Iranian businessman accused of violating an American embargo on exports to Iran. He had raised American suspicions by buying equipment for a front company in Malaysia that was then shipped secretly to Iranian military firms involved in Irans nuclear program.

title: New Assistant Takes Over as Hofstra Basketball Coach
description: A tumultuous off-season for college basketball in the New York metropolitan area has yielded its share of bizarre coaches stories, from the implosion of Fred Hill at Rutgers to the arrest of Hofstras newly hired Tim Welsh to the rebirth of Steve Lavin at St. Johns.

title: The Detective Who Spotted the Crucial Number
description: Detective John Wright was at home on Saturday night, rebuilding a bathroom, when the call came in: A smoke-filled vehicle in Times Square needed to be identified.

title: New Orleans Asks U.S. to Help Police Department
description: NEW ORLEANS  Citing the need for transformational change, the citys new mayor, Mitch Landrieu, announced on Wednesday that he was inviting the Justice Department to help restructure the troubled New Orleans Police Department.

title: Suspects Gun Proved Easy to Obtain
description: The mammoth clock-to-wire-to-gasoline-to-propane car bomb that the authorities said Faisal Shahzad hoped would claim many lives in Times Square has been analyzed, diagrammed, prodded and examined. But not long before his arrest, Mr. Shahzad was also equipped with a less-eccentric  and yet more dependably lethal  weapon. And he owned it legally.

title: Challenges Abound in 2-Week Tribute
description: The pianist Chick Corea, who always seems up for a challenge, is taking on another one. Its not some region of music thats new to him, or some techniquey Everest. Its not even especially Bill Evans, although his music lies at the center of the jazz tradition over the last half-century and is the pretext for Mr. Coreas current gig. The challenge is the drummer Paul Motian.

title: On the Inside
description: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute ball, borrowed finery and a dinner no one has any intention of eating are the norm.

title: War Zone Traumas Restaged at Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO  During her yearlong tour of duty in Iraq Maj. Elizabeth A. Condon saw all manner of horror and heartbreak, from dead bodies in the street and memorials for fallen friends to little babies with holes in their backs.

title: War Stories, Restaged
description: Jennifer Karadys photographs of veterans, on view in San Francisco, put a surreal twist on their war memories.

title: Conjuring a Conjurer of Movement and Light
description: Alwin Nikolais was the magician of dance, the forerunner of now wildly popular companies like Pilobolus and Momix and a pioneer in multimedia effects. From the 1950s to the 1990s his work was celebrated both in the United States and internationally (he was particularly popular in France), and his company continued to perform for several years after his death, in 1993.

title: Heart Surgery for Former Iowa Governor
description: Former Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, who is among the Republicans across the country who are running again for their old offices this year, underwent heart surgery today. He is challenging Gov. Chet Culver, a Democrat, in one of the races that Republicans are among the most enthusiastic about.

title: What Britain Should Hope For
description: On the eve of the British election, David Frum offers the case for optimism about David Cameron:

title: Callup for Young Red Bulls Player
description: Juan Agudelo is going to Europe.  No, not jumping ship from the Red Bulls to a new club, but as part of the United States under-20 national team.

title: Idol Croons the Blues
description: Foxs American Idol slid further in the ratings on Tuesday as the top 5 contestants performed ballads by Frank Sinatra. Idol drew 17.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, down considerably from the nearly 30 million viewers who tuned in to the season premiere in January, but enough for Fox to finish No. 1 for the night. But Idol hit its lowest rating among 18-to-49-year-old viewers, the most-valued group by many advertisers (and most networks), since its first summer season on the air. CBS placed second for the night over all, with NCIS (14.8 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (14.2 million) and The Good Wife (12.9 million). ABC finished third, and NBC was fourth.

title: Kilborn Is Returning
description: Craig Kilborn, the original host of The Daily Show and then a late-night host for CBS on its 12:35 a.m. Late Late Show, is about to return to television in a show for 20th Television, the syndication arm of Foxs television stations. The show in development would not be a late-night show, according to executives who are aware of the proposed deal. But a memo sent by the shows producer, seeking staff members, described it as a combination of a talk show and a nonpolitical Daily Show. The new show is likely to get a trial run on Fox stations this summer. It could be a daytime entry, along the lines of syndicated entertainment shows like the one hosted by Ellen DeGeneres.

title: Flooding Damages Home of Nashville Symphony
description: Floodwaters in Nashville seriously damaged one of the citys newest cultural gems, the Schermerhorn Symphony Center, above, home of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra. Disaster was averted when water that had filled the basement reached within a cellos thickness  roughly five inches  of the concert hall after the Cumberland River crested, Alan D. Valentine, the symphonys president and chief executive, said on Wednesday. The flooding caused the loss of two Steinway grand pianos, valued at more than $100,000 each. It also engulfed the console and blower room for the halls $2.5 million organ. The pipes  the costliest part of the organ  are in the hall and so were spared. In addition, concrete flooring in a storage area for the halls removable seats buckled and will have to be replaced. It was like a river was running through our basement, Mr. Valentine said. He said other sites will be found for the seasons remaining few concerts and for the summer series. Mr. Valentine said he hoped the hall, which opened in 2006, would be restored in time for next season.

title: Lost Finale Grows by 30 Minutes
description: ABCs send-off for Lost is starting to seem as long as a flight on Oceanic Airlines, not that its fans will mind. The network is extending the finale by half an hour, giving the producers two and a half hours in all, and delaying local newscasts that night, May 23. A total of seven and a half hours of Lost is planned that weekend, according to ABCs schedule. First the network will rerun the two-hour pilot on May 22, at 8 p.m. Then on May 23, Lost takes over the schedule, starting with a two-hour look back at 7 p.m. The finale starts at 9. Then at 12:05 a.m., Jimmy Kimmel will host a special episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live titled Aloha to Lost, featuring alternative endings to the show and appearances by the producers.

title: Young Rapper On Top
description: Justin Bieber is not the only young protg of a big Atlanta star to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart lately. B.o.B., a smooth-voiced 21-year-old under the wing of the rapper T. I., reached the top spot this week with his debut album, B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic), which sold 84,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (B.o.B., whose real name is Bobby Ray Simmons, has had help from more than just T. I. to make his pop crossover: the album also features Eminem, Rivers Cuomo of Weezer and Hayley Williams of Paramore.) The pop-country group Lady Antebellum held at No. 2 with 76,000 sales of Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), and Bullet for My Valentine  opened at No. 3 with its new album, Fever (Jive), which sold 71,000. Mr. Biebers My World 2.0 (Interscope) dropped one spot to No. 4, with 69,000, while Raymond vs. Raymond (Jive) by Mr. Biebers Atlanta mentor, Usher, fell one to No. 6, with 48,000. AC/DCs Iron Man 2 (Columbia), a collection of old hits released in conjunction with the new film, was No. 5, with 52,000.

title: A Gift For Bloomberg
description: At its spring gala on Tuesday evening, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts paid tribute to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with an unusual gift. The center will move its Calder sculpture, Le Guichet (The Box Office), right, for 90 days to any place in New York City the mayor chooses. In his remarks Mr. Bloomberg said that his first deputy mayor, Patricia E. Harris, would find a good place for it. Ms. Harris said on Wednesday that a site had yet to be determined. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, sits on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It was presented to Lincoln Center in 1965.

title: Honors and the End for Temperamentals
description: Despite winning a Lucille Lortel Award  for Michael Urie as outstanding lead actor  The Temperamentals, a play about five closeted gay men who built a pre-Stonewall gay rights group, will close on May 30 after three months of performances, its producers said on Wednesday. This Off Broadway production, written by Jon Marans and directed by Jonathan Silverstein, was one of about 10 major plays and musicals featuring gay characters and gay love stories that opened in New York this season. Unlike most of the other shows, The Temperamentals had only gay characters  all closeted at first  and threaded a love story between its leading men with a deep examination of the social, political and professional consequences of being gay in the 1950s. The Drama Desk Awards organization will present the five-man cast with an outstanding ensemble performance award this month.

title: Yankees-Mariners to Be in 3-D
description: The Yankees will be the stars of the latest sports test of 3-D production when the YES Network collaborates with DirecTV to produce two Yankees-Mariners games from Seattle in July using the burgeoning technology.

title: Inside, Vertical Gardens
description: A look inside homes with walls on which plants grow.

title: New York Military Academy
description: Photographs from one of the last military academies, which is suspending operations at the end of the school year.

title: Rules, Revolving Doors and the Oil Industry
description: A BP executive told members of Congress on Tuesday that the ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico could potentially spill as much as 60,000 barrels a day, more than 10 times the current estimate. With the spill growing worse by the day, questions about the adequacy and effectiveness of offshore drilling regulations have become more urgent.

title: An Idiosyncratic Apartment in the Village
description: Kenny White, a musician, lives under the eaves, in a small, top-floor space strewn with instruments.

title: Furniture and Lighting at Donzella 20th Century Gallery
description: For more than 20 years, Roberto Giulio Rida has been known as the go-to dealer in Milan for 20th-century Italian decorative arts.

title: Butterfly-Patterned Furnishings
description: WHEN butterflies began appearing on home furnishings recently, the fashion designer Anna Sui wasnt surprised.

title: Kenny Scharfs Chair at Auction. Those Lips and Eyes!
description: THE artist Kenny Scharfs contribution to Unframed, the art auction held in Manhattan last week by ACRIA, the AIDS Community Research Initiative of America, was a duck-yellow B&B Italia chair he had ornamented with red lips and big blue cartoon eyes. The guest we thought would have the greatest affinity for it was a tall woman in a black tutu, whose lean upper body and long white-stockinged legs gave her a birdlike air.

title: Intrieurs Furniture Moves to East Side
description: After 14 years downtown, Intrieurs, the TriBeCa furniture store, has moved to a new showroom on the East Side. I was nervous about it, said Francine Gardner, the owner. But in this space, people seem to be looking at the furniture in a different way. The 2,800-square-foot showroom, which is open to the public, is spread over two stories, with an additional 1,000 square feet of outdoor space  an ideal place for showing furniture and accessories for both indoors and out.

title: Auction Set at Kluge Estate in Virginia

title: The Arc Table Designed by Foster & Partners

The tabletop (available in four sizes) is made of glass with a low iron content, so it appears completely clear (rather than slightly greenish, like most glass tabletops); an etched edge makes it look as if its floating. The base, which comes in white, mid-gray and dark gray, is made of Ductal, a material known for its exceptional tensile strength and its amenability to molding. We wanted the tables base to mimic the natural flow of lines created by tensile structures, said John Small, who led the design team. Wed been looking at Ductal for a while, and finally found the perfect application for it. The table sells for $4,940 to $5,415 at the Molteni & C Dada Unifor flagship store, 60 Greene Street (Spring Street); information: (212) 673-7106 or molteni.it.

Tracey Guest, a spokeswoman for the publisher, said she had no information about the contents, and that the book did not yet have a title. Mr. Woodward, above, whose reporting with Carl Bernstein on Watergate first brought him prominence, is one of the few writers in recent years whose political books have consistently altered the talking points in Washington. title: Russian Warship Rushes to Aid Hijacked Tanker
description: A Russian warship was steaming toward an oil tanker that was hijacked at dawn with 23 Russian crew members aboard as it was heading east into the Indian Ocean from Sudan, the European anti-piracy naval force said Wednesday. The tanker had been on its way to China with a cargo of crude oil worth an estimated $52 million. Its seizure seemed a setback for the European force, which has recently been claiming successes for a new strategy of intercepting pirate vessels far out at sea before they attack shipping lines. Reuters quoted a pirate identified only as Abdi as warning against any rescue attempt as the tanker sailed toward the Somali coast, saying it would endanger the crew.

title: China: Government Considers New Rule for Online ID
description: China is exploring a system that would authenticate the identity of anyone who posts a message on an Internet bulletin board, expanding a policy that, since September, has required people to use their real names when posting comments. The current real-name policy can easily be subverted. The state-run Xinhua news agency, which reported the development on Wednesday, quoted the minister of the State Council Information Office, Wang Chen, as saying that the government was also considering real-name registration for cellphone users and a new law governing Internet security. Mr. Wang said new restrictions were needed to curb the online spread of harmful information and infiltration of the Internet by hostile overseas forces. Critics say the increasing crackdown on use of the Internet is a crucial element of the governments effort to silence domestic political dissent.

title: China: Aid Program Focuses on Xinjiang Region
description: The Chinese government plans to direct about $1.47 billion in aid from various provinces to the vast, restive region of Xinjiang in an effort to promote what it terms stability there, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official newspaper. In recent months, Chinese leaders have stressed the need to quickly develop the economies of Xinjiang and Tibet, huge areas of western China where ethnic minority groups have rebelled against Chinese rule. Last July, at least 197 people were killed and 1,700 injured in ethnic rioting in Xinjiang. Under the aid program, relatively wealthy provinces or cities in other parts of China would send money to designated counterparts in Xinjiang. The report said 82 cities or towns in Xinjiang would benefit. The government has been running a similar program in the region for 13 years, but is greatly expanding it now, the report said.

title: At Virginia, a Vigil and the First Attempts at Healing
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  On a night that was supposed to be a quiet one, with final exams just a day away, more than 1,500 students at the University of Virginia put down their books Wednesday and paid tribute to a fellow student killed this week.

title: Germany: Arms Dealer Convicted of Tax Evasion
description: A German court on Wednesday convicted the arms dealer and lobbyist at the center of a political fund-raising scandal that severely damaged the legacy of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The court, in Augsburg, sentenced Karlheinz Schreiber, 76, to eight years in prison for dodging $9.5 million in tax payments. Mr. Schreibers arms deals generated cash that went to Mr. Kohls Christian Democrats. Mr. Schreiber fought extradition from Canada, his adopted homeland, to Germany for 10 years, before he was sent back to Germany last summer.
