title: Now Showing | Roy McMakin
description: The exhibition Roy McMakin: When is a chair not a chair? opened on Tuesday at Cristina Grajales Inc. in SoHo, to coincide with the publication of a monograph with the same title published by Skira Rizzoli. McMakin, an artist and designer whose work has been featured in T and The New York Times Magazine, is known for his embrace of ambiguity and subversive humor in the design of seemingly mundane objects: A chest of drawers, for instance, that has no drawers; a teapot with the vestiges of a broken handle; a headboard that takes a pretty 1940s-inspired design and deconstructs it. While McMakin designs perfectly functional interior and furniture, he does it with an artists eye, eschewing conventional ideas of perfection or comfort. The exhibition runs until July 2.

title: Thats a Bingo: Quentin Tarantino to Head Venice Film Festival Jury
description: The Venice Film Festival runs this year Sept. 1-11, though its organizers might consider adding at least a few hours to that schedule: on Thursday they announced that Quentin Tarantino, the expansive and prolifically talkative filmmaker, would serve as chairman of the festivals jury, which gives out the Golden Lion award and other prizes, Reuters reported. In an announcement on the festivals Web site the organizers wrote that they had chosen Mr. Tarantino, whose films include Pulp Fiction and Inglourious Basterds, because he has become a studied and imitated point of reference, and he is perhaps the only American auteur to be adored worldwide like a rock star. The announcement also praised Mr. Tarantino for rediscovering overlooked actors in impressive roles, and for his own work as an atypical character actor in films like Takashi Miikes Sukiyaki Western Django (a 2008 Venice festival entry in which he played a mysterious gunfighter named Ringo). Not least of all, the festival organizers also noted Mr. Tarantino is a great admirer and connoisseur of Italian genre cinema.

title: Splendid Ruins: Hotels Built on History

The circa-1640 villa, once owned by J. Paul Getty, is now a 19-room inn furnished with Gettys antique furniture and tapestries. With the open windows bringing in cooling breezes, little could be heard but the sound of the wind and waves. Yet the hotel also gave us an additional, unexpected gift: a fascinating glimpse into daily life as it was lived 2,000 years ago.

title: Now Showing | Swid/Kaufman
description: In their own ways, Nan Swid and Donald Kaufman have always been enablers. A founder of the design company Swid Powell, Swid worked with an A-list of artists and architects like Frank Gehry, Richard Meier and Ettore Sottsass to produce all manner of tabletop objects. The company archives  from a coffee maker to candlesticks  now reside at the Yale University Museum of Art. Kaufman  who with his wife and business partner, Taffy Dahl, founded Donald Kaufman Color in the 70s  has long been the go-to guy for architects and decorators looking for that elusive shade of not-quite-gray-not-quite-white or flaming red. Take a tour of Philip Johnsons Glass House or grab a drink at the Julian Schnabel-designed Gramercy Park Hotel and you get the picture. But for four days this week, instead of making other people look good, Swid and Kaufman will bask in the spotlight as artists in their own right, when they show their personal work at Gallery 9E in Chelsea. Unsurprisingly, Kaufman  whose work has been in museums like the Whitney and the Hirshhorn, but who hasnt had an exhibition in over 30 years  is a painter. His series of gouaches on paper, he says, are inspired by architectural color samples. And true to form, Swid is more object-oriented, layering pieces of old books, cellophane, legal files and other found materials into three-dimensional reliefs.

title: Country Stars Take Stock After Nashville Flood

Ben Jumper, the owner of a storage plant called Soundcheck Nashville, where Mr. Paisley and other musicians kept their gear, said he expected his losses from the flood would amount to tens of millions of dollars. A publicist for Kenny Chesney told The A.P. that the musicians home would probably be condemned after water rose above its first floor.

title: Alva Smith Vanderbilt Belmont as Impulse Buyer

Although her feminist streak led her to battle for womens suffrage, she forced her daughter Consuelo into a stiflingly conventional marriage to a philandering English duke who needed Vanderbilt money. Mrs. Belmont, who lived in New York, Long Island, northern France and Newport, R.I., also collected antiques on impulse. At her Versailles-inspired Newport home, called Marble House (it contains 500,000 cubic feet of marble), she filled an 1890s Gothic reception room with pinnacled oak paneling, medieval stained glass, statues of saints, rock crystal watches and Roman cameos made of amethyst and carnelian.

title: Obsessions | The Beauty-From-Within Market

We take pills to sharpen our memory, to forget the awful things that have happened to us, to revitalize our libidos and to fall into a stuporous, amnesiac, refrigerator-clearing sleep.

title: Home-Sweet-Home Obsessed
description: Given my previous line of work, I thought I had seen it all: the deranged longing, the addled judgment, the willful denial, the glazed eyes, the hyperventilating, the quickened pulse, the night sweats, the insomnia  all the depredations of a love affair gone wrong. Anyone over the age of 30 who lived, worked or breathed in any proximity to the real estate market in the last decade will immediately recognize the signs of house lust. But I spent years as the editor of House & Garden, and I dont think I ever encountered a case like Meghan Daums. Cue up Nina Simone. Daums got it bad, and that aint good  for her. Readers of Life Would Be Perfect if I Lived in That House, though, are in for a memoir that adroitly manages to be funny, charming and shocking in its brutal frankness about an obsession that threatens to upend sanity and bank accounts. Luckily, as was not the case for so many caught in the national grip of cheap mortgages, Daums is the story of a love too big to fail.

title: Ballet Theater To Honor Alicia Alonso at 90
description: After Alicia Alonso, left, joined American Ballet Theater in 1941 her performances were described as breathtaking and eminently dainty and gracious. Now the woman synonymous with Cuban dance is returning to the company and the Metropolitan Opera House. Shell be there June 3 to celebrate her 90th birthday at an event that will include a film retrospective of her career and a special performance of Don Quixote, the Ballet Theaters artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, announced. The event is part of a celebration of another milestone: the companys 70th anniversary. Ms. Alonso, who became known for her interpretation of Giselle, also starred in original productions of George Balanchines Theme and Variations (1947), Antony Tudors Undertow (1945) and Agnes de Milles Fall River Legend (1948). In 1948 Ms. Alonso founded the Alicia Alonso Ballet Company, which became the government-supported National Ballet of Cuba in 1959. She went on to form the Cuban National Ballet School in 1960.

description: The Williamstown Theater Festival has announced the appointment of a new artistic director: Jenny Gersten, left, a widely admired producer in New York at the Public Theater who worked as associate producer at Williamstown from 1996 to 2004. Ms. Gersten, 41, will succeed Nicholas Martin, who is leaving this summer after his third season at Williamstown, one of the nations premiere summertime theater presenters. Ms. Gersten will depart as the associate producer of the Public Theater, the acclaimed nonprofit company in New York founded by Joseph Papp. At the Public, she has most recently produced The Book of Grace by Suzan-Lori Parks, The Brother/Sister Plays by Tarell Alvin McCraney, The Idiot Savant by Richard Foreman and Shakespeares Twelfth Night, which Daniel Sullivan directed last summer for the Public at Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Before joining the Public, Ms. Gersten was artistic director of the theater company Naked Angels.

title: Artifacts | Wade Guytons Monument to Epson
description: In the 1960s, Andy Warhol made paintings as if on a printing machine, forcing colored inks through a silkscreen with a squeegee. Paintings are too hard, he said. Machines have less problems. Id like to be a machine. Wade Guyton feels the same. Working in the digital age, he uses a more hands-off technique involving inkjet printers and flatbed scanners.

title: Perkins Out of Weeds
description: Even as the story lines on the Showtime comedy Weeds became increasingly byzantine and the series drifted away from its original premise about a suburban widow (Mary-Louise Parker) who sells pot to support her family, Elizabeth Perkins, left, was a welcome presence on the show. As Celia Hodes, the neighbor and frenemy of Ms. Parkers character, Ms. Perkins brought a ray of unmitigated malice to a merely cynical show, whether she was doing time in prison, using her cosmetics sales group as a front for a drug ring or getting kidnapped and taken to Mexico (and driving her kidnappers crazy in the process). But no more: Ms. Perkins, who was nominated for three Emmy Awards in her five seasons on Weeds, is leaving the series, The Hollywood Reporter said. She will instead take a role in a hybrid live-action and animated film called I Hop, directed by Tim Hill (Alvin and the Chipmunks), in which she will play the mother of a young man (James Marsden) who is forced to take care of the son of the Easter bunny (whose voice will be provided by Russell Brand). The Hollywood Reporter said Ms. Perkins was also developing a comedy series for herself.

title: Idol Sags Again
description: It wasnt just Aaron Kelly, the 17-year-old American Idol contestant who was cut from the show on Wednesday, who had a bad night: despite a live performance from Lady Gaga, among other bells and whistles, Idol drew its lowest-rated Wednesday night audience since 2002, with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. That was still more than enough to make the show and Fox No. 1 for the evening. CBS finished as runner-up for the night, garnering its best ratings with the procedurals Criminal Minds (12.2 million) and CSI: NY (10.2 million). NBC edged past ABC for third place, though its troubled hospital drama, Mercy (four million), hit a ratings low. ABC ranked fourth.

title: Millions for WNET From the Tisches
description: WNET.orgs new studios at Lincoln Center will be named after James S. Tisch and his wife, Merryl H. Tisch, in honor of a $15 million gift, the largest from individuals in WNETs nearly 50-year history. Im a great believer in public television and its mission and its importance, Mr. Tisch, the chief executive of Loews Corporation and chairman of WNET.org, said in a telephone interview. Its an island of sanity among a thousand channels, and it isnt free, and it needs support. Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET, said the donation would go toward the new studios and programming, including a half-hour program called Metrofocus, which is in development. Its a transformational gift, Mr. Shapiro said. This allows us to get to the next step, to develop new programming, to innovate new ways to produce. In a modern television age, thats what you have to do to survive.

title: Proposal to Audit Fed Is Modified
description: Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, has agreed to modify a proposal that would require public audits of the Federal Reserve in a potential compromise that would force a single audit of the central banks handling of the 2008 economic crisis.

title: Gen Art Folds, Victim of Recession
description: After 16 years of presenting film, art, fashion, music and parties, Gen Art, a showcase devoted to young talent and young audiences with branches in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, has folded, a victim of the financial downturn. After struggling for the past 18 months since the economic crisis, Gen Art has finally succumbed to the recession, its founders, the brothers Ian and Stefan Gerard, wrote in a letter sent out late Wednesday and posted on the Gen Art Web site, genart.org. We have now halted all operations, have let go all of our amazing staff, and shuttered the business, they wrote, adding that they hoped Gen Art in some small way was as close to your heart  as it was ours. With 80 percent of its revenue coming from corporate sponsorship, Gen Art was hit hard by the recession, Ian Gerard said in an interview on Thursday. After the fall of 2008 we were losing money hand over fist, he said. A $350,000 sponsorship deal with a major financial institution fell through at the last minute, in late March, and new investors could not be found quickly enough. We had cash flow for about four weeks, and four weeks was just not enough for us to bridge that gap with the debt that we were already carrying, Mr. Gerard said.

title: Theater Listings: May 7  13
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Country Stars Are Reeling After Nashville Flooding
description: As the water recedes and Nashville recovers from devastating flooding, many of the citys best-known musicians are assessing the damage to their properties and making plans to help Nashville get back on its feet. Brad Paisley, right, told The Associated Press that much of the staging and props for his coming concerts  called the H2O tour  were under water from the flood and that most of his guitars, amps and equipment had been destroyed. Ben Jumper, the owner of a storage business called Soundcheck Nashville where Mr. Paisley and other musicians kept their gear, said he expected his losses would amount to tens of millions of dollars. A publicist for Kenny Chesney told The A.P. that Mr. Chesneys home would probably be condemned, as water had risen above the first floor.

title: Here a Moo, There a Moo, but Old MacDonalds Its Not
description: The first thing you hear in Milk, Emily DeVotis offbeat, flawed new play, is the mooing of cows. A strangely comforting sound, it represents the domesticated life of the Massachusetts dairy farm where the drama is set. But this is no peaceable kingdom: bankruptcy threatens the farms existence, and something wild lurks just beyond the fence.

title: Digg Plans 10 Percent Layoff
description: In an e-mail message sent to employees on Thursday, the chief executive of Digg, the user-driven social news Web site, announced that the company planned to cut its staff by 10 percent.

title: A Country Star Rakes Through Bluegrass
description: It aint easy standing onstage with your heroes, the country star Dierks Bentley said at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Still, he hadnt dressed up for the occasion. His hair was maybe a bit more matted than usual, his 5 oclock shadow a bit more honest. His black T-shirt had seen crisper days.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: THE PREMIERE OF GOODNIGHT MOON,' WITH THE RUNAWAY BUNNY'

title: Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill: An Interactive Look at What Happened
description: Maps, video, audio, graphics and photos guide you through the fallout from an oil rig explosion in 2010.

title: A Ferry Ride Away From Seattle
description: THE Washington State ferry drones toward Bainbridge Island, whose evergreen-laden hills rise up from a rocky shoreline. Dozens of boats and clusters of houses come into view, evidence of the commuters, weekenders and retirees who have chosen Bainbridge Island to escape the buzz of Seattle, about 35 minutes away. This island city, about 5 miles wide and 10 miles long, has a push-pull relationship to decades of growth. In 1991 a growth plan was adopted, and one effect was to increase real estate values by limiting inventory.

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: From todays Therell-Always-Be-an-England file (subdivision: Wherever Theres a Cottage Small Beside a Field of Grain), comes Ben Stansalls photograph of a polling station in Cornwall. The tranquillity of this particular scene belied the fever of the close election campaign in Britain.

title: House G.O.P. Aid for More Candidates
description: A day after learning he was now running for an open seat, Sean Duffy received a promotion within a program offering support to Republican House candidates.

title: Rockefeller Center, 11:28 A.M.
description: The newly restored mural in the lobby of 30 Rockefeller Center American Progress, painted in 1933 by the Spanish artist Jose Maria Sert, was unveiled Thursday. The mural, 16 by 41 feet, was restored to the artists original vision through a detailed, slow process of chipping off a yellowish coating applied in the 1970s.

Movie and Film Series Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Boom Time for Boomer Models
description: JULIETTE BRANKER, 53, works two jobs.

title: Potential Court Pick Faced Dilemma at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  For nearly a quarter-century, Harvard Law School refused to help the nations military recruit its students, because the armed services discriminated against openly gay soldiers. But in 2002, the school relented to pressure from the Bush administration and agreed to allow recruiters on campus.

title: United Tastes: An Asian Take on Crayfish
description: Georgias Crawfish Shack Seafood and Southern Seafood serve heaping bowls of shellfish that are a little bit Louisiana, a little bit Vietnam.

title: Meeting Ernie Harwell, Drawing Inspiration
description: I have a somewhat different memory of Ernie Harwell, the affable and classy Detroit Tigers broadcaster who died Tuesday. I think of him as a newspaperman.

title: Pastor Returns Documents to Job Seekers
description: The Brooklyn pastor who promised hundreds of people social service jobs after falsely claiming he had millions in financing has begun to return applications and other documents.

title: A Gay Adoption Becomes a Musical
description: WHEN the musical librettist Michael Zam first read The Kid, a 1999 memoir about a gay couple adopting a baby, he was certain that he wanted to turn it into a musical. He loved the acerbic tone of the books author, the syndicated sex columnist Dan Savage, and the frank portrayal of a gay mans dream for a family. But rather than plunge into adaptation, Mr. Zam made it a long-term project, because he felt it would take time  years, it turned out  to wrest a successful show out of this particular book.

title: Crisis Economics
description: For the past half century, academic economists, Wall Street traders, and everyone in between have been led astray by fairy tales about the wonders of unregulated markets and the limitless benefits of financial innovation. The crisis dealt a body blow to that belief system, but nothing has replaced it.

title: Bruno Avoids Jail, for Now
description: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, the former Republican Senate majority leader who reigned for more than a decade as one of the most powerful politicians in New York State, was sentenced to two years on Thursday for concealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments he received from a businessman who sought help from the Legislature.

title: 36 Hours in Houston
description: A SNARL of superhighways and skyscrapers, Houston is easily dismissed as a corporate campus  home to Fortune 500 giants like Halliburton and Waste Management and a company formerly known as Enron (currently known as Enron Creditors Recovery Corporation). And the view from an airplane isnt exactly inviting: a flat and featureless plain of generic towers sprawling into the horizon. But in recent years, this Texas megalopolis has been inching back to its urban core. Cool art galleries have sprung up in once blighted neighborhoods. Midcentury modern buildings have been saved and restored. And former factories have been turned into buzzing restaurants and bars. Yes, oil money still reigns supreme, but it now competes with culture.

title: Everybody Loves the Weird Kid
description: BURBANK, Calif.

title: From a Prophet, a Call for Reform
description: He was known as Dr. Doom  a perennial pessimist in the often sunny world that is the dismal science of economics. And in 2008 his predictions of disaster  delivered two years earlier  came stunningly, frighteningly true, as the entire global financial system teetered on the brink of the abyss. Cassandra had belatedly become a much-celebrated prophet.

title: Surveillance Footage of Faisal Shahzad
description: Surveillance footage from the Phantom Fireworks Showroom in Matamoras, Penn. shows Faisal Shahzad making purchases on March 8, 2010.

title: Travelogues to the Nine Circles and Back
description: THERE is nothing quite as hypnotic as a travel show that suggests its better to stay home.

title: Fireworks Shop Releases Video of Bombing Suspect
description: Its not exactly riveting cinema, but it might be a help to investigators.

title: Google Maps Is Fine for Finding Subways
description: Thursdays Phone Smart column, on  apps for New York City commuters, alludes to the dearth of subway-related apps for Android phones.

title: A Comeback, of Sorts, for Leona Helmsley
description: Yes, they know that people called her the queen of mean. Yes, they know that people remember how she bragged that only the little people pay taxes.

title: A Google Tool to Translate a French Menu
description: Watch any science fiction television show, including Star Trek and Doctor Who, and you will likely hear about a little gadget called a Universal Translator. This fictitious device could instantly translate two languages from anywhere in the galaxy.

title: Obsessively Seeking Original Occupant
description: THIRTY-ODD years ago, when I was a young architectural historian moving into the Cornwall, at Broadway and 90th Street, I began wondering who had first slept in my apartment. Four years later, I had emptied my bag of tricks in researching the building.

title: Babies and Beyond
description: Thomas Balms, the director of "Babies," discusses each of his subjects from the film.

title: Foreclosure End Game
description: When a resident wont leave a foreclosed house, a real estate agent comes knocking to persuade them to leave. Its the next-to-last resort, before the sheriff.

title: As Homeowners Dreams Die, Hes the Undertaker
description: LAKE VILLA, Ill.  If you see Joseph Laubinger on your doorstep, start packing. His courtly presence means you have exhausted all excuses, arguments and options for keeping your house.

title: Invasion of the Superweeds
description: American farmers broad use of the weedkiller glyphosphate  particularly Roundup, which was originally made by Monsanto  has led to the rapid growth in recent years of herbicide-resistant weeds. To fight them, farmers are being forced to spray fields with more toxic herbicides, pull weeds by hand and return to more labor-intensive methods like regular plowing.

title: Record Crowd Expected for U.S.-Germany Game
description: A record crowd for a hockey game was expected for Fridays game between Germany and the United States, the opener of the 2010 International Ice Hockey Federation World Championship tournament.

title: Awwwwww, Ewwww, Whos a Good Baby?
description: The French globe-trotting documentarian Thomas Balms has taken up a delicate and treacherous assignment in his new film. Fanning out around the world  to the plains of Mongolia, the dusty grasslands of Namibia, the high rises of Tokyo and the streets of San Francisco  Mr. Balms and his crew set out, about three years ago, to probe a network of mysterious creatures who speak a common idiom barely comprehensible to the rest of us. The films subjects are hard to understand and nearly impossible to resist. They project weakness and innocence, yet they also possess almost terrifying powers. And they are just so gosh-darn cute!

title: M.L.S. Expands to Montreal
description: 10:38 a.m. | Updated

title: 2010 Mitsubishi Outlander
description: The GT further sharpens the Outlanders handling by adding an active front differential to the all-wheel-drive system.

title: Galleries Being Galleries, but More So
description: There are several ways to unpack the first New York Gallery Week, which will take place across the city in 50 art galleries, 5 alternative spaces and a park (the High Line) from Friday to Monday. Most obviously, this four-day week  with its coordinated solo exhibitions, special events and extended gallery hours  is a promotional ploy. But its also an impressive number of galleries doing what they usually do, only more intensely and overtly, in a legitimate effort to take back the spotlight too often hogged by art fairs and auctions. And its a somewhat off-putting assertion of hipness and exclusivity, what with only 50 of the citys several hundred galleries invited to participate.

title: Fashion Moments
description: New exhibits at two museums look at more than a century of evolving American fashion.

title: The Art of Style, and the Style of Art
description: Real women dont wear couture. Lacking the budgets or the bodies for it, they just watch. At best, they dress for short-term success, not posterity. That is, they dont buy or commission lavish and costly garments from reigning design geniuses that they plan to wear a few times during the evening hours, fastidiously maintain and finally bequeath to a museum.

title: Seeking Answers After Wall St.s Wild Bungee Jump
description: So what in the world happened to the stock market?

title: Dimanche and Other Stories
description: Dimanche [ Sunday ]

title: The Life of Irne Nmirovsky
description: Chapter 1: The Most Beautiful Country in the World (19031911)

title: Claude Monet: Late Work
description: Images from a new exhibit at Gagosian Gallery.

title: The Garden That Grew Into a Muse
description: The Gagosian Museum of Fine Art in Chelsea? Not yet, but Gagosian Gallery has definitely shaped itself into a periodic and ambitious kunsthalle over the past few years. In 2009 it gave us an invaluable retrospective of the proto-conceptualist Piero Manzoni and a survey of career-end Picassos. Now, moving closer to old master turf, it delivers Claude Monet: Late Work, a gorgeous where on earth did this come from? show of 27 Giverny paintings dating from 1904 to 1922.

title: The Nmirovsky Paradox
description: In the spring of 1942, the Russian-born novelist Irne Nmirovsky, then living in France, began to suspect that her recent conversion to Roman Catholicism was unlikely to exempt her from Hitlers plans for the Jews. Already considering her works-in-progress posthumous, she jotted this entry in her notebook: Try to do as many discussions and things as possible . . . that may interest people in 52 or 2052.

title: The Eye in a Hurricane of Corruption
description: Jack Abramoff could sweet-talk a dog off a meat truck.

title: Katarina Auster and Wilson Jaramillo
description: IT takes a lot to impress New Yorkers. The hallmark attention-grabbers that might turn heads in other places  crazy hair, loud music, body art  are seen as expected.

title: A Country Comedy a Russian Could Love
description: The setting is an estate in the Russian countryside in the 19th century. The dramatis personae include landed aristocrats, their bourgeois neighbors, peasants and servants. The story concerns the fate of a plot of land and the dissatisfactions of love.

title: Teaching Financial Literacy at a Student-Run Bank
description: The citys schools may be increasingly cash-starved, but at one high school in Harlem, the money is flowing in: Capital One Bank and the Abyssinian Development Corporation have opened a student-run bank inside it.

title: Calif. Attorney General Sues 2 Calpers Ex-Employees
description: Californias attorney general, Jerry Brown, on Thursday charged two former officials of Calpers with fraud, alleging a system of kickbacks in exchange for outside firms winning a piece of the giant pension funds investment portfolio, The Associated Press reported.

title: Down on the Commune, Where the Kids Run Wild
description: The wretched children born and raised on a rural hippie commune who flail through Adam Shermans new film, Happiness Runs, may not be as depraved as the members of the Manson family. But these teenagers, who were home-schooled in a climate drenched in sex and drugs, are a creepy lot. While the 40- and 50-something parents are fornicating and practicing new-age rituals, their aimless offspring spend their days drinking, smoking and dealing pot, ingesting any pharmaceutical they can get their hands on and having sex.

title: In a Melancholy Los Angeles, La Ronde of Motherhood
description: The bond between mother and child may be primal, but it is far from simple. That is both the premise and the conclusion of Mother and Child, Rodrigo Garcias dense and thoughtful  if also uneven  drama of maternal anguish and filial longing.

title: In Washington, a Renewed Taste for Auto Safety
description: In the new world of auto regulation, cars could be required to have black boxes to record crash data and be able to stop even with the engine at full power. Automakers could be ordered to recall defective vehicles immediately and pay safety fees to cover the costs of federal oversight.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Hail Writers and the Word, Just Not With One Another
description: JERUSALEM  There are moments in this splintered and hardhearted city when skeptics become believers. Thursday night  the ancient walls lighted up, the air filled with honeysuckle and jasmine  felt like such a moment. Distinguished foreign authors and talented local musicians threw themselves into a celebration of literature, music and international fellowship.

title: Tigers Fans Bid Farewell to a Beloved Broadcaster
description: DETROIT  His voice was a unifying factor that often helped tie a fractured city together.

title: Plagued by Midlife Malaise
description: As you watch Multiple Sarcasms, a reasonably intelligent, decently acted examination of a New York architects midlife crisis, starring Timothy Hutton, the question that arises is why? Why devote a single moment of your time to listening to his character, Gabriel Richmond, bellyache ad nauseam about having everything and still being miserable?

title: Latino Groups Urge Boycott of Arizona Over New Law
description: Several large Latino and civil rights organizations on Thursday announced a business boycott of Arizona, saying that a tough anti-illegal immigration law there would lead to racial profiling and wrongful arrests.

title: British Readers Document Election Day
description: Readers submitted their photographs and thoughts from around Britain.

title: Two Paths From Al Qaeda in the Post-9/11 World
description: What she meant to do, Laura Poitras has said, was to make a movie about the homecoming of a Guantnamo Bay prisoner. That was before she met Nasser al-Bahri, known by his nom de jihad, Abu Jandal.

title: Head of Atomic Agency Asserts Right to Scrutinize Iran
description: The new chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency on Thursday rejected Irans claim that international inspectors have no right to ask questions about research Tehran has conducted into missile technology and warheads.

title: The Scramble to Cover the Bouncing Dow
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: In China, Strong Debut for Supplier of Heparin
description: HONG KONG  As stock market stories go, the listing of Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical in China came with a few special ingredients: two low-key founders who have been turned into multibillionaires overnight; a stake held by Goldman Sachs; and pigs intestines.

title: Geriatric Delinquents, Rampaging Through Suburbia
description: In 1999 Harmony Korine began a video project called Fight Harm, in which he encouraged random people to beat him up. Because of his success (otherwise known as injuries), that project was abandoned, but it continues in spirit with Trash Humpers, a film that cries out for its maker to be bloodied, perhaps unfairly, by critics and audiences alike.

title: Keeping Score: Earning Their Money, One Win at a Time
description: There are few baseball players who inspire a love-hate relationship among their teams fans more than the Mets Carlos Beltran and the Red Sox J. D. Drew. Both are seen as fragile and nonchalant. Both have been All-Stars and garnered votes for the Most Valuable Player award.

title: Son of Babylon Opens in Baghdad
description: Iraqis attended the premiere of an Iraqi-made film starring Iraqi actors at the historic Semiramis Cinema.

title: In a Baghdad Cinema, Celebrating a Return of Iraqi Culture
description: BAGHDAD  The carpet was red, but too frayed for the tape around its edges to matter much. A letter of the marquee was lost to the years, a little like the street of shuttered shops, crumbling curbs and relentlessly gray barricades around it.

title: Market Drop Fueled by a Crisis, Anxiety and an Error
description: Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic.

title: With Fighting Spirit, New Coach Takes Over at Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Watching Robert Morris battle heavily favored Villanova in the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament in March, Tim Pernetti, the Rutgers athletic director, was intrigued by what he saw from the Colonials coach, Mike Rice.

title: Surprising Guests in a Russian Parade: American Troops
description: MOSCOW  There is a lot about Red Square these days that would make Khrushchev squirm. Three-hundred-dollar Italian negligees pool in the windows of the State Department Store, that showcase of proletarian output; a 20-foot Mercedes-Benz symbol glints on the skyline across the Moscow River.

title: Marking Off the Course to the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  Even before he went to work for President Obama, Bob Bauer was plotting strategy for the next Supreme Court confirmation.

title: Channel Crossing of the Urgent Kind
description: Philippe Liorets compelling, finely balanced immigration drama, Welcome, is set mostly in Calais, the port in northern France that is the closest French city to Britain. Here, where on a clear day the cliffs of Dover are visible like a glimpse of the promised land, is where Bilal (Firat Ayverdi), a 17-year-old Kurd, lands on a chilly, bleak February afternoon in 2008.

title: Palin Backs Fiorina in California
description: Sarah Palin, the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, is making her presence felt in Californias Senate race by backing Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard.

title: Whose Originalism?
description: Used as an epithet, activist judge is almost always applied to a judge who has just issued a decision that the speaker doesnt like. Conservatives affix the label to the Supreme Court of the 1960s and 1970s, as well as to anything they object to about the current court. The ink on Justice John Paul Stevenss letter of resignation last month was barely dry before conservative political candidates and bloggers lined up to bid good riddance to the liberal activist now leaving the court.

title: The Last Days of the Dragon Lady
description: FIFTY years ago today, the Soviet Union announced that it had shot down an American U-2 spy plane and that its pilot, Francis Gary Powers, was alive.

title: Red China, Green China
description: WITH the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf, talk has once again turned to clean energy. What few people appreciate is that the demand for everything from solar panels to energy-efficient light bulbs is already booming. Worldwide, $162 billion was spent in new clean-tech investments in 2009 alone.

title: Marriage Law Is Challenged as Equaling Discrimination
description: BOSTON  Nancy Gill has worked for the Postal Service for almost 23 years. But because she is married to a woman, she cannot provide the same health benefits to her spouse that her co-workers at the post office can provide for their families.

title: A Money Too Far
description: So, is Greece the next Lehman? No. It isnt either big enough or interconnected enough to cause global financial markets to freeze up the way they did in 2008. Whatever caused that brief 1,000-point swoon in the Dow, it wasnt justified by actual events in Europe.

title: Pain Gone, Walton Talks With Zeal Once Again
description: There was never any doubting Bill Waltons passions, not while the ball was bouncing, the cameras were rolling and the microphone was on. Words and opinions flowed freely, to a boisterous rhythm that was instantly identifiable.

title: As Agents Staked Out, Suspect Fled to Airport
description: The federal agent searching the streets of Bridgeport, Conn., at last laid eyes on Faisal Shahzad sometime Monday afternoon. The agent called for help, and soon there was a mix of federal agents and local police officers arrayed on the blocks around Mr. Shahzads apartment at 202 Sheridan Street, according to a federal official briefed on the events.

title: Genzyme Moves to Fend Off Proxy Challenge From Icahn
description: The Genzyme Corporation, facing a proxy challenge from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, said it would buy back $2 billion in stock and sell or spin off three units that were not part of its main business in rare-disease drugs.

title: Too Much Information?
description: I get asked from time to time about how the game has changed since I played it. For me, it feels like yesterday that I was part of the inaugural season at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, and this has lulled me into believing that change, if any, would be subtle. But that is far from the truth. For one thing, something as glaringly new as instant replay for home runs cannot be ignored.

title: Leading With Two Minds
description: They say that intellectual history travels slowly, and by hearse. The old generation has to die off before a new set of convictions can rise and replace entrenched ways of thinking. People also say that a large organization is like an aircraft carrier. You can move the rudder, but it still takes a long time to turn it around.

title: What?
description: Somewhere I read about a game in which youre supposed to do the maximum damage to a famous piece of literature with the minimum typo. The winner was

title: The Road Ahead Is Uncertain and Likely Difficult
description: LONDON  The Liberal Democrats hoped it would happen. The Conservatives warned that it could lead to disaster. And the Labour Party could potentially use it to cling to power for a little while longer.

title: As Spill Looms, City Plays the Waiting Game Again
description: NEW ORLEANS  Unsure what to do as oil continued to creep toward the Louisiana coast, the percussionist Shannon Powell left his shotgun house in the Trem section this week and lighted five candles at St. Louis Cathedral on Jackson Square. He said prayers for New Orleans, then played his usual nighttime jazz gig at Preservation Hall in the French Quarter.

title: Craft Work
description: In your latest book, Martha Stewarts Encyclopedia of Sewing and Fabric Crafts, theres a section that instructs the reader on how to turn her husbands old shirts into decorative pillows. Do you think that is a good use of a womans time in the 21st century?  At Martha Stewart Living we are all about creativity. We are about recycling the vintage past, and an old shirt doesnt have to end up in the rag bin. It really can make a beautiful pillow

title: French Spy Spoof Set in Swinging 67 Rio
description: Good James Bond spoofs, from Maxwell Smart to Derek Flint to Austin Powers, have always involved suffering copious indignities in the cause of sophomoric humor. Hubert Bonisseur de la Bath, the French spy code-named OSS 117, presents a Gallic variation on this formula: he can be arrogant, stupid, cowardly, sexist, xenophobic and anti-Semitic in search of laughs, as long as his hair and his accent stay shellacked in place.

title: Market Drop Fueled by a Crisis, a Glitch and Anxiety
description: Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic.

title: Risky Loans in Foreign Currencies Persist in Eastern Europe
description: FRANKFURT  No other region suffered more grievous economic damage from the financial crisis last year than Eastern Europe, and a main cause was extensive borrowing in euros and other foreign currencies.

title: Group Fears Lower Rents Will Expire, Cutting Gains
description: The Bloomberg administration made a proud announcement earlier this week: It had reached the 100,000 mark in its ambitious plan to create or preserve 165,000 units of moderate- and low-income housing by 2014.

title: What Were Reading: Ransom Notes
European Banks Assurances Fail to Placate Investors
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank disappointed investors hoping for decisive action on Thursday to contain the euro zones increasingly virulent debt crisis, pushing the euro to another low for the year.

title: The Gun Lobbys Long Shadow
description: While the rest of the nation comes to grips with fresh concerns about terrorism, domestic and foreign, Congress is wrapped up in the peculiar obsessions of the gun lobby  most of which are certain to make Americans less safe in their homes and on the streets.

title: Surveillance Culture of the East German Secret Police
description: Now that DDR/DDR, Amie Siegels film essay on the legacies of the former German Democratic Republic and its surveillance culture, is receiving a one-week commercial release, she wants us to know that its not a documentary. She prefers the term cin constellations for her movies, which show up in both film festivals and museum exhibitions (including the Whitney Biennial).

title: Blame Albany

title: Debate on Expanded Presence in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The evidence of ties between the man accused of being the Times Square bomber and Pakistani militants has intensified debate inside the Obama administration about expanding Americas military presence in Pakistan, with some officials making the case to increase the number of Special Operations troops working with Pakistani forces in the countrys western mountains.

description: Days after his arrest, the Times Square bombing suspect has not been seen in court, though American law provides a right to be charged promptly before a magistrate, usually within 48 hours.

description: Amazon.com is in court again, fighting what ought to be a losing battle to defend its longstanding practice of not collecting sales taxes in most states where it does business.

description: The glitch that sent markets tumbling Thursday was years in the making, driven by the rise of computers that transformed stock trading more in the last 20 years than in the previous 200.

description: For legions of 4- and 5-year-olds and their parents, the test known as the E.R.B. is the entree into the world of private schooling, its pressure and price a taste of the expensive years to come.

description: The question is not whether Steve Consalvi should have jumped onto the field during a major-league baseball game in Philadelphia on Monday, waving a towel and running in circles like a toddler trying to avoid bath time. He shouldnt have. Nor is it whether he should have been subdued and arrested. That seems obvious.

title: If the Golf Shoe Fits, Youll Want to Wear It Everywhere
description: I remember when golf shoes were not only funny looking things with plastic flaps over the laces, but they hurt your feet, too. The rigid heel cuffs would give me blisters and the metal spikes created pressure points on the soles of your feet. But we wore them anyway. Hey, we had carrying bags without kick stands, too.

description: WASHINGTON  The Pakistani-American man accused of trying to detonate a car bomb in Times Square has told investigators that he drew inspiration from Anwar al-Awlaki, a Yemeni-American cleric whose militant online lectures have been a catalyst for several recent attacks and plots, an American official said Thursday.

description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a bleak $63 billion budget on Thursday, he warned that it would cause a lot of pain to many New Yorkers and he did not mince words about where to lay the blame: on Albany.

description: Early in Ocean of Pearls, a kind of Sikh Jazz Singer, Amrit Singh poses a question: Why would someone work so hard to come to a new world just to keep on living in the old one? Amrit (a thoughtful Omid Abtahi), a Sikh whose parents emigrated from India to Toronto in the 1960s, lives among Sikhs governed by tradition and conservative mores. (Being alone with his girlfriend in her darkroom is risqu: her father might catch them.)

title: Bruno Gets 2-Year Prison Term, but Stays Free
description: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, for years one of the most powerful politicians in New York, was sentenced Thursday to two years in prison on federal corruption charges. But underscoring the serious doubts surrounding the constitutionality of the law used to convict him, Mr. Bruno was allowed to remain free until the Supreme Court rules on the statute.

title: The Vatican: Pope Accepts Resignation of Irish Bishops
description: Pope Benedict XVI on Thursday accepted the resignation of two Irish bishops, bringing to five the number of bishops to resign since the abuse crisis hit the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland. In a statement, the Vatican said that Joseph Duffy, bishop of Clogher, and Francis Lagan, the auxiliary bishop of Derry, stepped down after reaching the retirement age of 75. Bishops are required to tender their resignations at 75, but the pope can decline to accept and, in some cases, he has kept bishops well past that age. In March, Bishop Duffy said that he had known about abuse allegations against a priest in his diocese but that he had not told the civil authorities at the request of the victims parents, Irish news media reported. The priest was later jailed.

title: 5 More Suspects Identified in Dubai Killing
description: The Dubai police have identified five more suspects in the killing of a Hamas operative in a Dubai hotel in January, bringing the total number of suspects to 32, a person familiar with the investigation said. The new suspects carried passports from Britain, Australia and France. The case has put an unwelcome spotlight on Israel, whose intelligence service, the Mossad, is widely believed to have ordered the killing. The Dubai police released extraordinary security video of the killers in February, along with their passport information, which in many cases was obtained fraudulently from dual citizens living in Israel. The suspects can be seen on the videotape disguising themselves as tourists, and following the Hamas operative, Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, to his hotel room. Some of the killers used more than one alias, including one man believed to be Zev Barkan, an Israeli being sought by New Zealand authorities in a 2004 passport fraud case, the person familiar with the investigation said.

title: Feelings of Donors Remorse Emerge After Politician Switches Parties
description: He sits atop a sizable campaign fund, more than $4 million collected over the years from loyal supporters. But these days, Steve Levy, a candidate for governor in New York, is hearing from some contributors that they want their money back.

title: Iran: A Show of Strength in the Persian Gulf
description: Irans Revolutionary Guards began a new round of war games in the Persian Gulf for the second time in less than a month in an effort to show off the countrys military strength. A spokesman for the drills, Adm. Qasem Rstamabadi, said the navy deployed destroyers, missile launchers and submarines, and used Iranian-made systems capable of detecting those who might wish to slip into Iran by water.

title: Chicagos Open-Outcry Traders
description: Theres an elegiac poignancy in James Allen Smiths Floored, a documentary about the changing face of the Chicago futures exchanges. Open-outcry trading  the practice of calling out buy and sell orders in soybeans and pork bellies from the floor (the pit)  has declined, like print media, a victim of computer culture and the urgent hunger for instant new information. As electronic trading spreads, and traders work in front of lifeless, antiseptic monitors, a generation of outcry traders finds itself increasingly obsolete. (By around 2008, only hog and cattle futures were trading primarily the old-fashioned way.)

description: Any attempt to reduce New Yorks ignorance of serious postwar art elsewhere should be applauded, especially a glimpse of the influential ceramic sculptor Robert Arneson (1930-92) working toward maturity. This applies even if, like me, youre not crazy about mature Arneson.

description: That the New York gallery world may be entering the phase of the ostentatious project space is signaled by the narrow, beautifully restored Victorian house on East 64th Street that Marianne Boesky has rented for exhibitions that juxtapose older art with work by artists she represents. Obviously, this may further sales, but the endeavor has benefits, like the chance to see more of the Argentine-born Italian modernist Lucio Fontana, and in a setting that is itself worth a visit.

title: Co-Leaders New Focus Is Strategy, Not Distance
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  J. B. Holmes, who has a share of the lead after the first round of the Players Championship, is not your garden-variety touring professional. Built like a lumberjack, bearded, with barrel staves for forearms and a neck like a hickory stump, Holmes looks more like a bouncer than a golfer.

title: Mark Ryden: The Gay 90s: Old Tyme Art Show
description: Fathered by figures like Big Daddy Roth and Robert Williams, a movement affectionately called Lowbrow by its adherents has been percolating out of the quasi-underground pop culture of Southern California since the 1970s. Lowbrow paintings typically feature illustrative technique and comically weird imagery.

title: Leslie Hewitt: On Beauty, Objects, and Dissonance
description: Leslie Hewitt aspires to make photographs that are both personal and social, flat and sculptural, archival and insistently contemporary. Thats quite a tightrope walk, and in her solo at the Kitchen, which includes work from the last two years, shes still finding her balance.

title: Max Palevsky, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 85
description: Max Palevsky, a pioneer in the computer industry and a founder of the computer-chip giant Intel who used his fortune to back Democratic presidential candidates and to amass an important collection of American Arts and Crafts furniture, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 85.

title: Blackstone Said to Be in Talks to Buy Fidelity National
description: A group of private equity companies, including the Blackstone Group, Thomas H. Lee Partners and TPG Capital, is in talks to acquire Fidelity National Information Services in what could be the largest leveraged buyout since the credit crisis, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Clarifying Questions of Liability, Cleanup and Consequences
description: On the evening of April 20, the oil rig Deepwater Horizon exploded about 50 miles off the Louisiana coast in the Gulf of Mexico, killing 11 workers and injuring 17 more. Two days later it sank in 5,000 feet of water.

description: Giulietta Simionato, a leading Italian mezzo-soprano who sang in American opera houses in the 1950s and 60s, died on Wednesday at her home in Rome. She was 99.

description: WASHINGTON  Washington loves a guessing game, and Supreme Court vacancies are great that way: plenty of names to handicap and horse-race, assumptions to advance and debunk, records to scour and distort.

title: Walter Sear, an Audio Engineer With a Passion for Analog, Dies at 80
description: Walter Sear, an audio engineer whose steadfast devotion to pre-digital recording technology led him to maintain a studio with vintage, analog equipment, a risk that paid off in recent years as musicians like Norah Jones, Wilco and Wynton Marsalis flocked there for its rich natural sound, died on April 29 in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Most Popular Soccer Team in the U.S.: Mexico?
description: In late 1993, buoyed by having qualified for the World Cup in the United States the next year, Mexico stepped outside its usual sites  Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas and New York  to play an exhibition game in San Diego.

title: Marquette Rescinds Offer to Sociologist
description: Marquette University on Thursday abruptly rescinded an offer to a sociologist to serve as dean of one of its colleges, angering some students and faculty members who said the university did so after learning she was a lesbian who wrote about sexuality.

description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday ruled that Chevron could subpoena footage from a documentary about the pollution of the Amazon rainforests of Ecuador and the oil companys involvement.

title: An American Bailout of Greek Proportions
description: The bailout of Americas failed housing finance giants is taking on Greek proportions. On Wednesday, Freddie Mac asked the Treasury for an additional $10.6 billion after posting first-quarter losses. Together, Freddie and its cousin Fannie Mae have drawn $136.5 billion from Treasurys unlimited equity line since they were seized in September 2008. The European and International Monetary Fund rescue package for Greece, one that was supposed to shock and awe international markets, comes in at the same kind of figure, around $139.7 billion.

title: Group Backs Ritual Nick as Female Circumcision Option
description: In a controversial change to a longstanding policy concerning the practice of female circumcision in some African and Asian cultures, the American Academy of Pediatrics is suggesting that American doctors be given permission to perform a ceremonial pinprick or nick on girls from these cultures if it would keep their families from sending them overseas for the full circumcision.

description: MONTREAL  There is still magic this postseason for the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Losses Keep Mounting for the Angels

It was just the start they needed after six consecutive losses on their road trip and an overnight flight to Seattle (where they will face Felix Hernandez on Friday) coming up.

Excerpts of accidental audio recordings of the discussions obtained by Der Spiegel vividly display the deep rifts between China and India, on the one hand, and European leaders and other industrialized powers on the other. Ticket sales for the match, at the Veltins-Arena soccer stadium in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, have reached 76,152, tournament organizers announced. That would exceed the current record for hockey, the 74,554 who attended the Michigan-Michigan State Cold War game played in East Lansing on Oct. 6, 2001.

title: Reinventing a Historic Space in Hong Kong
description: Given the speed with which Hong Kongs colonial buildings have been torn down, its fortunate that the old British marine police headquarters survived at all. The 19th-century white-stucco structure had been neglected for more than a decade. Most visitors to the bustling Tsim Sha Tsui area probably did not notice its elegant curving staircase entrance, set back from the neon and noise of Salisbury Road. Late last year the complex, known as 1881 Heritage (1881heritage.com), began reopening in stages, first with a few luxury shops. The main building, Hullett House (hulletthouse.com) now has a number of restaurants, a bar and a boutique hotel that opened last month. Perhaps most impressively, the renovation has been done with care.
