title: Fortress First-Quarter Loss Widens
description: Fortress Investment Group, the hedge fund and private equity firm, said Thursday that its first-quarter loss widened, largely due to the distribution of share-based compensation to employees.

title: Somerset Chief Hit With Hamptons Countersuit
description: Ahh, summer in the Hamptons: sandy beaches, glittering parties and, oops, some lawsuits.

title: MIE Holdings Slashes I.P.O.
description: MIE Holdings, the Chinese oil company, on Thursday cut the number of shares and expected price of its initial public offering, potentially reducing its proceeds from the deal by 42 percent, The Associated Press reported.

title: North Korean Leader Reaffirms Commitment to Weapons Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader, told officials in Beijing that his government would try to restart talks on ending its nuclear weapons program, Chinese news media reported on Friday, as Mr. Kim wrapped up his five-day trip.

title: Monty Pythons Existential Circus
description: Todays idea: Is Monty Pythons Flying Circus Britains answer to existentialism? Case in point: the revival this weekend of its philosophers soccer match, where absurdity and deep thought go hand in hand.

title: BofA Team Splits Off to Start Private Equity Firm
description: A group of Bank of America executives are splitting off to start their own private equity firm, but will continue to manage a portfolio for the bank, The Charlotte Observer reported.

title: Digg Plans 10 Percent Layoff
description: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

title: Goldman Said to Be in Settlement Talks With S.E.C.
description: Goldman Sachss lawyers have begun talks with representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle the fraud charges brought against it by the regulator, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

title: Stray Questions for: Meghan Daum
description: Meghan Daums memoir, Life Would Be Perfect If I Lived in That House, is reviewed in this Sundays Book Review.

title: My Week in Cash Flow: Friday
description: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. Im publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially nail-biting because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it was the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and enough cash on hand to complete it.

title: Tip of the Week: Joining a Mail List
description: Want to join a mailing list or other e-mail group but dont want the rest of the messages in your Gmail in-box to get lost? Gmail has supported plus addressing for years, and with it, you can get multiple addresses out of one @gmail.com account. All you need to do is stick a + sign and another word after your account name in your Gmail address when signing up for the mailing list or group.

title: Your Jokes: Tyson Says Hes Now a Veganb
description: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

title: HSBC and RBS Watching Books as Greece Shakes
description: Two British banking chiefs said Friday that they were closely monitoring the impact of the Greek credit crisis on their businesses, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

title: Complaint Box | Brittney, Brittny, Brittneigh
description: I saw a birth announcement the other day and groaned. In recent years, Id learned to accept the flood of trendy tots named Madison, but this was my first Madicyn. If you care about spelling, my advice is to pour yourself a stiff drink before untying that pink or blue ribbon and reading news of the blessed event.

title: Does Belichick Get a Pass on Poor Drafts?
description: Following up on Chase Stuarts analysis of the collective ages of N.F.L. teams:

title: Q. and A.: Aboard the Plucky Plastiki
description: On March 20, the Plastiki, a 60-foot vessel made from recycled plastic bottles, set sail from San Francisco Bay on an 11,000-mile voyage to Sydney, Australia. The goal of the voyage, masterminded and financed by a banking heir, David de Rothschild, is to call attention to environmental issues like bottled water and plastic waste. Solar panels and windmills power the vessel, and the crew uses Skype, Twitter and blogs to stay in touch with the outside world. Theyve also posted regular video updates.

title: Speed Read for Friday, May 7
description: Here are some highlights from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: German Lawmakers Approve Greek Rescue
description: German lawmakers on Friday approved the countrys share of the rescue package for debt-laden Greece after a boisterous debate in which the finance minister told them they had no alternative to the unpopular measure, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: Beyond the Homestretch
description: Lynn Reardon is the founder and executive director of LoneStar Outreach to Place Ex-Racers (LOPE Texas), a nonprofit racehorse placement agency near Austin. Before founding LOPE, Lynn worked in nonprofit finance and administration in the Washington, D.C.-area for too many years. Lynn lives on the LOPE ranch with her husband, Sophie the dog, multiple cats and a herd of ex-racehorses up for adoption. Lynn has adopted three LOPE horses of her own: Tulsa Mambo, Sally and Lightening Ball.

title: Whom Would You Interview? What Would You Ask?
description: The Times Magazine regularly runs a series called Domains in which famous people talk about their homes, possessions and domestic habits. Last week humor writer Dave Barry was the subject of the column, and he talked about his fridge pet peeve, his eye patch collection, and what he wanted to be at age 5. Whom would you choose to visit if you were writing a Domains piece, and what would ask that person to talk about?

title: A.I.G. Posts $1.5 Billion 1st-Quarter Profit
description: The American International Group on Friday reported a $1.5 billion profit for its first quarter, as the insurance company benefited from gains in its core operations and the improving markets.

title: Burkle Sues Barnes & Noble Over Poison Pill
description: The Yucaipa Companies, the investment company run by the Los Angeles investor Ron Burkle, sued Barnes & Noble, saying the booksellers shareholder rights plan favored the controlling Riggio family.

title: Iron Man 2 and the Fate of the Rolls-Royces
description: Did the stunt wizards in Iron Man 2 really destroy a Rolls-Royce Phantom? Or was that just movie magic?

title: Restaurants Help Lead Beiruts Revival
description: After more than 30 years of civil war, invasion and occupation, Beirut is prospering again, perhaps on track to recapture its title as the Paris of the Middle East.

title: Digital Wizardry in Childrens Literature
description: Once upon a time  in the 1990s e-books for children came on CD-ROMs, and for digital wizardry, offered only mouse clicks and hidden pop-up-like animations. Not anymore. Touch-screens and app stores have given new tricks to old books, and the number of new titles is blossoming.

title: Sampler: Palin Endorses Fiorina, and Mondavi Estate Is for Sale
description: Palin Endorses Fiorina for Senate |Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, announced on Thursday her support of Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, in Californias crowded United States Senate race. Ms. Palin,the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, apparently does not hold a grudge against Ms. Fiorina for saying during that campaign that Ms. Palin could not run a major company. Ms. Palin, a favorite of the Tea Party movement, shared her choice on her Facebook page. The endorsement disappointed conservative DeVore supporters. On Thursday night, thethree Republican candidates  Ms. Fiorina, former Congressman Tom Campbell and Assemblyman Chuck DeVore  clashed over immigration, gun control and the rights of terrorism suspects in their only debate before the June primary. They are hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer in November. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Nocturnalist | If Seeing Is Believing, What Is Tasting?
Bruno Is Sentenced but Stays Free
description: Joseph L. Bruno, for years one of the most powerful politicians in New York, was sentenced Thursday to two years in prison on federal corruption charges. But underscoring the serious doubts surrounding the constitutionality of the law used to convict him, Mr. Bruno was allowed to remain free until the Supreme Court rules on the statute. [NYT]

title:
Economy Gains
Impetus as U.S.
Adds 290,000 Jobs
description: Despite growing unease in the financial markets, the American economy is gathering steam, adding an unexpectedly large number of jobs last month.

title: Does the Law Encourage Preventive Care?
description: Q.

title: Michael Moore Says Judges Ruling Could Have Chilling Effect on Documentaries
description: The director Michael Moore says that a federal judges ruling to allow Chevron to subpoena footage from the documentary Crude could have dire consequences on the documentary filmmaking process, and urged that films director to resist the subpoena if he can.

title: The Early Word: 290,000 Jobs
description: The American economy added 290,000 jobs in April  the most in four years or so. At the same time, the jobless rate grew to 9.9 percent, after hanging at 9.7 percent for three consecutive months.

title: Varied Critics Assail Official Probing Climate Scientist
description: Oct, 4, 11:34 p.m. | Updated  The Virginia attorney general, deterred by a judge, is trying a new fishing technique in search of a decades worth of e-mail exchanges on climate science.

title: Now Opening | Galerie BSL
description: Despite the close affinity between art, fashion and industrial design, they tend to be treated as different disciplines. They might spend time together, but in the end each has their home: the gallery, the boutique and the store.

title: A Misleading Jobless Rate
description: Pay no attention to the unemployment rate  that is, if youre trying to make sense of todays jobs report.

title: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Panic
description: Todays poem, chosen from nearly 200 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Erin, who is 17 years old and lives in Wallingford, Pa.

title: Wages and Hours Are Up
description: Besides the healthy gain in jobs, todays employment report had other good news, too.

title: Europeans Move to Head Off Spread of Debt Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  Leaders from the euro zone countries signed off on a support package for Greece on Friday night and pledged to take steps to stanch a spreading debt crisis before markets opened on Monday morning.

title: For New Ailey Leader, Its All in the Family
description: WHEN Robert Battle was 3 weeks old, his great-aunt and great-uncle couldnt have imagined that one day he would become the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. To them, he was just a bowlegged baby in need of leg braces.

title: Opera Companies Fraught Seasons
description: GEORGE STEEL has just completed his first season as the general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera. That the company had a season at all  let alone one that offered an important revival of a challenging contemporary American opera, Hugo Weisgalls Esther, and an inventively updated, sexy production of Mozarts Don Giovanni  is a real achievement. A year ago the possibility that the City Opera, crippled by a gnawing deficit and a leadership crisis, might fail seemed all too possible.

title: A Torrent of Deepwater Comments
description: As the oil leak spread in the gulf, activists, elected officials, energy industry reps and scientific experts of all stripes kicked into opinionator mode. Readers of The Times have not hesitated to make their views known, either. In thousands of comments here and elsewhere on the papers Web site, they have weighed the causes and consequences of the spill and the implications for the environment and the nation.

title: Regulator Deferred to Oil Industry on Rig Safety
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators warned offshore rig operators more than a decade ago that they needed to install backup systems to control the giant undersea valves known as blowout preventers, used to cut off the flow of oil from a well in an emergency.

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Wilson, Can You Still Have Fun?
description: Is it wrong to enjoy the company of a misanthrope so much? The title character of Wilson, a new graphic novel by Daniel Clowes, may be an unsympathetic guy, but that hasnt prevented the book from landing at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week.

title: Jury Demographics, and a Hate Crime Unit
description: New Yorks criminal justice system is just a governors pen stroke away from starting to figure out just how much it truly adheres to the principle of a jury of ones peers.

title: Smoothies With Substance (and Style)
description: Smoothies are a delicious and easy way to boost your fruit and vegetable consumption. This week, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to add extra nutrients to a smoothie by blending in nuts and grains.

title: A Factory-Built Prius for Plug-In Intenders
description: TOYOTA may be the 800-pound gorilla of hybrids, but so far it has been well behind the leading edge of one trend. The company will not have a plug-in hybrid version of its popular Prius for sale to the public until 2012.

title: Off the Well, if Only for One Week
description: Manhattan Beach, Calif.

title: A Crossover Thats More About Sport Than Utility
description: TESTED 2010 Mitsubishi Outlander GT

title: Will the Internet Kill Traditional Car Radio?
description: THE Internets tentacles seem to have no limit, reaching out and strangling CDs, bookstores, newspapers and magazines. Now it has its sights set on the car radio.

title: Bad Dash Light, Grinding Shifts
description: AUDIS needing oxygen sensors and Cadillacs that will not go into gear are among the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Oil Now and in the Long Haul
description: Its clear that the risks of pursuing offshore oil matter more to Americans the closer the petroleum deposits are to American camera crews. There were a lot of proponents of offshore drilling, including President Obama, when the spills were half a world away. Even the prospect of drilling off Alaskas Arctic coast has largely been an abstraction; after all, that exploratory work is to take place in icy waters that few Americans will ever see.

title: A Designer Who Makes Impalas Do the Limbo
description: The byline for the Auto Ego feature last Sunday was omitted. It was by Richard S. Chang.

title: Prosecutors Oppose Polanskis Request for Sealed Testimony
description: The legal battle over Roman Polanskis possible sentencing in the United States on a 33-year-old sex charge continues, as prosecutors on Thursday registered opposition to Mr. Polanskis request that recent secret testimony in the case be unsealed. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States before sentencing in 1978, and his lawyers have asked the Los Angeles County Superior Court to provide them with transcripts of testimony by Roger Gunson, the original prosecutor in the case. In court filings, Mr. Polanskis lawyers have said Mr. Gunson described a plan under which Judge Laurence J. Rittenband intended to use Mr. Polanskis time in prison for psychiatric evaluation as his punishment in the case. In their brief on Thursday, Los Angeles County District Attorney Steve Cooley and Deputy District Attorney David Walgren said that the testimony should remain sealed and noted that the authorities in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski is being held pending possible extradition, have not requested transcripts of the sealed testimony. A hearing on the request is set for Monday.

title: The Week in Pictures, May 7
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Friday Reading: Another Invitation-Only Travel Site
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Letters: Mind Over Meds
description: Is it possible that Americans are still inundated by mental-health professionals who peddle a one-size-fits-all therapy to anyone who walks in the office? Lets hope that Daniel Carlat becomes both savior and saboteur of what has become a grossly misguided, albeit well-intentioned, field of practice.

title: Inside the List
description: DOPPELGANGSTER: A decade ago, a young Rhodes scholar and Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Johns Hopkins named Wes Moore was conducting research in South Africa when he received a call from his mother. She said, I have something crazy to tell you, Moore remembered recently on National Public Radio. She said, You know, the cops are looking for a man with your name in your neighborhood for killing a cop. . . . There are wanted signs all over your neighborhood for Wes Moore, and if you happen to see Wes Moore, do not approach because hes assumed to be armed and very dangerous.

title: Theory, Literature, Hoax
description: We love stories as much as we need them, but a funny thing has happened to departments of literature. The study of literature as an art form, of its techniques for delighting and instructing, has been replaced by an amalgam of bad epistemology and worse prose that goes by many names but can be summed up as Theory. The situation seems to call for a story, and one written in the style of Jorge Luis Borges, the grand chronicler of the tragicomic struggle between humans and logic.

title: Deaths in Venice
description: The much-admired atmosphere of Donna Leons mysteries derives from more than their pungent descriptions of Venetian life. Not that we dont appreciate the scenic walks and vaporetto rides her detective, Commissario Guido Brunetti, takes from the police station in Castello to the apartment off the Grand Canal where he lives with his wife and two children. And what reader doesnt savor those leisurely family dinners on the terrace or the stops at favorite coffee bars.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE IMPERFECTIONISTS,  by Tom Rachman (Dial, $25.) This intricate first novel is built around the personal stories of staff members at an improbable English-language newspaper in Rome, and the family who founded it for obscure reasons in the 1950s.

title: Paperback Row
description: FOOLS GOLD: The Inside Story of J. P. Morgan and How Wall Street Greed Corrupted Its Bold Dream and Created a Financial Catastrophe,  by Gillian Tett (Free Press, $16.) Tett explains clearly how a group of talented but shortsighted bankers at J. P. Morgan figured out, or so they thought, how to repeal the financial law of gravity and make risk disappear. They assembled credit derivatives, securitized them and marketed them aggressively. Our reviewer, Paul M. Barrett, questioned Tetts view that the bold dream of Morgan financiers was corrupted by others but praised her ability to decipher Wall Street mumbo-jumbo.

title: Ancient Chinese Art, in a Western Context
description: Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine that has been in use for thousands of years.

title: The Morning Line: Confidence in Super Saver
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Acupuncture Is Popular, but Youll Need to Pay
description: WHEN Divya Kumar was having trouble getting pregnant four years ago, she meticulously tracked her menstrual cycles and found something was amiss. She was ovulating late, on Day 22, instead of on the more normal Day 14.

title: F1 Returns to Old Europe
description: The Formula One circus returned to Europe, and on Friday the first practice sessions were run for the first race of the European leg of the series  which will, as always, be cut in half by a trip to North America in June.

title: The Cost of Acupuncture
description: Despite growing evidence that acupuncture benefits certain health conditions, most insurance companies still dont pay for it, writes Lesley Alderman in todays Patient Money column.

title: Up Front: Harold Bloom
description: Harold Bloom is probably the most prominent  and the most formidable  literary critic and commentator in America today. Helen Vendler has called him the foremost critic of his generation. (For his part, Bloom, noting a physical resemblance to a figure as overwhelming on the stage as he is in the world of letters, has said, I am Zero Mostel.)

title: The Jewish Question: British Anti-Semitism
description: Anthony Julius has written a strong, somber book on an appalling subject: the long squalor of Jew-hatred in a supposedly enlightened, humane, liberal society. My first, personal, reflection is to give thanks that my own father, who migrated from Odessa, Russia, to London, had the sense, after sojourning there, to continue on to New York City.

title: Consumer Reports Lifts Dont Buy Warning for Lexus GX 460
description: Consumer Reports magazine says the recall to fix a dangerous handling problem on the 2010 Lexus GX 460 works , and so the magazine is lifting its Dont Buy: Safety Risk designation for the vehicle.

title: The Battle of Britain
description: I dont see how last nights British election results, which left David Camerons Tories a couple of dozen seats short of a working majority in Parliament, are anything but bad news for the United Kingdom. I defer to wiser heads on the ins-and-outs of the parliamentary maneuvering thats about to begin, but two things seem clear. First, as The Telegraph puts it this morning, no matter what kind of government gets formed in the next few days, the only certainty is another general election, and sooner rather than later. And second, as The Economists Buttonwood suggests, the next election will probably be precipitated by resistance  from regional parties and the Liberal Democrats as well as Labour  to the hard budgetary choices a Prime Minister Cameron will be forced to make. Cameron campaigned as a change agent this time, but if he finds himself facing the voters again in a year or so, it will be as the face of fiscal austerity  which is a role that no politician wants to inhabit.

title: In New York, Some Judges Are Now Skeptical About Debt Collectors Claims
description: As New Yorkers have tumbled into credit card debt in large numbers during the great recession, bill collectors have inundated the courts to get what they say is due. In turn, the courts have issued hundreds of thousands of orders against residents. Some consumer groups argue that by doing so, the courts have become little more than an arm of the debt collection industry.

title: Book Shelf | The Definitive Wonder Woman
description: At the very top tier of the pantheon of heroes published by DC Comics are Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman. Wonder Woman, the Amazing Amazon who has been around since 1941, doesnt seem to get quite the same amount of recognition as her caped comrades. But 2010 may be her year.

title: The Jewish Question: Martin Heidegger
description: It may seem surprising that so many books continue to be written debating Martin Heideggers Nazi affiliations, since the fact that Heidegger was a Nazi has never been in dispute. How could it be, when the great philosopher took office as rector of Freiburg University in April 1933 specifically in order to carry out the Gleichschaltung, or bringing into line, of the school with Hitlers new party-state? Didnt he tell the student body, in a speech that November, that the Fhrer and he alone is the present and future German reality and its law? After the war, didnt he go out of his way to minimize Nazi crimes, even describing the Holocaust, in one notorious essay, as just another manifestation of modern technology, like mechanized agriculture?

title: Nietzsche: A Philosophy in Context
description: One of the pitfalls of writing a biography of a great philosopher is the temptation to reduce important ideas to mere psychology, an outgrowth of some fluke in the philosophers personal development. Julian Young, a professor at the University of Auckland and Wake Forest University, has for the most part avoided this trap by writing a philosophical biography of Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) in which the life story provides context but ultimately not explanation for the ideas. In so doing he has provided a serious and readable, if not exactly ground-breaking, introduction to Nietzsches philosophy with a hammer.

title: Hot Planet, Cold Facts
description: There ought to be a word, probably in German, for a book that makes the reader boil over with life-changing eco-enthusiasm only to find himself, a month later, reverting to his old Hummer-driving, planet-destroying ways. An informal survey of Germanists has failed to come up with anything. But Bill McKibben has found a planet where such books sell well. It is a world where environmental news goes from bad to worse, a place where ice caps vanish, crops fail, oceans acidify, activists rally and an oil company makes more money in three years than any company in the history of money. The place McKibben has discovered is an unpronounceable land called Eaarth. Where is Eaarth, you may ask? Unfortunately, youre soaking in it.

title: Not the First Time the Dead-Man Switch Did Its Job
description: On April 27, as you may recall, a motorman on a G train apparently suffered a fatal heart attack at the controls, activating the so-called dead-man feature, which stops the train when the motorman takes his hand off the controller.

title: When Jamaica Lost Its Chains
description: Andrea Levy, an English novelist born in 1956 to Jamaican immigrant parents, has made herself a pre-eminent chronicler of Britains tangled relations with its former West Indian colonies. In her best-known novel, Small Island, which was adapted into a BBC mini-series, Levy portrayed with often heartbreaking wit the hardships faced by her parents generation. Highly cultured and ambitious men and women raised to revere the Mother Country, they settled in Britain after the war, only to find themselves shunned, reviled and frequently assaulted by their white working-class neighbors and colleagues, to whom these arrivals from the Caribbean were savages come to rape their women and steal their benefits.

title: Collision Course
description: Great Depression or not, the 1930s wasnt such a bad time for writers. For some there was the W.P.A., with its government subsidies for artists; for others Hollywood was a cash cow. Magazines still paid pretty well, a Broadway play could set you up and a little money went a long way.

title: Weekend Competition: Wedding Vows
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit wedding vows suitable for the times in which we live.

title: Goldman to Review Its Business Practices
description: Faced with accusations of securities fraud and conflicts of interest, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, asserted Friday that the firm was committed to its clients and said it would establish a committee to monitor its business practices.

title: Hindsight History
description: To the Editor:

title: From Kenya to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Washingtonspeak
description: To the Editor:

title: Lest We Forget
description: To the Editor:

title: Peeling the Onion
description: Spoon Fed is an excellent example of a relatively new genre, one that considers food as therapy. In Kim Seversons case, its not just cooking that helps her deal with lifes vicissitudes but writing about food  which she has done for The New York Times since 2004 and before that for The San Francisco Chronicle. Her subtitle, How Eight Cooks Saved My Life, is manifested partly in mini-profiles of Marion Cunningham, Alice Waters, Ruth Reichl, Marcella Hazan, Rachael Ray, Edna Lewis, Leah Chase and her own mother, Anne Marie Zappa Severson, but more in accounts of her dealings with these women. They are pegs on which she hangs her metaphorical garments, with the purpose of revealing a little more of herself each time one is removed. Its a funny way to construct what is fundamentally a memoir with recipes.

title: On Our Radar: The Smell of Oil?
description: A foul stench drifts over the Gulf region, with vapor from the oil slick the likely culprit.

title: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
description: An actually good employment report. A reminder: there are two separate surveys, one of employers  which is where the 290,000 jobs number comes from  and one of households, which is where the 9.9 percent unemployment rate comes from. Sampling error, seasonal adjustments, and other technical factors can make these reports give contradictory indications.

title: Maestros, Music, Bows: Big Moments at the New York Philharmonic
description: 1:19 p.m. | Updated As the New York Philharmonic marks an astounding musical milestone  15,000 concerts  three critics of The New York Times who have attended a good many of those performances  James R. Oestreich, Allan Kozinn and Anthony Tommasini  write about some of the orchestras moments that have remained most vivid to them. Readers, please chime in: What New York Philharmonic concerts did you find most memorable?

title: The Performance-Enhanced Military
description: The military has received much scrutiny in recent years for allegedly overmedicating soldiers who suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder or from other mental illnesses associated with combat.

title: A Bombshell Bomber
description: Given a few clues and fair warning, could a writer prevent the next terrorist bombing? After all, as David Goodwillie demonstrates in his hip and quick-paced literary thriller, American Subversive, which opens after an attack on the Barneys building in New York, the writers job is to notice things that other people might overlook and to string together seemingly random details into a coherent plot. Then again, writers are notorious for trying to see everyones point of view, and that kind of identification can be dangerous.

title: Hung Over in Britain
description: UK, Yuck. Not only does no party have a majority, the two somewhat sensible coalitions  Tory-Unionist or Labour-Lib Dem  also lack a majority. Josh Marshall is right: its an election that all three parties managed to lose.

title: Young Singer Just Wants to Act Her Age
description: NIKKI YANOFSKY was up early, and already on. Mee-ee-ee-ee, she sang one morning last month, warming up in a tiny dressing room of a Manhattan television studio. A makeup artist leaned in to apply some last-minute touches, and she paused, eyeing her reflection. You know how everyone says, Im a morning person, or Im a night person? she chirped. Im just a person. Her parents, seated on either side of her, smiled.

title: If You Build It . . .
description: On Aug. 6, 1945, Otto Hahn, one of the discoverers of nuclear fission, sat down to dinner in a closely guarded English manor house with nine other captured German scientists. They switched on the radio at 9 p.m. to learn that an atomic bomb had been dropped on Hiroshima. Hahn was so upset by the possibility that he might have been responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent people that he contemplated suicide. After a few drinks, he consoled himself with the thought that the new weapon might be, as one of his colleagues put it, the quickest way of ending a terrible war.

title: Backlash Over Bailout May Sway German Vote
description: BOCHUM, Germany  Germans have found themselves cast as the stingy villains in the financial drama over Greece. But in the struggling industrial cities in western Germany voting in state elections on Sunday, they see themselves as victims of endless demands inside and outside the country for dwindling resources.

title: Hotel Review: East, in Hong Kong
description: THE BASICS

title: Uncertainty vs. Risk
description: It is three years since the failure of two Bear Stearns hedge funds signaled the start of the biggest financial crisis since the Great Depression, and the air is thick with the sound of stable doors being shut long after the horses bolted. At some point this year a vast new picket fence will be built around the entire ranch, in the form of a new financial regulation act.

title: The Sisterhood
description: Friction between sisters has served as a plot staple since the dawn of the novel  from Sense and Sensibility to Housekeeping  if not the inception of the written word (see: Rachel and Leah). Handled properly, it provides a near-perfect occasion for exploring the societal and familial expectations placed on young women, as Heather Clay does in her introspective first novel, Losing Charlotte.

title: CKXs C.E.O. to Resign and May Place Takeover Bid
description: CKX, which owns a majority stake in the American Idol brand, said on Friday that its chairman and chief executive, Robert F. X. Sillerman, had resigned as part of a possible takeover bid for the media company.

title: Court Rejects Christies Limits on Campaign Donations From Labor
description: A New Jersey appeals court on Friday overturned an attempt by Gov. Christopher J. Christie to sharply limit campaign contributions by government employee unions, saying that he could not make such a change without the Legislatures cooperation.

title: Magic Noirism
description: It takes guts for a writer to give away his novels fundamental conceit in the title itself, yet thats just what Thomas Mullen has done with his second book, The Many Deaths of the Firefly Brothers. In a novel that in every other respect is more 1930s noir than Marquezian fantasy, Mullen has his Depression-era bank robbers  Jason and Whit Fireson, popularly known as the Firefly Brothers  killed violently at least three different times, and then, as if waking from a long nights sleep with a bad hangover, come achingly back to life. At which point its time to rob another bank. Or save a damsel in distress. Until theyre killed again, violently. And then. . . .

title: Star-Spangled Story
description: Most historians dismiss the story about Betsy Ross making the first American flag. Yet despite a century of debunking, the legend endures. Across the country, schoolchildren still cut out five-pointed stars using the pattern that Ross, a Philadelphia flag maker, supposedly invented. The legend endures because publishers, souvenir sellers and patriotic boosters find it useful and because it fills a void in the American epic. Nations need heroines. Betsy Ross gives women a place in the national pantheon without disrupting our dominant myths.

title: Kimmel: Let Him Out
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Hey, it turns out the prime suspect in the failed attempt to bomb Times Square is not the brightest. They figured out the events leading up to Saturday. First, Faisal Shahzad buys an S.U.V. off Craigslist, using a traceable email, and fills it with, basically, wedding sparklers. Then he drives two different cars into New York  the one with the bomb in it and a getaway car. He plants the bomb but leaves the keys to the getaway car in the car with the bomb in it. So he has to take the subway home. And then, once he gets home, he realizes he also left the key to his apartment in the SUV with the bomb in it, and has to get his landlord to let him in. If this isnt the work of a stoner, I dont know what is.

What is your emergency? Oh, man, you are not going to believe this. So, Im trying to blow up Times Square, right? I am in such a hurry to escape I totally locked the keys in my car. Its just one of those days.

title: Art That Sells Itself
description: On Jan. 28, while on a business trip to Chicago, Terence Spies used his iPhone to monitor an eBay auction. He was trying to outbid a couple of rivals to win a black plastic box that was at the time on display at an art gallery in Seattle. Spies had read about A Tool to Deceive and Slaughter, as the piece is called, on a Reuters financial blog. Thats a strange-enough place for a collector to learn about art, but Spiess interest seems even more curious given that the blogger Felix Salmons write-up of the pieces sale was titled The Uncollectible Artwork. Even if Spies won the object, created by a young artist named Caleb Larsen, his ownership would be tentative: the technical innards of A Tool to Deceive and Slaughter carried a program that would relist the thing on eBay every week, forever. Indeed, the terms and conditions for submitting a bid clearly stipulated that the device must be connected to the Internet, constantly trying to resell itself at a higher price to someone else.

title: The Plural of E-Mail
description: Ashley Mergen asks: "What is the proper plural of e-mail? When referring to snail mail, you would not say, 'I received a hundred mails,' but rather, 'I received a hundred pieces of mail' or 'I received a hundred mailings.' However, when referring to e-mail, one would say, 'I received a hundred e-mails.' Correct?"  The plural form of e-mail is, indeed, e-mails, even though there's no corresponding plural of mail as mails. This mismatch has rankled seekers of grammatical consistency over the years, but it has nonetheless settled into standard usage.  First some terminology. Nouns that can form plurals are called "count nouns." Mail, historically, is what is known as a "mass noun"  a noun that can't be enumerated and thus resists pluralization, much like mud and milk, patience and poppycock. Some nouns can be either count or mass, depending on the context. General Sherman used war as a mass noun when he said, "War is hell," while Benjamin Franklin used it as a count noun when he said, "All wars are follies, very expensive and very mischievous ones."  Many mass nouns have spawned countable spinoffs over time. Coffee is usually an undifferentiated mass ("Get me some coffee"), but in modern use it can also be treated as a count noun denoting a cupful of the beverage ("Get me a coffee") or a variety of the bean ("We serve the finest Arabica coffees"). The Stanford linguist Arnold Zwicky has dubbed this process "countification."  When the word e-mail first made its appearance in the early 1980s (often capitalized as E-mail), it was simply a shortening of electronic mail, and so it worked grammatically much like the mass noun mail. To itemize mail into its constituent parts you need to find a workaround like pieces of mail or letters. Similarly, individual pieces of e-mail came to be called e-mail notes or more commonly, e-mail messages. (Single terms like e-notes or e-letters never caught on.)  By the late '80s, e-mail message was slowly but surely shortened to e-mail. In the archives of the magazine InfoWorld, the earliest use of e-mail as a count noun that I can find is from July 20, 1987, in an advertisement for International Data Group (IDG). "Jane Lawrence, editor of IDG's PC Business World, receives an E-mail from [Ann] Wujcik requesting information," the ad reads. Though the magazine generally preferred e-mail message, by 1992 even InfoWorld's publisher Robert Metcalfe was using the short form: "I have to admit I am now getting so many E-mails I can only read all and answer a few of them."  The countable kind of e-mail(s) made further headway over the course of the '90s, despite complaints that it strayed from the founding model of mail, and by the turn of the millennium it had become widely accepted in mainstream usage. (The mass-noun version never went away, of course.) What happened? My theory is that the e- prefix no longer felt like such a transparent abbreviation of electronic, allowing e-mail to cast off the bonds that kept it close to mail of the snail variety. The word's new unitary feel was further strengthened by the trend of spelling it as email, without the hyphen. (The New York Times style guide continues to stick by hyphenated e-mail, and even advises using the older, longer form of the noun, e-mail message.)  The countification of e-mail mirrors some other recent developments in tech-talk. Unwanted e-mail, known as spam, is usually treated as a mass noun (just like the canned meat after which it is named), but individual spam messages now often get called spams. And the word blog, while always countable, has taken a new semantic turn: some use it to mean a single post to a Web site, rather than a whole site consisting of such posts. A recent survey by the Copyediting newsletter finds that most writers and editors reject this usage of blog as improper, but who knows? In a decade's time, it could be as unremarkable as countable e-mails.

title: The Demise of Datebooks
description: I miss my Filofax datebook, with its six rings and dark red leather binder. I had a green one first, with a calendar that cast each week across two cream-colored pages. Back then, at age 30, I was not busy enough to need a whole page per day, which some Filofax calendars provide, but far too busy, or so I liked to imagine, to fit a weeks activities on a single page. I left that green one in a taxi and replaced it with a red one. Old reddie is still around, with my life during half of 2007 memorialized. Even when I started half-heartedly to use iCal, Apples personal-calendar program for the Mac, I lugged around the Filofax in case I needed  I dont know  the address book? The dry-measure equivalent for bushel? The dialing code for Saudi Arabia? The size conversions for tailors (Glove sizes are the same in every country)? The centigrade temperature in Accra in May?

title: Pregnant and Pained
description: Even sitting quietly in the hospital bed, the young woman looked out of breath. The muscles of her neck were pulled tight, and she lifted her shoulders as she inhaled, as if simply taking in air required work. According to the chart that Dr. Roxanne Wadia had glanced through, the patient was five months pregnant. But her arms and legs were thin and wasted-looking, and she had only a tiny hint of the expected baby bump. Her eyes were sunken, and her skin was sallow. Looking at her new patient, Wadia, a resident in her second year of training at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, felt her own heart quicken. The patient was clearly sick. The doctor gave her patient oxygen and then sat down to take a history.

description: When John McEnroe considers the future of tennis, he imagines the height of his past. He can see a 21st-century version of himself, challenging the orthodoxy, combating the world, emerging from a laboratory that is named after him.

title: Resurrecting an Old Beauty
description: Through good times and bad, the Tudor-style house just off the corner of Buckingham Road and Church Avenue in Prospect Park South has always been a showstopper.

title: To the Rescue of a Tudor Beauty
description: THROUGH good times and bad, the Tudor-style house just off the corner of Buckingham Road and Church Avenue in Prospect Park South has always been a showstopper.

title: General Growth Picks Brookfield Plan Over Simons
description: 3:35 p.m. | Updated A federal bankruptcy judge granted General Growth Properties motion to certify an investment plan led by Brookfield Asset Management as its stalking-horse bid. Minutes later, the Simon Property Group said it was withdrawing its $20-a-share bid.

title: How Obama Sr. Came to Hawaii
description: In his review last month of The Bridge, David Remnicks biography of President Obama, Garry Wills touched briefly upon the airlift that brought students from East Africa, among them the man who would become Obamas father, to the United States.

title: Long Island City Comes Into Its Own
description: ITS got sushi bars. A teahouse. An upscale grocery store. A cocktail lounge where the word mixologist could reasonably be uttered. Multiple options for doggy day care. Its one stop from Manhattan, the views are fabulous, and, joy to the world, there are no alternate-side parking rules.

title: Now Showing | Neither Hollywood Nor Cannes, but Paris
description: Many models go on to become actors (Cameron Diaz, Famke Janssen); some become musicians (Carla Bruni, Nico); and others, moguls (Kate Moss, Tyra Banks). But not many can bust out the model-turned-photographer title as Ellen von Unwerth can.

title: Tasting Chablis
description: I had dinner one recent night at Apiary with John Gilman, who writes the excellent newsletter View From the Cellar, and John brought along some Chablis from Patrick Piuze, a producer with whom I was unfamiliar. The wines were from the 2008 vintage, which I hadnt tasted yet. If you recall how much I love Chablis, you would be correct in assuming that I was excited.

title: Answers About Etiquette in New York, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Lyudmila Bloch, an international etiquette expert, protocol consultant, and author of The Golden Rules of Etiquette at the Plaza.

title: To Some in Australia, U.S. Response Looks Good
description: As environmentalists in the United States watch the continuing clean up of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico with consternation, some Australian environmentalists say they are feeling, well, jealous.

title: BMW Recreates a 328 Kamm Coup for the Mille Miglia
description: The Mille Miglia, the road race from Brescia, Italy, to Rome and back that began this week, marks the 70th anniversary of the year BMW swept the races top spots in 1940. To commemorate, the company has entered what it describes as a contemporary replica of the so-called 328 Kamm Coup. The replica was unveiled at the recent concours delgance at the Villa dEste on Lake Como.

title: At Trumpeters Home, the Doors Always Open
description: On Thursday evening, Joey Pero walked past Lincoln Center and stepped into the lobby of a luxury high-rise apartment building on West 66th Street and told the doorman, Were here to see Wynton.

title: The Last Days of Bruce Llewellyn
description: ALMOST everyone who visited J. Bruce Llewellyn three years ago in the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan heard the same refrain: Get me out of here.

title: Pounding the Pavement on a Bryant Park Pedestal
description: The warm-weather sidewalks around Bryant Park are usually as packed as the stateroom scene in the Marx Brothers Night at the Opera. But beginning on Monday, if pedestrians plowing through raise their weary heads, they will encounter a vision of truly stunning Midtown Manhattan density in the air above them.

title: Eaarth
description: Preface

title: In a Laboratory, Turning Traditional Notions of Opera Upside Down
description: In 1999, when Paul Kellogg, then the general and artistic director of New York City Opera, inaugurated the VOX project, a laboratory for new American operas, he asked George Steel, the executive director of the Miller Theater, to host the workshops there. The idea was to present sizable excerpts from new and recent operas, and in some cases works in progress, in concert performances. Mr. Steel, who had made the Miller Theater a hotbed of contemporary music, embraced the project. VOX was so successful that it moved to larger spaces for its later annual workshops.

title: Volcker Says Derivatives Proposal Goes Too Far
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has voiced some concerns about Senator Blanche Lincolns proposal to regulate the derivatives market much more tightly, saying that he is not in favor of forcing banks to spin off their derivatives operations.

title: The Many Deaths of the Firefly Brothers
description: The First Death of the Firefly Brothers

title: What Were Reading: Happy Mothers Day
Volatile Week on Wall St. Ends With Another Slide
description: 5:44 p.m. | Updated Turbulence continued to rock the equity markets on Friday, as Wall Street closed out one of its most volatile weeks since the financial crisis of 2008, The New York Timess Christine Hauser and Matthew Saltmarsh report.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
description: No, this is not Athens. Nor is it Bangkok. On Friday, the city convulsed by civil unrest was Katmandu, Nepal, where a violent strike by the countrys Maoists has left most businesses shuttered, schools closed and transportation crippled. Paralysis of a different kind is feared in Britain after an election that denied an outright majority to any single political party. A triptych of the three party leaders begins with Slide 4.

title: White House Deputy Counsel Resigns
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated Daniel J. Meltzer, a top White House lawyer who has played a critical behind-the-scenes role in the administration legal team, is resigning next month and will return to his tenured position as a Harvard law school professor, the White House said on Friday.

title: A Maverick Upends Colombian Politics
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Given the staid nature of the political establishment in Colombia, Washingtons top ally in the region, and the broad popularity of President lvaro Uribe, it seemed a foregone conclusion to many here that his heir apparent would clinch the presidency in the coming elections without too much of a struggle.

title: Adding a Dimension to the Frenzy
description: AT this moment, poised between the release of How to Train Your Dragon  seven weeks and around $200 million of domestic box office in the past  and the arrival of the next and final Shrek movie two weekends from now, we find ourselves in the middle of what film historians of the future may remember as the great 3-D frenzy of 2010. It is difficult, in the middle of any momentous historical event, to discern its true nature. Is this a revolution or a craze? Will the new 3-D, like sound in the late 1920s and 30s, color and widescreen a generation later, or computer-generated imagery over the past decade, fundamentally alter the way movies are made and experienced? Or will it be more like the old 3-D: an intriguing but ultimately limited gimmick?

title: The Perils of Sexual Roundelays
description: HOOKING up has been held responsible for a number of interpersonal woes, from the proliferation of sexually transmitted diseases to the withering of courtship and the death of true love. Now, according to a round of tsking headlines, hook-ups and their Gen X cousin, friends with benefits, have been associated with another risk: overlapping lovers or, in academic parlance, concurrent partners.

title: Preakness Field Coming Together
description: Slowly, the gates are beginning to fill for the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes, and it appears that the Kentucky Derby winner Super Saver is going to have some formidable company, among them a colt who finished in front of him the last time they met, Schoolyard Dreams.

title: The New York Philharmonic, Way Back When
description: The New York Philharmonics 15,000th concert, reviewed by Anthony Tommasini in The New York Times on Friday, set Mr. Tommasini and two other Times critics, James R. Oestreich and Allan Kozinn, to pondering other Philharmonic milestones and favorite concerts. Their thoughts follow.

title: Autodesk for the People
description: Autodesk is having a consumer moment.

title: Yes, Those Are Real Girls Doing Icky Science Things
description: Heres hoping that one of the delightful young ladies on SciGirls, a new series under the PBS Kids Go! banner, grows up to be tech-savvy enough that she figures out how to remove annoying animated interlopers from otherwise excellent television programs.

title: Sunday Preview
description: During medieval times, the hilltop castles in the Languedoc region of southwestern France werestrongholds of the Cathars, a zealous religious grouppersecuted, sometimes horrifically, by the Catholic Church. Eight hundred years later, Tony Perrotet returns to the battlefield and finds a travelers playground.

title: A Non-Mothers Day
description: Pamela Mahoney Tsigdinos will be spending Mothers Day with a group of friends who are not mothers. And not for lack of trying. Tsigdinos is the author of Silent Sorority: A (Barren) Woman Gets Busy, Angry, Lost and Found, about coming to terms with her own infertility. She also blogs at A Fresh Start, a communal site she created for women to share their stories. Mothers Day looks different from where she stands, she writes in a guest blog today, as she does every other day of the year.

title: Running a Prius From the Sun
description: Saving the world might not be as tough as it looks. In this weekends Automobiles section, I investigate what its like to drive a Toyota Prius converted to plug-in-hybrid status, a 10 kilowatt-hour, lithium-iron-phosphate battery pack hidden under its trunk carpet.

title: Dispatch From Dubai | Mr. Armanis Dream Hotel
description: I am probably the only journalist who was invited to the opening of the worlds first Armani Hotel, located in Dubais soaring Burj Khalifa, and wasnt told that the event had been moved from the 21st to the 27th of April because of the volcano eruption in Iceland.

title: Submitted for Your Approval, a Current TV Series Pays Tribute to a Classic One
description: For those viewers of the ABC sitcom Modern Family who thought there was something vaguely familiar about a moment in Wednesdays episode, you are not living in The Twilight Zone. The scene paid homage, in a subtle way, to a well-remembered episode of The Twilight Zone.

title: Can Michelle Obama Make You a Star?
description: LAST Saturday night, Michelle Obama walked into a staid Washington hotel ballroom wearing a striking red gown, and within minutes the fashion world was talking.

title: Baffert Undecided About Lucky in the Preakness
description: Bob Bafferts Conveyance is not going to compete in the Preakness Stakes, but he has yet to decide whether his 2-year-old champion Lookin at Lucky will make the trip to Baltimore for the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Bennett Braces for Difficult Day
description: For those interested, Saturdays Republican convention in Utah could offer some hints about how dimly the country views both incumbents and Washington.

title: Long Island City: A Neighborhood That's a Long Time Coming
description: Has Long Island City, 30 years after it was first labeled hot, finally become a self-sustaining neighborhood?

title: Weekend Fare
description: Here, once again with some help from Dave Cook, is a weekends worth of food-related activities:

title: Swashbuckling Glover Adjusts to TPC Sawgrass
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  His work with the print media done, Lucas Glover stepped outside for a television Q. and A. He stood smiling behind the camera until a member of the crew gently directed to a spot in front of the lens.

title: F.C.C. Allows Movie Studios to Block Copying of New Video-on-Demand Releases
description: LOS ANGELES  In a significant victory for the major movie studios, the Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a request to allow companies that sell movies via video-on-demand services to activate signals that would block the copying or other re-use in home entertainment systems of recent releases.

title: Security Tour of Times Square
description: A former Secret Service agent gives a tour of Times Square in the aftermath of the failed car bombing.

title: Summer Stages: Pop and Jazz
description: CaliforniaHOLLYWOOD BOWL June 12-Oct. 8. It's become somewhat de rigueur to pair a pop act with an orchestra (one gets a little extra bombast, the other a little extra edge), and each summer, the Hollywood Bowl plays matchmaker. On June 15 Sting will perform with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra; on July 2-4 Vince Gill will team up with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; on Aug. 13-14 Harry Connick Jr. and his Big Band will do the same; and on Oct. 2 Carrie Underwood will sing alongside the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Other notable bookings: the Playboy Jazz Festival (June 12-13), Femi Kuti and the Positive Force (July 7), Kings of Leon (July 12), B.B. King and Buddy Guy (Aug. 11), and the Neville Brothers (Aug. 18). (323)850-2000, hollywoodbowl.com.

title: Rajaratnam Seeks to Throw Out Government Wiretaps
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund billionaire accused of insider trading, sought on Friday to dismiss the governments most powerful evidence against him: thousands of wiretapped conversations between him and family, friends and associates.

title: Chic in Review | Met Ball Madness
description: American ApparelClaims none of the people in its campaigns are professional models. Even though some of them have agencies. Which I think must make them models. Oops.

title: German Parliament Approves Greek Rescue
description: After one of its most heated debates in years, the German Parliament voted Friday to approve its part of the emergency package arranged by the International Monetary Fund and the European Union, The New York Timess Judy Dempsey reported.

title: Manet Self-Portrait: New Star on the Block
description: Paintings by douard Manet rarely come up for sale, let alone self-portraits, of which he painted only two. But Self-Portrait With a Palette, from 1878, which depicts the Impressionist master posed in an impeccably tailored jacket, will be a star of Sothebys Impressionist and Modern art auction in London on June 22, where it is expected to sell for $30.1 million to $45.2 million.

title: Asparagus Pesto
description: Mark Bittman cooks asparagus pesto, which makes a tasty topping for fish.

title: Caraoke, for When the Shower Is Too Far Away
description: Think of it as radio plus.

title: Joe and Mika, the Odd Couple of Morning TV
description: LAST week on the North Lawn of the White House, the morning after the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner, Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski held court on the grass, presiding over a special Sunday edition of their MSNBC daily news program, Morning Joe. As they sat beside one another in directors chairs  Mika in a black evening gown with a plunging neckline; Joe in a dinner jacket (sans tie), both of them wearing dark sunglasses  they exuded the reckless, easy glamour of old-style Hollywood stars: Rock Hudson and Doris Day (but Doris Day with a tan and killer abs).

title: The Week in Pictures for May 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include pocket-size hotel rooms, a failed car bombing in Times Square, and the sale of a Picasso.

title: Starving the Beast
description: In his Forbes.com column this week, Bruce Bartlett opines on the perniciousness of the starve the beast mantra. A former official in the Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations, Mr. Bartlett writes:

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
description: Images from this week in culture.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Containment Effort Inches Closer to Oil Target
description: ROBERT, La.  A giant steel container meant to capture oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico was lowered to within 200 feet of the seafloor on Friday afternoon, officials said.

title: Roasted Radishes: So Who Knew?
description: OF all the things you can do with a radish  slice it into salads, chop it into salsa, shred it into slaw or, better, top it with a thick layer of sweet butter and a sprinkling of flaky sea salt  the last thing Id thought to do was cook it.

title: Asparagus Pesto Packs Plenty of Flavor
description: THERE are few things that can be treated as simply as asparagus, which takes almost nothing to be delicious. But how many times can you eat lightly cooked, lightly seasoned asparagus before you tire of it?

title: After Flooding, Nashville Musicians Assess Losses
description: NASHVILLE  The country music star Brad Paisley was one of hundreds of performers who feared for their instruments this week after the Cumberland River overflowed. The water covered large areas of Nashville, flooding the Grand Ole Opry stage with two feet of it, causing heavy damage to the symphony hall and forcing electricity to be cut in a tourist neighborhood of downtown.

title: From Sarah Silverman, an Adorable Look, Followed by a Sucker Punch
description: EVEN with the Red Sox beanie pulled over the trademark mane of black hair, its not hard to spot Sarah Silverman in the lobby at the Bowery Hotel: shes the grown woman dressed like a 14-year-old boy. Promoting her new memoir, The Bedwetter  which was No. 9 last week on The New York Times nonfiction hardcover list  Ms. Silverman saunters toward me in an American Apparel sweatshirt, Free City sweats, and worn Adidas. In 18 months of working with her, I dont think I ever saw Sarah in a shirt that didnt have a number on it, says David Hirshey, her editor at HarperCollins, which paid $2.5 million for her book. She dresses as if shes always ready for a touch football game.

title: Films of G.I.s That Star Average Joes
description: Like many fictional works set during World War II, the film Pastrami on Rye is more than just a history lesson. The six-minute movie, about two American soldiers passing the interminable hours in their foxholes, musing about what theyll do when they return home and debating whether it is wiser to bring a sandwich or a gas mask into battle, has a fundamentally existential tone. It is less about death than it is about the many trivial things the mind can contemplate while facing the certainty of it.

title: A Cross Of Gold
description: Reacting to todays column, Greg Mankiw points out another reason American makes a better currency union than Europe: high labor mobility, thanks to our cultural homogeneity. Indeed; thats Mundells original optimum currency area argument. (It was actually in my first draft of todays column, but length was a problem  I needed to cut another 200 characters  and it also doesnt bear too directly on the current European issues.)

title: Serious Play, and Notes on Paper, in This Salon
description: The days when choreographers had lofts in SoHo, where they lived, and friends came over and drank wine and watched works in progress, and threw some money into a bowl, and then everyone sat around talking about the dances, are over, no?

title: Survivor Lifts CBS
description: CBS won its eighth consecutive Thursday night in the ratings as Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains earned its best numbers since its season premiere. According to Nielsens estimates, the CBS reality show attracted 12.8 million viewers, leading the 8 p.m. hour and helping to lift the network into the lead for the night. CBSs 10 p.m. crime show, The Mentalist, delivered the nights largest audience with 14.7 million viewers, while CSI (14.2 million) helped CBS outperform ABC and Greys Anatomy (10.7 million) in the 9 p.m. hour as well. ABC was second on the night, garnering 8.3 million viewers for Private Practice at 10 but only 4.8 million at 8 for FlashForward. In third place, Fox broadcast Bones at 8 (8.9 million) and Fringe at 9 (5.8 million), while NBC finished fourth, garnering its best ratings at 9 for The Office (6.8 million).

title: Polanski Transcript Plea Opposed by Prosecutors
description: The legal battle over Roman Polanskis possible sentencing in the United States on a 33-year-old sex charge continues, as prosecutors on Thursday registered opposition to Mr. Polanskis request that recent secret testimony in the case be unsealed. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States before sentencing in 1978, and his lawyers have asked the Los Angeles County Superior Court to provide them with transcripts of testimony by Roger Gunson, the original prosecutor in the case. In court filings, Mr. Polanskis lawyers have said Mr. Gunson described a plan under which Judge Laurence J. Rittenband intended to use Mr. Polanskis time in prison for psychiatric evaluation as his punishment in the case. In their brief on Thursday, District Attorney Steve Cooley of Los Angeles County and his deputy David Walgren asserted that the testimony should remain sealed and noted that the authorities in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski is being held pending possible extradition, had not requested transcripts of the sealed testimony. A hearing on the request is set for Monday.

title: Time Stands Still Returning to Broadway
description: After its limited run earlier this year netted it two Tony Award nominations on Tuesday, including one for best play, Time Stands Still, which stars Laura Linney, below, as a photojournalist recovering from wounds she sustained covering the war in Iraq, will take another shot at Broadway. Spokesmen for producers of the play, which was written by Donald Margulies and is directed by Daniel Sullivan, said that it would resume performances on Sept. 23 at a Shubert theater to be determined. The original run, presented by the Manhattan Theater Club at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, ended on March 27. Ms. Linney, who received a Tony nomination as best actress for her performance, will return to the production, as will Brian dArcy James (Next to Normal), who portrays Ms. Linneys partner, and Eric Bogosian, who plays her friend and former lover. The plays publicists said Time Stands Still was taking a hiatus to accommodate Ms. Linneys production schedule for a new Showtime television series, The Big C, which is to have its debut in August.

title: Sundance Channel Pulls Film About Bomber
description: The Sundance Channel has decided against additional showings of a film about a young woman preparing to become a suicide bomber in Times Square. The film, from 2006, is called Day Night Day Night, and was written and directed by Julia Loktev. Sundance, a cable channel that specializes in independent films and movies that are out of the mainstream, has been showing Day Night Day Night as part of a celebration of the Cannes International Film Festival, which starts next week; the film won a prize at Cannes in 2006. Day Night Day Night was most recently shown on Sundance early Thursday  just days after an S.U.V. packed with explosives was found in Times Square. On a Time Warner Cable system channel guide, the film was described as being about a young woman preparing to carry out her mission as a suicide bomber in New Yorks Times Square. It had been scheduled to appear on Sundance a couple of additional times this month. But given the events of the past week, Sundance said in a statement, the channel has opted to suspend additional airings.

title: Three Stars to Leave Production of Race
description: In the latest maneuver in a longstanding affair as tense as any courtroom case (and just as drawn out), the producers of the David Mamet play Race said on Friday that its Broadway production would remain open through Aug. 21, but that three of its key cast members would not stick around that long. David Alan Grier, top right, who on Tuesday was nominated for a Tony Award as a supporting actor for his role as the lawyer Henry Brown, will depart the show after its performance on June 13  the day of the Tony Awards ceremony  as will his co-star Kerry Washington, center, who plays the law firms new recruit Susan. James Spader, left, who plays the lawyer Jack Lawson, will give his final performance on June 20. No replacements were announced for these roles. Race, which is at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, was Mr. Mamets Broadway debut as a director but he was not nominated for a Tony in that category and the show was not nominated for best play.

title: Lady Gaga vs. Idol: Nobody Wins
description: This hasnt been an easy week to be a behemoth of either pop music or television. On the one hand you have the colossally popular Lady Gaga, right, who got the gossip columns buzzing about the amount of time it may or may not have taken her to emerge from her dressing room at the Costume Institute Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night. On the other you have the monstrously successful American Idol, whose ratings have seen worrisome declines this year amid complaints about a ho-hum lineup of contestants. Put the two phenomena together, as happened on Wednesday night, and you should have a high-wattage hit. But instead, the pairing just made the week worse for both parties. Hours after Lady Gaga appeared on the show to perform her songs Bad Romance and Alejandro, she was on Twitter complaining about how she was presented on the show. FOX POORLY + AMATEURLY edited+cut my performance/musical arrangement on idol, Lady Gaga wrote. She also provided a link to the Web site PerezHilton.com, where she said the full unedited performance could be found. Even in its shortened form, Lady Gagas performance was not much help to American Idol, which posted its worst Wednesday-night ratings since 2002. Fox declined to discuss Lady Gagas remarks and a representative for Fremantle Media, which produces the show, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: How to Say Greed Is Good in Hindi
description: Can you earn money and also earn respect? Thats the question in Parmeet Sethis Badmaash Company, a Hindi film about corruption and redemption.

title: Why You Care About Britains Hung Parliament
description: Well, fellow Americans, I hope were all feeling a little smug today: jobs are being created, terrorists are being captured, and our democratic system isnt some Rube Goldberg contraption  threatening to give us a government cobbled together through shameless political bribery followed by  good God!  a second national election in one calendar year. There will always be an England, or so it is said, but I doubt even the English are heartened by that sentiment at the moment.

title: Selling Cape Winds Future Wares
description: Cape Wind, the huge offshore wind farm that recently won federal permission to build near Cape Cod, Mass., announced on Friday that it had signed a deal to sell half the projects output to National Grid, a New England utility, for a price beginning at 20.7 cents a kilowatt-hour.

title: Seared Radish Crostini
description: Time: 25 minutes

title: O Nao!
description: Portugal is not looking good: interest rates where Greece was only a few weeks ago.

title: Pesto Works With Asparagus, Too
description: Looking for something new to do with asparagus? I was, which is why I decided that asparagus pesto was a long overdue addition to my repertoire.

title: International House of Joe
description: The outdoor seating at the Coffee Trade, buffered from the road by a robust stand of arborvitae, a few white birch and a healthy spruce, makes an enjoyable spot in which to sip fresh-brewed coffee. Yet it is the interior of this white clapboard-sided building that truly sets the place apart from other coffee purveyors.

title: Fritters to Paella, the Tastes of Portugal
description: NAMED for the river that flows across northern Portugal toward its outlet at Porto, Douro Restaurant and Bar, which opened in Greenwich about six months ago, calls its cuisine Portuguese-Mediterranean, but it is actually more the former than the latter.

title: B-Movie Newshound: Hello, Big Boy, Get Me Rewrite!
description: The Torchy Blane Collection

title: Congress Takes Aim at Wall St.s Wild Trading
description: As the financial markets remain unnerved by Thursdays wild trading on Wall Street, lawmakers are moving quickly to investigate what exactly went wrong.

title: Charting Creativity: Signposts of a Hazy Territory
description: Grab a timer and set it for one minute. Now list as many creative uses for a brick as you can imagine. Go.

title: Shells Kitchen
description: The $25 lobster roll at Day Boat Cafe in Irvington, reviewed at left, has inspired a lively debate in the blogosphere: Is it extravagantly expensive or worth every penny?

title: Tastes of the Sea, Beach Not Included
description: WITH nature dropping heavy hints of summer, Day Boat Cafe, a whitewashed New England seafood restaurant that opened in Irvington in early March, is reeling in a popped-collared crowd ready for a weekend party. Based loosely on the beloved clam shacks and chowder bars that dot the shores from Maine to Rhode Island  I say loosely because the dcor is more Newport than Freeport  Day Boat Cafe offers diners a day at the beach without the inconvenience of sand.

title: R.N.C. Fires Finance Chief and Deputy
description: The heads are still rolling at the Republican National Committee.

title: Save the Date, and Waste a Long Weekend?
description: SAVE the dates: Monica Lee and Kelly Milligan are marrying in Chicago on Memorial Day weekend. Jessica Mullens and Scott Engelman plan to wed on Independence Day weekend in San Francisco, and Ella Dutton and Alex Campbell have set their date for Labor Day weekend in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Irish Inspiration; French Twists
description: Its tempting to make a meal of the crusty breads at Blue Rooster Bakery and Caf in Cranbury  at least until you try a sandwich with fillings like chicken salad flecked with pears and walnuts ($10). Soups and salads are also among the offerings at this elegant yet casual cafe situated in a Victorian house.

title: Locally Rooted Flavors That Belie Their Setting
description: WHEN you make a last-minute dinner reservation for a Saturday night, you take what you can get. At Elements in Princeton, we were offered two seats at the four-seat bar for an hour before another party was scheduled to claim them. We took them, gambling that there would be a no-show. We lost.

title: Emily Grant and Scott Werthamer
description: Emily Beth Grant, the daughter of Madeleine Rudel Grant and Jeffrey S. Grant of New York, was married Saturday evening to Scott Matthew Werthamer, the son of Marilyn F. Werthamer and Rony Werthamer of Pikesville, Md. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York.

title: In Southold, From 4 Ross to 6
description: Croteaux Vineyards in Southold, the only Long Island producer specializing in ross, has added two new versions to its 2009 portfolio, bringing the total to six.

title: Small-Plate Seafood Spot Gets Off to a Fast Start
description: WHAT kind of person opens a restaurant in a resort town in the dead of winter? In the case of Noah Schwartz, who started Noahs in Greenport in January, the answer is: a brilliant one. He is a wizard in the kitchen and shows signs of similar talent in his debut as a restaurateur.

title: When an Opponent Errs, Declarer Wins the Big Bucks
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  The John Roberts Teams opened the Cavendish Invitational tournament at the Green Valley Ranch Resort here, just outside Las Vegas. There were nine 9-board rounds, with international match points converted to victory points. A win by at least 32 imps produced a 30 to 0 blitz.

title: God and Family, and the Changes to Come
description: As befits an actor playing Tevye, the Russian milkman in Fiddler on the Roof, Eddie Mekka has soulful eyes. He sometimes uses them skillfully to connect to the audience or while speaking to God, whom he considers a close friend.

title: What Are You Seeing?
description: As the oil from the Deepwater Horizon reaches land, we would like your updates and photographs of what youre seeing. Photos are optional but recommended. Please share your updates here.

title: Trying to Make Mozart Youth-Friendly
description: LAST November, thousands of teenage fans mobbed Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City for an appearance by the pop sensation Justin Bieber. The event was canceled because of the chaos. Now if only the Long Island Mozart Festival, taking place next weekend a few miles away at Old Westbury Gardens, would have the same drawing power.

title: Pamelee McFarland and Raymond Murphy
description: Pamelee Marie McFarland and Raymond Finley Murphy Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Dot Shot: Leafcutter Ants on Parade
description: In my academic role, Im visiting the La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica. About two dozen young scientists from around the Americas who spent three weeks studying together last year are convening here again to explore the interface of tropical ecology and climate.

title: Shari Braverman, Zachary Messing
description: Shari Erin Braverman, a daughter of Elyse P. Braverman and Alan P. Braverman of Bellmore, N.Y., was married last evening to Zachary Scott Messing, the son of Arden J. Messing and Shep Messing of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated at the Harvard Club of New York City.

title: Pettitte Wanted Input in Decision to Skip Start
description: BOSTON  From the Yankees perspective, their decision to skip Andy Pettittes next start came easily. When a nearly 38-year-old pitcher complains of elbow tightness 27 games into what they hope is another championship season, they see no reason to take unnecessary risks. They are taking a similarly cautious approach with Jorge Posada, who was held out of the lineup Friday night for a third consecutive game, and with Mariano Rivera, who had not pitched in a week because of a muscle pull in his rib cage but was expected to be available Friday night.

When asked by CSNBayArea.com whether he would settle it with knuckles, Braden said, Obviously theres things that are going to have to happen  just out of respect for my teammates, out of respect for the game.

description: Nick Clegg, leader of Britains Liberal Democrats, has emerged as the likely kingmaker in the British election, and that seems sure to unnerve the bankers and traders operating in the City of London. Mr. Clegg has put forth a range of tough regulatory proposals to change the way the City operates, saying that bankers should fear the Liberal Democrats gaining greater influence over the government.
