title: Spain Recovers, and Portugal Mulls Its Options
description: The Spanish economy, for all its troubles, came out of the recession last quarter, according to the Bank of Spain (PDF), with the countrys gross domestic product posting growth of 0.1 percent on the previous quarter and ending an 18-month contraction, shrinking 3.6 percent last year.

title: Six Days of School, and Then a Day Not of Rest
description: David Levin, 40, co-founder of the celebrated KIPP charter school network and superintendent of KIPPs New York City schools, works 75 to 90 hours a week training teachers, raising money and shuttling among six schools. Even Mr. Levins Saturdays tend to be consumed by KIPP, which stands for Knowledge Is Power Program. Sundays, though, are reserved for his wife, Nikki Chase-Levin, 38, a marketing consultant (they met speed-dating) and their 15-month-old son, Max. The family lives on the Upper West Side.

title: Parking Meters and the Cursed Washerwoman
description: Q. Settle an argument, please. Those big nests in the upper branches of trees in Central Park and other city parks: are they crows nests or squirrels nests?

title: A Black Abolitionist and Barbecue Diplomacy
description: Mention American abolitionists and David Ruggles rarely comes to mind. In David Ruggles: A Radical Black Abolitionist and the Underground Railroad in New York City  (University of North Carolina Press, $30), Graham Russell Gao Hodges goes a long way toward rectifying that oversight. Ruggles published what might have been the first black periodical in the country, sheltered a fugitive slave named Frederick Washington Bailey  later Frederick Douglass  at his home on Lispenard Street in Lower Manhattan, and led a committee that helped save more than 600 escaped slaves.

title: California: Tax Receipts Disappoint
description: State revenue trailed Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers forecast by $3.6 billion in April, deepening the budget deficit. The revenue in April, when income tax payments are due, was 26 percent below the governors projection and more than offset an unexpectedly large intake in the previous four months, Controller John Chiang said Friday. Californias collections are $1.3 billion below estimates for the current budget year, which goes through June 30.

title: Has the Big Apple Become the Big Eyeball?
description: Theres one, over by the Walgreens entrance, and theres another, just below the King Tut banner  video cameras, installed by private companies to survey the public spectacle of Times Square. I would not have seen the countless electronic eyes had Christopher Falkenberg, the president of a firm called Insite Security, not pointed them out. But I felt pretty sure those cameras had a clear view of me.

title: As Kyoto Attractions, Wave Pools vs. Temples
description: KYOTO, Japan  A dolphin pool, a penguin park and a giant wave pool could soon join the imperial-era townhouses and ancient Buddhist temples in Kyoto, Japans former imperial capital.

title: On the Street | Flowery Millinery
description: At the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, splendor of an earlier age was captured by the 1,200 guests in flowery millinery and spring-summer clothes.

title: Top White House Lawyer Resigns
description: Daniel J. Meltzer, who has played a crucial behind-the-scenes role in the White House legal team, is resigning in June and will return to his tenured position as a Harvard law school professor, the White House said Friday. He has worked on nearly every major legal issue the administration has handled and helped prepare Judge Sonia Sotomayor for her Supreme Court confirmation hearings. He might reprise the role in his final weeks by working with the next court nominee, expected to be named soon.

description: A rare strain of E. coli never before associated with foodborne illness in the United States has sickened 29 people in three states, public health officials said Friday. The outbreak has been tied to romaine lettuce served in restaurants, school cafeterias and deli and supermarket salad bars.

title: A Little Off the Top and Also the Mind
description: THE barber arrives on Tuesdays at 10 a.m. The men are already waiting in the hallways  some have been there for hours, knowing that the latecomers will have to idle past lunch.

description: A prominent law firm is expected to sign a lease next week for a new home in the vacant 40-story tower called 11 Times Square, ending months of speculation about the deal and providing another sign that the commercial real estate market may have hit bottom.

description: Alan Bennett Ilagan and Andrew Van Wagenen were married Friday in Boston. The ceremony in the Boston Public Garden was led by Christopher J. Vaeth, a friend of the couples, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the event.

title: Risk Seen for Europes Banks if Cuts Freeze Credit
description: FRANKFURT  Analysts and investors have begun to focus on the risks to European banks if severe budget cuts by debt-ridden countries freeze credit markets and cause a double-dip recession.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: PHILIPPE PETITS HIGH-WIRE CLASSROOM was unveiled on Thursday in the performance space that is S.L.A.M. (the Streb Lab for Action Mechanics), at 51 North First Street. Mr. Petit, a renowned high-wire artist and a subject of the documentary  Man on Wire,  has given some wire-walking clinics over the years. But he has decided to give master classes for the first time, at the behest of Elizabeth Streb, the choreographer and contemporary dance teacher who opened the space in 2003. Ive stalked Philippe for 10 years to get him to do this, Ms. Streb said. Mr. Petit, 60, recently designed and installed a cable 23 feet long and 10 feet high. He will begin reviewing applications for six precious spots in the summer class, which will include slack-rope walking and street performing. Walking between skyscrapers is not in the curriculum. This is for serious artists, Mr. Petit said, not for people who want something to talk about at cocktail parties.

title: Celebrating Artists Who Keep the Action in Abstraction
description: WHEN Dara Meyers-Kingsley was invited to curate ArtsWestchesters annual exhibition of Westchester artists, she knew that the theme of the show was to be abstraction. By setting her focus on the last six letters of that word, she has assembled a collection of artwork that, she said, offers a new perspective on abstract art. Opening May 15 at the Arts Exchange in White Plains, the exhibition is titled AbstrACTION, with action in various guises its highlight.

title: 2 at Faith-Based Bank Are Indicted Over Bribes
description: ATLANTA  When government regulators here shut down Integrity Bank at the height of the recession, in August of 2008, the bank was seen as just another failed lender that had overvalued the real estate market and collapsed.

title: Pythons in Florida Stalked by Hunters and Tourists Alike
description: FLORIDA CITY, Fla.  Thousands of Burmese pythons, the offspring of former pets, have invaded the Everglades, eating birds, bunnies, even alligators. It has gotten so bad that Congress is considering an outright ban on buying or selling nine kinds of giant snakes.

title: Bloggingheads: Was Bush Right?
description: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and David Frum of FrumForum debate whether President George W. Bush was right on national security.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Soap Opera for the Ages
description: Does it seem like overstating things to say that Friday Night Lights is the greatest television soap opera of all time? The series, which returned to NBC Friday night for its fourth season after an earlier run on DirecTV, whispers its heartaches and longings; it is melodrama that always manages to steer clear of feeling melodramatic. Often the show seems like a lesson in resilience to those members of its audience who are Eastern and privileged and lap it up. The people who live in the series fictional town of Dillon, Texas, never seem undone by the swelter of deprivation; they just go about the business of getting by.

title: Red Sox Nation Grumbles Like an Entitled Empire
description: The Red Sox are off to a troubled start, and barely a sixth of the way into the season, the Web sites and comment boards in Boston are warning of a long and miserable summer. But to any longtime Sox fan  born before, say, 1990  it just aint so. To us, this year promises to be a cathartic trip down memory lane and, maybe, a return to tradition, and sanity.

title: A Landfills Closing Alters How a Neighborhood Views Freight Trains
description: For decades, the people of Middle Village observed a rough truce with the freight trains that rumble through their Queens neighborhood. They did not love the hulking, clamorous boxcars and locomotives, but they understood that the trains were as much a part of the working-class row-house landscape as they were.

title: Yankees Johnson Leaves With Wrist Injury
description: Nick Johnson exited Fridays game in the fifth inning because of a sore right wrist. The same wrist required surgery in 2008, when Johnson was limited to 38 games with Washington. It was unclear how Johnson was injured. Marcus Thames pinch-hit for Johnson, who was 0 for 2, in the fifth inning.

title: Origin of Wall Streets Plunge Continues to Elude Officials
description: A day after a harrowing plunge in the stock market, federal regulators were still unable on Friday to answer the one question on every investors mind: What caused that near panic on Wall Street?

title: A Playwright Inspired by Teachers
description: A movie star walks into a small, run-down New York studio. Earning $6 million a picture, she feels like a fraud. She has come to seek the help of an acting teacher who was once a distinguished actor and now has a major chip on his shoulder.

title: A Party, by Way of Africa and Holland
description: Each spring in 18th-century New York, Dutch colonists and their African slaves discarded their roles for a few days to observe a cross-cultural holiday. Next Sunday, visitors to Philipsburg Manor can relive the festivities at Pinkster: An African-American Celebration of Spring.

title: Dominican Prospects Will Face Strict Rules
description: The top official for Major League Baseball in charge of overhauling its operations in the Dominican Republic said Friday that baseball would require top prospects as young as 15 to provide fingerprints and have testing for performance-enhancing drugs before they can sign with teams.

title: Unclear Result in Britain Puts Focus on Electoral Rules
description: LONDON  The British publics failure to elect a clear winner in Thursdays national election appeared to be a mass expression of exasperation with a discredited government and an uninspiring opposition. It also showed the voters disillusionment with the increasingly creaky electoral system itself.

title: Uncertainty in British Vote Adds to Economic Jitters
description: LONDON  The prospect of political stalemate after the indecisive British election sent the pound lower Friday and heightened fears that credit rating agencies, which have been quick to downgrade indebted economies in the euro zone, might do so to Britain.

title: Immigration Status of Army Spouses Often Leads to Snags
description: Lt. Kenneth Tenebro enlisted in the armed forces after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, signing up even before he became an American citizen.

title: Westwood Has Up-and-Comers in Line
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Golf has been abuzz about a youth movement again, especially this week after the fuzzy-cheeked duo of Ryo Ishikawa, 18, of Japan and Rory McIlroy, 21, of Northern Ireland shot record-low rounds to win on the Japan PGA and the PGA Tour last week. But here on Floridas First Coast, where alligator hide is not always a reference to the primordial-looking reptiles in the water hazards at T.P.C. Sawgrass, things are a bit different.

title: U.S. Orchestra Performs in China, in Echoes of 1973
description: BEIJING  Grant Xia had the misfortune of trying to take up violin as an amateur during the collective madness of the Cultural Revolution. Chinese officials banned classical music and sent musicians to re-education camps. Mr. Xias family collection of more than 1,000 vinyl records was destroyed. Mr. Xia soon stopped playing the violin.

description: IT seems as if every week I get a postcard or letter that reads something like this: Save money by reducing your property tax. 100 percent risk-free. No Reduction, No Risk.

description: Gordon Brown has lost his long-odds bid to lead the Labour Party in Britain to its fourth straight parliamentary majority, but it is not yet clear which party has won.

title: In Insider Trading Case, a Move to Throw Out Wiretaps
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund billionaire accused of insider trading, sought on Friday to dismiss the governments most powerful evidence against him: thousands of wiretapped conversations between him and his family, friends and associates. Lawyers for Mr. Rajaratnam argued that the wiretaps violated federal statutes governing the use of surveillance techniques. A spokeswoman for the United States Attorneys Office for the Southern District of New York declined to comment.

title: Greek Debt Crisis Raises Doubts About the European Union
description: PARIS  Europes consistent inability to move quickly enough to get ahead of the financial markets during the Greece crisis is shaking the euro and the foundations of the European Union itself, as critics of the euro have long predicted would happen.

title: How Should the Layoffs Work?
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City said this week that fiscal woes could force him to lay off more than 6,000 teachers. We hope the number will not be that high, but there will have to be layoffs. The question is, how will they be done?

description: A thousand years ago, popular birth control methods in the Western world included spitting into the mouth of a frog, eating bees and wearing the testicles of a weasel. In Crdoba, Spain, which was supposed to be on the scientific cutting edge, women were told to leap up and down vigorously after sex, and then jump backward nine times.

description: OTTAWA  Journalists do not have a constitutional right to protect the identities of their sources, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled Friday.

title: Cano Leaves Game After Being Hit by Pitch
description: The Yankees took a 9-1 lead against the Red Sox with a six-run sixth inning Friday, but it was a troubling inning for the Yanks in one respect. Second baseman Robinson Cano, one of the hottest hitters in the American League, left the game after he was hit by a Josh Beckett pitch. Cano tried to jump out of the way, but the ball struck his left knee. Cano walked to first base, but after a few moments he left the game. The severity of the injury was unclear.

But that argument could be difficult to make, because Robert Loggia, as Annas father, Siv, looks so robust, so engaged and enthusiastic that you would swear he could put off any funeral planning until at least 2030.

In the 1930s and 40s, this not-so-desirable niche was filled by Florence Foster Jenkins, a New York socialite with lofty musical aspirations and no vocal ability whatsoever.

title: Bombing Suspects Route to Citizenship Reveals Limitations

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, under intense political pressure from Capitol Hill and elsewhere, is engaged in a vigorous debate over whether to reverse course and join an international treaty banning land mines, administration officials said this week.

title: G.O.P. Committee Leaders Fired
description: The finance chief of the Republican National Committee, Rob Bickhart, and his deputy were fired Friday by Michael Steele, the party chairman, after months of sluggish fund-raising punctuated by unwelcome publicity over some of the committees spending. While we appreciate their service to the R.N.C. and wish them well in future endeavors, the chairman felt it was important to restructure the department in order to continue to improve on our strong fund-raising numbers, Mr. Steele said in an e-mail message forwarded to the committee staff by his chief of staff. Mary Heitman, a former finance director for the Republican Governors Association, will replace Mr. Bickhart.

title: After a Healthy Rout, Cleveland Exhales
description: BOSTON  For three anxious days, the greater Cleveland metropolitan area stressed about the soreness in LeBron Jamess right elbow and the tender state of the Cavaliers. There were daily reports about diagnostic tests that James may or may not have had, and some degree of bewilderment at a tied playoff series.

title: Russia: Motion to Ban American Adoptions Fails
description: Russias Parliament on Friday turned down a motion to halt all adoptions of Russian children by Americans, saying that it would not take action while the two countries were negotiating new adoption rules. Some members had called for the suspension in response to the case of a boy who was returned to Russia on his own by his adoptive American mother last month. Russian Foreign Ministry officials reacted to the case by saying that all adoptions by Americans would be stopped, but a senior Russian official said this week that they were continuing.

title: Russia: Sentence in Ship Hijacking
description: A Moscow court gave a five-year sentence on Friday to one of the men charged with hijacking a cargo ship off the coast of Sweden last summer, the court said in a statement, the first verdict in a rare case of European piracy. Andrei Lunev, 44, an Estonian citizen, pleaded guilty to charges that he and eight other men commandeered the ship, the Arctic Sea, along with its Russian crew and ferried it through heavily monitored European waters out into the Atlantic Ocean. The Russian Navy retook the ship and arrested the hijackers last August. The navys involvement in an operation to track down a ship that was officially only carrying cheap timber fueled rumors that the vessel was being used to smuggle illicit cargo. Russian investigators said they found only timber on board.

title: New Jersey Plan Calls for Bonuses for Effective Teachers and Schools
description: In an effort to compete again for federal education money that it recently failed to win, New Jersey unveiled an ambitious plan on Friday to award state-financed merit bonuses to teachers and schools based on the performance of their students.

title: China: Schedule for Rebuilding
description: Chinese officials say reconstruction work in the quake-ravaged Tibetan area of Yushu in Qinghai Province will be completed within three years, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported on Friday. The central government will provide the money for most of the rebuilding, while some will come from private donations, Hui Liangyu, a vice prime minister, said Thursday at a meeting of the State Council, Chinas cabinet, Xinhua reported. The government of Qinghai will oversee the reconstruction. At least 2,220 people were killed when an earthquake hit the area of Yushu in April. A pilot reconstruction program was scheduled to begin at two villages earlier this month.

title: Louganis Becomes Mentor
description: Greg Louganis, a four-time Olympic gold medalist, will make his debut as a mentor to up-and-coming Americans at this weekends USA Diving Grand Prix at the Fort Lauderdale Aquatic Center in Florida. His involvement comes nearly 22 years after he defended his gold medals in 3-meter springboard and 10-meter platform at the 1988 Seoul Games.

title: Jan van der Marck, Museum Administrator, Dies at 80

There would be a phone call before she got on, a text or two on the way in, and then a call when she arrived and walked across the street to my office. She is mature, quietly confident and careful, and had taken the trip with others many times before, so it seemed pretty straightforward.

description: Full disclosure: I love the heat; I like humidity. Its in my blood (Cuban) and my upbringing (in Miami). So it didnt take long for me to fall for hot power vinyasa yoga, a vigorous class taught in a room steamy enough to simulate the tropics in summer.

title: A Classic Outdoors
description: Speaking of hockey and soccer, the N.H.L. has something to learn from Fridays Germany-United States game in the opener of the world championship. The teams played before a world-record crowd of 77,803 at Veltins-Arena, the big soccer stadium in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.

title: Offering Help to a Troubled Colleague
description: Q. One of your co-workers has been acting strangely for a while, and youre beginning to suspect that something may be seriously wrong  perhaps problems at home, mental health issues or substance abuse. What kind of behavior could point to a problem like this?

title: Coyotes Deal in Chaos
description: The Phoenix Coyotes situation descended into chaos again Friday, as the arena lease deal between Jerry Reinsdorf and the city of Glendale, Ariz., reportedly fell apart. That forced Glendale to go back, hat in hand, to Ice Edge Holdings, the potential buyers the city rejected in favor of Reinsdorf last month.

title: Filling a Day With Everything Nice
description: Mark Pincus, 44, is the founder and chief executive of Zynga, the fast-growing San Francisco company known for online games like Mafia Wars and FarmVille, in which players run a virtual farm. Every day, some 45 million people play Zyngas games, which are popular on Facebook. His words have been edited and condensed. MALIA WOLLAN

title: Leading the Coastal Commission for 25 Years, a Crusader and Lightning Rod
description: Peter Douglas has survived Nazi Germany, throat cancer, accidentally setting himself on fire, and what he counts as 11 efforts to unseat him in his quarter-century as executive director of the California Coastal Commission.

title: Seeking the Fine Line of Where the Bay Ends
description: Typically in the Bay Area, a densely populated, transit-oriented development with schools, offices and grocery stores built near jobs and within walking distance of a mix of apartments and townhomes would be a big hit with environmentalists.

title: N.A.I.A. Team Forfeits Season
description: The Bellevue University baseball team has forfeited its entire 2010 season after one of its players was deemed ineligible. The Nebraska college, which was 35-7, announced that the team had violated an N.A.I.A. rule, prompting its decision to forfeit all 42 games. (AP)

title: New Setback in Attempt to Contain Gulf Oil Spill
description: ROBERT, La.  The latest effort to contain the oil spill that has poured millions of gallons of crude into the Gulf of Mexico encountered a setback 5,000 feet underwater, officials said Saturday, meaning oil will continue gushing into the ocean for at least several more days, and possibly months.

title: Problems Even Before a Ferryboats First Voyage
description: The Andrew J. Barberi first set sail across Upper New York Bay in August 1981 after a pomp-filled send-off from Staten Island by Mayor Edward I. Koch. Its engine promptly failed, the steering mechanism went dead, and the vessel ran aground near Governors Island.

title: Street Art Moves Onto Some New Streets
description: For a short while a few months ago, a mural by Eddie Colla enlivened an otherwise grubby stretch of wall in an alleyway in the upscale Hayes Valley neighborhood. The image, depicting two nearly naked and tattooed young women entwined in a sensual kiss, was a witty political message. The words Just Married, spray-painted in crimson above the couple, suggested the artists stance on gay marriage, while the six crushed beer cans dangling from strings attached to the womens thighs like postmodern wedding garters conveyed his offbeat sense of humor. But like many street works  broadly defined as the stencils, murals, posters, tags and stickers that appear, often illegally, in public spaces  Mr. Collas mural didnt last long.

title: Mothers Day at the White House
description: The White House is no stranger to generations of mothers, and this year, it even houses a grandmother.

title: Yanks Offense Erupts, and an Injury Flares Up
description: BOSTON  Even as afternoon faded to dusk Saturday and downpours gave way to puffy clouds and back to downpours again, two constants remained for the Yankees. One, they would forge ahead, tattered lineup and all, and impose their will upon the Boston Red Sox for a second straight day. Two, whatever wacky witchcraft is felling their players at a staggering pace would somehow claim another victim.

title: The $106.5 Million Anonymous Bid
description: Why spend a record-setting fortune on a painting and then keep your name out of the press? In this Sundays Week in Review, Roberta Smith explores the mystique of the mystery bidder:

title: Leader Board in Disarray, but Westwood Remains on Top
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  When the sun was going down Saturday, it looked as if Lee Westwood was sinking with it. With his golf ball atop a storm drain in the woods right of the 18th fairway  a seeming portent of the direction his luck and lead might be heading  Westwood came up with the kind of shot that reverses trends and wins big tournaments like the Players Championship.

title: New Union Leader Wants Group to Be More of a Political Powerhouse
description: WASHINGTON  As the eldest daughter among 10 siblings  and the third-eldest in all  Mary Kay Henry, the incoming president of the Service Employees International Union, says she was born to be an organizer.

title: States Move to Allow Overseas and Military Voters to Cast Ballots by Internet
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly three million overseas and military voters from at least 33 states will be permitted to cast ballots over the Internet in November using e-mail or fax, in part because of new regulations proposed last month by the federal agency that oversees voting.

title: For Priest, Intersection of Faith and Doubt
description: BOSTON  The questions were heartfelt, especially for women of faith, especially so late in life.

title: Johnson Is Expected to Be Out Several Weeks
description: BOSTON  When the Yankees signed Nick Johnson in December to be their designated hitter, they knew precisely what they were getting: an on-base machine with a lengthy injury history. Johnson has lived up to that reputation on both counts, and now he is expected to miss several weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed an inflamed tendon in his right wrist.

title: Bit of Disharmony in Alaska Over Adding to the State Song
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  It has been nearly a quarter-century since a former Alaska poet laureate composed a second verse for the Alaska state song, adding lines to celebrate the diverse indigenous people of the Last Frontier.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 9
description: A botched terror plot, Wall Streets wobbly week, and the Gulf Coast oil disaster headline the Sunday talk shows.

title: For BP, a History of Spills and Safety Lapses
description: After BPs Texas City, Tex., refinery blew up in 2005, killing 15 workers, the company vowed to address the safety shortfalls that caused the blast.

title: BP Is in the Spotlight for Now, but 3 Other Companies Could Share the Blame
description: As Congress prepares to hold hearings into the April 20 explosion that sank the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, a billion-dollar question is bobbing on the oil-slicked waves: Whose fault is it?

title: For Mothers Day: Organizations Making Motherhood Safer
description: Okay, youve handed over the flowers and taken your mother/wife/daughter/sister to brunch  and now youre thinking about doing something for motherhood generally. My Sunday column suggests some steps to make motherhood safer, and here are some organizations active in this space.

title: Utah Delegates Oust Three-Term G.O.P. Senator From Race
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Senator Robert F. Bennett, an 18-year veteran Republican who had been seeking a fourth term, was stripped of his partys nomination on Saturday at the state convention here, becoming one of the first Congressional victims of the surging discontent from the Tea Party-infused Republican right.

title: Peter ODonnell, the Creator of Modesty Blaise, Dies at 90
description: Peter ODonnell, the British writer who created Modesty Blaise, the sexy, resourceful action hero who was a distaff answer to James Bond, first as a comic strip character and later as the heroine of novels and short stories, died Monday in Brighton, on the south coast of England. He was 90.

title: Infant Found Dead in Manhattan Hotel Room
description: The medical examiner was investigating after a 2-month-old boy was found dead at a budget hotel on East 28th Street on Saturday afternoon.

title: Devra G. Kleiman, Biologist Who Helped Change Zoos, Is Dead at 67
description: Devra G. Kleiman, a conservation biologist who reintroduced into the wild the tiny endangered monkey known as the golden lion tamarin, and who learned so much about the lives of giant pandas that scientists could later help them reproduce in captivity, died on April 29 in Washington. She was 67 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Rhonda Copelon, Lawyer in Groundbreaking Rights Cases, Dies at 65
description: Rhonda Copelon, a human rights lawyer who played a major role in several groundbreaking cases, including one that allowed victims of abuses in other countries to seek justice in American courts, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

title: Muddy Road Molds Debate on the Future of Guyana
description: FIFTY EIGHT, Guyana  A battered, decades-old Bedford truck that would not look out of place in a Mad Max movie pulled off the road. Gold miners crawled out of its mud-splattered cab, sauntered into Peter Rajmenjans diner and asked if he had any bush hog for sale.

title: The Conrad Black Style of Doing Hard Time
description: In the somber environment of a prison, most inmates do time. Baron Black of Crossharbour, however, does book reviews. Perhaps former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich should take note.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Deportations Brief Adios and Prolonged Anguish
description: When Sheena Perez walked into the federal detention center in Broadview just after dawn Tuesday, she carried $200 in cash and a backpack filled with two T-shirts, two pairs of jeans and underwear, all freshly ironed. Slung over her right arm was her boyfriends favorite leather jacket; in her left hand was a bottle of 212 cologne.

title: The Pulse: Housing Authority to Open a Wait List for Units
description: The Chicago Housing Authority is preparing to open its family housing wait list for the first time in more than a decade. The city uses the list, which has been closed since 1999, to fill vacancies in its nearly 10,000 rental units designated for family housing, said Kellie O'Connell-Miller, a spokeswoman for the housing authority.

title: The Pulse: Caremark Triumphs With Lucrative Contract
Tough and Smart and Behind the Plate
description: Muddy Ruel talked like a lawyer and thought like a ballplayer, which isnt surprising given that he worked both jobs during his 67 years on Earth.

title: A Mothers Life
description: I first met Ethel Morgan Smith one year ago this weekend when she left an elegy of sorts in the comments section of a Motherlode post about Mothers Day and consumerism. Hers was a stunning tribute to a woman who had done what she could with a hard life, and even though it was tucked into the comments, readers found her words and sent thanks for them.

title: Winds Delay Travelers and Commuters
description: The New York area remained under a wind advisory early Sunday morning after a day of winds greater than 20 miles per hour caused inconvenience and frustration around the region, especially for travelers. The National Weather Service measured gusts of up to 38 m.p.h. in Central Park as a low-pressure system traveled toward the St. Lawrence River Valley.

title: Lottery Numbers
Population Study Finds Change in the Suburbs
description: As the first decade of the 21st century comes to a close, more black, Asian, Hispanic, foreign-born and poor people live in the suburbs of the nations largest metropolitan areas than in their primary cities.

title: The Man Behind the Coastal Commission and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Fighting for His Vision of Californias Coastline | Peter M. Douglas is strongly identified with the California Coastal Commission in part because he was a co-author of both the ballot initiative that created it and the 1976 law making the agency permanent. Over the years, commission actions have helped preserve much of Highway 1 as a two-lane road weaving through farmland, rocks and empty dunes. The question now is whether both Mr. Douglas, 67, and the 12-member commission can weather the states next budget and continue enforcing the 1976 Coastal Act. Mr. Douglas said he was deeply concerned that an item in Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers proposed budget could limit the agencys access to state legal services. The commission, based in San Francisco, is one of the nations most powerful  and litigious  land-use authorities.When Is a Bay Not a Bay? | A major development proposed in Redwood City is, depending on whom you ask, either on the shore of San Francisco Bay  or actually in the bay itself. Which one it is may not ultimately have any legal bearing on whether the project can be built. But the developer and the projects opponents are fighting over the question as if it will decide the matter.

title: Betty White on S.N.L.
description: Video | Facebook? How about good ol phone book? Golden Girl, 88, finally does Saturday Night Live. Opening monologue:

title: Vows: Avery & Matt
description: Avery Willis and Matt Hoffman met on a Brooklyn-bound F Train three years ago on Friday the 13th and went on an impromptu date. They soon discovered their markedly different backgrounds.

title: Tate Modern in London Celebrates a Decade
description: As the first public gallery in London to be devoted entirely to modern art, the Tate Modern  housed in a once derelict power station on the South Bank of the Thames that was transformed a decade ago by the architectural firm Herzog and de Meuron has become one of the most visited museums of modern and contemporary art in the world, with over 45 million visitors to date. The Modern (www.tate.org.uk) is celebrating its 10th anniversary this month, and a number of upcoming events are planned to celebrate the milestone.

title: Qatar Holding Buys Harrods Store
description: LONDON  Mohamed al-Fayed agreed Saturday to sell the London luxury department store Harrods to Qatar Holding, adding another well-known brand to the emirates investments.

title: Raiders, Rappers and JaMarcus Russell
description: An all-Raiders aggregation post, starting with a sneak peek at Straight Outta L.A., which ESPN will show as one of its 30 for 30 films next month.

title: Bring Your Questions on the European Debt Crisis
description: In light of the fiscal turmoil facing much of Europe, we have asked a panel of experts to answer your questions about the Greek debt crisis, contagion worries, the future of the euro zone, how Europes issues might affect the United States, and the effect of all this on the markets.

title: Betty White in the Mother of All Saturday Night Live Episodes
description: All it took to reinvigorate a 35-year-old comedy show was the presence of an 88-year-old woman.

title: Sweating the Details in Climate Discourse
description: The journal Science, which has long had an editorial stance pushing for action to cut emissions of greenhouse gases, published a piece of artwork last week that provided a nice bit of raw meat for foes of such steps.

title: E.U. Details $957 Billion Rescue Package
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders agreed on Monday to provide a huge rescue package of nearly $1 trillion in a sweeping effort to combat the debt crisis that has engulfed Europe and threatened markets around the world.

title: Twin Explosions at a Siberian Mine Kill 12 and Trap Scores
description: MOSCOW  Twin methane gas explosions killed 12 coal miners and trapped 80 underground in western Siberia under conditions so dangerous that officials called off all rescue operations for fear of sending additional men to their deaths.

title: Holder Backs a Miranda Limit for Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Sunday it would seek a law allowing investigators to interrogate terrorism suspects without informing them of their rights, as Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. flatly asserted that the defendant in the Times Square bombing attempt was trained by the Taliban in Pakistan.

title: The Early Word: Congrats, Grads
description: Its graduation season and the Obamas are making the rounds.

title: Aquino Son One to Watch in Philippine Elections
description: MANILA  Senator Benigno S. Aquino III, the only son of the Philippines two democracy icons, was favored to win in the presidential election on Monday, as he and his main rivals wrapped up their campaigns over the weekend amid worries of widespread violence, cheating and the reliability of a new automated voting system.

title: Webber Dominates Race, Schumacher Provides Show
description: BARCELONA  It was difficult to distinguish between what might be volcanic ash clouds or just light rain clouds over the Grand Prix circuit outside Barcelona during the Spanish Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: Apollo Walk of Fame: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
description: Hollywood has the famous one, and New York already has at least three. But on Monday, the city will get another walk of fame.

title: Minimizing the Risk of a Blowout
description: Just after midnight on March 15, 2001, a gas explosion ripped through the starboard aft of the P-36, a drilling platform anchored off the coast of Brazil.

title: Woods Withdraws From Players Championship
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Tiger Woods withdrew on the seventh hole of Sundays final round at the Players Championship with a neck injury. He was two-over par through his first six holes and two under for the tournament.

title: 'No Man's Land'
description: Time-lapse video of the installation of Christian Boltanski's work at the Park Avenue Armory. (Video courtesy of the Park Avenue Armory)

title: Borel to Ride Super Saver on Monday
description: The Kentucky Derby champion Super Saver is going to get a half-mile workout Monday at Churchill Downs with his regular rider Calvin Borel up. The colts trainer, Todd Pletcher, had taken a-wait-and-see-approach to whether Super Saver needed a timed workout before next weekends Preakness Stakes, the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: The Morning Line: All Borel, All the Time
description: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: U.S.-Brokered Mideast Shuttle Talks Begin Again
description: JERUSALEM  The Obama administration announced Sunday that indirect, American-brokered talks had resumed between Israel and the Palestinians, capping a year of efforts by Washington to revive the peace process.

title: Allies Join Russians in Victory Day Celebration
description: MOSCOW  As they always do, Russias finest infantrymen, sailors and airmen strode across Red Square on Sunday for the annual Victory Day parade, accompanied by a customary display of intimidating weaponry. Tanks rumbled by, planes zoomed overhead and missiles as long as subway cars were towed across the historic cobblestones.

title: Its 9:16 PM In Europe
description: And were still waiting for the rescue plan

title: Obama Asks Graduates to Close Education Gap
description: HAMPTON, Va.  For the first time as president, Barack Obama on Sunday delivered a commencement address to a historically black college, Hampton University, telling graduates that they have a separate responsibility to become mentors to other young African-Americans to help close a persistent gap in educational achievement.

title: Mitch Triples his Continent Count
description: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africahis first time ever outside of the country.

title: Robust Opening of Iron Man 2 and Summer Films
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood is hoping that a barrage of sequels, newly increased ticket prices and the 3-D boom will power its crucial summer season, which kicked off this weekend, to a record $5 billion in North American ticket sales.

title: The Hilbert Hotel
description: In late February I received an e-mail message from a reader named Kim Forbes. Her six-year-old son Ben had asked her a math question she couldnt answer, and she was hoping I could help:

title: Obama Says Education Means Emancipation
description: Addressing graduates at Hampton University, a historically black college, President Obama said the college's founders once stated that education means emancipation. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Who Wants a Contract in Hearts, South or East?
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  The Cavendish Invitational Pairs ended late Sunday afternoon with a victory for the defending champions, Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein. They finished 128 international match points ahead of the Norwegians Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, with Josef Piekarek and Alex Smirnov from Germany third.

title: New CDs
description: THE DEAD WEATHER

title: Found Objects and Other Percussive Items
description: Unpredictability is a quality that new music festivals prize, and the Look & Listen Festival has discovered an odd twist. Its mission is to present music of the 20th and 21st centuries alongside contemporary visual art. And on Saturday, at the second of its three concerts this year, that was partly what happened: So Percussion and Phyllis Chen, who plays the toy piano, performed new works at the Gary Snyder/Project Space, a gallery on West 26th Street, where they were surrounded by Beatrice Mandelmans Abstract Expressionist paintings.

title: Two Indie Bands, With Plenty of Three-Part Harmonies
description: A few strains of contemporary indie-rock orthodoxy converged at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night. Local Natives, from Los Angeles, and Suckers, from Brooklyn, were passing through town together, not quite three weeks into their seven-week tour.

title: The Man Who Broke Babes Record
description: Im not sure what this says about America, or about publishing or baseball or sports writers, but it has taken 36 years for a proper full-dress biography of Henry Aaron, the man who, in 1974, broke Babe Ruths home run record, and did so as a black man playing for Major League Baseballs first franchise in the Deep South. His is a great American life, and Howard Bryants Last Hero: A Life of Henry Aaron rises confidently to meet it.

title: Exploring Mortality With Clothes and a Claw
description: At first sight, the monumental artwork being installed at the Park Avenue Armory suggests nothing so much as a crane claw, the frustrating arcade game in which a player tries to pull a stuffed animal from a pile of many, and to hold on to it, with a grapple controlled by a joystick.

title: Some Air Pollution
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Have a seat. Anywhere. Today, you have plenty of choices; one in every long answer word.

title: A Womans Flights of Fantasy and Fear
description: SEATTLE  For 27 years as its general director, Speight Jenkins has done very well by the Seattle Opera. But amid his many accomplishments, which include an extensive renovation of the companys house, there was one glaring omission: Mr. Jenkins had never presented the premiere of a commissioned opera.

title: On the Ferry, Gifts and Some Apprehension
description: It was almost like any other Sunday aboard the Staten Island Ferry.

title: Those Old Gut Busters, War and Prejudice
description: Ah, togetherness! As the reassuring title of Tom Lehrers contemplation of nuclear annihilation puts it, We Will All Go Together When We Go. That jolly singalong, written in 1958, anticipated by more than a decade Randy Newmans Political Science, whose narrator, a cranky misanthrope fed up with the rest of the worlds ingratitude for American beneficence, grouses: They all hate us anyhow/So lets drop the big one now.

title: A Bleak Story With a New Conductor as Its Caretaker
description: Among the many issues that James Levines health problems have raised at the Metropolitan Opera, his withdrawal from the companys latest revival of Lulu, Bergs bleak final opera, was probably not the most urgent. But Lulu is one of the pieces in the Met repertory most closely associated with Mr. Levine; before Saturday, he had conducted all but three presentations of the companys efficient, intelligent John Dexter staging since its introduction in 1977.

title: Interactivity, Inside and Out, Creates Informal Feeling
description: Not so very long ago, when contemporary composers had to hustle and scratch for places to present their work, art galleries provided a crucial outlet. Even now that modern music is welcome in concert halls and nightclubs alike, galleries can still be particularly congenial spaces  a point made by the Look & Listen Festival, which opened at the Chelsea Art Museum on Friday night.

title: When the Drive for Power and Money Led to a Slaughter on the Sea
description: Whale lovers be warned: you will want to watch Into the Deep: America, Whaling & the World, even though theres an awful lot in it that you wont want to see.

title: Giants Rally to End Mets Home Winning Streak
description: With the flags atop the upper deck at Citi Field pointing rigidly back at him, Jason Bay hit a ball into the teeth of an fierce wind. Instead of going over the fence in left field as Bay had hoped, the ball wilted against the blustery assault and dropped in front of left fielder Andres Torres for a bloop single.

title: The Agenda Behind Electronic Health Records
description: In the nations drive to computerize patient records, Jonathan Bush surely qualifies as the most disgruntled beneficiary of the governments largess  billions of dollars in incentives to accelerate adoption by doctors and hospitals.

title: Youth Give Fresh Look to Robbins
description: There is a purified, elevated simplicity to Jerome Robbinss 2 & 3 Part Inventions, a paring away of extraneous detail that its tempting to regard as the wisdom of a master; after all, Robbins made the piece late in life, just four years before his death in 1998.

title: Two Scandinavian Acts, Layering Electropop With Sharp Falsetto
description: In 1984, a fledgling band from Norway, A-ha, released a perky electropop single with a startling chorus: Take On Me. Morten Harkets voice keeps jumping upward in that chorus until it has spanned over two-and-a-half octaves to arrive at a piercing falsetto. That leap into falsetto is a change from earthly to ethereal, from masculine to androgynous. And it has echoed through Scandinavian pop.

title: More Met Opera in HD
description: The Metropolitan Opera has announced another summer of opera at the movies. The Summer HD Encores program will present screenings of popular operas from the Mets most recent Live in HD series, which transmits live performances from the Met to movie theaters across the United States. From June 16 through July 28, six operas will be shown in more than 400 movie theaters across the country. This seasons presentations will include Aida, with Violeta Urmana, Dolora Zajick and Johan Botha (June 16); Romo et Juliette, starring Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna (June 23); Eugene Onegin, featuring Rene Fleming and Dmitri Hvorostovsky, above, (July 7); La Bohme, starring Angela Gheorghiu and Ramn Vargas (July 14); Turandot, with Maria Guleghina and Marcello Giordani (July 21); and Carmen, starring Elina Garanca and Roberto Alagna (July 28). The Met Opera began screening live performances of operas in 2006. The events will take place on Wednesday evenings at 6:30 in each time zone. Theaters and ticket information: metopera.org/hdlive.

title: The Sound of Julie Andrews, Onstage in London
description: Julie Andrews, right, sang with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra at Londons O2 Arena on Saturday night in what was her first vocal performance in 13 years and her first stage appearance in Britain in more than 30 years, BBC News reported. The 74-year-old Ms. Andrews  whose voice was damaged in 1997 by surgery to remove throat polyps  mostly spoke during the performance, singing occasionally when accompanied by other vocalists and, in one case, the enthusiastic audience. She opened with Getting to Know You, from The King and I, and faded into the background as five other singers took over. That song began a tribute to Rodgers and Hammerstein, throughout which Ms. Andrews told stories about her work on stage and screen while video clips of her performances were shown above the stage. Though it was obvious that Ms. Andrews would not be hitting the high notes that helped define her career, she reassured her fans that she could still sing the hell out of Ol Man River. The audience, in turn, cheered for her rendition of My Funny Valentine, her one solo of the evening, and participated in a boisterous Do-Re-Mi singalong. During the second half of the show, Ms. Andrews narrated Simeons Gift, a childrens book she wrote with her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton, while the supporting cast played the books characters. And a finale of classics from South Pacific and The Sound of Music drew the last of the nights many standing ovations.

title: Massachusetts Theaters Announce Seasons
description: Two theaters in Massachusetts are bringing premieres by award-winning playwrights to their seasons. The Huntington Theater Company in Boston has announced that its next season will include a debut from Stephen Karam (Speech and Debate), as well as productions of plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage and a New York Drama Critics Circle honoree, Annie Baker. Ms. Bakers Circle Mirror Transformation begins Oct. 15 and Ms. Nottages Ruined opens Jan. 7. Sons of the Prophet, Mr. Karams new comedy, opens March 25, with direction from Huntingtons artistic director, Peter DuBois. ... American Repertory Theater, in Cambridge, will present the premiere of a new rock musical by the Tony and Grammy award-winning playwright Steven Sater (Spring Awakening), as well as Sophocles Ajax, to be directed by the Soho Reps artistic director, Sarah Benson, in its coming season. Charles Connaghans new translation of Ajax, the story of a warrior recovering from a bout of madness, will have its premiere in February. Prometheus Bound, based on the Greek tragedy by Aeschylus, will open in March in a production with text and lyrics from Mr. Sater and music by Serj Tankian, from the band System of a Down. It will be directed by Diane Paulus, who led Hair on Broadway and is the artistic director of American Repertory Theater.

title: Footnote
description: The actor Terrence Howard (Hustle & Flow, Crash), above, has been cast as Nelson Mandela in Winnie, a film based on the story of the South African leaders former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Jennifer Hudson, above, has already been cast to play the title role, with Darrell Roodt directing the $15 million production set to begin filming May 31 in Cape Town.

title: John Guare to Judge New Drama Award
description: The playwright John Guare has been named the judge of the Yale Drama Series playwriting award for the next three years, according to the David C. Horn Foundation, which sponsors the competition. The award is given annually for an original, full-length play written in English that has not been published or produced. It comes with a prize of $10,000, publication of the manuscript by the Yale University Press and a staged reading at Yale Repertory Theater. Mr. Guare will choose the winners for the years 2011, 2012 and 2013. Past judges have included Edward Albee, for the series first two prizes in 2007 and 2008, and David Hare, who chose the 2009 award as well as this years winner, Virginia Grise, for her play blu.

title: Betty White Helps Boost Ratings of SNL
description: All it took to reinvigorate a 35-year-old comedy show was the presence of an 88-year-old woman. On Saturday, after more than 70 years in show business, six Emmy Awards and one improbable Facebook campaign, Betty White, left, got her shot at hosting Saturday Night Live. With her, the show had its highest ratings in a year and a half, according to preliminary Nielsen figures provided by NBC. Despite Ms. Whites opening monologue, which made distinctions between her generation and that of the SNL fans who pushed for her to host, she seemed at home on the show. She appeared in every sketch, playing, among others, an inadvertently naughty muffin mogul and a loopy census interviewee. The Mothers Day-themed episode, which brought back the past cast members Molly Shannon, Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Rachel Dratch and Ana Gasteyer, was also a rare occasion on which the mostly male SNL cast took a back seat to its women: Ms. Shannon and Ms. Gasteyer appeared in their NPR parody, Delicious Dish; Ms. Rudolph made a return appearance as Whitney Houston; and Ms. Poehler was temporarily reseated at the Weekend Update desk. The musical guest was Jay-Z. Support for Ms. White, who became host of the show after a Facebook campaign, was evident on Twitter, where she was a trending topic on Sunday and had praise from fans including the teenage singer Justin Bieber, who tweeted after the broadcast, BETTY WHITE RULES.

title: Does the Climate Bill Have a Chance?
description: The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has revived interest in long-stalled Congressional legislation aimed at addressing climate change and American dependence on fossil fuels.

title: Chelsea (Emphatically) Wins Premier League
description: Chelsea is the best team in England, and anyone who disputes that need only look at the scoresheet from its final victory  an 8-0 thrashing of visiting Wigan on Sunday. Chelseas Premier League crown was its third in six years.

title: Fatal Fighting Pits Villagers and Taliban in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four men from a village militia set up by American troops in western Afghanistan were killed on Saturday, and they may have been beheaded by Taliban militants, an Afghan Army officer said on Sunday. Ten Taliban militants were killed in retaliation, he said.

title: Sampler: Budget Cuts, Part XXIV, and Jumping Frog Turf War
description: Bracing for More Budget Cuts | Get ready to hear more bad news from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Friday about the states finances. He is scheduled to release an updated budget plan, which is likely to include even deeper cuts to state services than those proposed in January, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. Governor Schwarzenegger included $6.9 billion in federal aid in his January budget, but so far, the state has received less than $3 billion. The states controller, John Chiang, reported last Friday that the state collected $3.6 billion less in tax revenue in April than had been projected. Despite a budget deficit that could run over $20 billion, both Republicans and Democrats in the Legislature have pledged not to seek new taxes this year.[The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Neck Injury Knocks Out Dudamel for a Night

Mr. Dudamel finished the concerto on Thursday but was replaced for the rest of the program by the associate conductor Lionel Bringuier. Deborah Borda, the president of the Philharmonic, told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Dudamel had heard a loud pop and lost sensation in parts of his body; a medical consultation later showed that he had pulled a muscle in his neck area. After going home to rest Mr. Dudamel returned to conduct the same program on Friday. On Monday, he was scheduled to begin a national tour with the Philharmonic in San Francisco.

Other performers in the lineup include Brooks & Dunn, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Amy Grant, LeAnn Rimes, Miranda Lambert and Martina McBride. Tickets will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. Central time at ticketmaster.com and will range in price from $25 to $75. Proceeds from the event are to go to the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee, a nonprofit group that provides philanthropic services.
