St. Peters is renowned for its jazz ministry.

title: After S.E.C. Suit Warning, Traders Flee Moodys Shares
description: Shares of Moodys fell sharply on Monday after it disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had warned that it might sue the firm for making false and misleading statements as part of its application as a ratings organization.

title: Cherry Jones and Doug Hughes Reunite at Roundabout
description: The actress Cherry Jones and director Doug Hughes, who both won Tony Awards in 2005 for the Broadway production of Doubt, will reunite for the first time this fall for Roundabout Theater Companys revival of Shaws Mrs. Warrens Profession, the theater announced on Tuesday.

title: What to Do When a Newborn Cant Hear
description: The 8-year-old boy already had hearing aids when I met him, back in the 1990s. He had been born before newborns were routinely screened for hearing problems, so the diagnosis had not taken place until he was a slow-to-talk toddler.

title: Payment Offers to Egg Donors Prompt Scrutiny
description: As an undergraduate at the University of Washington in the late 1990s, Wendie Wilson noticed some striking ads in the campus newspaper: appeals to young women to sell their eggs for what seemed to her exorbitant sums of money. But she had no idea what was involved until she herself decided to go through the process a few years later.

title: Fences Breaks Box Office Record
description: Fresh off earning the most Tony Award nominations ever for a play revival, the new Broadway production of August Wilsons Fences broke the box office record last week at the Cort Theater, earning $1,008,104 for eight performances and becoming the rare play to join the million-dollar club of Broadway commercial hits.

title: Manhattan Federal Court, 11:23 A.M.
description: Six days after his arrest, Faisal Shahzad has yet to be taken to a courtroom and charged before a judge in the failed Times Square car bombing. So the reporters and photographers camped outside the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan had to content themselves with a lone marshal.

title: Win a Piece of a Convicted Ponzi Schemers Spoils
description: If you have a yearning for high-powered sports cars  say, a 2008 Bugatti Veyron (right) or a Ferrari F430 Spyder  consider booking a ticket to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for early June.

title: Never Able to Forget a Chronic Disease
description: I hate blood drives. But I didnt always. As recently as last year, I was excited to learn that my office was holding one, in partnership with the Red Cross. Donors went around the office wearing little white stickers declaring they had given the gift of life. The gift of life! Thats much better than a gift of canned food, or old clothes. I definitely wanted to be a Life Giver.

title: A Fed President for a Bank Tax
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis  Narayana R. Kocherlakota  came out in favor of a bank tax today:

title: Back in Magazines, With Stars
description: When Magnus Greaves founded Doubledown Media, which published magazines like Trader Monthly, in 2004, the intersection of Wall Street and luxury advertising seemed like a cant-miss proposition. Then they both simultaneously imploded, and Doubledown closed last year. But Mr. Greaves decided he was not yet done with the magazine game.

title: The Temptation (and Danger) of Past Investment Performance
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: Photo Mix-up With Obama Is Called Hoax
description: Obama touts wind energy in Iowa, a headline read on The Washington Posts Web site in late April. But if a readers screen grab is to be believed, the headline ran with a photo not of the president but of Malcolm X. And in an age when any mistake is possible grist for a public flogging, this was a catchy gotcha.

title: Sharp Turn for Miley Cyrus
description: When Miley Cyrus, 17, released her new music video last week, chatter about her attire (fetish gear), suggestive dance moves (writhing on her back) and setting (inside a black bird cage) spread like wildfire.

title: Pictures of the Day: Siberia and Elsewhere
description: Rescuers found the bodies on Monday morning of 17 of their colleagues who were killed while trying to reach trapped coal miners in western Siberia, bringing the death toll in the disaster to 30, with 60 still missing, Ellen Barry reports from Moscow. Officials had suspended rescue operations for nearly a day after two explosions sealed the miners in caverns filling with water and smoke, saying they could not try to save the men until methane gas had dropped to safe levels. The agonizing wait marred Russias celebration of Victory Day (For Russians, an Old Victory Lives On, on Lens), which brought millions of Russians onto the streets for lavish parades and fireworks displays.

title: Off the Menu: Le Pain Quotidien in Central Park
description: When Le Pain Quotidien won the contract to operate the Mineral Springs Pavilion near the Sheep Meadow in Central Park  which it plans to open on Saturday  there were complaints that it was a chain. But while the company of sandwiches, soups, snacks and sweets, based in Brussels, has more 140 locations worldwide, its not the average chain. The owner, Alain Coumont, has followed a vision of making his places green and using organic ingredients as much as possible. (Here is the menu.)

title: Dustin Kellers Hot Dog Tour in Manhattan
description: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down.

title: Bank Agrees to Forfeit $500 Million to U.S.
description: The Justice Department said Monday that the Dutch bank ABN Amro, which is now part of the Royal Bank of Scotland, had agreed to forfeit $500 million for helping move illegal funds through the American financial system, The Associated Press reports.

title: City Selects 50 Senior Centers to Close
description: In Manhattan, the number is 16.

title: A New Look for Google Mobile
description: You may have noticed a change in Google online, the addition of a column on the left side that lets you narrow your results to just images, videos, blogs, shopping and other categories. That change has come to Google mobile as well, although it is concealed.

title: Second Thoughts?
description: Yes, I know  the point is not to lift the euro. Still, the exchange rate is a quick measure of the impact on eurozone confidence, which bounced with the policy announcement but doesnt seem to be staying up

title: Vande Velde Crashes Out of Giro dItalia
description: Christian Vande Velde of the Garmin-Transitions team broke his right collarbone in a crash during Stage 3 of the Giro dItalia on Monday, making it two years in a row that he has dropped out of the race with a serious injury. Both times, he injured himself on the third day of competition.

title: A Phrase for Safety After 9/11 Goes Global
description: The Times Square street vendors who alerted the police to a smoking Nissan Pathfinder on May 1 seemed to be acting on a combination of their streetwise instincts, their sense of civic duty, their military training and the advice of Allen Kay.

title: Short? No Worries: Just Ask This Texan
description: People of normal height or taller might be inclined to assume, as that silly Randy Newman song put it, that Short people got no reason to live.... Short people got nobody to love.

title: Boldness Comes With Manifesto
description: For proof that abstract painting can be as controversial as any other kind, look no further than Amy Sillmans latest show at Sikkema Jenkins. Art blogs and other online forums are filled with both praise and jeers for Ms. Sillman, and while admirers outnumber detractors, the collective intensity is worth noting.

title: Tall Tales About Being Short
description: In Tuesdays Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about life as a short person, and the many wrong assumptions made about people of below-average height.

title: A New Twist on Pretzels
description: Around here, it seems like every day is National Pretzel Day. New Yorkers used to have two basic choices: a pigeon-worthy pedestrian softy from a Sabrett-umbrellaed cart or City Bakerys haute pretzel croissant. Some housemade strays turned up here and there  one in the breadbasket at Commerce, another at Kurt Gutenbrunners Blaue Gans and, naturally, the expected Biergarten regulation.A few months ago, though, there was an explosion of artisanal twists and braids.Now, the salty risers tempt at every turn and are being incorporated into both sweet and savory culinary compositions.

title: A Pianist Fills in, Saving the Day
description: The Peoples Symphony Concerts series was to have closed its season on Sunday afternoon with a recital at Town Hall by Ingrid Fliter, the Argentine pianist who won the Gilmore Artist Award in 2006. But when Ms. Fliter, down with the flu, bowed out of the engagement on Saturday evening, the Irving S. Gilmore International Keyboard Festival in Kalamazoo, Mich., offered a substitute: Kirill Gerstein, this years winner of the $300,000 quadrennial prize, who was in Kalamazoo to perform at the festival, and planned to fly to Europe on Sunday. With a slight juggling of his travel plans, Mr. Gerstein, a naturalized American who was born in Russia, performed instead of Ms. Fliter.

title: 'Memphis'
description: Chad Kimball and cast members sing "Memphis Lives in Me." (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Should Egg Donors Be Paid?
description: Demand for human ova has been growing in recent years, fueled by infertility treatments and increased investment in stem cell research, reports David Tuller in Tuesdays Science Times.

title: Correction
description: The cover article on May 2 about Cartagena, Colombia, referred incorrectly to the writer Gabriel Garca Mrquez, whose fiction has been inspired by the city. As is customary in Latin America and in Spain, where a person carries both the paternal surname and maternal maiden name, the writer is Mr. Garca Mrquez, not Mr. Mrquez.

title: U.S. World Cup Roster to Be Announced Tuesday
description: Tuesday, 10:22 a.m. ET |Capello Drafts Carragher

title: Following Up on a Babys Hearing Test
description: In Tuesdays 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, reports on the problem of babies who get screened for hearing problems without proper follow-up.

title: New Spending for a Wider Range of Sex Education
description: In a sharp departure from the abstinence-only message of the Bush years, the new health law pours hundreds of millions of dollars into sex education programs that aim to provide teenagers with comprehensive information about protecting themselves from pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Embracing Stravinskys Wild Side
description: Stravinskys Rite of Spring, almost a century old, clearly has a tale to tell. It is suggested in the title. It is made explicit in the original dance scenario of 1913, which details a series of pagan rituals surrounding a human sacrifice. And it is borne out in the eruptive nature of the music, with hushed passages of exotic colorations and expectant mystery repeatedly cast aside by brutal, pounding rhythms or savage, brassy whoops.

title: Europes Debt Crisis: Your Questions Answered
description: 7:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Yank! Announces a Change in Direction
description: The director David Cromer (Our Town, When the Rain Stops Falling) has been enlisted to lead next seasons expected Broadway production of Yank!, a musical about two American servicemen who fall in love during World War II, the producers said on Monday. Mr. Cromer will replace Igor Goldin, who has been with Yank! since its inception at the New York Musical Theater Festival in 2005 and who directed the Off Broadway production of the show this winter. But as theater directors go Mr. Cromer comes with star power, which will probably help the producers raise the $5 million they estimate as the cost of mounting the musical on Broadway. A spokesman for Yank! did not immediately respond to an inquiry about why Mr. Goldin was being replaced.

title: Kristin Chenoweth Has Some Words for Newsweek
description: Not that we have any beef with Kristin Chenoweth, left, to begin with, but wed think long and hard about picking a war of words with her after this. On Friday Ms. Chenoweth, the Tony Award-winner and star of Promises, Promises, posted a lengthy online rebuttal to a Newsweek article that she called horrendously homophobic for contending that gay actors could not play straight characters and citing her Promises, Promises co-star Sean Hayes as an example. In the original Newsweek article, published online in April, Ramin Setoodeh, a Newsweek contributor, wrote: While its OK for straight actors to play gay (as Jake Gyllenhaal and Heath Ledger did in Brokeback Mountain), its rare for someone to pull off the trick in reverse. Of Mr. Hayess performance in Promises, Promises, Mr. Setoodeh wrote: Frankly, its weird seeing Hayes play straight. He comes off as wooden and insincere, like hes trying to hide something, which of course he is. In her response, published on Newsweek.com, Ms. Chenoweth wrote: This article offends me because I am a human being, a woman and a Christian. For example, there was a time when Jewish actors had to change their names because anti-Semites thought no Jew could convincingly play Gentile. She added: Audiences arent giving a darn about who a person is sleeping with or his personal life. Give me a break! Were actors first, whether were playing prostitutes, baseball players, or the Lion King. About her co-star, Ms. Chenoweth said, Id put Hayes and his brilliance up there with some of the greatest actors period.

title: CBS Tops Sunday
description: Jesse Stone: No Remorse, the sixth in a long-running series of made-for-television movies on CBS, delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as the two-hour Tom Selleck movie attracted 11.4 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. CBS led the night over all in the ratings, garnering 10.9 million viewers at 7 p.m. for 60 Minutes and 10.6 million at 8 for the season finale of The Amazing Race. ABC finished in second with the combination of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (7.6 million), Desperate Housewives at 9 (11.2 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (8.3 million). NBC was third with Dateline (3.6 million) and Minute to Win It (5.1 million), followed by a two-hour installment of The Celebrity Apprentice (7.3 million), while Fox ranked fourth with its comedy lineup. Over the weekend, NBCs episode of Saturday Night Live, featuring the actress Betty White as host, attracted the sketch comedy shows most viewers in a year and a half, according to preliminary ratings estimates.

title: Tony-Winning Tandem Take on Mrs. Warren
description: The actress Cherry Jones and the director Doug Hughes, who both won Tony Awards in 2005 for the Broadway production of Doubt, will reunite this fall for the first time for the Roundabout Theater Companys revival of Shaws Mrs. Warrens Profession, the theater said. Ms. Jones, right, will star as Mrs. Kitty Warren, a mother who turns to the worlds oldest profession to pull herself out of poverty and support her daughter Vivie, whose reactions to her mothers choices lead to many Shavian flourishes. It will be Ms. Joness first role on Broadway since the play Faith Healer, which closed in August 2006. No other casting was announced on Monday, but Mr. Hughes was named director. The production is scheduled to begin preview performances on Sept. 3 at the American Airlines Theater. In addition, the Roundabout said that the Academy Award-winning actress Olympia Dukakis (Moonstruck) would star in Tennessee Williamss play The Milk Train Doesnt Stop Here Anymore, to be directed by Michael Wilson (The Orphans Home Cycle). Previews are scheduled to begin Off Broadway in January at the Roundabouts Laura Pels Theater.

title: The Science of a Happy Marriage
description: Why do some men and women cheat on their partners while others resist the temptation?

title: Walters to Undergo Heart-Valve Surgery
description: Barbara Walters surprised her audience on The View on Monday morning by saying she would undergo surgery later this week to replace what she called a faulty heart valve. Ms. Walters, who is 80, said she had always enjoyed excellent health but had been aware of this condition for some time and decided that the summer would be a good time to recuperate. The office of her personal publicist, Cindi Berger, later said that Ms. Walters would make no further comment about the condition and would give no interviews about it  even to her longtime employer, ABC News.

title: Benefit Concert Planned For Nashville
description: Taylor Swift, Carrie Underwood and Miley Cyrus are among the country stars who Tim McGraw and Faith Hill have announced will perform at a benefit concert planned for June to aid victims of the recent flooding in the Nashville area. On Monday, Mr. McGraw and Ms. Hill said in a news release that they would host the event, called Nashville Rising: A Benefit Concert for Flood Recovery, on June 22 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Other performers in the lineup include Brooks & Dunn, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Amy Grant, LeAnn Rimes, Miranda Lambert and Martina McBride. Tickets will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. Central time at ticketmaster.com and will range in price from $25 to $75. Proceeds from the event are to go to the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee, a nonprofit group that provides philanthropic services.

title: At Cannes, Controversy Makes Early Entrance
description: The Cannes Film Festival wont officially open until Wednesday, but the annual competition is already contending with a government boycott and  more manageable  the late entry of a new film. Sandro Bondi, the Italian culture minister, said he would not attend the festival because it is showing a film on the 2009 earthquake in LAquila that he considers propaganda, Agence France-Presse reported. In the film, Draquila: Italy Trembles, which is being shown out of competition, the satirist Sabina Guzzanti impersonates Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, and criticizes the governments takeover of reconstruction projects in LAquila. Declining an invitation to Cannes, Mr. Bondi expressed regret and his concern over the film, which he said insults the truth and the Italian people. Meanwhile, The Guardian reported that Route Irish, a new film by Ken Loach, had been added to the competitions lineup. Mr. Loach, whose movie is about two rival ex-soldiers who become private contractors in Iraq, won the Palme dOr in 2006 for his film The Wind That Shakes the Barley.

title: Britain Leaves Its Monetary Policy Unchanged Amid Political Uncertainty
description: LONDON  The Bank of England decided Monday to hold steady on monetary policy after last weeks election failed to give any party a governing majority and the recent turmoil in European markets remained a fresh memory.

title: Brittney, Brittny and Brittneigh on Whats in a Name
description: I have a major gripe with the trend of misspelling baby names. On purpose, wrote Paul Schmidtberger in this weeks Complaint Box.

title: Warm and Fuzzy Department | Tending the Fashion Flock
description: With cheap cashmere so ubiquitous even dogs are wearing it, whither the lowly sheep? Ranchers of the gentle creatures, whether for milk or for meat, can hardly give their wool away after their seasonal shearings. Wool is literally now considered a waste product in much of Britain. Perhaps what the hearty fiber needs is a pedigree, some T.L.C., a bit of pizazz and maybe a supermodel.

title: A Storyteller Back at Her Craft
description: Three years ago the country-folk singer-songwriter Mary Chapin Carpenter was lying on an emergency room gurney, terrified by a sharp pain in her chest that was so bad that she had cut short a tour to return home to her farm near Charlottesville, Va.

title: Mapping Ancient Civilization, in a Matter of Days
description: For a quarter of a century, two archaeologists and their team slogged through wild tropical vegetation to investigate and map the remains of one of the largest Maya cities, in Central America. Slow, sweaty hacking with machetes seemed to be the only way to discover the breadth of an ancient urban landscape now hidden beneath a dense forest canopy.

title: Tehran Students Protest Ahmadinejad Visit
description: As my colleague Nazila Fathi explains, a surprise visit to the campus of Shahid Beheshti University in Tehran on Monday by Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, reportedly set off a protest by students. Jaras, an opposition Web site, posted a report with what it said was a slide show of photographs from the campus.

title: Where Was the Mayor? On the Phone
description: Where was Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg when the ferry hit the dock?

title: Casting News for In the Heights and Race
description: Productions of the Tony Award-winning musical In the Heights are getting new stars. The Broadway production will add Jordin Sparks, the 2007 winner of the American Idol television competition, in the role of Nina Rosario from Aug. 19 through Nov. 14. And Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator and original star of the Broadway production, will reprise his performance as Usnavi in the Los Angeles premiere of the musical at the Pantages Theater, scheduled to run from June 22 to July 11.

title: Producing a Grandchild Before Grandma Dies
description: The dialogue in Ben Androns play Whites Lies, which opened on Thursday at New World Stages, is peppered with mentions of familiar titles like Cheers, Mr. Belvedere, Alf, Punky Brewster, Growing Pains and Newhart, suggesting a frame of reference rooted entirely in sitcom.

title: Envisioning the Stark Expo
description: Aaron McBride, the art director for "Iron Man 2" at Industrial Light & Magic, discusses the designs behind the Stark Expo that appears in the film.

title: Life and Death and Life in Iraq
description: This is a soldiers story, a tale of life and of death and of lifes return.

title: Tracing the Scourge of AIDS in Deadly and Banal Ways
description: In one of many epistolary interludes in Letters to the End of the World, the protagonist describes holding death in his arms in the form of an H.I.V.-infected Zambian infants ravaged body. The vivid horror of that image lingers even if the reams of talk surrounding it in Anton Dudleys mannered play are considerably less evocative.

title: Scientists Unite Against Climate Skeptics
description: Tuesday, May 11, 11:15 a.m. | Updated  The latest issue of Science carries a letter that calls recent political attacks on the work of climate scientists McCarthy-like threats of criminal prosecution.

title: For Crime, Is Anatomy Destiny?
description: Poverty, greed, anger, jealousy, pride, revenge. These are the usual suspects when it comes to discussing the causes of crime. In recent years, however, economists have started to investigate a different explanation for criminal activity: physical attributes.

title: Focus Turns to Well-Blocking System
description: HOUSTON  At 53 feet tall and 325 tons, the blowout preventer that occupies center stage in the worst American oil spill in two decades is a huge stack of equipment. But it is also a jumble of contradictions.

title: The Sexual Revolution Dissected
description: This remarkably tedious new novel by Martin Amis is a sort of messy improvisation on Boccaccios 14th-century collection of tales known as The Decameron, which concerned a group of young people spending an interlude together in an Italian villa and explored the varieties and disappointments of love. Jane Smiley tried something similar in her tiresome 2007 novel, Ten Days in the Hills, and in The Pregnant Widow, Mr. Amis makes many of the same mistakes she did  most notably, assuming that readers will be interested in a bunch of spoiled, self-absorbed twits, who natter on endlessly about their desires and resentments and body parts.

title: Absent a Moon or Mars, Recreating Space 65 Feet Under the Sea
description: Astronauts will not be sent by the United States to the Moon or Mars for at least a decade, but they can still get an idea of what it would be like by living 65 feet underwater.

title: Union and City Extend Deal on Teacher Assistants
description: The citys teachers union and the Education Department have extended their deal to permit the use of classroom aides whose salaries are paid by parent groups.

title: A Diphtheria Cure, 1894
description: Until the late 19th century, diphtheria was a gruesome killer with no known cause and many ineffective treatments. In 1874, The New-York Times printed an advertisement for a medicine that would cure not only diphtheria, but also corns, bunions and pains in the loins and back. The same year, a news article began, There has been spreading for some time an idea or hypothesis among the more philosophic medical men, and among the thoughtful laity, that many species of disease have their sources in, and are scattered by, seeds or germs.

title: Kagan Constructs, for Now
description: When President Obama officially named Elena Kagan, the solicitor general, as his choice for a Supreme Court vacancy earlier on Monday, many of the themes that opponents and supporters will draw out in the coming weeks had already become palpable and were amply researched during the weeks that shed been a frontrunner to replace Justice John Paul Stevens.

title: China: A New Market Economy and Old Stigmas Lead to an Increase in Cases of Syphilis
description: Syphilis, which was nearly eliminated from China under Maoist rule, is now the most commonly reported communicable disease in the countrys largest city, Shanghai, according to an article in The New England Journal of Medicine last week.

title: Gum Ads That Seek Longer-Lasting Chewers
description: IN a memorable scene in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, the 1971 film, Gene Wilder, who plays an eccentric confectioner, displays a piece of gum that changes flavor while being chewed, replicating a three-course meal by tasting first like tomato soup, then roast beef, then blueberry pie.

title: In Boston, Balanchine Without the Frills
description: BOSTON  This season, after many years of performing at the Wang Center here, the Boston Ballet moved to the Opera House. The Wang, which seats 3,600 people, has always been a barn too large for most dance programs. The Opera House  which, seating 2,600, is still larger than almost any European opera house  has been through a checkered history since it opened as a vaudeville theater in 1928; last year it reopened after being dark for more than 10 years.

title: Just Like Other Dads (Well, Almost)
description: Vibrators, leather bars and good old-fashioned sodomy have never looked more wholesome than they do in The Kid, the easygoing, sentimental new musical about a gay couple trying to adopt a baby. The homosexual partners at the center of this surprisingly unsurprising production, which opened Monday night on Theater Row, feel like truly ordinary people, folks youve met many times before in depictions of American spouses in pursuit of parenthood.

title: In Dvoraks Folk Works, Elegance, Too
description: Dvorak is the latest composer to seize the collective attention of the Emerson String Quartet, that brightest of stars in the American chamber music firmament. Old World  New World, the newest in the ensembles long string of distinguished recordings for Deutsche Grammophon, focuses on that Bohemian composers late string quartets, along with his American String Quintet and Cypresses, a quaint, charming early cycle. Most of these pieces are included in the groups latest Lincoln Center residency, which opened on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Icahn and Lions Gate Duel Over Shareholders
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn and Lions Gate Entertainment skirmished once again on Monday before a special shareholders meeting that may or may not be moot.

title: Pairings: White Sangria and Red Sangria
description: Cavas, often blessed with notes of citrus and spring blossoms, are genial sparkling wines, all the more so because of their modest prices. They can be called on for many occasions, and are the ideal finishing touch for sangria, either red or white. The white sangria is unusual and strong, though white wine in place of manzanilla sherry will moderate the alcohol. The red is clearly classic. Both are more refreshing than sweet.

title: Cava, the Prosecco of Spain, Gets Its Due  at Last
description: YEARS ago I was a regular cava drinker. I couldnt help it; cava was the cheapest sparkling wine around. Our graduate-student parties and celebrations seemed incomplete without numerous bottles of Freixenet Cordon Negro Brut scattered about the room, reflections of dancing candlelight absorbed by the black matte finish of the bottles.

title: Company With Osteoporosis Treatment Wins the Super Bowl
description: The McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas, Austin, held its Global Moot Corp business plan competition over the weekend. Billing itself as the Super Bowl of business plan competitions, Moot Corp invites top teams from previous, qualifying competitions to compete for a grand prize of $25,000 cash and $70,000 of in-kind services. It began in 1984 and was the first competition of its kind.

title: Art in the Rubble
description: Images of art works damaged during the earthquake in Haiti.

title: Rescuing Art From the Rubble of the Quake
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Susan Blakney, a paintings conservator from New York, scrambled up a mound of rubble left by the collapse of the Episcopal Holy Trinity Cathedral here, searching for small shards of the cathedrals murals.

title: Judge Denies Polanski Request to Unseal Testimony
description: LOS ANGELESRoman Polanskis legal options narrowed, as a judge here denied his request to unseal testimony about a sentencing plan in his 33-year-old sex case. Lawyers for Mr. Polanski had hoped to use the testimony, by a retired prosecutor, Roger Gunson, to fight his extradition by authorities in Switzerland. Mr. Gunsons conditional testimony was taken earlier this year, so that it could be used if he were not available to testify in a sentencing hearing, should Mr. Polanski be returned to the United States. In denying the request, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Peter Espinoza said of the Swiss: Im satisfied that they have information that they need. Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978, on the eve of his sentencing for having unlawful sex with a 13-year-old girl. His lawyers have argued that Judge Laurence J. Rittenband, who is now deceased, improperly used Mr. Polanskis psychiatric evaluation in a California prison as his punishment, and that Mr. Gunsons testimony, if provided to the Swiss, would show that Mr. Polanski does not qualify for extradition under a treaty between Switzerland and the United States.

title: Twitter Software Bug Exploits Users Follower Count
description: If you have ever wanted Oprah Winfrey to follow you on Twitter, you might have been able to make that possible early Monday morning, when a software bug surfaced on Twitters Web site.

title: Stephen Rosenfeld, Retired Columnist, Dies at 77
description: Stephen S. Rosenfeld, a retired columnist and editorial page editor of The Washington Post who wrote for many years on foreign affairs, died on Sunday in Springfield, Va. He was 77 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Toreador Works With Hess to Explore Paris Basin
description: Toreador Resources of France and the Hess Corporation said on Monday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to explore and develop Toreadors 1 million gross acres in Frances Paris Basin, a potentially big resource of shale oil.

title: BofA Merrill Hires 2 Clean Tech Bankers
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Monday that it had hired two executives from Deutsche Bank for its clean technology investment banking team.

title: Tigers Salute Ernie Harwell
description: DETROIT  Comerica Park fell silent before the game as the Tigers paid tribute to their beloved broadcaster, Ernie Harwell, who called Detroit games for 42 years and died last Tuesday at 92.

title: Bob Mercer, Executive Who Signed the Sex Pistols, Dies at 65
description: Bob Mercer, a music executive who signed the Sex Pistols, helped Jimmy Buffett set up his own record company and oversaw the popular compilation series Now Thats What I Call Music!, died on May 5 in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 65.

title: New York Legislature Approves 1-Day Furloughs
description: ALBANY  The Legislature approved an emergency budget bill on Monday that would authorize Gov. David A. Paterson to furlough about 100,000 state employees, roughly half the states work force, without pay for one day.

title: Specter Ad Will Feature Obama
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama is about to be thrust firmly behind Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the Republican-turned Democrat who is facing a very tough challenge for the Democratic nomination here in a primary next Tuesday. Mr. Specter announced tonight that he will begin airing an advertisement tomorrow that features a testimonial from the president.

title: What Were Reading: Android vs. Apple
description: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times thought these articles merited a wider audience:

title: Injured Woods May Miss U.S. Open
description: Tiger Woods insisted Monday that there was no connection between the neck injury that prompted him to withdraw from the Players Championship on Sunday and the injuries he sustained in the car accident in November that unraveled his image. He also called his schedule up in the air and said he did not know if he would be able to play in the United States Open in June.

title: A Vista of War and Peace at a Lebanese Crossroads
description: WAZZANI, Lebanon  The rocky green hills on the outskirts of this southern town form one of the most volatile borders in the world. Tensions have been particularly high ever since Israel accused Hezbollah of obtaining Scud missiles from Syria last month, and many Lebanese say they believe it will not be long before war breaks out here again.

title: Virginia Coach Says Playing Will Help
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. title: Israel: 2 Israeli Arab Activists Arrested
description: Two Israeli Arab activists have been arrested and charged with spying and making contact with Hezbollah of Lebanon. The men, Ameer Makhoul, 52, director of a charity, and Omar Said, 50, active in the political party Balad, were detained over the past couple of weeks but the military censor forbade reporting on the arrests until Monday. Lawyers for the men said that Israeli espionage laws were overly broad and that e-mail messages and telephone conversations with anyone in Lebanon were seen as cause for arrest.

title: Turkey: Opposition Leader Resigns
description: Deniz Baykal, the longstanding leader of the main opposition party, resigned Monday after an Internet video appeared to show him in a bedroom with a female lawmaker from his party. Mr. Baykal, 71, left, leader of the secular Republican Peoples Party, neither denied nor acknowledged having an affair but called the distribution of the video a conspiracy. He said the recording had been obtained illegally by an intrusion on private property, and was distributed with the consent of the governing Justice and Development Party. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan denied any involvement with the video, saying it was not anything we would either accept or tolerate.

title: China: Murder Victim Turns Up Alive, and a Prisoner Becomes a Free Man

The two men, from a village in Henan Province, had had a fight, the authorities later found a headless body in a village well, and Zhao Zuohai confessed to the killing. He had served 10 years in prison when the victim, Zhao Zhenshang, resurfaced last week. Zhao Zhenshang said he had gone into hiding because he thought he had killed Zhao Zuohai. It remained a mystery why Zhao Zuohai confessed, and whose body was found in the well.

Other artists expected to perform include Allen Toussaint, Mos Def, Ani DiFranco, the Voice of the Wetlands Allstars (including Tab Benoit, Dr. John and Cyril Neville) and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. title: On the Bench? Vetting Supreme Court Nominee Elena Kagan
description: Overview | Who is Elena Kagan? What questions surround her nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court? In this lesson, students reflect on the qualities and role of a Supreme Court justice. They then consider the issues surrounding Ms. Kagans nomination and determine whether they believe she should be appointed to the bench after learning about her experience, background and stances. They then develop a game plan for supporting or opposing the nomination. and even create one component of the plan.

title: A Peek at Vanity Fairs iPad App
description: Magazines are actually pretty brilliant concepts the way they are, said Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter on Tuesday as he previewed his magazines new iPad app. At the same time, we have a few bells and whistles that a magazine cannot provide.

title: Gensler Lays Out Timeline for Wild Wall St. Trading
description: Mark Wilson/Getty Images From left, Mary L. Schapiro, the S.E.C. chairwoman; Robert W. Cook, director of S.E.C.s division of trading and markets, and Gary Gensler, the C.F.T.C. chairman, testified about the markets plunge on Thursday during a House hearing.

title: Will Gulf Fish Get a Break?
description: In 2005 conservation groups filed suit against the Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council, which regulates fishing in the gulf, over its stewardship of the red snapper, a favorite catch of commercial and recreational fishermen. The suit alleged that despite ample evidence of enormous declines in stocks of red snapper, the council had failed to institute catch limits and other protections required under federal law.

title: More Americans Are Paying for Television
description: Tired of costly cable bills, many Americans have talked about cutting the cord and relying on the Internets patchwork of streaming television and movie services. Decoder admits its a tantalizing proposition. But a new report reminds us that more people than ever are forking over monthly payments for TV.

title: Now Booking | East London Duo
description: The East End of London has been the focus of contemporary fashion, design and music in the the city for the last decade. But suitable places to stay have been slow in coming. The Hoxton Hotel arrived in 2006, and Terence Conrans 17-room Boundary opened its doors last year. Now two new arrivals are vying for the attention of design-savvy travelers.

title: Cushing Made His Choice; Voters Have an Easy One
description: Taking away Brian Cushings award is a no-brainer. He forfeited the right to remain defensive rookie of 2009 in the N.F.L. as soon as the bells and whistles went off in the laboratory.

title: Insomniac City
description: I moved to New York a year ago and felt at once at home. In the haggard buildings and bloodshot skies, in trains that never stopped running, like my racing mind at night, I recognized my insomniac self. If New York were a patient, it would be diagnosed with agrypnia excitata, a rare genetic condition characterized by insomnia, nervous energy, constant twitching, and dream enactment. An apt description of a city that never sleeps, a place where one comes to reinvent himself.

title: Off the Menu, Bay Area Edition: Corey Lees New Restaurant
description: Corey Lee, who was the chef de cuisine at Thomas Kellers French Laundry until August, when he resigned to open his own restaurant in San Francisco, is now on track to do just that. In late July he plans to open Benu. The name means phoenix, or rebirth, in ancient Egyptian.

title: Cartel Papers Show Bribes to Mexican Authorities
description: MEXICO CITY  Internal documents from one of Mexicos largest and most profitable drug trafficking cartels help explain why the groups leader remains at large, nearly a decade after he boldly escaped from a maximum-security prison by hiding in a laundry cart.

title: Looking for a Hole in Tax-Cutting Laws Armor
description: In San Francisco, since the passage of Proposition 13, the property tax burden has shifted from commercial to residential property owners. In 1975, commercial property owners paid 59 percent of property taxes. Today, they pay 43 percent, according to Phil Ting, San Franciscos assessor-recorder.Thats true even, though San Franciscos population has remained relatively flat, and the city has seen a downtown building boom.

title: Video of Prime Minister David Camerons First Remarks
description: The new British prime minister, David Cameron, made these remarks on Tuesday evening in London after he arrived at 10 Downing Street, his new residence (from Britains Channel 4 News):

title: Google-AdMob Deal Gets Extended Federal Review
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google may have gotten some help from its rival Apple in its attempt to acquire the mobile advertising start-up AdMob.

title: Off the Menu: Go Burger, BLT Burgers Successor
description: After splitting with the chef Laurent Tourondel, Jimmy Haber, who now owns the BLT Restaurant Group with a new partner, has shed the BLT name for a new series of restaurants patterned after the BLT Burgers in New York, Hong Kong and Las Vegas. The company held an online contest in April for a new name, offering $4,000 to the winner. Go Burger is the winner. It is also the name of the companys burger truck.

title: A Road Trip to the End of the Road
description: Sterlin Harjos spare, cosmically solemn film Barking Water follows the road trip across Oklahoma made by an American Indian man and the woman he loved and left, who has come back at the end of his life to help him die. Their destination: Wewoka, capital of the Seminole nation. As the story begins, Frankie (Richard Ray Whitman), who is in the final stages of cancer, is wheeled from a hospital bed to a battered station wagon driven by his best friend and former lover, Irene (Casey Camp-Horinek).

title: Disneys Movie Studio: the Mouse That Roared
description: The Walt Disney Companys movie studio roared back to life in the most recent quarter, with operating income increasing to $223 million from $13 million in the year-ago period. The only problem: executives who have since been fired were largely to thank.

title: A Modern Touch to a Rural Cottage
description: The Schooltinks added a modern extension to their historically-registered cottage in the Netherlands.

title: Pictures of the Day: Siberia and Elsewhere
description: As the mining city of Mezhdurechensk began to bury its dead on Tuesday, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin flew to the site of the disaster in western Siberia, vowing to discover whether human error or lax safety standards had contributed to one of the most lethal mine disasters here since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: Newspaper Industrys International Trade Group Cancels Its Annual Conference
description: PARIS  For the troubled newspaper business, another disappointment.

title: The Bling Factor | American Woman at the Met
description: The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museums Costume Institute, American Woman: Fashioning a National Identity, examines the evolution of style in this country and the appreciation of the breeze-easy female. Replacingthe cosseted womanwith a spirited American paradigm trumpeted more than the exchange of a corset for a shift dress, however. It sparked an upheaval in social etiquette: Women of independent means began buying their own jewelry. Fashion may have rattled the cage for change, yet it was gems and precious metals that broke the chains of Europe.

title: Recycling With a Vengeance
description: Melena Ryzik reports from "Glassphemy," an interactive installation in Brooklyn that turns recycling into an experiment in therapy.

title: Spun by Hoaxes
description: Video | Yo-yo faker who reportedly fooled Midwest TV stations

title: Manhattan Theater Club Announces 2010-2011 Productions
description: The Pitmen Painters, the hit British play about a group of miners who find a creative outlet that doesnt involve ballet dancing or stripping off their clothes to music, will open the new season at Manhattan Theater Club in September. The play by Lee Hall (the screenwriter of Billy Elliot and a Tony Award-winner for its musical adaptation) will begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sept. 14 and open on Sept. 30, the theater company said on Tuesday. As its producer Bob Boyett said in January, the play will transfer with its London cast as well as its director, Max Roberts.

title: Bill Clinton Woos Donors on Wifes Debt
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential race is long over, but her debt lives on.

title: Einstein Looks Back, With Help From Puppets
description: The best thing I can say about Breath on the Mirror, now playing at La MaMa E.T.C., is that the shows puppets are more expressive than its people. The worst part, as you may have guessed, is that the people have set the bar pretty low.

title: CNN Pundit Draws Ire From All Sides
description: MACON, Ga.  In his seven weeks as one of CNNs newest contributors, Erick Erickson has made scarcely more than a dozen appearances on the network.

title: New Palin Book Set for November
description: Sarah Palin has chosen a title for her upcoming second book, her publisher announced on Tuesday: America By Heart: Reflections on Family, Faith and Flag.

title: Does Poetry Matter?
description: Sometimes the planets align and you start seeing the same idea discussed by different people everywhere you look, as if your brain had stumbled late at night across a niche cable station broadcast by the universe itself. For me lately the show has been all about the relevance of poetry, as in: Is poetry relevant? Even among poets there seems to be a nervous consensus that its not.

title: Starz to Produce Spartacus Prequel
description: While the actor who plays the title character in the Starz drama Spartacus: Blood and Sand undergoes cancer treatments, the channel will produce a six-episode prequel to the series.

title: Table Hopping | Ralphs in Paris
description: Lets just say I saw it coming. When the waitress at the furiously fashionable Ralphs, the restaurant at the new Ralph Lauren boutique in Saint-Germain-des-Prs, threaded her way through the tight maze of brown leather armchairs in the snug, beamed dining room  complete with hunt-themed oil paintings and a gas fire  and placed a small bowl of deep-fried olives on the table, my friend Marie-Odile, achtelaine in town for the day from Bordeaux, rolled her eyes. Deep-fried olives! she said. Only you Americans would think of doing such a thing. You deep-fry everything, dont you?

title: Iraqi Deal to End De-Baathification
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi politicians have reached an agreement to halt a four-month campaign to bar candidates from politics for ties to the Baath Party, American and Iraqi officials said, papering over the sectarian tensions it unleashed, at least for now, and removing an obstacle in the long-delayed process of forming a new government.

title: Classic Childrens Stories, With a Little Gender Bending Thrown In
description: Its always nice to see a show thats kid- and gay-friendly  why should audiences have to choose between bedtime stories and Lady Gaga, especially in Brooklyn, a borough that in recent years has had the dubious distinction of offering happy hours for moms?

title: Kagans Video on White House Blog
description: White Houses usually keep their Supreme Court nominees under wraps, shunning all interviews. With Elena Kagan, the Obama White House made an exception.

title: An Austrian Vacation Home
description: A seven-bedroom vacation home with a bell tower in the Salzkammergut region of Austria is on the market for 2.25 million euros ($2.85 million).

title: A Software Fix for iPad Troubles
description: A software update to solve wireless network connectivity issues with some iPads will be forthcoming from Apple, but the company has not offered a time frame for the fix.

title: House Hunting in ... Austria
description: A SEVEN-BEDROOM VACATION HOME WITH A BELL TOWER IN THE SALZKAMMERGUT REGION

title: Operation Mincemeat
description: Chapter 1: The Sardine Spotter

title: Floating a Wild Plan and a Dead Man to Defeat the Nazis
description: Excellent westerns have been composed by people who could barely ride a horse, and the best writers of sex scenes are often novelists you wouldnt wish to see naked. But when it comes to spy fiction, life and art tend to collide fully: nearly all of the genres greatest practitioners worked in intelligence before signing their first book contract.

title: Properties for $300,000
description: Properties in San Antonio, in Asheville, N.C., and Chicago.

title: What You Get for ... $300,000
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Doubt Is Cast on Many Reports of Food Allergies
description: Many who think they have food allergies actually do not.

title: In the Netherlands, When Modern Meets Fairy Tale
description: BAAK, the Netherlands  Melissa Schooltink-Hubers and Leon Schooltinks cottage here in the rural Gelderland province, about a 20-mile drive from the city of Arnhem, sits in the middle of a fairy tale scene.

title: Letters: Mind Over Meds
description: We agree with Daniel Carlat (April 25) that psychotherapy has an important place in the comprehensive treatment of individuals with psychiatric disorders. The divide between brain-based and mind-based training of young psychiatrists, however, is not always as wide as Carlat contends, even in research-focused departments like ours at Mass General.

title: Just Looking | Edward Kienholzs Roxys
description: When people say the art world is full of pimps and whores (which they do a bit less frequently now that hard times have struck), theyre usually referring to the slick dealers and artists who prostitute their talents for money. But theres a whorehouse in Chelsea right now, and it doesnt involve the well-oiled machinery of artistic success  the cavernous, pristine spaces of galleries where the staffs sublime indifference suggests a substantial waiting list for the works on display.

title: She Doesnt Put Her Feet Up, but a Proper Woman Makes Herself at Home
description: Nancy Wilson, now 73, made her way slowly to the stage at the Blue Note on Monday, with the help of an assistant. She had a broken ankle, she explained; she sat on a chair to sing, and looked a little drained.

title: In Japan, the Children Are Buying Bugs
description: While American children are buying Japanese action figures, Japanese children are buying bugs. Thats one lesson to be drawn from Jessica Orecks documentary Beetle Queen Conquers Tokyo, a guided tour of a national predilection that introduces us to insect stores, insect fairs, insect video games, insect vending machines and insect viewing areas.

title: Poster Boy Sentenced to 11 Months in Prison for Vandalism
description: The street artist known as Poster Boy, who cuts up and rearranges subway posters, often to witty effect, wont be riding the subway anytime soon. Hes at Rikers Island, sentenced to 11 months for vandalism, the blog animalnewyork reported.

title: Many Voices on the Road to Damascus
description: It must have been a rare alignment of the planets that produced a performance of Mendelssohns oratorio Paulus on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the Boston Symphony Orchestra had performed its better-known sibling, Elijah, just five weeks before. Kent Tritle conducted the venerable Oratorio Society of New York, which had not performed the work since 1947, to close its 137th season.

title: Tavern Talks Resume
description: Can Tavern on the Green be resurrected in our lifetime? Tuesday, for the second day, the designated new operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, Dean J. Poll, conducted negotiations with the Hotel and Motel Trades Council, which represents some 400 employees who have been looking for work since the restaurant shuttered early on Jan. 1.

title: Facebook Executive Answers Reader Questions
description: Last week we asked readers to submit questions about Facebook and its approach to privacy, which Elliot Schrage, vice president for public policy at the company, had agreed to answer.

title: A Composer Arguing With Plato
description: The composer Louis Andriessens pugnacious and exhilarating piece De Staat has a reputation as a milestone of avant-garde music in the later decades of the 20th century. Yet you hear about the work, composed in 1976, more than you actually hear it. For whatever reasons, it does not turn up often in concert.

title: Black Men in America as Stressed-Out Strivers
description: Run, black man, run, Daniel Beaty says fiercely. Run to your children  hold them tight.

title: New Help to Free Legs From a Web
description: LEG-BARING weather inspires come-out-of-hibernation rituals. The fake tan. The depilation of winter hair. The springtime jog, when even layabouts acknowledge that the season of calf definition is nigh.

title: Dystopia Animated
description: The distinctive voices of Vincent Gallo and Juliette Lewis emerge from the lead characters in Metropia but provide no comfort: Tarik Salehs dystopian vision of a depleted, smog-engulfed, financially collapsed Europe in the year 2024 seems a touch too close to home. In any case, the real star here is the films eerily unsettling animation, a digitally manipulated photomontage that makes everyone look almost human  in a heavily medicated, genetically suspect kind of way.

title: Strangers Find Solace From Riots Against U.S.
description: In the distinctive world of the Japanese playwright Toshiki Okada, actors do not perform a scene so much as circle it warily, introducing their roles, narrating and commenting on them, comparing notes on what happened before finally settling into a yarn.

title: Hell Find Something Thats Wrong With You
description: What if life itself were a pre-existing condition?

title: Obama and Cameron: Vacation Dreams
description: President Obama made a call of congratulations on Tuesday to newly minted British Prime Minister David Cameron, saying that he reiterated my deep and personal commitment to the special relationship between our two countries, a bond that has endured for generations and across party lines.

title: Finding Meaning in Cleaning
description: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle is like Clerks reimagined by William S. Burroughs. Looking as if it were devised on acid and executed on mushrooms, this imaginative debut feature from the Seattle artist and filmmaker David Russo finds meaning in cleaning and life in dead ends.

title: New Credit and Debt Tools From Jean Chatzky
description: Having trouble figuring out how exactly to improve your credit score or best pay off your debt? The personal finance author and television personality Jean Chatzky introduced two new tools Tuesday to perform those functions.

title: A Smashing Idea: Eco-Friendly Aggression
description: How do you one-up a Dumpster pool?

title: British Election Tweet of the Day
description: In the end, a British election campaign that included many twists and turns concluded as so many have before, with a defeated prime minister walking out of 10 Downing Street to resign and a newly-minted one walking in through the same famous front door.

title: Britains Coalition of Pain
description: London

title: Environmental Action
description: If shopping for an examination of the science of climate change, or of the political and economic debates surrounding it, be warned: the title of this documentary is misleading. It concerns environmental action, yes, but only tangentially refers to the effects of global warming. Instead, the director, Brian Hill, has traveled the planet to assemble portraits of citizens who are thinking globally and acting locally.

title: 4 Big Banks Score Perfect 61-Day Run
description: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a perfect game of baseball  27 up, 27 down, the final score measured in millions of dollars a day.

title: Drug Cases Are Scrutinized After Crime Lab Shortcuts
description: The apparent shortcuts taken by a New York Police Department criminalist in testing suspected drug samples left prosecutors throughout the city scrambling on Tuesday to find out how many cases might be affected and what to do about them.

title: Artist Struts Her Stuff in Others Shoes
description: With Walk the Walk, a piece being staged during office hours in Bryant Park through Friday, the artist Kate Gilmore expands beyond the solo act that has characterized her performance work so far. In this it represents a big, courageous move, but that doesnt keep it from feeling transitional and not quite up to her usual level.

title: Dean Baker on the Housing Bubble
description: Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington, D.C., on the Federal Reserve's response to the collapse of the housing market in 2007.

title: What Were Reading: The Future
description: The tech editors and reporters at the New York Times found these articles worth passing on to others:

title: Ladies Loved
description: The British romantic comedy My Last Five Girlfriends, loosely based on the novel On Love by Alain de Botton, is all concept and very little comedy, beyond the occasional chuckle. Julian Kemp, the writer and director, tries to deflect attention from a thin script with a constant stream of storytelling devices: fake commercials, Barbie-doll dioramas, old movie clips, a talking stuffed elephant. Recurring scenes show the sad-sack hero, Duncan (Brendan Patricks), at a theme park based on his life, where the rides are named after his former lovers.

title: Splashing Through Comedy
description: What is it about men and synchronized swimming that so reliably brings the funny? Many Saturday Night Live fans have never forgotten the 1984 sketch with Harry Shearer and Martin Short as brothers pursuing a dream of Olympic gold. (It was going to take some time, they conceded, especially since, the Short character noted, I dont swim.)

title: Lawsuit Against Cuban Calls Mavericks Insolvent
description: Mark Cubans financial management of the Dallas Mavericks was described as reckless in a lawsuit filed Monday in Texas by a minority investor in the team who accused the flamboyant billionaire owner of amassing net losses of $273 million and debt of more than $200 million, The New York Timess Richard Sandomir reports.

title: Off-Kilter and British
description: THEY buried Malcolm McLaren in a suit, a new one. At least, thats what hed asked for. Mr. McLaren, who died last month at 64, spearheaded punk music and style in London in the 1970s by cutting the Sex Pistols, jaggedly, more or less from whole cloth and by operating, with Vivienne Westwood, the boutique Sex, which offered the lifestyle to go  when the store could be bothered to open, anyway.

title: Glee Co-Creator Seeks Boycott of Newsweek After Article Criticizes Gay Actors
description: 3:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Burger Blends That Taste Like Steak
description: For a burger blend like the ones that fussy chefs use, Dicksons Farmstand Meats in Chelsea Market grinds a mix of short ribs and other cuts from Wrighteous Organics in Schoharie, N.Y. Dry aged, with about 20 percent fat, it makes for a burger with the flavor of a good steak and less shrinkage than other ground beef. For major grilling, Jake Dickson, above, sells it in what he calls a weekend burger pack. Another weekend package comes with Dicksons own sausages and bacon, as well as the ground beef. And a barbecue package has several smoked cuts, ready for a quick reheating. All come in an insulated bag.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Dining Calendar
description: Beer and Cheese

title: Canteen 82
description: 467 Columbus Avenue (82nd Street), Upper West Side; (212) 595-4300.

title: Rick Bayless, the Chicago Chef, to Prepare a State Dinner
description: FOR the Obama administrations second state dinner, the White House has once again turned the cooking over to a guest chef. Rick Bayless has been asked to prepare the elegantly balanced, many layered Mexican food for which he has become famous at the dinner on May 19 that will honor President Felipe Caldern of Mexico.

title: French-Press Coffee to Go
description: Its unusual enough that the rough-hewn African coffee bar BKoffie freshly grinds beans only from Rwanda, Tanzania, Kenya and Ethiopia, and a house blend, and brews them to order. The real surprise comes when you get coffee to go, in a disposable French press cup with a sippable plunger lid. There are also African teas, including rooibos; fair trade chocolates; and condiments like chutneys, peri peri and a nicely funky fish spread from Cape Town called Pecks Anchovette. BKoffie is the third outpost on West 51st Street from Tanya Hira, who, with her partners, opened the South African wine bar Xai Xai and Braai, a restaurant specializing in exotic meats like ostrich on the grill.

title: A New Chocolate Sorbet to Savor
description: The latest addition to the menu at Dessert Club ChikaLicious is a silky, deeply intense yet refreshing chocolate sorbet, made with a new 80 percent cacao Coeur de Guanaja chocolate from Valrhona. It is a worthwhile indulgence plain, but to paint this lily with an ever-so-delicate hand, it is also served as a sandwich, between two snowy almond macaron shells, which add texture to the confection.

title: Pairing a DVD and a Drink Takes Care
description: I COULD blame Don Draper, but if it was anyones fault, it was Robert Mitchums.

title: Benefits
description: Helping Rwanda

title: The Rise of Company Gardens
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.

title: The White House Pastry Chef Revamps Sweets
description: Washington

title: 21st-Century Mamie Eisenhower Cheesecake
description: Adapted from The Perfect Finish by Bill Yosses and Melissa Clark (W. W. Norton, 2010)

title: Betel
description: 51 Grove Street (Bleecker Street), Greenwich Village; (212) 352-0460.

title: Seminal Jasper Johns Painting Draws $28.6 Million Bid
description: One of Jasper Johnss seminal Flag paintings, from 1960-1966, that had belonged to Michael Crichton, the best-selling writer, became the star of Christies post-war and contemporary art auction on Tuesday night when it brought $28.6 million. That figure was a record for the artist at auction, though the painting did not manage to beat the record for a work by a living artist, as many had speculated it might. (That record is held by Lucian Freuds painting Benefits Supervisor, which sold for $33.6 million at Christies in New York two years ago.)

title: Employees Only Bottles Its Cocktail Mixers
description: The folks at Employees Only have been working to improve your cocktail hour, at home and at the restaurant. The nonalcoholic syrups that Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas, the mixologists, are making for some cocktails are now sold retail. Theres a suitably tart lime cordial, a mix of lime juice, kaffir lime leaf and agave nectar for gimlets and lime rickeys. Their grenadine, used in a drink called the Billionaire, is dark and intense.

title: Needing Offense, Mets Again Place Call to Buffalo
description: When Chris Carter entered the Mets clubhouse Tuesday, he became the third left-handed-hitting Buffalo Bison to be promoted to the major league roster this season.

title: Flyers Counting on Backup Goalie
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Michael Leighton said he thought he was 7 or 8 when he was called up to his older brothers hockey team in Petrolia, Ontario, and was asked to play goaltender. He recalled that his team lost his first game, 8-0, but he told his parents how much he loved the position. So he stuck with it.

title: Fatty Cue
description: FATTY CUE, Zakary Pelaccios funky new barbecue joint on South Sixth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, looks like a biker bar for the kind of bikers who dont ride Harleys in leathers and boots, but stripped-down Schwinns in boat shoes and skinny jeans.

title: Will Increased Viewership Reach Beyond the Triple Crown?
description: Patrick Patten, author of the blog Handride, is part of a group called the Thoroughbred Bloggers Alliance.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

The Door to Private School
description: To the Editor:
