title: Critical Cannes Film Angers Italian Official
description: ROME  Movie stars, politicians and sundry glitterati mugged for the red-carpet cameras on Wednesday at the start of the Cannes Film Festival. But Sandro Bondi, the Italian culture minister, was not among them.

title: Cavendish Showdown Stays Close to the End
description: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Henderson, Nev., had a very close finish on Sunday.

title: Silvermans Schlep on Comedy Central Ends
description: Unlike some of her Comedy Central brethren, Sarah Silverman never made an episode of her show that elicited ominous messages from shadowy groups. Her only sin was producing a series that grew too expensive for that cable channel to produce. (O.K., and possibly showing a man deriving illicit pleasure from a toy train. And casting Ed Asner as a Nazi officer.) But those days are no more: Comedy Central said on Wednesday that it was not picking up The Sarah Silverman Program for a fourth season, confirming a report in The Hollywood Reporter. The series was barely renewed for its third season after Comedy Central sought to lower its budget, and Ms. Silverman, right, and her fellow producers said they would walk away from the show if they did. Ultimately a deal was struck in which Logo, the gay-theme cable channel, helped pick up some of the production costs. When many of those episodes were broadcast earlier this year they were shown by Comedy Central in a midnight time slot. Representatives for Ms. Silverman did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

title: Pompidou Center Opens Branch in Metz
description: The Pompidou Center in Paris  home to Frances National Museum of Modern Art  opened the doors on Wednesday to its first provincial branch, in Metz, a small city 170 miles east of Paris. The new museum, above, which cost $89 million, according to the Pompidou Center, is part of an effort to expand the display of government-owned art beyond Pariss large museums. With no permanent collection, Pompidou-Metz will depend on loans from the mother house and other institutions. Its first show, Chefs-dOeuvre?, is meant to trace the meaning of masterpieces from the Middle Ages through much of the 20th century. The museums building, designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban and his French associate Jean de Gastines, has a curving and asymmetrical pagoda-like roof topped by a spire and punctured by upper galleries that stick out like airport pods.

title: Two Ways to Find Yourself
description: Two Ways

title: Quebec Family Dies as Home Vanishes Into Crater
description: OTTAWA  Richard Prfontaine and his wife, Lynne Charbonneau, were watching a playoff hockey game with their two daughters on Monday night when the ground beneath their house gave way suddenly and without warning.

title: Moms Love Godsmack?
description: Big holidays often give sales bumps to certain albums, and Mothers Day is no different, often helping performers like Michael Bubl or Neil Diamond reach No. 1. By that logic, though, the album on the top of the new Billboard album chart is a bit of a head scratcher: The Oracle (Universal Republic), by the long-running, heavily tattooed metal band Godsmack. It sold 117,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and is the bands third album to open at No. 1. But mothers  or those who shop for them  may have helped a number of other acts reach high on the chart. The Christian soft-rock group MercyMe opened at No. 3 with The Generous Mr. Lovewell (INO), which had 88,000 sales; Live at the Troubadour (Hear Music), by Carole King and James Taylor, bowed at No. 4 with 78,000; and sales of Mr. Bubls Crazy Love (143/Reprise) nearly doubled from the week before, to 29,000, lifting it seven spots to No. 15. Also on this weeks album chart, the pop-country band Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 97,000 sales, and Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island) falls one spot to No. 5 with 64,000. Last weeks top seller, The Adventures of Bobby Ray (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic) by the 21-year-old rapper B.o.B., dropped to No. 12, giving it the dubious distinction of being the first No. 1 this year to fall straight out of the Top 10 the following week.

title: Landmark Designation Is Upheld for Church
description: The New York City Council on Wednesday upheld the landmark designation of West Park Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street, rewarding preservationists for their 20-year effort to save the Romanesque Revival building. The ruling disappointed the church leadership, which wanted to develop part of the site, a plan that involved tearing down part of the building. Forced landmarking has the effect of imposing the governmental idea of mission on the congregation, the churchs pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert L. Brashear, said in an interview on Wednesday. There is a profound church-state issue here. Religious liberty has not been well served by this decision. Dr. Brashear estimated that it would cost $11 million to $12 million to restore the church, which has been closed about two years because of physical deterioration. The congregation, which has dwindled over the years, has been meeting at the nearby Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew. The 116-year-old West Park Church was designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in January. Gale A. Brewer, a city councilwoman from the Upper West Side, who helped lead efforts to preserve the church, acknowledged on Wednesday, There is a lot of work to be done.

title: A Win for Idol, but Not for Fox
description: Ratings for Foxs American Idol recovered somewhat on Tuesday after falling to an eight-year low last week, but CBS won the night over all by a thin margin. According to Nielsens estimates, a movie-theme episode of Idol, with guest-mentoring (and T-shirts) from Jamie Foxx, remained the nights top-rated show, earning 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., up from 17.5 million a week ago, but CBSs NCIS was close behind in the time slot with 16.9 million viewers. The CBS shows NCIS: Los Angeles (15.9 million) at 9 p.m. and The Good Wife (12.9 million) at 10 won their time slots as well. ABC placed third on the night and NBC was fourth.

title: Illness of Star Prompts Spartacus Prequel
description: While the actor who plays the title character in the Starz drama Spartacus: Blood and Sand undergoes cancer treatment, the channel will produce a six-episode prequel to the series. Starz said Tuesday that the prequel is now in pre-production, with a tentative premiere date of January. Andy Whitfield, right, who plays Spartacus, has non-Hodgkins lymphoma; he will appear in a limited capacity in the prequel, Starz said, and the focus will be on two other characters from the shows first season, played by Lucy Lawless and John Hannah. The Starz president and chief executive, Chris Albrecht, said that Mr. Whitfield was responding to his treatments, and that as soon as hes able, we look forward to continuing the Spartacus story.

title: BlogTalk: Calls for Repealing Dont Ask
description: A group of military bloggers has put out a joint statement calling for the military to repeal the Dont Ask, Dont Tell law. Now, as you know, in February the top two Pentagon officials, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, went before Congress and called for an end to the policy. President Obama also wants to see the end to Dont Ask, but Congress has not yet acted.

title: Batter Up: Ken Burnss Follow-Up to Baseball
description: As a baseball great once said, It aint over till its over, and in the case of the Ken Burns documentary Baseball, it aint over yet. In September PBS will broadcast a new documentary, The Tenth Inning, directed by Mr. Burns and Lynn Novick, that will continue the story begun by Mr. Burnss 1994 film about the great American pastime. The Tenth Inning, which will be shown in two parts, on Sept. 28 and 29, will track baseballs history from the 1990s to the present. The series is produced by Florentine Films and WETA television of Washington, and is narrated by Keith David.

title: Different Nationals Outfielder, Same Mets Result
description: Another Mets victory died in the glove of a Nationals outfielder Wednesday. This time, however, the glove did not belong to Willie Harris.

title: Indie Film Distributor Sentenced in Film Festival Scam
description: A word to the many indie film types headed for the annual film festival just getting under way in Cannes: Let the seller beware. The United States attorneys office in Los Angeles on Wednesday said that an independent film distributor, Harel Goldstein, was sentenced to four years in federal prison after having pleaded guilty to bank fraud in a scheme that bilked Comerica Bank of more than $7 million.

description: Computerworld has an excellent breakdown of how to manage data consumption on your iPad 3G so you can stay within the confines of AT&Ts 250-megabyte data plan (at $15 monthly) and avoid the $30 charge for unlimited monthly data use.

description: In this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein revisits the early days of personal computing with Jason Bitner, the creator of the How I Met Your Motherboard Web site. It celebrates the time when computers were beige and business-y by collecting stories and photos of early home computers like the Sinclair, Osborne, Kaypro and Commodore.

But they again insisted that Swiss officials were given a misleading description of Mr. Polanskis intended sentence, and noted a French news report in which a Swiss justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, on Wednesday said his office had asked for, but had not received, supplementary information from the U.S.

title: The Twilight of the Welfare State?
description: The debt crisis in Greece may have been temporarily eased by the European Unions infusion of aid, but many analysts think that Europes debt problems and Americas are just beginning. Several analysts have noted that the welfare states in Greece, Spain and Portugal were greatly expanded in the 1990s, leading to an extraordinary rise in the standards of living in those countries but also unsustainable spending. David Leonhardt of The Times and Robert Samuelson of The Washington Post this week compared the welfare state obligations in Europe to the entitlement burden in the United States.

title: New Data on 2008 Election
description: Ninety-three percent of blacks who were registered voted in the 2008 presidential election, a greater proportion than any other racial or ethnic group measured by the Census Bureau, according to an analysis released Wednesday. Non-Hispanic whites were second, at 90 percent. The bureau, which is rarely prone to hyperbole, said it was remarkable that when the impact of age, region, sex, income and educational attainment were taken into account, the odds of voting in 2008 were about twice as high for blacks as they were for non-Hispanic whites. While whites who did not vote cited busy schedules more than any other reason, blacks listed illness or disability the most.

title: California: Los Angeles Approves a Boycott of Arizona
description: The Los Angeles City Council voted Wednesday to ban official travel to Arizona and block future contracts with companies there in protest of that states new immigration law. Some members of the Council have repeatedly spoken against the law since its enactment, and several marched with immigrants-rights activists and thousands of protesters on May 1 in downtown Los Angeles to oppose the law. The Council has asked officials for the citys port, airport and utilities to review all contracts with companies based in Arizona.

description: Ive been hearing some muttering about the April tax receipts, which are well below those of a year ago. Doesnt that mean that all hopes of recovery, either in the economy or in the budget, should be abandoned?

title: And Heres How It Got on Your Head
description: BOYFRIEND jeans. Boyfriend shirts. Now boyfriend hats. At Block Headwear in NoLIta, women cut out the middleman (i.e., the boyfriend) and buy the hats for themselves (left, a range from $35 to $85). For the Cuban-born designer Ciomi McCabe, hatmaking is a family tradition; she perfected her craft at Kangol, where her father was chief financial officer, before founding her brand 10 years ago. Block refers to the manufacturing, which includes molding and steaming material around a block of wood. Antique equipment will be set up for clients to see the process. Block Headwear, 10 Prince Street (between Elizabeth Street and the Bowery); (212) 219-2328; blockheadwear.com.

title: Colleges Seeing No Downturn in Freshman Acceptances
description: One measurement that selective colleges use to compare themselves is their respective admissions yields: the percentage of applicants offered acceptance who ultimately decide to enroll. A few institutions  including Harvard, Dartmouth, Cornell and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill  have begun to report those figures for the freshman class that will take its seats next fall, and so far none have experienced any downturn in the midst of the sluggish economy. At Harvard, for example, more than three of every four applicants who received an acceptance letter had committed by the May 1 deadline to enroll, a slight increase over last year. (The university said it still expected to offer acceptance to as many as 75 applicants on its waiting list.) At Dartmouth, the yield for the new freshman class was 55 percent, an increase of seven percentage points; the increase was so large that the college said it might not have room for anyone on its waiting list. North Carolina said its yield was 53.3 percent (compared with 53.9 percent at this time last year). But that figure is likely to rise, as it does not include all responses to the nearly 350 wait-list offers the university made and whose replies are due next week. Cornell said its yield rate was relatively flat, 49 percent, as was that of the University of Pennsylvania, at 63 percent. Neither institution said it had decided its waiting-list offers.

title: In Harlem, a Minister Serves Those Who No Longer Can
description: It was about 20 minutes after lunch at the Northern Manhattan Nursing Home on 125th Street in Harlem, and the sounds of feet shuffling and wheelchairs squeaking in a ninth-floor hallway seemed to fade as the Rev. Olevia Stewart-Smith began to read aloud the Lords Prayer.

title: Art? Jewelry? Fashion? Maybe All Three
description: A SHLEY HANOSH, of Honey in the Rough, is merchandising the new jewelry collection from Florian, called Zulu Soiree, by displaying it on the wall of her Lower East Side womens-wear store like works of art. The hand-done pieces include ones made entirely of glass beads with silver findings (above, $380). The more-eccentric statement pieces are concentric loops; the wearer can poke her head through the loop of her choice and drape the rest across the chest, or let it drop down the back. Prices range from $175 to $840. Ms. Hanosh also introduced an improved e-commerce site this week.

title: She Never Outgrew These Shoes
description: A S a child, Gabriela Lanardonne (above) would spend vacations in her fathers native Buenos Aires, where she became obsessed by the alpargatas, a version of the espadrille. In her line MYMU, Ms. Lanardonne updated the humble shoe, making it slimmer and sleeker, and offering it in vibrant colors like fuchsia and in fabrics like silk, nylon and leather ($98 to $175). The shoes are unisex. Her new pop-up shop will be at the David Lawrence Studio, 14 East 63rd Street, May 19 to June 2, Monday to Saturday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 6 p.m.; mymuworld.com.

title: Afghans Distrust Threatens U.S. War Strategy
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  Nearly a year into a new war strategy for Afghanistan, the hardest fighting is still ahead, but already it is clear that the biggest challenge lies not on the battlefield but in the governing of Afghanistan itself.

description: Twos Company, a wholesaler of decorative accessories, is having a warehouse sale May 14 to 16, with hundreds of products marked down by as much as 90 percent (a metal-top 60-inch table, originally $720, is $150; the Biarritz etched mirror, originally $600, is $150); 275 Clearbrook Road, Elmsford, N.Y., (914) 345-2222.

title: Flos Arrives in SoHo
description: The Italian lighting manufacturer Flos is opening its first American store in SoHo on May 15. It will carry the companys most popular fixtures, including classic models like the Arco floor lamp and the Taccia table lamp, by Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, as well as more recent pieces like Philippe Starcks table lamp modeled after an AK-47. Piero Gandini, chief executive of Flos, said he hopes the lighting will deliver the feeling of joy and a little bit of irony and enthusiasm. His enthusiasm will be reflected in a special installation for the opening  a giant Kelvin LED task lamp, designed by Antonio Citterio with Toan Nguyen, which will tower over visitors at 15 times its normal size. The showroom takes over a space on Greene Street previously used by the design store Moss. Mr. Gandini said that he searched for a New York location for years, but that when he heard about the availability of the corner space from the retailer Murray Moss, this decision took five seconds. Flos, 152 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 941-4760, flosusa.com.

title: Furniture by Chris Rucker at Industry Gallery
description: Chris Rucker, a New York designer, is a fan of the work of Donald Judd, something that is apparent in If I Told You One Time ..., a show of furniture made of oriented strand board opening May 15 at Industry Gallery in Washington.

title: Discussing Public Gardens in New York and Paris
description: Public Gardens in Paris and New York, a panel discussion at the French Institute Alliance Franaise on May 17, will include Darrel Morrison, a Manhattan landscape architect; Alexandre Chemetoff, an architect and urban planner in Paris; and Adrian Benepe, the commissioner of parks and recreation for New York City. The discussion will focus on transforming cities with green spaces. It will be moderated by Paula Dietz, the editor of the Hudson Review, and subjects discussed will include Fort Tryon Park, above, and the Brooklyn Bridge Park, designed by Michael Van Valkenburgh Associates. The event is at 7 p.m., at 22 East 60th Street (Park Avenue); admission is $20 for members and $25 for nonmembers. Information: (212) 355-6160 or fiaf.org.

title: Products From Portugal at the MoMa Design Store
description: With summer almost here, the time to stock up on hostess gifts is now. But when that urge to impose upon your friends with country houses is upon you, you need not trouble yourself with shopping. Today, the MoMA Design Store unveils Destination: Portugal, a line of more than 100 new products from that country, including tableware and serving pieces.

title: Terrarium Artist Moves Into Tableware
description: Paula Hayes, the artist and gardener who creates fantastical environments like hand-blown terrariums, blobby silicone planters and otherworldly crystal-strewn landscapes for art world heavies, is now making objects for the rest of us. Her handmade tableware is sculptural and tactile and comes in the biomorphic shapes that are her signature: a deep blue wineglass is like a hobbits boot ($140); a glass plate looks like a jellyfish ($575); a cranberry-red water glass could be a vibrating bean ($160). Napkins ($75) are silk-screened with images of roots, houses and communications satellites, as are repositionable art squares  a k a self-adhesive wallpaper panels (set of nine, $150).

Its outline was still visible, marked by a stone wall running the length of the garden and a listing metal fence that enclosed a few wilted peonies and one spindly rosebush. description: The pitching arm is considered the most valuable and vulnerable of baseball commodities. At the games highest levels, it is treated with tender loving care, often limited to prescribed game usage, with rest strictly enforced between outings.

description: WASHINGTON  The Republican Party selected Tampa, Fla., on Wednesday as the site of its 2012 presidential nominating convention, with the city winning out over Phoenix and Salt Lake City as the place to kick off the partys quest to defeat President Obama.

Toss in fake money, real money, Pokmon cards, metal washers, roof insulation and 1,700 condoms.

description: Britains new coalition government  its first since World War II  honors the mixed verdict of last weeks election. The voters rejected the Labour Party of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown. But they denied David Cameron and the Conservative Party a majority. The third place Liberal Democrats have become Mr. Camerons junior partner.

title: On Capitol Hill, Kagan Gets to Know Her Voters
description: WASHINGTON  Elena Kagans lack of judicial experience and her stance on the militarys Dont Ask, Dont Tell policy emerged Wednesday as potential flashpoints in her confirmation hearings. The top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee said he was not satisfied with her explanation of why she had briefly barred military recruiters from using Harvard Law School facilities when she was dean.

description: As we all know, in the arid world of Arizona, political temperatures have been rising about a new law that makes it a crime to be without immigration papers, and relies heavily on reasonable suspicion. The reaction within the professional sports world would have been unheard of in my playing days, and underlines a real generational gap. In an unprecedented show of solidarity, players, owners and front-office personnel are uniting, disgusted by Arizonas approach to addressing concerns over the undocumented.

The challenge for Mayor Michael Bloomberg is to make the High Bridge, the citys oldest standing bridge, as successful.

title: Leg Lost to Land Mine, Boy, 11, Moves Israel
description: JERUSALEM  On his junior year abroad here in 1984, Jerry White, a student at Brown University, stepped on a buried land mine while hiking with friends in the Golan Heights. The explosion tore off part of his right leg and nearly killed him. It also set the course for his lifes work  leading him to help found what is today called Survivor Corps, an organization that shared the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize, and persuade scores of countries to clear their lands of antipersonnel mines and ban their production and use.

title: Mr. Obama and Mr. Karzai, Take Two
description: After months of rancor, President Obama made nice to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Wednesday, and Mr. Karzai made nice back. At a White House press conference, the two men painted a sunny, improbable picture of cooperation and mutual respect. There was no mention of the many failings of Mr. Karzais government or his resentment of American pressure.

title: Somalia: U.N. Revamps Food Program
description: The World Food Program in Somalia is addressing flaws in its distribution system exposed earlier this year by a United Nations Security Council report, which concluded that half the $485 million in food aid in 2009 was diverted by corrupt contractors, Islamic militants or United Nations staff members. The United Nations team in Somalia is developing a database of all service providers and revising its control system for the delivery of aid and cash transfers, according to the latest council report.

title: China: Confession Obtained by Torture
description: Officials in the city of Shangqiu in Henan Province have admitted that police officers tortured a man to get him to falsely confess to a murder that he did not commit, official Chinese news organizations reported Wednesday. The man who confessed, Zhao Zuohai, spent 10 years in jail but was released when the supposed victim reappeared in their village on April 30. The police arrested Mr. Zhao, beat him and forced him to drink a toxic substance, he told Chinese reporters this week. Mr. Zhao said he feared he would be killed if he did not confess.

title: China: Quake Memorial on Internet
description: On Wednesday, the second anniversary of the Sichuan earthquake, Ai Weiwei, left, a prominent Chinese artist, posted an Internet audio project in which volunteers read the names of nearly 5,000 children who were killed when the quake struck several provinces in western China. Mr. Ai, a frequent critic of the government, is trying to call attention to shoddy construction that led to the collapse of many schools during the quake.

title: Putting a Price on Words
description: Last year, Sam Apple got the idea into his head that what the world needed was a new kind of newspaper. This was, to put it mildly, at odds with the consensus of the marketplace. At the time, several large media companies were in bankruptcy, others were trading at penny-stock levels and analysts were seriously asking whether some venerable publications  including this one  might soon cease to exist. The recession was only worsening a fundamental problem: the industrys physical product, printed paper, was going the way of the rotary phone, and no one had yet figured out how to generate comparable revenues online. But Apple, a 34-year-old writer, wasnt ready to give up on journalism as a profit-making enterprise. He began telling friends about his plans to start a Web publication called The Faster Times.

description: An explosion and fire on a drilling rig on April 20 left 11 workers missing and presumed dead. The rig sank two days later about 50 miles off the Louisiana coast. Since then, attempts to shut off the flow of oil streaming into the Gulf of Mexico have been unsuccessful and the search continues for a cause and for ways to prevent such blowouts in the future. Questions persist about who will be liable for damage from the spill and the risks to local wildlife. Following is an updated oil spill primer. title: Chile: Detainee Not Linked to Attempted Attack in Times Square, Official Says
description: A Pakistani man who was arrested by Chilean police on Monday after traces of explosive material were detected on his belongings during a check at the United States Embassy in Santiago is not believed to be connected to the attempted bombing in Times Square earlier this month, a State Department official said Wednesday. The man now under investigation in Santiago, Mohamed Saif ur-Rehman, 28 , was put on a watch list by American intelligence services prior to the Times Square event, so we dont see any connection, said Virginia Staab, a State Department spokeswoman. We have explored that angle and law enforcement so far sees no connection between the two incidents.

Mr. Aziz, 53, who grew up in Claremont Village in the South Bronx, began practicing at age 8. For the last decade he has taught karate to children at the Harlem Childrens Zones Truce Nutrition and Fitness Center. (Truce stands for The Renaissance University for Community Education.) title: Correction
description: A theater entry for Massachusetts in the Summer Stages listings last Sunday misspelled the surname of the playwright who wrote The Taster, which will be presented by Shakespeare & Company in Lenox. She is Joan Ackermann, not Ackerman. Another theater entry misidentified the company that is presenting Susurrus at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven. It is Fire Exit  not the National Theater of the United States of America, which is presenting Chautauqua! at the festival. And a picture credit for a scene from Richard III, another Shakespeare & Company production in Lenox, omitted the name of the photographer. The picture, supplied by a publicist for the company, was taken by Kevin Sprague.

title: Letter: The Data-Driven Life
description: Before psychotherapists reject the notion of using electronic devices to track human emotions while treating mood disorders, like those described by Gary Wolf, and before advocates for such devices reject the need for psychotherapy, let us consider these two seemingly separate interventions synergistically. Imagining electronic devices without recognizing the power of relationships  the live human connection  is a fallow notion. Yet considering them as tools to support cognitive and behavioral change may hold potential. The automatic e-mailing of friends when a mood-tracking score signifies a lowered mood is a novel idea, but it left me wondering how this information is then integrated by the individual with the illness beyond the quick feedback from the friend. Hunter College School of Social Work, New YorkLORRAINE R. TEMPEL, PH.D.Hunter College School of Social Work,New York

title: Letter: What Makes Marion Jones Run?
description: It is very interesting to watch the press coverage, by Maggie Jones and others, of Marion Joness attempt to re-enter the sports world. I first met Marion Jones at a benefit in early 2001, fresh off her Olympic victories. The applause for her was loud and prolonged. How could she have shown such pride, knowing that she cheated? All of the rightful winners saw another person get their medals and heard another anthem played and saw another flag raised at the Olympics instead of their own. That is a travesty. Jones does not deserve another chance at sports. Everything she does now is subject to the highest scrutiny.

title: The Voices of Thyroid Disease

title: Letter: The Real World 44

The article reinforces what I have seen for myself: there are many talented, devoted and hard-working young people in this country, and its future is in good hands.JOHN MANNHAUPTCarrollton, Tex.

title: Green Economics
description: Paul Krugman (April 11) does an excellent job of explaining climate-change economics but omits one important factor: the immediate and local human health benefits of the cleaner air that most climate-change-mitigation measures will also provide. When reducing carbon dioxide emissions (e.g., by reducing the burning of coal), other air pollutants, like particles and ozone, that are associated with increased risk of asthma attacks, hospital admissions and mortality will often also be reduced at the same time.

title: The Eternal Godmother of La Bayadre
description: ONE by one, clad in diaphanous white, they enter to a flowing adagio musical phrase. One arm is stretched forward toward infinity, one leg stretched back to create a glorious arabesque line; then each ghostly figure arches backward, arms framing the head like a halo. The phrase is repeated over and over, the line of dancers winding across the stage in seemingly never-ending serpentine progression: a poetic image of eternity, of order, symmetry, harmony, of classical ballet itself.

description: KNOCK, knock, knock. Thats me, rapping on the front door of a large brick house set high above Main Street in Amherst, Mass. September 1963. Im 16.

title: Would They Sound as Sweet by Other Names?
description: REVIEWING Juilliard415 recently, my colleague James R. Oestreich puzzled over the name of this new period-instrument band and that of another Juilliard group, Ensemble ACJW. The meaning of the names didnt stop him: as someone with a longstanding passion for early music, he would immediately have recognized 415 as an allusion to Baroque pitch. (The note A is believed to have been tuned, on average, to something closer to 415 cycles per second than to todays standard, 440 cycles; the letter A is highlighted in the Juilliard415 logo as a clue.) And ACJW refers to the Academy, supported by Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute.

title: Riding Herd on the Wild Orchestra
description: SEIZED during the 1990s with the notion of creating a complex, large-scale symphonic work yet lacking a commission to facilitate it, the French composer Pascal Dusapin came up with a novel solution in his Seven Solos for Orchestra, a cycle composed in individual installments yet organically linked in ways evident or not. Introduced by various orchestras between 1992 and 2009, the pieces finally appear together on a new two-disc set by the conductor Pascal Roph and the Lige Philharmonic Orchestra, issued by the French label Nave (MO 782180).

Despite being in the red (or perhaps because of it  cheap rents!), the Greek city is starting to steal the cultural spotlight from the increasingly gentrified Berlin, which seems more interested in spawning an outpost of Londons Soho House than in nurturing the careers of creative types.

title: Sunday Magazine Preview: A New-Style Newspaper Entrepreneur
description: In an article in this Sundays issue of The New York Times Magazine, Andrew Rice writes about Sam Apple, a writer and Web site director who quit his job to become a latter-day newspaper entrepreneur. Using customized open-source software, he started an online publication he calls The Faster Times, an attempt to keep newspaper-style journalism alive in a Web-only version. Instead of paying his writers a salary or a flat freelance fee, Mr. Apple shares advertising revenue with them  a small amount at the moment, but potentially more lucrative if the enterprise takes off.

It got us thinking about whether you could fill a respectable 25-man roster entirely with Yankees castaways just by going back a few seasons. It turns out you can, sort of, if you can live with Jason Giambi as your starting first baseman.

title: My Legal Lesson (Continued)
description: My last post created a bit of a stir. As you may recall, Im subletting new office space and was referred to a firm that specializes in real estate law by another lawyer who had done some personal work for me. My legal needs were simple: I just needed a lawyer to review a standard sublease agreement given to me by my new landlord. The post recounted how the real estate lawyers requested a $2,500 retainer and said that the total fee probably wouldnt exceed that amount. In the end, however, the fee was $6,450  including $60 for sending me this courtesy e-mail: I hope everything is O.K. Take your time.

title: New York Is the Next Greece Is the New Black

description: After enough years of leaping out of bed and scampering up the Bowery to the Union Square Greenmarket to load up on ramps and fiddleheads  which are currently high on the precipice of their short, seasonal apex  my relationship with these two first wild-grown signs that spring is upon us and summer is on its way is waning. Theyre good vegetables with real appeal, but theyre not as flexible as some produce.

title: Theyll Meet in St. Louis
description: The United States Championship begins tomorrow at the Chess Club and Scholastic Center of Saint Louis. The field includes all the top American players, among them Hikaru Nakamura, the defending champion. Nakamura, a New York City-native who has lived in Seattle for the last year, is moving to St. Louis after the tournament.

title: Theater Talkback: Premium Seats, at a Price
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated For theater critics, acquiring tickets to the hot new show, or the cold new turkey, is as easy as falling off that proverbial log. You make a phone call (or send an e-mail message) in response to an invitation, you show up at the theater and find the publicist standing helpfully outside the doors with your tickets in hand, and you head on in. If you are not attending a designated press performance, you may have to endure the indignity of standing in line at the box office for a minute or two.

The brothers Noah and Logan Miller discuss how they came to write, direct, produce and star in their first feature film,

title: U.S. Grants Visa to Singer of Castros Praises
description: The singer and songwriter Silvio Rodrguez, the Cuban artist who is probably most closely identified with the Cuban Revolution and Fidel Castros half-century in power, has been granted a visa to perform in the United States for the first time in more than 30 years, according to his American immigration lawyer. Mr. Rodrguez plans to tour the United States next month, the lawyer, William Martinez, said, and is scheduled to perform at Carnegie Hall on June 4 with his seven-piece band.

title: Monaco and the Driver Factor
description: MONACO  It is well known that Monaco is one circuit where the driver can make a difference. That is to say, if at most of the high-speed circuits of the Formula One calendar the car accounts for 95 percent of the lap time and the drivers skill accounts for the other 5 percent, at Monaco the driver might account for a larger percentage of what will make a car do a good lap.

title: Upfronts: How Do You Say McDreamy in Spanish?

Beginning on Monday, Telemundo will be all telenovelas in prime time, replacing a game show that has been running from 7 to 8 p.m. with a Spanish-language version of the ABC series Greys Anatomy.

description: As Swiss lawmakers lock horns over a bill to resolve a thorny tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the countrys pre-eminent financial sector, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

description: Americans spend more time researching a car purchase than they do researching a home mortgage, according to a survey that the online lending marketplace Zillow Mortgage Marketplace recently released.

title: Answers About Robert Moses, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs, which looks at New Yorks urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs.

title: To Fix Bridge, Skateboard Mecca May Be Lost
description: To most people, the area under the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge, in the shadows of the off ramps and against the hulking stone structure of the famous East River crossing, is not a place to stop. It is a place to leave.

description: On Thursday, Scvngr (pronounced scavenger) introduced a new set of features and mobile applications that it hoped would become a location-based game for consumers.

description: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Goodwin Liu to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, sending him to the full Senate for consideration after a party-line vote of 12 Democrats in favor and seven Republicans opposed.

title: Seeing Things | Shanghai Expo 2010
description: Once upon a time, back when international travel was a novelty rather than a nuisance, and the Internet was nothing but a sci-fi fantasy, world expositions had a certain cachet. Countries competed to showcase the latest advancements in technology, science and culture in swanky national pavilions. As a young child visiting Expo 67 in Montreal, I was dazzled by the U.S. Pavilion, a sparkling geodesic dome designed by Buckminster Fuller. Perhaps those expos were so exciting because they were all about the promise of the future. But now that were living in that future, the idea of an international exposition doesnt have the same allure.

title: TimesCast: Oil Pressure Builds
description: Todays TimesCast takes an early look at the political fallout of the oil rig explosion and its potential implications for offshore drilling beyond the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Want to Talk to Kagans Family? Permission Denied
description: White Houses traditionally put a muzzle on their Supreme Court nominees, to keep them from saying anything that might jeopardize Senate confirmation. But the Obama White House has taken it one step further. It is limiting, if not blocking, access to the nominees family.

title: Uma, Alfa. Alfa, Uma.
description: Heres one more reason to bemoan Alfa Romeos absence in the United States: as part of an ambitious Italian advertising campaign that will be revealing the multifaceted soul of the new 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta, the actress Uma Thurman will star in a sensuous (were told by Alfa) television spot that will be shown in Europe starting next week.

title: A Long Wednesday for Jeter
description: DETROIT  The strong pitching by Javier Vazquez and Phil Hughes in Wednesdays doubleheader overshadowed a long day at the plate for Derek Jeter. He went 0 for 8 to fall deeper into a weeklong slide.

title: A Mash-Up on Behalf of Mother Africa
description: STEPPING out of a shiny black SUV in a baggy denim suit, his dreadlocks so long they nearly brushed his boots, Damian Marley came to the Fillmore at Irving Plaza in March on a stealth mission. This Jamaican dancehall star, also known as Jr Gong, and the New York rapper Nasir Jones, also known as Nas, planned to surprise the audience gathered for a show by the hip-hop artist KNaan with a song from their new album, Distant Relatives.

title: Writing to Explain: Creating How-to Scripts and Demonstrations
description: Overview | What are the qualities of good expository writing? What is process analysis, and how can it help us write for clarity? In this lesson, students examine and evaluate a Times slide show that explains how to pack 10 days worth of clothes in a carry-on suitcase. They then generate qualities of good process analysis or procedural writing and create their own physical, video or explanatory, audio demonstrations or explanations.

title: Delivering Better Primary Care
description: What is clear is this: primary care is hurtling toward a crisis point. Once lauded as health cares frontline clinicians, primary care practitioners  general internists, family physicians, geriatricians, general pediatricians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants  are instead struggling with growing paperwork demands, inadequate and misaligned reimbursement and dwindling numbers of providers.

title: Hearing From the Community Doctor
description: Much has been written lately about the impending primary care crisis, with everyone from presidential advisers to political pundits offering scores of suggestions on how our countrys front-line health care providers can tackle the growing paperwork problem, deal with inadequate reimbursements and inspire a new generation of practitioners, all while caring for more and more patients.

title: Seven Rivers Less Paddled
description: Looking to get far from the paddling crowds? We consulted kayaking experts around the country, and came up with seven less-trafficked places to hit the water this spring and summer. One of them is sure to float your boat.

title: After Friends Death, Cho Finds Solace on the Course
description: MOBILE, Ala.  At 10 minutes before 7 on Thursday morning, Irene Cho struck her opening shot of the Bell Micro L.P.G.A. Classic, her tee time so early that not a single ticket-holding fan was there to applaud her perfect drive.

title: The Nature and Destiny of the Tea Parties
description: Just when you thought the well of anti-Tea Party sentiment had been drained by months of liberal broadsides, along come two of the most stinging critiques of the movement yet published one from Mark Lilla in The New York Review of Books, and one from Michael Kinsley in The Atlantic. I may have more to say about their pieces later, but for now, as a partial counterpoint, heres a Tea Party-related clip from a bloggingheads conversation I just recorded with Reihan Salam. (Hopefully youll forgive my tendency to throw around the phrase good for the republic like an extra in a Julius Caesar biopic.)

title: Service Members in Afghanistan: Send Us Your Photos
description: The New York Times invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the FOB, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

title: Seeing Double With Noah and Logan Miller
description: Directors, actors, screenwriters, producers: with their first film project, the twin brothers Noah and Logan Miller have checked off just about every box on the credits list. Their movie, Touching Home, is a semiautobiographical look at the brothers relationship with their father (played by Ed Harris). In addition to the film, the brothers wrote a book about their experience called Either Youre In or Youre In the Way. Here, the two talk about their unlikely journey from working at a car wash in Tucson to making a feature film with no experience or industry contacts. View a trailer for Touching Home here.
