description: Lets put the 76ers coaching search in terms of the cheesy reality show The Bachelor.

title: The Capeman Continues Its Comeback This Summer
description: Are theatergoers ready to forgive  or, at least, revisit  The Capeman? Students of Broadway probably know its back story better than its music by now: this notorious musical about the gang member Salvador Agron, with a book and lyrics by Paul Simon and Derek Walcott, and music by Mr. Simon, went through five directors en route to its opening at the Marquis Theater in 1998, where it lasted all of two months. But a concert production, Songs From the Capeman, presented by Mr. Simon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2008, drew better notices, and now the Public Theater will provide the musical with another step on its road to rehabilitation.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Makayla Moore squirms away from a cold bucket of water as she is buried in sand on a beach in Galveston, Tex.

title: Internet Advertising Keeps Growing
description: The first quarter of 2010 saw a 7.5 percent increase in Internet advertising revenue over the same period last year, growing to $5.9 billion, the Interactive Advertising Bureau and PricewaterhouseCoopers said this morning.

title: Arms Pact Submitted for Senates Consent
description: President Obama on Thursday formally kicked off his campaign to win Senate approval of a new arms control treaty with Russia, sending the pact and various additional papers to the Senate for consideration.

title: Growing Up With Dad, Distilled With Bite
description: IN making an autobiographical film, the brothers Josh and Benny Safdie had the advantage of a well-documented childhood. On a recent afternoon in their office on lower Broadway, the Safdies sifted through boxes of videotapes and photographs preserved in scrapbooks, all of it emotional raw material for their new fiction feature Daddy Longlegs.

title: Pope Decries Gay Marriage in Portugal Visit
description: FTIMA, Portugal  Pope Benedict XVI used a famous Portuguese shrine to the Virgin Mary on Thursday as a stage to denounce abortion and gay marriage, just days before Portugal is expected to join five European countries that have legalized same-sex weddings.

title: Obama, in Buffalo, Is Upbeat on the Economy
description: BUFFALO  President Obama defended his economic policies on Thursday, declaring beyond a shadow of a doubt that job growth would continue and that his recovery package had broken the economic free fall he faced when he took office 16 months ago.

title: G.M. President Gives 2011 Chevrolet Cruze One Final Test Drive
description: Mark Reuss slipped behind the wheel of the metallic-red Chevrolet Cruze, buckled his seat belt and adjusted the seat and mirrors. Surveying the cars instrument cluster and control console, he ran his fingertips across the dashboard, checking its surface texture and the consistency of fit between trim panels.

title: The Rise and Fall of the G.D.P.
description: Whatever you may think progress looks like  a rebounding stock market, a new house, a good raise  the governments of the world have long held the view that only one statistic, the measure of gross domestic product, can really show whether things seem to be getting better or getting worse. G.D.P. is an index of a countrys entire economic output  a tally of, among many other things, manufacturers shipments, farmers harvests, retail sales and construction spending. Its a figure that compresses the immensity of a national economy into a single data point of surpassing density. The conventional feeling about G.D.P. is that the more it grows, the better a country and its citizens are doing. In the U.S., economic activity plummeted at the start of 2009 and only started moving up during the second half of the year. Apparently things are moving in that direction still. In the first quarter of this year, the economy again expanded, this time by an annual rate of about 3.2 percent.

title: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
description: The professors in Hyde Park believe in something called the University of Chicago mind. It runs cold and analytical when the rest of the culture runs hot. Chicago scholars tend to be social scientists at heart, contrarian but empirical, following evidence to logical extremes. They are centrally interested not in what it is like to be an individual within society but in how society washes over individuals, making and remaking them. During the campaign, when his former Chicago colleagues were asked to detail Barack Obamas intellectual evolution, many of them described him in these terms. But they knew Obama, at best, only partly exhibited this tradition. His friend Cass Sunstein, who is certainly the most productive and probably the most influential liberal legal scholar of his generation, inherited it in full. Cass has, says Saul Levmore, a former dean of the law school, the quintessential University of Chicago habit of mind.

title: Eminem and Jay-Z Team Up for Two Concerts
description: Eminem and Jay-Z will be tag-teaming at baseball stadiums this fall.

title: The Legacy of Jacob Wrey Mould
description: The 1870 Central Park Precinct building, on 86th Street, is part of the legacy of Jacob Wrey Mould, one of New Yorks most talented and versatile architects.

title: Grand Jury: Bicyclists, Motorists, Dial Down the Anger and Obey the Law!
description: Just in time for Bike to Work Day, the San Francisco Civil Grand Jury has issued a report calling on drivers and bicyclists to get along.

title: The Architecture of Jacob Wrey Mould Is a Study in Contrasts
description: THE reconstruction of the 1870 Central Park Precinct building, on 86th Street, is under way, and only the decoratively tiled dormers peep out over a plywood fence. These are traces of the work of Jacob Wrey Mould, one of New Yorks most talented and versatile architects. He described himself as hell on color, but his striking polychrome legacy is mysteriously mixed.

title: Rob the Rich? Give to the Poor? Oh, Puh-leeze!
description: Who was Robin Hood? As with any long-lived figure in the popular imagination  and the legend of the outlaw of Sherwood Forest and his Merry Men goes back to the Middle Ages  the answer changes with the times. In the movies he has been played most memorably by Errol Flynn, most forgettably by Kevin Costner and now, least merrily, by Russell Crowe.

title: Senate Votes to Tighten Rules for Rating Agencies
description: 5:02 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn has more details of the Senates action on The Caucus.

title: Savoys Pice de Rsistance Is Going Palatial
description: He has opened a restaurant in Las Vegas and three others around Paris. Now, Guy Savoy is upgrading his flagship restaurant.

title: Its Not About You
description: So Republicans are coming out to oppose US participation in a bailout of Greece  which is interesting, given that nobody is asking us to participate. (Yes, were part of the IMF, which will provide part of the money  but thats a fraction of a fraction, and its a really bad idea for IMF members to start picking and choosing which programs theyre part of.)

title: Eddie Izzard Joining Cast of Race
description: Apparently the theater gods and goddesses were listening when we noted earlier today that there was still one more gavel yet to fall in the re-casting of the Broadway play Race: When James Spader leaves that David Mamet drama after June 20, he will be replaced by Eddie Izzard, its producers said. Mr. Izzard, the comedian and actor who will take over in the role of the lawyer Jack Lawson, made his Broadway debut in the 2003 revival of A Day in the Death of Joe Egg, the Peter Nichols comedy; hes also an Emmy Award winner for his comedy special Eddie Izzard: Dress to Kill, and looks smashing in drag (which he wont be doing for Race, alas). Race is slated to run through Aug. 21 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater with a cast that will include Dennis Haysbert and Afton C. Williamson, as well as Richard Thomas, who has been in the play since its opening.

title: Vain Glorious | Tom Fords Luxe Lips
description: Who: Tom Ford

title: LED Bulbs Light Up
description: Osram Sylvania says it will be the first major light bulb maker to sell an LED lamp that produces the same amount of light as a 60-watt incandescent lamp. It expects to sell the LED bulb, as part of its Ultra line, this August.

title: Tax Exemption Sought for Venture Capital Firms
description: Four Senate Democrats and a Republican, Scott Brown of Massachusetts, are seeking to exempt venture capital firms from a proposed tax increase on managers of investment partnerships, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Boehner: Efforts to Highlight Laws Implementation Are Propaganda
description: Its fair to say that time hasnt softened Representative John A. Boehners take on the new health care law.

title: ZenCity Resort
description: WHAT Caribbean residential development.

title: Where Every Seat Is Front Row Center
description: Most Broadway producers would be crushed if only one person showed up for a performance. But an audience of one is exactly what Christine Jones wants.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: The sight of a jetliners proud tailfin  still in full livery as it rises from a scene of wreckage  is one that can send especially mournful chills through New Yorkers of a certain age; reawakening the blurred outlines of a nightmare never completely forgotten. When that sight (an Afriqiyah Airways Airbus, in Slide 2) is accompanied by news that the only survivor was a young boy, the memory grows irresistible.

title: Western Senators Propose Ban on Pacific Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  The political ripples from the Gulf of Mexico oil disaster spread in the capital on Thursday as six West Coast senators proposed a permanent ban on drilling in the Pacific and another group tried to raise oil company liability in a spill to $10 billion from the current $75 million.

title: Lesser Lineup for Yankees Is No Match for Verlander
description: DETROIT  The Yankees challenged the Detroit ace Justin Verlander on Thursday with a lineup ending with Juan Miranda, Randy Winn and Greg Golson. They rested the banged-up Nick Swisher, and Derek Jeter, their leadoff hitter, is slumping, not that he would call it that. It was all a blueprint for trouble, and the outcome played true.

title: Strolling Old Halls and Streets With Ghosts of Civil War
description: ALTON, Ill.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: The Morning Skate: Penguins Stanley Cup Reign a Short One
description: There will be a new Stanley Cup champion for the 11th consecutive season. Once again, the Canadiens have eliminated an N.H.L. power and in Pittsburgh and elsewhere, disbelief reigns.

title: Recording Customer Service Calls to India
description: Last month, I wrote a Bucks post, When and Why You Should Record Customer Service Calls, with resources and guidelines for recording customer service calls.

title: Here to Deliver the Gloomy, Mesmerizing News
description: Drones, throbs, somber vocals and, every so often, a dance beat orchestrated a dire world when Massive Attack performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night. Massive Attack, a group from Bristol, England, that defined trip-hop in the early 1990s, has only grown gloomier, artier and more politicized through the years. Onstage, even its (typically glum) songs about love took on a topical overlay from the concerts centerpiece: a wraparound backdrop of LEDs spelling out quotations, statistics and headlines. The concert was singlemindedly dour. But it was also frequently mesmerizing.

title: A California Island, Ready for Its Face-Lift
description: Santa CATALINA ISLAND, Calif.

title: A Master Returns With a Firm Grip
description: Kurt Masur seemed deeply gratified by the warm applause and bravos he received when he appeared onstage at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night to conduct the New York Philharmonic. This was his first return to the podium since Alan Gilbert became the orchestras music director.

title: Tony Nomination for Costume Design Withdrawn From Ragtime
description: The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of Ragtime because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production of Ragtime.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: THE BIG DRAW

title: A Post-Punk Band From Australia Reunites, in a Way
description: I need to review the laws of reunion concerts. What are they, again? At least three-quarters of the original lineup is needed to guarantee authenticity? The original lead singer must be present? The band cant have stopped and restarted several times in its working years, because then a reunion is just another start?

title: Local Stop: Flatiron District
description: The area surrounding the districts acutely angled namesake building is rich with history and offers opportunities to shop, dine and enjoy nature.

title: Voices of the Brooklyn Banks
description: The Brooklyn Banks are a skateboarding space under the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge. Riders are preparing for the closing of this area.

title: An Evolution to a Hot Spot for Cuisine
description: The Flatiron district, home of its namesake skyscraper and the jewel-like green space known as Madison Square Park, is a place of endless reinvention. Later this year, for example, Mario Batalis Eataly, an emporium of gourmet restaurants and food markets, is scheduled to open at 200 Fifth Avenue, and the owner of the iconic Flatiron Building plans to convert it into a luxury hotel. For a close look at this always-morphing area, take the N, R or W line to the 23rd Street subway stop. And come hungry. In another of its incarnations, the district is a restaurant destination.

title: Air Products Names Candidates for Airgass Board
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated with Airgas response Air Products and Chemicals, the industrial gases company, on Thursday named its three candidates for the board of Airgas, the rival it is seeking to acquire.

title: Brown Says Kagan Supports Military
description: Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts, one of the Republicans seen as a potential vote in favor of Elena Kagans nomination to the Supreme Court, did not wait long in his meeting with her Thursday to raise her role in barring military recruiters at Harvard Law School.

title: A Father Who Needs Some Supervision
description: Things that might come easily to other people seem to pose special challenges to Lenny (Ronald Bronstein), the Manhattan movie projectionist whose personality is explored in Daddy Longlegs as though it were a mountainous landscape or a daunting mathematical problem. To purchase and consume a hot dog is, for most New Yorkers, a fairly straightforward proposition, but for Lenny it is a gantlet of complications involving money, taste, social norms and the laws of gravity. Lunch does not quite work out as planned, but his response to this minor catastrophe is laughter.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Senate Acts on Credit-Rating Agencies
description: 5:22 p.m. | Updated  The Senate on Thursday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill aimed at addressing the role that major credit ratings agencies played in the 2008 financial collapse, including one proposal that would force federal officials to come up with alternative methods for judging securities and other investments as a way of limiting the reliance on companies like Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors.

title: Next Round in the Adobe-Apple Fight
description: Adobe, the software company, began a nationwide, multi-Web site advertising campaign on Thursday criticizing Apples refusal to allow the Adobe multimedia Flash software on the iPhone and iPad.

title: Promoting the Preakness, 1960s Style
description: Eric Banks is a writer and degenerate handicapper in Brooklyn.

title: High Above Queens, the Dirt Is Deep, and Good
description: Brooklyn Grange, one of the biggest farms to start in the city since the days when Brooklyn and Queens were the nations leading vegetable producers, began to take shape Thursday as a crane hoisted bag after enormous bag of dirt  each weighing more than a ton  onto the roof of an industrial building in Long Island City.

title: Twins Trying to Reverse Yankee Stadium Futility
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The topic got old for Minnesota Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire years ago. And because the Twins keep losing at an alarming rate in the Bronx - Minnesota takes a 10-game losing streak there into Fridays series opener against the Yankees - a question about that futility on Wednesday abruptly swung Gardenhires mood from sunny to surly.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Joy of Being Groupies in Lofty Halls of Ballet
description: Each year, in the spring and early summer, New York becomes a world capital of balletomania. The ultimate American example of this genre of obsession can be found during American Ballet Theaters annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House (which begins with a gala on Monday night). Whats a balletomane? Someone who thinks dancers matter more than choreography.

title: Boulud Opens His First European Restaurant
description: For his first foray into Europe, Daniel Boulud, a French chef who has conquered the New York dining scene, has opened an outpost of Bar Boulud in the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park in London.

title: Dude! Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof Answer Your Questions About Lost
description: There are many small questions in life that confound me and no one is providing me with answers, says Carlton Cuse, an executive producer and show runner of Lost, in an upcoming interview in The New York Times. But whos to say we have to let him off as easy?

title: Ms. Wright Meets Mr. Right, but Will They Be a Pair?
description: The heroine of Just Wright, a formulaic sports romance with the texture of a strawberry smoothie, isnt just any old Hollywood Cinderella in search of Prince Charming. As played by the redoubtable Queen Latifah, this full-figured Cinderella  an unmarried 35-year-old physical therapist and avid New Jersey Nets fan named Leslie Wright  is, in her own self-effacing words, the perfect homegirl.

title: Sweetness From Adversity?
description: Isnt there an old saying that if it rains on your wedding day, youll have a good marriage? Well, Im hoping my normal dose of bumbling will lead to prosperous hives.

title: Setting Up a Rooftop Farm in Queens
description: Over on City Room, Diane Cardwell writes about Brooklyn Grange, a new farm setting up its beds on a 40,000-square-foot rooftop in Queens.

title: The E.P.A. Announces a New Rule on Polluters
description: The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled a final rule on Thursday for regulating major emitters of greenhouse gases, like coal-fired power plants, under the Clean Air Act.

title: An Assault on Hearts and Minds
description: Just about the last thing you would expect to see on a New York stage today  or maybe want to see on a New York stage today  is a juicy romantic melodrama set during World War II. The musty attractions of the genre are best savored in the wee hours of the night, surely, when sleeplessness torments and Turner Classic Movies beckons. Or maybe in a downtown drag bar, where the plucky heroine is portrayed by a biological male outfitted with Joan Crawford shoulder pads.

title: Now Showing | The Selby for Louis Vuitton
description: Tickled as we were by the sight of Mikhail Gorbachev in a Louis Vuitton ad, were glad that LV stopped using world leaders as luxury pitchmen before Ban Ki-moon showed up in a monogrammed thong. In its latest promotional essay, out today, the French juggernaut teams up with the at-home photographer Todd Selby, who calls himself just The Selby. Given that name, and considering all the Louis Vuitton bootlegs, one could easily have called this project The Genuine Article Meets the Definite Article. Alas,The Journey of a Mans Wardrobe showcases the fall/winter collection through Selbys portraits of Vuitton-ified style icons in New York (Ruben Toledo, Andr Balazs and Waris Ahluwalia), along with others from Shanghai, London and Tokyo. Perhaps most interesting for diehard Vuitton fans are Selbys photos of the Vuitton family home in Asnires, France, the place where Monsieur Vuitton moved his workshop in 1859. Visit the site for a peek.

title: In Pursuit of a Long-Distance Romance, Abandoned Long Ago
description: Letters to Juliet represents an interesting paradox: it is a movie that is very nearly perfect without being especially good. Directed by Gary Winick from a script by Jose Rivera and Tim Sullivan, the film fulfills every one of its ambitions with the same kind of brisk efficiency that its heroine brings to her job of magazine fact-checking. But its goals are so modest, so tiny, so timid that fulfillment is exactly what it does not provide. No hard feelings are risked, no feathers of audience sensitivity are ruffled, and as a result no memorable lines are uttered, no startling scenes unfold, and no character emerges toward whom you feel anything more than tepid good will.

title: Uzi Ben-Abraham Duplex on the Market
description: THE nice thing about buying an apartment is that you can customize your space. If you like to cook, you can wave goodbye to that ancient rental stove, with its indelible evidence of steak charred during the Reagan administration. You can stop staring at the bright white rental walls and choose a color. And if clothing is your thing, you can build closets.

title: Condos in Former Hotels on the Market
description: HOW much room service could you get if you lived in a hotel and had $15 million to spend?

title: By Any Means Necessary: An Activists Life as Opera
description: New York City Opera has always prized the peoples opera image that it cultivated in its early days, and when an opportunity to extend that reputation arises, the company invariably takes it. In recent years City Opera has collaborated with the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem on a series of concerts devoted to excerpts from operas by black composers.

title: Joseph Moinian Cuts Co-op Price
description: FOR much of the last 20 years, the real estate mogul Joseph Moinian has been on a shopping spree, buying up some 20 million square feet of residential, industrial and office space. Now hes looking to sell. His five-bedroom Park Avenue apartment has been on the market for over a year, and last weekend it hit the sale rack.

title: Americas Mayor
description: Images from a new exhibition about John V. Lindsay, the former mayor of New York City.

title: You Can Fight City Hall
description: What on earth happened? We enter the fine new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York and see that handsome patrician, boyishly grinning on posters and magazine covers: John V. Lindsay, Park Avenue-born son of privilege, graduate of Yale and Yale Law School and, in 1965, newly elected mayor of New York City. He is just out of his early 40s and is so charismatic, striding through the city streets with such casual authority, that he might have been a gift of the Fates to replace another boyish, privileged political leader, a president assassinated just two years before.

title: 61 Hours
description: Chapter One

title: He Needs Only His Wits and the Shirt on His Back
description: In 61 Hours, the 14th, craftiest and most highly evolved of Lee Childs electrifying Jack Reacher books, we find out about a metal desk in a musty old office that Reacher once occupied in Virginia. Theres a big dent on the right hand side, says the offices current resident, the sultry-voiced woman who holds Reachers old job with the military police. People say you made it, with someones head.

title: BlogTalk: McCains Danged Fence
description: Senator John McCain has a new ad out to show Arizona voters that he is serious about stopping the flow of illegal immigration, and it has drawn snickering from many quarters. The ad, which Steve Benan at Political Animal wrote about the other day, shows Mr. McCain walking along the border in Arizona, with a sheriff in uniform complaining about illegal immigrants. Mr. McCain says, Complete the danged fence.

title: Condos Dominate North Brooklyn Sales
description: IF youre thinking of buying in Williamsburg or Greenpoint, Brooklyn, maybe you envision life in an old warehouse, or perhaps one of those brownstones the borough is so famous for.

title: Avis Seeks Antitrust Approval of Likely Dollar Bid
description: The Avis Budget Group moved closer on Thursday to making a bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, saying it was seeking federal antitrust approval of its potential acquisition. The move is somewhat unusual in that Avis has not yet made a formal offer, while Dollar Thrifty has already agreed to be acquired by Hertz Global Holdings for $1.2 billion in cash and stock.

title: Stars or Not, Cannes Finds Glamour
description: CANNES, France  Thats a lot of French. When these words, uttered with palpable alarm, came out of the mouth of one of the characters in Ridley Scotts Robin Hood, the inaugural attraction at the 63rd annual Cannes Film Festival, it was hard not to sympathize. Nothing seems to strike fear into hearts like the sight of French hordes, a sentiment that will be familiar to those who have elbowed their way through the masses who congregate near the red carpet hoping to catch sight of Russell, Cate and the other boldface names who make the pilgrimage to the Cte dAzur for one of cinemas last glamorous kingdoms.

title: Shedding New Light on Old Friends
description: Alexander Calder and Yves Tanguy  old friends, drinking buddies and Connecticut neighbors  are together again. Or rather, their art is, in a delightful, immersive exercise in mutual illumination at L&M Arts on the Upper East Side. Surprisingly, this has never happened before.

title: Service Disruptions: Half or Whole Hog?
description: City and state watchdogs wanted to know why late-night and weekend subway disruptions were so common, and whether the service changes were justified.

title: Why Design Now?
description: Images from the National Design Triennial at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

title: Thinking Green: Function Over Form
description: As we know, everything is connected. So what happens when the butterfly in Brazil, whose fluttering wings are creating wind-power in Texas, dies off because of pollution or deforestation? Somewhere on the planet, wind drops, energy stalls, lights go out. And whether we know it or not, were all in trouble.

title: Auction House Leaves Without a Farewell
description: Tepper Galleries has folded quietly, without much of a public goodbye.

title: Matthew Barney Series Now Has Two Homes
Where Beauty Collides With Creepy
description: Here is a novel proposition: Henry Darger (1892-1973), the self-taught Chicago recluse who painted big, lurid watercolors of bands of little girls violently persecuted by adult male soldiers, was an art collector. That is what The Private Collection of Henry Darger, a revelatory exhibition at the American Folk Art Museum, is supposed to show.

title: Mark Gertler
description: Economist Mark Gertler reflects on how the Ben S. Bernanke as Fed chairman handled the financial crisis.

title: EMC Now Performing Data Contortion Act
description: EMC has sent big data to a yoga seminar and made it more flexible.

title: Senate Considers Credit Card Fee Relief for Merchants
description: Small businesses may have caught a break in the swiftly moving negotiations over the Senate financial reform bill. On Wednesday, Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois offered an amendment to the reform bill that would loosen the hold that credit card networks like Visa and MasterCard now have over merchants. Senate leaders are expected to bring the amendment up for a vote  an important milestone, because in major bills, most amendments never get this far.

title: In Russia, One Grand Prix Is Over, but Another Is Underway
Dissident Thai General Shot
description: A renegade Thai general was shot in Bangkok on Thursday as the military prepared to encircle the barricaded encampment of antigovernment protestors.

title: Time for Regulators to Impose Order in the Markets
description: If your machine makes a mistake that the dumbest human would never make, then maybe you dont have a very good machine.

title: Life in a Congolese Border Town
description: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africahis first time ever outside of the country.

title: An Evolution to a Hot Spot for Cuisine
description: The Flatiron district, home of its namesake skyscraper and the jewel-like green space known as Madison Square Park, is a place of endless reinvention. Later this year, for example, Mario Batalis Eataly, an emporium of upscale restaurants and food markets, is scheduled to open at 200 Fifth Avenue, and the owner of the iconic Flatiron Building plans to convert it into a luxury hotel. For a close look at this always-morphing area, take the N, R or W line to the 23rd Street subway stop. And come hungry. In another of its incarnations, the district is a restaurant destination.

title: Mark Gertler
description: Economics professor Mark Gertler on the Fed's decision to bail out AIG and Bear Sterns.

title: Jobs That Arent Coming Back
description: I had an article today about structural unemployment  the idea that some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets dont match what employers want (for example, they are highly specialized auto workers, but the only local job opening is for an oncologist). The typical causes of structural unemployment are the three Ts: trade, technology and changing tastes (e.g., consumers want more iPods and fewer C.D. players).

title: The Years Do Go Fast
description: The older sister of a childhood friend has become part of my social circle through a new marriage. Shes lovely. I just received an invitation to a lavish 40th birthday party in her honor. Trouble is, Im 44, and shes older than me. Our mutual friends are now asking when Ill turn 40. I dont want to cause trouble, and Im guessing that her new husband doesnt know her real age. But Im not sure how much new math I can keep track of. Must I rewrite my history just because shes rewritten hers?

title: Excavating What Dad Left Behind
description: What do you do with the detritus of your dead? All those hauntingly, definitively empty clothes; the papers that fill box after box; the books and the knickknacks; the forbidding, uninhabited furniture. The performance artist Cynthia Hopkins has provided her own solution for this emotionally fraught storage problem: she wears what her father left behind. It has become her theatrical costume.

title: TowerBrook to Work With Evergreen on Industrial Deals
description: TowerBrook Capital Partners, a private equity firm, said on Thursday that it had retained executives from Evergreen Capital Partners, an advisory firm, to help it find potential industrial investments.

title: Mark Gertler
description: Economics professor Mark Gertler reflects on how Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, handled the financial crisis.

title: Bronx Flavor
description: "Bronx Flavor" was originally produced and developed by BronxNet and is offered by New York City's government owned and operated television station, NYC Life, through a licensing agreement.

title: Footballer as Life Coach (the Imaginary Kind)
description: There are two Erics in Looking for Eric. One is Eric Bishop (Steve Evets), a middle-aged Manchester, England, postal worker whose existence has been a chronicle of hardship and disappointment, much of it self-inflicted. We first see him driving the wrong way around a traffic circle, as if trying to outrun decades of accumulated anxiety. The inevitable accident is almost redundant, since he was already pretty much a wreck.

title: From Budding Poets, an Ode to Water
description: Where do New York Citys budding poets find inspiration?

title: Gabrielle Rubinstein and Anthony Cheong
description: THE coffee served at a wedding is typically an afterthought.

title: Joe Drapes Preakness Picks
description: The horses in Saturdays Preakness Stakes. The morning-line odds were set by the Pimlico oddsmaker Frank Carulli. The horses are listed in order of preference by Joe Drape, who provided the comments.

title: For Dad, There Are 2 Outs in the Bottom of the 9th
description: In Touching Home Ed Harris, an actor almost incapable of sounding a false dramatic note, gives a deeply affecting portrayal of a homeless alcoholic with a gambling habit living in Northern California.

title: Is Law & Order About to Be Canceled?
description: People close to Law & Order were told Thursday afternoon that the pioneering NBC drama had been canceled. But the network has not yet confirmed the decision, and there were indications late Thursday that talks about its fate were continuing.

title: Facebook Moves to Thwart Cybercrooks
description: Facebook has unveiled new features to help protect your account from getting taken over by cybercrooks, bitter ex-boyfriends or anyone else who might want to impersonate you to do you wrong.

title: 2010 Ford Flex
description: In addition to its distinctive style and versatile accommodations, the Flex is engaging to drive.

title: Imminent End of Secrecy to Shake Up Swiss Banking
description: As Swiss lawmakers appear poised to resolve a tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the countrys pre-eminent financial sector.

title: Chinas School Killings and Social Despair
description: For the past two months, Chinese authorities have been trying to deal with a string of vicious attacks on young children in rural elementary schools. They have clamped down on news coverage, citing fears of copycat crimes and called for heightened school security. But on May 12, a man stormed a village school in Shaanxi Province and hacked to death seven children and two adults. It was the fifth attack since March, all involving middle-aged men using knives, cleavers or tools. Seventeen people have been killed and nearly 100 wounded in the attacks.

title: In 1953 Iran, Sisterhood Sought During a Coup
description: Every frame of Women Without Men and every image within those frames attest to the background of its first-time director, Shirin Neshat, as a photographer celebrated for her explorations of Islamic gender issues. This visually transfixing film, which originated as a video installation, has the feel of an exhibition of Ms. Neshats work whose figures have stirred to life to play out a tragic feminist allegory.

title: MGM Gets Another Reprieve
description: Another day, another plea from MGM to its creditors.

title: A Nod to History in Tale of a Hawaiian Aristocrat and Romance
description: After playing Pocahantas in The New World, Qorianka Kilcher has moved about 5,000 miles west and three centuries ahead for her next feature, Princess Kaiulani, thereby cornering the market on indigenous American princesses who sojourned in England, while also dangerously typecasting herself. At least her role as the pampered, Westernized niece of Hawaiis last king in the late 1800s does not require her to dance expressively in buckskin, though there are a few uncomfortable moments involving hula.

title: Moelis Adds 2 Tech Bankers and a Brokerage Firm
description: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, continued its recent expansion on Thursday, announcing the hiring of two senior technology bankers and the purchase of an Australian brokerage firm.

title: I Capped the Well Competition
description: Could it be that BP read my post seeking a Feynman fix for the unrelenting seabed oil gusher? Theres a new YouTube clip promoting a nationwide competition the oil giant is holding, offering prizes (Lady Ga Ga tickets and a $50 BP gas card) for the winning proposal to cap the leak.

title: What Were Reading: Happiness
description: Here is what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times have been reading over the past two days:

title: Despite Lower Sales, Sony Trims Annual Loss and Predicts a 2010 Profit
description: TOKYO  Sony narrowed its losses last year and forecast a return to profit this year as an ambitious rollout of 3-D technology, as well an aggressive revamping push, start to buoy its bottom line.

title: MGM Gets Another Debt Reprieve
description: From Brooks Barnes at Media Decoder:

title: Affluent Qataris Seek What Money Cannot Buy
description: DOHA, Qatar  Citizens of Qatar appear to have it made. They tend to drive big cars, live in big houses and get big loans to pay for big watches and an outsize lifestyle. They have an army of laborers from the developing world to build a sparkling skyline and to work whatever jobs they feel are beneath them. And their nation has enough oil and gas to keep the good times rolling for decades.

title: Life, Death and Other Subjects
description: Larger than life and headed for death, K. Roth Binew (Mike OConnell), the self-aggrandizing antihero of The Living Wake, is about to succumb to a mysteriously punctual illness. A failed artist and successful alcoholic, Binew aims to spend his last hours tying up his affairs and planning a pre-expiration party: he wants a full house for his final curtain.

title: A Thriving Business Built on Geeks Backs
description: Barb Staples makes geek dreams come true.

title: Leaders Put Different Face on Afghan Drive
description: WASHINGTON  In an unusual public conversation about Afghanistan on Thursday, the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton went to some lengths to depict a looming coalition offensive around Kandahar as not a full-fledged military assault, but, in Mr. Karzais words, a process.

title: A Sci-Fi Love Story
description: Timer, a charming comedy written and directed by Jac Schaeffer, leaves you free to ponder moderately pithy questions afterward, if you choose. For instance: if you knew in advance the exact day you would meet your soul mate, would you be more likely to spend the intervening weeks or years remaining chaste for that future partner, or would you try to squeeze in as many one-night stands as possible beforehand? Which is worse, knowing that your soul mate is still many years in your future, or meeting him or her while youre still in junior high?

title: Under the Pink Carpet
description: One of the shows offered by NYC Life, the television station owned by the city.

title: Secrets of New York
description: One of the offerings on NYC Life, the city's television channel.

title: Money Matters
description: The Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago pays some of the highest government salaries in the state, with 16 district officials receiving more this year than Mayor Richard M. Daley ($198,881.38). The number of highly paid officials in the agency has increased sharply in recent years.

title: Photo Replay: May 13
description: A view of the day in sports, with shuttlecocks and saves.

title: Online Talk, Suicides and a Thorny Court Case
description: The seemingly empathetic nurse struck up conversations over the Internet with people who were pondering suicide. She told them what methods worked best. She told some that it was all right to let go, that they would be better in heaven, and entered into suicide pacts with others.

title: Bleep or No Bleep, Bolder Words Blow In
description: HOW much more frank is the language used in everyday advertising getting? Look, or listen, no further than a print, online and radio campaign for that most prosaic of products, Franks RedHot sauce.

title: An Actors Not-So-Big Break
description: Best Worst Movie, a funny-sad documentary about the 1990 horror movie disaster Troll 2, tries to pin down the alchemy that transports a film from reject bin to cult favorite. When that goal proves elusive, the director, Michael Paul Stephenson, settles for one closer to home: a touching and at times uncomfortable portrait of people making peace with an unwanted past.

title: Ground Shifts Strongly in a Democrats District
description: LOWELL, Mass.  Just two years ago, not a single Republican stepped forward to run against Representative Niki Tsongas, a Democrat, whose late husband, Paul, was a senator from Massachusetts and a presidential candidate.

title: Court Backs Oil Project
description: A federal appeals court on Thursday rejected an effort by environmental and Native American groups to stop exploratory oil drilling off the coast of Alaska that could begin this summer.

title: Teachers Fiscal Sacrifices
description: To the Editor:

title: School Reformers?
description: To the Editor:

title: A City of Warehoused Souls
description: In Here and There, a rough-edged first film written and directed by Darko Lungulov, Robert (David Thornton) is a down-and-out saxophonist from New York so clinically depressed that he can barely interact socially.

title: K.K.R. Posts $674.8 Million Profit in Q1
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reported a $674.8 million profit for its first quarter on Thursday, as it benefited from a rise in the value of its portfolio companies and in fees.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Like Spain, Portugal Hopes to Make Cuts, but It Is Mired in Structural Weakness
description: LISBON  Jos Gago da Graa owns a Portuguese real estate company and has two identical apartments in the same building in the heart of Lisbon. One rents for 2,750 euros ($3,480.21) a month, the other for almost 40 times less, 75 euros ($94.91).

title: Surfers Slaying Exposes Gang Tensions in a Beach Area
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  A wooden cross nailed to a palm tree at the beach is the only physical remnant of Robert Burke Simpson, who spent much of his 44 years surfing here. His blood no longer stains the picnic benches, and his ashes have been sprinkled among the waves.

title: Senate Amends Financial Overhaul Bill
description: WASHINGTON  In the latest sign of the zeal in Congress to get tough on Wall Street, the Senate approved two initiatives on Thursday aimed at addressing the role that major credit rating agencies played in the 2008 financial collapse, including a proposal to end the reliance on companies like Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors.

title: Texas: State Says Company Promising I.R.S. Aid, at a Price, Has Misled Its Customers
description: A national company that claims it can help people in trouble with the Internal Revenue Service has been misleading its clients, charging them hefty fees and failing to deliver on its promises, the Texas attorney general charged Thursday. The attorney general, Greg Abbott, said he was filing a civil law suit against Taxmasters Inc., a company based in Houston that advertises on cable television, claiming deceptive trade practices. The lawsuit says the company persuaded clients to pay thousands in fees through an Internet installment plan and told them that work would begin immediately on their cases. The clients later discovered that no action had been taken. A Taxmasters spokesman said the company would work with the state to resolve the complaints.

title: A Case for Gold at $5,000 an Ounce
description: It sounds like a gold bugs dream. But looking back to the last inflation-adjusted peak price in 1980, its far from impossible that the gold price could soon go above $5,000 an ounce.

title: U.S. Approval of Killing of Cleric Causes Unease
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations decision to authorize the killing by the Central Intelligence Agency of a terrorism suspect who is an American citizen has set off a debate over the legal and political limits of drone missile strikes, a mainstay of the campaign against terrorism.

title: An Immigrant Story
description: Mariana and her two children, Gabriel, 10, and Andrea, 6, have been abandoned by Marianas husband after leaving their native Colombia to join him in Jackson Heights, Queens. Now Mariana  unemployed, not knowing English, kicked out of her apartment and pregnant again  is starting to crack under her mounting misfortunes.

title: With Banks Under Fire, Some Expect a Settlement
description: It is starting to feel as if everyone on Wall Street is under investigation by someone for something.

title: Regular-Season Form Hasnt Held Up in East Playoffs
description: One by one the favorites have fallen: the Penguins, the Capitals, the Red Wings, the Devils. All practitioners of creative, attacking hockey, and all knocked out by regular-season strugglers now playing a creative, attacking hockey of their own.

title: Disputed Judicial Nominee Advances on Party-Line Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Goodwin Liu to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, sending him to the full Senate for consideration after a party-line vote of 12 Democrats in favor to 7 Republicans opposed.

title: Twice Accused
description: How, my heart shrieks, how can I be doing this again? asks Judge Rusty Sabich, the hero of Scott Turows cunning, intricate legal thriller Innocent. And its a fair question, for both the character and his creator. Twenty-three years ago, in Turows best-selling novel Presumed Innocent, Sabich cheated on his wife, was charged with the murder of his mistress and, after a long and exceptionally messy trial, walked. Innocent finds Sabich  just turned 60 and still living, uneasily, with his wife  once more violating his marriage vows, now with a woman young enough to be his daughter: hence the shrieking heart, the italicized self-interrogation. Its only natural that he feel a touch of foreboding in this situation. The age difference between him and his eager lover, a lawyer named Anna Vostic, is of course worrisome, as is the effect this new infidelity might have on his campaign for election to the state supreme court. Sabich has become wary of himself, spooked by the intensity of his late-life desire. But the greatest cause for concern while hes conducting this affair is his wife, Barbara, who is, he knows all too well, dangerously unstable: bipolar and prone to rage.

title: 35 Years On, Islanders See Themselves in the Flyers
description: On April 26, 1975, a 26-year-old rookie Islanders goaltender named Glenn Resch, better known as Chico, leaned down to kiss the goal posts several times during a Stanley Cup playoff game at Pittsburgh Civic Arena, better known as the Igloo.

title: To Nurture Boulder, Back-to-Basics Venture Capital
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Like students who choose to go to college in a small town to avoid the distractions of big-city life, the venture capitalists at Foundry Group have shunned Silicon Valley or New York for Boulder.

title: Boulder, Colo., a Magnet for High-Tech Start-Ups
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Sixty engineers, entrepreneurs and financiers were sipping yerba mate tea at a coffee shop down the street from a bong-and-lingerie store on a recent sunny Tuesday in Boulder, and discussing how Boulder  usually seen as an enclave of hippies, marijuana dispensaries and rock climbers  has become a hotbed of capitalism.

title: Size of Oil Spill Underestimated, Scientists Say
description: Two weeks ago, the government put out a round estimate of the size of the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico: 5,000 barrels a day. Repeated endlessly in news reports, it has become conventional wisdom.

title: Can We Get You Anything Else?
description: The feckless Federal Election Commission has done it again. It is supposed to enforce campaign finance laws and protect elections and voters from the worst money abuses. Instead, it has tailored another loophole in the ban on unlimited soft money politicking  allowing Congressional candidates unrestricted war chests to try to influence the redrawing of electoral maps.

title: Renewed Fight Looms Over Ending Role of Political Parties in Elections
description: In the opening salvo of what could become a major political battle, a dozen New York City activist and civic groups are urging the commission reviewing the structure of city government not to pursue a proposal that would eliminate the role of parties in elections, an idea long favored by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: The Wavering War on AIDS
description: The global war on AIDS has racked up enormous successes over the past decade, most notably by providing drugs for millions of infected people in developing countries who would be doomed without this life-prolonging treatment. Now the campaign is faltering.

title: In New York Trip, Obama Is Optimistic on Economy
description: BUFFALO  President Obama delivered an upbeat economic forecast and a defense of his economic policies on Thursday, telling a crowd at a manufacturing plant here that job growth would continue and that next year is going to be better than this year.

title: Law & Order Series Said to Be in Jeopardy
description: NBC is having trouble making up its mind about Law & Order.

title: Obama Lets Campaign Metaphors Roll
description: President Obama has a metaphor for Republicans: they are like bad drivers, he says, who still want the keys the car.

title: Nominee Scrutinized for Hiring on Race
Mets Lead the Majors in Declining Attendance
description: A year after moving into a sparkling new $800 million stadium, the Mets have the most home victories in the major leagues, but neither their stadium nor their record is translating into box-office success.

title: In India, Hitching Hopes on a Subway
description: NEW DELHI  The trains arrive with a whisper. The doors slide open and a puff of refrigerated air confronts the citys summertime miasma. A bell dings, the doors close and the train whisks its passengers to the next stop.

title: Citing Individualism, Arizona Tries to Rein in Ethnic Studies in School
description: Less than a month after signing the nations toughest law on illegal immigration, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona has again upset the states large Hispanic population, signing a bill aimed at ending ethnic studies in Tucson schools.

title: The Aliens Among Us
description: FOR centuries, speculation about the existence of life elsewhere in the universe was the preserve of philosophers and theologians. Then, 50 years ago last month, the question entered the scientific sphere when a young American astronomer named Frank Drake began sweeping the skies with a radio telescope in hopes of picking up a signal from an extraterrestrial civilization. Initially, his quest was considered somewhat eccentric. But now the pendulum of scientific opinion has swung to the point where even a scientist of the stature of Stephen Hawking is speculating that aliens exist in other parts of our galaxy.

title: Lottery Numbers
Growth of CUNY Chancellors Salary Outpaces Rise in Facultys Pay
description: In his 11 years as chancellor of the City University of New York, Matthew Goldstein has been credited with increasing enrollment, helping raise more than a billion dollars and restoring rigor and energy to a system that had seeped both for decades.

title: U.S. Said to Allow Drilling Without Needed Permits
description: WASHINGTON  The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to BP and dozens of other oil companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency that assesses threats to endangered species  and despite strong warnings from that agency about the impact the drilling was likely to have on the gulf.

title: A Rescue for Affordable Housing
description: The recession has dealt a devastating blow to the federal tax credit program that encourages investors and developers to build affordable housing across the United States. Unless Congress moves quickly to restructure the program, billions of dollars in investment will be lost, along with thousands of affordable housing units and tens of thousands of desperately needed construction jobs.

title: Metric Mania
description: In the realm of public policy, we live in an age of numbers. To hold teachers accountable, we examine their students test scores. To improve medical care, we quantify the effectiveness of different treatments. There is much to be said for such efforts, which are often backed by cutting-edge reformers. But do wehold an outsize belief in our ability to gauge complex phenomena, measure outcomes and come up with compelling numerical evidence? A well-known quotation usually attributed to Einstein is Not everything that can be counted counts, and not everything that counts can be counted. Id amend it to a less eloquent, more prosaic statement: Unless we know how things are counted, we dont know if its wise to count on the numbers.

title: The Bear Market
description: Youre the former chairman of Bear Stearns, the once-revered investment firm that self-destructed in 2008. How do you feel about your successor, James Cayne, who just testified before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington and conceded that he had taken on too much risk?  Enough has been said about Jimmy. There is little I can add.

title: Profit Sharing
description: I live in the United States, and my sister lives in Canada. Last year I needed to borrow $5,000, and she was kind enough to send me the money. At the time, the two countries currencies were nearly at par, so she was out only about 5,020 Canadian dollars. I am now in better shape, but the Canadian dollar is not: it has fallen. To repay her 5,020 Canadian dollars will cost me only $4,267. Assuming the exchange rates hold, may I make $733, or should she be the winner in our inadvertent currency speculation? By the way, shes an accountant, so its not like shes not going to notice. DAVID FOSTER, CHARLESTON, S.C.

title: Valuing $0
description: Lewis Hyde wrote  The Gift  decades ago for an audience of artists, writers and other people who create. He advised these readers that for their expression to endure  to become what we might think of as art  it could not be tailored to the demands of the market. Rather, such work must be made within the context of what he called a gift economy, distinct from the market economy.

title: Quants
description: For the uninitiated, financial writing can sometimes sound like science fiction. Take this sentence from The Quants, a new book by the Wall Street Journal reporter Scott Patterson: To the quants, beta is bad, alpha is good. Out of context, that could easily be mistaken for dialogue from the  Star Trek  franchise.

title: Credit-Card Message Boards
description: For his everyday credit card, a man with the online handle Mogul of Pineapples says he uses American Express Blue Cash, but for special occasions he will break out American Expresss Simply Cash, Bank of Americas Financial Rewards Visa Platinum Plus, Chases rewards Visa and Amazon.com Visa and Discovers More card.

title: Bottom Line
description: In early 2008, when the Portland-based artist and designer Tsilli Pines began experimenting with the metrics of money, she did so out of fascination with her personal finances: she was trying to figure out whether she had enough in the bank to quit her full-time design job and go out on her own. By the time the economy began melting down some months later, her series of collages, "The Figures," started evoking a more collective state of mind. Pines uses stitching, pages from an old bookkeeping manual and the traditional black and red of profit and loss to explore what she has called "the topography of money in human consciousness." In her work, missing assets fall through Swiss-cheese-like holes and risk tolerance appears as complicated as a Pentagon PowerPoint. According to Pines, the piece she created for this issue of the magazine, above, titled, "Corporations," isn't just about the way accounting practices are "wacky on such a large scale for so many businesses." To her, "everything, from the way we are trying to make up for personal losses to the way the economy is being propped up, feels like it's being put back together imperfectly."

title: Texans Cushing Denies Taking Drug That Prompted Suspension
description: Brian Cushing, a Houston Texans linebacker, offered his first public comments Thursday about his failed test for performance-enhancing drugs, but his explanation is unlikely to convince many that he was wrongly flagged.

title: 'Lost': A Character Gallery
description: An interactive primer to help sort out the state of "Lost" characters as the series nears its end.

title: Obama Expands Modernization of  Nuclear Arsenal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama promised Thursday to spend $80 billion over 10 years to maintain and modernize the nations nuclear arsenal, a commitment that could help win Republican support for his new arms control treaty with Russia.

title: While the Senate Fiddles
description: You dont have to look far for proof that this country must cut its dependence on fossil fuels and develop cleaner sources of energy.

title: Judge Asks U.S. to Consider Forgoing Death Penalty in Imprisoned Mobsters Trial
description: A federal judge overseeing the trial of a notorious mobster already serving life in prison is asking the Justice Department to reconsider seeking the death penalty on the new charges.

title: Police Say They Smashed  a Major Bronx Drug Ring
description: They knew what the unmarked police cars looked like, down to their license plate numbers and the dents in their bodies. An apartment building tucked away on a one-way street in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx was their guarded fortress: They could see every car coming their way and brandished guns when they sensed trouble approaching.

title: A Theater in Times Square With Seating for Just One
description: Most Broadway producers would be crushed if only one person showed up for a performance. But an audience of one is exactly what Christine Jones wants.

title: Were Not Greece
description: Its an ill wind that blows nobody good, and the crisis in Greece is making some people  people who opposed health care reform and are itching for an excuse to dismantle Social Security  very, very happy. Everywhere you look there are editorials and commentaries, some posing as objective reporting, asserting that Greece today will be America tomorrow unless we abandon all that nonsense about taking care of those in need.

title: Six Stories Above Queens, a Fine Spot for a Little Farming
description: The stretch of Northern Boulevard near 36th Street in Long Island City, Queens, is about as far from bucolic as it gets: Old industrial buildings loom, traffic whizzes by, car dealerships line the street. Off in the distance, Manhattans skyscrapers glitter, the trains rumble, and the closest thing to a meadow is a small patch of plants the Parks Department has named Triangle 37.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,053 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Charlie Francis, Coach Linked to Steroids, Dies at 61
description: Charlie Francis, the Canadian coach whose star sprinter, Ben Johnson, was the first Olympic champion to be stripped of a gold medal after testing positive for anabolic steroids, and whose unapologetic admission that his athletes used performance-enhancing drugs forced Olympic officials to confront a widespread problem, died on Wednesday in Toronto. He was 61.

title: Stonewalled by the S.E.C.
description: On President Obamas first full day in office, he struck a much-needed symphonic chord in favor of press freedom, openness and a willingness to err on the side of sharing too much information rather than too little.

title: Cellphones Now Used More for Data Than for Calls
description: Liza Colburn uses her cellphone constantly.

title: Prosecutors Seek Longer Term for Ex-Senator Who Tried to Withdraw Guilty Plea
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are seeking a significantly longer prison sentence for former State Senator Efrain Gonzlez Jr., claiming that he lied when he told a judge he wanted to withdraw his guilty plea because he was innocent of the charges.

title: New Delhis Metro Nears Completion
description: New Delhis subway system, known as the Metro, is on track to finish its 118-mile network by fall, right on schedule and within its $6.55 billion budget.

title: At U.S.-Afghan Meetings, Talk of Nuts and Bolts
description: WASHINGTON  On Wednesday, as a delegation of eight Afghan ministers took seats across a polished oval table from President Obama in the Cabinet Room, the leadoff speaking role went to Muhammad Asif Rahimi, an articulate, burly fellow with salt-and-pepper hair.

title: Farmers Markets
description: In the past few years, farmers markets have had a resurgence in the Bay Area and across the United States as consumers seek both a way to connect with their meals and an alternative to large grocery chains. The generation of going green wants to know where its food comes from, how long it is in transit and what techniques are used to grow it  information individuals can get from their grower but not from their local chain store.  RACHEL GROSS

title: An F.B.I. Raid in Newburgh
description: Law enforcement officers raided dozens of homes in the city of Newburgh, about an hour north of Manhattan, in a major show of force against street gangs.

title: A High-Tech Moguls Low-Tech Wine Trail
description: Some have grumbled that Silicon Valley moguls have helped turn the Napa Valley from an agricultural paradise into a winery theme park.

title: Kenyan Constitution Opens New Front in Culture Wars
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The push to pass a new constitution in Kenya, a cornerstone of the effort to correct longstanding imbalances of power and prevent the kind of upheaval that followed deeply flawed elections here, has attracted some unexpected interference  from more than 7,000 miles away.

title: Fighting a Tax Appraisal (and Perhaps Something More)
description: January 2009 was pretty close to rock bottom for home sales prices in San Francisco in recent years. Few would contend that a homes value was soaring.

title: Legal Ticket Scalping Law to Lapse as Albany Debates a New Provision
description: A bill to extend New Yorks three-year-old experiment in legalized ticket scalping hit a roadblock this week as state lawmakers were unable to agree on whether to regulate paperless ticketing.

title: Glimmers of Hope
description: If youre elected president or prime minister in pretty much any country in the developed world today, youre faced with the same set of challenges: to reduce national deficits without choking off a fragile recovery; to trim the welfare state and raise taxes while still funding the things that lead to long-term growth; to try to enact brutally painful measures at a time when voters dont trust their leaders; to do it at a time when politics are polarized and a hundred different interest groups have the ability to block change.

title: Kurds Stage Strike in Iran to Protest Executions of Activists
description: Iranian Kurds staged one of their largest strikes in recent years, closing shops and bazaars in nearly all Sunni Kurdish cities and towns in western Iran to protest the executions of five people, including four Kurdish activists, on Sunday, according to opposition Web sites and witnesses.

title: At Phillips de Pury, the Hammer Falls on the Spoils of a Spree
description: After watching millions and millions of dollars being dropped for Warhols and Rauschenbergs, Picassos, Calders and Johnses at the spring auctions in the last two weeks, it might seem that the money troubles of the recent past were little more than a bad dream  in the art world anyway. But a distress sale that took place Thursday night at Phillips de Pury, the struggling third-place auction house, was a reminder that the ghosts of the recession have not been fully exorcised.

title: Washing-Up Place
description: If we dont have to hide my studying from God, then why from the neighbors? Yentl

title: Elena Kagans Approach to the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Refurbished Liberty Chasing a W.N.B.A. Title
description: The news of Cappie Pondexters desire to be traded was passed along to Carol Blazejowski, the Libertys president and general manager, in midwinter, and she was immediately warmed by the thought. Pondexters agent, Boris Lelchitski, let Blazejowski know that she wanted a one-way ticket out of Phoenix and bound only for New York.

title: Popes Remarks on Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: What Did We Learn From the Spill?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: China: Vice President Turns to Speech Editing
description: Vice President Xi Jinping is urging Communist Party officials to rid their speeches and documents of empty words and political jargon, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. Official documents and speeches are infamous for their empty blather. Mr. Xi, left, who is widely expected to be the next president, told more than 900 officials and students at the Central Committees Party School on Wednesday that they should study party theory and learn from ancient Chinese literature to simplify their writings, Xinhua reported. The content should have substance, he said, and any unhealthy writing could undermine efficiency.

title: Pakistan: Lake Flooding Forces Evacuations
description: Flooding from a lake formed by a landslide in northern Pakistan has submerged dozen of villages and roads and forced a mass evacuation, the army said. The lake stretches for 10 miles across the picturesque Hunza Valley and is rising by three feet a day. The army said flooding could affect 36 villages. Army engineers have built a spillway and expect to drain the lake by the end of the month.

title: A New Life for Dias Old Chelsea Space
description: The red brick building at 548 W. 22nd St., which was home to the Dia Art Foundation from 1987 to 2004 and more recently to a temporary project called the X-Initiative, is about to enter a new era.

title: Russia: Bombing Against Police Kills 5 in Dagestan
description: A bomb attack on a police convoy in the southern Russian region of Dagestan killed at least five people on Thursday, the prosecutor generals office said. Most of the dead were repair workers traveling under police escort to fix a cellphone tower that had been damaged the previous evening, apparently in a sabotage attack.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about Five Days in March, at La MaMa E.T.C. in the East Village, referred incompletely to the casting of the role of Minobe. In addition to Mike Mikos, Wil Petre plays the role. The review also misidentified the character who explains why he likes bad movies. It is Azuma (played by Sean Donovan), not Minobe.

title: Russia: Judge Who Kept Dying Woman in Jail Resigns
description: A judge who denied repeated requests to release a seriously ill businesswoman who died in a Moscow prison last month has resigned, a spokeswoman for the Moscow Region Court said Thursday. The judge, Olga Makarova, stepped down Saturday on her own initiative, the spokeswoman said, though she could not say whether the judge would face charges in the death of the businesswoman, Vera V. Trifonova. A Moscow court ruled this week that Ms. Makarovas April ruling to extend Ms. Trifonovas custody was illegal. The death of Ms. Trifonova, who was suffering from severe diabetes and kidney failure, was the latest of several recent cases to underscore corruption and abuse in Russias prison system.

title: New Members Elected for Human Rights Council
description: The United Nations General Assembly elected 14 new members to the Human Rights Council on Thursday, including several countries accused of human rights violations. Dozens of human rights organizations criticized the selection of Libya, Angola, Malaysia, Thailand and Uganda. The American ambassador, Susan E. Rice, expressed regret that a number of countries with problematic records had gained seats. Washington still views the council as flawed, she said, but will stay on it to help shape its agenda.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Escapes pages last Friday about a car trip on U.S. 281 in Texas and an accompanying picture caption misidentified the site of Glen Rose, Tex., in describing a 300-mile stretch of the highway south to San Antonio. It is about 25 miles east of 281, not on it. The article also misstated the name of a park near the Fossil Rim Wildlife Center, which is close to Glen Rose. It is Dinosaur Valley State Park, not Fossil Rim State Park.

title: Mexico: Traffickers Wife Arrested
description: Federal officials took into custody this week the wife of Joaqun Guzmn Loera, one of the country's most wanted drug traffickers, who is known as El Chapo or Shorty, according to Mexican news media reports published Thursday. Griselda Lpez Prez was detained on Wednesday in Culiacn, the capital of the state of Sinaloa, where Mr. Guzmn's drug trafficking operation is based, unidentified federal officials were quoted as saying.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Pitching Duel Ends With a Wild Pitch
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The Florida Marlins and the Mets are division rivals, but they found some common ground Thursday night at Sun Life Stadium by having a little fun at the expense of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: A New York Outpost For Italian Design
description: A little bit of Italy is coming to West 53rd Street in Manhattan. In September the building at 40 West 53rd Street that formerly housed the Museum of Arts and Design, across the street from the Museum of Modern Art, will open as the Triennale di Milano New York, an exhibition-and-events center focused on Italian design. The building (above, a computer rendering), which is being renovated by the Italian architects Michele de Lucchi and Pierluigi Cerri, in collaboration with New York Studio CUH2a, will have a 9,000-square foot gallery as well as a restaurant, espresso bar, bookstore and shop. The original Triennale was founded in 1923 and is now a Milan foundation with a museum and library dedicated to design. In addition to its New York branch it recently established an outpost in Seoul, South Korea, and will open one in Shanghai. Its expansion is being supported by the Italian Ministry of Economic Development, and, in New York, by Artlivingny, a private company that will operate the commercial elements. The Triennale New Yorks first exhibition will focus on the architect and designer Gio Ponti and will be organized by Germano Celant, the director of the Prada Foundation.

title: Ragtime Is Stripped of Tony Nomination
description: The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of Ragtime because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production. The theater and film designer Santo Loquasto created the costumes for the original Ragtime and for this seasons revival, and several of the costumes in both productions bore similarities. Costume designs that substantially duplicate work from a previous production are not eligible for Tony Awards, according to the Tony rulebook, but no one involved with Ragtime or the Tony Awards made a determination about Mr. Loquastos designs before they were announced on May 4 as among the four nominees for best costume design for a musical. In a statement on Thursday, Tony Award Productions  a joint venture of the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing, which oversee the Tonys  said that the revivals costume designs were too similar to the original designs to be eligible. We learned this too late to remove the costumes from consideration by the nominators but feel that we cannot allow the designs to remain in contention this year, and we must regretfully withdraw them from consideration as a nominee in the best costume design of a musical category, according to the statement. There will be no replacement made for the nomination, and voters will vote for one of the three remaining nominees. The other nominees are Marina Draghici for Fela!, Paul Tazewell for Memphis and Matthew Wright for La Cage Aux Folles.

title: Facebook Background a Mixed Political Blessing and More From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Does a Stint as Facebooks Sheriff Help or Hurt a Politician? | Social media companies like Facebook are at the heart of intense debates over what privacy means in the 21st century, and how well Facebook users can be protected from predators of all sorts. As a Facebook executive, Chris Kelly confronted these policy choices daily. But the changes in online practices may be out of synch with public attitudes. If so, reports Chase Davis of California Watch, Mr. Kelly, a Democratic candidate for Attorney General who used to be charged with protecting security and privacy on Facebook, may soon be confronting some backlash. And while high-tech politicians are not much of a novelty these days, Mr. Kelly is among the first to emerge from the lightly regulated world of social media, where companies that collect and disseminate huge amounts of personal data from millions of users have been the focus of highly publicized privacy and security controversies.A Vineyard-Centric Bike Trail Is Born | One mile down, 43 to go.The Vine Trail in Napa is taking off thanks in large part to the leadership of Chuck McMinn of Vineyard 29, who spent 25 years in Silicon Valley at Intel and running start-ups. At a cost of roughly $1 million a mile, it will take years to complete the full length from the ferry terminal in Vallejo north to Calistoga. Mr. McMinn is applying the same energy to this project as he did to leveraging his high-tech skill and start-up fearlessness to build a gravity-flow winery with microturbine technology allowing it to generate its own electricity with extreme efficiency. Vineyard 29 became one of the hottest high-end wine brands. Then he turned his attention to philanthropic projects like the Vine Trail. It turned out that Mr. McMinns vision and expertise were the exact requirements to build the low-tech Vine Trail, which Mr. McMinn hopes to see finished within 10 years.
