title: The Man Who Never Was
description: In February of 1943, a cast of colorful oddballs developed and carried out one of the most elaborate deceptions of World War II, a plan to disguise the impending Allied invasion of Sicily, framed around the body of a dead man. The deceased, who would wash up on the Spanish coast, was a complete fraud, but the lies he would carry from Room 13 of the British Admiralty all the way to Hitlers desk would help win the war. The defining feature of this spy would be his falsity, Ben Macintyre writes in Operation Mincemeat. He was a pure figment of imagination, a weapon in a war far removed from the traditional battle of bombs and bullets.

title: Operation Mincemeat': The Man Who Was
description: In Operation Mincemeat, reviewed in this Sundays issue by Jennet Conant, Ben Macintyre tells the story of how British intelligence used a corpse with a trumped-up military identity to convey spurious documents to fool the Nazis ahead of the Allied invasion of Sicily. The tale is perhaps best known from the 1956 movie The Man Who Never Was, starring Clifton Webb and Gloria Grahame. The title refers to Maj. William Martin, the nonexistent officer wrapped in the corpse.

title: Bear Down
description: Video | This goes to show you that a mothers cub doesnt fall too far from the tree:

title: One Man Bats for Himself, and One Switches Sides
description: Every now and then we get a defendant who does not trust the system and deems himself best suited to play the role of his own lawyer in court  better suited, that is, than someone who went to law school.

title: Where the Stars Are Built, Not Born
description: THE makers of Bullitt reportedly put together that films legendary car chase in 1968 using two 1968 Dodge Chargers and two 1968 Ford Mustangs. In 1977, the director Hal Needham recalls, all of the mayhem in Smokey and the Bandit was accomplished with five black 1977 Pontiac Firebird Trans Ams.

title: Jobless Recovery
description: Once upon a time, not so very long ago, Dominique Browning had the world at her feet. She had written two inspiring and widely admired books that combined tantalizing fragments of memoir with graceful meditations on the healing power of place. She had  so the first of those books, Around the House and in the Garden, told us  allowed her own home to salve the wounds caused by the brusque ending of a 15-year marriage. Paths of Desire, Brownings follow-up book, applied the same treatment, with the same entrancing combination of humor and humanity, to a beloved garden. What Browning scarcely mentioned in either book was that for nearly 13 years she was also the editor in chief of House & Garden magazine. Work, she now confesses, was the scaffolding of my life.

title: Fords Twin-Turbo V-6: Its All Gain, No Pain
description: OF all the conundrums faced by car-shopping friends, this spurs the most calls for my advice: We need room for the family, but we dont want a giant S.U.V. And no matter what, do not tell us to get a minivan.

title: When a Bank Loses Documents
description: Q.

title: Travel Deals: Memorial Day Getaways
description: Its not too late to find deals for a Memorial Day getaway.

title: The Sponsors Voice Is Heard the Loudest
description: Q.

title: Exclusive Rights to Common Space
description: Q.

title: Nothing to Do but Kill and Wait
description: For five years American soldiers manned a series of outposts in what was perhaps the most hostile corner in all of Afghanistan. The place was the Korangal Valley, which unfolds beneath the crags and terraced ridges of Kunar Province about 25 miles from the border with Pakistan. The idea was to put Americans on the ground to intercept Taliban fighters who were passing through to fight in other parts of the country.

title: Obama Points Finger on Oil Mess
description: 2:30 p.m. | Updated  President Obama delivered a statement on BP and the seabed oil gusher today, decrying the ridiculous spectacle of the three main companies involved in the mess pointing fingers at each other in congressional hearings.

title: Picture Cars
description: movie cars

title: Stopping Pain Without Drugs
description: As a non-surgeon practicing at the busiest orthopedic surgery hospital in the country, Dr. Vijay Vad stands out. Instead of sending his patients to surgery, his goal is to keep them out of it. A sports medicine specialist at New Yorks Hospital for Special Surgery who regularly works with professional golfers and tennis players, Dr. Vad is a believer in the power of the mind-body connection and regularly prescribes yoga exercises and other alternative strategies for his patients. He is also the author of the new book Stop Pain: Inflammation Relief for an Active Life, which is packed with practical advice and self-care options to help chronic pain patients reduce their dependence on narcotics and avoid additional medical procedures.

title: An Oblique Life
description: Margaret Mayfield is 5 years old when her brother Lawrence takes her to see a public hanging. The year is 1883 and the place is Darlington, Mo., 300 miles from St. Louis. The rest of her family has other concerns that day: her mother is at home giving birth and her father, known to all, even his children, as Dr. Mayfield, is attending. Margaret will later claim not to remember much at all about what she saw, allowing only a ghostly recollection of this bit or that bit  of her hand reaching up into Lawrences hand, or of him handing her a bit of a crab apple, or of her bonnet hanging over her eyes so that she couldnt see anything except her feet.

title: Celtics Revival Lost in the Fixation on James
description: This just in: there were other players on the floor besides LeBron James during the Cleveland Cavaliers loss in Game 6 at the TD Banknorth Garden.

title: Truce in Gay Actor Debate?
description: After calling for a boycott of Newsweek, Ryan Murphy, a creator of the Fox television series Glee, has invited the writer of a piece about gay actors published on the magazines Web site to watch the shows writers and its casting process at work. Mr. Murphy called for the boycott after Ramin Setoodeh wrote that gay actors should not portray heterosexual men because they were not believable in such roles. According to Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Setoodeh contacted Mr. Murphy and is going to meet with the shows writers to discuss why they found the piece so offensive and watch the creative process. In a letter Mr. Murphy sent to EW, he said that Mr. Setoodeh felt misunderstood and was receiving anonymous attacks.

title: The Ecstasy and the Ecstasy
description: What is it about church that is so damn sexy? The question has bugged me for a long time. An erotic current runs just below the displays of rectitude and purity, despite the hard pews and organ repertory. I suspect it has to do with the congregants concerted effort to suppress carnality in favor of distant heavenly rewards. Denying the flesh only makes it throb harder. Its tricky to defeat ones own biology, especially when young. It bubbles up during sermons as eyes and thoughts wander. The nape of a boys neck sitting two rows up  that modest strip of naked flesh between hairline and suit jacket  can surprisingly arouse.

title: The Morning Line: Got a Preakness Winner?
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Jamess Off-Season Begins
description: Its official now that the Cavaliers have lost. It is no longer the National Basketball Association. Its the National LeBron Association. There are four teams left playing? Really? Will anyone notice? Or will they all be staring mindlessly at the LeBron James free-agency countdown clock so helpfully posted on ESPNs New York site? Absorbing the endless stories of which direction King James glanced on his way to Krispy Kreme?

title: The 411 on 311
description: Facts and figures about 311, New York Citys phone number created to field complaints and questions of any kind about the city.

title: Its Not Where Hes Going; Its Why Hes Losing
description: Boston

title: Endangered Species: The Telephone Call
description: I hate talking on the phone.

title: Henry Rising
description: The Dead Republic tells of the later life of Henry Smart, an Irishman born in 1901: a handsome man to all the women, an I.R.A. hit man as a teenager, a con man after he arrives in the United States in 1924, and almost a dead man when the director John Ford finds him in the Utah desert in 1946. These events were recounted in Roddy Doyles novels A Star Called Henry and Oh, Play That Thing. But if you dont already know Henry, The Dead Republic is an excellent place to meet him  because its the best of Doyles trilogy and because in it Henry reviews his past while serving as Fords consultant for a movie about the Irish revolution.

title: This Really Happened: Dont Stop Believin Performed by Elton John, Lady Gaga, Sting and Bruuuuuuuce
description: We heard rumblings of this on Twitter last night, but we didnt believe it until we saw it with our own eyes (after being pointed to it by The Awl): a Thursday-night benefit concert for the Rainforest Fund brought together Sting, Lady Gaga, Elton John, Shirley Bassey, Debbie Harry and Bruce Springsteen on a Carnegie Hall stage. So what does this all-star lineup sing? Dont Stop Believin' by Journey, which is the mathematical average of the six performers, we guess? In any case, its like the best episode of Glee ever.

title: The Education of Diane Ravitch
description: Attending high school in Houston in the 1950s, Diane Ravitch came into contact with a teacher named Ruby Ratliff. A passionate lover of literature and a fierce editor of homework, Ratliff, following Tennyson, told Ravitch to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield. The student evidently followed the teachers advice. Ravitch, a historian of American education and assistant secretary of education under the first George Bush, has long sought to find out what makes schools work. She has now found what that is, or at least what it isnt: choice and testing. Her case against both is unyielding.

title: Insights From a Week as a 311 Operator in N.Y.
description: THE lovely sounding gentleman on the other end of the line was simply trying to improve his corner of the world. Instead, he was rapidly losing faith in city government. As I placed him on hold for the third time, I heard him mutter: Shes having a hard time finding it! It was on 1010 WINS this morning!

title: Older Moms, Grandparents and Hand-Me-Down Highchairs
description: The first time I had even a fleeting thought of my own grandchildren came last weekend, as I lobbed most of the contents of my garage into a rented dumpster. (Yep, thats what I asked for on Mothers Day. Best gift ever!) Cracked bike helmets, followed by rain-stiffened mitts, followed by sand-filled boogie boards, followed by bent tennis rackets. As I purged my boys pasts I didnt look back.

title: Odd Smells in New Orleans, Thoughts of the Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS  At almost 300 years old, somewhat moldy from the remnants of Hurricane Katrina and surrounded by muddy water and swamps, this city is not exactly known for being lemony fresh.

title: Keef Speaks!
description: Its Keith Richards! Of the Rolling Stones! On Late Night With Jimmy Fallon! Hes mostly intelligible! Charming, even! What more do you need to know?

title: Love 'em or Hate 'em, New York's White Brick Buildings
description: Manhattans white-brick buildings have never exactly been anyones dream house. But they are hard to beat for value, and their clean lines are drawing midcentury design fans.

title: From Destruction Comes Beauty, Sometimes
description: The other day there was a pretty sunrise, and we wondered whether it might be a belated gift from our old friend Eyjafjallajokull.

title: Will James Saga Blot Out the N.B.A. Playoffs?
description: Its official now that the Cavaliers have lost. It is no longer the National Basketball Association. Its the National LeBron Association. There are four teams left playing? Really? Will anyone notice? Or will they all be staring mindlessly at the LeBron James free-agency countdown clock so helpfully posted on ESPN.coms New York site? Absorbing the endless stories of which direction King James glanced on his way to Krispy Kreme?

title: A Strident Political Voice on Iraqs Airwaves
description: BAGHDAD

title: The Pretender
description: Over the past 10 years, Paul Berman has been exploring a theme: the repudiation by liberal intellectuals of their values and ideals. The theme has been elaborated in several books  Terror and Liberalism, Power and the Idealists and now The Flight of the Intellectuals. Berman himself is a man who identifies with the liberal left.

title: Q&A | Tom Dixon
description: At this years ICFF, the British designer Tom Dixon will present his new INDUSTRY line, as well as the first in a series of limited-edition, self-published books to be updated and re-released every few months. Dixon will also host theFlash Factory, a hands-on booth where his $175, digitally-manufactured Etch lamp will be made on the spot. Conceived for the ICFF and last months Milan Furniture Fair, Etch demonstrates Dixons hopes for the design industry of the future, wherein individual designers will control the entire design process, from concept to consumption, offering mass customization to consumers.

title: Death of a Dream
description: When asked what he hopes to achieve with a book, the nonfiction writer James B. Stewart likes to say that his goal is to inform and entertain, a premise that might raise eyebrows in fustier quarters. But this is a worthy balance for popular history, I think. After all, mounds of new material dont do much good if a book is too dull or dense a slog. Slighting fresh research in favor of entertainment, however, means you end up with Abe Lincoln the vampire hunter.

title: Inside the List
description: FATHER KNOWS BEST: Last August, Justin Halpern was a 28-year-old semi-employed comedy writer living with his parents in Los Angeles when he decided to start posting his 73-year-old fathers irascible, foul-mouthed wisdom on a Twitter feed that well call Stuff My Dad Says. Nine months later, he has more than a million followers, a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner (tentatively titled Bleep My Dad Says) and a book at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Its tough to quote from the book in a family newspaper, but a few recent nuggets from the Twitter feed give a bit of the flavor. On being a proud papa: A parents only as good as their dumbest kid. If one wins a Nobel Prize but the other gets robbed by a hooker, you failed. On marriage: Pressure? Get married when you want. Your weddings just one more day in my life I cant wear sweat pants.

title: NBC Cancels Law & Order
description: NBC confirmed Friday that it had canceled the original Law & Order, bringing an end to a 20-year-old television drama that jump-started an era of television production in New York City.

title: Up Front: Anthony Julius
description: If a public intellectual is someone who can discourse knowledgeably on a wide variety of subjects, then Anthony Julius is surely one of Englands leading public intellectuals. A visiting professor at London University, he has written books on T. S. Eliot, on modern art and, most recently, on anti-Semitism in England (which Harold Bloom, last week in the Book Review, described as a strong, somber book on an appalling subject).

title: New Rules for Congressional Travel
description: The House Democratic leadership took steps Friday to curb the costs of accommodating globetrotting members by putting new restrictions on Congressional travel  one of the favorite perks of House membership.

title: New Qaeda War Minister Warns of Days Colored in Blood
description: BAGHDAD  A man purporting to be the new military commander of the Islamic State of Iraq, the front for Al Qaeda in Iraq, has warned of a long gloomy night and dark days colored in blood, according to a statement circulated on Friday.

title: The Financial Burden of Food Allergies
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores the heavy financial burden parents face when a child is given a diagnosis of food allergies. She tells the story of the Delgadillo family in San Diego, who spend about $400 a month on costs associated with son Andrews food allergies.

title: Weird Tales of GP2 Winners
description: MONACO  Friday is traditionally a down day in Monaco for Formula One. I have come to the paddock anyway to do some interviewing and catch up on a few things, and it is the perfect time to tell a story that I had been intending to talk about since last week in Barcelona, but which Im glad I didnt have the time for.

title: Editors Choice
description: TRIALS OF THE DIASPORA: A History of Anti-Semitism in England,  by Anthony Julius (Oxford University, $45.) Juliuss fiercely relevant book is particularly strong on Shylock, Fagin and the whole cavalcade of anti-Semitism in English literature.

title: Paperback Row
description: FORDLANDIA: The Rise and Fall of Henry Fords Forgotten Jungle City,  by Greg Grandin.  (Picador, $16.) Henry Ford needed rubber to make tires for his cars, and Europeans controlled the Asian markets. So in 1927, he bought 2.5 million acres on the banks of a tributary of the Amazon. The plan was not only to grow rubber but to share the benefits of Ford-style capitalism (high wages, moral improvement) with American managers and Brazilian workers alike. To that end, a replica Midwestern town was built in the jungle. It didnt turn out well, Grandin (inset) explains.  Heart of Darkness resonates through every page, our reviewer, Ben Macintyre, said. A quarter-century earlier, American workers in the Panama Canal Zone lived in settlements that resembled gated communities. In THE CANAL BUILDERS: Making Americas Empire at the Panama Canal  (Penguin, $18) , Julie Greene recreates the lives of the 60,000 people who actually built the canal  the unskilled laborers from Jamaica and Barbados who did the dirty, dangerous jobs, and the Americans in segregated neighborhoods who found themselves as comfortable here as in Illinois, in one visitors words.

title: Censors Without Borders
description: The Chinese-Canadian writer Denise Chongs 1994 book The Concubines Children, a memoir of her maternal grandparents, won admiring reviews and spent more than a year and a half on The Globe and Mails best-seller list. But when her later book, Egg on Mao, came out in 2009, many people responded with trepidation. What I heard most often was, Is this a China-bashing book?  Chong told me over the phone. When I saw the cover, I understood. It features a photo of Chairman Maos paint-splattered face underneath the bold type: The Story of an Ordinary Man Who Defaced an Icon and Unmasked a Dictatorship. The book tells the true story of Lu Decheng, who threw paint-filled eggs at Maos portrait in Tiananmen Square during the 1989 protests.

title: Robert Hasss Empathy and Desire
description: The publication of a volume of selected poems is an appropriate occasion to appraise a poets career, and an equally appropriate occasion to wonder why we use the word career in connection with poetry at all. Many readers would agree with Randall Jarrells definition of a poet as someone who manages, in a lifetime of standing out in thunderstorms, to be struck by lightning five or six times. This assumes that writing poetry is mostly a matter of waiting and hoping, which in turn raises questions about how confident we can be in discussing (to say nothing of criticizing) a poets development. As long as the writer in question makes a valiant effort to prepare himself for revelation  as long as he greets every raindrop by waving a putter, like Bishop Pickering in  Caddyshack   is it really his fault if the lightning striketh not?

title: TimesCast | May 14, 2010
description: Today, more deaths as police move in on anti-government protesters in Bangkok, growing questions about oil drilling permits in the Gulf of Mexico and a Preakness Preview ahead of Saturday's race.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE CHANGELING  By Kenzaburo Oe. Translated by Deborah Boliver Boehm. Grove, $26.

title: Talking Preakness With Alex Brown
description: Join The Rails Alex Brown for his weekly radio show as he talks about the Preakness with two other exercise riders, Andy Durnin and Bob Hatfield, and a guest handicapper, Lisa Grimm.

title: What Percentage of Your Employee Health Plan Do You Cover?
description: In todays post, Paul Downs gets at an intriguing question. One of his readers was under the impression that Paul was covering 100 percent of his employee health plan costs. Actually, Paul said, hes paying 70 percent, and his employees pay the rest.

title: Sharks Hope Momentum Is Not Lost While They Wait
description: Hello, San Jose Sharks  are you still there?

title: Weekend Competition: Punch Lines in Search of a Joke
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest punch lines for jokes they cant be bothered to write.

title: Europes Turmoil Weighs on UBS and Credit Suisse
description: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, downgraded the Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse to neutral from buy on Friday, citing a deteriorating situation in Europes financial community for the cut. The move comes as European markets continued to slide amid growing uncertainty over the stability of the euro, which traded at an 18-month low to the dollar on Friday.

title: What Is Art? Considering and Creating Artistic Works
description: Overview | What is art? Do contemporary installations challenge student notions of what art is supposed to be and do? In this lesson, students experience various works of fine and performance art in the classroom and online as well as consider artists and critics definitions of art. They then create their own definitions and express them in the form of original works for an evening gallery opening.

title: Alex Abrams
description: Mr. Abrams, 44, is an executive vice president of the Real Estate Disposition Corporation, or R.E.D.C., of Irvine, Calif., one of the countrys largest real estate auction companies.

title: Obamas Remarks on Oil Spill Response
description: Following are President Obama's remarks on the response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, as provided by the White House.

title: Liquor License Procedures Return to Normal as Backlogs Decline
description: And now, stunning news from Albany: the demise of a program that was so successful it will soon cease to exist.

title: NBC Cancels Law & Order
description: In a blow to New York actors looking to build their rsums, NBC confirmed Friday that it had canceled the original Law & Order, bringing an end to a 20-year-old television drama that jump-started an era of television production in New York City, according to our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog

title: Animal Crossing
description: Looking at different picture books can feel like taking different kinds of walks in the wood. As you turn the pages the pictures influence the pace at which you read and the attention you give to the images. Some books may feel like being in a forest with tree branches beckoning forward, encouraging you to move at a steady pace down the path. (William Steig is the master of this kind of book, his drawings, easy-going and efficient, so inextricably linked to his words that they lead effortlessly to the conclusion.) Another kind of book may feel more like a great alle of oaks where you are inclined to stop and admire the whorls and indentations of particular trees. In yet another, the experience is more akin to walking through an arboretum, where every turn brings you face to face with an exciting new specimen of bush or flower.

title: Choosing Sides
description: Robert Lipsytes superb young adult novel Center Field makes you wonder if its possible to be neglected and smothered at the same time. Mike Semak, the hero, is basically home alone. His parents, at once overly solicitous and absent, fret over every detail of his high school career while spending all their time at their new flooring store. A passing altercation in a hallway with another student draws threats of lawsuits and criminal charges. Mikes baseball team, and apparently much of his school, Ridgedale High, is run by Coach Cody, a mysterious former Army Ranger hired as dean of discipline because there had been gang violence and drug dealing in nearby New Jersey towns. The school board was afraid it would spread to Ridgedale.

title: Bridge Between Generations
description: Twelve short chapters into Louis Sachars young adult novel The Cardturner, a whale appears. The whale is an inch long, gray and centered above the text; its job is to indicate that the next few paragraphs consist of what the novels protagonist, Alton Richards, calls bridge gibberish, the uniquely dotty lingo of the card game bridge.

title: Life After the Mississippi
description: What if your child wrote a book about your life? How would the story of your days read when channeled through those shrewd, judgmental eyes? Would you seem like God when God walked in the garden, or would you seem like Papa Doc, the tyrant, the crafter of rules and breaker of treaties?

title: Inside, Looking Out
description: Reese Anderson lives in a 93-inch-square jail cell. At 14, hes spent the past 22 months locked away for stealing prescription pads and selling them to a drug dealer. Hell be up for release soon. But its hard to keep your mind on freedom when everyone around you seems bent on self-destruction. Even the name of the jail, the Progress Center, sounds darkly ironic. What could progress possibly mean in a place like this?

title: Blood, Sweat and Teeth
description: If it is a rite of passage to become your most unattractive self when you first hit adolescence, what would it be like if you added traumatic dental surgery on top? Raina Telgemeier knows because it happened to her, and she tells the story in witty and harrowing detail in her graphic-novel memoir, Smile.

title: My Life in Pictures
description: Memory is an act of preservation. To remember, you have to do something: pay attention, take a picture, nab a souvenir. Laurel Crozas I Know Here is a simple and profound book about a child who, on learning her family is moving, draws pictures of her home as keepsakes.

title: Living Large
description: Written especially for the vertically challenged, John Schwartzs Short: Walking Tall When Youre Not Tall at All identifies a well-known coping strategy among those of us who were half-pints. In a world of alpha dogs (bullies at skating rinks, high school girls making slighting comments) we became the smart alecks, the sidekicks, the class clowns. Later in life, Schwartz observes, the related verbal skills can wonderfully pave the way to a career in, say, the upper echelons of journalism (Schwartz is the national legal correspondent for The New York Times and an occasional contributor to these pages). Given that logic, you may wonder whether the newspaper you are currently reading was prepared primarily by those known during their school days as shrimp.

title: Our Preakness Picks, Down to the Wire
description: The Rails contributors make their Preakness selections.

title: Seedorf Responds: Doping, Champions League and the World Cup
description: Q.

title: Google Admits Defeat in Selling Nexus One Direct
description: Googles flagship Nexus One phone debuted earlier this year to much fanfare. The phone was not only flashy  evocative of Apples iPhone in many respects  but Google was also using it to try to change the dynamics of the wireless industry by selling it directly from its Web store and bypassing the powerful wireless carriers.

title: Letterman: Brown is Out
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: They got a new prime minister in Great Britain. Name is David Cameron, and he has pledged to protect the country from terrorism. So today, he met with the nations top T-shirt vendors.

title: Obama Vows End to Cozy Oversight of Oil Industry
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday angrily assailed the finger-pointing among the three companies involved in the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico as a ridiculous spectacle, even as his own administration came under criticism for failing to do enough to prevent an environmental calamity.

title: Waddell Named as Mystery Trader in Market Plunge
description: 6:58 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Nelson D. Schwartz provides more details about Waddell & Reeds role in the market plunge.

title: Living in Wakefield, the Bronx
description: Wakefield, one of the northernmost places in the Bronx, and therefore the city, shares a suburban character with Westchester, its neighbor across the border.

title: After Flood, Repairs at Opry
description: Damaged by a flood two weeks ago, country musics mecca, the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, is in the midst of major repairs. The hall has been stripped to its concrete foundation, The Associated Press reported. The famous six-foot circle cut from the floorboards of the Oprys old home at the Ryman Auditorium and incorporated into the Oprys stage has been salvaged, Steve Buchanan, president of the Grand Ole Opry, said, adding that it would receive a few new coats of varnish.

title: Flation
description: Ever since the economic crisis began there have been two schools of thought about inflation prospects. One school basically has a Phillips curve, aggregate demand view: because major economies are operating far below full employment, we should expect disinflation, and possibly deflation. The other is basically monetarist with a touch of Austrianism: look at all the money central banks are printing and governments are borrowing, it says, inflation  maybe even hyperinflation  is just around the corner.

title: Leno: Tar Balls Have Started Washing Ashore
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC: At a stop in Buffalo today, a woman walked up to President Obama and said, Youre a hottie with a smokin little body. Ill tell you, Betty White is out of control.

title: An Enclave at the Bronxs Border With Westchester
description: THE elevated subway line that clatters northward through the Bronx on White Plains Road comes to an unceremonious stop, just before the city line, at 241st Street. After the hulking metal tracks end, there is nothing overhead but sky. Two more blocks up, at 243rd Street, the street signs change from green to blue, and Westchester County begins.

title: High Season | Montauks Navy Beach
description: Even with the raucous Surf Lodge (locals tend to sidestep it) and summer visitors Robert De Niro and Gwyneth Paltrow on the scene, the vibe in Montauk is still decidedly laid-back.

title: Why Libertarianism Doesnt Work, Part N
description: Thinking about BP and the Gulf: in this old interview, Milton Friedman says that theres no need for product safety regulation, because corporations know that if they do harm theyll be sued.

title: Book Review Podcast: Scott Turow
description: This week: a conversation with novelist Scott Turow about his long-awaited sequel to Presumed Innocent; The Timess legal reporter John Schwartz discusses his new childrens book about the perils of being short; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Blown Up Yet Again, to Movie Size
description: HAS any Hollywood institution shown more dogged persistence than the Saturday Night Live spinoff movie? Over the past 30 years team after team of directors, screenwriters and comedians has tackled a vexing task: turning a successful sketch into a successful feature film. Meanwhile audiences have wondered why SNL even keeps trying.

title: Doctors Found Guilty of Malpractice, but Not Wrongful Death
description: A civil jury found two doctors committed malpractice in their treatment of an Italian cancer patient but were not responsible for her death, a mixed verdict that did little to resolve larger questions about a controversial cancer treatment program at Staten Island University Hospital.

title: A Country Retreat in Brooklyn
description: The artist Joan Snyder and her partner, Maggie Cammer, live in a two-story building with a graceful front porch in Brooklyn.

title: The Climate Bills, Side by Side
description: Many of the differences between the House and Senate climate and energy bills are so slight that you could almost call them similarities, judging from a side-by-side comparison put together by the National Commission on Energy Policy, a bipartisan advisory group.

title: A Brooklyn House With Country Roots
description: THE artist Joan Snyder has lived in many places in her 70 years.

title: The Struggle to Preserve the Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: FOR three years, some of the most powerful forces in New York real estate  including the federal and city governments, developers, preservationists and community advocates  have fought over the fate of a cluster of historically significant turn-of-the-last-century houses known as Admirals Row in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Focusing on Dublin, With the Help of an Informant
description: The creator of the acclaimed HBO series The Wire, David Simon worked at The Baltimore Sun for 12 years. His latest show, a post-Katrina look at New Orleans called Treme, airs on Sunday nights on HBO.

title: What Were Reading: Intelligent Night Owls
Seeing White Brick Buildings in a New Light
description: WHEN Lori Berger began looking for a Manhattan pied--terre three years ago, she came armed with a list of priorities. The West Side was preferable to the East because it would simplify the drive into the city from her familys primary residence in Fairfield, Conn. She wanted outdoor space, which took most prewar buildings off the table. And because she and her husband had lived through kitchen and bathroom renovations at home, they wanted an apartment that they could move into right away.

title: The Tangled Vine Opens on the Upper West Side
description: By any measure, the Tangled Vine is a welcome addition to New Yorks thriving community of wine bars. But by the special calculus required to assess restaurants on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Tangled Vine is manna from heaven.

title: When Salad Meets Sandwich
description: Since Ive never seen a sandwich in an airport that Id want to eat, I like to pack a lunch, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: A Compatible Apartment, With Charm

Her living room sofas had been moved to the attic to make room for more traditional couches. Heavy chintz drapes had been hung over her sheer white curtains. Though it was May 6, a winter garland festooned her porch and a Christmas wreath hung on her front door.

title: Hes Big, Hes Green, and Hes Gone
description: SOONER or later every fairy tale reaches its happily ever after. For Shrek, the long-running animated fantasy franchise about a curmudgeonly ogre (voiced by Mike Myers), his human-turned-ogre wife, Fiona (Cameron Diaz), and his pals Donkey (Eddie Murphy) and Puss in Boots (Antonio Banderas), that time is now. On Friday, DreamWorks Animation and Paramount will release Shrek Forever After, the fourth  and, the studios say, final  installment in the series, in which the titular green guy is thrown into an alternate version of his Far, Far Away kingdom where he never existed and life turned out much differently for his pals. Before the storybook shuts for good, Dave Itzkoff asked some of the Shrek stars about the series and what its ending means to them. These are excerpts from the conversations.

title: Linked In | The Curious Case of Samuels Button

title: Shuttle Atlantis Lifts Off for Final Planned Flight
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a crew of six, a Russian docking module and critical spare parts, vaulted into orbit Friday on a 12-day space station assembly mission, the orbiters 32nd and final planned flight after a quarter century of service.

title: Moral Babies and Painters on High
Malevolent Design
description: In his tragicomic first novel, The Dream of Perpetual Motion, Dexter Palmer takes elements from Nabokov, Neal Stephenson, Steven Millhauser and The Tempest, tosses them into a retro-futuristic blender and hits pure. The result is a singular riff on steampunk  sophisticated, subversive entertainment that never settles for escapism.

title: A Star (Charmingly) Sells the Goods at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  My 10 minutes with Michael Douglas ran precisely 13:58. That, at least, is the time on my recorder, though the hovering, smiling, apologetic if insistent publicist tried to cut it short. Mr. Douglas and I shared our 13 long minutes together on Thursday afternoon on the roof of the Palais Stphanie, a htel de luxe facing the Mediterranean that was recently spiffed up with striped carpeting and a giant palm frond  as in Palme dOr, the highest prize at the Cannes Film Festival  which juts up like an obelisk in the yawning lobby. We were there to discuss his return to his most famous character, Gordon Gekko, the Wall Street don who made us feel so good about greed. Everybody, Mr. Douglas said with a laugh, likes a bad guy.

title: The Accidental Mom
description: More than once in Marina Endicotts new novel, Good to a Fault, you might wonder if youve wandered into the world of Barbara Pym and her excellent women. Theres the poetry-quoting Anglican vicar who lacks a proper helpmeet. And the wittily rendered minutiae of a meddlesome community. And, of course, an inquisitive spinster, Clara Purdy, defined by the absence of Event in her life. Even the metaphors seem plucked from lavender and mothballs. Her self, we are told of Clara, was an abandoned sampler, half the letters unstitched, the picture in the middle still vague. Yet were not in postwar England but in contemporary Saskatchewan, and Claras life is about to be filled with Event. It comes in the first paragraph.

title: The Morning Skate: Mitchell Calls Campbells Rulings Into Question
description: Canucks defenseman Willie Mitchell, who missed the balance of the N.H.L. season and the playoffs after suffering a concussion on a January 16 hit by the Penguins Evgeni Malkin, spoke for the first time yesterday about the hit. The fact that Malkin was not suspended by the N.H.L. caused Mitchell to say he was disappointed in the league and disappointed in Colin Campbell, the N.H.L, senior vice president of hockey operations who handles player discipline.

title: Chameleon Fever, but No Malaria
description: 8th May 2010, Madagascar

title: I Do. I Do. I Do. I Do.
description: Golden Richards, the lonely polygamist of Brady Udalls second novel and third published work of fiction, is not only lonesome but also many other things that, ideally, a patriarch and apostle of the Lord would not be: indecisive, feckless, withdrawn and hesitant. All of which puts his four wives in the excruciating position of having to beg him, often, to embrace his God-given patriarchal authority and make a decision once in a while. At one time it seemed as if Golden, a mammoth, unkempt man referred to as Sasquatch by one of his sons, might be the One Mighty and Strong, a venerated figure in the polygamist society that broke off from Mormonism in 1890 after plural marriage was banned, to be delivered from on high to set in order the house of God. He is still a leading figure in this particular not very well-off community in the far southwestern corner of Utah, near both Arizona and Nevada, as a member of the Council of the Twelve that now, rather sadly, comprises only eight.

title: Practically Speaking, Stocks May Be a Good Bet
description: AFTER a nice run, the stock market looks a lot like the movie Jaws 2: just when you thought it was safe to go back into the water... (cue the menacing music). But before the concern about Greek debt and the wild ride the stock markets took at the end of last week, I had begun to hear people talking up stocks again.

title: The Call in the Middle of the Night
description: As I reported in Fridays paper, serious questions are being raised about the governments estimate of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The estimate of 5,000 barrels per day has not changed since April 28, and many scientists and environmental groups argue that it cannot be right, given the seemingly rapid flow from the undersea well, as seen in this video of the gushing fluid released on Wednesday.

title: The War Beneath the Sea
description: Hitler called Fritz Todt, who ran the state company that built the German autobahns and other monuments of the Thousand Year Reich, our dear Master Builder. Some of Todts most impressive achievements still stand in French ports along the Bay of Biscay: massive concrete bunkers, constructed with slave labor, to shelter the Unterseeboote, the U-boats, of the Nazi navy. The bunkers blast doors were a yard thick, the roofs 25 feet thick. The British tried to destroy these submarine pens with hundreds of air raids and 12,000-pound bombs, but instead wiped out the town of Lorient. Only three houses were left standing by 1945, one of them a chateau occupied by the U-boat fleet commander, Adm. Karl Dnitz. When, in 1987, filmmakers needed a set for the popular submarine movie Das Boot, they simply moved into La Pallice  one of the occupied French ports  where the old machinery stood intact and dim Gothic lettering still proclaimed its exhortations and prohibitions from the unmarred walls, Richard Snow tells us in A Measureless Peril, his evocative and at times moving account of the American role in the Battle of the Atlantic.

description: A new agency whose name, Purpose, signals the kind of campaigns it hopes to produce is creating for Livestrong, the Lance Armstrong initiative that fights cancer, a virtual version of an annual bicycle race.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs election commission announced Friday that it had completed a partial recount of ballots from the countrys election two months ago and found no widespread fraud or irregularities.

title: Monster Burgers in San Francisco
description: I dont eat as many burgers as I used to, but Im in a bit of a frenzy, burger-wise, developing recipes for a Mini that will run in a couple of weeks. Which I suppose is my excuse for visiting San Franciscos Upper Haight yesterday to eat at Rosamunde Sausage Grill, which does burgers Tuesday only. As one of the people who took me said, Sometimes you just want a burger, and one without a farms name attached to it.

description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. - The experiment of batting Jose Reyes third could be coming to a merciful end soon. Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said before Fridays game that he was open to the idea of moving Reyes back to the leadoff spot, where he probably belongs.

title: Commission Seeks to Revoke Licenses of 633 Cabbies
description: Updated, 4:02 p.m. | The citys Taxi and Limousine Commission will try and revoke the licenses of 633 drivers for routinely overcharging customers as part of a scheme that cost passengers $1.1 million, it was announced on Friday.

description: New Yorks leading gay rights group, the Empire State Pride Agenda, is poised to select a senior aide to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein as its next executive director.

title: Stars Sing to Save Rain Forests (and Maybe Redeem the 80s, Too)
description: Camping in the rain forest got a new meaning on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. It was the annual benefit for the Rainforest Fund that features Sting and is produced by his wife, Trudie Styler. The fund supports the preservation of rain forests worldwide and the rights of their indigenous peoples. The camp was in this years lineup  including Elton John, Lady Gaga and the diva of James Bond movie scores, Shirley Bassey  and some wry production numbers.

title: Asked and Answered | Shirin Neshat
description: Shirin Neshats Women Without Men, which opens Friday in New York, represents this experimental photographer and video artists first venture into feature filmmaking, and its already proven to be an auspicious start. Neshat won the Silver Lion for Best Director at the Venice Film Festival last year for her exploration of political and religious oppression in her native Iran. And given the increased international attention to Iranian politics in recent months, the New York-based artists work  much of which deals with gender and identity in the Muslim world  is more in demand than ever. A comprehensive monograph of her work is out this month from Rizzoli, and she has just optioned the novel The Palace of Dreams, by Ismail Kadare, for her second film.

title: Farmers Markets by the Numbers
description: In the past few years, farmers markets have experienced a resurgence in the Bay Area and across the United States as consumers have sought ways to connect with their meals and an alternative to large grocery chains. A new generation wants to know where its food comes from, how long it is in transit and what techniques are used to grow it  information individuals can get from their growers but not from their local chain stores.

She loved her health insurance; it was hard won and she didnt want to cash it in for what she viewed as some schleppy government issue. Jan Brewer and tourism-industry leaders are so worried about the loss in convention and tourism business that they are setting up a task force, funded by $250,000 from the states commerce department, to counter what they say is misinformation about the new law.

It fell short of the 9.8 million for Game 4 of last years western conference final between the Los Angeles Lakers and Denver Nuggets.

description: Strawberry-rhubarb pie is a classic spring dessert. But heres an alternative: ultra-tart rhubarb makes an unbelievably good crisp. Check it out in this weeks Minimalist column.

description: IN the past, my preferred method for finding the ideal dish of stir-fried beef and snow peas would be to order in from all the Chinese restaurants in my neighborhood, and sample my way to the best.

description: Why did David Parker and Jeffrey Kazin call their West End Theater dance series Soaking Wet? Could they have been waiting for the moment that has just arrived? One of their current shows is called Soaking Wet Shorts. Research (that is, asking Mr. Parker) turns up a more prosaic reason; its a play on the initials of the theaters name. And that theater is a New York City curiosity: a small space with a soaring ceiling, framed by curtained galleries, in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, on the Upper West Side.

title: They Have Made a Desert

title: Carrying the Burden of a Great History Modestly
description: For a musical ensemble with a famous name, legacy is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, a storied name can grab attention. On the other, an illustrious history can be burdensome when it sets up expectations that are difficult to live up to. The Pro Arte Quartet, which performed at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening, is presumably acquainted with both sides of the issue.

title: Weekend Fare

It will also be available indoors: 1220 Avenue of the Americas (49th Street), (212) 759-5941.

title: Where Light Replaces Sound, and Movement Offers Comfort
description: At one moment in the hourlong Necessary Weather, Sara Rudner and Dana Reitz are dancing simultaneous solos, each in a separate pool of light created by Jennifer Tipton. Even if you disliked dance, the show  a revival of a 1994 collaboration by these three women at the Baryshnikov Arts Center  would be worth seeing for Ms. Tiptons astounding contribution; and even if you already knew from many other productions that Ms. Tipton has long been the worlds most remarkable creator of lighting for dance, you havent seen her most miraculous ideas until youve seen Necessary Weather. But this particular moment is memorable because of the quite different ways the two dancers react to the light.

title: Arts Groups See Mayors Budget Plan and Shudder
description: It has become a New York version of Washingtons cherry blossoms: the springtime tussle over the citys culture budget. The mayor puts forward his plan for the coming fiscal year, as he did on May 6; arts institutions insist they will be ruined by the cuts to their allocations; and the City Council puts in additional funds  sometimes more than the mayor has taken out  to ease the pain.

title: In the Iraq War, People Acting Like Animals, and Vice Versa
description: LOS ANGELES  Its alarming, this life after death, muses one of the many ghosts that haunt a ravaged city in Rajiv Josephs play Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo. Of course, life before death was no ticker tape parade for Mr. Josephs cast of characters, either. Set in the chaotic first days of the American invasion of Iraq, this boldly imagined, harrowing and surprisingly funny drama considers the long afterlife of violent acts, as well as the impenetrable mysteries of the afterlife itself.

title: Custom-Made Clothes to Match Your Kicks
description: MARK SERRANO says he spends 98 percent of his money on sneakers and the rest on food. He looks it. Thin as a skeleton, he sports spotless black Nikes  one of more than 200 pairs he owns.

description: The flash crash on May 6 that transfixed investors  and has been the source of finger-pointing ever since  may not have originated in the canyons of Wall Street or a hedge fund managers European lair.

title: Toasting Graduation and Making the Scene
description: It is all about chatty group dining at this Lower East Side restaurant and lounge that specializes in small bites, almost like cocktail-party fare, tailored to the number of people in the group  no dish of three dumplings for four people, said Chris Santos, the chef-owner and a judge on Chopped on the Food Network. Five years after its opening, Stanton Social is usually packed with a mix of creative types  models, musicians, photographers, foodies, cast members of Gossip Girl  and the people who like to watch them. On Thursday night, under a throbbing backbeat, university students at several tables celebrated graduation and the end of exams.

title: Debit Fee Cut Is a Rare Loss for Big Banks
description: WASHINGTON  Retailers have begged Congress for years, in vain, to limit the fees they must pay to banks when customers swipe credit or debit cards. Bills never reached a vote. Amendments were left on the table. The Senate did not even grant the courtesy of a committee hearing.

description: With the aim of depoliticizing a largely Republican assault, the leading lobbying group for small businesses has joined officials from 20 states in their legal challenge to the new health care law.

He injected his hip-hop sensibility into clothing with Phat Fashions and moved into television with Russell Simmons Def Comedy Jam. Mr. Simmons recently created GlobalGrind.com, a Web site for the hip-hop community. A native of Queens, he has since migrated to a penthouse in Lower Manhattan.

description: It is something of an annual budget ritual: Public libraries, always among the first city services to be threatened with substantial cuts in financing, are forced to face the abyss, only to be saved in the end, in whole or significant part.

title: Hawks Cut Loose Coach
description: The Atlanta Hawks made significant improvement under Coach Mike Woodson, but he lost his job Friday, four days after the team was swept by the Orlando Magic in the second round of the playoffs. General Manager Rick Sund, after consulting with the ownership group, decided not to offer Woodson a new contract. So ended a six-year coaching tenure in which the Hawks won just 13 games in Woodsons first season, then improved every season since  including three straight playoff appearances.

title: Theres Something About Art School Girls
description: Spring is here and, with it, the damp heat of desire  a substance that, while invisible, can still be felt like pollen in the air. The following poems about desire were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. title: Up Next, How I Outran the Giant Fireball
description: There are roughly 101 reasons a man can end up blindfolded and hogtied in the trunk of a car, says Baron Ambrosia, dressed as usual in the manner of a Blaxploitation-era pimp. Believe me, Ive tried them all. However, this particular circumstance stemmed from one of the most beloved of Latin foods, the pastel.

description: Ron Fimrite, a writer and author whose wry take on sports made him a fixture at Sports Illustrated for more than 34 years, died April 30 at his home in San Francisco. He was 79.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas legal advisers are considering asking Congress to allow the government to detain terrorism suspects longer after their arrests before presenting them to a judge for an initial hearing, according to administration officials familiar with the discussions.

description: SACRAMENTO  When organizers of the Tour of California, the most prestigious professional cycling race in the United States, decided to move their event to May from February this year, they took a calculated risk.

title: A Hole in the Spring Sky
description: Twenty-five years ago this month, a small team of scientists discovered that the ozone layer above their Antarctic station was thinning more and more every spring. The layer protects life on earth from the suns ultraviolet light. The response to that discovery is a rare, happy environmental morality tale.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Worshiping at the Idol Church
description: ITS 10:01 p.m., and my mother, who has learned the art of the text message for this express purpose, is weighing in with her feelings on the latest American Idol results-show telecast. So glad Aaron Kelly survived, she writes, her fandom for the polite, pint-size teenager unwavering in the wake of his deeply unconvincing cover of Blue Suede Shoes the night before.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

Old Music, via New Technology

description: New York City moved on Friday to revoke the cab licenses of 633 taxi drivers who it said routinely charged customers higher out-of-town rates for trips within the five boroughs. The city said some of the overcharging was so egregious that it had asked prosecutors to investigate.

title: Acting Happy Wins Black-Eyed Susan; Leparoux Injured
description: 10:18 a.m. | Updated Julien Leparoux has no broken bones after being examined at a hospital, according to his friend Fanny Salmon. He is sore and bruised but is expected to ride. He has eight mounts Saturday, including Pleasant Prince in the Preakness.

title: In East Hampton, Art and Craft in Motion
description: The line between art and craft is relaxed at three exhibitions mounted this season at LongHouse Reserve in East Hampton, a 16-acre sculpture garden and preserve founded by the textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen. Mr. Larsens own creations have included, among others, curtains for Lever House and seat fabric for Braniff International Airways.

title: Jobs for Albanys Do-Nothings
description: Here are two important dates to keep in mind. April 1. Thats when New York State was supposed to have a new budget. And June 1. Thats when the state is scheduled to make a payment to local schools that is about $1 billion more than the cash on hand.

title: Want Cheese With That?
description: At With Cheese Please!, a 10-month-old fast-food place in Rockville Centre, you can order a simple grilled cheese on white ($3). Or you can go all out and have a bun made of grilled cheese sandwiches, with a six-ounce Angus cheeseburger between them ($9.25).

title: Study Pokes Holes in Air Bag Standards
description: New research into front air bags in automobiles is raising troubling questions about their effectiveness for drivers wearing seat belts.

title: Still Homeless in Haiti
description: Of the more than 1.5 million Haitians left homeless by the Jan. 12 earthquake, about 7,500 have been moved from the most dangerous areas of crowded tent cities to new resettlement sites. The conditions in those tent cities are grim. Thunderstorms are fierce, and the plastic sheets and tarps distributed after the disaster are fraying, along with the peoples patience.

description: Among the disastrous moves that turned Wall Street into the Wild West was a 1999 ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission that let stockbrokers call themselves advisers without making them abide by the law that requires investment advisers to put their clients interests first.

description: Im bowled almost over by how many readers replied so intelligently, and revealingly, on this subject: the mystery of dreams and dreaming.

title: Rustic Barbecue With a City Twist
description: THOUGH it has made strides in recent years, New York hardly qualifies as a barbecue Mecca on the order of, say, Kansas City or Memphis. Still, New York was the namesake chosen by the five co-owners of Big Apple BBQ, who include the executive chef, Roy Bruce, formerly of Rothmanns Steakhouse in East Norwich. The rustic spot in Glen Cove opened in April in the quarters that were last home to Wild Harvest.

title: Made to Order
description: When Zeytinia, a specialty market with branches in Manhattan, New Jersey and Connecticut, opened in Croton-on-Hudson nearly six years ago, it filled a hole in northwest Westchesters culinary landscape. Customers have been drawn ever since by the 30-plus choices at the salad bar ($6.99 a pound) and the vast array of grocery items and prepared foods.

title: Independent Inquiry Into Oil Spill Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration moves to end a conflict-of-interest problem in the operation of the Minerals Management Service, a rising chorus of experts is demanding that it rectify a similar conflict and appoint an independent blue-ribbon commission to investigate the gulf spill.

title: Setting the Mood With Dramatic Flair
description: MUCH thought has gone into the ambience at Finalmente, a handsome, sophisticated restaurant and wine bar in Sleepy Hollow. Careful touches of Baroque and Venetian Byzantine have created a dramatic vibe, with Moorish pierced-metal lighting fixtures and a pair of lantern sconces that look as though they came straight off a gondola dock or the doorway to a palazzo on the Grand Canal.

title: In South Africa, an Unlikely Leader on AIDS
description: CAPE TOWN  In a nation ravaged by AIDS, a disease still hidden in shadows of stigma and shame, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa has begun to engage in an extraordinarily open conversation about sex, AIDS and H.I.V. prevention, one ignited in part by his own recent admission that he had unprotected sex during an extramarital affair.

title: Junk Shot Is Next Step for Leaking Gulf of Mexico Well
description: HOUSTON  Can golf balls save the gulf?

title: In Cleveland, Sports Fans Cheer Until It Hurts
description: CLEVELAND  The three sports bars on Coventry Road, in the eastside Cleveland suburb of Cleveland Heights, are among the places that Northeast Ohios sports fans congregate by the hundreds for important games. In galvanizing moments, the roar of their simultaneous cheers can be heard blocks away.

title: G.I.s Find Bullets Still Flying at Outpost in Iraq
description: ASH SHURA, Iraq  Technically, American soldiers have stopped fighting in Iraq. But they can fire back when attacked, which happens frequently in this village of wheat and barley farmers, as well as an uncomfortable number of Baathist insurgents.

description: Pleasantville

description: Sandra Lee, a sunny on-screen chef with a homey Midwestern manner, has built a media empire around how-to advice.

title: Hey, Hey, Theyre the Monkees
description: THE four members of Big Time Rush  the boy-band-within-a-TV-show that Nickelodeon has been pumping  were being their usual adorable selves at the Chelsea Piers sports center: making a racket, chatting with strangers and cracking lame jokes. A female staff member wondered aloud just who these guys were.

title: Where the Table Is at the Farm
description: Meals at Bush Meadow Farm embrace the farm-to-table concept to its fullest: Nearly everything on the breakfast and lunch menus is raised and processed within the confines of this family-run enterprise.

title: Italian Flavors, With Water Views
description: CONNECTICUTS magnificent coastline may be littered with restaurants, but its not that easy to eat well by the water. Assaggio Ristorante, subtitled On the Harbor, does a better job than most. Under the shadow of Interstate 95, Assaggio has an urban water view with soundtrack to match: the hum of highway traffic punctuated by the occasional growl of a train.

title: A Dolls House in Contemporary Suburbia
description: When Henrik Ibsens Nora Helmer first took off her wedding ring, emptied her purse and slammed the door, it caused a sensation. Some audiences at A Dolls House reviled her for abandoning her husband, Torvald, and their three children. Others recognized in her desperate act a first, necessary step to adulthood after a lifetime of allowing men to define her.

title: Arms and the Airport
description: Do you support allowing people to carry loaded guns into an American airport? Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey asked the attorney general at a recent Appropriations Committee hearing.

title: Corrections
description: A film column on Friday about the Cannes festival misstated part of the title of a film shown at last years festival (the composer of the films music, Alexandre Desplat, is on this years jury). It is A Prophet, not The Prophet. The column also referred incorrectly to a film being shown this year, Tourne (On Tour). In the movie, a troupe of performers tours provincial France, not provisional France.

title: Hartford to Play a Native Sons Works
description: WHEN Edward Cumming became the Hartford Symphony Orchestras music director in June 2002, he was determined to give Charles Ives a prominent place on his programming list. European colleagues had long asked him why more Americans did not champion Ives, a native son of Connecticut and one of Cummings personal favorites.

title: An Overdue Welcome Home
description: Watching a new documentary about Vietnam War veterans, I was surprised at how old they looked and how worn their faces had become. These were fellows who had once laughed and danced to the music of the Beatles and Motown.

title: Church Crisis Shakes Faith of German Town
description: OBERAMMERGAU, Germany  The residents of this Bavarian village have connected with the Roman Catholic Church in a particular and persistent way: every 10 years since 1634, they have brought the crucifixion of Jesus Christ to life in a Passion play that has earned them worldwide renown but no small amount of criticism.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Brazils Iran Diplomacy Worries U.S. Officials
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva heads to Tehran this weekend to make what many Western diplomats consider a last-ditch attempt at persuading Iran to temper its nuclear ambitions, officials in Washington have expressed concern that the effort could backfire, helping the Islamic republic to block  or at least delay  the United States and its allies from imposing sanctions.

title: Fed Up, Greece Lists Tax Dodgers
description: Trying to crack down on rampant tax evasion, the Greek authorities have made good on promises to name  and shame  some of the worst offenders.

title: Senate Panel Acts to Bar Changes to Human Spaceflight Program
description: President Obamas effort to reshape the nations human spaceflight program encountered another obstacle Friday as a Senate committee sought to block any changes to the program through the end of the current fiscal year, Sept. 30. The Senate Appropriations Committee has added the clause to a supplemental budget package that includes money for troops in Afghanistan, and Senate staff members doubt that the House will make any changes or that Mr. Obama would reject the bill. Last year, Congress passed a measure that prohibited ending or changing NASAs Constellation program to return astronauts to the moon. The new clause affirms that prohibition and adds that the money allocated to the Constellation program shall be available to fund continued performance of Constellation contracts.

title: Rotarix Vaccine Approved for Children
description: The Rotarix vaccine made by GlaxoSmithKline is again recommended for use in children, two months after some samples were contaminated with a virus found in meat products. The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it had no evidence that the virus posed safety concerns and that the vaccines benefits outweighed any potential risk. The agency urged suspending Rotarix use on March 22 after an academic research team found pieces of porcine circovirus virus type 1, or PCV-1, in materials used to make more than 69 million doses globally.

title: Turkish Party Asks Court to Reject Changes
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys main opposition party asked the Constitutional Court on Friday to declare unlawful proposed changes to the Constitution that the opposition says would undercut some of the nations most staunchly secular institutions, including the court itself.

title: New Restrictions Are Imposed on House Members Air Travel
description: The House Democratic leadership took steps Friday to curb the costs of lawmakers globetrotting by putting new restrictions on Congressional travel, one of the favorite perks of House membership. Under new rules announced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, representatives and their committee aides will be required to fly coach or economy instead of business class on flights of less than 14 hours. The speaker also required more documentation for the rationale of the committee-arranged trips known universally as Codels, short for Congressional delegation. The rules do not apply to the Senate.

title: Liberals in Limbo
description: Is Left becoming a four-letter word?

title: Lena Horne, Who Moved Barriers and Emotions, Is Remembered
description: To thousands of black soldiers in World War II, she was, as one put it on Friday, our pinup girl.

title: Staging the Lessons of Literacy
description: On stage at Symphony Space, the actress Rita Wolf narrated the story of a birthday gathering of a Dominican family in the South Bronx. The plot twist: a visit from the police.

title: Pulse
description: An art seller blends the classic and the creative; styling tips for the slicked-down wet look; and more items.

title: Paperless Reading Materials
description: Je te plumerai la tteJe te plumerai la tte

title: Karpov Finds Support in a Surprising Place: Russia
description: In an unexpected development, Anatoly Karpov, the former world chess champion who is running for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, seems to have secured the endorsement of the Russian Chess Federation.

title: Genetically Engineered Distortions
description: A REPORT by the National Research Council last month gave ammunition to both sides in the debate over the cultivation of genetically engineered crops. More than 80 percent of the corn, soybeans and cotton grown in the United States is genetically engineered, and the report details the long and impressive list of benefits that has come from these crops, including improved soil quality, reduced erosion and reduced insecticide use.

title: Companies We Keep, and Pay For
description: Just about 10 years ago, the Cond Nast publishing company moved into 4 Times Square, and newly minted No Parking signs declared that the spaces out front were reserved for FHVs  that is, they were the exclusive domain of for-hire vehicles, the black town cars that waited in tight ranks for the companys senior officials. The FHV signs, planted in front of new skyscrapers in Midtown and Lower Manhattan, flew as the standards of the gilded age. They were the least of it.

title: Bloggingheads:  Confirmation Error
description: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and Lawrence Lessig of Harvard Law School debate Elena Kagan's confirmation hearings.

title: Bloomberg Plan Would Simplify Gun-Permits
description: The Bloomberg administration announced on Friday that it was moving to simplify the process for New Yorkers to obtain gun permits, thus speeding up a set of byzantine licensing requirements that gun-rights advocates have long criticized as among the most restrictive in the country.

title: Magics Van Gundy: Cavaliers Looked Bad Because of the Celtics
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The playoffs are a marathon, and, for some teams that marathon has a slow pace. The Orlando Magic is set to resume its march against the Boston Celtics on Sunday in the Eastern Conference finals. Because it has swept through the first two rounds, Orlando will have played eight games in four weeks when it meets the Celtics.

title: Details Emerge About 3 Men Detained in Bomb Case
description: The three Pakistani men detained by federal authorities who are investigating the failed Times Square car bombing came from varied backgrounds: one was a computer programmer, one a gas station attendant and one a cabdriver.

title: A Passion Play Where Devotion Wanes
description: The dedication of Catholics who participate in a centuries-old ritual in Oberammergau, Germany, is being dampened by their disappointment.

title: Dinky or Bus? A Town Is Torn
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The run of the train known as the Princeton Dinky is both impressively long and unusually short. For 145 years, this rail link in a college town has ferried students and commuters over the briefest of distances. But Year 146 has not been kind to the nations shortest regularly scheduled commuter route, which travels a four-minute, 2.7-mile stretch of track between a small station at Princeton University and a larger one at Princeton Junction.

title: When Signs Are Stolen, Managers Mostly Shrug
description: MILWAUKEE  Except for a brief look at ESPNs coverage, Willie Randolph, the Milwaukee Brewers bench coach and a former Mets manager, said he knew little about the latest sign-stealing controversy involving the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Panel Upholds Infringement in Optical Device Case
description: Avago Technologies won a patent-infringement case against the Emcore Corporation and can seek an order to block imports of Emcores opto-electronic devices used to connect computers in a local area network, the United States International Trade Commission said Friday. The commission it would let stand Judge Theodore Essexs finding that Emcores products infringe on one Avago patent, and not a second patent, according to a notice on the agencys Web site. The six-member commission ordered both sides to submit arguments on whether an import ban should be imposed. Avago, based in Singapore, filed the complaint a year ago, seeking to block fiber optic components like transmitters, receivers and transceivers made by Emcore in Thailand. The patent found to be infringed, issued in 1994, is related to features of optical communications systems that transit digital information using light waves. Shares of Emcore, which is based in Albuquerque, fell 11 cents, or 9 percent, to $1.15.

title: In Game and Series, a Rally to Remember
description: BOSTON  The players on the Philadelphia Flyers bench, which had been a dark place as they tumbled into a three-goal abyss in Game 7, suddenly jumped up and down, slamming their sticks against the boards. The Bruins had too many men on the ice, they shouted. The referees, too, had noticed.

title: Granderson Tests His Timing but Measures It in Weeks
description: In the batting cage beneath the stands and behind the Yankees dugout Friday night, center fielder Curtis Granderson hit a baseball off a tee. As athletic feats go, it was not a big deal.

title: China: U.S. Engineer Is Released
description: The Chinese authorities have released an American engineer who had been detained since November 2008 on accusations that he violated trade secrets, the United States Embassy in Beijing said Friday. The engineer, Hu Zhicheng, was released late last month and is still in China, but plans to return home soon. Mr. Hu was detained for 17 months in the city of Tianjin over what appeared to be a dispute involving automobile technology. Detentions of foreign citizens in China are common in commercial disputes.

title: Portugal: Pope Wraps Up Visit
description: Wrapping up a four-day visit to Portugal aimed at shoring up Christian belief in increasingly secular Europe, but in which he also spoke out against the sexual abuse crisis in the church, Pope Benedict XVI on Friday appealed to Catholics to spread the faith not only to non-Christians in faraway lands but also in socio-cultural environments closer to home. Celebrating Mass in the northern city of Porto, he added that the church was ready to dialogue with different cultures and religions.

title: CBS Leads With Crime
description: With its Thursday-night crime shows and the seasons second-to-last episode of  Survivor,  CBS easily led the ratings in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates, The Mentalist delivered the largest audience of the night as 14.6 million viewers tuned in at 10 p.m. for the CBS procedural. At 9, CBSs CSI drew 13.3 million viewers, slightly more than the 13 million who watched Survivor at 8. ABC ranked runner-up, largely due to Greys Anatomy at 9 (10.9 million) and the third-season finale of Private Practice at 10 (9.3 million). Fox finished third for the night and NBC was fourth.

title: Claims Of Safety Issues at Los Angeles Opera
description: Opera singers periodically lash out at directors and their productions, and now the Los Angeles Opera has taken its turn. Two performers in the companys new Ring cycle, created by the visual artist and director Achim Freyer, have criticized the production as dangerous for the singers and of dubious artistic value. This entire production has been a trying and difficult time, the tenor John Treleaven was quoted as saying by The Los Angeles Times on Friday. He also said, The character development that I bring to the part is almost expunged by this clownlike makeup. Mr. Treleaven, who plays Siegfried, said he had suffered two minor injuries on the raked stage. The Times quoted Linda Watson, who sings Brnnhilde, as calling the set the most dangerous stage Ive been on in my entire career. She added, It takes years to be able to sing a Ring and to just toss this all away  he doesnt say it in words, but his gestures speak louder than words. Christopher Koelsch, head of artistic planning for the company, said in a statement on Friday that the company places the highest priority on safety in our onstage environment, and takes every precaution to prevent incidents and that we are proud of the overall work, as well as the contributions of each individual within it. Individual operas in the $32 million production have been performed since last season, and the full cycle will be presented starting late this month as the centerpiece of a Wagner festival.

title: Rosa Rio, Organist From Silent Films to Soap Operas, Dies at 107
description: On Oct. 6, 1927, the day The Jazz Singer splashed noisily across American movie screens, Rosa Rio broke down and wept. Al Jolson was talking, and the very sound of him, she knew, would put her out of business.

title: Craig Kauffman, Sculptor in Plastic, Is Dead at 78
description: Craig Kauffman, who in the 1960s helped put Los Angeles on the art map with audacious experiments in molding industrial plastic to create ethereal wall-mounted sculptures  some resembling giant pieces of jelly candy  died Sunday in Angeles City in the Philippines. He was 78.

title: Twins Test Rodriguez, but He Has the Answer
