The telethon, shown on the Great American Country television channel, began with Mr. Paisleys performance of his song Welcome to the Future, after which he announced his donation. If there is a silver lining, he said, its that the world is getting to see Nashville at its best through this tragedy. The concert also featured performances by Sheryl Crow, Kellie Pickler and Lady Antebellum, as well as Keith Urban, who played the Beatles Help while his wife, Nicole Kidman, watched. Scott Borchetta, the chief executive of Big Machine Records, which releases music by Taylor Swift and other artists, also donated $100,000 to the telethon, which will benefit the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee.

title: Mays Political Best Sellers
description: Laura Bushs memoir, Spoken From the Heart, debuts at No. 1 on this months Caucus list of political best sellers. While she reveals little in the way of surprising details, the former first lady writes about the fatal car accident she was involved in as a youth that killed her friend. She also discusses some of her husbands presidential decisions, noting a key split over gay marriage, which she advised him to play down as a political issue.

title: Outgoing British Ministers Joke About Deficit Falls Flat
description: When there is a government change in Britain, it is customary for the outgoing ministers to leave a note to their successors, offering some advice. But when David Laws, the new chief secretary of the Treasury, arrived at his desk, he found some unexpected words.

title: G.M. Posts First Profit in 3 Years
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Upfronts: NBC, Claiming Momentum, Unveils Its New Programs
description: Pressing the reset button after a few years it would like to forget, NBC unveiled a bevy of new dramas and sitcoms to advertiser clients Monday morning. The network impressed the hundreds of assembled media buyers with previews of the high-octane drama The Event and the married spy caper Undercovers, among others.

title: At New Istanbul Hotel, Luxury at Lower Prices
description: Hotels in Istanbul tend to be either touristy affairs in the Old City or splashy (and pricey) luxury digs that hug the shores of the Bosporus. The House Hotel Galatasaray, which opened last month in Beyoglu, is aiming for the space in between: its a short stroll from the popular and central Taksim Square, but with rates starting at a fairly reasonable 120 euros (about $150).

title: India Counts Civilians Among Dead in Maoist Attack
description: NEW DELHI  A passenger bus carrying civilians and Indian police officers through a remote region at the heart of the Maoist insurgency hit an explosive device on Monday. The authorities were still verifying the number of dead, but the local police chief said at least 23 people had been killed.

title: Pilot Season
description: Much prognosticating about the worlds emerging destinations is pure speculation, but consider where the airlines are placing their bets. New routes point to where the money is  and provide a glimpse into travels crystal ball. Case in point: Lufthansa is now flying from Frankfurt to Iraqs newly expanded Erbil airport for the first time in 20 years, catering to workers in the oil and gas industry. So what do the airlines latest touch-downs tell us about where to go next?

title: Nutrition: Study Finds Eating Nuts Helps Cholesterol
description: Eating about two and a half airplane snacks worth of nuts every day helps lower total cholesterol and bad LDL cholesterol, and improves the ratio of total cholesterol to good HDL cholesterol, a study reports.

title: Community Board Manager Challenges Espada
description: Yet another challenger with more ambition than political experience has entered the race to topple the embattled State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. from his northwest Bronx district seat.

title: Perceptions: Hookahs Safer Than Cigarettes? Wrong
description: At least in Canada, many young people seem to believe that hookahs and other water pipes are safer than cigarettes, researchers say.

title: Patterns: Testing Link Between Diabetes and Family History
description: Diet and lifestyle contribute to diabetes, but so does family history. So Australian researchers undertook an unusual experiment: they recruited healthy volunteers from families with and without a history of Type 2 diabetes and overfed them.

title: Cameron and Conservative Reform
description: Daniel Larison wonders about the enthusiasm that reform-minded American conservatives (like yours truly, among others) have expressed for the decentralizing, Philip Blond-influenced, Red Tory aspects of David Camerons project in Britain:

title: Central Bank Buys Billions in European Debt
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank disclosed Monday that it had bought 16.5 billion euros in bonds in the first week since taking the unprecedented step of intervening in markets to halt a sell-off of Greek and other European debt.

title: When the Stars Are Misaligned
description: If you were rating the weekend by the number of times you looked at the sports news and said, No way! it was a truly remarkable weekend. At every turn there was a forehead-slapper. Mariano Rivera, the Old Faithful of baseball relievers, gave up a grand slam, which happens slightly less often than Halleys Comet. Syracuse, which seems to win every N.C.A.A. title in lacrosse (but actually doesnt), lost in the first round to Army. Roger Federer, who by tennis law must be referred to in reverent, hushed tones reserved for immortals, whiffed on a ball to lose match point to Rafael Nadal.

title: Europes Debt Crisis Casts a Shadow Over China
description: HONG KONG  The pain of the European debt crisis is spreading as the plummeting euro makes Chinese companies less competitive in Europe, their largest market, and complicates any move to break the Chinese currencys peg to the dollar.

title: Afghan Roundup
description: A brief survey of some of the Afghan stories in Mondays papers:

title: Mamatetsu
description: A Japanese term for mothers who  via their children  develop a fascination with trains.

title: Ford Fiesta Gets 40 M.P.G. on the Highway
description: Ford has spent years prepping the North American market for its Ford Fiesta subcompact, which was conceived in the automakers British studios nearly three years ago. It is a testament to the British teams Kinetic Design language that the Fiesta, which arrives in United States showrooms this summer, looks fresher than anything in its segment. And according to Ford, the Fiesta returns better mileage, too.

title: Mikes World: Inside the Button-Down Mind of Mike Myers
description: How often do you get a half-hour or so to poke around the head of Mike Myers? Almost never. Mr. Myers, the soft-spoken Saturday Night Live-performer-turned-Austin Powers star, can be press shy and tends to let his characters do the talking for him. He also hasnt had a major screen role since The Love Guru in 2008.

title: Ginos Makes It Official: May 29 Is the End
description: This time, Ginos means it.

title: For Some Brokers, Location Is All Relative
description: Last year, when many Park Avenue real estate brokers were struggling to sell their co-ops, Vickie Palmos and her business partner helped sell 37 condos in Astoria, Queens, as if it were 2006.

title: The Morning Line: Post-Preakness Gloom and Doom
description: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Shirin Neshats I Am Its Secret
description: We publish many striking images in the arts feature that accompanies our fiction and nonfiction Chronicle columns. But I Am Its Secret, by the Iranian-born photographer and artist Shirin Neshat  which shows a veiled Muslim woman (who is Neshat herself) staring intently into the camera, her skin covered with a swirl of black and red Farsi script  attracted more than the usual attention during our production cycle for Sundays issue as editors checked the copy.

title: Getting Treated for Common Ailments Online
description: In a recent Bucks post, Doctors, Let Me Pay You for E-Mail, my colleague Ron Lieber said he would gladly pay his family doctors a flat annual fee to be able to e-mail them questions and get a timely electronic response, and he questioned why this isnt the norm.

title: TimesCast | May 17, 2010
description: Today, the Supreme Court bans life without parole for children except for murder, Iran agrees to ship some of its uranium to Turkey and Tuesday's primaries foreshadow this fall's midterm elections.

title: The Claim: Caffeine Helps Prevent Nighttime Accidents on the Job
description: THE FACTS

title: World Warm, Chicago Cooling
description: The month of April, and the stretch from January through April, were both the warmest such periods in the instrumental record, according to the latest analysis by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The warmth is there despite a fading El Nio is heating of the Pacific.

title: Providence to Take Virtual Radiologic Private
description: Shares of Virtual Radiologic jumped about 30 percent on Monday after the health care company agreed to be taken private by Providence Equity Partners.

title: Numberplay: Prime Rib at Hogwarts
description: At last we have barbecue weather here in the Northeast, and doubtless many of you have started dusting off the old grill in preparation for Memorial Day. If you are considering ribs, we have a perfect set of problems for you, conceived and linked to grilling ribs by our graphic genius Justin Thyme.

title: Obama Signs Bill Intended to Promote Free Press
description: Updated: President Obama signed legislation on Monday intended to promote free press around the world, a bipartisan measure inspired by the murder in Pakistan of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter, shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: The Compromises of City Living
description: In this weeks installment of my column, The Appraisal, I explore how and why New Yorkers rent and buy apartments in terrible locations with terrible drawbacks  an elevated train rumbles past your bedroom window; drivers on the B.Q.E. gaze into your kitchen while you peel carrots for a stir-fry; you wake up each morning to a coughing bus bleeping louder than any alarm clock.

title: Upfronts: CBS Orders Up Some Series, Including New Hawaii 5-0
description: While NBC and Fox are announcing new schedules on Monday, CBS is notifying producers about which new shows it is ordering for the fall. So far, it has given series orders to three dramas: Hawaii 5-0, Defenders and Blue Bloods.

title: High Low | Oliver Spencer for Topman
description: What: Oliver Spencer for Topman desert boots

title: In France, Sleep Like a Hamster
description: Most hotels encourage guests to sleep like a king. A hotel in Nantes, on the French Atlantic Coast, is designed to let guests sleep like a hamster. No, this is not a joke.

title: Jessica Biel on the Verge of Verge Musical
description: Jessica Biel, best known for appearing in the television series 7th Heaven and for being Justin Timberlakes girlfriend, is expected to star in this falls Broadway musical adaptation of the movie Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, the films director, Pedro Almodvar, said in a report in The Daily News of New York.

title: A Eureka for Hardy Biologists
description: Biologists braved flash floods and torrential storms on an expedition to Indonesias Foja Mountains, a remote area on the island of New Guinea.

title: Justices Limit Life Sentences for Juveniles
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that juveniles who commit crimes in which no one is killed may not be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: In iPhone-BlackBerry War, Standard Chartered Chooses Choice
description: For a Wall Street financier, few tools are as essential as the BlackBerry. Fingers are all but glued to the devices plastic keyboard, eyes fixated on its blinking message light.

title: Ex-Consultant to Pay $2.8 Million in Galleon Case
description: A former director of McKinsey & Company who pleaded guilty to criminal charges in the Galleon Group insider trading case reached a $2.8 million civil settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to a court document filed on Monday.

title: Four Are Tied for Lead of U.S. Championship
Donovan Discusses His Bid for Attorney General
description: This weekend, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, became the first Republican to formally enter the crowded field for New York attorney general.

title: Another Reduced Summer Season for the Metropolitan Opera
description: Tough economic times have kept the Metropolitan Opera to a reduced summer season for the third year in a row. The Met said on Monday it would put on six free recitals in parks across New Yorks five boroughs, July 12 to July 29. It called the performers, to be accompanied by piano, rising stars; the established star Nathan Gunn will sing on the first program. The Met stopped its tradition of presenting full-length operas in concert after the summer of 2007 for budgetary reasons, presenting a gala concert in 2008 and recitals in 2009.

title: Morningside Heights, 11:30 A.M.
description: As Columbia College at Columbia University held its graduation ceremony, demonstrators protested the lack of guaranteed jobs for local tradesman in the universitys expansion plans.

title: British Airways Moves to Block Strike
description: PARIS  A British court late Monday granted an emergency injunction to British Airways, blocking plans for a strike by its cabin crews just hours before it was to begin, the airline said.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Spring Vegetable Soups
description: After teaching a cooking class on knife skills recently, I ended up with a refrigerator full of diced carrots, celery, onions and peppers. So how to clear them out? I made soups.

title: McCain Shakes Up Campaign Staff
description: John McCain, who is known for reshuffling his team at the height of his campaigns, is changing his campaign manager and her No. 2 in his fight to win a fifth term as Arizonas senior senator.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: Bailey Gardiner, San Diego, hired four employees. They are: Jen Jenkins, public relations account coordinator; Sayamon Riddang, graphic designer; Maria Swanson, advertising account supervisor; and Ryan Thompson, advertising account supervisor.

title: You Dont Have to Be Jewish to Love This Campaign
description: As fans of Something Sort of Grand-ish from Finians Rainbow could tell you, ish, when used as a suffix, is meant to express everything from roughly and somewhat to kind of and close to. In an effort to get close to younger potential donors, a philanthropic organization is seeking to take the ish from Jewish and turn it into an expression of its own.

title: A New Clue to Explain Existence
description: Physicists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory are reporting that they have discovered a new clue that could help unravel one of the biggest mysteries of cosmology: why the universe is composed of matter and not its evil-twin opposite, antimatter. If confirmed, the finding portends fundamental discoveries at the new Large Hadron Collider outside Geneva, as well as a possible explanation for our own existence.

title: Priscilla Finds Her Men for Broadway
description: The musical version of Priscilla Queen of the Desert, adapted from the 1994 film about three transvestites making their way across the Australian outback, may have a few surprises to offer but the identities of at least two of its leads isnt one of them. Confirming longstanding reports, the musicals producers said on Monday that its Broadway transfer would star Will Swenson (Hair) as Tick/Mitzi, and Tony Sheldon, an Olivier Award nominee for the shows West End production, who will reprise his role as Bernadette. (No casting was announced for the role of Adam/Felicia, the third member of the trio.) The musical, which was presented in Australia and New Zealand before it reached London, is written by Stephan Elliott, the writer and director of the film, and Allan Scott, and directed by Simon Phillips. A Toronto run is scheduled to begin in October before the production moves to a yet to be determined Broadway theater next spring.

title: Now Baking | First Prize Piess SMores Pie
description: The smoky, spicy food at Williamsburgs  Fatty Cue is certainly deserving of the star  Sam Sifton gave it last week. But on my visit a few weeks ago, it was the smores pie  made by the sister of the executive chef, Corwin Kave, Allison, of  First Prize Pies  that had my table scrambling for the last bite of campfire craziness.

title: Why Did the Bruins Lose? Let Us Count the Ways
description: Plenty of words have been used to describe the Boston Bruins second-round playoff loss to the Flyers, in which they became just the third N.H.L. team to blow a 3-0 series lead. Embarrassing. Humiliating. Devastating. Pathetic. Inexcusable.

title: Taking the Pulse on Yankees-Red Sox
description: The Yankees and Red Sox enter a two-game series Monday night in very different places.

title: Searching for Your Name in a Moment
description: It is now possible to search the Moment in Time interactive gallery by the name given in the photographers credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose).

title: Godard Practices Film Socialism
description: CANNES, France  If I am remembering clearly  and my head is filled with so many densely layered words and images, it is hard to unpack them  the first image in Film Socialism, the new movie by Jean-Luc Godard, is of two red-headed parrots, side by side on a tree limb. The parrots are among a handful of animals that appear in the movie, which had its press premiere Monday morning at the Cannes Film Festival, including a pair of hilariously talkative cats (whose meows are, in turn, parroted by a young woman watching them on a laptop), as well as a llama and a donkey. Surrounding these animals is a menagerie of talking, quoting, babbling human beings, speaking in French, German, Russian, English and Arabic, among other tongues.

title: Wireless Umbilical Cords
description: In response to my post last week about a study showing that mothers voices calmed their daughters as surely as their hugs, Lorrie Goldin, a therapist in Northern California, had the same thought I did  but what is the effect of all that long-distance soothing on Mom?

title: Putin Blames Mine Leaders for Skimping on Safety
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin delivered an icy reproach Monday to the management of the Raspadskaya coal mine in Siberia, where around 90 miners and rescue workers were killed in twin methane explosions, expressing bafflement that its director had not been dismissed for safety violations.

title: Leaving the Chameleons of Madagascar
description: 9th May 2010, Madagascar

title: Obamas Aunt Is Granted Asylum
description: BOSTON  An immigration judge has granted asylum to President Obamas aunt and will allow her to stay in the United States, her lawyers said Monday. She could become a citizen in about six years.

title: The Morning Skate: Changes Needed for Game 1 Losers
description: To win in the playoffs, teams must adjust their game plans, juggle their personnel, take what they learned from earlier outings and put it to use quickly. Thats the task facing Montreal and San Jose after Game 1 losses in the conference championships.

title: More Help for Hoarding
description: Thanks to reality programming and cable television, to Hoarders on A&E and to Hoarding: Buried Alive on TLC, more people are probably aware of compulsive hoarding as a disorder than ever before. (And The New Old Age can probably take a bow, too.)

title: Behind the Battle for Psychiatric Solutions
description: Universal Health Services executives had little to say on Monday about the reportedly heated negotiations over the weekend in the battle to acquire the health care provider Psychiatric Solutions. A deal with Bain Capital had seemed likely, but Universal apparently outbid the private equity firm with its offer of $2 billion in cash.

title: Travel Deals: Family Discounts at All-Inclusive Resorts
description: Club Med is offering family discounts of up to 50 percent at several resorts. The seven-night Family Escapes package starts at $549 a person, all-inclusive, and is available at the Club Med Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic, La Caravelle on Guadeloupe and Buccaneers Creek on Martinique, Columbus Isle in the Bahamas, Cancn Yucatn and Ixtapa Pacific in Mexico and the Sandpiper, in Florida. Book by June 28 for travel through Dec. 11. Reserve at (800) 258-2633 or clubmed.us

title: TimesCast: Senate Primaries
description: The results in three Senate primaries on Tuesday may provide lessons to help frame the debate for the remaining six months of the midterm election season, with Democrats fighting to hold their control of the House and Senate. The Timess Jeff Zeleny discusses why these primary elections in Arkansas, Pennsylvania and Kentucky matter, and what the outcomes could mean for President Obama, in Mondays edition of TimesCast.

title: NATO Urged to Look Beyond Borders
description: PARIS  NATO must be willing to fight and operate far from its borders to defend its members in a new world of terrorism, piracy and cyberattacks, according to a proposed strategy for the alliance released Monday.

title: All Investment Mistakes Are Investor Mistakes
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: Q. and A.: Tending to His Bayou Constituents
description: Charlie Melancon represents the Third Congressional District of Louisiana, which covers much of the states rural southeast. This region of bayous, wetlands, rivers and estuaries, where many earn their living through commercial fishing, is now directly threatened by the huge oil slick hovering just off the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: U.S.O.C. Ex-Chief Earned $1 Million
description: Stephanie Streeter, the acting chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee during a tumultuous year that culminated in Chicagos losing its bid to host the Olympic Games, earned $1,006,336 in salary and other compensation in 2009, according to federal tax records made public Monday.

title: France Moves to Free Man Who Killed Iran Official
description: PARIS  A day after Tehran freed a young French academic accused of spying, France prepared on Monday to release an Iranian serving a life sentence for assassinating an exiled former Iranian prime minister, Shapour Bakhtiar, in August 1991.

title: Law & Order Creator Still Looking to Bring Original Back
description: Is Law & Order really dead?

title: Now Showing | Migrating Forms
description: When the New York Underground Film Festival folded back in 2008, its programmers created the Migrating Forms organization, which is hosting the 2nd edition of its eponymous festival at the Anthology Archives through to May 23. We wanted to take a fresh break, said Kevin McGarry, co-director of Migrating Forms. Some critics thought the NYUFF was too associated with the 1990s brand of anti-establishment type of films and didnt encompass the trend toward experimental videos, he explained.

title: Soon, Three Times the Space to Help the Needy
description: The kitchen coordinator works at a desk inside a windowless pantry. A colleague works at a computer kept inside a closet. Without space to get dressed, men who use the free shower change clothes in the hallway.

title: White House Names Deputy F.B.I. Director as T.S.A. Chief
description: Updated:  Third times the charm? President Obama on Monday made his third try to fill the vacant chair atop one of the governments primary security agencies, this time picking someone who may have an easier time passing the F.B.I. background check  the deputy director of the F.B.I.

title: Great Debate: Developing Argumentation Skills
description: Overview | What makes for a strong debater and for a winning debate? In this lesson, students consider the characteristics of effective debate and learn about various formats. They then engage in debates about controversial issues in the news and/or curriculum and conclude by writing evaluations.

title: Iraqi Court Supports Barred Candidates
description: BAGHDAD  An appeals courts ruled Monday that no winning candidates would be barred from Iraqs Parliament for ties to the Baath Party, Iraqi officials said, ending for now a bitter dispute that tarnished the election in March.

title: Welcome to the Mets K-Zone
description: Watching the Flushing Nine play these days, fans might be forgiven for thinking they are traveling through another dimension, not only of sight and sound, but of mind, a dimension that Rod Serling might call the Mets K-Zone.

title: Your Lost Questions, Answered
description: If you watch Lost, youre almost guaranteed to have plenty of questions. Over the next few days well provide some answers.

title: When Grieving Is an Awkward Family Affair
description: Last time I checked, Elisabeth Kbler-Rosss stages of grief did not include a sixth consisting of getting wildly drunk, picking up an older man and then canoodling with his teenage son. But we all have our own ways of coping, right?

title: Motherhood: Norway Tops List of the Best Places to Be a Mother; Afghanistan Rates Worst
description: Norway is the best country in the world in which to be a new mother, followed by Australia, according to Save the Childrens annual State of the Worlds Mothers report, issued this month.

title: Happy 10th Anniversary to Tivoli Audio
description: Tivoli Audio, a maker of high-end table radios, is celebrating its 10th year in business with a new clock radio thats clad in aluminum, the material from which traditional first-decade anniversary gifts are made.

title: Panthers Name Dale Tallon General Manager
description: Dale Tallon, the former general manager of the Blackhawks who was largely responsible for rebuilding them into an N.H.L. power, has been selected as the new general manager of the Florida Panthers.

title: With a Kindle Hiring Spree, Amazon Gears Up for Battle With Apple
description: Since Apple announced its plans for the iPad, Amazon has shared few details about how it would respond to the competition for its Kindle. But over the last few weeks, it has offered some more clues.

title: New Evidence of a Fluid Sea on Saturns Moon Titan
description: Last July, a glint of sunlight from Saturns moon Titan sped through space and fell upon the sensors of the Cassini spacecraft, starting a process of discovery that is now strengthening the idea that the icy moon harbors liquid seas.

title: Lower Fees Ease Tensions in Private Equity
description: Despite long lock-ups, shaky performance and coming regulatory changes, limited partners in private equity firms say that on the whole they are sticking by the general partners who run the firms, according to a new study from Bank of New York Mellon and PEI Media.

title: Caffeine on the Night Shift
description: How much do night workers depend on caffeine? In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores the role of caffeine in helping night shift workers stay alert.

title: From Police Chief to Prison: Kerik Starts Sentence
description: In the coming days, Bernard B. Kerik will begin work as a groundskeeper, or maybe a housing orderly, at a starting salary of 12 cents an hour. His blog, where he defended his blemished record and discussed finding strength in Rocky movies, will go dark. His exercise regimen, which helped shape his fireplug physique, will be limited to the hours between dinner and bedtime.

title: Is This a Recovery? Or Is It Just a Bump?
description: Note to readers: Like my recent posts chronicling My Week in Cash Flow, this post was written at the time of the events described  this one on March 10.I hired a guy today.

title: Pictures of the Day: Columbia University and Elsewhere
description: No, violence did not suddenly end on Monday. But Fred R. Conrad did find a delightfully fresh view of that hardy perennial, the commencement ceremony. So we began the report with it.

title: Women Win a Bias Suit Against Novartis
description: A federal jury in New York reached a verdict on Monday requiring Novartis Pharmaceuticals to pay $3.36 million to 12 former female sales representatives for discrimination in pay and promotions.

title: Book Shelf | Vroom Vroom
description: Photographers have long been obsessed with the body, capturing the male and female form in many states of rest and unrest  dressed and not. Koto Bolofo, the South African fashion photographer best known for his graphic, dynamic black-and-white photographs, which have appeared in LUomo Vogue and many international editions of Vogue, has chosen to shoot a different kind of body for his latest Steidl tome: a car. More specifically, the body of the highly coveted and collectible Bugatti.

title: Real Films Meet Reel Football
description: Abas Suans life straddles two worlds that seem inexorably locked in eternal conflict.

title: Before First Season, Orchestra Festival Lines Up Its Next
description: Orchestral pickings typically become slim this time of year in New York. That will change next year when Spring for Music, a new festival of concerts featuring North American orchestras of many shapes and sizes, takes over Carnegie Hall from May 6 to May 14. In addition, the festival is just announcing its lineup for a second season of concerts, from May 7 through May 12, 2012.

title: Can an Enemy Be a Childs Friend?
description: In sixth grade they were unlikely friends, the good kid and the bad one, the girl who studied and the one who smoked in the alley. They hung out; they met for lunch. They even walked home from school together, one watching, awestruck, while the other ducked into drugstores to shoplift lip gloss, cigarettes, candy.

title: Zero Decibels
description: The Broadway Train

title: Wilpon Says a Firing Is Not on Agenda
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated with Wilpon addressing reporters

title: Stirring the Sweetly Melodic Into the Darkly Intense
description: The Emerson String Quartet has built three concerts around Dvoraks string quartets  a recent recording project for the group  with works by Janacek and Martinu providing variety and sufficient breadth to warrant the title for the series, Adventures in Bohemia.

title: A Patient, a Death, but No One to Grieve
description: My patients body was unclaimed, and it had already been sent for burial by the time I learned of his death on a Thursday afternoon. It had happened on Saturday, at another hospital. He hadnt left any next-of-kin contact, and it had taken that hospitals social worker four days to trace a trail back to me.

title: Rules for Debt Collectors Are Tightened
description: The Bloomberg administration announced new rules on Monday that are intended to change the way debt collectors operate by making sure they are going after the right people.

title: A Record for La Cage
description: The Broadway musical revival La Cage aux Folles set a house record at the Longacre Theater last week, grossing $673,454 for eight performances  about $8,000 more than the previous record held by the musical Burn the Floor for a week of performances in mid-August 2009. Starring Kelsey Grammer and the British stage actor Douglas Hodge, La Cage has tied the new musical Fela! with the most Tony Award nominations, 11, for the 2009-10 Broadway season.

title: Whats a Degree Worth?
description: In a fascinating article in the Week in Review section on Sunday, Jacques Steinberg gave a hearing to those who think some people would be better off not going to college. Today my colleague David Leonhardt, in a blog post, begs to differ.

title: Stall in Applications for Federal Mortgage Program
description: A major effort by the Obama administration to keep homeowners out of foreclosure may be reaching its limits long before the crisis abates.

title: Judge Grants Asylum to Chinese Immigrant
description: An immigration judge in New York wrote a happy ending on Monday to the story of Xiu Ping Jiang, a Chinese asylum-seeker whose year-long detention in a Florida immigration jail has become emblematic of the pitfalls of a system with no rules for determining mental competency and no obligation to provide anyone a lawyer.

title: The Right Way to Warm Up Is (Your Answer Here)
description: At the Boston Marathon last month, my running partner, Jen Davis, said things were pretty much the same as the 10 other times she has run this race. Most runners stood around waiting for the race to start. Some did strides  short bursts of speed  or ran briefly at close to their race pace. There was a lot of stretching, too, and applications of heat rubs like Bengay and jumping up and down to stay warm.

title: Misconceptions About Fuel Economy
description: Remember those magazine ads for the space-age carburetor that could double your gas mileage  an invention that the government, for mysterious and unstated reasons, did not want you to know about?

title: Extended Civil Commitment of Sex Offenders Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON  In a broad endorsement of federal power, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that Congress has the authority under the Constitution to allow the continued civil commitment of sex offenders after they have completed their criminal sentences.

title: Nancy Pelosi, Errol Morris and Other Bay Area Graduation Speakers
description: Cue Pomp and Circumstance.

title: Grove Backs an Engineers Approach to Medicine
description: Andrew S. Grove, the former chief executive of Intel, is taking the next step in his quest to infuse the engineering discipline of Silicon Valley into the development of new medical treatments.

title: U.S. to Promote Press Freedom
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signed legislation on Monday intended to promote a free press around the world, a bipartisan measure inspired by the murder in Pakistan of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter, shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: In Health Law, a Clearer View of Coverage
description: Ever since Thomas DeLorenzo was accepted to three law schools outside his home state of California, he has spent entire days on the phone with health insurers in other states, compiling information that he enters on a giant spreadsheet.

title: Farewell to Bayswater Point
description: Take a trip to the dreamy new Bayswater Point Park, a cool, leafy peninsula at the foot of Mott Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens, The New York Times rhapsodized in the bygone year 1996. The sun shimmers over the irregular prongs of Jamaica Bay, and distant jumbo jets taxi at Kennedy Airport far across the water, like elephants on the veldt, a mesmerizing sight.

title: From Kind Words, Lessons on Condolences
description: After my husband, Richard, fell ill with terminal cancer this winter, I wrote two articles about our experiences. The first was about living with a fatal diagnosis; the second, after he died on March 18, was about losing a spouse.

title: Words of Comfort After a Loss
description: In todays Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about the power of condolences after the outpouring of support she received following the death of her husband.

title: Human Cost of Combat Can Come Due at Home
description: The Wounded Platoon opens with the death of an American soldier. He had been to Iraq, but he didnt die there. That soldier, Specialist Kevin Shields, survived combat only to be killed in Colorado Springs after a night of drinking with three Army buddies, who are all now serving prison sentences for his murder.

title: Upfronts: Fox Proselytizes for Broadcast TV
description: Just as it did last year, Fox opened its upfront presentation on Monday afternoon by pitching advertisers on the very purpose of prime-time network television. Armed with PowerPoint slides, Foxs president of sales, Jon Nesvig, told media buyers that return-on-investment studies confirm TVs direct contribution to sales.

title: Encore Beach Club to Open in Vegas
description: Never mind that there is no beach. Steve Wynn, the Las Vegas casino developer, is planning to unwrap the Encore Beach Club on Memorial Day: a 60,000-square-foot adults-only pleasure palace with three-tiered swimming pools, oversize lily pads, and some two dozen private cabanas with refrigerators and flat-screen televisions.

title: The Banality of Evil, Romanian-Style
description: CANNES, France No national cinema has had a higher profile at Cannes in recent years than that of Romania. Cristian Mungius 4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days won the Palme dOr in 2007. Corneliu Porumboiu took home the Camera dOr for best first feature in 2006 with 12:08 East of Bucharest and returned last year with the well-received Police, Adjective. But the film that kicked off the Romanian renaissance, in 2005, was Cristi Puius Death of Mr. Lazarescu, a three-hour black comedy about a Bucharest old-timers nightmarish odyssey through the Romanian health care system.

title: Time to Review Workplace Reviews?
description: After years of studying the ill effects of workplace stress, psychologists are turning their attention to its causes. Along with the usual suspects  long hours, bad bosses, office bullies  they have identified some surprising ones.

title: Johnson Opts for Surgery on Wrist
description: Nick Johnson has decided to have surgery to repair a tendon in his right wrist, a development that should sideline him through the All-Star Break.

title: Godard, With That Certain Je Ne Sais Quoi at the Cannes Film Festival
description: CANNES, France  If I am remembering clearly  and my head is filled with so many densely layered words and images, it is hard to unpack them  the first image in Film Socialism, the new movie by Jean-Luc Godard, is of two red-headed parrots, side by side on a tree limb. The parrots are among a handful of animals that appear in the movie, which had its press premiere Monday morning at the Cannes Film Festival, including a pair of hilariously talkative cats (whose meows are, in turn, parroted by a young woman watching them on a laptop), as well as a llama and a donkey. Surrounding these animals is a menagerie of talking, quoting, babbling human beings, speaking in French, German, Russian, English and Arabic, among other tongues.

title: In Yiddish Authors Papers, Potential Gold
description: Chaim Grade was the other great postwar Yiddish writer, the one few people outside of scholarly circles have ever heard of. And for that, some people blame his widow.

title: Quote Unquote | Label Lust
description: The editor and stylist Anna Dello Russo explains how she chooses her outfits. Also, she likes to take her clothes dancing.

title: Birds, Banksy and the Odd Presidential Trial
description: A Brooklyn art project is all about the birds. Located at two sites  the corner of Fort Greene Park at Myrtle Avenue and St. Edwards Street and in Person Park at Myrtle and Carlton Avenues  the Myrtle Avenue Bird Town aims to attract and accommodate our avian friends in 50 houses and feeders while also seeking to educate local residents about their animal neighbors, according to the artists statement. Quirky NYC provides a video report.

title: For Bradley, Training Video Confirmed Davies Was Not Ready to Return
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Bob Bradley suggested that emotion got the better of Charlie Davies last week when he lashed out at his French club team, Sochaux, for not giving him medical clearance to join the United States World Cup team.

title: New Enforcement Chief for Buildings
description: For the first time in its history, the Buildings Department has named a former law enforcement official to serve in the highest ranks of the agency, where corruption and mismanagement have been a persistent embarrassment to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: The Teachers Unions Last Stand
description: MICHAEL MULGREW is an affable former Brooklyn vocational-high-school teacher who took over last year as head of New York Citys United Federation of Teachers when his predecessor, Randi Weingarten, moved to Washington to run the national American Federation of Teachers. Over breakfast in March, we talked about a movement spreading across the country to hold public-school teachers accountable by compensating, promoting or even removing them according to the results they produce in class, as measured in part by student test scores. Mulgrews 165-page union contract takes the opposite approach. It not only specifies everything that teachers will do and will not do during a six-hour-57 -minute workday but also requires that teachers be paid based on how long they have been on the job. Once theyve been teaching for three years and judged satisfactory in a process that invariably judges all but a few of them satisfactory, they are ensured lifetime tenure.

title: Bos Worth a Bundle
description: Thats no ordinary mutt at the White House. Bo, the first dog, is worth $1,600, according to a financial disclosure form released on Monday.

title: On Teachers Unions, Accountability and School Reform
description: Education reform is moving into prime time, writes Steven Brill in the Times Magazine article The Teachers Unions Last Stand. He looks at how Race to the Top, the charter-school movement and other factors are coming together to overhaul public education in the United States  and why teachers unions are resisting many of these reforms.

title: A Marine Chemist Studies How Life Began
description: Jeffrey L. Bada, 67, is the distinguished professor of marine chemistry at the University of California, San Diego. He studies how life began. We spoke for an hour during the American Association for the Advancement of Sciences annual meeting in San Diego last winter and again this month by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows:

title: Catholic Museums Angels Fail to Save It
description: In many ways, the opening of the National Museum of Catholic Art and History in East Harlem was a kind of miracle.

title: Mexican Leader to Visit U.S. as Woes Mount
description: MEXICO CITY  If President Felipe Caldern of Mexico looks a little preoccupied during the state dinner President Obama has planned for him in Washington this week, it would not be hard to understand why.

title: City Rethinks Its Plan to Move Clinton School
description: On the eve of a final approval vote, the Department of Education has said it will rethink its contentious plan to move the Clinton School for Writers and Artists in Chelsea to the American Sign Language School in the East Village, and says it will explore other alternatives.

title: Britain Braces for Europes Debate on Hedge Funds
description: The growing power of European Union institutions has long been anathema for many British Conservatives. Now those institutions could be a lifeline for the Tories as they battle to keep the hedge fund industry based in London, The New York Timess James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Creatures of Cambrian May Have Lived On
description: Ever since their discovery in 1909, the spectacular Burgess Shale outcrops in the Canadian Rockies have presented scientists with a cornucopia of evidence for the explosion of complex, multicellular life beginning some 550 million years ago.

title: Upfronts: Fox Goes for Laughs and a Pair of Big Dramas
description: Fox whetted the appetites of advertisers with previews of its forthcoming shows on Monday, with an emphasis as expected on comedies and on developing just a couple of new dramas.

title: Opposition to a Book Inspires More Art
description: In the surreal young-adult novel The Metal Children by Tobin Falmouth, one by one the teenage girls of a middle-American town become pregnant and vanish, only to reappear as inanimate statues in a nearby cornfield. The book ends with a horrific act of self-inflicted violence that can be seen as either martyrdom or tragic folly, a provocative ambiguity of the sort that teachers are wont to exploit in the classroom. But when The Metal Children showed up in the high school curriculum of a town called Midlothia, the school board took exception to its content and banned it, unleashing a torrent of angry reaction.

title: At a Long-Awaited Concert, Pierre Boulez Offers a Trademark Style
description: The list of significant conductors who have never appeared at the Metropolitan Opera grew shorter during the past two seasons with the acclaimed house debuts of Daniel Barenboim, Riccardo Muti and Esa-Pekka Salonen. One notable maestro, Pierre Boulez, remains on that list, and at 85 he is not likely to commit to a Met production, which would involve several weeks of residency.

title: AmEx Offers Deep Discounts on Products
description: How many times do you receive come-ons from various companies, offering great, limited time prices that are neither great nor limited? For a change, American Express is offering products at discounts that really do undercut the competition.

title: Big Nation. Big People. Its Clearly a Big Deal.
description: There are two Americas.

title: Readers Take On Ambulance Chasers
description: Picture this television commercial: a lawyer sitting behind a dark wood desk, or better, sitting in a wheelchair with the American flag perched behind him, in an office plastered with framed educational degrees on the wall. The lawyer looks straight into the camera and says, Have you been injured in an accident?

title: Arizona: The Gift That Keeps On Giving
description: The loud debate over the recently passed Arizona House Bill 2281, which bans from the public schools ethnic studies courses that promote race consciousness, is a clash between two bad paradigms.

title: The High Low | Zara Pants, $59.90
description: What: Zara pants

title: Meditations on Noise
description: There is dignity in quiet things and quiet people, and gravity accrues to those activities we mostly perform in silence: reading, praying, looking at paintings, standing in the woods. We equate loud noise with violence. Without loudspeakers, Hitler observed, the Nazis never would have conquered Germany. Its hard to imagine Gandhi astride a Harley.

title: 'In the Name of the Father'
description: A. O. Scott on Jim Sheridan's 1993 drama, featuring Daniel Day Lewis and Pete Postlethwaite.

title: A Fathers Reproductive Rights
description: If a man makes it clear  very, very clear  before a child is conceived that he does not want to be a father, and if a woman agrees in advance that she will terminate an accidental pregnancy, should he have to pay child support when she changes her mind?

title: Waddell Defends Its Trades During Flash Crash
description: Waddell & Reed Financial, a Kansas-based mutual fund company, said an internal analysis of trading activity indicated it was not the cause of the flash crash that briefly wiped out $1 trillion in stock market wealth earlier this month, Reuters reports.

title: Redefining Cruel Punishment for Juveniles
description: The Supreme Court ruling in Graham v. Florida held that the Eighth Amendments ban on cruel and unusual punishment forbids sentencing juvenile offenders who do not participate in homicides to life without parole. In 2005, the court ruled that the Eighth Amendment prohibited the execution of juvenile offenders.

title: Looking at a Novelists Career While Keeping a Close Eye on His Sexuality
description: At the age of 4, Edward Morgan Forster learned etiquette from a book that was aptly entitled Dont! He grew up to become a figure of such excessive caution that, when asked if it was raining, he once walked slowly toward a window and answered, I will try to decide.

title: Doomsayers Beware, a Bright Future Beckons
description: Long before sustainable became a buzzword, intellectuals wondered how long industrial society could survive. In The Idea of Decline in Western History, after surveying predictions from the mid-19th century until today, the historian Arthur Herman identifies two consistently dominant schools of thought.

title: Good Night to Be Bad
description: If nice guys finish last, does that mean bad girls finish first? On Sunday night Sandra Diaz-Twine, a reluctant member of the Villains tribe on the 20th edition of Survivor, became the first person to win this CBS reality competition twice. The two-hour finale of Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains, on which Ms. Diaz-Twine, a previous winner of Survivor: Pearl Islands, defeated Parvati Shallow and Russell Hantz, drew 13.3 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, and led CBS to a victory for the night. ABC was second with strong finishes for Desperate Housewives (12.6 million) and Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (9.7 million). NBC ranked third with a Donald J. Trump-theme night, drawing 5.3 million viewers for The 2010 Miss USA Pageant (owned by Mr. Trump) and 6.1 million for Celebrity Apprentice, on which Mr. Trump narrowed the finalists to Bret Michaels and Holly Robinson Peete. Fox finished fourth.

title: Seabiscuit Author Has New Book
description: The second book by Laura Hillenbrand, the author of Seabiscuit, is to be published in November, Random House announced on Monday. The book, Unbroken, is the story of Louis Zamperini, a World War II bombardier who crashed into the Pacific, was marooned on a raft and survived for 47 days until he was captured by the Japanese and held as a prisoner of war for more than two years. Ms. Hillenbrand spent seven years working on the book, which her editor described as a story of fierce determination in the face of nearly insurmountable challenges, set against a backdrop of a fascinating period in American history. Unbroken is Ms. Hillenbrands first book since her debut in 2001 with Seabiscuit, a best seller and a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award.

title: Priscilla Finds Her Men for Broadway Production
description: Priscilla Queen of the Desert, a musical adapted from a 1994 film about three transvestites making their way across the Australian outback, may have a few surprises to offer but the identities of at least two of its leads are not among them. Confirming longstanding reports, the musicals producers said on Monday that the shows Broadway transfer would star Will Swenson (Hair), above right, as Tick/Mitzi, and Tony Sheldon, right, an Olivier Award nominee for the shows West End production, who will reprise his role as Bernadette. (No casting was announced for the role of Adam/Felicia, the trios third member.) The musical, which was presented in Australia and New Zealand before it reached London, is written by Stephan Elliott, the writer and director of the film, and Allan Scott, and directed by Simon Phillips. A Toronto run is scheduled to begin in October before the production moves to a yet-to-be-determined Broadway theater next spring.

title: Scaled-Back Summer for Metropolitan Opera
description: Tough economic times have kept the Metropolitan Opera to a reduced summer season for the third year in a row. The Met said on Monday that it would put on six free recitals in parks across the five boroughs of New York, from July 12 to July 29. It called the performers, to be accompanied by piano, rising stars; the established star Nathan Gunn will sing on the first program. The Met stopped its tradition of presenting full-length operas in concert after the summer of 2007 for budgetary reasons, presenting a gala concert in 2008 and recitals in 2009. The Met also said it would show 10 high-definition broadcasts in the Lincoln Center Plaza, Aug. 28 to Sept. 6, with free first-come seating. Details are available at metopera.org/parks.

title: Raising Money for Cities in Need
description: The country singer Brad Paisley donated $100,000 at a Sunday telethon and concert that raised more than $1.5 million to benefit people affected by the recent flooding in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. The telethon, shown on the Great American Country television channel, began with Mr. Paisleys performance of his song Welcome to the Future, after which he announced his donation. If there is a silver lining, he said, its that the world is getting to see Nashville at its best through this tragedy. The concert also featured performances by Sheryl Crow, Kellie Pickler and Lady Antebellum, as well as Keith Urban, who played the Beatles Help while his wife, Nicole Kidman, watched. Scott Borchetta, the chief executive of Big Machine Records, which releases music by Taylor Swift and other artists, also donated $100,000 to the telethon, which will benefit the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee. Also on Sunday, Lenny Kravitz and John Legend were among the headliners at the Gulf Aid concert in New Orleans, which was organized to help residents affected by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The A.P. reported that concertgoers withstood a torrential rainstorm to see performances by Ani DiFranco, Mos Def, Allen Toussaint and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. The Gulf Relief Foundation, which organized the event, did not immediately release a fund-raising total.

title: Son of Zeppelin: Tribute Concerts Planned
description: To the world John Bonham was the formidable rock n roll drummer of Led Zeppelin, who brought an explosive percussion style to songs like When the Levee Breaks and Four Sticks. To Jason Bonham, left, he was simply Dad, a man whose musicianship he did not fully appreciate when John died in 1980 at 32, when Jason was just 14. I really wish I had the time to tell him when he was alive how much I loved him as a player, and his music, Mr. Bonham said recently in a telephone interview. In that spirit Mr. Bonham, now 44, announced on Monday that he would perform a series of concerts in the fall paying tribute to his father and the music of Led Zeppelin. The lineup of musicians and tour dates is still being completed, but Mr. Bonham said the tour, called Jason Bonhams Led Zeppelin Experience, would perform 30 shows in North America in honor of the 30th anniversary of John Bonhams death. Mr. Bonham, who in 2007 played with the bands surviving members  Jimmy Page, Robert Plant and John Paul Jones  at the O2 Arena in London, said he had not yet approached them about participating. Of course, I would love to have them involved, he said. I had the time of my life working with them in that six weeks up to the O2 show, and to have been part of that, just for that moment.

title: Review Cites Flaws in U.S. Antimissile Program
description: President Obamas plans for reducing Americas nuclear arsenal and defeating Irans missiles rely heavily on a new generation of antimissile defenses, which last year he called proven and effective.

title: Wealth, Race and the Great Recession
description: The primal economic divide in America remains the chasm between the wealth of black and white families, and it has widened steadily over the last generation.

title: Critics Picks Video: In the Name of the Father
description: In this weeks Critics Picks video, A. O. Scott looks at Jim Sheridans 1993 drama In the Name of the Father, starring Daniel Day-Lewis as Gerry Conlon, a man who is wrongly convicted of participating in an I.R.A. bombing. Pete Postelthwaite plays Gerrys father, who is charged with being an accomplice and is convicted alongside his son. The film makes a passionate case for correcting flaws in the criminal justice system, but, Mr. Scott says, what makes it great is its depiction of the changing relationship between father and son. Have you seen In the Name of the Father? Please share your thoughts on the film.

title: Buffett Cuts Holdings in Kraft and P.&G.
description: Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, says it cut its holdings in a dozen companies in the first quarter, including Kraft Foods and Procter & Gamble, as it finished raising cash for its $26.7 billion acquisition of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad, The Associated Press reports.

title: Blackstone-Led Group to Drop Fidelity National Bid
description: A group of private equity firms led by the  Blackstone Group has dropped plans to place a $15 billion bid for Fidelity National Information Services, citing concerns over price, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

title: The Rails Scoreboard
description: How The Rails contributors are doing with their predictions through the first two legs of the Triple Crown (using a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show). Our guest pickers, Jim Rome and David Simon, have combined for 1 point.

title: Senate Votes for a Clear Credit Score
description: WASHINGTON  Anyone rejected for a credit card, car loan or department store charge account has most likely discovered a frustrating aspect of the government-mandated, free credit reports: the glaring absence of the numerical credit score that lenders rely on to make their decisions.

title: Lions Gate Considers Negotiations With Icahn
description: Lions Gate Entertainment said Monday that it was considering whether to negotiate with the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who has made a hostile $7-a-share offer for the movie studio, Reuters reports.

title: Massachusetts: F.A.A. Clears Wind Farm
description: One of the last remaining hurdles to a proposed wind farm off Cape Cod was cleared Monday when the Federal Aviation Administration said the farms developer, Cape Wind, had agreed to fix the air traffic control radar system at nearby Otis Air Force Base. The agency had said earlier that the proposed 130 turbines, each rising 440 feet above the water in Nantucket Sound, could interfere with the radar. The agency said Monday that by requiring Cape Wind to modify the system or install a new one, at a cost of $15 million, there would be no hazard to air navigation. Cape Wind said it agreed. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar approved the project last month, but opponents say they still intend to file lawsuits to stop it.

title: Far From the Ocean Floor, the Cleanup Starts Here
description: HOUSTON  The cables dangling from the ceiling panels said it all.

title: The Children Are Bright; the Setting, Scruffy
description: The hulking three-story school building has corrugated metal siding and grates on the windows.

title: As Attention Wanders, Rethinking the Autopilot
description: A captain returned to the cockpit after taking a bathroom break and found the first officer facing away from the instruments and talking to a flight attendant. Unnoticed was the fact that the autopilot had disconnected and the plane was in danger of stalling.

title: Why Poodles May Outlive Pit Bulls
description: The Great Dane was bred as a guard dog, the German shepherd as a herder and the tiny Pomeranian as a lap dog.

title: Match Making
description: Q. Is a voice print as distinctive as a fingerprint, or have I just been watching too much 24?

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Over Variety Review
description: The trade paper Variety has escaped from a legal tangle over a negative review for the independent film Iron Cross.

title: Balconies Declared Unsafe at 16 New York Buildings
description: Thousands of residents in 16 buildings across New York City have been ordered to stop using balconies that were found to be unsafe by the Department of Buildings.

title: Deal Follows All-Nighters in Minnesota
description: As Sunday turned into Monday, lawmakers in Minnesota were still at their desks, rumpled and bleary-eyed, dozing off at times.

title: When a Mouse Smells a Rat
description: When a mouse catches a whiff of a cat or a rat, it cautiously steps away from the direction of the scent, generally backward so it can keep an eye on the predator.

title: In an Ancient Mexican Tomb, High Society
description: Last month, in their second season at the site of an ancient settlement in southern Mexico, archaeologists digging into the ruins of a pyramid came upon a row of large, flat stones  the wall of a tomb. Inside, they found skeletons of a prominent man, possibly a ruler, and two human sacrifices. Another apparently elite adult was on a landing just outside the tomb.

title: Filmmakers Tread Softly on Early Release to Cable
description: LOS ANGELES  A little over a week ago, the movie business got its eagerly sought permission to activate technology to protect new releases from being copied if they were sold through video-on-demand systems before being issued on DVD.

description: The Yankees Nick Johnson has decided to have surgery to repair a tendon in his right wrist, a development that will probably sideline him through the All-Star break.

description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Dressed in a black cap, T-shirt, shorts and running shoes, Simon Gagne sauntered through the Philadelphia Flyers practice facility Monday as his teammates made it through another off-day practice. Maybe he will feel healthy enough to join them someday.

description: Norman Hand, a defensive tackle who played for five National Football League teams and helped the 2000 New Orleans Saints gain the first playoff victory in their history, died Friday in Walterboro, S.C. He was 37.

title: Dead Football Player Had Sickle-Cell Trait
description: A University of Mississippi football player who collapsed during a February workout carried the sickle-cell trait, which contributed to his death, a county coroner said Monday.

description: The Yankees showed a Babe Ruth documentary on the scoreboard during batting practice Monday. Behind the cage, Aaron Boone huddled with Nomar Garciaparra, the handpicked broadcast crew for ESPN. Yes, the Boston Red Sox were back in the Bronx. Cue the history.

description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers approved a draft law Tuesday that would make it harder for foreign hedge fund managers to do business in the trading bloc and that could threaten Londons preeminence as a financial center.

description: Facing a $43 million budget gap in the next fiscal year, Yonkers school officials called Monday for all 4,000 employees to agree to a one-year wage freeze  or face the possibility of layoffs of 13 percent of the staff.

title: Scouring the World for Grilled Meat
description: MICHELIN ranks restaurants according to how far you should be willing to travel to try them. You might say I take a similar approach to barbecue. Countries have lured me on the promise of a single dish.

title: Obama Taps F.B.I. Deputy to Head a Security Agency
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday made his third try to fill the top job at the Transportation Security Administration, this time picking someone who might have an easier time passing the F.B.I. background check  the deputy director of the F.B.I.

title: Travel Horror Stories Worth Telling in a Bar
description: I DONT know about you, but I sometimes talk back rudely to dumb travel writing, much in the way I sometimes talk back to dumb local television news. I am not interested in that fabulous hotel spa, I might complain (and I am paraphrasing here), or your raptures about the dawn mists on Englands lakes.

title: Postseason Brings Out Best in Celtics Wallace
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Early in the playoffs, everything coalesced for the Boston Celtics. The past (Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce) synched with the future (Rajon Rondo and Kendrick Perkins) to form a somewhat spectacular present.

title: Short on Defense and Time, U.S. Opens Training Camp
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The United States opened its World Cup training camp Monday with its goalkeeper and three of four potential defensive starters unavailable for full workouts. As of now, Coach Bob Bradley is treating the absences with mild concern rather than evident alarm.

title: Obamas Aunt Is Granted Asylum on Second Try
description: BOSTON  An immigration judge has granted asylum to President Obamas aunt, allowing her to stay in the United States and possibly become a citizen in about six years, her lawyers said Monday.

title: Blumenthal Says He Served in Vietnam
description: Addressing a crowd of veterans and supporters in March 2008, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut said that he had served in Vietnam.

title: Assessing Blumenthal's Military Service Records
description: A closer look at Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal's military service and deferments during the Vietnam War.

title: The Euros Lost Promise
description: Singapore

title: Cable Takes a Front-Row Seat at Upfront Week
description: FOR decades, the upfront week in mid-May  devoted to previewing the coming television season for advertisers  was reserved for the big broadcast networks. Recently, however, the cable channels, emboldened by gains in ratings and advertising revenue, started sneaking onto the schedule.

title: Richard Blumenthals Words on Vietnam Service Differ From History
description: At a ceremony honoring veterans and senior citizens who sent presents to soldiers overseas, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut rose and spoke of an earlier time in his life.

title: Blackstone Group Ends Bid for Fidelity National
description: A group of private equity firms led by the Blackstone Group has dropped plans for a $15 billion bid for Fidelity National Information Services, people briefed on the matter said Monday.

title: Nobelist Is Chosen to Fill Cancer Post
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Harold E. Varmus, a Nobel Prize-winning biologist and former director of the National Institutes of Health, will become director of the National Cancer Institute, the White House announced Monday.

title: A Reading to Recall the Father of Tevye
description: Bel Kaufman turned 99 last week, but did her nephew have to announce it? Did the whole world need to know her business?

title: Justice Department to Review New Orleanss Troubled Police Force
description: NEW ORLEANS  Officials from the Justice Department announced a widespread review of this citys troubled police department on Monday, the necessary first step in a full-scale overhaul.

title: Lottery Numbers
Crashes Can Make Even the Best Cyclists Uneasy
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  On a day of wicked weather at the Tour of California, where roads were slick with rain and winds were whipping, the German rider Jens Voigt stayed atop his bike Monday and crossed the finish line of Stage 2 unscathed.

title: Liberty Island to Open Evenings in Summer
description: New York City offers thousands of options for dinner out on a Thursday night, but until this summer, the Statue of Liberty was not one of them.

title: Going Back to School: Fired Staff Is Rehired
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I. All the staff members of Central Falls High School, who were fired in February as part of a turnaround plan for the chronically underperforming school, will be able to keep their jobs under an agreement ratified Monday.

title: Cooper-Hewitt Director Starts Talks on Design
description: Bill Moggridge, the new director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, wants to make the museum a center of education and debate. To that end, hes inaugurating a series called Bills Design Talks, in which he will moderate discussions among designers and museum professionals on chosen topics.

title: No Bail for Man Accused of Qaeda Computer Aid
description: A federal magistrate judge in Manhattan refused on Monday to grant bail to a former Brooklyn resident charged with conspiring to provide Al Qaeda with computer advice and other assistance, finding that the man was dangerous and might flee.

title: Arrest in Killing of Woman and Child
description: The police charged a 20-year-old man on Monday with strangling a Brooklyn woman and her 8-year-old daughter, who were found dead on Sunday in a bathtub in their apartment in Sheepshead Bay.

title: Moscow Journalists Under Attack
description: In the Moscow suburbs, freedom of the press may be legal, but it's not always tolerated.

title: Blight Made Right
description: There is a well-understood but impolite thing to be said about Americas suburbs, particularly the old ones. They can be beautiful in places but ugly in far too many others, especially in the desolate commercial spaces that shoppers and time forgot. The failed strip malls, closed warehouses, abandoned big-box stores and moon-cratered parking lots. The light industry in heavy decline.

title: Beaten Russian Editor Is Told to Say Its His Fault

A helicopter putters past overhead, and there is the sudden, tubular flare of a motorcycle  a big one  climbing the on-ramp just a few blocks away. Mockingbirds swoop from fence to wire down the long line of backyards in this part of town, and the small, gray bird nesting in an angle of my porch-roof has bedded down with her eggs for the night. The police said the womans family had told officers her name was Xing. She was seen last Thursday using the knife to carve into a tree outside a youth center. Xing, 35, then wandered into the center, where guards and police officers stopped her. She did not harm anyone. The episode took place a day after a man with a kitchen cleaver hacked to death seven kindergartners and two adults at a school in Shaanxi Province. China is reeling from a series of attacks on schoolchildren that have resulted in the deaths of 17 people.

The prohibited area now covers 19 percent of the gulf, nearly double what it was, according to the agency.

In the traditional soup, only the spinach stems are used, while the leaves are reserved for another dish. Using that recipe as a starting point, Ive added a few ingredients  most notably the spinach leaves. This is an easy soup to make.

Witness the opening-night celebration of American Ballet Theaters spring season on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The audience came dressed to the nines. The dancers, dressed no less splendidly, did their jumps, their turns, their spectacular lifts, their dramatic gestures, their noble curtain calls. Was that wonderful for you, darling? It was wonderful for me too. Eager applause all round.

description: At this point, Microsoft must have developed its own seminar for employees called something like Apologizing With Optimism: How to Persuade People to Give You Another Try.

Senator Charles Grassley, the Iowa Republican, has sent a letter pressing the Department of Interior for more information on its questionable oversight of offshore oil drilling. At the same time, Senator Bill Nelson, the Florida Democrat, has intensified his criticism of BP.

title: Case Study | Looking East
description: If you missed your favorite barkeep last Monday or Tuesday, it was quite possible he or she was packed into the Hiro Ballroom at the Maritime Hotel for what constituted the cant-miss event of the year for the shake-and-stir set, a gathering that had cocktailian tongues wagging for months beforehand. Kazuo Uyeda, the reigning patriarch of Japanese bartending and self-professed inventor of the controversial hard shake, was making his first United States speaking appearance at a two-day seminar on Japanese bartending methods. As American cocktail culture has exploded over the past decade, cycling through every trend  from resurrecting 19th-century recipes and ingredients to molecular reinterpretation of drinks  a communal grasping has remained to understand the fastidious Japanese scene, which is focused in the tiny bars that dot Tokyos nightlife centers like Roppongi and Ginza, where Uyedas bar, Tender, is located. In the more recessed aeries of cocktail culture, an intense curiosity about and mimicry of the Japanese interpretation of the cocktail exists. It is safe to say that this fixation is almost entirely due to Uyedas reputation, and collective puzzlement over the hard shake.

She imagines herself as a a psychedelic picture show, with platinum (formerly blue, then hot pink) hair, trippy Alexander McQueen bondage heels and Chlo 2148 sunglasses. A Kiwi by birth, a New Yorker by inclination, the 26-year-old is a devotee of the byzantine echo chamber known as social media, with 10,320 followers on Twitter and 4,357 friends on Facebook. She signs her blog posts  on fashion and also on how to live magically  with love letters and feather headdresses. Her next book, on radical self-love, is only partially about masturbation. At least 47 people were wounded, nearly all of them civilians caught in heavy traffic during the morning rush. The blast sent a fireball billowing into the air, set cars aflame and blew bodies apart. Limbs and entrails flew hundreds of feet, littering yards and walls and streets. The survivors, many of them women and children, some of them missing limbs, lay in the road moaning and calling for help.

But the understated charm of the island off of Floridas Gulf Coast (which Ive been assured has seen no effects of the oil spill) is not for lack of achievement. When I was there for a week not long ago, I met international litigators, art directors for major ad agencies and artisanal cheese sellers, all drawn to Captivas gorgeous beaches and profound sense of ease. The island has no celebrity chefs, no flashy main drag, no late night botes  and thats exactly how locals and regular visitors like it.
