title: AAA Release iPhone App with Voice Navigation
description: Within the past year, AAA has released three iPhone apps  all free. While none of them will fix your flat, its latest app  TripTik Mobile  offers voice guidance for drivers looking for shortcuts, compares fuel prices at gas stations and finds AAA-approved restaurants and hotels.

title: Jessica Hecht, Tony Nominee, Buys a Co-op
description: TO fans of the television comedy  Friends,  Jessica Hecht is Susan, the life partner of Carol, the ex-wife of Ross Geller, one of the lead characters. And as almost everybody knows, she made broadcast history in 1995 when Susan and Carol became the first lesbian couple on TV to become parents.

title: Welcome to P.S. 87, or Not
description: More than 50 parents of kindergarten children wait-listed for popular Public School 87 on the Upper West Side got great news on Monday. They all received letters saying that their childs alternate placement for kindergarten was none other than P.S. 87.

title: High-End Retailers Are Scouting Sites in Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn, the new bastion of cool for many New Yorkers, is poised to go mainstream chic. The announcement that Barneys Co-op will open its first store in Cobble Hill has cleared the way for other nationally recognized high-end retailers to make a similar move across the bridge, according to brokers who specialize in representing luxury clothiers.

title: Searching for Hidden Treasure
description: If youre looking for an activity for your children or grandchildren, you might try geocaching, a treasure-hunting game played by using GPS devices to find hidden containers, or geocaches, outdoors and then sharing the experiences online. A typical geocache treasure is an inexpensive but intriguing object, like a tiny Rubiks cube, a postcard or a coin from a different country. Sometimes the caches contain a Travel Bug with a code that can be tracked, so you can see where its been.

title: Axl Rose Sues His Former Manager for $5 Million
description: Perhaps no day in the life of Guns N Roses is complete without news of both a new vook and a mud-slinging lawsuit.

title: Dorgan Is Retiring but Not Relenting
description: Never underestimate a retiring senator with nothing to lose.

title: New Rules Would Limit Trades in Volatile Market
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that it would temporarily institute circuit breakers on all the stocks in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index after the huge market gyrations on May 6.

title: Rules to Limit Trading in Highly Volatile Markets
description: 6:52 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday proposed a trial of individual circuit breakers on all of the stocks in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index in response to the May 6 market disruption, The New York Timess Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

title: Artifacts | Christian Boltanskis Bonfire of Humanity
description: Clothes may perform as fashion statements but thats hardly all theyre good for. On a live body they also shelter and expose, enhance and diminish, challenge and flatter, instantly telegraphing taste, class, style and sense of self. Discarded garments tell another story  especially when 30 tons of them are tossed willy-nilly into a twenty-five-foot high, bonfire-like pyramid surrounded by a mass grave of 60,000 pieces of apparel in every size, shape and color. Then they speak for the dead.

title: Until We Meet Again
description: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick spent the last week traveling through Africa, with stops in Gabon, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congoand now, South Africa. This is Mitchs final post from Africa.

title: On Brooklyn Homefront, the Women Are Restless
description: Dont you sometimes catch yourself being happy youre on your own? May Black asks her friend Alice. What a terrible thing to say, Alice answers.

title: Scottsboro Boys to Begin Performances in October at the Lyceum
description: The producers of the Broadway-bound Scottsboro Boys musical plan to begin performances in October at the Lyceum Theater, shortly after the show concludes an out-of-town run at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, according to Barry Weissler, one of the lead producers.

title: A Smooth Operator, at the Vanguard of the Gallery World in the 1960s
description: In 1967, writing in The New York Herald Tribune, Tom Wolfe described an art opening at the Leo Castelli gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. It was a big, crazy night. Castelli was showing new work by Jasper Johns, his favorite, the groundbreaking painter hed discovered and championed nearly a decade earlier.

title: European Businesses Hit in Credit Squeeze From Greek Crisis
description: When Tadeusz Nowicki visited his local bank in early May looking for credit to expand production at his profitable and fast-growing plastics processing company in Warsaw, Ergis-Eurofilms, he got a lecture instead.

title: Do You Have a Mother? Then You Have Someone to Blame
description: Youve probably heard it said that some people just shouldnt have children. But consider this: if the people who shouldnt have children didnt have children, where would Western literature be? Half the memoirs on best-seller lists, it seems, are about surviving monster parents, as are too many first novels to count.

title: Protecting Us With Guns and Chuckles
description: Hardly anybody enforces the law with a straight face anymore. Jack Bauer is on his last mission on 24, and Law & Order was just canceled. NBC shook off Southland after only one abbreviated season, and the show ended up on TNT. Crime dramas are in a mannerist phase  almost all the top-rated network dramas about murder and mayhem have a flippant overlay, from NCIS and its spinoff, NCIS: Los Angeles, to The Mentalist and Bones.

title: Marijuana Fuels a New Kitchen Culture
description: EVEN preschool teachers unwind with a round of drinks now and then. But in professional kitchens, where the hours are long, the pace intense and the goal is to deliver pleasure, the need to blow off steam has long involved substances that are mind-altering and, often enough, illegal.

title: Two Daring Directors Who Changed Film History
description: In Emmanuel Laurents new documentary, Two in the Wave, the two are the filmmakers Franois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard. The wave, needless to say, is La Nouvelle Vague, a journalistic name that not only stuck to Truffaut, Mr. Godard and their colleagues, but that also changed the way film history is understood.

title: Bordeaux Loses Prestige Among Younger Wine Lovers
description: THE hyperbole over 2009 Bordeaux began building even before the harvest last fall. Ripples of praise grew into waves this spring as critics and the trade descended on Bordeaux for the annual ritual of tasting the most recent vintage from barrels. Their ecstatic reviews reverberated through Britain, which takes its claret extremely seriously. They rang out in Hong Kong, the leading edge of what Bordeaux hopes will be a huge Asian market.

title: An Urban Farming Pioneer Sows His Own Legacy
description: JOHN AMEROSO didnt hoe the rows of vegetables that help feed the Bronx at the Padre Plaza Success Garden in the boroughs Mott Haven section. He didnt pick any tomatoes from the vines at the Brooklyn Rescue Missions farm. And he didnt turn the composting bins that kept East New York Farms! fertile ground for collards, cilantro and chard.

title: Working Under the Water, in a Job Measured in Minutes
description: Delta Divers, a two-parter that begins Wednesday night on the National Geographic Channel, looks like just another entry in the increasingly tedious collection of reality programs about obscure jobs that are rarely as glamorous as they sound. But the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has suddenly made the show more interesting than it might have been.

title: Be Wary the Rush to Gold
description: Most of us have seen advertisements to buy gold or offering cash for gold. With the economy still unsettled and gold prices steadily rising, you may be tempted.

title: Fried Chicken and Position Players on the Menu
description: On day two of his visit to Atlanta, Jeff Wilpon, the Mets chief operating officer, had lunch in the team hotel with other Mets executives. The menu included fried chicken. The agenda focused on the teams position players.

title: Strange Trip for a Piece of Nazi Past
description: BERLIN  Robert Edsel, author of The Monuments Men, came to town the other day with a heavy album bound in green Moroccan leather. Gemldegalerie Linz XIII was embossed on the spine. Inside were black-and-white photographs of mostly obscure 19th-century German paintings.

title: Blogging the Primaries
description: 11:19 p.m. |Wrap Up

title: A Wall Street Presence in the World of Chess Politics
description: The masters of the universe gathered around the small stage in the Hudson Square Ballroom of the Trump SoHo Hotel on Monday night to bid in an auction. Sprinkled among them were a dozen thin models in backless dresses, but the businessmen seemed not to notice.

title: Lucas Fine Foods to Open in Brooklyn
description: A former photo director who moonlighted as a caterer, Misty Kurpier, above, gave up her day job and is opening a prepared-food store dressed up with sparkly little chandeliers and a few seats. Her mostly seasonal menu will include gazpacho with grilled shrimp, grilled chimichurri steak on ciabatta, orecchiette in a light toss of plum tomatoes, and assorted salads. Brian Smith will make his new Ample Hills Creamery ice cream in the store. Among the flavors: maple with candied bacon, coconut mojito and bubblegum tinted with beet juice.

title: Land Rover Is Working on a Diesel Hybrid and Two-Wheel Drive
description: Land Rover, a storied British brand that is virtually synonymous with four-wheel drive, has announced a two-wheel drive option for its new compact Range Rover, based on the LRX Concept. The new vehicle, which a Land Rover news release described as the lightest, most fuel-efficient Range Rover ever, is scheduled for 2011 availability.

title: Thick White Asparagus a Spring Specialty
description: No amount of fiddleheads, ramps or anything else in the United States generates the springtime frenzy that white asparagus does in some places in Europe. The thicker the spears the better, because they tend to be fibrous and must be peeled. The bottom inch or so should also be sliced off. They should be cooked until very tender. At Seasonal, Wolfgang Ban simmers his in milk to diminish any hint of bitterness. A few stores are selling the jumbos, with stalks at least an inch in diameter, imported from France and the Netherlands. Youll need no more than one per person. For a twist, serve them for lunch or a picnic like hot dogs, still warm, in toasted buns, with a slather of ravigote sauce and a little sauerkraut.

title: Goat Milk Caramel From France, Not Mexico
description: Goat milk caramel is known as cajeta in Mexico. But who knew that its also made inroads in France? A caramel company in Beauvais, north of Paris, gives its firm but luscious goat milk caramels a little crunch with the unusual addition of roasted buckwheat grains. The candies, individually wrapped, come deceptively packed in a plain wooden box stamped with the head of a goat, the kind youd expect to contain cheese, not sweets.

title: Why We Travel 2008
description: I was trying to be a little bit more creative, but the jurys out on whether I succeeded or not.

title: Why We Travel 2009
description:
Bonaire
There were a few spots where a huge school would completely surround you.

title: Mr. Blumenthals Misdirection
description: There are few sins less forgivable in American politics than claiming unearned military valor. Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut, may consider his false claim to have served in Vietnam to be a few misplaced words, as he put it on Tuesday, but, in fact, this deception seems to have been part of a larger pattern of misleading voters.

title: Oil Sands as a Source of Energy
description: Canadian oil sands are expected to become the top source of imported oil, surpassing other conventional oil imports.

title: 'Cremaster Cycle' Returns
description: A look inside the artist Matthew Barneys film series Cremaster Cycle, which screens this month.

title: Last Day of School, but Cutback Assignment Incomplete
description: The school year may be wrapping up, but local school districts are still working to complete a difficult assignment: hammering out their budgets for next year, under the pressure of ongoing state budget cuts and financial uncertainty.

title: Platter Keeps Foods Cool
description: Keeping platters of seafood, sushi, cut fresh fruit or other perishables cool can be a challenge as the weather warms. The simple new white ceramic platter at the Museum of Modern Art stores provides a clever and convenient solution. The platter sits on a black melamine base that comes with a flat gel insert. Freeze the insert and place it on the base, with the platter on top, and whatever you are serving will keep its cool for a couple of hours. It works even better if you also chill the platter. Its quite flat, so a big whipped cream cake can also go on it.

title: The Counting Behind a Grim Milestone
description: Exactly how many American service members have died in the war in Afghanistan? The question is not as simple as it might seem.

title: The Slow Route to Homemade Pizza
description: THERES little point in trying to match the horsepower available to a pizzaiolo. Their professional pizza ovens, especially the models that burn wood or coal, are the muscle cars of kitchens: when blazing at temperatures that range from 800 degrees to an infernal 1,000 degrees, they can turn raw dough into a blistered, bubbling pizza in as little as 75 seconds. It puts the home cook, whose oven typically reaches 550 degrees, at a permanent disadvantage.

title: Tips for Making Pizza at Home
description: You can produce pizzeria-quality pizza with the perfectly normal stove in your kitchen.

title: Toyota Pays Its $16.4 Million Fine Over Pedals
description: The Transportation Department said Tuesday that Toyota Motor had paid a $16.4 million civil fine, the largest allowed, over a recall of sticking accelerator pedals on 2.3 million vehicles.

title: A Plea for Honesty in Photo Specs
description: Im a big fan of photography magazines. Theres nothing like seeing someones successful photo and reading, right next to it, how they did it. You learn so much so fast.

title: Inspectors Find Fraud at Centers for Children
description: Federal undercover investigators found workers at federally financed child care centers frequently misrepresenting information about applicants job status and earnings to fraudulently register ineligible children, the Government Accountability Office said in a report issued Tuesday.

title: Conspiracy Seen to Rig Bids in Muni Market
description: More than a dozen banks have been accused of taking part in a nationwide conspiracy to rig bids in the $2.8 billion municipal bond market, Bloomberg News reports. They included Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and Wachovia.

title: Somalia: Prime Minister Refuses to Step Down
description: The prime minister of Somalias weak transitional federal government on Tuesday rebuffed a move by the president to replace him, further deepening the bitter dispute within the government. Prime Minister Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke said he would leave office only after a no-confidence vote by Parliament. On Monday, the president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed, had said he would appoint a new prime minister in an effort to end the longstanding rift within the government. That move immediately drew support from the United Nations special representative for Somalia, Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah. Somalia has been without an effective central government since 1991, when the former government was toppled by clan militias and later turned against each other. The current transitional government, which was formed in a 2008 deal brokered by the United Nations, has failed to restore security and been weakened by constant attacks, roadside bombs, corruption, disputes, suicide bombers and piracy. Many analysts caution that the latest strife within the government institutions could result in a total breakdown.

title: The Lost Linz Album
description: A look at the recently rediscovered Volume XIII of Hitlers Linz albums.

title: Grant Lets Frontline Expand PBS Programming
description: At a time when many news organizations are cutting back, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is continuing its efforts to bolster in-depth journalism in public media. The corporation said on Tuesday that it was giving Frontline a $6 million, two-year grant that would allow it to expand its investigative programming to a year-round schedule on PBS stations.

title: Mia Dona
description: A FRIDAY night on East 58th Street; the long, low dining room of Mia Dona, an Italian restaurant run by the ambitious young food personality Donatella Arpaia. The restaurant is neither full nor empty, but pleasant with date-nights and after-workers drinking primitivo and listening to Counting Crows first album playing on the stereo up by the bar, Adam Duritz singing, We all want to be big stars.

title: In Vietnam, Recreating French Roots
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, VIETNAM  In Valerie Gregori McKenzies childhood home in Toulouse, France, the exotic was never far. Family lore was rooted in colonial Algiers, where three generations of Gregoris had lived until Algerias war for independence forced their return to France in 1961.

title: Russia: Jailed Oil Tycoon Announces Hunger Strike
description: An imprisoned former oil tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, has declared a hunger strike to protest a court decision made earlier this month that extended his term in custody while he stood trial for large-scale money laundering and embezzlement. Mr. Khodorkovsky was the owner of the now bankrupt Yukos oil company. In a letter to the chairman of Russias Supreme Court, published on his Web site on Tuesday, Mr. Khodorkovsky said the decision violated amendments to Russian law recently signed by President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

title: The Technicality Generation
description: THE problems faced by Richard Blumenthal, Connecticuts attorney general, over his depiction of his military service are indicative of a broader disease in our society. The issues of integrity in business and politics that plague us today  the way elites are no longer trusted  are rooted in the dishonesty that surrounded the Vietnam-era draft.

title: Obama Tells Ohio, Our Economy Is Growing Again
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  President Obama came Tuesday to this area long synonymous with economic distress to take a few strides on a victory lap for the policies he credits with helping create jobs and to knock Republicans for standing in the way.

title: Donatella Style: Mia Dona in Midtown Reviewed
Inside Pies n Thighs
description: The Williamsburg, Brooklyn, restaurant has a new location.

title: Q. and A. With John Ameroso on Growing Food
description: Since 1976, John Ameroso has been showing New Yorkers how to grow what they eat. As the first and, probably last, extension agent in the city focused on farming, Mr. Ameroso is more responsible than anyone for the rise of urban agriculture in the city and the tons of produce now raised in plots big and small. Hes recently retired, but is still winding down his work in the five boroughs, making sure his legacy will continue. While hes at it, he will also answer questions from Diners Journal readers about city farming and growing food. Post your question as a comment below hell respond in later posts this week.

title: At 2nd State Dinner, a Wish for No Drama
description: WASHINGTON  The last (and first) time President Obama hosted a state dinner at the White House, for Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India, it resulted in a quasi-national-security crisis, hours of Congressional testimony and the eventual departure of the White House social secretary, Desire Rogers.

title: A Haven in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
description: After stints in Paris, Los Angeles and Nevis, in 1992, Valerie Gregori McKenzie settled in Vietnam and renovated a two-story, 940-square-foot structure and its fifth-of-an-acre grounds into a lush, barefoot-friendly haven.

title: Reliance on Oil Sands Grows Despite Environmental Risks
description: CONKLIN, Alberta  Beneath the subarctic forests of western Canada, deep under the peat bogs and herds of wild caribou, lies the tarry rock that is one of Americas top sources of imported oil.

title: Homes Built as Statement Razed to Make Another
description: RAFAH, Gaza  Nidal Eid was praised by Hamas officials as an example of anti-Zionist resistance when he managed to build a house here last year despite an Israeli blockade that barred the import of any building materials. But earlier this week, his house was the first to be demolished by the Hamas government, which said it had been illegally built on public land.

title: Karpov Raises Money (With a Little Help From His Friends)
description: A fundraiser for Anatoly Karpovs campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation drew a crowd of financiers and chess players Monday night in Manhattan. The main attractions were Karpov, his old rival, Garry Kasparov, and Magnus Carlsen, the 19-year-old from Norway who is now the worlds top-ranked player.

title: Pies N Thighs
description: ONE of the most fervently discussed new restaurants of the year is the reincarnation of a seedy biker-bar offshoot that served fried chicken and pulled pork until it suddenly closed up shop in 2008, just one step ahead of the Department of Health.

title: Senate Republicans Call Reform Bill a Takeover of the Banking Industry
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republican leaders on Tuesday unleashed a barrage of criticism at the far-reaching financial regulatory legislation being debated on the Senate floor, indicating that many of the partys leaders were prepared to vote against the bill.

title: Protecting Kemps Ridley Sea Turtles
description: Scientists are closely monitoring the endangered turtles as a major oil disaster threatens their habitat.

description: To the Editor:

title: He Didnt Serve in Vietnam, but Said He Did
description: To the Editor:

title: Killing Taints Iraqi Kurdistans Image
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  Kurdish writers and human rights advocates are protesting the torture and slaying of a young journalist, challenging what they say are oppressive restrictions to free speech in a part of Iraq that presents itself as safe and democratic.

title: Restoring the Grandeur of the Citys High Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Square Bombing Suspect Appears in Court
description: Over the last two weeks, the naturalized Pakistani immigrant charged with driving a crude car bomb into Times Square settled into something of a strange daily routine: He signed a piece of paper waiving his right to a lawyer and a speedy court appearance. Then he continued to talk to federal authorities, providing what they have called valuable intelligence.

title: Industry Strives for Cleaner Oil From Oil Sands
description: As Elisabeth Rosenthal and I discuss in an article appearing Wednesday in Business Day, oil sands  or tar sands, as their detractors like to call them  have a serious image problem, even among fossil fuels.

title: The Hurdles of Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: The Senate at the Finish Line
description: It is a bad sign, as the Senate enters the home stretch on financial regulatory reform, that there are so many unresolved issues since weaknesses and ambiguities in the legislation play into the hands of opponents of reform at this late date. It is especially disturbing that the vital area of reform  the regulation of derivatives trading  is being left to last.

title: Symantec Nears Deal for VeriSigns Security Unit
description: 9:46 p.m. | Updated Symantec is near a deal to buy VeriSigns authentication services unit for $1.3 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Close to the Beach
description: A 530-square meter (5,700-square-foot) farmhouse in Plettenberg Bay is on the market for 6.5 million rand ($856,000).

title: Crane Owner Pleads Guilty to Bribery
description: The owner of a crane company pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he had bribed the former chief crane inspector for the citys Department of Buildings.

title: A Follow-Up to Home-Delivered Diet Meals
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulf Oil Again Imperils Sea Turtle
description: PADRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE, Tex.  It is nesting season here, and just offshore, Kemps ridley sea turtle No. 15 circles in the water before dragging herself onto the sand to lay another clutch of eggs.

title: Iran, the Deal and the Council
description: Every time it looks as if the big powers have finally run out of patience with Irans nuclear misdeeds, Tehrans leaders suddenly decide theyre in the mood to compromise. And every time the big powers let up on the pressure, Tehrans compromises turn to smoke.

title: Life in the Third Realm
description: Its that time of the month again. Yes: its time for Life-form of the Month. In case youve forgotten, this coming Saturday is International Day for Biological Diversity, a day of celebrations and parties to appreciate the other occupants of the planet. So if you do nothing else this weekend, drink a toast to Other Life-forms! In honor of this event, my nomination for Life-form of the Month: May is a group of abundant and fascinating beings that are undeservedly obscure: the archaea.

title: Yvonne Loriod, Pianist and Messiaen Muse, Dies at 86
description: Yvonne Loriod, the French pianist whose musical exactitude and intensity inspired numerous masterpieces by her husband, the composer Olivier Messiaen, died on Monday at a retirement home in Saint-Denis, on the edge of Paris. She was 86.

title: Off the Menu
description: East End Openings

title: 2 Officers, 2 Courts and Charges of Eliciting Sexual Favors
description: Both cases started the same way, with a womans complaint that she had been coerced into performing sexual favors for a police officer. The ensuing investigations reached the same alarming conclusion: These women were not the only victims.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Chicken on the Agenda

title: Spideys Song Is Sung
description: The rock band Carney on Tuesday unveiled a new song by U2, Boy Falls From the Sky, an emolike mix of ballad and hard, aching energy that is intended as a major number in Act II of the coming Broadway mega-musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. Bono and the Edge of U2 wrote Boy and a dozen more songs for the show, their first Broadway musical, which has suffered production delays because of financial problems but is expected to begin performances in New York this fall. Reeve Carney, the singer-frontman of the band that bears his name, is set to play Peter Parker and Spider-Man on Broadway, though he did not act in character while performing Boy at a luncheon honoring the musicals director, Julie Taymor. In the musical, Peter Parker sings the number after his love interest, Mary Jane, has been abducted and his super-powers are gone. Before the luncheon, Ms. Taymor described the financial stakes of the musical as extraordinarily high, saying Spider-Man would need to be a huge audience hit on par with her Disney musical The Lion King to cover its significant costs and ultimately turn a profit. But she sounded a note of confidence, adding: Im not doing this for a small audience. Im doing it for a world audience.

title: Education Secretary Steps Into a Minefield in Brooklyn
description: It was meant to be a cheerful visit to put the spotlight on successful teachers and charter schools  an event that more-cynical observers tend to call a dog and pony show.

title: Charlie Sheen Returning to Two and a Half Men
description: Charlie Sheen, below, said he would remain with his long-running sitcom, Two and a Half Men, The Hollywood Reporter said. In a statement, Mr. Sheen said, To put a fitting end on the two and one-half months of whirlwind speculation, Im looking forward to returning to my CBS home on Monday nights. Mr. Sheen, whose contract expired last month, set off a wave of speculation about his status with the show by stating that he was prepared to walk away from it. The comedy continues to perform strongly in its seventh season, drawing nearly 15 million viewers an episode, and there was speculation that Mr. Sheens willingness to leave the show was a renegotiation ploy. The Hollywood Reporter said Mr. Sheen had re-signed for two more seasons. A jury trial for Mr. Sheen is scheduled to begin on July 21 in Aspen, Colo., where he will face domestic violence charges stemming from an altercation with his wife, Brooke Mueller.

title: Colleague Says Blumenthal Claims Grew in Time
description: Former Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut found it puzzling: over time, his friend Attorney General Richard Blumenthal kept revising how he talked about his military service during the Vietnam War. At first, in the 1980s, he was humble. He played it down, Mr. Shays recalled, characterizing it as humdrum desk work.

title: Elvis Costello Cancels Concerts in Israel
description: Elvis Costello has canceled two concerts he was planning to perform in Israel this summer, citing the complexities of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Costello was scheduled to appear at the Caesarea Amphitheater on June 30 and July 1. But in a statement on his official Web site, he wrote, It is after considerable contemplation that I have lately arrived at the decision that I must withdraw from the two performances. Mr. Costello went on to write that there are occasions when merely having your name added to a concert schedule may be interpreted as a political act that resonates more than anything that might be sung, and he added, I must believe that the audience for the coming concerts would have contained many people who question the policies of their government on settlement and deplore conditions that visit intimidation, humiliation or much worse on Palestinian civilians in the name of national security. Mr. Costello, above right, also said that he was keenly aware of the sensitivity of these themes in the wake of so many despicable acts of violence perpetrated in the name of liberation.

title: Clients Worried About Goldmans Dueling Goals
description: Questions have been raised that go to the heart of this institutions most fundamental value: how we treat our clients.  Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman Sachss C.E.O., at the firms annual meeting in May

title: Guns N Roses Gets Its Own Vook
description: A video-enhanced digital book chronicling the exploits of the rock band Guns N Roses will be released on Wednesday by Vook, the multimedia company. The video-enhanced book, or vook, Reckless Road, will include the text of the book of the same title by Marc Canter, the bands historian, accompanied by videos, pictures and behind-the-scenes interviews with strippers, roadies, ex-bandmates and rock insiders, Vook announced on Tuesday. Vook has joined with publishers and authors to make enhanced editions of electronic books, including a short story by Anne Rice and a childrens book by Rudyard Kipling, that can be read on iPhones, iPads and other digital devices.

title: A New Chance in New Orleans
description: The Justice Department described the New Orleans Police Department earlier this year as one of the nations worst. There is no doubt about that. The city suffers from one of the countrys highest rates of violent crime and unsolved murders. Its police force is currently the subject of at least eight federal investigations into accusations of brutality and unjustified killings of citizens at the hands of armed officers.

title: Dancing Scores Again
description: The final four couples on Dancing With the Stars competed on Monday night as that ABC reality show drew 18.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC was No. 1 for the evening while CBS placed second.

title: College Bound, DNA Swab in Hand
description: Instead of the usual required summer-reading book, this years incoming freshmen at the University of California, Berkeley, will get something quite different: a cotton swab on which they can, if they choose, send in a DNA sample.

title: Early Census Is Found in a New Jersey Universitys Files
description: Talk about being late with your census forms. Curators at Kean University in New Jersey recently found a population count of the United States from an actual enumeration conducted at least four years before the countrys first official census in 1790.

title: Lottery Numbers
What You Get for ... $725,000
description: LIVINGSTON, MONT.

title: Wizards Go From Chaos to the Top Draft Choice
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  The machine that swirls the Ping-Pong balls does not have a conscience or sympathy, just a rush of air and a low hum. Occasionally, however, a little karma seeps out when the motor starts for the N.B.A. draft lottery.

title: Obie Awards Presented
description: Annie Bakers play Circle Mirror Transformation, a comic look at a group of strangers who come together in a creative drama class, was among the most celebrated productions at this years Obie Awards, which are presented annually by The Village Voice to honor Off Broadway theater. In a ceremony on Monday night the Circle Mirror Transformation cast (Reed Birney, Tracee Chimo, Peter Friedman, Deirdre OConnell and Heidi Schreck) was given an award as an ensemble in the Obies performance category. Sam Gold, who directed the production for Playwrights Horizons, also won an Obie as director of Circle Mirror Transformation and The Aliens, a play by Ms. Baker that is being presented by Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. The Aliens, about a group of young men who gather outside a coffeehouse, and Circle Mirror Transformation shared the award for best new American play. Other performance awards were given to Dane DeHaan (The Aliens), Jonathan Hammond (The Boys in the Band), Marc Damon Johnson (The Brother/Sister Plays), Laurie Metcalf (A Lie of the Mind) and Juliet Rylance (As You Like It).

title: Donovan Pushes Ahead, Looking Inside
description: PRINCETON, N.J.

title: Grants Focus on Regional Issues

The foundation will support efforts to expand affordable housing, build and enhance public transportation systems, and extend the use of regional land banks to address the problems of abandoned urban neighborhoods. Additionally, Ford, which has long supported various community development efforts, will now direct any money it grants for urban revitalization toward building integrated urban-suburban regions. Metropolitan areas that manage to interweave urban and suburban development, everything from transportation to arts and culture, attract more people and more investment, Luis Ubinas, Fords president, said in an address to a conference of local, state and federal officials concerned about the redevelopment of cities that have relied heavily on the auto industry, which is now shrinking.

title: Phys Ed: Do Our Genes Influence Our Desire to Exercise?
description: Is the urge to exercise bred in our bones? Thats the intriguing question that European researchers recently set out to examine by looking at the activity habits of 37,051 sets of twins. Twins are popular with geneticists, because they provide a neat statistical model for determining whether a behavior is influenced by genetics or exclusively by environment. Identical twins share 100 percent of their genome, fraternal twins share 50 percent. All twin pairs, if raised together, share approximately the same early environment. So if a behavior is more common between identical twins than between fraternal twins, it is presumably being directed to some degree by genes.

Battlefield And Church Among Threatened Sites
description: The battlefield where Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant faced off for the first time in the Civil War is among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday. Wal-Mart plans to build a 240,000-square-foot store within the historic boundaries of the Wilderness Battlefield and adjacent to the Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park, which protects only a portion of the battlefield. The 51-acre Wal-Mart development would include a supercenter store and other chain retail stores. We know from experience this will draw other sprawl, the trusts president, Richard Moe, said in a telephone interview. Its total saturation at the expense of history. Mr. Moe is to announce the 2010 list at the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, above  the national cathedral of African Methodism and a landmark. The Wilderness site is famous for two days of bitter fighting in May 1864 that left nearly 30,000 casualties  dead, wounded or missing. Other sites on this years roster are Hinchliffe Stadium, in Paterson, N.J., one of the last remaining Negro League ballparks; the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, known for its decorative bridges and natural landscaping; and the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, which held the funerals of Frederick Douglass in 1895 and Rosa Parks a century later.

title: City Halls Economic Development Chief to Step Down

title: City Tells Carriage-Horse Stable Its Time to Close

But by mid-June, those shavings, the smell of manure, and the quiet whispers of the stables Irish owners will probably be replaced by the sites and sounds of construction as the city plans to move forward with a luxury and moderately priced housing development that will also include a new school, stores and open space.

title: Justin Bieber Nabs a BET Nomination

The teen pop star and hair-spiration, will compete for a best new artist prize with Wale, a rapper from Washington, and Young Money, the rapper Drakes group, among others. The awards, from the Black Entertainment Television cable channel, usually honor African-American artists and performers like Jay-Z, Beyonc and Alicia Keys, who lead the nominations this year. But Stephen Hill, BETs President of Music Programing and Specials, said he considered Mr. Bieber a crossover artist, according to Reuters.

title: Authorities Say Passenger Voices Were Recorded in Cockpit of Doomed Polish Plane

title: Academies (Again) Seek Climate Action
description: The National Academies, fulfilling a congressional request, have issued a trio of invaluable reports affirming the scientific case for a growing and largely harmful human influence on climate; proposing a path and strategies for curbing American emissions of heat-trapping gases; and urging the country to work to cut risks attending life with no new normal climate patterns or coastlines.

title: Does Exercise Make Raynauds Worse?

Those are among the questions posed by readers about Raynauds phenomenon, the mysterious ailment that causes painful feelings of coldness in the fingers and toes. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School explores the links between exercise and Raynauds. For more information, see Dr. Wigleys earlier responses in How Serious Is Raynauds Phenomenon? and Ask the Expert: Raynauds Phenomenon, as well as The Times Health Guide: Raynauds.

Coffee, Kickstand brings fresh, hand-crafted coffee to the grassy splendor of a public park. Weather permitting.

title: Worst Week for Album Sales Since 1991
description: Combine the downward trend of album sales with a week of no major releases and what do you get? The fewest number of total album sales, 5.3 million, in a single week since Nielsen SoundScan started its tracking in 1991. Topping this weeks Billboard chart is Justin Biebers My World 2.0 (Island), its fourth time in the spot, with sales of just over 60,000, barely escaping the specter of being the lowest selling No. 1 album in SoundScans history. (The Dreamgirls soundtrack sold about 300 fewer copies in January 2007.) Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), the years most consistent seller, stayed at No. 2 for the fourth straight week, moving 54,000 copies.

title: Geek Chic | Power Ranger
description: Considering how long stylish travelers have had to cart around less-than-beautiful electrical doohickeys, its a wonder that fashion hasnt come to the rescue sooner. The Yves Saint Laurent travel adapter ($450) is a one-piece electrical dual-voltage plug adapter that connects gadget to outlet in any combination in more than 150 countries (Japanese cellphone to American outlet, German shaver to Australian socket). The circular device swivels to each regions plug, and a leather bag available in fuchsia, black and violet provides the panache.

title: Last Nights Elections
description: It wasnt a good night for Republicans. Yes, the G.O.P. can theoretically retake the House of Representatives without winning races like Pennsylvanias 12th district (which has been solidly Democratic for years, after all). But at the very least Mark Critzs relatively easy victory in yesterdays special election should throw some cold water on the more optimistic conservative visions for how this November will shake out. Yes, Pat Toomey polls almost as well against the victorious Joe Sestak as he did against against Arlen Specter. But given the mood in the country these days, I bet that Toomey would have preferred to campaign against a turncoat five-term incumbent this autumn, rather than a fresh-faced (by political standards) former rear admiral. And yes, Rand Paul will probably be the next United States senator from Kentucky  but hes clearly less of a shoo-in for the G.O.P. than Trey Grayson likely would have been, had matters been arranged differently.

title: Threatened Historical Sites Include Battlefield
description: The battlefield where Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant faced off for the first time in the Civil War is among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday. Wal-Mart plans to build a 240,000-square-foot store within the historic boundaries of the Wilderness Battlefield and adjacent to the Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park, which protects only a portion of the battlefield. The 51-acre Wal-Mart development would include a supercenter store and other chain retail stores. We know from experience this will draw other sprawl, the trusts president, Richard Moe, said in a telephone interview. Its total saturation at the expense of history. Mr. Moe is to announce the 2010 list at the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, above  the national cathedral of African Methodism and a landmark. The Wilderness site is famous for two days of bitter fighting in May 1864 that left nearly 30,000 casualties  dead, wounded or missing. Other sites on this years roster are Hinchliffe Stadium, in Paterson, N.J., one of the last remaining Negro League ballparks; the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, known for its decorative bridges and natural landscaping; and the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, which held the funerals of Frederick Douglass in 1895 and Rosa Parks a century later.

title: Gregory Krum | Practicing Photographer
description: Photographic evidence  say, the kind of indefatigable proof that one has, in fact, visited the Great Wall of China  typically suffices as testament to having actually been there and done that. The photographer Gregory Krum (who is also the director of retail for the shop at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum) has been to the base of the Matterhorn and has seen the tombstones erected there in a climbers cemetery. The photos he took areon display as part of his first solo exhibition, Practice, at Jen Bekman Gallery in SoHo. These images, along with shots of flowers, dust, still-lifes and interiors also seek to illuminate something inherently more tenuous: devotion. The idea behind the show is those things that become true solely by belief, he says.

title: Theater Talkback: Scenes With Streams (and Squirts)

What would Macbeth be without a few buckets of stage blood? Or Ophelia without tears, be they real or glycerine? As for sweat, well, you try standing under a ceiling of thousand-watt bulbs in full costume and keeping your powder dry. (I have been dripped upon by heavily perspiring actors in intimate environmental productions.) Add to this trio of effluvia projectile spitting, which often accompanies fierce diction in emotional scenes and can be a hazard for front-row audience members.

description: 11:50 p.m. | Updated  Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts has convinced BP to start streaming live video from the seabed oil gusher, he announced on his House Web site tonight.

title: Sad News Highlights Service to Country for Bradley
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  The United States World Cup training camp turned somber for Coach Bob Bradley on Wednesday, when he learned that a family friend had been killed a day earlier by a roadside bomb while serving in the military in Afghanistan.

title: Fulton Stall Market Is Opening Soon for the Season
description: The Fulton Stall Market at South Street Seaport will open on May 30 for the second year. It will operate noon to 6 p.m. every Sunday and Wednesday through Oct. 3. Some new vendors include:

title: Do Scores Counselors Know the Score?
description: There are not a lot of places to go for small-business advice. One of the places most frequently mentioned on this blog and in other business venues is Score, an organization that is affiliated with the Small Business Administration. If you go to the Web site, you will find that Score is a nonprofit 503c organization that was started in 1964 and has 364 offices and about 12,400 volunteers who help small businesses succeed. Its slogan is Counselors to Americas small business. If you go through the Web site, you will find an impressive board of directors, a variety of ways to get advice and lots of success stories.

title: Wisdom in the Palm of Your Hand
description: Whats the meaning of life? Theres an app for that.AskPhilosophers.org, a Web site that makes philosophers available to answer questions, is going mobile, creating a free downloadable app for mobile devices.

title: Preakness Cant Keep Derby Viewers
description: Lookin at Luckys Preakness Stakes victory on Saturday attracted an average of 8.4 million viewers on NBC, down 23 percent from the 10.9 million who watched the filly Rachel Alexandras win at Pimlico last year.

title: And Then the Clothes Come Off
description: DO I look like a Pomeranian? Cary Curran, a k a Cherry Dazzle, asked on Sunday. Inverted over a velvet pouf in a backstage area of a party space on lower Fifth Avenue, Ms. Curran was grooming her peroxide hair into pert little ponytails.

title: Answers About Free Events in New Yorks Parks
description: Following is the first set of responses from David Rivel, the executive director of City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that organizes free arts, sports and education programs and activities in New Yorks parks.

description: Typing documents on the iPads touch screen keyboard can be a chore. As I wrote in an article earlier this month, one solution is to pair up an Apple Bluetooth wireless keyboard with the iPad.

description: Marines and Afghan soldiers have been taking fire regularly as they try to eliminate pockets of resistance around Marja, a town that was largely wrested from the Taliban earlier this year.

title: Lincoln Center Finally Gets a Lawn
description: Do walk on the grass.

description: I really feel it was a bargain, said John Reznikoff.

description: Hollywood clashed with Wall Street on Wednesday at a government hearing about the potential sale of futures contracts linked to box office receipts of major motion pictures.

title: Booker Prize Awarded  for 1970
description: Its a little late, but the best book of 1970 has finally won its Man Booker prize. Troubles, by J. G. Farrell, was anointed the winner of the Lost Man Booker Prize, a one-time-only award intended to honor the books that missed out an opportunity to win the Booker Prize in 1970, the Booker Prize Foundation announced on Wednesday.

title: Developer May Proceed With Apthorp Conversion
description: After an extensive investigation into the renovation of the storied Apthorp apartment building on Manhattans Upper West Side, the New York attorney general has given the developer approval to move forward and start closing on luxury apartments there.

title: Old School Gregg Araki at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  A onetime enfant terrible and a central figure of the 1990s New Queer Cinema, Gregg Araki seemed to inaugurate a new phase of his career in 2004 with Mysterious Skin, a tender story about two young men haunted by a formative sexual trauma. He followed that film, which many critics considered his best and most mature, with the eccentric stoner comedy Smiley Face (2007), which has become an underground hit on DVD.

title: Men in Tights | A Brief History
description: Sadly, for me at least, the new Robin Hood movie is bereft of tights. Its got grit. It has a vibrant undertone of socioeconomic injustice. Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett are great; praise the Lord and pass the Oscar campaign. But there are no tights in this Nottingham, alas. Despite being an unapologetic old school swashbuckler, Crowe recently apologized in The Chicago Tribune, to everybody who wants tights. They, he said, never made sense to meyoure a bloke, you live in the forest, and you wear tights? Well, yeah, whats the problem? Tights were developed precisely by blokes on horses in forests. (They are cousins of riding breeches.) Whats the worst that can happen? You pass a briar, a burr is buried and you get a run in your tights? Man up, Robin Hood, you live life on the run. Crowe should not have cowed from the challenge of tights but since he has, weve compiled some great moments of men in tights.

title: Organic Feed? Birds Say No Thanks
description: Birds may prefer conventionally grown seed over organic seed, according to a new study in the Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture. Wild birds visiting more than 30 gardens across the north of England consciously chose to stick with conventional seed after eating both varieties, said Ailsa McKenzie, the studys lead author and a research associate at the School of Biology at Newcastle University.

title: Keeping It Simple, the Flyers Zip Along in the Playoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA  Pinning down Philadelphia Flyers defenseman Chris Pronger these days for his grizzled perspective seems to be as difficult as checking him into the boards. The 35-year-old Pronger, 6 feet 6 inches and 220 pounds, gets a kick out of dodging big-picture questions.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangkok and Elsewhere
description: A crackdown on antigovernment protesters begun by the Thai military on Wednesday degenerated into riots, firebombing attacks, looting and street battles after militants allied with the protest movement resisted the armys onslaught with grenades and assault weapons.

title: When Its Important, Its Paper
description: Never let it be said that the world of fine personal stationery is without its drama.

title: Club for Growth Endorses in Nevada
description: The Club for Growth has endorsed Sharron Angle in Nevadas Senate race, a move that could give the former state assemblywoman a boost in the Republican primary.

title: Sea Lion Population at Pier 39 Stages Comeback
description: Hark: Whats that barking sound?

title: Symantec Confirms $1.3 Billion Deal for VeriSign Unit
description: Symantec announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy VeriSigns authentication services business, which encrypts online payments, for $1.28 billion in cash.

title: Pactivs Shares Climb as 2 More Bidders Are Seen
description: Shares of Pactiv, the maker of Hefty trash bags, rose as much as 7 percent on Wednesday after a report that two more companies are interested in buying it.

title: Upfronts: CBSs Moonves Sounds an Especially Upbeat Note
description: Virtually everyone in the TV industry is expecting this years upfront to draw millions of dollars more in advertising commitments than the one last year, which was beaten down by the recession.

title: M.T.A. to End Relationship With Goldman Sachs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to sever its relationship with Goldman Sachs, the transit agencys longtime financial adviser, according to two individuals with knowledge of its decision.

title: Photo Replay: May 19
description: A view of the day in sports, including soccer players on snowy mountains and dirt fields.

title: Building a Network of Gay Entrepreneurs
description: Lots of entrepreneurs would like to pick Chip Conleys brain. But when several dozen gathered in November to meet the founder of Joie de Vivre, a boutique hotel chain that he said had $220 million in revenue last year, their questions were not just about the nuts and bolts of running a company.

title: Who Are They, Indeed
description: THE latest teen-fashion-focused store to set up shop on the block of 34th Street east of Macys, the one that is quickly becoming Manhattans version of the Mall at Short Hills, is called WHO.A.U. Thats text-ese for who are you?  which is surely what a lot of people must be thinking when they see a giant stuffed bear wearing patchwork madras shorts in the window.

title: A Sneak Peek of 2011 Jeep Grand Cherokee
description: 8:06 a.m. | Updated

title: Senate Fails to Advance Financial Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday rejected an effort by Democratic leaders to complete work on a sweeping financial regulatory bill as two key Democratic holdouts said it still did not tighten rules on Wall Street enough.

title: Handle With Care | The Campanas Get Creepy
description: If youve ever looked askance at a piece by the Brazilian designers Humberto and Fernando Campana and wondered what they were thinking or what youre supposed to be thinking  youre not alone. Their new monograph, Campana Brothers: Complete Works (So Far), which is published by Rizzoli, may help explain the method behind what often seems like madness. The hefty book was published with three different covers, each of which is a different color and embellished with circular patterns that look hand stitched. Our work is very texturized, so we wanted to bring an element of this to the book  to make it an object in itself, to make it feel handmade, Humberto explained. He likes the black cover best because it shows the lines, the color becomes much more alive. His brother Fernando prefers the green.

title: Democratic Holdouts Block Financial Bill
description: 5:42 p.m. | Updated The Senate on Wednesday rejected an effort by Democratic leaders to complete work on a sweeping financial regulatory bill as two key Democratic holdouts said it still did not sufficiently tighten rules on Wall Street, The New York Timess David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

title: Letter: The Cathar Threat
description: To the Editor: The cover article, The Besieged and the Beautiful; (May 9), on the crusade against the Cathars, does not present the full story. A much more serious issue than religious fanaticism was involved. The Cathars Gnostic belief that the physical world was so evil that children should not be brought into it was a major threat to the prosperity and even the very survival of the secular governments. A depopulated Europe would have been at even greater risk at a time when every sword was needed to defend Christian countries against Islamic invaders.

title: Another C.C. in the Yankees Future?
description: With the Tampa Bay Rays making their first appearance of the season at Yankee Stadium, it was only natural to wonder about the future of Carl Crawford, their star left fielder. Crawford has tormented the Yankees and the rest of baseball in his nine-year career, and he will be a free agent after the season.

title: Letter: Scotland Seasons
description: To the Editor: Regarding A Baedeker, 100 Years Later (May 9): Married to Pat, a Scottish lass, for over 44 years, Ive visited Scotland almost every year since 1966, including a few visits to Hamilton and Mallaig. To visit in January, as the author Simon Akam did, would be akin to riding around Manhattan on the upper deck of an open-top tour bus during a winter blizzard at midnight. No small wonder that the Alexandra Hotel looked like a stern and gray matron.

title: Revisiting Main St., Rethinking the Myth
description: A LESSER-KNOWN version of the Rolling Stones Loving Cup, found on the bonus disc of the new reissue of the bands 1972 album, Exile on Main St., seems to me the best thing the Stones ever did.

title: Beneath the Surface, More and More Layers
description: A really big man takes a very long bath in Restoration, the leisurely new comedy written by and starring Claudia Shear, and hes not the only one who comes clean. In this girl-meets-statue story, Giulia (Ms. Shear), a lonely Brooklyn art conservator, lands the plum job of scrubbing down Michelangelos 17-foot statue of David at the Galleria dellAccademia in Florence.

title: Frugal Europe, on Foot
description: ONCE upon a time, a young man went for a walk. It was December 1933, and an 18-year-old Englishman named Patrick Leigh Fermor put on a pair of hobnail boots and a secondhand greatcoat, gathered up his rucksack and left London on a ship bound for Rotterdam, where he planned to travel 1,400 miles to Istanbul  on foot. He had virtually no money; at best, hed arrive in, say, Munich to find his mother had sent him 5. But what he did have was an outgoing nature, a sense of adventure, an affinity for languages and a broad network of friends of friends.

title: Inside 'Le Grand Macabre'
description: The director Douglas Fitch and the producer Edouard Getaz discuss the New York Philharmonic's staged production of "Le Grand Macabre."

title: Memories of Gino
description: Ping went the in-box here at Diners Journal and there was a message from John Pizzarelli, the great bandleader, guitarist and entertainer. Mr. Pizzarellis letter was a lament at yesterdays news that Gino, the East Side Italian restaurant, would close on May 29. We publish it below because the memories are sweet and worth ventilating.

title: Finding a More Serene Vietnam
description: AS the suns last rays streaked the sky bubble-gum pink and tangerine, the residents of Con Dao Island were calling it a day, and the mile-and-a-half-long beachfront promenade that serves as this small Vietnamese islands social hub was filling up as the heat of the day finally relented.

title: Hotel Review: CitizenM Hotel in Amsterdam
description: THE BASICS

title: The State Dinners Menu and Guest List
description: As President Obama and Michelle Obama host their second state dinner, this one for President Felipe Caldern of Mexico, they may be without the company of the gatecrashing Salahis, but they have a few other notables on the guest list.

title: Videophiles | Earth Matter
description: Videophiles features a series of clips curated for The Moment by cutting-edge directors, artists and other creative types.

title: The Invisible Bridge
description: Chapter 1: A Letter

title: Saving Towns by Filling Rooms in Italy
description: ONE spring afternoon in the early 1980s Giancarlo DallAra, an Italian hotel marketing consultant, was wandering the streets of a tiny village near Maranzanis, in Friuli, a rural mountainous region in the northeast corner of Italy.

title: Saint Anns Chooses New Headmaster
description: Saint Anns School, the prestigious and progressive Brooklyn Heights school, has selected Vincent Tompkins, the deputy provost of Brown University, to be its new headmaster.

title: Big Sensor, Tiny Camera, Nice Results
description: Centuries ago, a young boy in Japan was preparing for a long journey. You will need much drinking water, said his master. Construct a barrel that will catch the rain.

title: An Arts Enclave in Cape Town
description: JUST southeast of downtown, Woodstock was one of few Cape Town communities to, in part, avoid South Africas Group Areas Act. That strict apartheid policy demarcated regions by race, forcefully removing residents; Woodstock, however, managed to maintain aspects of its multiethnic character. While its still shedding the coarse complexities of an impoverished past, Woodstock is evolving into the media hub of the countrys Mother City.

title: Friends Gathered Around in Celebration of Bechet
description: The gig by the clarinetist Evan Christopher on Monday night took place in a theater, but the language of the show was house party. It was sponsored by the Sidney Bechet Society, which since 1997 has promoted music associated with Bechet  which is to say New Orleans and Chicago jazz of the 1920s.

title: Landing in New York After Circling It for 60 Years
description: For stars who have devoted their careers to flaunting hard-edged glamour, there often comes a time when the urge to pull back the tinselly curtain and be real is irresistible. But how real is real if what is exposed is show business reality?

title: Getting Muddy in the Netherlands
description: WERE driving on top of a dike in the northern province of Friesland in the Netherlands, with a sliver of pink-hued sunrise slicing through an otherwise gray sky. We zoom past verdant pastures full of cows and sheep, past centuries-old churches, and past windmills, both old and modern. I notice the blades on the newer machines are spinning fast. Thats a bad sign: more wind means more water. That is, more water in the Wadden Sea, a thin and shallow stretch of the North Sea that separates the Dutch mainland from a series of islands, including Ameland, a narrow slip of pristine land thats home to four villages.

title: Store Review: Greece Is for Lovers, in Athens
description: The tourist-packed streets at the base of the Acropolis in Athens are a vibrant if somewhat kitsch-laden extension of the achievements of ancient Greece. Kiosks overflow with posters and guidebooks, and the roads are jammed with shops selling everything from pricey marble busts of Athena to gaudy Parthenon refrigerator magnets.

title: Architects at Play, Dangling Medals
description: THE veterans debated over which was more memorable: the Versailles dinner, with fountains and all, for Tadao Ando, or the gilded reception for architectures queen bee, Zaha Hadid, in St. Petersburg. Rem Koolhaas had his shining moment beneath the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, while the Clintons brought out the White House welcome mat for Renzo Piano in that heady, pre-dot-com-bust year of 1998.

title: Revolutionary Militant as Thug
description: CANNES, France  The Cannes Film Festival has become the go-to event to see premieres of backbreaking biopics about far-left (and far-out) Latino warriors: in 2008, Steven Soderberghs 286-minute Che played here and on Wednesday, Olivier Assayass 333-minute Carlos did. Long before the festival opened, this 5 hour 33 minute movie about the Venezuelan-born terrorist, international man of mystery and brutishly committed ladies man, Ilich Ramrez Snchez  i.e., Carlos the Jackal  was a must-see. The movie, which screened just once, and out of competition, is scheduled to play on French television this week. It is likely to pop up in the United States this fall at the New York Film Festival before it plays on-demand and in good old-fashioned theaters.

title: A Game That Thinks Its an Eerie TV Drama
description: Among the more interesting aspects of the video game world is that the sequels are often better than the originals. After all, continual creative iteration is the heart of game design. Most of that process should take place before the game is released to the public, but there are plenty of franchises that have not come into their own until a second title addresses the flaws of the first. (My favorite games of 2009, Assassins Creed II and Uncharted 2, provide recent examples.)

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. The Harvard scammer. Harvard is being karmically punished for having foisted Facebook and Alan Dershowitz on the world.

title: Idol Wins the Night
description: Lee DeWyze, Crystal Bowersox and Casey James performed in the semifinal round of American Idol on Tuesday as the Fox reality show attracted 18.3 million viewers and the largest audience in prime time, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox won the nights ratings over all thanks largely to Idol at 8 p.m. CBS finished close behind Fox as its complementary crime shows NCIS (15.6 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (15.2 million) remained strong opposite the competition. ABC ranked third, and NBC was fourth.

title: Theater Cancels Play With Wiesel Character
description: A Jewish theater in Washington, Theater J, has canceled a play that included a character based on Elie Wiesel after he objected, The Washington Post reported. The play, Imagining Madoff, by Deb Margolin, included a fictional meeting between Bernard L. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and writer, who lost several million dollars of his wealth as well as all of the assets of his foundation, in Mr. Madoffs huge Ponzi scheme. Ms. Margolin told The Post that she had used Mr. Wiesel as a foil for Mr. Madoff because his name is synonymous with decency, morality, the struggle for human dignity and kindness. But Mr. Wiesel apparently saw the representation differently. After reading the script, he called the play defamatory and obscene and threatened to have his lawyer try to stop the production. Theater Js artistic director, Ari Roth, suggested that Ms. Margolin revise the play and replace Mr. Wiesel with a fictional character. She ultimately declined. Imagining Madoff was to open Theater Js season in August; it has been replaced with Something You Did, by Willy Holtzman.

title: TV Networks Plan Cancer Fund-Raiser
description: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to broadcast a cancer research fund-raiser in September to be hosted by the evening news anchors at each network. The event, Stand Up to Cancer, is a sequel; the first such telethon took place in September 2008 and helped to raise more than $100 million, according to the organizers at the nonprofit Entertainment Industry Foundation. This years telethon, on the night of Sept. 10, will be hosted by Brian Williams of NBC, Diane Sawyer of ABC and Katie Couric, above, of CBS. The broadcast is a way of saying, Together, we can do this, Ms. Sawyer said in a statement. The three networks are donating an hour of prime time for the commercial-free, celebrity-heavy event, and they will be joined by HBO, E!, Discovery Health and the MLB Network, among others. The original event in 2008 wound up being shown in 170 countries, the foundation said.

title: Oil Is Fouling Wetlands, Official Says
description: VENICE, La.  Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Wednesday that sheets of heavy crude oil from the offshore spill had seeped deep into the delicate marshes around the mouth of the Mississippi River. He called on the federal government to approve a plan to build sand berms to protect the bayou country.

title: Now in Berlin, Tastes of Mexico
description: WHEN Maria Bonita opened in Berlins Prenzlauer Berg district in August, the rundown, eight-barstool restaurant created a sensation. In a city where seeded rolls accompany ketchup-based salsa, and burritos are doused in mayonnaise, Maria Bonita was serving up fresh Mexican street food: thick Oaxacan corn tortillas filled with salted meat and cactus salad, homemade chorizo, deep-fried pork skins and egg-filled tortillas baked in a creamy habanero-pumpkinseed sauce.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
description: THE Plaza, the heart of old Santa Fe, hasnt changed much since the Spanish settled here 400 years ago. But surrounding the Plaza is an increasingly cosmopolitan city. Sure, its possible to focus entirely just on the historic center, where Native American handicrafts are for sale on every corner.

title: Tech Talk Podcast
description: On this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Brad Stone about YouTubes past, present and future. Five years after its debut as a quirky repository of online videos, YouTube says that more than two billion videos a day are viewed on the site. Its owner, Google, plans to expand its reach to the television set, and as Mr. Stone explains, YouTube is expected to play a important role in that effort.

title: In Petipas Tragedy, a Meeting of Dreams, Devotion, Death and Opium
description: After a work of theater art is over, two different ideas of it can form in your mind. Theres the actual impression it has made, which becomes mysteriously connected to your imagination and can grow powerfully. (In ballet, this effect can be remarkably like that of drugs. This is why some people need to keep returning to the same work several times in quick succession, in need of a fix.) But theres also the theory of it, so that we find ourselves starting to engage anew with what Shakespeare wanted to express in As You Like It, or Mozart in The Magic Flute.

title: Amid War, Destinies Are Found and Lost
description: In the first half of The Invisible Bridge, Julie Orringer tells the evocative, coincidence-strewn, oddly theatrical story of Andras Levi, a young Hungarian Jew who travels to Paris in 1937 to study architecture.

title: Newly Released Books
description: The coming-of-age novel is a perennial favorite, and this months list of new books is rich with examples. Whether in the hothouse environment of an arts school or in Iraq in the 1940s, adolescents struggling toward adulthood offer moments of tenderness and amusement. And, of course, there are killers, too.

title: The Insider | Jonathan Caouette
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: Three Lighthearted Debuts From a Familiar Classicist
description: Since Beethovens death in 1827, musicians and academics have pored over his life, letters and documents with a fine-tooth comb; even his hair was the subject of an entire book. By now a new scholarly treatise analyzing his fingernails seems likelier than an evening of Beethoven premieres.

title: Putting New Faces on Islamic History
description: ONE balmy evening this month, a glamorous crowd was packed into the tiny Leila Taghinia-Milani Heller Gallery on the Upper East Side for the opening of  Icons,  a show of video installations by the Iranian-born filmmaker Shoja Azari that runs through Friday.

title: Against Juristocracy
description: Writing for National Review Online, Robert F. Nagel offers a critique of the right-wing hope that the Supreme Court will overturn Obamacare, and a brief against the judicial usurpation of politics in general. Here are some of the arguments he musters for a judicial system that knows when to leave well enough alone:

title: M.T.A. to End Relationship With Goldman Sachs
description: From Michael M. Grynbaum at City Room:

title: Worried Girl Asks Michelle Obama if Her Mother Will Be Deported
description: Updated | Friday | 10:40 a.m. Michelle Obama fielded an awkward question on the immigration debate on Wednesday. It came from a worried young girl who seemed to say that her mother is an illegal immigrant. The encounter, caught on video, came during a visit by the first lady and Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexican President Felipe Caldern to a second-grade class in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Celluloid Tribute to a Painter Who Gave Life to Dinosaurs
description: Charles R. Knight is not much of a household name these days. But his work is thrillingly familiar to anyone whos ever stood entranced before his murals of grazing mastodons and rampaging tyrannosaurs at the American Museum of Natural History or other museums, or leafed through certain grade-school science textbooks.

title: Back to Rage Anew, Fires Smoldering Still
description: For your dubious pleasure! John Lydon proclaimed as Public Image Ltd. started its set on Tuesday night at Terminal 5. That was Mr. Lydons famous cynicism. His corrosive mockery made him the voice of anarchy and nihilism for the brief, indelible punk flare-up of the Sex Pistols and then, from 1978 to 1992, a provocateur and post-punk pioneer as the leader of Public Image Ltd., abbreviated to PiL for the bands logo.

title: Upfronts: CBS Shows Off Hawaii 5-0 and Mike & Molly
description: We dont have a million new shows, the CBS entertainment president Nina Tassler said Wednesday at her networks upfront. And were not asking any of them to be self-starters.

title: Politicians and Their Fake War Stories
description: This week, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut found himself in the hot seat. A Times article reported that Mr. Blumenthal, a Democrat running for the United States Senate, had not fought in Vietnam, and yet in a speech in 2008 he said, We have learned something important since the days that I served in Vietnam. In fact, he received five military deferments between 1965 and 1970, when he landed a coveted spot in the Marine Reserve, which allowed him to avoid combat overseas.

title: Whats Up, Doc? New Looneys
description: LOS ANGELES  Ask a first grader to identify Bugs Bunny and the response more likely than not will be a blank stare. Dora, sure. Mickey, alive and kicking. But Porky who?

title: Lincoln Center Updates Plaza and Maybe Its Liability
description: In the brightness of morning, when the sun glints off the gushing fountain, or at twilight, as people cross the travertine on their way to performances, the plaza at Lincoln Center can be one of New Yorks tranquil oases.

title: Khaki With an Urban Edge
description: More dressed up than jeans without getting all fancy-pants, khaki can go to the office, then go to the dogs.

title: Real Stuff Referendum
description: Sex, lies, and hypocrisy: does an election day get any more entertaining? And that was before Republicans in Kentucky voted against the advice of the top Republican in Kentucky, and voters in Pennsylvania sent a Democrat to Congress who vowed to take on Democrats in Congress.

title: Khaki Gets Street Cred
description: THE country may not be in the midst of a great color conciliation, what with Red and Blue paint balls flying as furiously as ever, but fashion is. In the last few seasons, even arch-cosmopolites, whose tastes normally range from asphalt to charcoal, have dipped into enough preppy All-American colors to make a three-piece madras suit.

title: Not at All Shy About Taking the Plunge
description: When you can see that your contract depends on, say, guessing a suit correctly or a finesse, what is your approach? Do you delay the evil trick as long as possible by cashing other winners, or do you decide immediately?

title: Joo Pinto: My National Team
description: LISBON  I almost did not make it to the Portugal national teams official player presentation. I had flight delays resulting from technical difficulties and then the volcanic dust cloud. The airport was absolute chaos. I just made it in time, but my bags arrived a day later. That is another story for another day.

title: Awkward Question for First Lady
description: Michelle Obama fielded an awkward question from a young girl on the immigration debate on Wednesday. The encounter, caught on video, came during a visit by the first lady and Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexican President Felipe Caldern to a second-grade class in Silver Spring, Md. Watch the video, and comment on the exchange, at our sib-blog, The Lede.

title: Turning a Catskills Cabin Into a Midcentury Retreat
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y.

title: Tour: A Catskills Fishing Cottage
description: A publicist makes over a cabin with a mix of global influences and an indoor-melting-into-outdoor style.

title: As American as Cherry Pie
description: I imagine there are plenty of people who travel around the country going to baseball games, and that those people can tell you everything there is to know about the motels near the various stadiums and the quality of the chili dogs. What they know of Americas cities they know insofar as it relates to the game: the convenience of the parking, the freshness of the popcorn. Over time, the things that make us travel can also give us a certain kind of expertise. It could be amusement parks, Civil War battlefields, marinas, museums.

title: Divorce, Apartment Style
description: I LOVED my neighbors.

title: Poggenpohls New Kitchen System
description: Poggenpohls latest kitchen system, +Artesio, was designed to be open to the rest of the home, blending into the living space around it. Its not only a workshop for preparing dishes, said Hadi Teherani, the Hamburg architect who created the kitchen in collaboration with the German design company. It is the place where you would also read a book, paint a picture or receive guests.

title: Maria Pergay, 79, Furniture Designer
description: Last weekend, while New York City was overrun by design enthusiasts in town for the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, Maria Pergay, a 79-year-old Parisian furniture designer relatively unknown in this country, was ensconced in a nautical modernist room at the Maritime Hotel. She was in New York not for the furniture fair  an event, it turns out, that she has never heard of  but to show her latest work at the Demisch Danant gallery in Chelsea (including a sofa of broken bricks she is shown sitting on). Those expecting a woman of her age to produce soft, feminine, upholstered pieces appropriate for a Paris pied--terre may be surprised by what has been Ms. Pergays material of choice for decades: stainless steel.

title: Industrial-Style Furniture at Strawser & Smith
description: For years, Fred Strawser has been drawing renovators to FS-20, his Asbury Park, N.J., emporium for all things midcentury modern. title: Solving a Dress-Design Sudoku
description: THE designers Jeffrey Costello, right, and Robert Tagliapietra (shown with Sam) embarked on their collaboration with Uniqlo, the Japanese fashion retailer, as a brain teaser. We approached it as problem solving: how to come up with an untricky way of doing dresses, Mr. Tagliapietra said in a joint phone interview. (Asked to confirm that it was Mr. Tagliapietra speaking, there was laughter, and a reference to their 16 years of living and working together: Were interchangeable.) Known for their own uniform of plaid shirts and suspenders, the team produces elegant dresses, with details like French seams. We knew we were going to leave that behind, Mr. Costello said. What they cleaved to was their trademark draping and a modernist minimalist take. A muted palette includes a range of spring colors from gray to rose to cornflower blue. And a bright mustard yellow. The capsule collection has 14 styles in prices ranging from $29.50 to $39.50. At 546 Broadway (between Prince and Spring Streets); (917) 237-8811 and uniqlo.com.
