title: Fraught
description: W.F. Young asks: "Long ago I developed the expectation that on encountering the word fraught, I'd find it associated with a prepositional phrase, 'with [something].' Now, in old age, I find that expectation dashed, often. Can you say what it was based on and anything about when, how or by whom it was undercut?"  Here we have a case of a very old word undergoing a rapid shift in contemporary usage. In Middle English, fraught (an etymological cousin of freight) was a verb meaning "to load (a ship)," and the identical form could serve as a past participle meaning "laden (with)." While the verb dropped out of the language almost entirely, the past participle stuck around, typically followed by "with" and an object -- often a burden, whether real or figurative.  Fraught as a standalone adjective meaning "distressed, anxious, tense," without an accompanying prepositional phrase, is a 20th-century innovation. When the word cropped up on William Safire's radar in 2006, he offered a line from "King Lear" as a putative early example: Goneril tells her father to "make use of that good wisdom, whereof I know you are fraught." But Shakespeare did use fraught with a preposition, whereof, and an object, wisdom, so it is in fact very much in line with the usage of the era. Lear was surely in a distressed emotional state, but that wasn't what his daughter was driving at.  By the nineteenth century, the metaphorical extension of the word had developed a new twist. Instead of the traditional phrasing, fraught with followed by an object (something usually unpleasant or unfortunate), the object could appear before fraught in a hyphenated compound, such as danger-fraught, pain-fraught or war-fraught. Thus if a moment was fraught with emotion, it could just as well have been described as emotion-fraught or in time as emotionally fraught, signaling the implied object in the adverb.  The first glimmers of fraught without even a hint of an object start appearing in the 1920s and '30s. The earliest example I've found so far comes from a 1925 serialized story by Henry Leyford Gates about a flapper named Joanna. In one installment Gates writes, "It was Joanna who at last broke the fraught silence." The lyrical phrase fraught silence, perhaps evoking pregnant pause, shows up again in books from1934, 1946 and 1958. Another early use is in George O'Neil's 1931 novel about the poet John Keats, "Special Hunger": "For Keats this was a singularly fraught circumstance." Circumstances, along with anxiety-ridden situations, issues and relationships, would soon become familiar companions for fraught.  Standalone fraught picked up steam in the 1960s, attracting the notice of dictionaries and usage guides, but the last couple of decades have seen an even stronger uptick. In the texts collected in the Corpus of Contemporary American English from 1990 to 1994, only about 9 percent of the instances of fraught do not take the preposition with. From 2005 to 2009, however, the rate jumps to a whopping 30 percent. The usage has become a journalistic commonplace, as in the recent New York Times headlines, "For New Stadium, a Fraught Coin Flip" and "Opera Companies' Fraught Seasons." No doubt about it, we're living in fraught times.

title: Sects and the City
description: I had almost forgotten Id sent in an application when the e-mail message appeared, like Mr. Big, out of nowhere. Hi, Moustafa, it began, as if we were old friends. Thank you for e-mailing us regarding your interest in working on Sex and the City 2.

title: The Feminist
description: As a Somali native who was raised as a Muslim and grew up to become one of the most outspoken critics of Islam, you fled to Amsterdam and served in the Dutch Parliament before fleeing again, to America. What kind of security do you have here? I dont go from A to B without being escorted by people who are armed. But please, lets not talk about my security.

title: Letter: The Moral Life of Babies
description: Paul Blooms article is certainly amazing in what it says about the capabilities of the very youngest among us. One piece of information, however, appears to be missing from this complex equation of becoming human. Nowhere in the article is information given about the home lives of these infants. Shouldnt the supportive or nonsupportive backgrounds of the infants be taken into account as one ingredient to babies reactions to stimuli? From birth, what has been the environment these subjects lived in? Would neglected babies react in the same way to those who have had a warm, nurturing environment from birth? These questions kept badgering me as I read this most informative study. Early Childhood Educator and Consultant, Beachwood, Ohio

title: Lost Motives, Explained
description: On Thursday night Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse appeared at a Times Talk event to riff about Lost with Lorne Manly, entertainment editor for The Times, and we are posting excerpts from the discussion. You can watch earlier clips here.

title: Last Stop in Congress for the Financial Bill
description: The financial regulatory bill needs to overcome one more hurdle before it reaches President Obamas desk: the conference committee. Members from both houses of Congress will meet together to meld the House and Senate versions for a final vote of approval. The size and makeup of that committee could determine how tough the bill will be on Wall Street.

description: LOS ANGELES  Pity the high school students whose summer jobs involve changing movie theater marquees. Hollywood has come down with a serious case of title elongation. That is, if you can figure out the title at all.

title: Letter:  Half a Degree
description: As a community-college professor, I agree that our institutions can and should do more for our new students. While David Leonhardt correctly identifies some of the obstacles to student retention and success, he misses an important factor in student failure: unrealistic expectations. I have observed that school is often a third priority for many of my students, who may place family and work above school commitments.

title: Letter: Calendar Daze
description: Virginia Heffernans column evoked pleasant memories of a predigital era. I purchased my Filofax at Harrods 25 years ago while on sabbatical in England. The Filofax is much more than an analog date book, with an almost-limitless variety of pages that can be added for projects and finances. My Filofax was eventually replaced by a P.D.A., and like Heffernan, I also miss it.

title: Fund Executive Is Sentenced in Galleon Case
description: A co-founder of the New Castle Funds hedge fund, Mark Kurland, was sentenced on Friday to 27 months in prison for insider trading in connection with the Galleon Group case, Bloomberg News reported. He was also ordered to forfeit $900,000.

title: The Kidney Was a Gift
description: Last fall, a stranger donated a kidney to my husband. We offered her a gift after the operation, which she declined. Recently she wrote us that her house is in foreclosure, and she needs money. We obviously have no legal responsibility to respond, but what is our ethical responsibility? I wish it were legal to sell organs; it would be much cleaner in many ways. NAME WITHHELD

description: The Web is a teeming commercial city. Its haphazardly planned. Its public spaces are mobbed, and signs of urban decay abound in broken links and abandoned projects. Malware and spam have turned living conditions in many quarters unsafe and unsanitary. Bullies and hucksters roam the streets. An entrenched population of rowdy, polyglot rabble seems to dominate major sites.

He has since galvanized Los Angeles with his exuberant music making and inspiring capacity for outreach.

description: Q.

title: Judge Stays Order Against Filmmaker
description: A filmmaker fighting an oil companys demand for more than 600 hours of unused footage got a reprieve from a federal appeals judge in Manhattan on Friday. Judge Denny Chin ordered a June 8 hearing to consider a subpoena issued on May 6 by a federal district judge that ordered Joe Berlinger, the filmmaker, to turn over all footage from the making of his film Crude. The film focuses on a lawsuit by Ecuadoreans against Chevron over pollution in the Amazon said to have been caused by Texaco before Chevron acquired it. The subpoena will be stayed until the hearing, Judge Chin ruled. Ilann M. Maazel, whose firm represents the Ecuadorean plaintiffs, applauded Judge Chins decision, and called the subpoena another last-ditch attempt to derail and delay justice in Ecuador. Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer for Chevron, said he was not concerned about the coming hearing.

title: Michael Jackson Sleepover Tribute
description: June 25 will mark a year since Michael Jacksons death, and to pay tribute a Japanese promoter is holding a sleepover of sorts inside the Tokyo Tower where the Neverland Collection  a huge assortment of the singers personal objects including sculptures, left, a 1967 Rolls-Royce Phantom, right, clothes and costumes from his Thriller video  has been on view since May 1. Reuters reported that starting on Sunday, people are expected to line up to buy tickets costing as much as $1,000 for the chance to sleep among Jacksons belongings. Fans, to be selected at random, will enter the tower from 10:30 p.m. on June 25 and will be able to stay until 8 the next morning. In Japan, Hiroyuki Takamura of the Tokyo Tower said, the tradition of being with the remains and possessions of passed love ones on the anniversary of their passing is an important ritual.

title: Motion Against Gallery Is Rejected
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday declined to give immediate help to an art collector who has been blacklisted by the South African painter Marlene Dumas, prohibited from buying new works by her after he angered her by selling an older work. The collector, Craig Robins, asserts in a lawsuit that he sold a Dumas painting through the David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea in 2004 with an agreement that the sale remain confidential. But the gallery, which took over representation of Ms. Dumas in 2008, told her about it, Mr. Robins says, causing her to add his name to the blacklist. In court testimony, Ms. Dumass former dealer confirmed that the artist maintains a blacklist of collectors and dealers whom she believes to be speculating in her works. Mr. Robins says that the Zwirner gallery promised to help get him off the blacklist and to sell him new paintings but failed to do so. The gallery has denied the claims. Mr. Robins sought a temporary restraining order to prevent the gallery from selling three paintings in a show of new work, paintings that Mr. Robins contends he should have the right to buy. But Judge William H. Pauley denied the request for the restraining order, in part because Mr. Robins provided no written evidence of his claims against the gallery.

title: Lohan Avoids Arrest
description: It looks as if Lindsay Lohan will not be arrested after all. While the 23-year-old actress was at the Cannes Film Festival on Thursday promoting her new film about Linda Lovelace, a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge issued a warrant for her arrest, saying that she had no valid excuse for missing a probation hearing in a drunken-driving case. But hours later her legal team posted bail of $100,000, according to Reuters, which allows Ms. Lohan to avoid jail by providing money that would be forfeited if she became a fugitive. Shawn Chapman Holley, Ms. Lohans lawyer, told the judge that the actress was stranded in France because her passport had been stolen at the festival. Ms. Holley has since said that Ms. Lohan has a new passport, though it was unclear when she would return to Los Angeles.

title: CBS Wins Battle of Thursday Finales
description: CBS eked out a victory ahead of ABC in the ratings on Thursday night. According to Nielsens estimates, CBSs season finale of The Mentalist at 10 p.m. drew 15 million viewers, tying ABCs two-hour season conclusion of Greys Anatomy as the nights most-watched show. ABC, which finished No. 1 in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49, would have led the night over all in total viewers were it not for lower ratings at 8 for FlashForward (5.3 million), which trailed in its time slot behind the finale of Foxs Bones (9.2 million) and a CBS repeat of The Mentalist (8.1 million). CBSs 10th-season finale of CSI drew 13.9 million viewers at 9, outperforming Foxs Fringe (5.7 million) and NBCs finales of The Office (6.6 million) and 30 Rock (5.5 million). Fox finished ahead of NBC to rank third.

title: It Was a Royal Pain, but It Ended Well
description: Were it not for the cloud of volcanic ash that disrupted air travel last month, one particular document on view through May 30 at the Morgan Library & Museum would have been returned to its home at the Bodleian Library at Oxford University weeks ago. But this document also would not be here (or anywhere else, for that matter) if the royal figure involved in its creation had been any less violent, venal, treacherous, incompetent and boorish.

title: U2 Tour Thrown Off By Injury To Bono
description: U2 has postponed the first concert in this years leg of the 360 world tour after its lead singer, Bono, above, was injured during a rehearsal and underwent emergency surgery on his back in Munich on Friday, The Associated Press reported. Bono will spend the next few days there, before returning home to recuperate, a statement on U2.com said. Once his condition has been assessed further, a statement will be made regarding the impact on forthcoming tour dates. The tour was to start in Salt Lake City on June 3. After that the band is scheduled to play in Anaheim, Calif., on June 6 and 7 followed by Denver on June 12 and Oakland, Calif., on June 16. So far the tour, which began last year and draws its name from the giant circular stage the band uses, has earned around $109 million, according to Billboard. No details have been released about when the Salt Lake City concert might take place or if other concerts will have to be postponed as well.

title: Adventures in Synthetic Biology
description: While geologists are debating whether Earth really has entered a new epoch, the Anthropocene, named for the dominant influence on the planets geochemistry these days, theres no question that biology will never be quite the same again.

title: Jil Sander for Less
description: I have always loved the designs of both Jil Sander and Raf Simons for Jil Sander. These clothes, however, have always been somewhat out of my price range. But now with the introduction of the new Jil Sander Navy line, I might finally be able to get my Jil fix.

title: A Crib for the Baby, a Cradle for the Cats, a Home for Them
description: ERICA BUCKLEY has long since left the ranch house near Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where she grew up. But she has vivid memories of trotting across the yard and visiting her grandmothers house, which was just next door.

description: AS co-op boards across the city head into annual meeting season, many are facing a paradox: despite the real estate markets decline, building assessments and real estate taxes have continued to go up.

description: EVEN though all television signals went digital last year and cable has been around for decades, old-fashioned TV antennas can still be found atop many houses and apartment buildings in the New York region. But those vestigial limbs from the analog era are more than just quaint aluminum artifacts.

description: FOR all the recent price cuts and rental conversions in the turbulent New York condominium market, developers rarely resort to auctioning off unsold units.

description: TO fans of the television comedy Friends, Jessica Hecht is Susan, the life partner of Carol, the ex-wife of Ross Geller, one of the lead characters. And as almost everybody knows, she made broadcast history in 1995 when Susan and Carol became the first lesbian couple on TV to become parents.

title: The Gift of Sperm Donor 8282
description: TEN years ago Carey Goldberg, a Boston reporter who was then single and about to turn 39, reached her self-imposed biological midnight. Determined to be a mother and with no man yet on the horizon, she did some research on sperm banks and then ordered eight vials of sperm from an anonymous donor.

title: A Double Bill With Binoche and Kiarostami
description: CANNES, France The couple in Abbas Kiarostamis Certified Copy, screening in competition at this years Cannes Film Festival, are a French gallery owner (Juliette Binoche) and an English art critic (the opera singer William Shimmel) on a Tuscan day trip. They seem to be strangers until a case of mistaken identity or a bout of magic-realist role play propels the movie into an alternate reality.

title: Puzzles in Layers of Cool Suspense
description: The authority with which the choreographer Pam Tanowitz orders time and space in The Wanderer Fantasy is something rare, but theres an offbeat quality to it. On more than one level the work, now at Danspace Project, puzzles the mind. Yet its easy to discard any such sense of puzzle, because at every moment its arresting, suspenseful, coolly witty. Her work has an instinct for the contrasts that make dance count: stillness against motion, small against large, slow against fast, the individual against the group, one group against another, upright beside supine.

title: Dance Lessons From Bounce Musics Audacious Star
description: The Bar 13 stage was tiny and crowded in the small hours of Friday morning, but Big Freedia saw plenty of room left to fill. How many of yall took that class today? he asked the crowd.

title: A Solid Rock of the Ages, Mixing New and Vintage
description: Pearl Jam began its first encore at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night with a portrait of ailment, fraught with emotion. Eddie Vedder, the bands lead singer, returned alone to the stage, where a string quartet had assembled. This is one of the sadder songs we know, he said, referring to The End, from Backspacer (Monkeywrench), Pearl Jams most recent album. Finger-picking an acoustic guitar, he sang the songs first line in a tentative quaver: What were all those dreams we shared those many years ago?

title: Golfer and Caddie Pay Tribute to a Friend
description: IRVING, Tex.  Rickie Fowlers wardrobe is like a Crayola crayon box, bursting with bright colors. He looked like a walking creamsicle on Friday, but thats not why he attracted the attention of a few hecklers during his round of one-over-par 71.

title: Three Men to Watch at the French Open
description: Ernests GulbisIn 2008 Ernests Gulbis reached the quarterfinals at Roland Garros, and seemed poised to break into the top 10. With a huge serve and a penetrating ground game, the 63 Gulbis played fearlessly, hitting for the lines when the pressure mounted. He was so outrageously talented that he made the game look easy. And then he faltered, losing early and often as rumors spread that he preferred partying to the practice court.

description: IT was just a year ago that Cherry Pickman left the one-bedroom where she was living in Harlem for Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in order to be closer to her girlfriend, Kara Mason. She had no trouble finding a one-bedroom rental for $1,425 in a thriving Graham Avenue location surrounded by little delis, meat markets and grocery stores.

Herszenhorn report from Washington.

description: ITS surprising that in a part of Connecticut with names ending in field, ford and port, the name St. Marys-by-the-Sea ever stuck. The St. Marys in question, a tiny log-walled chapel, stood only from 1893 to 1925 in this affluent section of Bridgeport, about 60 miles from Manhattan.

title: Cinematic Change and the End of Film
description: CANNES, France On Thursday, the day after Carlos had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, I was surprised to learn it had been shot on 35 millimeter film. Heres why: Directed by Olivier Assayas, the film is a 5-hour, 33-minute portrait of the terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. It will be shown on French television this week and is scheduled to open in the United States in the fall. Its a fascinating work about an uninteresting brutish historical figure and I havent stopped thinking about it since I saw it. The thin visual quality of the images and occasional tell-tale splotches of yellow in white images strongly suggested that we were looking at a movie that had been shot in digital, perhaps with the RED, the camera which Steven Soderbergh used to shoot Che, his movie about Che Guevara, which played at Cannes in 2008.

Markey, the chairman of the Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment, accused BP of deceiving the public. It is clear BP has been lying, Mr. Markey said. We cannot be relying on BP to be making any of these decisions, he said, referring to cleanup efforts. The federal government has created a Flow Rate Technical Team to establish a more precise estimate. Its first report is expected Saturday.

Perhaps, having signed with the EMI Classics record label, he wanted to establish a break with the sober persona of his outstanding albums for Deutsche Grammophon, released in the shadow of a more famous and flamboyant compatriot and label mate, Lang Lang. EMI has experience with this phenomenon, having tended to the career of the violinist Nigel Kennedy once he had decided to be known as Kennedy.

title: Lottery Numbers
Investor Puts $25 Million Into Borders Group
description: The Borders Group, the book store chain, will raise $25 million in a private sale to an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, pushing him past Pershing Square Capital Management as the companys largest shareholder. Mr. LeBow, 72, will buy 11.1 million shares for $2.25 each and become chairman, replacing Richard McGuire, who resigned, Borders said Friday. The bookseller has closed stores and cut costs in an effort to become profitable after four consecutive yearly losses. Mr. LeBow is chairman of the Vector Group, a Miami-based holding company for the cigarette maker Liggett Group. Stock in Borders, which is based in Ann Arbor, Mich., rose 1 cent, to close at $2.24 a share.

title: Lazard Is Hired to Advise G.M. On a Share Sale

The hiring of a financial adviser is the latest step in the Obama administrations efforts to sell its 61 percent stake in G.M., which it gained when the government bailed out the automaker last year. G.M.s chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., has suggested that the company could take the final step to repurchase the shares by Dec. 31, citing strong financial progress after years of losses. G.M. reported its first quarterly profit since 2007 on Monday. Lazard will be paid at least $7.5 million for the assignment, at a rate of $500,000 a month for the first 12 months.

title: Appeal Will Keep Vikings Eligible
description: A Minnesota state judge ruled Friday that Kevin Williams and Pat Williams, two defensive tackles on the Minnesota Vikings, could avoid four-game suspensions by the N.F.L. if they appealed an earlier court decision. The players, who are not related, were suspended by the league in 2008 because they tested positive for bumetanide, a diuretic banned by the league because it can mask steroids. The substance was in StarCaps, a weight-loss supplement that the players admitted taking. The players claimed in court that they were employed by the Vikings and therefore governed by Minnesotas drug testing policies, which are at odds with the N.F.L.s policy in some ways. Earlier this month, Gary Larson, a Minnesota district court judge, said that the N.F.L. was the players employer and that they were beholden to the leagues drug policy. On Friday, Larson said that the league could not suspend the players while they appealed that decision to the Minnesota Court of Appeals.

title: After Quake, Panic and Death in a Haitian Prison
description: After the Haitian earthquake, prisoners crowded into a handful of cells rioted, and the official response to their actions turned deadly.

title: Senator Bennet Trails Challenger in Colorado Party Assembly
description: If the political rules of Colorado were similar to those in neighboring Utah, yet another United States senator would have fallen to defeat on Saturday.

title: Turkish Party Picks Leader
description: MUGLA, Turkey  Turkeys main opposition party elected a new leader on Saturday after a sex scandal earlier this month led to the abrupt resignation of his predecessor, who had led the party for 18 years.

title: The Unwanted Sound of Everything We Want
description: Noise Is Interested in You

title: No Afternoon Stroll, but Close, as Flyers Cruise to a Commanding Lead
description: MONTREAL  Saturday night is the time for hockey here, not Saturday afternoon, and it has been that way for generations. Maybe it was that disruption to their circadian rhythms that did in the Canadiens, most notably in the second period, when the Flyers outshot them, 13-1, and outscored them, 2-0, as Philadelphia won, 3-0, and took a three-games-to-one lead in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Its All Shown in the Core
description: The common-sense axiom that it takes a 25-man team to win is practically written on the Mets clubhouse walls. The mantra for the slumping Jose Reyes and the brooding David Wright is eagerly echoed by the reeling general manager, Omar Minaya.

title: Surveillance Suspected as Spacecrafts Main Role
description: A team of amateur sky watchers has pierced the veil of secrecy surrounding the debut flight of the nations first robotic spaceplane, finding clues that suggest the military craft is engaged in the development of spy satellites rather than space weapons, which some experts have suspected but the Pentagon strongly denies.

title: Hernia Surgery for Bocanegra
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Carlos Bocanegra, the United States captain, recently underwent hernia surgery after being injured with his French club team, Coach Bob Bradley said Saturday.

title: Spokes | More Room to Ride in East Harlem
description: Edward George rode his Titan folding bike, with its twin mirrors pointing up like antennae, from his apartment on 110th Street and Madison Avenue to the Gabaron Barber Shop on Second Avenue and 119th Street. But, as he often does, Mr. George, 82, took to the sidewalk for the trip because he feels unsafe in the fast-moving traffic.

title: Specter Legacy Is Study of the Perils of a Switch
description: After decades in public life, Senator Arlen Specter has left his mark on the big issues of his time, from President John F. Kennedys assassination and President Bill Clintons impeachment trial to matters of terrorism and biomedical research. He steered billions of federal dollars home to Pennsylvania and played a major role in shaping the makeup of the Supreme Court and the federal judiciary.

title: Allan Manings, Writer and Creator of Television Shows, Dies at 86
description: Allan Manings, an Emmy-winning writer who created One Day at a Time, a hit sitcom about a divorced woman and her teenage daughters that was progressive for the mid-1970s, died on May 12 in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: Ready to Ship in Hawaii: 20,000 Tons of Garbage
description: KAPOLEI, Hawaii  At first glance, it does not look much like garbage. More than 20,000 tons of it have been shrink-wrapped into green bales that are neatly stacked, ready to ship about 2,300 miles across the Pacific to the mainland as an another export  opala, as garbage is called in Hawaiian.

title: David E. Durston, Who Wrote and Directed I Drink Your Blood, Dies at 88
description: Men become animals and eat their victims! ... You will sit and watch this shocking ugliness splashing across the screen! ... Can you take it? ...

title: Graduation at West Point
description: President Obama delivered a commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: Despite Leak, Louisiana Is Still Devoted to Oil
description: MORGAN CITY, La.  In some parts of the country, the sight of oil drifting toward the Louisiana coast, oozing into the fragile marshlands and bringing large parts of the states economy to a halt, has prompted calls to stop offshore drilling indefinitely, if not altogether.

title: College Offers Quirky Shirts Designed by Students
description: Forget the standard college sweatshirt.

title: Too Soon to Tell on Vazquez
description: The Yankees skipped one of Javier Vazquezs starts because of ineffectiveness. They skipped another because they needed him in the bullpen. It is too early to tell, Manager Joe Girardi said, if they will skip Vazquez a third time, this one because of injury.

title: A Small Town in Arkansas Mourns Two Slain Officers
description: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark.  The sewing machine at the front of Tobey and Kelly Duncans outdoor apparel store whirred continuously on Saturday as seamstresses stitched together one new police dress uniform after the next.

title: Bay Has Struggled to Fill the Shoes Laid Out for Him
description: The Mets signed Jason Bay for his power. He knows it, and he feels its absence. When he scorched a double off the left-center-field wall against Mariano Rivera in the ninth inning Friday, he grimaced upon arrival at second base. He was still stuck on one home run for the season.

title: A Silicon Valley Group Gives Voice to Voiceless
description: Adrian Avila was a 17-year-old street graffiti artist who had a job at a local hot dog stand when he wandered into the offices of Silicon Valley De-Bug eight years ago. He wasnt sure what he was looking for. But he found it.

title: State Lags in Dental Health Care for Children
description: Early in the morning on April 2, Dominique Allens family rushed her to the emergency room at Petaluma Valley Hospital because of jaw pain and inflammation.

title: Kerr, After Wobbly Start, Steers the Suns Revival
description: PHOENIX  As a sweet-shooting guard, Steve Kerr brought a measure of predictability to an unpredictable game. His wrists flicked, the ball sailed, the net snapped.

title: Family Time, Dad Time, Down Time
description: For the last 16 years, Sedge Thomson has hosted West Coast Live, a two-hour radio variety show broadcast Saturdays on KALW 91.7 FM. Mr. Thomson, with his signature baritone and low-key style, interviews musicians, writers, actors and artists about their lives and work. He lives in Berkeley with his wife, the novelist Sylvia Brownrigg, and their two children Samuel, 8, and Romilly, 6. Mr. Thomsons son from a previous marriage, 14-year-old Henry, spends every other week at the house. His words have been edited and condensed.

title: Inter Milan Wins Champions League Title
description: MADRID  As the stadium loudspeakers announced the lineup for the Champions League final between Inter Milan and Bayern Munich, the name of Jos Mourinho, Inters Portuguese coach, drew a thunderous shout of approval from the section of fans in Inters black and blue.

title: How About a Beer?
description: My Sunday column probably makes me look like a sanctimonious misanthrope. I argue that one of the problems that we havent adequately acknowledged in trying to fight poverty is the degree to which money is poorly spent.

title: Finding the Rhythms in a Playwrights Words
description: After a run-through early last week of the play Gods Ear, the director Erika Chong Shuch assembled her cast for a post-rehearsal debriefing. The actors, members of the Shotgun Players, were dissatisfied with their work that evening on this dark and surreal drama, written by Jenny Schwartz. They said they felt their collective lack of focus had sapped the play of its energy.

title: A Homecoming of Sorts
description: It must have been a thrill for Kevin Russo to record his first career hit and drive in both of the Yankees runs Friday night in Queens, so close to his Long Island birthplace, right? A thrill, definitely, but Russo identifies more with Boulder, Colo., where he moved when he was 3.

title: State Lags in Dental Care for Children and Other Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Pages
description: Painful Neglect |  It is not unusual in California for children to endure crippling pain and disability from untreated tooth decay  by the age of 5, 28 percent of the states children have untreated dental decay. Dr. Jared I. Fine, the dental health administrator at the Alameda County Public Health Department, said, We have an epidemic of dental disease in children thats absurdly pervasive.

title: To Honor Teammate, Virginia Maintains Perspective as Its Season Ends
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  For the first time since the death of the senior defender Yeardley Love, the Virginia womens lacrosse team stepped away from its campus, away from the place where memories of Love  both sorrowful and pleasant  remain vivid.

title: Corrections
description: SPORTS

title: Recession Played a Part, but ShoreBank Wounded Itself, Too
description: As some of the nations biggest financial institutions rushed to assemble a $150 million bailout of ShoreBank last week, people knowledgeable about the banks image as a successful, crusading lender in some of the countrys most impoverished communities began focusing on a related issue: How ShoreBank had fallen nearly to the point of collapse.

title: What a More Humane Welfare System Could Look Like
description: Helen Olbrecht, 54, of Oak Lawn, lost her office managers job and is left with two daughters, a grandchild, a dog and a stiff mortgage. She searches fitfully for work and gets by on $318 a month in welfare and $286 in food stamps, while dealing with a foreclosure notice on her home.

title: Pressed Together, Mets Feel The Heat
description: Perhaps sensing a growing tightness and mounting pressure within his team, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel did something unusual Friday night. He called every member of the team into his office and held an impromptu meeting to remind his players that the point of baseball is to have fun, and the best way to do that is to win.

title: At Museum, RoboSue Roars to Life
description: The Field Museum of Natural History this week will open an exhibit that features a reincarnated Sue  the museums iconic Tyrannosaurus rex  as a lifelike animatronic creature that turns its head to track visitors movements and lets out a loud roar.

title: After Cubs, Baker Feels the Love in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI  For a certain segment of Cubs fans, a look at the National League Central standings early last week was doubly distressing: The Cubs were in fifth place, seven games under .500 and closer to last place than to first, and the Cincinnati Reds held the division lead.

title: Michael Kuchwara, Prolific Theater Writer, Dies at 63
description: Michael Kuchwara, who found a worldwide readership in writing about the theater for The Associated Press, as both reporter and critic, for a quarter-century, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: A 16-Year-Old Amateur Trails by 6, but Fans Treat Him Like a Champion
description: IRVING, Tex.  There was a deafening roar on the first hole at the T.P.C. Four Seasons resort Saturday, the ground practically quaking under Kenny Perrys feet as he stood at the second tee box.

title: Lottery Numbers
Landis Joins Races Crowd, but Riders Ignore Him
description: LOS ANGELES  Floyd Landis, the cyclist who recently admitted to doping after four years of vehemently denying it, showed up at the Tour of California on Saturday, looking like an important man.

title: Feeling Urgency to Win, the Mets Go Out and Do It
description: Baseball people are conditioned to say that every game is important, regardless of the opponent, the circumstances, or juncture of the schedule. But sometimes their actions suggest that some games may be more important than others. The night after the Mets called a team meeting to stress the urgency of winning immediately (and frequently), their manager, Jerry Manuel, on Saturday called on his closer, Francisco Rodriguez, to record the final five outs of what became a 5-3 victory against the Yankees at Citi Field.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about MacGruber erroneously attributed a distinction to the film. It was The Blues Brothers (1980)  not MacGruber  that was the first film based on a Saturday Night Live sketch to be rated R.

title: Not Worried About Rivera
description: Mariano Rivera has given up runs in three straight games, only the sixth time he has done so as a reliever. Therefore some are thinking his aura of invincibility is waning, his career is winding down, his age is catching up, and something must be wrong. Except every year Rivera seems to encounter a rough patch, and every year he rebounds and regains his indomitable form.

title: In High-Stakes Games, Rivals Can Suddenly Become Allies
description: When it comes to strange bedfellows, politics has nothing on chess.

title: Celtics Leave No Doubt, Overwhelming Magic
description: BOSTON  These are not old legs  not with the 15-year veteran Kevin Garnett swishing jumpers off the dribble and the equally seasoned Rasheed Wallace putting the finishing touches on alley oops.

title: The Suns Long Road
description: If it is true that there is no place like home, then the Phoenix Suns may have an excuse for opening the Western Conference finals with consecutive losses to the Los Angeles Lakers: their last home game was May 5.

title: Republican Wins in Blue Hawaii
description: A Republican candidate has prevailed over a crowded special election to represent President Obamas Hawaiian birthplace in the House of Representatives. The victory of Charles Djou, a Honolulu city councilman, was not a surprise, but it served to bolster his party as it seeks to chip away at the Democratic majority.

title: Vows: Sona & Justin
description: Sona Rai and Justin Collins share a unique mix of Sikh, Jewish, and Catholic cultural backgrounds in their families.

title: Two Aces in the Batters Box
description: As former aces in the American League Central, C.C. Sabathia and Johan Santana would regularly pitch against each other. Sabathia owns a 3-1 edge in games against Santana, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, with their last matchup coming on Sept. 3, 2007, when he pitched eight shutout innings for the Indians against Santanas Twins.

title: The Graying of the Gym
description: Adults 55 and older make up the faster-growing segment of membership nationwide, and gyms are catering to them.

title: The Winter Antiques Show
description: The Park Avenue Armory hosted the antiques market's premier annual event this January. Attendance was up and sales were strong.

title: Nuclear Power: A Resurgence, an Opportunity
description: Seventeen companies have applied to build 26 new nuclear power reactors around the United States.

title: A Prague Landmark Is Reborn
description: Behind the newly restored Renaissance facade of a landmark palace, all of Mala Strana comes alive in one place. That is how Petr Kutilek, a 34-year-old marketing executive, summed up his recent visit to Malostranska Beseda (Malostranske namesti 21; www.malostranska-beseda.cz), a 15th-century building that re-opened last month after a $10.5 million renovation. The space, once a town hall, most recently housed a grungy rock club until it closed two years ago, and now includes two bars, a restaurant and cafe, concert hall and art gallery over five levels.

title: An American in the Mens Final? Now That Would Be an Upset

description: If you happen to be on a United Airlines flight and find a blue iPod Nano around seat 23A, please let me know.

description: Leslie Guttman is an independent journalist and freelance writer. Equine ER: Stories from a Year in the Life of an Equine Veterinary Hospital is her first book. It chronicles a year inside Rood & Riddle Equine Hospital, one of the countrys largest hospitals for horses, located in the Bluegrass.

title: The Wellness Industry as an Echo of the Internet in the 1990s
description: At a health innovation and investment conference in California earlier this month, there was a lot of energy and excitement about the emerging health and wellness industry. The wellness movement, as its called, is seen as both a social phenomenon and a big investment opportunity.

As The Timess Eric Lichtblau and Edward Wyatt report, the banking industry was confident that the provision forcing banks to spin off their derivatives businesses would be scrapped, but in the haste to pass the bill, it remained.

title: Japan Relents on U.S. Base on Okinawa
description: TOKYO  Reneging on a prominent campaign promise, Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama told outraged residents of Okinawa on Sunday that an American air base would be moved only to the north side of the island rather than off the island.

title: All-Time Cycle Team Leaders
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: U.S. Presses China to Punish North Korea for Ship
description: BEIJING  The United States began pressing the Chinese on Sunday to back punitive measures against North Korea over strong evidence it had torpedoed a South Korean warship, but American officials acknowledged Chinas reluctance to discipline its isolated neighbor.

title: 3 Shot Dead in Queens and the Bronx
description: Three people were killed and five others were wounded in two unrelated shootings in the Bronx and in Queens early Sunday morning, the police said.

title: On Friday Night Lights, Buddy Makes Himself Known
description: The casting and performances on Friday Night Lights are so famously top-notch every week that the slightest deviation from the sublime can really irritate (see my harping about Kyle Chandler last week) and, at the same time any moment can get lost in the whole. So lets take some time to celebrate Brad Leland as Buddy Garrity, the most purely avid patron of high school football in all of Dillon (O.K. maybe all of Texas). I say purely because Buddy has been supplanted this season and last by the twisted Panther fanatic Joe McCoy whose interest in Panther football is more or less entirely a function of his obsessive control of his star quarterback son. Except for Julie Taylor no kid in Dillon really avoids abuse of some kind  mostly it is the abuse of absent parentage  but in young J.D. McCoys case the abuse is both emotional and physical. Joe McCoy is a really, really awful guy  venal, entitled, misogynistic-  and Buddy has finally had enough of him. Poolside at Joes giant house  a house that seems like one big wet bar  Buddy gives it to him and calls him a cancer for poisoning the well of Dillon football love with his base antagonisms and threats and psycho micro-managing.

title: Heartland of Thailand, Still Angry and Divided
description: UDON THANI, Thailand  Hello, Abhisit! shouted a young man, holding an imaginary telephone with an imaginary connection to the prime minister. Thank you for giving us stupid buffaloes this train! Too bad you killed us!

title: On North Korea, China Prefers Fence
description: BEIJING  In the best of times, Chinese foreign affairs scholars here say, Beijing grits its teeth while playing best friend to Kim Jong-il, North Koreas ailing and erratic 68-year-old leader. South Koreas charge last week that North Korea sank one of its warships, killing 46 crewmen, makes that role exponentially harder.

title: Gibbs on Sestaks Claim of a Job Offer
description: The White House appeared to confirm Sunday that the Obama administration had some kind of conversations with Representative Joe Sestak, the Pennsylvania Democrat who was challenging Senator Arlen Specter, but asserted that the conversations were not inappropriate.

title: Louisiana Officials Threaten Action if Spill Response Proves Inadequate
description: VENICE, La.  Louisiana state and local officials continued to hammer BP and the federal agencies responding to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill on Sunday, repeatedly threatening to take matters into our own hands if the response fell short.

title: A Conversation With the Top Prize Winner of Cannes
description: CANNES, France  The Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul is known for his shape-shifting tales. Many of his films, like Tropical Malady (2004) and Syndromes of a Century (2006), seem to start over midway through, as if reincarnated.

title: No Worries, Israel Insists, Defense Drill Is Just a Drill
description: JERUSALEM  As Israel embarked on a large-scale civil defense exercise on Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sought to reassure Israelis and some jittery Arab neighbors that the nationwide drill was not meant to signal a deterioration in security or an imminent war.

title: Bocanegra Says He Is Ready to Play
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Defender Carlos Bocanegra, the captain of the United States soccer team, said Sunday that he felt healthy enough to play in exhibition matches Tuesday and Saturday after undergoing surgery for a sports hernia earlier this month.

title: On Friday, Security and Politics at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  At 8:30 a.m. on Friday at the Cannes Film Festival, just before the first daily screening, attendees were greeted with a disquieting sight: four police vans were parked in front of the festival headquarters and numerous gendarmes, some in riot gear, had taken up position on the street and even next to the red carpet. We festival-goers are used to security checks at Cannes. Guards electronically check your bags whenever you enter the headquarters, a massive building called the Palais. Another guard checks or rather glances at the contents of your bags, while a third passes an electronic wand over your body, rituals that grow lax as the festival wears on. (Similar security checks are common at studio screenings in the United States.)

title: The Morning Line: Some Work, but a Lot of Commentary
description: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Jose Lima, Former All-Star Pitcher, Dies at 37
description: 11:52 p.m. | Updated Jose Lima, who pitched for five teams during a 13-year career, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles of an apparent heart attack. He was 37.

title: Lodge Kerrigans Hall of Mirrors Comes to Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Like his last two films, Claire Dolan (1998) and Keane (2004), Lodge Kerrigans Rebecca H. (Return to the Dogs) is named for its protagonist. And in keeping with the work of this American independent auteur, it is premised on getting close, often disturbingly so, to the character under scrutiny. The difference is that this time, the character herself is hard to keep in focus.

title: Patriots Welker Is Moving Fast in Recovery
description: Good news for Patriots fans, for football fans, for fantasy football fans. (Even most Jets fans probably wouldnt begrudge him his health.)

title: The Joys of Jumpology
description: When the photographer Philippe Halsman said, Jump, no one asked how high. People simply pushed off or leapt up to the extent that physical ability and personal decorum allowed. In that airborne instant Mr. Halsman clicked the shutter. He called his method jumpology.

title: Breathing Life Into Henry Roth
description: The writer Henry Roth was a tortured, hard-luck case who at the end life enjoyed an unexpected redemption. Blocked for decades, full of doubt and self-loathing, he began writing again in his late 80s, even though crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, and finished four new novels, two of which he lived to see into print before his death in 1995. Now, almost miraculously, there is a fifth, An American Type, which W. W. Norton will publish on June 7.

title: An American Type
description: Prologue: At Times in Flight

title: Romo Gives Byron Nelson Officials Something to Consider
description: IRVING, Tex.  Who knew the 16-year-old amateur Jordan Spieth would make the biggest stage entrance since another J.S. with Dallas ties, Jordin Sparks, the 17-year-old American Idol winner whose father played for the Cowboys?

title: 'Jump'
description: Images from an exhibit of Philippe Halsmans photographs.

title: Sean Hayes Answers Readers Questions
description: Sean Hayes, who is nominated this year for a Tony Award for his performance in the Broadway revival of Promises, Promises, has been in the center of a cultural whirlwind recently after a Newsweek column that suggested that gay actors could not play straight characters pointed to Mr. Hayess performance in the show as one example.

title: Laura Linney Answers Readers Questions
description: Laura Linney was nominated for a Tony Award this year for her performance as an emotionally and physically wounded photojournalist in Donald Marguliess play Time Stands Still, which closed in March. In his review, Ben Brantley called Ms. Linney an actress of unusual economy and seemingly innate grace whose tough but gently shaded performance honors the characters seeming contradictions.

title: Insurgents Attack Palace in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 14 people were killed and more than 25 were wounded on Sunday in heavy fighting between government troops and insurgents who attacked the presidential palace with mortars, witnesses and officials said.

title: The Lost Finale: The End Is Near
description: Goodnight Desmond Hume. Goodnight Ben Linuss perpetual gloom. Goodnight Boone, who we hardly knew. Goodnight origin of Jacks tattoos. Goodnight Jughead. Goodnight polar bear. Goodnight smoke monsters everywhere.

title: Sitting With Marina
description: Performance art, as currently practiced, emerged as an avant garde movement in the 1960s and 70s, and some of its features made it difficult to visualize how it might make the transition from galleries and public spaces to the more institutional environment of the museum.

title: Limbaugh, Somewhat Airbrushed
description: In July 2008 The New York Times Magazine published Zev Chafetss appreciative profile of a surprisingly candid Rush Limbaugh. There was spontaneity to the piece, perhaps because it had come about only by accident, after Mr. Chafetss original assignment to write about John McCain (and interview Mr. Limbaugh in the process) fell through. And there was an overriding idea that still holds true: The only way to form a fair opinion about Mr. Limbaugh is to listen to him directly. His pronouncements are distorted and yanked out of context by acolytes and enemies alike.

title: Rush Limbaugh
description: Chapter 1: I Hope He Fails

title: Lives Lost in the Oil Age
description: On Sunday, a column by Doug Simpson on AOL News noted that relatives of some of the 11 men who died aboard the Deepwater Horizon were upset that most coverage was focused on the unfolding environmental disaster. This may change on Tuesday, when Transocean holds a memorial service in Jackson, Miss., for those who were lost. Its important to recall, as you gas up or pay your bill for heating oil, that there are invisible costs of many kinds attending the conveniences of the fossil-fuel age.

title: Iranian Says Uranium Deal Off if Sanctions Are On
description: CAIRO  The speaker of Irans Parliament said Sunday that his country would abandon a deal to ship some of its nuclear fuel to Turkey and rethink its cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency if the United States pushed new sanctions through the United Nations Security Council.

title: Clevelands Voluptuous Lulu, Surrounded by Beethoven
description: In assessing an orchestra, classical music insiders and audiences can get too caught up with the issue of sound. Yes, to be enveloped in the sheer sonic splendor of a great orchestra is a wonderful thing. But I am willing to trade a little aural roughness for bracing performances when a conductor and players challenge themselves in the best sense and bring striking insights to standard repertory or champion living composers. There is more at stake for the American orchestra than the pursuit of glorious sound.

title: If Not 76 Trombones, Everything Else a One-Man Band Can Handle
description: Imagine a player piano. Now imagine youre a guitarist and composer named Pat Metheny and that you have a kind of player piano that can both play what youve composed for it  not through perforated paper but digital technology  and also replicate whatever youre playing on the guitar. You can also play a long phrase on the guitar and command the piano to loop the phrase, so that you can play against the loop.

title: Dudamel Presents a Popular Pairing
description: Gustavo Dudamel began his tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in October with a concert that brought together John Adamss City Noir, a work composed for the occasion, and Mahlers First Symphony. Since then the orchestra has gotten plenty of mileage out of that program: it was broadcast on television and radio at the time; Deutsche Grammophon has released recordings of both works (separately) on iTunes; and the pairing was revived as one of the programs Mr. Dudamel led on his first cross-country tour with the orchestra. The tour ended with the Adams and Mahler program at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening.

title: Zimbabwe Past and Present in a Mix of Reality and Myth
description: The title of Nora Chipaumires new dance is a mouthful and, fittingly, loaded with meaning: lions will roar, swans will fly, angels will wrestle heaven, rains will break: gukurahundi.

title: Remembering a Champion and Teacher
description: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Bill Passell, 79, died of multiple myeloma on May 9 in his hometown, Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: How Equal Was This Separate School?
description: You could listen to a lot of dry lectures by a lot of windy history professors and still not learn as much about race issues in the century after the Civil War as you do in A Place Out of Time: The Bordentown School.

title: Cows Offspring
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Im hungry. Are you hungry?

title: Thai Filmmaker Wins Palme dOr at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  On Sunday evening the 63rd Cannes Film Festival came to a shocking, exhilarating close with the Palme dOr going to Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives from the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul. Surely the only Palme winner to feature sex between a princess and a thrashing catfish, Boonmee is a fantastical tale about a dying man whose past lives  and ghostly relatives  enraptured some critics while turning others off. The speculation that it might appeal to the jury president, Tim Burton, along with some of his more discerning fellow jury members, proved true.

title: The Green Ogre Stumbles
description: Shrek Forever After was No. 1 at North American multiplexes over the weekend but failed to meet even cautious expectations, probably because of franchise fatigue and pushback from consumers over the rising cost of 3-D tickets. The movie, from DreamWorks Animation, brought in an estimated $71.3 million, far from chump change but sharply below opening tallies for the franchises previous two movies, which did not have premium-priced 3-D tickets to prop them up. DreamWorks expects positive word of mouth and a lack of competition from other family films to help Shrek Forever After blossom into a substantial hit, much as the studios How to Train Your Dragon overcame a soft opening weekend. DreamWorks always expected the fourth Shrek to have a weaker debut than Shrek the Third (more than $122 million opening; $799 million global total), partly because of the franchises age. Last week analysts lowered expectations for Shrek Forever After based on prerelease surveys. Doug Creutz, an analyst at Cowen & Company, wrote that those surveys pointed to an opening below the $110 million to $140 million range we think the film needs to hit in order to meet investor expectations. Other analysts had lowered expectations to $75 million to $90 million. Iron Man 2 was second over the weekend with $26.6 million, for a new total of $251.3 million. Robin Hood was third with $18.7 million ($66.1 million total). Letters to Juliet was fourth with $9.1 million ($27.4 million total), and Just Wright was fifth with $4.2 million ($14.6 million total).

title: Madonna Reprimands Malawi Court
description: Madonna, below, said she was shocked and saddened by a court in Malawis decision to sentence a gay couple to 14 years of hard labor in prison, Agence France-Presse reported. After their engagement party was announced on the front page of a newspaper in December, Tiwonge Chimbalanga and Steven Monjeza were arrested. Last week they were convicted of unnatural acts and gross indecency, and given the maximum sentence. In a statement on the Web site of her foundation, Raising Malawi (raisingmalawi.org), Madonna, who has adopted two children from that country, said two innocent men were being sent to prison. She wrote: As a matter of principle, I believe in equal rights for all people, no matter what their gender, race, color, religion, or sexual orientation. This week, Malawi took a giant step backward. She asked that the progressive people in Malawi, and around the world, challenge this decision in the name of human dignity and equal rights for all, by adding their names to her statement.

title: In the Wings

The show will chronicle his divorce from his third wife, Alyce Faye Eichelberger, in 2008, which culminated in a settlement reported to be more than $17 million. The tour is planned to begin in May of next year in Cambridge, with shows in Birmingham, Salford, Liverpool, Oxford, Leeds, Edinburgh and Bristol. ... Though the regional debut of the musical stage adaptation of Heathers, the 1988 cult film starring Winona Ryder and Christian Slater, has been postponed, producers will offer a concert staging in New York in September, Playbill.com reported. The composer Laurence OKeefe (Legally Blonde), who wrote the book and music with Kevin Murphy (Reefer Madness), said he could not confirm casting for the concert but said it would be full of surprises and special guests. Andy Fickman, another Reefer Madness alum, will direct the production, the dates and location of which are still to be determined.

title: Tenor to Close This Summer
description: Despite three Tony nominations and a cast and crew of stars from Broadway and Hollywood, producers for the revival of Lend Me a Tenor have announced that the show is to close on Aug. 15, Playbill.com reported. That date coincides with the end of the casts current contracts. This production, the Broadway directorial debut of Stanley Tucci, stars Anthony LaPaglia (A View From the Bridge), Tony Shalhoub (Monk) and Jan Maxwell, who is nominated for a Tony award in the featured actress category for her work in Tenor, as well as for lead actress for The Royal Family. Nominations for best revival of a play and best costume design could help to ensure that this production, which opened at the Music Box Theater on April 4 to tepid reviews, could go out with a bang, not just banging doors.

title: A Golden Ticket for St. Louis Opera Fans
description: The Golden Ticket, a new opera based on Roald Dahls book  Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,  is to have its world premiere on June 13 with the Opera Theater of Saint Louis at the Loretto-Hilton Center of Webster University. The bass-baritone Daniel Okulitch, left, who sang the title role in  Don Giovanni  at New York City Opera last year, is to play Willy Wonka. He will be joined by Michael Kepler Meo as Charlie, Jennifer Rivera as Veruca Salt, David Trudgen as Mike Teavee, Andrew Drost as Augustus Gloop and Tracy Dahl as Violet. Timothy Redmond will conduct the runs six performances, June 13 through June 26. The opera, commissioned by American Lyric Theater and by Dahls widow, Felicity Dahl, has a score by Peter Ash and a libretto by Donald Sturrock, and is a production of the American Lyric Theater, the Opera Theater of Saint Louis and the Wexford Festival Opera, in Ireland, where five performances will be presented, Oct. 17 to Oct. 29. Additional dates in the United States are to be announced by American Lyric Theater later this year.

Now the National Endowment for the Arts has partnered with Blue Star Families, a nonprofit network of military families, to offer free admission to more than 600 museums nationwide for active-duty service members and their families from Memorial Day to Labor Day. The complete list of museums is available on the Endowments Web site: arts.gov. Some special exhibitions may not be included in the free admission.

title: The Lost Finale
description: There were three reasons to watch Lost or to stick with it, more aptly, across six immensely engrossing and immensely frustrating seasons. You could watch for the characters, who were two-dimensional and archetypal in a way, but rich and relatable and even lovable in the way that great pulp casts can sometimes be. You could watch for the thrill of it  the endless cliffhangers, the constant narrative whiplash, the mobius-strip plotting, and the way the show could blithely disassemble and reassemble its narrative architecture (flashbacks followed by flashforwards! flashforwards followed by time travel!) and somehow have the whole thing work. And of course, you could watch for the macro-plot the mythology of a mysterious island, which layered puzzle atop riddle atop intrigue like no show since The X-Files, promising all the while (or seeming to promise, at least) to be building up to a revelatory denouement.

And  oh, yes  he recently came out publicly and was criticized by Newsweek in an article that said he and other gay actors were unconvincing as straight characters. And what better way to put that behind him than by hosting a nationally televised awards program? The much buzzed-about Mr. Hayes has been chosen to host the 64th Annual Tony Awards, its organizers said on Monday. The awards ceremony that honors Broadways best will be held on June 13 at Radio City Music Hall and will be broadcast live on CBS. The shows longtime executive producers, Glenn Weiss and Ricky Kirshner of White Cherry Entertainment, will return and Mr. Weiss will once again direct the program. The 2010 Tonys team will come into the show with some momentum, or some big shoes to fill, depending on how you look at it: the 2009 awards ceremony, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew the shows best ratings in three years.

title: Green Beans Bring Flavor to Pastas and Pilafs Alike
