description: ONeals, the Irish pub near Lincoln Center, is closing, to be replaced by a branch of Atlantic Grill, the Upper East Side seafood restaurant owned by Stephen Hansons B.R. Guest.

title: Blair to Join Venture Firm as Adviser on Technology
description: SAUSALITO, Calif.  Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, is turning his attention to Silicon Valley. Mr. Blair is becoming a senior adviser at Khosla Ventures, the venture capital firm founded by Vinod Khosla, an investor and a proponent of green technology.

title: Americans Hoping for Better at French Open
description: PARIS  It has been 11 years since an American man reached the French Open final and only 3 years since men from the United States were an ignominious 0-9 in the first round. The record book is bleak for the women, too; an American has not reached the final since 2002.

title: Off the Menu: Cupcakes Replace Zebras
description: What does this say about our food culture? As Gay Talese reported in this weeks New Yorker, Sprinkles, a cupcake store based in Los Angeles, will replace Gino, the venerable Italian restaurant with the zebra-patterned wallpaper that is closing on Saturday after more than 60 years in business. The new lease was signed on Monday.

title: Paula Abdul Returns as a Judge on New Got to Dance
description: CBS has signed the former American Idol judge Paula Abdul to headline its coming dance competition, Got to Dance.

title: Faber Will Be a Host of New CNBC Show
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: No Longer Lost, but Still Searching
description: As the last two and a half hours of Lost unspooled on Sunday night, Desmond and Jack walked into a cave for the final showdown with evil, and Desmond said, This doesnt matter, him destroying the island, you destroying him. Jack, serious to the end, replied, All of this matters.

title: Make Way for Killer Swans
Dubai Police Arrest Two in Connection With Highway Stunts
description: A pickup truck doing doughouts. An S.U.V. driving on two wheels. While YouTube is filled with automotive chicanery like these, theyre usually on quiet streets or parking lots. But in a video that was uploaded last week on YouTube, these sorts of stunts were being performed on Dubais busiest highway, Sheikh Zayed Road.

title: Wind Advocates Rally in Dallas
description: Houston may be working frantically to clean up the oil spill, but Dallas is focusing on a different kind of energy this week: wind.

title: Federer Cautions Against Moving French Open
description: PARIS - The idea of moving the French Open from Roland Garros to the Paris suburbs appears to bother Roger Federer.

title: For Berra, It Aint Over Till ... Well, You Know the Rest
description: Editors Note: Because In Advertising will observe Memorial Day, look for the next issue on Tuesday, June 1, rather than on Monday, May 31.

title: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
description: Miriam Arias, publicity director at Syfy, part of the NBC Universal unit of General Electric, joined another NBC Universal unit, iVillage, as vice president for communications. She succeeds Lauren Meller, who left, the company said, to pursue other interests.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: A European Voice Mail Innovation
description: We all know that Europe has a happier cellphone culture than we do. Nobody there seems to complain of dropped calls. They dont have to pay twice for text messages (once by the sender, once by the receiver).

title: Travel Deals: Up to 30% off Memorial Day Weekend
description: Deals for Memorial Day keep rolling in. Omni Hotels and Resorts nationwide are offering 10 percent off a one-night stay, 20 percent off a two-night stay and 30 percent off a three-night stay, fromMay 28 to 31.

title: Glimmers of Hope for Grads
description: This springs college graduates face better job prospects than the dismal environment encountered by last years grads. But that doesnt mean the job market is thriving.

title: Having a Baby: Depression Affects New Fathers, Too
description: One in 10 new fathers experience prenatal or postpartum depression, a condition long thought to affect only mothers, according to a new analysis of dozens of earlier studies.

title: Tony Blair to Join Khosla Ventures
description: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, is turning his attention to Silicon Valley. Mr. Blair will become a senior adviser at Khosla Ventures, the venture capital firm founded by Vinod Khosla, an entrepreneur, investor and proponent of green technology.

title: New York Super Bowl Leaders Prepare Pitch to Owners
description: IRVING, Tex.  Members of the New York Super Bowl bid committee planned to spend much of much of the day Monday rehearsing the presentation they will give to owners on Tuesday. New York is considered the heavy favorite to host the 2014 game over Tampa and South Florida. Each group is allotted 15 minutes to speak to the owners and the presentations often include videos. The Giants co-chairman John Mara  who gave the commencement address Monday at his alma mater, Fordham Law School  will speak during the presentation, as will the Jets owner, Woody Johnson.

title: Hazards: Report on Sanitation at Swimming Pools
description: One in eight public swimming pools inspected in 2008 were closed immediately because of serious health code violations, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Smaller Banks Are No Safer
description: Writing at Vox, four Italian economists argue that big banks werent the problem:

title: Assassination and Candidate Prohibitions Roil Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A newly elected member of Iraqs Parliament was shot and killed in northern Iraq on Monday night.

title: The 10 Biggest Choking Hazards
description: According to a 2008 study, the 10 foods that pose the highest choking hazards for young children are hot dogs, peanuts, carrots, boned chicken, candy, meat, popcorn, fish with bones, sunflower seeds and apples.

title: Creature Comforts | The Presidio Habitats
description: Two days after Presidio Habitats opened in the Presidio of San Francisco, a stunning 1,491-acre national park in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge, Hal Fischer took a visitor on a tour of the art installation. Fischer is the director of special projects for the FOR-SITE Foundation, the San Francisco arts nonprofit that spearheaded the show, for which 11 international architects, artists and designers created conceptual habitats for the parks animal residents. The first site-based exhibition organized for and presented in a United States national park, the pieces in Presidio Habitats will be up for a full year, until May 15, 2011  unless furry and winged residents actually move into their new high-design homes, in which case their leases will be extended indefinitely, by decree of Presidio Trust naturalists. But will the Western screech owl actually find the Chinese artist Ai Weiweis glazed blue-and-white porcelain vessels hospitable, tethered in the branches of a cypress tree? Only time shall tell.

title: Celebrity Autobiography Expands
description: Celebrity Autobiography, the stage show where actors and comedians read highlights and lowlights from celebrities memoirs, will hold its first performances in Pittsburgh and New Orleans this summer and has accepted an invitation to join the Edinburgh International Festival in August.

title: On Second Try, Lindsay Lohan Makes Her Court Date
description: Will the hot new fashion accessory of the summer be an alcohol-monitoring ankle bracelet? That depends on how much cultural influence Lindsay Lohan still wields  and how many magazine shoots and movie roles shell be able to book after a judge ruled on Monday that Ms. Lohan must wear such a device, The Associated Press reported.

title: Food Court Is Set to Open in the Plaza Hotel
description: The luxury retailers who are setting up shop on the lower concourse level of the Plaza Hotel will be getting company in the next week, with the opening of a multifaceted food hall serving morning coffee, an evening glass of wine and much in between. It was devised by the chef Todd English, a fan of European food halls. Designed by Jeffrey Beers in sharp black and white with a glittering mosaic floor, it occupies 5,400 square feet, about 20 percent of the lower level, with 80 seats at assorted dining counters and cooking stations, and fresh, prepared and packaged foods sold retail.

title: More on Malaria in a Warming World
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated Below The climate blogger Joe Romm and I agree (breaking news): Scientific research and assessments examining the link between human-driven climate change and malaria exposure have, for the most part, accurately gauged and conveyed the nature of the risk that warming could swell the ranks of people afflicted with this awful mosquito-borne disease. I did so last week in a piece on a new study in the journal Nature concluding that efforts to stem the disease are swamping the potential expansion of malaria endemicity from warming; hes done so today in a piece attacking those who chose to report on this news.

title: Terry Gosliner Diving for Nudibranchs
description: California Academy of Sciences researcher Terry Gosliner on a dive in the Philippines.

title: Lies, Damned Lies and WeinerFacts
description: To start the week: something old and something new, something borrowed and something that flirts with the boundaries of blue.First, the old: The earnest lifter-of-weights and creator of personal narratives Aleksey (Impossible Is Nothing) Vayner sat down for a chat recently as part of a series of video interviews around ROFLcon, the conference that celebrates Internet memes.

title: Murrays Discipline Helps Him Survive
description: PARIS  It was not quite self-loathing. It never went as far on Monday as it used to go for Andy Murray, a perfectionist in a game where perfection is simply not an option.

title: Do Video Games Equal Less Crime?
Michael McKean Joins Our Town
description: The actor Michael McKean, the star of Superior Donuts on Broadway this season and a featured actor in many films, among them This is Spinal Tap and A Mighty Wind, will assume the role of the Stage Manager in the Off Broadway revival of Our Town. Mr. McKean, who is still best known in some circles as Lenny on televisions Laverne & Shirley, will begin performing on June 2, succeeding the actor Michael Shannon, who gave his final show on Sunday; Robert Beitzel will play the role in the interim. Our Town has been running at the Barrow Street Theater in Greenwich Village since February 2009; the production is directed by David Cromer, who also played the Stage Manager during the shows first several months. Last December, this Our Town became the longest-running production of the play in its 72-year history, with its record-setting 337th performance at Barrow Street.

title: Afghan Spy Agency Accuses Pakistan Agency in Suicide Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A spokesman for Afghanistans intelligence agency on Monday accused Pakistans intelligence agency of involvement in the suicide bombing here last week that killed six NATO soldiers, including four colonels.

title: Throat Exercise for Sleep Apnea
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores an alternative treatment for sleep apnea  throat exercises.

title: How Do I Get My Employees to Think Like Owners?
description: One of the things you often hear business owners say is, If only I could get my employees to think like owners.

title: The Morning Line: Belmont Doings
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School. He also serves as a member of the board of the New York Racing Association.

title: The Morning Skate: Flyers Kick Sand in Habs Face, Hawks Depth Wins
description: The latest controversy is being called Sandgate, even though  as Ray Parrillo in The Philadelphia Daily News reported today  the substance allegedly found in the runway outside the Flyers dressing room leading to the ice in Montreal on Saturday was not identified as sand; even though some Flyers players who had to get their skates sharpened during the game denied their blades had been damaged by it; even though no one, including Flyers General Manager Paul Holmgren, has accused the Canadiens of sabotaging Flyers equipment.

title: La Bte to Begin Previews in September
description: The previously announced Broadway revival of David Hirsons comedy La Bte, starring the Tony Award winners David Hyde Pierce and Mark Rylance and the British television star Joanna Lumley (Absolutely Fabulous), is now scheduled to being preview performances at the Music Box Theater on Sept. 23 with an opening night of Oct. 14. The production, to be directed by Matthew Warchus (God of Carnage), will have a pre-Broadway limited run at the Comedy Theater in Londons West End this summer. The current show at the Music Box, the revival of Lend Me a Tenor, is scheduled to close on Aug. 15, though a production spokeswoman said that an extension through Labor Day is under discussion.

title: Widening the Pool of N.H.L. Referees and Diving In
description: The N.H.L. recently broke a barrier when it announced the hiring of Marcus Vinnerborg as their first European referee. The announcement was yet another step in the leagues ongoing efforts to find enough officials to fill out its roster.

title: BP Rejects Blasts as Oil Well Response
description: In a telephone conference call with reporters, Doug Suttles, the chief operating officer of BP, all but ruled out the use of explosives to crimp or implode the seabed oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico. (Heres a recording of the call.)

title: White House and Congress Meet on Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: White House and Congressional officials met Monday in a carefully orchestrated effort to discuss a possible repeal of the militarys Dont Ask, Dont Tell policy in advance of a House vote on the issue this week.

title: For 77 Years, a Regular at Sardis
description: Eating lunch at Sardis last Tuesday, William Herz did not have to order coffee. It was brought to him, right when he wanted it (in the middle of his meal, not after) by a waiter who served it in a white mug that no one else but Mr. Herz drinks from.

title: A New Role for a Familiar Face at G.M.
description: It has been a fast-paced year in the career of Susan Docherty, a General Motors vice president. On Monday, she was assigned to another new post, her sixth since last summer, this time in international sales and marketing.

title: Did The Postwar System Fail?
description: Ive been posting about the contrast between the popular perception on the right that America had slow growth until Reagan came along, and the reality that we did fine pre-Reagan, in fact better; see here, here, and here. And what Im getting as a common response  including from liberals  is something along the lines of, Thats all very well, but by 1980 the postwar system was clearly failing, so what would you have done instead of Reaganomics?

title: Taking Pains to Take Care, Both Now and Then
description: Now that our hospitals electronic medical record keeps reasonably good track of patients blood test and X-ray results, we no longer routinely file the paper copies. And now that I routinely offer these copies to patients, I have learned that the world is divided when it comes to medical self-knowledge.

title: Its a Keyboard! No! Its a PC!
description: The idea of containing an entire computer  including display screen  on what is essentially just a keyboard, has been in the fermenting stage for some time at Asus.

title: Texas Rangers Enter Bankruptcy to Expedite Sale
description: The Texas Rangers voluntarily pushed themselves into bankruptcy on Monday to facilitate the teams sale to a group of investors led by Chuck Greenberg and the teams president, Nolan Ryan, for about $575 million.

title: New Plans Try to Revive Carbon Trading
description: BRUSSELS  Carbon trading was meant to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union by making polluting more expensive for heavy industries, encouraging them to invest in cleaner technology. But even supporters admit that the system, also known as cap and trade, is falling far short of that goal. Critics decry it as just another form of financial profiteering with little environmental benefit.

title: New Way Bacterium Spreads in Hospital
description: Health care workers and patients have yet another source of hospital-acquired infection to worry about, British researchers are reporting.

title: Behind the Trends in an M.&A. Uptick
description: The American takeover market has become more active. It is a nervous time, however. The strength of any return is uncertain amid a market decline, the continuing ramifications of the Greek-euro crisis and a potential popping of a Chinese real estate bubble. In this environment, corporate executives may decide it is better to focus on core businesses rather than risk acquisitions. Nonetheless, in this mergers and acquisitions boomlet, we are beginning to see what the takeover market will look like if and when it experiences a sustained return anytime soon.

title: Here Come the Regulars
description: William Herz is not sure how it happened. He has been eating at Sardis for roughly 77 years.

title: For Sestak Matter, a Trust Us Response From White House
description: WASHINGTON  For three months, the White House has refused to say whether it offered a job to Representative Joe Sestak to get him to drop his challenge to Senator Arlen Specter in a Pennsylvania Democratic primary, as Mr. Sestak has asserted.

title: Big Gains for Young People in Health Law
description: After Eric Heininger left his job (and medical insurance) to follow his girlfriend to graduate school in New Haven, he wanted to get a physical, so he volunteered to take part in a medical study.

title: Labels Urged for Food That Can Choke
description: On a July afternoon in 2006, Patrick Hale microwaved a bag of popcorn for his two young children and sat down with them to watch television. When he got up to change the channel, he heard a strange noise behind him, and turned to see his 23-month-old daughter, Allison, turning purple and unable to breathe.

title: Hot Dogs and Other Edible Choking Hazards
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics now says that when it comes to choking risk, food should be subject to as much scrutiny as toys. The group is asking for warning labels on foods that are known choking hazards, writes reporter Laurie Tarkan in todays Science Times.

title: Texas Rangers Enter Bankruptcy to Expedite Sale
description: 6:13 p.m. | Corrected The Texas Rangers voluntarily filed for bankruptcy on Monday to facilitate the teams sale to a group of investors led by Chuck Greenberg and the teams president, Nolan Ryan (pictured), for about $575 million, The New York Timess Ken Belson reported.

title: When Your Son Crashes the (Very Expensive) Car
description: Peter Cheney reviews automobiles for The Toronto Globe and Mail. His 18-year-old son, Will, thinks thats a pretty cool job, and often brings his friends to the family garage to check out the loaner car his dad is reviewing next.

title: 7,000 Miles Nonstop, and No Pretzels
description: In 1976, the biologist Robert E. Gill Jr. came to the southern coast of Alaska to survey the birds preparing for their migrations for the winter. One species in particular, wading birds called bar-tailed godwits, puzzled him deeply. They were too fat.

title: For Children in Sports, a Breaking Point
description: Id be the last person to discourage children from playing sports. Indeed, I wish many more would move away from their computers, put down their iPods and cellphones and devote more time and energy to physical activities.

title: Heres Looking at Me, Kid
description: As the vodka market gets more crowded, even the most venerable brands in the category must try new ways to differentiate themselves. Case in point, Stolichnaya, which is introducing a campaign on Monday that takes a novel tack.

title: Tropical Diseases: Outbreak of Dengue Fever Is Reported in Florida, Health Officials Say
description: Dengue fever, a growing scourge in the tropics, has established itself in a popular American tourist destination, federal health officials reported last week.

title: Premature Birth Rate Drops for 2nd Year
description: The rate of premature births declined for the second year in a row in 2008, the first two-year decrease in almost 30 years, the government reported this month.

title: An Even Better Number for Betty Whites SNL Turn
description: Betty White turned out to be an even bigger star than NBC thought: Her appearance earlier this month on Saturday Night Live got a huge kick upward in ratings when digital recorder numbers were included.

title: Transocean President Takes Center Stage
description: In 2009, Transocean president Steven Newman performed for employees in Mumbai to celebrate the India Division team posting the best safety performance for two consecutive years.

title: Islanders Cancel Trip to China
description: The Islanders have canceled their training camp trip to China planned for this fall over a disagreement between Islanders owner Charles Wang and the N.H.L. Players Association, sources close to the team confirmed on Monday.

title: Pictures of the Day: The DMZ and Elsewhere
description: The South Korean president, Lee Myung-bak, said his nation would sever nearly all trade with North Korea, deny North Korean merchant ships use of South Korean sea lanes and ask the United Nations Security Council to punish the North, Choe Sang-Hun and Thom Shanker write. The steps outlined by Mr. Lee in a nationally televised speech  coupled with new moves by South Koreas military to resume psychological warfare propaganda broadcasts at the border after a six-year suspension  amounted to the most serious action the South could take short of an armed retaliation for the sinking of a warship two months ago, the Souths worst military loss since the Korean War ended.

title: Can Apples Jobs Still Wow After Leaks?
description: Two or three times a year, Steven P. Jobs, Apples chiefexecutive, dons his classic black turtleneck, blue jeans and grey New Balance sneakers, and presents new or updated products that start with an i.

title: From Big Leagues, Hints at Sibling Behavior
description: When B. J. Upton hit a home run last Thursday night to help the Tampa Bay Rays defeat the New York Yankees, it was not the first time that day that Upton had gone deep. Just a few hours earlier, chatting in front of his locker, he had helped confirm the results of a recent study of sibling risk-taking behavior.

title: A Return to Normalcy, for All to Admire
description: I stare harder into the bathroom mirror these days than I ever have. Not out of some pathetic middle-aged vanity, but more out of curiosity. Two years after learning I had an aggressive prostate cancer, I want to see how my face has been weathered and sculptured by the uncertainty and wisdom wrought by the storms of serious disease.

title: Muse des Arts Dcoratif's History of Fashion
description: A Paris exhibition at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs re-assesses the style of the 1970s through multimedia installations that bring each designers spirit to screen life.

title: The Haul | Hebrew Fashionable
description: Introducing The Haul: an occasional peek at what our contributors forage on vacation.

title: New Nudibranchs, and the Sting of Biodiversity
description: Thursday

title: Remembering the Tiananmen Protests
description: Nicholas D. Kristof, who was Beijing bureau chief for The Times in spring of 1989, recalls the citys mood during the student protests leading up to June 4, 1989.

title: Andrew Cuomo, Reconsidered
description: ALBANY  Theres a tradition in this town ofcozying up to those perceived to be incoming governors, regardless of political affiliations.

title: Phillies Riding the Knuckleball Express
description: Its unusual for a team to face knuckleball pitchers in consecutive games.

title: City Principals Bracing for Steep Budget Cuts
description: City principals will find out next week exactly how much money they will be asked to shave from their already stretched budgets for the coming school year, and they are getting ready for bad news.

title: An Old Maid Meets a Scientist. No Sparks Fly.
description: Few fiction writers have been as adventurous and enterprising as Jane Smiley  a fox, not a hedgehog, of a writer; a decathlete in a world of specialists. Having written some masterly novellas about the hazards and consolations of love (The Age of Grief, Ordinary Love & Good Will), she has gone on to write a sprawling folkloric epic about the worlds largest island (The Greenlanders), a variation on King Lear set on an Iowa farm (A Thousand Acres), a funny-bittersweet portrait of a fictional Midwestern college (Moo) and a Faustian tale set in the Rust Belt (Good Faith).

title: A Last-Gasp Airlift for Oily Birds
description: In an unusual and no doubt bewildering migration, a handful of birds oiled by the BP oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico have been transported by military aircraft from coastal Louisiana to Florida and released at coastal wildlife refuges there.

title: Tracking the Ancestry of Corn Back 9,000 Years
description: It is now growing season across the Corn Belt of the United States. Seeds that have just been sown will, with the right mixture of sunshine and rain, be knee-high plants by the Fourth of July and tall stalks with ears ripe for picking by late August.

title: Chinas Flood of iPad Flankers
description: China has rather quickly emerged as the home of the iPad Flanker.

title: Noting Alcohol Content
description: In my column this week on Savennieres, you may notice something a little different in the tasting report. For the first time, Ive listed the alcohol content of each wine.

title: Scandal Or No, Duchess Is Fully Booked
description: An embarrassing influence-peddling scandal is not keeping Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, away from an annual booksellers convention in New York this week. A British newspaper reported on Sunday that the duchess, right, had accepted $40,000 in cash from a reporter (posing as a businessman) in exchange for a meeting with her ex-husband, Prince Andrew. That report did not spur the duchess, who is a best-selling childrens book author, to cancel her scheduled breakfast speech at BookExpo America on Wednesday, an appearance to promote her new series that is scheduled to be published this fall. The series, Helping Hand Books, is intended to help children understand personal and social issues that affect them growing up, including starting school, coping with bullying and learning about strangers. Leigh Ann Ambrosi, a spokeswoman for Sterling Publishing, said the duchess planned to keep all her commitments at the convention, including a cocktail reception in her honor on Wednesday. Were happy to be publishing her and were happy to support all of her publishing endeavors, Ms. Ambrosi said.

title: Asking Puzzling Questions, With Full-Frontal Intensity
description: There are times in life when the question of knowing if one can think differently than one thinks, and perceive differently than one sees, is absolutely necessary if one is to go on looking and reflecting at all. So said Michel Foucault in The Uses of Pleasure, and it is quoted on the Web site of Fitzgerald & Stapleton (fitzgeraldandstapleton.com), the Irish duo whose brief run at the Chocolate Factory marks that theaters first international commission.

title: Not All Is Lost
description: Although ABC topped Sunday night with its Lost finale, a CBS tribute concert to the country-music duo Brooks & Dunn earned solid ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in to CBS for ACM Presents: Brooks & Dunn  The Last Rodeo. That audience was less than the 13.5 million that watched Lost, but enough to lift CBS to second place. NBCs two-hour season finale of Celebrity Apprentice averaged 9.3 million viewers and NBC was third over all.

title: Higher Education and the Pursuit of Living High Off the Hog
description: Tech Transfer is the deceptively mild title of a mordant satire about scientists and universities and how they do business.

title: Daz Joins Pulitzer Panel
description: The novelist Junot Daz has been elected to the Pulitzer board, according to Columbia University, which administers the annual awards. Mr. Daz, 41, winner of the 2008 Pulitzer Prize for fiction for his book The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, will join the board of 20 members. He teaches creative writing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Michaelss Hard Month Has a Good Ending
description: One month after suffering a brain hemorrhage and days after being re-admitted to the hospital for a warning stroke, the rock musician Bret Michaels, below, won NBCs Celebrity Apprentice contest on Sunday. Mr. Michaels beat the other finalist, Holly Robinson Peete. Donald Trumps announcement of the winner came after he said that Mr. Michaelss doctors did not want him to fly to New York for the live finale, not at all. The business challenges on Celebrity Apprentice had all been taped before Mr. Michaels had an emergency appendectomy in mid-April. A week later the brain hemorrhage was discovered. And last week, during Mr. Michaelss rehabilitation, doctors found a hole in his heart. His friends and family are making sure that Mr. Michaels takes no unnecessary risks, according to his Web site, bretmichaels.com, and every precaution is being taken to protect his health.

title: Suit Against Christies Yields $8.57. Million
description: The technology entrepreneur Halsey Minor has won a multimillion-dollar judgment against the auction house Christies, which a jury decided was in breach of its contract with Mr. Minor and defrauded him after failing to promptly return works that he owned but which the auction house was unable to sell, The Wall Street Journal reported. Judge William Alsup of United States District Court in San Francisco awarded Mr. Minor $8.57 million in damages, concluding a suit that Mr. Minor brought against Christies at the end of 2008. Mr. Minor, a founder of the technology site CNet, approached Christies earlier that year to help him sell seven paintings by Richard Prince, including his work Nurse in Hollywood #4, above. The Journal said that Mr. Minor owed Christies about $12 million for other works he had purchased from the auction company, and when Mr. Minor asked Christies to return the Prince paintings in August 2008, the company had decided not to send them back until Mr. Minor paid his debts. Christies was awarded $1.4 million in a counterclaim against Mr. Minor, who was found to be in breach of contract. The Nurse painting was sold earlier this month at a Phillips de Pury auction for $6.4 million including fees.

title: Resort Report | Bottega Veneta, Easy Breezy
description: The Cruise collections are underway, which means that for the next few months we will be attending a loose schedule of shows and appointments to see what designers have in store for that micro-season otherwise known as Resort. The clothes are meant to be real  a respite between the spring and fall fashion statements. More specifically, they are designed to be worn on that warm weather holiday that you will definitely be taking (one can only hope) in late December or early January.

title: Lost Finale Lifts ABC to a Big Night
description: Fans of Lost clearly came together  much like its cast of players  for one last dive into the pool of sci-fi and spirituality on Sunday night, lifting ABC to its best non-Oscars Sunday night in two and a half years and posting what are likely to be the best finale numbers for any scripted show this television season.

title: Frank to Head Joint Panel on Financial Bill
description: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a sharp critic of Wall Street and close ally of the Obama administration, will head a House-Senate conference committee to prepare a final bill on financial regulation, Reuters reports.

title: Ready or Not, Here Come the Clowns
description: Dear Theater Ethicist: Should I feel guilty that, for me, the most satisfying moment of Cirque du Soleils Banana Shpeel came when a clown was riddled with mock machine-gun fire?

title: Observing Squirrels
description: Created by Jason Freeman and Richard Katz. Performed by Jenny Lin.

title: A Classic Turns 50, and Parties Are Planned
description: In Santa Cruz, Calif., volunteers will re-enact every word and movement in the famous courtroom scene. In Monroeville, Ala., residents dressed in 1930s garb will read aloud from memorable passages. In Rhinebeck, N.Y., Oblong Books will host a party with Mocktails and recorded music by the indie band the Boo Radleys.

title: AIDS Is Still a Crisis. Is Anyone Really Surprised?
description: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda.

title: I.B.M.s Bet on Smart Plumbing for Businesses
description: Earlier this month, I.B.M. executives told investors that the company planned to double its spending on acquisitions over the next five years, to $20 billion.

title: Hihowareya?  We Asked, and You Answered
description: When you ask someone how are you, do you really care?

title: Eli Broad Said to Pick Site for New Museum
description: Where will Eli Broad build his museum? For months, Los Angeless most influential philanthropist and art collector has publicly toyed with various locations for a museum to house his contemporary-art collection. Although a Beverly Hills site fell out of the running in mid-April, Mr. Broad told The Los Angeles Times just over two weeks ago that he was still considering both a Santa Monica site and one downtown, on Grand Avenue.

title: Artifacts | A Short History of Richard Prince, On a T-Shirt
description: One thing that makes New York fascinating is the way it can change overnight and still feel like New York. Take the Bowery. Where sweatshops once stood, high-end habitations flourish. Doorways in which derelicts used to sleep now give way to trendy nightspots. And where thrifty cooks once snagged used kitchen supplies, a person can be enchanted by T-shirts.

title: 'Trying to Be Hip'
description: Created by Jason Freeman and Kit Eakle. Performed by Jenny Lin.

title: Overseas Madoff Investors Settle With Banks
description: MADRID  About 720,000 investors outside the United States who lost money to the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion in all, according to law firms representing those victims of the fraud.

title: The Countdown Continues, at a New Address
description: Paul Myerberg of The Times hasnt stopped writing long-winded college football previews, hes just changed addresses, for now. The Countdown will return to The Quad later in the summer, as Paul explains below.

title: 'Reading a Poem'
description: Created by Jason Freeman and Jason Carl Rosenberg. Performed by Jenny Lin.

title: The Lost Finale, in Twitter Traffic
description: By midafternoon Sunday, Twitter was ablaze with anticipation. The hot topic of conversation? The 4.5-hour conclusion  of Lost, which kicked off at 7 p.m. Eastern time with a recap of the shows six seasons. As I reported on Saturday, Lost has amassed a huge following of devotees online, many of whom cant resist the urge to trade one liners, dissect jaw-dropping plot twists and generally chitchat about the show on Twitter and Facebook as it airs.

title: 'Learning to Dance'
description: Created by Jason Freeman and Evan Hill. Performed by Jenny Lin.

title: New Judging Role for Paula Abdul
description: Moving from singing to dancing, the former American Idol judge Paula Abdul will headline the coming CBS dance competition, Got to Dance, the network announced on Monday. Ms. Abdul, right, will be the lead judge and a mentor for the amateur contestants on that reality show. Behind the scenes she will also be an executive producer and a creative partner, CBS said. With Got to Dance  a title that may change  CBS will be competing with ABCs Dancing With the Stars and Foxs So You Think You Can Dance. A CBS spokesman said that the network had not determined a premiere date for the series. In a statement, Ms. Abdul said, Each and every week well showcase the challenges and successes of a fantastic group of dancers as they perform and compete. The Got to Dance format comes from Britain, where it started last year.

title: Sean Hayes to Host Tony Awards Ceremony
description: These have been some busy weeks for Sean Hayes, below, the Emmy Award-winning Will & Grace star: he has been starring on Broadway in the revival of Promises, Promises, which netted him a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical. And  oh, yes  he recently came out publicly and was criticized in an article on Newsweeks Web site (newsweek.com) that said he and other gay actors were unconvincing as straight characters. And what better way to put that behind him than by hosting a nationally televised awards program? Mr. Hayes has been chosen to host the 64th Annual Tony Awards, its organizers said on Monday. The awards ceremony that honors Broadways best will be held on June 13 at Radio City Music Hall and will be broadcast live on CBS. The 2010 Tonys team will come into the show with some momentum, or some big shoes to fill, depending on how you look at it: the 2009 ceremony, hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew the shows best ratings in three years.

title: Talking Head Sues Charlie Crist
description: The singer and former Talking Heads frontman David Byrne has sued Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, saying that he used the Talking Heads song Road to Nowhere in a Senate campaign ad without permission. The song was used in an online video posted in January that attacked Marco Rubio, a Republican who is Governor Crists opponent for the seat that will be vacated this year by Mel Martinez. The governor, a longtime Republican, is now running as an independent.

title: Where U.S. Helped to Rebuild Europe, Past Glories Are Restored
description: PARIS  The United States on Tuesday will unveil the newly restored Htel de Talleyrand, the historic Parisian palace on the Place de la Concorde that once served as the headquarters of the Marshall Plan, the postwar American reconstruction plan for Western Europe.

title: Gold Face Cream: A Costly Leap of Faith
description: CHRISTINE VALMYS Golden Collagen facial mask is a visual and tactile delight: gelatinous, face-shaped and thoroughly golden, it arrives in a sheer plastic enclosure that invites you to squish it the way that bubble wrap begs you to pop it.

title: Australia Expels Israeli Official Over Dubai Killing
description: The diplomatic fallout from the killing of a Hamas operative in his Dubai hotel room expanded Monday as Australia became the latest country to expel an Israeli official, saying that Israel had played a role in falsifying passports used by suspected members of the assassination team.

title: Even Cleopatra Didnt Have These
description: GOLD is expensive, yes, but the price of gold-infused products seems more closely aligned to what the market will bear. Fans of La Prairie, the luxury brand, pay $580 for an ounce of Cellular Radiance Concentrate Pure Gold, an anti-aging serum that comes in a thumb-size tube (above, far left) and claims that with one single drop, it diminishes lines and wrinkles and helps regulate pigmentation.

title: NYC Popfest
description: A look at the four-day pop music festival in New York.

title: Clean-Cut Pop, on the Upswing
description: The real revelation of this years NYC Popfest came during the Friday night encore of Allo Darlin, from London. First, that there was an encore at all: the middle act on a five-band lineup playing its first New York show rarely gets that privilege. But for its allotted half-hour at Don Hills, Allo Darlin had been terrific, witty and heartfelt, like a less moody Belle & Sebastian.

title: A Hospital Stay Puts Off a Maestros Return to La Scala
description: Claudio Abbados grand return as conductor of the orchestra of La Scala, ending a 24-year dry spell, has been canceled. Mr. Abbado entered a Berlin hospital last week with exhaustion and has pulled out of all performances for the next several weeks, La Scala said on Monday.

title: Swift Rage in Pakistan Over Facebook and Its Ban
description: Pakistanis can be emotional, and their sensitivities heighten over matters of faith. Blasphemy is a particularly combustible issue. Reactions are intense and extreme. So, it was no surprise here that angry protests erupted countrywide last week over a cartoon contest on Facebook to draw the Prophet Mohammed.

title: A Display of Young Muscle, Flashing New Chops
description: I have yet to attend a concert by the New York Youth Symphony from which I have not come away struck anew by the polish and confidence reliably shown by this excellent ensemble of student musicians ages 12 to 22. Its programs follow a formula: nearly all include a noteworthy soloist, a premiere by an emerging composer and at least one repertory staple. But what a formula, and what a remarkable value its inexpensive tickets represent.

title: Flying Far From Land
description: Ornithologists using miniature transmitters have discovered that some species fly great distances in surprising feats of navigation and endurance.

title: Back-Seat Jumpers Now Have Their Day
description: As someone who has played electronic games almost my entire life, my deepest shame has always been that Im not a great jumper.

title: A Pianist Chooses a Light Touch Over Heavy Hands
description: The Russian pianist Nikolai Lugansky has a formidable technique, and when he puts a bit of muscle behind it, he produces the big sound that characterizes the Russian style. But mostly, in his recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday as on his recordings, Mr. Lugansky seemed less interested in traditional Russian pyrotechnics than in transparency and refinement.

title: Vulcanism and Cataclysm
description: Q. Is there any evidence of a volcanic tube or magma chamber coming in contact with an oil or gas field? Would that have caused a massive explosion when vaporized oil came into contact with air at the earths surface, releasing carbon dioxide and carbon debris? Might it even have led to global cooling or an ice age?

title: Mineo Lawyers Say Police Tampered With Evidence
description: Lawyers representing Michael Mineo, a Brooklyn man who said he was sodomized by a New York City police officer as he was being arrested in 2008, have filed papers in federal court alleging that police investigators tampered with an important piece of evidence - Mr. Mineos boxer shorts - in order to protect the arresting officers from criminal charges.

title: Budget Cuts Polarize a Long Island County
description: HUNTINGTON HARBOR, N.Y.  The 911 call came in from the North Shore of Long Island on a blustery night in March: Three people were unconscious on a houseboat, overcome by carbon monoxide fumes. Tied up to a dock a few hundred yards away sat a 25-foot police boat, stocked with defibrillators and other first-aid gear.

description: After the first movement of Brahmss String Quintet in G (Op. 111) during a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, the violist Paul Neubauer stood up, told the audience he would return and exited the stage. The rubber band attaching his shoulder pad to his instrument had broken, so he left the stage to replace it. The incident provided one of the few dramatic moments during the first half of the program, the last in the societys 40th-anniversary season.

title: Young Composers Share Their New Sounds
description: Behind the polished veneer of any orchestral premiere there lies a process of familiarization and toil, a process made unusually transparent by the American Composers Orchestra in its annual Underwood New Music Readings. The program, designed to give young composers access to an orchestra as well as crucial feedback from experienced colleagues, offers an invaluable glimpse behind the curtain, allowing audience members to witness firsthand the labor that goes into bringing new symphonic works to the stage.

title: Russia: Ex-Premier Accuses Putin in Tycoons Trial
description: Vladimir V. Putin, then Russias president, ordered the prosecution of an oil tycoon because he was supporting political parties without Mr. Putins permission, former Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov said in court on Monday. The tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, owner of the now bankrupt Yukos company, and his partner, Platon Lebedev, are accused of embezzling 350 million tons of oil. After Mr. Khodorkovsky was arrested, Mr. Kasyanov, left, pressed Mr. Putin for an explanation. He said something like this: That Yukos was financing political parties  not just the Union of Right Forces and Yabloko, which he, President Putin, allowed them to finance, but also the Communist Party, which he, President Putin, did not allow them to finance, Mr. Kasyanov testified. He said he was shocked to learn that lawful support of political parties still required secret approval from the president of the Russian Federation.

They commemorated the anniversary of Alex Rodriguezs return from the disabled list by torching the Boston Red Sox for 14 runs at Fenway Park. But in the aftermath of that game, their sixth straight victory, it was easy to overlook a bad omen.

description: Manhattans chief prosecutor on Monday announced the formation of a unit that will use a CompStat-like approach to detecting, analyzing and tackling crime trends.

title: Waste, Fraud and the Truth
description: We certainly cant argue with the stated goal of the proposal that President Obama sent to Congress on Monday  the Reduce Unnecessary Spending Act of 2010. It is an obvious challenge to the many Republicans who spent much of the last decade helping drive up the deficit with unjustifiable tax cuts and unrestrained spending and who are now caterwauling about fiscal responsibility.

title: 24 Ends With a (Literal) Vengeance
description: Sundays final Lost continues to elicit plenty of chatter in the Twitterverse and elsewhere, but the episode was only the first of several high-profile finales this week. Law & Order will call it a series on Monday night, assuming a cable channel doesnt pick it up, and on Wednesday America will pick its newest Idol.

description: 24 came to an end on Monday night with what was literally a vengeance: Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland) went on one last cathartic killing jag that rivaled scenes from The Terminator and Charles Bronson in Death Wish mode.

title: John P. Lewis, an Adviser to Presidents on Economic Aid, Dies at 89
description: John P. Lewis, who was an economic adviser to three presidents, largely on the subject of foreign aid, died Wednesday in Montgomery, N.J. He was 89 and lived at Stonebridge at Montgomery, a retirement community.

title: United Nations: Sentence for Malawi Gay Couple Condemned
description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said Monday that he would travel to Malawi this weekend where among other issues he will take up with President Bingu wa Mutharika is the 14-year jail sentence handed down to two homosexual men who held an engagement ceremony. Mr. Ban said the sentence violated human rights principles that ban both discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, as well as the criminalization of sexual acts between consenting adults.

title: Shaky Rule in Madagascar Threatens Trees
description: MAROANSETRA, Madagascar  Exploiting a political crisis, Malagasy timber barons are robbing this island nation of its sylvan heritage, illegally cutting down scarce species of rosewood trees in poorly protected national parks and exporting most of the valuable logs to China.

title: Inspector Generals Inquiry Faults Regulators
description: WASHINGTON  Federal regulators responsible for oversight of drilling in the Gulf of Mexico allowed industry officials several years ago to fill in their own inspection reports in pencil  and then turned them over to the regulators, who traced over them in pen before submitting the reports to the agency, according to an inspector generals report to be released this week. The report said that investigators "could not discern if any fraudulent alterations were present on these forms."

title: A Night on the Plaza

title: N.F.L. Fails in Its Request for Antitrust Immunity

title: Flyers, Who Slipped Into Playoffs on Seasons Last Day, Sail Into Finals

title: Finding the Nerve to Make That Hire
description: Alexandra Drane was one of the many entrepreneurs who thought she could do it all. Ms. Drane is co-founder and president of Eliza Corporation, a firm based in Beverly, Mass., that uses patented technology to communicate with health plan members, often with automated calls to encourage them to take advantage of the services their plans offer. She joined Eliza in 1999, when it consisted of just two scientists and a technology that she was charged with commercializing. She recruited the chief executive, Lucas Merrow, and by 2004, Eliza had hired engineering and operations teams. But when it came to Ms. Dranes responsibilities  sales, marketing and account management  she was largely a solo operator. That was around the time, she said, that a board member read her the riot act, insisting that the company would not be able to achieve scale until she started hiring.

title: Slipknot Bassist Is Found Dead
description: The police in Iowa said that they would have more information on the death of Paul Gray, the bassist and a co-founder of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, after an autopsy on Tuesday, but that foul play was not immediately suspected, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gray, 38, was found dead on Monday at a TownePlace Suites hotel in Johnston, Iowa, north of Des Moines. In the early 1990s he helped found Slipknot, the nihilistic if highly theatrical band whose members wear gruesome masks and refer to themselves by numbers and evocative nicknames. (Mr. Gray went by No. 2 or The Pig.) The group  which also includes the vocalist Corey Taylor, the guitarists James Root and Mick Thomson, and the drummer Joey Jordison  won a Grammy in 2005 for its song Before I Forget, and its 2008 album, All Hope Is Gone, reached No. 1 on the Billboard sales chart.

title: Tina Fey to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
description: When we last saw Liz Lemon, the hapless, harried television alter ego of Tina Fey, she seemed to have found true love at last with an airline pilot who just happened to be played by Matt Damon. Though the romantic entanglements of Liz tend not to last too long, her creator and performer is about to receive an honor thats a little more enduring. On Tuesday the Kennedy Centerannounced that it would present its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor to Ms. Fey, the 30 Rock star, Saturday Night Live alumna and occasional cribber of punch lines from her daughter, Alice. In the 13-year history of the prize, Ms. Fey will be the third woman to receive it: it was previously presented to Lily Tomlin in 2003 and Whoopi Goldberg in 2001. Other recent winners include Bill Cosby, George Carlin and Ms. Feys former SNL boss and current 30 Rock executive producer, Lorne Michaels. In a statement Ms Fey said: I am truly thrilled to receive this honor. I assume Betty White was disqualified for steroid use.

title: Remembering a Marine, Step by Step
description: COMBAT OUTPOST LILY, Helmand Province For Marines who have experienced combat together, the many rituals and gestures of bidding farewell to the dead, beginning from the point of medevac and continuing beyond the fallen Marines journey to the grave, are observed with a devotion that is at once quiet, fiercely followed and unsummoned. The more formal rituals are matters of tradition, like memorial services in the field and the escorts who accompany a dead Marine through his or her funeral back home. Some Marines are further memorialized in the names of outposts and landing zones; thus, Combat Outpost Hanson and the adjacent Landing Zone Currier, named after two Marines from Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines, who were killed several hundred yards from here in fighting against the Taliban in February. Other gestures are impromptu, spontaneous and intensely personal, propelled by feelings that take hold within young infantrymen who fight through ambush after ambush together, and who find, as their tattoos often say, that they are bound by blood and then by a set of memories that will be theirs alone for the decades ahead.

title: Life and Other Cycles | Tim Hawkinson at Blum & Poe
description: Tim Hawkinson likes to tinker. In his first solo exhibition with the Los Angeles gallery Blum & Poe, which opened on Saturday, the artist not only tinkers with scale, moving parts and myriad materials, but also grapples with big life issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time. The centerpiece of the exhibition is a monumental kinetic sculpture called Orrery, a reference to apparatuses that represent the motions and phases of the solar system. A larger-than-life figure of a woman, at once benign and sinister  is she Mother Time, perhaps?  sits at a spinning wheel made of recycled plastic bottles. Everything about the sculpture is circular, interconnected and eternally spinning  the womans ears, fingers and the bun on her head; the spinning wheel and the circular platform on which she sits. Even the pattern on her dress, a motion illusion designed by a Japanese psychology professor, seems to spin. The effect is hypnotic as both viewer and figure cycle between the material and cosmic worlds.

On Tuesday the Kennedy Center announced that it would present its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor to Ms. Fey, the 30 Rock star, Saturday Night Live alumna and occasional cribber of punch lines from her daughter, Alice. title: Star-Driven Shows Helped Broadway Sales
description: Broadway productions grossed a total of $1.02 billion during the 2009-10 season, which officially ended on Sunday, with premium-price tickets for star-driven shows like A Steady Rain, Hamlet and A Little Night Music (above, with Catherine Zeta-Jones and Aaron Lazar) increasing box-office sales despite a 3 percent decline in attendance compared with the previous season, according to new data from the Broadway League. The overall gross of $1.02 billion was a slight improvement on the $1 billion gross for 2008-9, although the latter figure did not include box-office sales for the now-shuttered musical Young Frankenstein. That shows producers did not provide weekly grosses to the Broadway League, an industry group of theater owners and producers that collects and publicly releases weekly box-office data. Factoring in Young Frankenstein, the 2008-9 season could have grossed up to 1 percent more money than the 2009-10 season, said Charlotte St. Martin, executive director of the Broadway League. Total attendance at Broadway shows during the 2009-10 season was 11.9 million. The seasons financial gains despite audience losses can be explained partly by the success of some plays and musicals that sold a portion of their best seats at a premium, for $300 or more, while other shows struggled to fill seats.

The tweet included a link to a YouTube video of Mr. Cormans speech, given on May 16 at the Class Day ceremony for the School of General Studies, in which Mr. Corman shared a story that seemed to come from his firsthand experience about a student who challenged a Star Trek-theme question on an exam. Mr. Oswalt has told a similar anecdote in his stand-up routine. In a telephone interview on Tuesday, Mr. Oswalt said that Mr. Cormans actions reflected a lack of respect for comedians. In peoples heads they think that comedians cant possibly make up their own material, Mr. Oswalt said. They must get it out of joke books. In a statement Peter J. Awn, dean of the School of General Studies, said, The student speaker has appropriately issued an apology to his classmates and to Mr. Oswalt for failing to provide such attribution.

description: On the Grammy Awards in 2009, Maya Arulpragasam, also known as M.I.A., performed her biggest hit, Paper Planes, a rap song that infuses rebellious, defiant lyrics with the sounds of her native Sri Lanka, a riff lifted from the Clash, the bang-bang of a gun and the ka-ching of a cash register. Maya, as she is called, was nine months pregnant (to the day), and while she was onstage rapping about some some some I some I murder, some I some I let go  in a black skintight, body-stocking dress, transparent except for polka-dot patches that strategically covered her belly, breasts and derrire  she began to experience contractions. As the pain hit, Maya was performing with the male titans of rap (Jay-Z, Kanye West, Lil Wayne, T.I.) and she later told me that she thought all the free-floating testosterone caused her to go into labor. While American rappers today tend to celebrate sex, wealth and status, Maya, who grew up listening to the politicized rhymes of Public Enemy, takes international dance beats and meshes them with the very un-American voice of the militant rebel. In contrast to, say, Bono or John Lennon, with their peacenik messages, Maya taps into her rage at the persecution of Tamils in Sri Lanka to espouse violence: while youre under the sway of the beat, shes rapping, You wanna win a war?/Like P.L.O. I dont surrender.

The music, dance, theater and opera festival will open on Sept. 21 with Delusion, a musical work about memory and identity created by Laurie Anderson for the Vancouver Winter Olympics that will make its American debut and run through Oct. 3. Other events include a production of Vollmond (Full Moon), a dance work performed by the German company Tanztheater Wuppertal-Pina Bausch and choreographed by Bausch, which begins on Sept. 29 and runs through Oct. 9. The program will also feature Brooklyn Omnibus, a new song cycle by Stew and Ms. Rodewald that they will perform with their band, the Negro Problem, from Oct. 20 to 23. The complete festival will run through Dec. 19, and will also include a celebration of Louisiana music, called Red Hot + New Orleans, with musical direction by Trombone Shorty. More information is at bam.org.

As a pedestrian, the only issue that would probably prompt any thinking on this subject are the sewers that line Kandahars dusty streets; they are the open-air type. The exhibition, which includes more than 100 posters that were designed  mostly between the world wars  for the London Underground (and, to a lesser extent, British railways), illustrates the degree to which the Underground, led by the enlightened Frank Pick, captured public goodwill, helped forge a civic identity for the city, and became a patron of modern artists.

title: Concert Manager at Metropolitan Museum to Step Down
description: Hilde Limondjian is stepping down as the Metropolitan Museum of Arts music impresario, the Met said, ending a 41-year run that turned the Mets concert series into a New York fixture. Under her direction as general manager of concerts and lectures the Met program helped inaugurate major careers, brought back prominent performers on a regular basis and popularized now-common ideas like concerts with themes and commentary. She established lengthy residences for the Beaux Arts Trio and Guarneri String Quartet (now replaced by the Pacifica Quartet) and brought in a young Yo-Yo Ma, Martha Argerich and Cecilia Bartoli, as well as the Emerson String Quartet and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. The Met said Ms. Limondjian would depart June 30 and had already planned next season. The search for a successor is on, it said.

title: Overcoming the Stigma of Herpes
description: Genital herpes may be the largest epidemic no one wants to talk about. An estimated one out of five Americans over the age of 12 quietly harbor a meek but distressing virus that can cause painful and ugly outbreaks on areas that seldom see the light of day.

title: Wal-Mart Cuts the iPhone Price to $97
description: Wal-Mart must be serious about those price rollbacks, and not just on produce. Starting on Tuesday, a 16 GB iPhone costs $97 with a two-year AT&T contract or qualified upgrade at more than 1,800 Wal-Mart stores.

title: Understanding Genital Herpes
description: Dr. Peter A. Leone is an associate professor at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and Public Health. He also directs the H.I.V./sexually transmitted disease prevention program for the state of North Carolina and serves on the National Coalition of STD Directors, a group of public health officials who promote awareness of sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Yahoo Heads to FarmVille
description: Its investor day at Yahoo, so the Web portal is talking to Wall Street analysts, sharing company strategy and unveiling a bit of news: it just signed a partnership with the fast-growing gaming start-up Zynga to bring Zyngas popular social games to its site. That means Yahoos 600 million users will soon be able to access and and play Zynga games like FarmVille and Mafia Wars on Yahoo properties like Yahoo.com, Yahoo Mail and Yahoo Games  that is, if they are not already playing those games on Facebook.

title: Stage Scenes: Nathan Lane
description: Photos of some of the actors performances on and off Broadway.

title: What to Ask About Herpes
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: TimesCast | May 26, 2010
description: Today, BP reviews plans for a top kill procedure to stem the Gulf oil spill, Facebook reverses changes to default privacy settings and Pakistan grows more paranoid over U.S. intentions.

title: Selected Studies: Genital Herpes
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: It Rains, It Pours
description: By virtue of his standing as the best mens player in the game, and maybe in history, and his typically thoughtful analysis when questioned by reporters, Roger Federer has become a sort of conscience for tennis. On Wednesday, after winning in twice-delayed straight sets over Alejandro Falla, Federer was asked about the possibility of the French Open moving somewhere else, perhaps to the suburbs of Paris, to find room to expand. (Federer would love to see it stay where it is, in southwest Paris, because he would love to come back in 20 years, 40 years time.)

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: 5 Things to Know About Herpes
description: This week in The Times Health Guide, New York Times contributor Eric Sabo writes about genital herpes, the largest epidemic no one wants to talk about. Genital herpes spreads so easily because many people dont realize they have an infection and typical safe sex practices, like wearing condoms, do not completely prevent spread of the virus. Here are five things experts say you should know about protecting yourself against herpes.

title: Answers About Child Psychiatry
description: Following is the first set of responses from Dr. Harold Koplewicz, a child and adolescent psychiatrist and president of the Child Study Center Foundation. This week he is responding to readers questions about the myths and stigma surrounding psychiatric disorders of children and adolescents.

title: The Eyes Have It | Sex and the City Shades
description: Carrie Bradshaw and co. have spawned many contentious fashion trends over the years, including Uggs (ugh!). But the bold, gold mirrored aviators that SJP sports in Sex and the City 2 are pure eye candy. A collaboration between the Belgian fashion designer Bernhard Willhelm and the Berlin-based eyewear company MYKITA, the light, sleek, stainless frames were inspired by the Alpine ski racer Franz Klammers downhill heroics during the 1976 Winter Olympics. Theyre $525 at Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys New York and patriciafield.com.

title: L.I. Man Gets 25-Year Term in Killing of Immigrant
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.   The white Long Island teenager convicted of killing a Hispanic immigrant in a 2008 hate crime attack in Patchogue was sentenced on Wednesday to 25 years in prison in a hearing that ended with the teenagers father leaving the courtroom in a tearful rage.

title: Travel Deals: Early Bird Special in Breckenridge, Colo.
description: On June 1, One Ski Hill Place, a RockResort property, will open at the base of Breckenridge Ski Resorts Peak 8, in Breckenridge, Colo. To mark the opening, the hotel is offering introductory rates starting at $75 a person, each night. Book by June 1 for stays through June 30.

title: Operation Desert Togs
description: The first Sex and The City movie, which came out two years ago, qualifies as a comedy both because it is somewhat funny and because, according to a more classical definition, it ends, after some reversals and delays, with a wedding. The sequel  which should have borrowed a subtitle from another picture opening this week and called itself Sex and the City: The Sands of Time  begins with a wedding and never seems to end. Your watch will tell you that a shade less than two and a half hours have elapsed, but you may be shocked at just how much older you feel when the whole thing is over.

title: Live Blogging Facebooks Privacy Announcement
description: When Facebook added a range of new features at its developer conference last month, it came under a barrage of fire from users and the news media over its confusing privacy policy and how it was sharing users information on the Web. One point of concern in particular has been the sites complex privacy settings.

title: Mahindra to Buy Stake in Electric Car Company
description: MUMBAI, India  One of Indias largest automakers, Mahindra & Mahindra, said Wednesday that it would acquire a controlling stake in Reva, an electric car maker in Bangalore, that has been looking for partners to invest in its technology.

title: Tastings With Craft Beers
description: YOU could be forgiven a bit of indecision when ordering a drink at Beer Revolution in Oakland, Calif. While its coolers glisten with bottles of the worlds choice beers, the bar offers a list of exquisite and rare brews that changes daily  it could take an enthusiast months (or a visit to a potentially far-flung brewery) to catch some of them again.

title: The Lost Decade
description: Walter Russell Mead, whos recently emerged as one of the finest long-form bloggers (no, thats not a contradiction in terms), has a post on the top ten lessons of the global economic meltdown. His choices are all interesting, but I wanted to focus on lesson number eight, which is that the demographic crunch has officially arrived:

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Sex and the City 2'
description: The director Michael Patrick King discusses a scene from "Sex and the City 2."

title: The Link Between Frugality and Health
description: Heres an unlikely effect of recession: It may actually be helping some Americans improve their health.

title: New York Harbor, 6:05 A.M.
description: Sailors and Marines aboard the assault ship Iwo Jima prepare to man the rails as the ship makes its way up the Hudson River during the 23rd annual Fleet Week parade of ships.

title: Glee Tops the Chart Again
description: Glee rules. This week the show is pretty much everywhere, with a sold-out concert tour coming to Radio City Music Hall and news that Fox, its network, has ordered  a third season. Now the show has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the second time in a month.

title: Straw Stirs The Mets Drink
description: Whether or not Jeff Francoeur and Jason Bay were upset that Darryl Strawberry gave the team a pep talk in Washington is up for debate. A radio report said they were, but Francoeur denied he was miffed at Strawberrys direct talk and said none of his teammates were, either.

title: Tennis Fashion: An Oxymoron
description: Tennis outfits have fueled debate in mens and womens tennis.

title: Apt. 168, Inc.
description: Yuki Mark Lim, the president and founder of Apt. 168, Inc. describes how his he saved his company after his clients stopped calling.

title: Expecting to See Term Limits on the Ballot
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not be on the ballot in 2010, but the issue that many New Yorkers lambasted him over in the 2009 election very likely will be: term limits.

title: Iran and Russia Exchange Acerbic Barbs on Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  Russia and Iran publicly traded barbs on Wednesday, showing strains in their longstanding alliance because of Moscows support for a new set of American-backed sanctions over the Iranian nuclear program.

title: In Tennis, Fashion Police Look the Other Way
description: PARIS  Venus Williamss serves have long been a big focus of her every match, but never more so than now.

title: Invoking the Oil Crisis, Obama Lauds Clean Energy
description: In another visit intended to showcase a recipient of economic stimulus dollars, President Obama toured a solar panel plant on Wednesday in Fremont, Calif. He took the opportunity to contrast the potential of clean energy with the environmental perils of fossil fuels, reflected in what he called a heartbreaking oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Thanks, Africa
description: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. Earlier this month, he and Nick traveled through Africa, with stops in Gabon, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo and South Africa. This is Mitchs final post about the experience.

title: A Lot of Runs for the Yankees, but Not a Lot of Pie
description: By this time last season, the Yankees had one fewer victory than they have this season but were covered in a lot more cream.

title: Museum Quality | Florida Tropicale
description: Fort Lauderdale, Fla., may not be the first place one expects to find some of the most avant-garde early-20th-century art, design and architecture. But there it is, hidden behind a cluster of pedestrian high-rises, in the Bonnet House, an astonishing  albeit bizarre  museum and gardens created by two great visionary collectors of the last century.

title: Apple Passes Microsoft as No. 1 in Tech
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Wall Street has called the end of an era and the beginning of the next one: The most important technology product no longer sits on your desk but rather fits in your hand.

title: Oil Rigs and Reality
description: Gail Collins: David, just this once can we not talk about politics? What did you think of the Lost finale? Personally, Im a sucker for series that end with a complete repudiation of everything thats gone before  like the one for St. Elsewhere where everything turned out to be an autistic childs fantasies of life inside a snow globe. Or the one for Bob Newharts second series, in which everything turned out to be a nightmare, dreamed up by the hero of Bob Newharts first series.

title: Heres to the Ladies Who Lunch: A. O. Scott Reviews Sex and the City 2
description: Its here! The moment youve awaited for the two years (and 145 minutes) since you saw the original Sex and the City movie: not only the release of Sex and the City 2, but also A.O. Scotts review of Sex and the City 2.

title: Sony Showcases New Rollable, Flexible Screen
description: Imagine carrying around a tiny screen that can act as a cellphone or movie display and when its not in use, you can roll it up to the size of a pencil and slip it into your pocket or behind your ear?

title: Stylish Hotel to Open Spa in Heart of Jerusalem
description: The Mamilla Hotel, a chic hotel less than a mile from Jerusalems Old City which opened last summer, has gotten plenty of buzz, including being listed on Cond Nast Travelers Hot List for 2010. It will be adding a new wellness spa, Akasha, this August.

title: Reach Customers in 140 Characters, All of Them Free
description: Does Twitter still leave you scratching your head?

title: Elongating the Skirt
description: Women are turning away from the frivolity of thigh-high hems.

title: At the Whitney in the Wee Small Hours of the Morning
description: You can call New York the city that never sleeps, but the fact is, its institutions can seem pretty drowsy. Not so the Whitney Museum of American Art, which through 11:59 p.m. on Friday will be open 24 hours a day on a late night pay what you will basis, an experiment in conceptual art, artistic appetite and staffing.

title: A Long, Lean Backlash to the Mini
description: JEAN RHYS knew a thing or two about style and, in particular, about the hauteur conveyed by the sweep of a hem. In her novel Wide Sargasso Sea, a Goth-tinged prequel to Jane Eyre, Christophine, a servant, lets the tail of her skirt fan out behind her  a gesture of breeding, the reader is told. Hitching up ones hem, on the other hand, sends quite a different message. When your man is abusive, Christophine advises her young Creole mistress, just pick up your skirt and walk out.

title: Kernels of Wisdom: Investigating Natural Variation in Corn
description: Overview | Where did corn, or maize, originate, and how did its cultivation contribute to civilization? Why do botanists and agronomists continue to study and selectively breed corn today? How is variation important in this process? In this lesson, students use prior knowledge to tout corn in a 30-second commercial spot. Then, using observation skills, they investigate variations in different types of corn and develop an understanding of the role natural variation plays in its selective breeding. Finally, they apply their knowledge to explain how artificial selection works and to execute a concluding project.

title: Dont Swing That Arm, Mr. Nadal
description: IF you are the maker of a little-known collection of watches hoping to increase your brand profile, you would be lucky to know Rafael Nadal.

title: In California, Obama Tours Solar Panel Plant
description: In another visit intended to showcase a recipient of economic stimulus dollars, President Obama toured a state-of-the-art solar panel plant on Wednesday in Fremont, Calif. He took the opportunity to contrast the potential of clean energy with the environmental perils of fossil fuel, reflected in what he called the heartbreaking oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Read more at our sib-blog, Green.

title: How I Saved My Company
description: The New York Times is inviting small-business owners to submit videos about what its like to own a company that struggles but survives. Go to nytimes.com/boss for details on how to participate.

title: Alice Ripley to Leave Next to Normal on Broadway
description: Alice Ripley will give her final performance as the mentally ill mother Diana Goodman in the Broadway musical Next to Normal on July 18, in the role that won her the 2009 Tony Award for best actress in a musical, the producers announced on Wednesday. Ms. Ripley will then return to lead the shows 36-week North American tour starting Nov. 23 with a six-week run at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Final Cuts for U.S. World Cup Roster
description: The emerging forwards Edson Buddle and Herculez Gomez, once considered long shots, were named to the United States World Cup team Wednesday, while the veteran striker Brian Ching did not make the final 23-man roster.

title: Commander Cites Progress and Frustration in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The commander in charge of southern Afghanistan acknowledged on Wednesday that we are not yet where we need to be in the farming zone of Marja, the site of a major offensive in February that sought to flush out the Taliban. The commander, Maj. Gen. Nick Carter, also said that a more complex military operation was on schedule to begin in the city of Kandahar in June.

title: Crocs
description: 143 Spring Street (Wooster Street); (212) 219-4046.

title: New Designer at Herms
description: Hot news from Paris: After seven years, Jean Paul Gaultier is giving up his ready-to-wear duties at Herms and will be replaced by Christophe Lemaire, who has been designing for Lacoste since 2000. Mr. Gaultiers move was expected, but the replacement was something of a surprise, since Mr. Lemaire has always flown a bit under the radar and doesnt show his own collection on the runway.

title: Facebook Bows to Pressure Over Privacy
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Ever since Facebook was founded in 2004, Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive, has pushed its users to share more information about themselves. Time and again, users have pushed back, complaining that some new feature or setting on the site violated their privacy.

title: 11 Companies to Follow on Twitter
description: Weve just published a small-business guide to using Twitter that was written by Kermit Pattison. Below, Mr. Pattison offers 11 examples of businesses (theyre not all small businesses) that make smart use of the micro-blogging service. You can check out the Twitter feeds individually, or you can see them compiled in one list.
