description: SALES

title: At J. Crews Bridal Store, a Parisian Air
description: ALWAYS a wedding guest? Then the new J. Crew Bridal store has you covered, along with the wedding party and, oh, the bride. The first floor of the boutique, which opens May 27, has cocktail dresses from the 769 Collection that are exclusive to the store (the one at left is $795) and jewelry pieces like Lulu Frost mesh necklaces with vintage pins and brooches attached (below, $695). There are also collaborations with Bobbi Brown cosmetics, Cosabella lingerie and a key necessity, Spanx.

title: Live From the Ira Sohn 2010 Conference
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated Unlike previous years, this years Ira Sohn Investment Research Conference didnt have any blockbuster revelations  certainly nothing on the order of David Einhorns bet against Lehman Brothers or William A. Ackmans assault on MBIA, the bond insurer.

title: Millions of Frogs Force Closure of Highway in Greece
description: As if the political and economic tumult wasnt enough to rattle the people of Greece, little frogs  millions, according to the police chief of Thessaloniki, Giorgos Thanoglou  closed one of the countrys major highways for more than two hours on Wednesday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Shop Till Youre Thirsty
description: DRINK. Shop. Play, said the fashion designer Bob Bland, the proprietor of the Kingdom, as she showed a visitor around the combination bar and clothes store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She pointed out the Skee-Ball and foosball tables in a back alcove.

title: Putting It Together | Babs on Design
description: As a rule, we avoid the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center like Chinese buffet. But for Barbra Joan Streisand, we made an exception. On Tuesday evening, Babs was on 11th Avenue to unveil her coming book, My Passion for Design, which is to be published by Viking in November. Passion? You could call it that, though Streisands relationship with design sounds more like an obsession. When something is off its mark, it disturbs me viscerally, she told a packed audience of publishing types gathered for BookExpo. Its not a good thing.

title: Its Good to Have Best Sellers

title: Making a Mess off Broadway
description: Patrick Healy recently wrote about how the chic, immense and expensive-looking sets of several new productions, mostly on Broadway, have generated real estate envy among some theatergoers. (In this video, the designer Santo Loquasto talks about his intellectual bohemian look for the play Collected Stories.)

title: Pick a Pocket, Any Pocket
description: RACHEL COMEYS Utility Clutch is aptly named: it has pockets galore for everything a gal may need, plus a removable long leather strap that converts it to a shoulder bag.

title: Judiciary Republicans Call for Special Prosecutor
description: All seven Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee joined together on Wednesday to request appointment of a special prosecutor to look into Representative Joe Sestaks claim that the White House offered him a job to drop out of the Senate Democratic primary race in Pennsylvania.

description: 1. Sex and the City 2: Vintage Dior + a camel = a dry-cleaners nightmare.

title: A Dermatologist to the Stars Calls on Them to Heal Haiti
description: WHEN Dr. David Colbert, a former emergency room doctor, went to Haiti to help treat the injured after the earthquake in January, the most potent medical tool in his duffel bag was arguably not the surgical scissors, gauze, rubber gloves or antibiotics. It was his BlackBerry.

title: Poverty Through the Decades
description: That chart, which shows the percentage of Americans of various ages living in poverty, is adapted from a report released recently by the Congressional Research Service.

title: A Handful of One-Acts, Some Packing a Punch
description: Ensemble Studio Theaters annual one-act festivals are nerve-racking affairs: you know that the bill, always laden with pretty good stuff, is going to have one thing on it that really jolts you.

title: Brooklyn College Blocked From Paving Garden
description: Updated, 4:46 p.m. | Paradise is safe from paving, for now.

title: Climate Watchdog Denies Hippie Agenda
description: The precarious state of the economy has come to dominate the way European governments make decisions. That means tougher times  and a good deal of frustration  for policymakers whose job is to advocate potentially costly action aimed at tackling climate change.

title: Woodss Return Portends a Memorable Summer
description: So, the neck pain that forced Tiger Woods to withdraw in the middle of the second round of the Players Championship in May has apparently abated, and he has committed to play at the Memorial Tournament next week. This is great news, not just for Jack Nicklauss tournament but for the United States Open two weeks thereafter at Pebble Beach and for the game of golf for the remainder of the year.

title: 'Lady of the Camellias'
description: American Ballet Theater performed John Neumeiers 1979 ballet on Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Reader Tips for Getting Back Items Left on Planes
description: My recent post, The Hassles of Getting Back Items Left on Planes, about how hard it is to get back items left on planes, got a lot of reader comments.

title: Tweaking a Camera to Suit a Hobby
description: When he is not fighting fires in Waterloo, Iowa, Pete Lilja likes to rig his camera to a weather balloon and send it up to record the world.

title: Fink Worries About Europe, but Sees Euro Surviving
description: Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, minced no words about the European sovereign debt crisis, saying on Wednesday that he was frightened and was avoiding investing in the debt of southern Europe.

title: An Improvised Shrimp and Ginger Dinner
description: If youre trying to buy as much of your food as possible from producers you can look in the eye, the last couple of evenings before the next market day can present supply problems. My wife, Jackie, and I often have two farmers market days: Wednesday near where we live and Saturday at Union Square. But on a recent weekend we were induced to get on a bus and travel beyond the city limits (I saw a big turtle!), and so missed one of our shopping days. By Tuesday the vegetable bins of our refrigerator were in a sad state of depletion.

title: Developer Said to Seek Relocation of an Arena
description: The developer Steven Roth is quietly trying to revive a plan to move Madison Square Garden one block west of its current home atop Pennsylvania Station just as the arena is beginning a major $850 million renovation.

title: Affable Thugs, Playful Crimes, Rough Justice
description: How many characters from a Thomas Perry book would it take to screw in a light bulb? A lot  because one would steal the bulb as a creative challenge, and the others would keep bumping into one another in interesting but futile attempts to find it. All of them would work at cross-purposes. And the light bulb would never get screwed in. After a long, roundabout journey it would wind up in the hands of whichever flawed character most deserved it. Mr. Perry always manages to mete out poetic justice in his books final moments.

title: Weighing the Costs of a Marquee Education
description: This week on CNN, Alina Cho, a correspondent, has been focusing on issues that have been of front-of-mind for many readers of The Choice this spring  whether attending a less prestigious college with a smaller price tag might, in the long run, prove of more value than enrolling in a more expensive, marquee institution.

title: Chris Schlesinger on Grilling
description: Chris Schlesinger replies to readers questions about grilling:

title: One for the Books | Inside Donald Judds Library
description: Assorted pornography, native plants and the Cold War are among the subjects that fill the library of the artist Donald Judd (1928-1994). But you dont have to travel to Marfa, Tex., to browse the shelves. Today, Web visitors can click on a floor plan of his two-room library to view the 13,004 volumes arranged exactly as Judd arranged them. The virtual library has been rendered so faithfully that visitors navigate furniture and art designed by Judd and glimpse an artwork by Dan Flavin between the custom bookcases.

title: Resumption Creates a Start for Robertson
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Maybe it was gamesmanship. But less than two hours before Tuesday nights suspended Yankees-Twins game was supposed to resume in the top of the sixth on Wednesday, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi still had not announced his choice to pitch.

title: For Planners, the Party Never Ends
description: PAGES fly off calendars, as in old movies. Months blur into one another. Seasons collapse. Yes, Memorial Day is just around the corner. But in the life of a professional party planner, summer is just a place holder on the events horizon, a false lull between the benefit season that winds down this week and the one that cranks up again immediately after Labor Day.

title: Proposed Overhaul of Accounting Standards Contains Mark-to-Market Rule
description: The group that sets corporate accounting standards proposed an overhaul Wednesday of the way lenders record the value of their assets, hoping that more stringent and consistent reporting rules might help avert another financial crisis.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gulf Coast and Elsewhere
description: Not for the first time since an explosion aboard the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico unleashed an underwater gusher, there is a certain awful beauty to photographs of the oil-slicked seas and oil-soaked coastline. Win McNamee of Getty Images, whose byline is familiar to Lens readers on photos from Washington, took a picture on Wednesday that called to mind one of M. C. Eschers best-known images.

title: Whitney Biennial 2008
description: A multimedia introduction to this year's exhibition, including narration by Holland Cotter, an art critic for The Times.

title: As Far as the Eye Can See
description: Images from the 40-year retrospective of Lawrence Weiner's work at the Whitney Museum.

title: Jacob Lawrence
description: The Migration of the Negro, Jacob Lawrences series of small pictures, is most effective when seen complete.

title: Silhouettes and Film
description: Images from "My Complement, My Enemy, My Oppressor, My Love" the show of works by Kara Walker at the Whitney Museum.

title: Excerpt: 'Dancing With the Stars'
description: Nicole Scherzinger and Derek Hough won the tenth season of ABC's highly-rated dance competition.

title: 41st-Ranked Player Cant Find Point to Beat Kuznetsova
description: PARIS  No one came closer to advancing to the third round of the French Open on Wednesday without actually doing it than Andrea Petkovic. The up-and-coming 22-year-old had the defending champion, Svetlana Kuznetsova, on the verge of becoming the French Opens first big-surprise loser.

title: Fewer Viewers for This Years Dancing With the Stars Finale
description: LOS ANGELES  Dancing With the Stars had its lowest season-finale audience when Nicole Scherzinger and her professional partner Derek Hough were awarded the disco ball trophy on Tuesday night. Yet the shows Monday night performances have never been more popular.

title: With This Ring, I Thee What?
description: A CELEBRITYS left hand can often break big news. Sandra Bullock Not Wearing Wedding Ring, one recent tabloid headline said. Another: Tiger Woods Wife Spotted Ringless!

title: Begin the Beguine and Other Delicacies From the Shaw Oeuvre
description: To commemorate the centennial of Artie Shaw, who would have turned 100 on Sunday, two of his most ardent admirers, the Anderson Twins, are celebrating his music at 59E59 Theaters. Handsome, soft-spoken 23-year-old identical twins from Bethesda, Md., Pete and Will Anderson are virtuosos on both clarinet and saxophone. They lead a sextet that includes Jon-Erik Kellso on trumpet, Steve Ash on piano, Clovis Nicholas on bass and Kevin Dorn on drums. On Tuesday evening the group was joined by Daryl Sherman, the ebullient swing vocalist who briefly sang with Shaws band when he reconvened it in 1983.

title: Art Linkletter, TV Host, Dies at 97
description: Art Linkletter, the genial host who parlayed his talent for the ad-libbed interview into two of televisions longest-running shows, People Are Funny and House Party, in the 1950s and 1960s, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 97.

title: Rumors Are Realized in New App Phones
description: Its all about the app phones these days, isnt it?

title: Haute Mexican Restaurant Opens in Los Angeles
description: After cooking at the White House state dinner in honor of Mexico last week, the chef Rick Bayless flew across the country for an encore to open Red O Restaurant (8155 Melrose Avenue; 323-655-5009; redorestaurant.com) on trendy Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles.

title: Popeyes Adds a New Chicken Dish, Too
description: Never mind the swine flu. Fast feeders have a case of chicken fever as they bring out menu items that feature new ways to present chicken to hungry consumers.

title: Service Before Self
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff came to the front range of the Rocky Mountains on Wednesday to remind the Air Forces newest officers that Americas wars were far from over and that they would soon be tested by combat.

title: Visitors From Berlin, Their Gear Full of Blips and Syncopations
description: Dance-music producers lead multiple lives. Walter Merziger and Arno Kammermeier, best known as the Berlin duo Booka Shade, have also produced tracks for other performers and have written music for advertisements, and they are among the partners in the Berlin electronica label Get Physical. Even making their own music, as Booka Shade, they have two guises.

title: Mets Prepared to Start Nieve on Saturday
description: R. A. Dickey has done wonders as an emergency starter for the Mets. So has Hisanori Takahashi. So why not Fernando Nieve, the frequently used right-handed reliever? On Wednesday, Manager Jerry Manuel said that Nieve would most likely be the starter on Saturday when the Mets play the Brewers in Milwaukee.

title: Asked & Answered | Patricia Field
description: Just as the clothes in Sex and the City are characters in their own right, so too is Patricia Field. For 15 years, Field has worked as the Emmy Award-winning costume designer for the estrogen-heavy television series and its two movie adaptations. Im behind the scenes and older than all of them, but Im definitely the fifth, says Field, who was born and raised in Astoria, Queens, by Greek and Turkish parents and who has been a fixture on the New York fashion scene since opening her boutique in 1966. On the eve of the New York premiere of Sex and the City 2, The Moment caught up with the eccentrics eccentric.

title: The Thorny and Serene, Submitted Side by Side
description: The Keys to the Future Festival, now in its fifth year, is devoted to new piano music, performed by specialists in contemporary repertory. Though relatively brief  this years festival includes only three concerts  its charm is in its eclecticism and its big reach. Instead of imposing an overarching style, Joseph Rubenstein, the composer and pianist who runs the festival, seems to enjoy assembling programs in which harmonically thorny works, jazz-inspired scores and pieces that, if not entirely Minimalist, borrow from that styles technical arsenal, are offered side by side.

title: Union Leader Lobbies for Jobs Measure
description: Republicans and some moderate Democrats on Capitol Hill have expressed concern all week about a package of business tax breaks and aid for the unemployed, pointing out that the measure would add to the deficit.

title: Apples Struggle With Political Apps
description: Apple has again changed its mind.

title: Dwyer, Coach and Pivotal Figure in Wheelchair Tennis, Dies
description: The New York area tennis community is mourning the death of Daniel B. Dwyer, who died Tuesday of a heart attack at age 68. Dwyer, childhood coach to John McEnroe and Mary Carillo and a longtime coach and director of Point Set Indoor Racquet Club in Oceanside, N.Y., was instrumental in the development of wheelchair tennis as an organized sport.

title: Bradley Makes His Cuts
description: Jere Longman has a report on the final United States roster for the World Cup, and the biggest surprise might have been Bob Bradleys decision to take Robbie Findley over the more experienced Brian Ching at forward.

title: Parisian Courtesan Returns, Bearing Feminist Credentials
description: Ballet, because it is centrally concerned with the differences between man and woman, frequently addresses the same issues as feminism, though seldom with the same goals. Its very being arises out of an either/or dualistic view of gender. The woman goes on point, whereas the man does not. It is expected that he will partner her, not she him.

title: Apple Struggles With Political Apps
description: At our Bits blog, Joshua Brustein reports on the latest flap over the creation of apps for iPhones, this time in the political realm. Apple first rejected an app desired by an opponent of Representative Henry Waxman, the California Democrat, but then the company reversed its position.

title: U.S. Sells 20% of Its Citi Shares at a Profit
description: More than a year after bailing out Citigroup, the Treasury Department announced Wednesday that it had begun to sell its stake in the financial giant  and that the government was turning a profit on its investment.

title: A Final Plea by Restaurateurs Before Letter Grades Arrive
description: After the vision thing, the nuts and bolts are an inevitability  but not necessarily an easy layup. And so, the New York City Board of Health subjected the specifics of its new restaurant letter-grading plan Tuesday to a public hearing in Manhattan. Unsurprisingly, the public was only too eager to be heard about the forthcoming visible posting, starting in July, of 8-by-10-inch placards that will give dining establishments an A, B or C rating.

title: Leaping Through Time From Donizetti to Jazz
description: Just as every ballet has a different flavor, the secret of a good program is harmony  with the right pinches of sweetness, tartness and spice. At New York City Ballet on Tuesday night that balance created a delight: the sunny Donizetti Variations, followed by the crystalline Stravinsky Violin Concerto and finally the ever-cool N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz.

title: Swear-Jar Economics
description: Over at Marginal Revolution, Tyler Cowen quotes the following passage:

title: Take 5: Smuin Ballet, 1001 and the Birth of Impressionism
description: Want to know what to do this Memorial Day weekend? We have you covered.

title: How I Saved My Company
description: Almost every successful small-business owner has survived a near-death business crisis. Today, we are beginning to collect these personal stories in a series of video contributions called How I Saved My Company.

title: Gilt for Restaurants Comes to New York
description: You can already buy designer clothes, spa treatments and vacations on private, limited-time sale Web sites. Now you can make restaurant reservations, too.

description: The woman saved by a man who jumped onto the subway tracks when she fell wants him to come forward, so she can thank him in person.

description: LOS ANGELES  Moving aggressively to expand its hold on childrens entertainment, the Walt Disney Company will close its SoapNet cable channel and replace it with a service aimed at preschoolers.

title: The Trials of Trevor Hoffman
description: MILWAUKEE  Last week in Pittsburgh, Trevor Hoffman was working on mechanics in the Milwaukee Brewers bullpen with the pitching coach Rick Peterson. Hoffman broke off a vintage changeup, the kind that has abandoned him for much of this season. Just as he did, the public-address system at PNC Park began to play Hells Bells, the AC/DC song that has long been Hoffmans anthem.

title: Trampled in a Land Rush, Chinese Resist
description: BEIJING  When Chinas land boom excited a frenzy of popular resistance late last year  including headline-grabbing suicides by people routed from their homes  Chinese policy makers finally proposed a solution: rules to protect citizens from unchecked development and to fairly compensate the evicted.

description: Chapter 1

title: Out for a Test Spin on the Citys New A.T.V.s
description: By the time we got to Lesson 7, I was kicking up more dust than Pig-Pen in the comic strip Peanuts, except that Pig-Pen did it without an all-terrain vehicle  specifically, a bright yellow Can-Am Renegade 800R EFI X xc with a liquid-cooled, overhead cam engine that roared with glee when I finally dared to give it some gas.

title: At Book Expo, Anxiety Amid the Chatter
description: As the book industry gathered for its annual convention in New York this week, it had plenty to be nervous about: the threat of piracy, the decline of brick-and-mortar stores and the perhaps-too-low price of e-books.

description: All the cookbooks I own are packed away. The tower of boxes makes a handy shelf for things we want to keep out of the implacable hands of our 2-year-old, Elliot. Thats the only use weve found for the books since our family moved into a rental apartment in January. I meant to unpack them and set them on shelves right away, marking the borrowed kitchen as my own.

title: Guilty Pleas in Landrieu Incident
description: The conservative provocateur James OKeefe and three other men pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to a misdemeanor in a scheme in which they posed as telephone repairmen in Senator Mary L. Landrieus New Orleans office.

description: Its fair to ask if Renzo Piano was fully sane when he agreed to design the addition to Louis Kahns Kimbell Art Museum.

title: The Tastemaker
description: It has been more than a generation since your films  Pink Flamingos  and  Polyester  established you as a champion of the trash-into-art aesthetic. But now that bad taste is so prevalent in America, does it still carryan artistic charge for you?  Bad taste per se does not, because today its reality television and gross-out, big-budget Hollywood comedies. Everything we export  its all about bad taste, so its not new anymore. You have to know the rules to break them with happiness, and thank God my mother taught me proper table manners.

description: MINNEAPOLIS  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi customarily conducts his pregame news briefing in the dugout. On Wednesday afternoon, however, he held more of a midgame session.

description: Conflict between police and residents erupted in Laogucheng, where residents say they are being unlawfully evicted by real estate developers working and local government.

description: The Dutch Bridge Federation gives strong support to its top players. There are coaching sessions every Friday, and if this costs a days pay, the federation compensates that player.

Not quite fiction but definitely not a documentary, its a bit like a Saturday Night Live episode devoted to the film theories of North Koreas Dear Leader, Kim Jong-il.

description: In Marxs view, religion was the opiate of the masses. Now the drug is celebrity news, and cellphones are well on their way to becoming the worlds biggest pushers.

description: Q. I have an older laptop that cant support Windows 7s requirements. If I reformat it to run the free Linux system, will I be able to import and edit photos from my digital camera?

title: Shopping With Peter Som
description: PETER SOM, a fashion designer known for his feminine sportswear, describes himself as a beach bum at heart.

title: A New Side Table From Philippe Starck
description: Ghost Buster, a commode designed by Philippe Starck for Kartell, is a single piece of transparent molded plastic with two open shelves that requires the user to be scrupulously, compulsively, obsessively neat. No books in lopsided piles. No crumpled pieces of paper.

title: A Contemporary Bench With Classical Curves
description: For most people, the soaring columns of Greek temples wouldnt immediately conjure up visions of seating. But Laurie Beckerman, a New York designer, saw the Ionic column capital as an obvious model for a bench.

title: The Spanish Designer Patricia Urquiola
description: Patricia Urquiola, the Spanish designer, does not like the nickname she has been given  Hurricane  yet those who spend any time in her presence come away feeling as if they have survived a whirlwind. At the furniture fair in Milan last month, the list of products or installations with her name on them numbered more than 35; at the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York, there were fewer, but her presence was still undeniably felt.

title: Contemporary Design on Display at British Castle
description: When visitors arrive this summer at the 15th-century Sudeley Castle in one of the prettiest parts of southwest England, they will discover its historic gardens, ancient walks and ruined tithe barn. They will also find some show-stopping works by contemporary designers.

title: Even Appliances Need a Spring Cleaning
description: KIRBY HILLS, the owner of At Your Service Appliance Repair in Kansas City, Mo., sees hundreds of appliances stopped up with all manner of goo, dust and gunk every year.

title: Sales at Apartment 48 and Others
description: Apartment 48, a home-accessories shop in the Flatiron district, is taking 30 percent off John Derian decoupage items, 20 percent off glassware and dinnerware and 50 percent off vintage furniture through June 30 (a Monkey Bell Jar by John Derian, originally $880, is $616; Sabre French dinner plates, left, originally $38, are $30.40); 12 West 17th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 807-1391 or apartment48.com.

title: Planting the Strip Between Sidewalk and Street
description: HERES a partial inventory of the things Ive found in front of my duplex on a boozy block of northeast Minneapolis: two abandoned bicycles; a disemboweled 13-inch TV; a frenzied Chihuahua named Apollo; three small boulders hurled by anguished college football fans; and a puzzled gentleman in a windbreaker, bleeding from the head.

title: Domestic Detox: Extreme Home Cleaning
description: WHEN Matthew Waletzke appeared at the door of my East Village apartment to evaluate my home for what he calls toxic exposure  the alternative worlds catch-all phrase for potential health hazards like mold, indoor air pollution, household chemicals and electromagnetic radiation (beware your Wi-Fi!)  I half-expected to see a guy in an Andromeda Strain-era hazmat suit.

title: Urban Archaeologys Wharf Light, in Color
description: Urban Archaeologys Wharf Light has become synonymous with a certain type of interior. During the recent period in design associated with great rooms, there were few lofts that didnt have several hanging over a kitchen island.

title: The AIA Guide, Updated
description: The fifth edition of the AIA Guide to New York City ($39.95; Oxford University Press) will be published next week, and like the previous editions, it is a witty, informative and delightful critique of thousands of buildings and spaces in the five boroughs. It is also richly updated with new material  not just additions to the city since the last guide in 2000, like the High Line park and the Time Warner Center, but also sweet entries like the one on 447 West 18th Street and 459 West 18th Street: Two young apartment buildings standing arm in arm, cheek to cheek, dancing the Chelsea Waltz around the corner from the High Line.

title: Full A.I.G. Payment Called Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON  The American International Group is likely to repay the $83.2 billion it owes the Federal Reserve, but whether an additional $49.1 billion in taxpayer investments in the company will ever be recovered remains uncertain, officials said Wednesday.

title: Service Chiefs Seek to Delay Vote on Gays
description: WASHINGTON  The chiefs of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines objected on Wednesday to a compromise plan to repeal the militarys ban on allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly, a position that put them at odds with President Obama and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates.

description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebooks founder and chief executive, held a press conference on Wednesday to showcase new simplified privacy settings for the Facebook Web site and platform.

title: In E. Coli Fight, Some Strains Are Largely Ignored
description: For nearly two decades, Public Enemy No. 1 for the food industry and its government regulators has been a virulent strain of E. coli bacteria that has killed hundreds of people, sickened thousands and prompted the recall of millions of pounds of hamburger, spinach and other foods.

title: M.L.B. Financing Will Keep Rangers Afloat Until Sale
description: In Day 3 of the Texas Rangers bankruptcy, creditors and Major League Baseball vied in a courtroom in Fort Worth on Wednesday to make loans to keep the team running.

description: [May 27, 7:57 a.m. | Updated  A Democratic senator from Alaska said Thursday night that President Obama plans to suspend new permits for offshore drilling in Arctic waters at least through the rest of this year.]

title: A Case Built in New York Against a Jamaican Kingpin
description: In October 2007, federal drug enforcement agents were questioning a man who had been arrested in the Bronx on gun and drug charges when he began to talk about someone he depicted as one of the most powerful men in all of Jamaica, records show.

title: For Peru and American Inmate, Much Is Changed
description: BOGOT, Colombia  When Lori Berenson was jailed in Peru on terrorism charges over 14 years ago, she was a fiery young leftist from New York enmeshed in a shadowy Marxist rebel group, stunning a war-weary nation with her clenched fists and defiant statements in support of revolution.

title: New Breed of  Specialist Steps In for Family Doctor
description: PHILADELPHIA  By the time Djigui Keita left the hospital for home, his follow-up appointment had been scheduled. Emergency health insurance was arranged until he could apply for public assistance. He knew about changes in his medication  his doctor had found less expensive brands at local pharmacy chains. And Mr. Keita, 35, who had passed out from dehydration, was cautioned to carry spare water bottles in the taxi he drove for a living.

title: In Hospitals, New Fingers on the Pulse
description: Jane Gross reports on the rise of a new type of health professional, the hospitalist, on Thursday in The Times. A hybrid in the health ecosystem, the hospitalist is both physician and administrator; he or she may coordinate virtually all aspects of a patients care, an increasingly necessary function in the nations overburdened hospitals.

title: 2 Charged With Selling Insider Data From Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  An administrative assistant at the Walt Disney Company and a male friend were arrested and charged with selling early access to the entertainment giants confidential earnings reports.

title: Witness Issue Prompts a Hearing on Possible Misconduct by Prosecutors to Be Postponed
description: A federal hearing into possible misconduct by Brooklyn prosecutors in a murder trial was postponed on Wednesday because the lead lawyer representing the district attorneys office might be called as a witness.

title: Polish Leaders Mother Finally Learns of His Death
description: WARSAW  Perhaps the last person in Poland to learn that the countrys president was killed last month in a plane crash was his invalid mother, and it fell to his twin brother, the former prime minister, to break the news.

title: Keeping the Peace by Riding the Urban Range
description: John B. Reillys mother plopped him on a pony in Connecticut when he was 2, but back home in Jamaica, Queens, he forgot about horses until he was a teenager, when he began riding in Forest and Pelham Bay Parks. Jumping lessons and gymkhana competitions on borrowed horses came later. Ten years into a career with the New York City Police Department, he was accepted into the elite Mounted Unit. Detective Reilly, 54, with 16 years in the saddle, is the senior member of the unit.

title: Health and Safety Tips for World Cup Travelers
description: If youre traveling to South Africa for the World Cup, you should worry more about mundane problems like diarrhea, measles and tick bites than you do about exotic tropical diseases like malaria and yellow fever, according to a new study in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

title: France: Rwandan Doctor Arrested and Accused in 94 Genocide
description: The French police on Wednesday arrested a Rwandan doctor on an international warrant. The doctor, Eugene Rwamucyo, is suspected of being involved in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, judicial officials said. The Kigali government has accused him of planning and carrying out atrocities in the Butare region of southern Rwanda. Dr. Rwamucyo lives in Belgium, and was dismissed last month from a hospital post in northern France. He was arrested north of Paris after attending the funeral of another Rwandan, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, who was convicted of war crimes in 2003 by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in The Hague.

title: Portugal Old, New and Undiscovered
description: SEE these olive trees? said Celso Pereira as his pickup truck slalomed down a road flanked by thousands of them, their pale, pointy leaves glistening faintly, their limbs wretched and magnificent with age. They make the most wonderful olive oil.

title: Mexico: Candidate Faces Charges
description: A gubernatorial candidate from the coastal state of Quintana Roo, which includes Cancn, was arrested by the federal police on Tuesday night on charges of drug trafficking, money laundering and organized crime. Supporters of the candidate, Gregorio Snchez, who took a leave as Cancns mayor to run for governor, condemned the charges as politically motivated. The attorney generals office said Mr. Snchez collaborated with two drug trafficking organizations that use Mexicos Yucatn Peninsula to move cocaine and other drugs.

title: Romes Soft Spot for Caravaggio
description: WHEN Caravaggio arrived in Rome in 1592 he was just another young, aspiring painter. It took only a few years for his unconventional aesthetic vision and colorful, often violent lifestyle to transfix Roman society. To read his 17th-century biographers, Caravaggio was more likely to have a sword in his hand than a paintbrush, and court papers from the time amply substantiate his bad-boy behavior, which ranged from churlish (hurling artichokes at a waiter) to deadly (murder).

title: With Cuomo, a Mayor With an Eye on Education
description: For Mayor Robert J. Duffy of Rochester, the shooting of a police officer by a sixth-grade dropout last year drove home an urgent message: His city could do nothing about crime if it did not fix its broken schools.

title: In Germany, War and Reunion
description: A STEADY stream of BMWs, Porsches and Mercedeses buzz by as I walk south on a lakeside bike and pedestrian path on a glorious Sunday afternoon in May. The cars carry apparently prosperous day-trippers from Munich, a 45-minute drive to the north, bound for Tegernsee, a popular resort town on the small Alpine lake of the same name in Bavaria.

title: U.S. Sells 20% of Its Citi Shares at a Profit
description: More than a year after bailing out Citigroup, the Treasury Department announced on Wednesday that it had begun to sell its stake in the financial giant  and that the government was turning a profit on its investment.

title: Questions for Makers on Defects in Drugs
description: For consumers who turned to drugstore house brands after the recall last month of liquid childrens Tylenol and other medicines made by a unit of Johnson & Johnson, there is yet more unsettling news.

title: The Palin Brand
description: In the midst of one of the most precipitous political crashes in the Mountain West, Sarah Palin made a mad dash into Boise on Friday, urging the election of a man who had plagiarized his campaign speech from Barack Obama, had been rebuked by the military for misusing the Marine uniform and had called the American territory of Puerto Rico a separate country.

title: Glass Half-Full
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

title: A Silicon Valley Relaunch
description: REDWOOD CITY, about 25 miles south of San Francisco, was a bustling shipping and lumber town in the mid-19th century, until it fell off the radar in the 70s  owing, in part, to major retail development in nearby Palo Alto  and was tagged with the unfortunate nickname Deadwood City. But over the last few years, this sleepy Silicon Valley suburb has begun shaking off that moniker, re-emerging with an influx of new restaurants, shops and theaters. The town is also striving to preserve historic landmarks, like the glass-domed courthouse, which celebrates its centennial this summer with outdoor concerts and a Fourth of July dedication ceremony.

title: Tying Series, the Suns Cut the Lakers Down to Size
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Pau Gasol gazed downward into a sea of cameras and microphones and lowered his head slightly to meet the questions. Clearly, he was still much taller than the average person.

title: Panel on Haitian Prison Deaths
description: The Haitian government and the United Nations are establishing a joint commission of inquiry into the Jan. 19 killings of a dozen or more inmates at a prison in Les Cayes, Haiti.

title: Lotus Position in a Backpackers Town
description: BREATHING clearly lifts the mind and spirit, said Amar Puri, a wiry man in a sweat-stained T-shirt, as he crouched on a patch of lawn and poured saltwater in one nostril with a neti pot. He snorted and sneezed, as the morning mist hovered just above the lead-gray surface of Phewa Lake, reflecting the Himalayas. And now, I am ready for yoga.

title: Sister Margarets Choice
description: We finally have a case where the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy is responding forcefully and speedily to allegations of wrongdoing.

title: U.S. Stands With an Ally, Eager for China to Join the Line
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday declared Americas solidarity with South Korea in its mounting confrontation with North Korea, she had more than a domestic audience in mind: she was also speaking to the Chinese.

title: Voices on Albany's Troubled Government
description: Four New York Democrats discussed the state's much-maligned government.

title: Tenants and Landlords Criticize Patersons Rent Regulation Proposal
description: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed changes to housing laws on Wednesday that would make it harder for landlords to lift apartments out of rent regulation but would also override a landmark pro-tenant court ruling so that it could not apply in future cases.

title: Immigration Overhaul Advocates Question Troops
description: WASHINGTON  In deciding to deploy up to 1,200 National Guard troops to bolster security at the Mexican border, President Obama has stepped into one of the thorniest issues facing American presidents  illegal immigration  and has confounded allies who say he is squandering his chance to address it in a comprehensive way.

title: Manuels Bullpen Use Under the Microscope
description: The one art of managing a baseball team that draws the most scrutiny is his use of the bullpen. To that end, Jerry Manuel has offered up plenty of material.

title: Budget Problems in New York and Mr. Cuomo
description: Attorney General Andrew Cuomo of New York accepts the Democratic nomination for governor on Thursday with an agenda that calls for cleaning up the national disgrace in Albany, a goal every New Yorker can applaud. To demonstrate that he is the one to lead New York forward, Mr. Cuomo also needs to address the states fiscal meltdown.

title: Some Tests, Long Ignored, Showed Signs of Heart Illness
description: New York Citys public hospital system said on Wednesday that some of the thousands of heart test results that were never sent to doctors at Harlem Hospital Center since 2007 had shown signs of abnormal heart function.

title: Lehman Suit Seeks $5 Billion From JPMorgan
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings and a group of unsecured creditors sued JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday for more than $5 billion, accusing it of siphoning billions of dollars of assets and hastening Lehmans bankruptcy.

title: Check It Again
description: These days it is hard enough to find a job. Far too many Americans miss a chance to get hired because the F.B.I. background checks employers commonly use to screen applicants have incomplete or inaccurate information. A bill introduced by Representative Bobby Scott, a Democrat of Virginia, would fix this problem by requiring the F.B.I. to verify and correct criminal data before issuing the background check for employment purposes.

title: Often-Used Mets Reliever May Get Shot as Starter
description: R.A. Dickey has done wonders as an emergency starter for the Mets. So has Hisanori Takahashi. So why not Fernando Nieve, the frequently used right-handed reliever?

title: Throwing the Rule Book at the N.F.L.
description: The National Football League does not condone gambling, but it lost a giant bet this week when the Supreme Court firmly rejected its contention that it is not subject to the nations antitrust laws. The courts unanimous decision sends a conspicuous message to other sports leagues  except Major League Baseball  that when it comes to selling merchandise, charging for parking and paying players, they have to play by the rules.

title: Study Finds Condom Use Is Increasing
description: Women and their partners in the United States are increasingly using male condoms when they have premarital sex for the first time, which may explain why teenage birth rates have declined in recent decades, according to a new government survey of contraceptive methods.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Gathering of Democrats, Except for One at the Top
description: RYE BROOK, N.Y.  Gov. David A. Paterson is known for enjoying a good party. So there must be a pretty good reason why he has been a no-show at one of the biggest New York political events of the year.

title: Concrete Testing Executive Sentenced to Up to 21 Years
description: A judge sentenced the former president of a prominent concrete testing company in New York City to 7 to 21 years in prison on Wednesday, saying he had betrayed the public and his profession with years of lying and fakery.

title: Meadowlands in February? Watch for Snowballs
description: In the lead-up to the decision to grant the Super Bowl to the New York area in 2014, why all these whiny assertions of how unwise it will be to play football here because of temperatures in February below those that sustain human life?

title: A Busy Schedule Is Never Boring
description: Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, a 32-year-old hospitalist, splits her time between clinical care and information technology designed to save money and increase efficiency. Id be bored doing the same thing every day, she said.

title: After Rain Delays, Unfinished Business
description: According to AccuWeather.com, Thursdays second-round matches will be played in cooler temperatures and could be interrupted again by rain. And you know what that means: more time to deconstruct extreme fashion, be it Venus Williamss lacy dress and skin-tone undergarment or Rafael Nadals half-million dollar watch.

title: Germany vs. Europe
description: Germanys commitment to the European Union has been central to its postwar rehabilitation and its economic success. For years, Germany played the role in Europe that America so frequently plays globally  the locomotive whose dynamism and demand helps turn around recessions before they deepen into depressions.

title: Unchecked Squares
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Todays grid by Josh Knapp looks different because it breaks one of the standard rules of crossword construction. White squares must be checked. That is, they must be part of two different answers, one Across and one Down. This grid appears to have ten unchecked squares. By convention, cryptic crosswords have unchecked squares all the time  heres what the latest New York Times cryptic looks like: (Across Lite, Solution)  but theyre not allowed in the regular daily puzzles, right? Whats going on?

And the episode Top Kill even had a cliffhanger: it could be days before viewers know whether the latest effort to plug the well is successful.

title: Is It Obamas Oil Spill Now?
description: Updated, May 27, 5:50 p.m. | On Thursday, President Obama ordered work suspended on exploratory drilling in the gulf. In a White House news conference, he said, In case youre wondering whos responsible, I take responsibility.

title: For Atlantis, a Flight Path to Retirement
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Gliding into retirement after 32 missions covering 120 million miles, the shuttle Atlantis dropped out of orbit and returned to Earth on Wednesday, wrapping up a 25-year career with a near-flawless space station assembly mission.

title: Michael H. Jordan, Turnaround Expert, Dies at 73
description: Michael H. Jordan, a turnaround specialist who recast Westinghouse as a media company and revived both CBS and Electronic Data Systems, died Tuesday night in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Bloggingheads: Illiberal Israel?
description: Peter Beinart, left, of The Daily Beast and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate whether democracy is dying in Israel.

title: Clifford Grodd, the Driving Force at Paul Stuart, Dies at 86
description: Clifford Grodd, who brought a subtle flair to classic mens wear as the president and chief executive of the private-label retailer Paul Stuart, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Obama Takes His Cash-Drawing Power on the Road
description: SAN FRANCISCO  By the time President Obama flew here on Tuesday for a trio of fund-raisers, he had put in a full day three time zones away in Washington  meeting with small-business leaders and the president of Italy, sparring with Senate Republicans over lunch, making plans to inspect the gulf oil spill and ordering National Guard troops to the border with Mexico.

title: Full A.I.G. Payment Called Uncertain
description: The American International Group is likely to repay the $83.2 billion it owes the Federal Reserve, but whether an additional $49.1 billion in taxpayer investments in the company will ever be recovered remains uncertain, officials said Wednesday, according to The New York Timess Sewell Chan.

title: Cost of Jobs Bill Leaves Some Democrats Leery
description: WASHINGTON  The emergence of the escalating federal debt and government spending as a defining political issue is complicating Democratic efforts this week to push through a major package of tax breaks and unemployment aid over the reluctance of Democrats wary of being painted as budget busters.

title: Mets Revamped Rotation Stifles Phillies Again
description: Now the Mets are winning again, beating good teams, even shutting them out. The Phillies fell for the second consecutive time, this one by 5-0 before 33,223 pleasantly surprised witnesses Wednesday night at Citi Field.

title: NASA Finds New Criticism and Skepticism Before Congress
description: The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was buffeted with more criticism and skepticism before Congress on Wednesday as he sought to defend the Obama administrations proposal to revamp the space agency.

title: Kraft Hopes to Encourage Adults to Revert to a Childhood Favorite
description: KRAFT FOODS wants grown-ups to get the blues in the night, and in the afternoon and at snack time, too.

title: Inquiry Sought Into Sestak Claim
description: The seven Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday requested appointment of a special prosecutor to look into Representative Joe Sestaks claim that the White House offered him a job to drop out of the Senate Democratic primary race in Pennsylvania. In a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., the seven said the assertions, if true, suggest a possible violation of various federal criminal laws intended to safeguard our political process from the taint of bribes and political machine manipulation. The Justice Department as recently as last Friday said it saw no need for a special prosecutor.

title: Massachusetts: EMTs Falsified Records
description: About 200 emergency medical technicians in Massachusetts and New Hampshire bought and submitted to their employer falsified recertification records, officials said Wednesday. The fraudulent paperwork got the EMTs out of the 24 to 48 hours of classroom training, said Jennifer Manley, a spokeswoman for the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. Public safety was never at risk, she said, and those who falsified records cannot go on calls until they are recertified. The agency has contacted the state attorney generals office.

title: Doctors Reverse Stand on Circumcision
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics has reversed its decision last month regarding the practice of female circumcision by immigrants from some African, Middle Eastern and Asian cultures. The academy had suggested in a policy statement that doctors be given permission to perform a ceremonial pinprick or nick on girls if it would keep their families from sending them overseas for the full circumcision. Although the nick on a girls clitoris is illegal in the United States, the academys bioethics panel had noted it is practiced in some countries. The policy statement ignited a storm of criticism from opponents of female genital cutting. Dr. Judith S. Palfrey, president of the academy, said: Were saying dont do it. Do everything that you can to support that family in this tough time, but dont be pulled into the procedure.

title: Winfreys Charity Ends Its Work
description: Oprah Winfrey is wrapping up Oprahs Angel Network, a nonprofit she founded in 1998 to raise money from her fans to support a wide range of causes and organizations. The group will have given away more than $80 million, and Ms. Winfrey, whose talk show is ending in 2011, has often added her own money. Among other causes, the organization raised $15.6 million to help rebuild homes after Hurricane Katrina, and its donors have supported construction of several schools in rural areas around the world. Since the network was an outgrowth of the show, it seems appropriate to wind it down in tandem with the shows final season, Angela DePaul, a spokeswoman for Harpo Inc., Ms. Winfreys company, said Wednesday.

title: The Real Idol Leaves the Stage
description: Lee DeWyze came out ahead of Crystal Bowersox in the finale of American Idol on Wednesday night but it wasnt a dramatic finish. Both singers are similarly gifted and likeable in a low-key way  voters had a narrow choice.

title: Facebooks Power, and Its Weakness
description: Witness the power of Facebook. About a month ago, one of the social networking sites users set up a discussion forum titled No I will not pay $3.98 a month to use Facebook as of July 10th 2010! Within a few weeks, more than 825,000 people had joined the page. Trouble is, the whole thing was based on a faulty premise: Facebook has no such intention to charge.

title: S.E.C. Proposes a Uniform Audit Trail to Track Trading
description: Federal regulators moved on Wednesday toward requiring a uniform system for tracking all securities orders on American exchanges, in hopes of making it easier to investigate market disruptions like the plunge on May 6, The Associated Press reported.

description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Glen Davis attempted to pick himself up before falling again. He rose and, like a stunned boxer, staggered to midcourt before collapsing into the arms of the referee Joey Crawford.

title: New Role for Degeneres: Record Company Mogul
description: A month after David Letterman said he had started a record company, Ellen DeGeneres has followed him with an announcement that she has created her own label. On The Ellen DeGeneres Show, her syndicated talk show, Ms. DeGeneres on Wednesday introduced a song by Greyson Chance, a 12-year-old from Oklahoma (with an uncanny resemblance to Justin Bieber) who has been an Internet sensation recently for his version of Lady Gagas Paparazzi. When Mr. Chance (above, with Ms. DeGeneres) finished his performance at the piano, Ms. DeGeneres said: He inspired me to start a record label called eleveneleven. He is my first artist. We are making a record together. How about that? Ms. DeGeneres is not a total stranger to the music business of course; she has been a judge on American Idol this season.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Concert Manager at Museum Is Leaving
description: Hilde Limondjian is stepping down as the Metropolitan Museum of Arts music impresario, the Met said, ending a 41-year run that turned the Mets concert series into a New York fixture. Under her direction as general manager of concerts and lectures the Met program helped inaugurate major careers, brought back prominent performers regularly and popularized ideas like concerts with themes and commentary. She established lengthy residences for the Beaux Arts Trio and Guarneri String Quartet (now replaced by the Pacifica Quartet) and brought in a young Yo-Yo Ma, Martha Argerich and Cecilia Bartoli, as well as the Emerson String Quartet and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. The Met said Ms. Limondjian would depart June 30 and had already planned next season. The search for a successor is on, it said.

title: Director Resigns at Corcoran Gallery
description: Paul Greenhalgh has resigned as the director and president of the Corcoran Gallery of Art and College of Art + Design in Washington, effective June 1, the Corcoran announced. Mr. Greenhalgh, who has held his position since 2006, will remain at the Corcoran as artistic director until Nov. 1, then return to his native Britain to run the Sainsbury Center for the Visual Arts at the University of East Anglia. (He will retain the title of adjunct curator of European fine and decorative arts at the Corcoran.) A spokeswoman for the Corcoran, Kristin Guiter, said a search for a new director would begin in late summer. In the meantime the current chief operating officer, Fred Bollerer, will serve as director and chief executive, and Kirk Pillow, the provost and dean of the college, will serve as interim president. The Corcoran ran a $3.5 million deficit in the last fiscal year, which ended June 30, 2009, and expects to run a nearly $4 million deficit in the current year.

title: Idol Wins, but Barely
description: The final night of competition on American Idol topped the ratings race on Tuesday as 19.6 million viewers tuned in to watch Crystal Bowersox and Lee DeWyze (above) face off on that Fox reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox led the nights ratings, edging past ABC and its finale of Dancing With the Stars, which drew 18.2 million from 9 to 11. Foxs Glee earned a considerably smaller audience at 9 (11.5 million) but managed to maintain high numbers among viewers 18 to 49, finishing second only to Idol in that demographic. CBS placed third over all with its night of finales, attracting 15.9 million at 8 for NCIS, 13.1 million at 9 for NCIS: Los Angeles and 10.6 million at 10 for The Good Wife. NBC was fourth.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Car Viruses
description: This weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at a new target for hackers: the car. Bettina Edelstein speaks to John Markoff, a Times reporter who has written about how vulnerable automotive computer systems are to malicious attacks. Computer security experts from the University of California, San Diego, and the University of Washington, backed by the National Science Foundation, were able to remotely take over car brakes and other critical controls. With modern vehicles increasingly dependent on computers, the researchers say, its important to address these issues before they become a problem.

title: Somali Journalists Are Assaulted and Jailed
description: Security forces in Somalias semiautonomous Puntland region have attacked journalists covering the aftermath of recent rains, jailing several reporters and seriously beating others, witnesses said. On Wednesday, several journalists were filming and conducting interviews at the market in Boosaaso, Puntlands main port, when a squad of security agents rounded them up. One cameraman said he was beaten in the face, kidneys and legs. Somalia, which has not had a fully functioning government since 1991, is one of the most dangerous places in the world for journalists. In recent years, dozens of Somali journalists have been assassinated or killed while covering their countrys civil war.

title: Sampler: Oakland Gang Injunction Mulled, and Point Reyes Light Sold
description: Judge Weighs Gang Injunction | The latest effort by regional law enforcement authorities to use the court system to control gang violence will be under the microscope in Alameda County Superior Court, where officials will press for an injunction to control Oaklands North Side gang. It would restrain 15 named individuals from a variety of activities, including weapons possession, trespassing and witness intimidation. It would also keep suspected gang members from associating with one another in a 100-block swath of the city and impose a curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. In other Bay Area cities, like Fairfield, civil liberties groups have attacked such injunctions as violations of constitutional rights. In Oakland, opponents argue that an injunction would do little to curb crime and much to prompt racial profiling. A report in The Bay Citizen said that a series of at least four killings put law enforcements focus on the north Oakland group. [The Oakland Tribune, The New York Times, The Bay Citizen]Proposition Billed as Antidote to Polarization | Proposition 14, backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is gaining traction. The initiative would replace traditional primaries in state and Congressional elections with twofold elections. All candidates would run in the first round. The top two vote-getters, regardless of party affiliation, or lack thereof, would face each other in the general election. Voters ultimate choice could be two Republicans or two Democrats, but it is likely that they would be the best-known or the wealthiest of the original field. Supporters say the measure would empower moderates and increase turnout. The states $19 billion deficit, high unemployment and low morale may help the measures chances; polls show a majority of voters favor it. [The New York Times]

title: 36 Hours in Genoa, Italy
description: TELL people youre planning to spend part of your Italian vacation in Genoa, and youll most likely get an incredulous Why? Until a few years ago, Genoa was far more grit than glamour  a way station to more fabulous places like Cinque Terre. And its industrial port was among the more forgettable spots along the Italian Riviera. But a complete scrub-down and restoration of its once seedy waterfront, combined with an influx of young, well-funded entrepreneurs, has made Genoa a city bustling with cosmopolitan wine bars and restaurants. Now with summer arriving next week, Im excited about a new take on my tried and true uniform: the summer chukka boot. Keds, makers of the classic canvas sneaks, have introduced the Champion Chukka, a high-top spin on their low-top. Its a sleek take on the desert boot, done in breathable, lightweight canvas with a molded rubber bottom. The boots come in a bunch of colors, allowing you to coordinate, clash, neutralize or pop at will. Im partial to the navy, which will blend with a rolled up jean or be a bit more of an exclamation point with a slender, rolled-up chino. The pale grey is another favorite, more akin to its tonal cousin in suede. These sneaks are also the perfect pairing for shorts, from Bermudas to cargos. Just ditch the socks.

Its a bit of an unconventional choice, given that Mr. Lemaire, at Lacoste for the last decade, isnt a big name like Mr. Gaultier or his predecessor Martin Margiela. title: New York City Ballet Announces 2010-2011 Season
description: For the first time in its history New York City Ballet will present a fall season in September and October at Lincoln Center. The company, which has previously presented a repertory season that started in November, opens its 2010-2011 season on Sept. 14 at the David H. Koch Theater, and it will feature performances of 28 different ballets, including 13 works by George Balanchine and 5 by Jerome Robbins. Other highlights of the fall run, which continues through Oct. 10, include a New York premiere by the choreographer Benjamin Millepied and a revival of The Magic Flute by the companys ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. The annual presentation of George Balanchines The Nutcracker begins on Nov. 26 and runs through Jan. 2, and a six-week winter repertory season opens on Jan. 18. Other highlights of the season include a new work by Susan Stroman, and the previously announced new production of The Seven Deadly Sins, by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, featuring Patti LuPone in her New York City Ballet debut. In addition, the 2010-2011 season will feature ballets by Melissa Barak, Mauro Bigonzetti, Wayne McGregor, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon and a full-length staging of Tchaikovskys Swan Lake by Mr. Martins.

title: Letters: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
description: The libertarian nudging espoused by Cass Sunstein sounds like a happier and more effective way to get things done than the paternalistic dictatorialism so pervasive on all sides of todays legislative and policy divides. Where Sunsteins notion involves understanding and leveraging human nature to promote essential behavior change, the governing mantra on topics like safe cellphone use, resource conservation and health care reform consistently seems to hinge on the imposition of iron-fisted mandates backed by punishments for noncompliance. This isnt to argue that both pleasure and pain cannot have a role in affecting widely distributed individual actions. But social and environmental-marketing case history is replete with successes that came because policy makers clearly perceived the true strategic value of inspiring people to do the right thing before pulling out the big Draconian stick. In the world of governance, I think the technical name for that approach is leadership.JEF LOEBSan Francisco

title: Introduction to Simone de Beauvoirs The Second Sex

That October, my maiden aunt, Beauvoirs contemporary, came to visit me in the hospital nursery. I was a day old, and she found a little tag on my bassinet that announced, Its a Girl! In the next bassinet was another newborn (a lot punier, she recalled), whose little tag announced, Im a Boy! There we lay, innocent of a distinction  between a female object and a male subject  that would shape our destinies. It would also shape Beauvoirs great treatise on the subject.

title: Dispatches From the Other
description: In 1946, when Simone de Beauvoir began to write her landmark study of women, The Second Sex, legislation allowing French women to vote was little more than a year old. Birth control would be legally denied them until 1967. Next door, in Switzerland, women would not be enfranchised until 1971. Such repressive circumstances account for both the fierce, often wrathful urgency of Beauvoirs book and the vehement controversies this founding text of feminism aroused when it was first published in France in 1949 and in the United States in 1953. The Vatican placed it on the Index of Forbidden Books. Albert Camus complained that Beauvoir made Frenchmen look ridiculous. On these shores, the novelist Philip Wylie eulogized it as one of the few great books of our era, the psychiatrist Karl Menninger found it pretentious and tiresome, and a reviewer in The Atlantic Monthly faulted it for being bespattered with the repulsive lingo of existentialism.

But not necessarily at the top: top-seeded Roger Federer faces the German qualifier Julian Reister in the third round, while No. 2 Rafael Nadal plays the first match on Court Chatrier, facing Horacio Zeballos of Argentina in the second round (5 a.m. alarm for you East Coasters). Top-seeded Serena Williams, also in the second round, faces Julia Goerges of Germany in the days first match on Lenglen, while No. 2 Venus Williams meets No. 26 Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia in the third round.

title: A Chain Bets Youre Going to Like the Way Its New Campaign Looks
description: FOR almost as long as there have been television commercials, there have been commercials that consumers love to hate. Whether deemed boring, annoying, repetitive, corny or amateurish, such spots are recalled almost as much as  if not more so than  the commercials that consumers love to love.

title: The President Confronts the Spill
description: President Obamas news conference on Thursday was partly a political exercise aimed at showing that his administration is on top of the unfolding disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. But what really mattered were Mr. Obamas promises to call a timeout on coastal drilling and to shape up the federal bureaucracy, strengthen oversight of the drilling industry and do whatever else is required to prevent similar catastrophes in the future.

title: Troops and the Border
description: President Obama made a surprise decision on Tuesday to send 1,200 additional National Guard troops to the border with Mexico and seek more money to combat drug smuggling. It followed a testy meeting with Republican senators, many of whom have been pressing the administration to take drastic action to lock down the border.

title: While China Stands By
description: There is only one country with any chance of getting through to North Korea. That is China, the Norths major supplier of aid, food and oil. As tensions on the Korean Peninsula continue to spiral  frighteningly  upward, China is refusing to get involved.

title: When Fun City Wasnt
description: There is a sobering lesson in the glory and despair of Messianic politicking in retrospectives on John V. Lindsay, the former mayor of New York City. He took the city by media storm 45 years ago but eventually fell flat when he tried to go national for the presidency.

title: Baby Steps to New Life-Forms
description: Intelligent design. Thats one goal of synthetic biology, a field that was catapulted into the news last week with the announcement that a group of biologists had manufactured a genome that exists nowhere in nature and inserted it into a bacterial cell. The dream is that, one day, well be able to sit and think about what sort of life-form wed like to make  and then design and build it in much the same way we make a bridge or a car.

description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company is expected to tell dealers this fall that it is phasing out Mercury, a 71-year-old brand that will be down to just two models by next year.

The Flyers path has been a roller-coaster thrill ride, deep troughs of incompetence alternating with lofty peaks of achievement. The Blackhawks advance has been a regal procession.

description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes only national daily newspaper, the state-owned Herald, long a propaganda sheet for President Robert Mugabe, will soon have some competition.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama refused to say Thursday whether his White House offered a job to Representative Joe Sestak of Pennsylvania to drop out of a Democratic primary but promised that the administration would respond soon.

description: The owner of HH Bagels on the Upper West Side pleaded guilty on Thursday to grand larceny for cheating on his companys taxes.

title: Senate Approves Nearly $60 Billion for Wars
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a nearly $60 billion measure to pay for continuing military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq as House Democrats struggled to round up votes for a major package of business tax breaks and safety-net programs for the long-term unemployed.

description: From initial accounts, Al-Taya Conyers had a series of troubling relationships, even at age 16.

title: Indonesia: Forest-Clearing Moratorium
description: Indonesia has declared a two-year moratorium on clearing natural forests as part of a billion-dollar deal aimed at reviving international efforts to fight climate change. The deal, signed Wednesday in Oslo, is part of a United Nations-backed plan in which wealthy countries help pay for the preservation of forests in developing countries. The clearing of forests for commercial uses has helped make Indonesia the worlds third largest greenhouse gas emitter, behind the United States and China, according to some estimates.

title: Mexico: Morning-After Pills to Be Offered to Rape Victims
description: The Supreme Court upheld a federal law on Thursday requiring health providers to offer morning-after pills to rape victims. The ruling came in response to a challenge brought by Emilio Gonzlez, the governor of the state of Jalisco, who argued that prosecutors, not health workers, ought to decide whether a woman was raped. The state should not force rape victims to suffer an imposed pregnancy, Jos Miguel Vivanco, Americas director at Human Rights Watch, said in praising the decision. Mexico has a hodgepodge of state-imposed restrictions on abortion, with Mexico City permitting all women to end their pregnancies in the first trimester.

title: N.B.A. Clears Perkins, but Celtics Are Aching
description: The N.B.A. offered the Boston Celtics some healing Thursday by revoking one of Kendrick Perkinss technical fouls, leaving him eligible to play in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. The league treated them more kindly than did the Orlando Magic, which left the Celtics discarded, dazed and concussed.

description: SEATTLE  James Fogle was in prison when a critically acclaimed movie based on his novel Drugstore Cowboy was released in 1989. Starring Matt Dillon and directed by Gus Van Sant, the film portrayed a fumbling band of thieves and addicts who roamed the Pacific Northwest in the 1970s stealing drugs and money from pharmacies.

description: BP is likely to eventually stop the flow of oil from its explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. After that happens, the autopsy of the spill will begin in earnest. But if the information dribbling into the public domain proves correct, the British energy giant will be a weakened creature  so weak it will be vulnerable to a takeover.

title: Strike Forces Honda to Shut Plants in China
description: HONG KONG  A strike at a crucial parts factory has forced Honda to shut down all four of its joint venture assembly plants in China. It was the clearest sign yet of growing labor unrest in a country that now stands at the cornerstone of companies global supply chains.

title: Decades Later, Ex-Police Commander in Chicago Goes on Trial in Abuse Cases
description: CHICAGO  The retired police commander, now white-haired and in ill health, sat silently in a courtroom here as federal prosecutors described how, more than two decades ago, he hit a suspect over the head with a stapler and stuck a gun in another suspects mouth.

description: Mets catcher Rod Barajas wore a hard, white brace on his right wrist Thursday afternoon. While speaking to reporters, he tucked most of it in the pouch of his hooded sweatshirt.

description: Ample of girth, his scalp gleaming beneath a thinning thatch of hair, Alex De Francis stood out in the small sea of veterans that filled a Midtown hotel ballroom on Thursday.

title: Keeping Score: An Edge to Friendly Confines
description: In major league baseball from 2000 to 2009, the home team won 54 percent of the time. Many cite the home teams last at-bat as the reason. At the end of games, the thinking goes, the home team can tailor its strategy to match the situation. If the team is down by three runs, it can play for the big inning. If it needs one run, it can use small-ball strategies like bunting and base stealing to get that run.

title: Arizona Law Is Stoking Unease Among Latinos
description: PHOENIX  When Gov. Jan Brewer signed Arizonas new immigration enforcement law, giving police departments broad power to make immigration checks, she sought to allay concerns from Hispanic citizens and legal residents that they would be singled out for scrutiny.

title: U.S. and Japan Reach Okinawa Deal
description: TOKYO  An American air base in Japan will remain on the southern island of Okinawa, the two allies said in a joint statement on Friday, as they reached an agreement that resolved a lingering diplomatic dispute but could also present new domestic challenges for Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama.

title: Corrections

Though the work is presented as an act of grief and mourning, Ms. Hopkinss father, while elderly and ailing, is still alive. description: The 22nd century may not look a bit like anything predicted in 50 Artists Photograph the Future, but at least this large show in a tiny space makes for some exotic sights in the present. What are some of the developments envisioned? Anatomical alterations, for one thing. Mariah Robertson seems to see a sort of vegetable-human hybrid in the cards, while Claire Pentecost surmises that well all be reduced to walking stomachs with multiple tongues.

title: Rains Sets Up Tennis-Palooza
description: PARIS  If there is one group of people happy about the rain that disrupted the French Open schedule on Wednesday and Thursday, it is Fridays ticket holders.

title: Offense Sputters, as Vazquez Takes a Step Back
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Three runs were in, the Minnesota Twins were hitting rockets everywhere, and Javier Vazquez stood one more bad pitch away from a runaway fiasco Thursday night. When Jason Kubel pulled a deep fly to right field with two on and two out in the third inning, Vazquez walked backward off the mound onto the infield grass and watched to see if his night had been ruined.

title: Mamma Andersson and Jockum Nordstrom: Who Is Sleeping on My Pillow
description: Zwirners husband-and-wife show of the Swedish artists Mamma Andersson and Jockum Nordstrom works, as many marriages do, because each person has plenty of space. The exhibition takes the form of his-and-hers solos, joined by a hallway of collaborative works on paper.

title: Texas: Student Convicted of Aiding Taliban
description: Adnan Babar Mirza, 33, a Pakistani who came to the United States as a student, was convicted in federal District Court in Houston Thursday of conspiring to aid the Taliban and of illegal possession of firearms. Prosecutors said Mr. Mirza had raised about $900 for the Taliban and had trained with other would-be Jihadists in paramilitary camps outside Houston, and that he intended to fight American troops in Afghanistan. His lawyer said the money was intended to go to the families of Taliban militants for humanitarian purposes and that a paid F.B.I. informant urged his client to take part in the camping trips and paramilitary training. He faces up to 10 years in prison.

title: Anneliese Rothenberger, German Opera Singer, Dies
description: Anneliese Rothenberger, an internationally known German soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera in New York in the 1960s, died on Monday in Switzerland. As befits a diva, her exact age had long been shrouded in obscurity; she was believed to have been either 83 or 85.

title: Virginia: University Objects to an Inquiry
description: The University of Virginia on Thursday filed a motion in circuit court asking the state to halt an investigation into the work of a prominent climate researcher, saying that the inquiry threatened academic freedom. The researcher, Michael Mann, came under scrutiny last year after the unauthorized release of more than a thousand e-mail messages and documents from a British climate research center. The messages led to accusations that Dr. Mann and other scientists had exaggerated or manipulated data pointing to human-driven global warming. Virginias attorney general has issued a subpoena for all communication, research and data produced by Dr. Mann during his tenure at the university.

title: $45 Million Match Is Pledged
description: Michelle Obama on Thursday announced that five foundations  the Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation, the Omidyar Network, the Skoll Foundation, the Open Society Institute and the Benificus Foundation  would provide a total of $45 million to match the money the government plans to grant to nonprofit groups through its Social Innovation Fund, which will help expand social programs that have proven successful. More than 20 other foundations and organizations will provide an additional $5 million so that the fund will have $100 million, half in federal money, to award beginning in July.
