title: Brandeis Seeks Plan to Keep Its Artworks
description: Brandeis University, stung by criticism last year after its board authorized the sale of masterpieces from the universitys Rose Art Museum, is to announce on Friday that it has begun to explore alternatives to selling the works and will not contemplate the sale of any Rose artwork while it looks at other options. In January 2009, as Brandeiss finances eroded badly during the recession, its trustees voted to transition the museum  founded in 1961 and the repository of works by de Kooning, Warhol, Lichtenstein and other major artists  into a teaching center and gallery, followed by an orderly sale or other disposition of its works in order to raise money for the school. In a telephone interview Jehuda Reinharz, the Brandeis president, said the university was now working with Sothebys, which approached it a year ago, to find ways to make money by lending works from the collection or entering into partnerships with other institutions. He said the university would be committed to using some of the income to benefit both the museum and the fine arts program. The income from any kind of partnership or lease would generate fewer dollars, but on the other hand wed still be the owner of the art, said Dr. Reinharz, who last year announced his plans to step down as president as soon as a successor was named. A group of the museums benefactors sued the university in July 2009 to prevent any sales, and that lawsuit is proceeding. While Dr. Reinharz would not rule out the possibility that selling might still be necessary at some point, he said it was now unlikely. RANDY KENNEDY

title: In Non-Idol TV News
description: Season finales of the crime shows Criminal Minds and CSI: NY lifted CBS to a solid second-place finish in the ratings on Wednesday, a night in which network television audiences were otherwise preoccupied with the final round of Foxs American Idol. According to Nielsens estimates Criminal Minds delivered the second-largest audience after Idol, drawing 12.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. compared to the 24.2 million who tuned in to Foxs two-hour edition of Idol. CBSs CSI: NY led the 10 p.m. time slot with 11.9 million viewers, while the networks repeat of Undercover Boss at 8 garnered lower ratings (6.1 million). ABC ranked third, and NBC was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

title: Sports by the Numbers and Other Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: The Pros, the College Standouts and the Rest of Us | While batting averages and marathon finishing times are part of the familiar background of big-time sports, a whole different class of statistics has its own resonance. Did you know that 2:20:06 is the record time in the mens challenged-athlete category of the Escape From Alcatraz triathlon? Or that more than 100 boats now compete each year in the Treasure Island dragon-boat regatta? Or how many times one woman has ridden a metric century on her bicycle in the Cinderella Classic? Look up the numbers behind the sports for the rest of us.First Local Food, Now Clothes and Furniture | With the help of the citys planning department, neighborhoods like Hayes Valley and North Beach have banned chain stores. Any formula retailer, which is defined as a store with more than 10 locations nationwide, must be approved by the planning commission before it can open. The feeling is that potentially, if you allow a number of formula retail stores, you lose neighborhood character and locally owned businesses, said John Rahaim, director of the San Francisco Planning Department. But some residents and shopkeepers wonder if this hyper-local form of protectionism is good for residents and merchants  and who should have a say over how and where people shop.

title: The Dumbest Thing Ive Ever Done (in My Business Life)
description: Im not sure why Im telling this story, but here goes: When we moved into our new shop in 2002, we quadrupled our square footage. So I knew overhead expenses would be going up considerably. Some of that increase was easy to predict, like more rent. Some was not so easy, like how much our electric bill would rise. Before the move, my bill was about $2,000 a month (we have some big machines). Afterward it ended up being about $6,000 a month. Billboard.com reported that Mr. DeWyze would release his first post-Idol album on RCA Records, which also put out albums by the Idol contestants Chris Daughtry and Adam Lambert, while Ms. Bowersox will release hers on Jive Records, which is also home to the Idol alumni Jordin Sparks, Kris Allen and Allison Iraheta. No release date was given for either album, though Mr. Allen and Mr. Lambert, last years Idol winner and runner-up, put out their records in November. The debut singles of Mr. DeWyze (a cover of U2s Beautiful Day) and Ms. Bowersox (a cover of Patty Griffins Up to the Mountain) have been released, though download results for those tracks werent immediately available.

title: The Integrationist
description: While slouching against a wall in a former cigarette factory in the industrial outskirts of The Hague one day last month, I was visited with the sudden realization that over the formative centuries of European history the two words that most succinctly signaled other, foreign or enemy were these: Jew and Turk. Crudely unpacking them, Turk meant Muslim, Arab, infidel, the threat from without; a Jew was the enemy within, someone who, even if born and raised in your hometown, was part of another political as well as religious entity; the Jews of a city were referred to not as a community but as the Jewish nation. Jew and Turk were in fact constructs Europeans used to help define their own identity: that which we are not.

title: Noises Off
description: Writers are notoriously noise-averse, perhaps none more so than the historian Thomas Carlyle. SILENCE, SILENCE: in a thousand senses I proclaim the indispensable worth of Silence, our only safe dwelling-place often, he wrote a friend in 1840. A few years later, after his neighbor in Londons Chelsea district added a flock of demon fowl to his yard, Carlyle resolved to defend himself against the clamor of roosters, organ grinders, the neighbors piano, etc., by adding a floor to his house for a sound-proof study. It didnt work: with certain sounds shut out, others became more audible  distant whistles among them. The silent room is the noisiest room in the house, his wife, Jane, observed.

description: Today, Ill examine two deals  the acquisitions of Mariner Energy and Javelin Pharmaceuticals  and how they appear to be falling apart.

title: The Joy of (Outdated) Facts
description: The other day I realized I absolutely had to own a copy of the recently published facsimile of the first Guinness Book of Records from 1955 (limited edition of 5,000, mine is No. 177). Its a fine book, and it gave me just want I wanted. Since I bought it, Ive been regaling people with stories of Jacko, a dog owned by one Mr. J. Shaw of London that killed 1,000 rats in an hour and 40 minutes in May 1862; Mrs. Theresa Vaughan of Sheffield, who had had 61 bigamous marriages by the age of 24; and Dionsio Sanchez of Spain, who once drank 40 pints of wine in 59 minutes. It was a different world.

title: Up Front: Jed Perl
description: The critic Jed Perl has written that his ideal artist is a traditionalist with radical ambitions.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE FIRST TYCOON: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt,  by T. J. Stiles (Vintage, $19.95.) This mighty  and mighty confident  work, Dwight Garner wrote in The Times, moves with force and conviction and imperious wit through Vanderbilts noisy life. Self-made and ruthless, Vanderbilt achieved a near monopoly on steamship travel, then moved into the railroad business. (He built Grand Central Terminal.) He became the richest man in 19th-century America and inspired the term robber baron. This state-of-the-art biography, as Garner called it, won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize.

title: The Hacker and the Hack
description: If youre a latecomer to the Stieg Larsson phenomenon, here, briefly, is the deal: Larsson was a Swedish journalist who edited a magazine called Expo, which was devoted to exposing racist and extremist organizations in his nativeland. In his spare time, he worked on a trilogy of crime thrillers, delivering them to his Swedish publisher in 2004. In November of that year, a few months before the first of these novels came out, he died of a heart attack. He was only 50, and he never got to see his books become enormous best sellers  first in Sweden and then, in translation, all over the globe.

title: Finding His Way to Paris
description: James Lord, who died last year at the age of 86, is a tremendous storyteller. He brings dramatic intricacies to his encounters with Picasso, Gertrude Stein, Cocteau, Alberto Giacometti, Peggy Guggenheim and a host of other characters in the memoirs and recollections he published over the course of nearly half a century, from A Giacometti Portrait in 1965 to My Queer War, completed before his death. Sometimes I have the sneaking suspicion that Lord enjoys exaggerating his own role as the guileless young man, so as to push some hero or villain into higher relief. And he certainly knows how to grab a reader, beginning his portrait of another one of his friends, the Viscountess of Noailles, with this wealthy patron of the arts on her deathbed, shrieking, I dont want to die, a tragic figure in a Parisian mansion hung with her peerless collection of work by Goya, Degas and Picasso. There is a fablelike power and a sensuous, seductive rhythm about the narratives as Lord unfurls them, a quality almost of mythmaking that can feel a little old-fashioned, but beautifully old-fashioned.

title: When Europe Wept
description: A few years ago, the permanent secretary of the Nobel Prize jury had some less than charitable things to say about American literature. The U.S. is too isolated, too insular, the secretary, Horace Engdahl, argued. They dont translate enough and dont really participate in the big dialogue of literature. That ignorance is restraining. His comments upset some people on our shores, but despite the obvious oversimplification he was right.

title: Interim Report
description: Barack Obama may be struggling to right the listing economy, but he has stimulated a remarkable growth spurt in at least one battered sector. His presidency has ignited a literary boomlet. The Obama administration, as Howard Kurtz of The Washington Post recently observed, is under siege  not from lobbyists or hostile Republicans, but from a welter of elite journalists demanding interviews as they race to complete their books about the White House.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PREGNANT WIDOW: Inside History,  by Martin Amis (Knopf, $26.95.) Amiss novel concerns three students from the University of London, one male, two female, who stay at a castle in Italy in 1970, during the opening skirmishes of the sexual revolution.

title: Palin Builds Fence After Author Moves In Next Door
description: If good fences make good neighbors, Sarah Palin and the author Joe McGinniss should get along beautifully. Ms. Palin has just had a 14-foot-high fence erected between her property and the house next door, which Mr. McGinniss has rented for the summer while he researches a book about Ms. Palin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGinniss, the author of The Selling of the President and Fatal Vision, drew criticism from both the right and the left this week when Ms. Palin announced on her Facebook page that he had moved next door to her family on Lake Lucille in Wasilla, Alaska. Ms. Palin told Glenn Beck on his radio show that her husband, Todd, and his friends began working on a fence almost immediately after Mr. McGinniss moved in.

title: Engagement in Cairo
description: In 2003, as a 21-year-old convert to Islam, I moved from Colorado to Cairo to see what life was like in a Muslim country. I got a much better look than I bargained for. While I was there, I fell in love and was engaged to a young Egyptian man named Omar.

title: Cool
description: The Times Literary Supplement, the erudite British weekly, isnt the first place you would expect to find an outbreak of cool. But for a recent stretch of a few months, its letters page was home to a protracted debate over exactly how cool got cool.

title: Bare Necessity
description: The sneaker seems like a dumbed-down version of the athletic shoe. As casual wear suitable for use in the yard, a nightclub or the office, sneakers compete (ferociously) on the basis of style and signaling power. Picking an athletic shoe, in contrast, has less to do with, say, drooling over stylish designs than with translating exuberant jargon. The Asics GEL-Kinsei 3 draws on pure running science, which evidently involves Spacemaster mesh containing a nanoscale metal film that reacts to weather  not to mention its new Propulsion Trusstic. Adidas adiSTAR Salvation W, meanwhile, offers ForMotion, which I dont understand but is trademarked, as well as an Extended Torsion System, surely better than a Stunted Torsion System. Reeboks ZigTech shoes promise to disburse a wave of energy along the strange-looking sole, reducing wear and tear on leg muscles by up to 20 percent. Just figuring out which model to study on Nikes Web site involves a multistep process concerning running surfaces, the shape of your foot and the specifics of your stride.

title: Book Review Podcast: Charles McGrath on Stieg Larsson

description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar on Friday named Bob Abbey, director of the departments Bureau of Land Management, as interim director of the Minerals Management Service, the scandal-ridden agency responsible for oversight of offshore drilling.

title: Bad Box Office Omens for Prince of Persia
description: Disneys Prince is starting to look like a pauper.

title: Green Bean Season
description: Martha Rose Shulman calls green beans her go-to spring vegetable. The key, she says is proper cooking: four to five minutes of either steaming or par-boiling. Green beans are great on their own or tossed in a salad; they can also be paired with pasta or rice dishes. In this weeks Recipes for Health, she offers five delicious ways to prepare green beans, including a longer cooked Mediterranean bean stew that is packed with flavor.

title: The Philharmonics Challenge: Merely the End of the World

title: Neil Jordans Possible World of the Impossible
description: I DID Ondine, really, because I wanted to see this kind of film, the Irish writer and director Neil Jordan said on a hot, bright afternoon during the Tribeca Film Festival last month. The movie had been screened the night before  People seemed to be responding to it, in a good way, he said  and Mr. Jordan, 60, looked a little tired as he sat down to lunch in the Mercer Hotel and tried to elaborate on what kind of film this very strange creature actually is. Ive done so many things in Ireland about brutality and violence  punishing, unforgiving things, he said. I suppose I wanted to do something just gentle, like those early fairy tales of Yeats and Lady Gregory, which are terribly childish, terribly romantic, quite beautiful.

title: George A. Romero: A Career Undead

Mr. Romeros latest film, appropriately titled Survival of the Dead, keeps his career and those pesky, lumbering zombies, very much alive.

Paying for a Louse-y Problem

title: Around the Grill in Prospect Park
description: Barbecue season unofficially begins Memorial Day weekend. The Daalling family started early in Brooklyn's Prospect Park.

title: Fun to Climb, Until the Temperature Does, Too
description: A bill to make playgrounds safer for children is garnering more attention as parents across New York complain about playground equipment that heats up in the summer sun and scorches their childrens hands and feet.

title: Nick Is Taking Questions
description: Nicholas D. Kristof has spent many years traveling around the world and covering development issues, such as health, education, sex trafficking and civil war.

title: We Three Things | Pass the Marmalade
description: Marmalade is Anglophilia in a pot: fussy, traditional and deliciously tooth-rotting. The word itself sounds like a mysterious ribbon of malaise and bonkers. In addition to bringing a blob of cheer to rainy weekday mornings, it recalls wartime London and lost toy bears, hallucinogens and manga. It is the definition of bittersweet: comforting, but with a sharp rind edge and a dark aftertaste. Watch Fry and Laurie put the marm in marmalade in a famous 1992 sketch.

title: Placing the Blame as Students Are Buried in Debt
description: Like many middle-class families, Cortney Munna and her mother began the college selection process with a grim determination. They would do whatever they could to get Cortney into the best possible college, and they maintained a blind faith that the investment would be worth it.

title: Elliot Allagash
description: My parents always took my side when I was a kid, no matter how much I screwed up. When I smashed my brand new Sega Genesis during a temper tantrum, they blamed the game Sonic the Hedgehog for getting me riled up. When I lost my passport at the airport, they blamed themselves for entrusting it to me. So when I told them what Elliot had done to me, I was pretty surprised by their reaction.

title: After Governors Pardon, Citizenship for Chinese Immigrant
description: It was his application for United States citizenship that derailed the American life of Qing Hong Wu, an information technology executive who had risen from poverty and street crime in Chinatown. He had fulfilled the promise he made to the judge who sentenced him for teenage muggings, but immigration authorities jailed him for mandatory deportation to China, a country he had left at 5.

title: Mickelsons Short Game: An Ensemble Approach to Practice
description: Ever notice how people typically warm up their short game before a round? They drop three balls on the putting green and putt for five minutes. Then they might hit four or five chip shots from just off the green, often practicing from the same spot. Thats better than nothing  and a lot of golfers do nothing before a round  but its not simulating the golf round that is about to begin and its not how professional golfers warm up their short games.

title: Another Way to Keep Track of the Elderly
description: As the population ages, home monitoring devices like Lifeline and others  which keep track of your whereabouts, monitor your bodily functions and remind you to take their medicines  have become more popular. Lifeline, made by Philips, is easy to use. By pushing a button on a pendant, you connect to a home base station, which automatically alerts a central station that theres an emergency. Trained operators with the customers medical history can quickly call for help and alert relatives that somethings wrong.

title: Novelists and Other Artists
description: When novelists write about other art forms, it can serve as a metaphor and an apologia for their own aims. In Steve Martins lovingly precise and miniature Shopgirl, the title character spends her nights making lovingly precise and miniature drawings, while in Don DeLillos monumental and historically minded Underworld, the artist Klara Sax earns her reputation with monumental, historically minded paintings that use decommissioned B-52 bombers as their canvas. (DeLillo loves to write about the arts, especially film and conceptual performance pieces, though the parallels to his own work arent always so explicit.) Artists are at the heart of relatively recent books by Nell Freudenberger, Nick Laird, Olga Grushin and Stacey DErasmo, among many others. Novels about music, meanwhile, are so ubiquitous as to constitute their own genre.

Maybe its because I grew up in the South, eating a home-cooked meal every night of my life  often a slab of meat fired on the back porch  and have long been intrigued by how food brings people together, particularly outdoors, especially in the sizzle of summer.

description: Venus Williamss straight-sets victory over Dominika Cibulkova was a clinic in strong serving and clean play. Cibulkova, a solid counterpuncher who reached the semifinals here a year ago, is a tough opponent, especially on a slow court, but she could never gain a toehold in the match. She did fight to gain three break points, but she only won one of them. Williams broke Cibulkova three times on five break point opportunities.

Many smart observers are picking the Blackhawks, and six games seems to be a popular length (continuing today with this piece by Cam Cole of The Vancouver Sun, Michael Obernauer of the Daily News.

title: Jaclyn Greenstein, Jason Frasco
description: Jaclyn Dawn Greenstein and Jason Benjamin Frasco are to be married Sunday evening at the Forsgate Country Club in Monroe Township, N.J. Rabbi Julie Roth is to officiate.

title: Salony Patel, Maulik Majmudar
description: Salony Mahendra Patel and Dr. Maulik Dilipkumar Majmudar are to be married Sunday at the Hyatt Regency in Greenwich, Conn. Pandit Bharatkumar Jani, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

title: Nianda Clouden, Howard Reid
description: Dr. Nianda Simone Clouden, a daughter of Lystra Small Clouden and Dean R. Clouden of Franklin Park, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Howard Benton Reid II, a son of Jennifer and Mr. Reid Sr. of Rochester. The Rev. Dr. Elmer Gillett, a minister of the Church of the Nazarene, is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton Golf and Spa Resort, Rosehall, in St. James, Jamaica.

title: Barbra Leung, Craig Askinazi
description: Barbra SuPing Leung and Craig Scott Askinazi are to be married Sunday evening at the Fox Hollow, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y. Cantor Sheila Nesis is to officiate.

title: Jamie Beilin, Christopher Joseph
description: Jamie Sarasohn Beilin and Christopher John Joseph were married Saturday at Solage, a resort in Calistoga, Calif. Kimberly A. Thompson, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: American Lawyer for Opposition Figure Is Arrested in Rwanda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Rwandan authorities on Friday arrested an American lawyer who is representing a leading Rwandan opposition figure, the latest sign of an increasingly repressive atmosphere there.

title: Communists Could Gain in Czech Vote
description: PRAGUE  A popular online video here called Convince Granny urges young Czechs to withhold visits to their grandparents unless the old folks agree not to vote for leftist parties like the Communists in Saturdays elections.

description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Some Rouge Dresses Up Courts at Roland Garros
description: PARIS  It really is not red clay. The famous courts of the French Open are white limestone, frosted with a few millimeters of powdered red brick dust.

title: Squatters Wrongs
description: Some friends have discovered that its lucrative to rent their homes as vacation properties. They can make several thousand dollars a week. A few of these families of four and five have asked if they can stay with us, for free, during the rental periods. This seems like a big intrusion and very greedy to me. But theyre close friends, so Im afraid we have to relent. What do you think? Anonymous

title: Kuznetsova Slide Continues With French Open Ouster
description: For most of 2010, Svetlana Kuznetsova has struggled to retain the form that has made her a top-10 presence for four years and a two-time Grand Slam champion. When she arrived to defend her French Open championship, she was the only top-10 player with a losing record for the season. She was 1-3 on clay. A year ago, she was 17-3.

title: Classical Crossover: Dont Forget the Bite
description: Anthony Tommasini and Jon Pareles discussed musical crossovers. Read the previous posts here.

title: Presidents Remarks on the Oil Spill
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on Friday on the government's response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, as released by the White House:

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Our show opens amid the chaos of Friday Prayer in Lahore, Pakistan, where gunmen and suicide bombers stormed two mosques belonging to a minority sect. The attackers seized hostages, killed at least 70 worshipers and wounded 78 others, according to the authorities (Slides 1, 2 and 3). At one mosque, dozens of men were said to have survived by scurrying down a narrow passage and hiding in the basement. The attacks were aimed at the Ahmadi community, which considers itself Muslim but is severely discriminated against under Pakistani law.In Afghanistan, Rahmat Gul of The Associated Press captured an arresting image of a boy running past a burning oil tanker. The vehicle had been carrying fuel supplies for NATO forces (Slide 5).

title: Ristretto | Londons Penny University
description: Last Saturday, Londons Square Mile Coffee Roasters opened their first coffee bar, Penny University, in a storefront just off of Shoreditch High Street. Its small, little more than a burnished wood counter with six stools in a warm if austere room  the decor is limited to a framed map of the world on the wall and the scuff patterns on the floor.

title: Sessions Pushes for Release of Kagan Papers
description: The senior Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee suggested on Friday that the White House is foot-dragging on the release of 160,000 pages of documents relating to Solicitor General Elena Kagans days in the Clinton White House.

title: Visiting Gulf, Obama Tells Residents You Are Not Alone
description: GRAND ISLE, La.  President Obama, on the defensive about the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, made his second trip in the month to Louisianas coast on Friday to monitor troubled efforts to cap the well, and to reassure people in this beleaguered community that he will solve the crisis.

title: Race to the End of the Earth
description: A new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History surveys the 1911 race to the South Pole between the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen, who arrived first, and his British rival, Robert Falcon Scott, who did not survive the expedition.

title: Laura Cuzzillo, Caryn Berman
description: Laura Cuzzillo and Caryn Berman were married Saturday in Des Moines. Judge Robert B. Hanson of Iowas Fifth Judicial District officiated at the Pappajohn Sculpture Garden in Western Gateway Park.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: Ive been taking readers questions here at Diners Journal. Ill be answering in clips and clops over the course of the coming days, and in next Fridays print edition of the Weekend section. Keep them coming!

title: Alexandra Rubenstein, Evan Rachlin
description: Alexandra Nicole Rubenstein, a daughter of Alice Rogoff Rubenstein and David M. Rubenstein of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Evan Lockwood Rachlin, a son of Barbara L. Rachlin and Alan R. Rachlin of Great Falls, Va. The Rev. Jennifer J. S. Brooks, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard.

title: Rupa Magge, Kurt Cross
description: Rupa Magge and Kurt Cross were married Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton in Marina del Rey, Calif. Yogeendra Bhat, a Hindu priest, officiated.

description: Q.

title: Beth Kaplan, Adam Cohen
description: Dr. Beth Meryl Kaplan and Adam Lee Cohen are to be married Sunday at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to lead the ceremony.

title: Mens Shapewear Is a Retail Hit
description: IN its decade on the market, the Spanx line of modern girdles has become both a must-have undergarment and an easy punch line. Celebrities like Tyra Banks, Janeane Garofalo and Wanda Sykes declare their allegiance to Spanx, even as they joke about it.

description: Q.

title: When a Condo Board Seems Invisible
description: Q.

title: Gary Coleman, Diffrent Strokes Star, Dies at 42
description: Gary Coleman, the former child star of the hit television series Diffrent Strokes, who dealt with a well-publicized string of financial and personal difficulties after the show ended, died on Friday in Provo, Utah. He was 42 and lived in Santaquin, a small town near Provo.

description: From our colleagues at Room for Debate:

title: Sohini Ramachandran, Jeremy Mumford
description: Sohini Ramachandran, a daughter of Geetha Ramachandran and Doraiswamy Ramachandran of Gold River, Calif., is to be married Sunday in Cambridge, Mass., to Jeremy Ravi Mumford, a son of David B. Mumford of Boston and the late Erika M. Mumford. The Rev. Scotty McLennan, the dean for religious life at Stanford and a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard, which is to include Christian and Hindu religious and cultural traditions.

title: Sunday Preview
description: The Douro region of Portugal has painterly views, architectural splendor andambitious winemaking.In other words, you get all the joys of Tuscany without all the you musts from friends, says Frank Bruni, a writer at large for The New York Times Magazine, who visited the country in April.

title: University of Virginia Asks Judge to Block Subpoena
description: As we noted briefly in The New York Times on Friday, the University of Virginia has filed a court petition asking a judge to block a subpoena seeking a prominent climate scientists research materials.

title: Granderson Returns, Winn Departs, Russo Stays
description: After missing 24 games with a strained left groin, Curtis Granderson rejoined the Yankees for Friday nights game against Cleveland. His return upgrades the Yankees outfield defense and lengthens their lineup, which over the last week has struggled to hit with runners in scoring position. Granderson batted seventh before he got hurt, but he is hitting second Friday, and Joe Girardi suggested he will continue to hit there while Jorge Posada remains sidelined.

title: Raymond Haysbert Sr., Baltimore Civic Leader and Businessman, Is Dead at 90
description: Raymond V. Haysbert Sr., a former chief executive of the Parks Sausage Company and a longtime leader in Baltimores black community, died Monday in Baltimore. He was 90.

title: Whats an Ex-Frontman to Do?
description: SAUNTERING along Central Park West, Liam Gallagher looked as if hed just stepped off Carnaby Street in London circa 1969. Turned out in a black velvet jacket with an upturned collar, skinny scarf around his neck and hair combed forward all modlike, the former Oasis frontman would have fit in well alongside Brian Jones and Ray Davies in their heyday.

title: Braised Artichokes
description: Mark Bittman makes braised artichokes in a lemon-butter sauce.

title: Judge Urges Resolution in Use of Obama Photo
description: A federal judge on Friday encouraged the parties involved in a dispute over Shepard Faireys Hope poster of Barack Obama, which is based on an Associated Press photograph, to come to a resolution, suggesting that The A.P. was likely to prevail in court.

title: Smackdowns, No Height Limit
description: STEVE RICHARDSON is not squeamish about using the word midget. Then again, Mr. Richardson, who stands 4 foot 4, is not squeamish about a lot of things, like diving headfirst into a pile of broken glass or stapling dollar bills to his genitalia. But lets get to the controversial point first.

title: The Secret Lives of Teachers
description: They're used to instant feedback from their students, but how will these teachers fare during Amateur Night at the Apollo Theater?

title: At TBS, Diversity Pays Its Own Way
description: IN 2004 the cable station TBS, based in Atlanta, rebranded itself with a bold slogan: very funny. What it had to back up the tag line, at the time, were reruns of Seinfeld and Friends  shows that had already proven their hilarity on NBC.

title: House Passes Bill With Dont Tell Repeal
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Friday adopted an annual Pentagon policy bill that includes a provision allowing the Defense Department to repeal the ban on gay and bisexual people from serving openly in the military.

title: The Godparent Trap
description: WEVE grown accustomed to London society scandals over the years on everything from money to sex to dental hygiene. (Who can forget the brouhaha over Martin Amiss pricey new teeth?)

title: Lost, With Laptops, in Psychedelic Space
description: THE Los Angeles electronic music producer Flying Lotus sees his new album, Cosmogramma, as something of a space opera. Its kind of a space epic, he said, very theatrical at times, only in the Star Wars sense of things. Not like Pavarotti Space Viking.

title: Somalias Parliament Chooses a New Speaker
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalias Parliament elected a new speaker on Friday, choosing one of the most powerful businessmen in the country to lead what has often been a fractious and rebellious group of lawmakers.

title: Artichokes Take a Dip in a Pool of Stock
description: WHEN the good artichokes start arriving, I try to come up with something new to do with them. This year, I turned to a time-honored technique, just one Id never applied to artichokes. It will be a permanent addition to my repertory.

title: Thrash, Introspection and a Touch of the Cantor
description: Trash Talk

title: Jessica ONeill, Andrew Cole
description: Jessica Ross ONeill and Andrew Scott Cole were married Saturday at One if By Land, Two if By Sea, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Joanna Fernandez, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Anne on the Move | The Brant Foundation, Greenwich, Conn.
description: Ive never really had a reason to go to Greenwich, Conn., before but now I have a reason to go back: Oscar the Grouch, the solo show by Urs Fischer at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center. The show presents various pieces of Fishers work set in a beautiful stone house on the Greenwich polo field. The awe-inspiring setting (only 45 minutes from New York City!) is nothing compared to the awe-inspiring work that is inside.

title: Avenue Q to Honor Gary Coleman
description: The Off-Broadway musical Avenue Q, whose characters include a fictionalized version of Gary Coleman, the former child star who died on Friday, said it will pay tribute to Mr. Coleman in Fridays performance at New World Stages.

title: Amy Bodnick, Howard Levy
description: Amy Karen Bodnick and Howard Adam Levy are to be married Sunday at the Vanderbilt at South Beach, an event space in South Beach, Staten Island. Rabbi Ronald Barry is to officiate with the assistance of Cantor David F. Tilman.

title: Dance Track Master, Accidental Fan
description: LCD SOUNDSYSTEM, essentially the one-man project of James Murphy, is the connoisseurs dance band. It emerged in 2002 already poking fun at its own snobbishness, with the single Losing My Edge, the hilariously fibbed bragging rights of an aging, anxious hipster. Since then Mr. Murphy, 40, has usually played the part of the guy who might be a little too cool for his own good. (Im losing my edge to the art-school Brooklynites in little jackets and borrowed nostalgia for the unremembered 80s, he sang-spoke on Losing My Edge, which Pitchfork called the 13th best song of the 2000s.)

title: Sarah Palin Finds an Unwelcome Boswell Next Door: Joe McGinniss
description: One of the conceits of literary journalism is that a writer spends as much time in close proximity to his or her subjects as possible. Joe McGinniss, a veteran practitioner, has taken that approach into new realms by moving in next to Sarah Palin in Wasilla, Alaska. The former governor of Alaska and the vice presidential candidate is the subject of his book titled Sarah Palins Year of Living Dangerously, due out in the fall of 2011.

title: Anne Maged, Robert Becker
description: Anne Avery Maged, the daughter of Randy S. Maged and Stephen Maged of Potomac, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Robert Sandler Becker, the son of Abbe D. Becker and Steven R. Becker of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Jonathan A. Schnitzer is to officiate at the Willard Hotel in Washington. The brides maternal grandfather, Cantor Ralph S. Snyder, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Tiramis That Soaks Up Wine Instead of Coffee
description: I hadnt thought of making tiramis since the 1990s when it was all the rage, but in March friends asked me to bring dessert to their party, and it came to mind. Fashionable or not, its perfect for a crowd but also foolproof enough to assemble with my toddler daughter underfoot.

title: Erica De Bruin, Sam Rosenfeld
description: Erica Susanne De Bruin and Sam Hoffmann Rosenfeld are to be married Sunday at the Carousel at Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven. The Rev. James M. Rand, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate.

title: Eurydice and Mary, at the Height of Sorrow
description: After its debut at the Bang on a Can marathon in 2008, Signal, the new-music orchestra conducted by Brad Lubman, built its reputation mainly with the music of Steve Reich and Philip Glass. But this year Mr. Lubman has been expanding the ensembles diet. Last month the group devoted a concert to the idiosyncratic music of Helmut Lachenmann. And at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening Mr. Lubman led Harrison Birtwistles Corridor, a musically and psychologically thorny piece that focuses on one particularly fraught moment in the Orpheus legend, and a new work by Nico Muhly.

title: Tale of a Life, Unabridged
description: BILL CLEGG, literary agent and recovering crack user, is pacing the lobby of the Gansevoort Hotel, a BlackBerry glued to his ear. A security guard gives him over a once-over before holding the elevator door open.

title: Are 5,001 Facebook Friends One Too Many?
description: THE British anthropologist and Oxford professor Robin Dunbar has posed a theory that the number of individuals with whom a stable interpersonal relationship can be maintained (read: friends) is limited by the size of the human brain, specifically the neocortex. Dunbars number, as this hypothesis has become known, is 150.

title: Looking at Love, No Sugarcoating Required
description: This week the Lounge at Dixon Place, a pub cozy enough to make you sentimental for the old East Village and for the way that so many theaters in Europe actually have bars, is the center of a first-time festival celebrating dance from the former Yugoslav republics.

title: How Much for a Bikini That Suits You?
description: J. CREWS Tipped Luxe Halter bathing suit top and its matching bikini bottom in pale coral, with delicate orange piping, is pretty enough. But is it $90 worth of pretty? (Tax not included.)

title: The Forces That Divide, in Motion and Images
description: Its the rare contemporary dance choreographer these days who doesnt have interactive, multimedia goals. (Video is the new scenery.) The YelleB Dance Ensemble, a mostly Israeli group, has ambitious objectives of this sort: the program notes describe a continuing collaboration between the choreographers Ella Ben-Aharon and Edo Ceder, the video artist Adi Shniderman and the architect Matthias Neumann.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell, Dont Pull Your Punches
description: Its been a good week, perhaps too good of a week, for disclosure and transparency. The blogosphere has brought us more than we ever wanted to know about the telephony habits of a South Carolina legislator; we discovered that, in one case, the White Houses efforts to provide employment amid a recession has gotten both the current and a former president into trouble; and we learned that were all going get a peek over the fence and into the lives of Wasilla, Alaskas, most famous resident. There are times when more feels like less

title: Braising Artichokes: Quick and Easy
description: One of my spring challenges is coming up with a new artichoke recipe. This year, I browned and thenbraised, and was astonished at the results. This technique (its not unlike one Ive used for Brussels sprouts for about 10 years) gets rid of the choke early in the process, is only marginally more complicated and just as fast as steaming, and produces a gorgeous, easy-to-eat vegetable. Its going to become my go-to.

title: Sea of Pink at Colonial Is a Show of Support for Breast Cancer Research
description: FORT WORTH  After Amy Mickelsons breast cancer diagnosis a year ago last week led to a swiftly organized Pink Out to raise awareness and funds to fight the disease, the sponsors and organizers of the Crowne Plaza Invitational at Colonial Country Club decided to expand the event this year.

title: On the Street | Bleached
description: This year, white is being worn in a fresh way: oversize shirts over stemlike leggings. Also appearing are neutral and off-white, and whimsical ribbon and lace creations.

title: Musicians Differ in Responses to Arizonas New Immigration Law
description: For the singer Larry Hernandez, the 2010 Billboard Latin Music Awards should have been a moment of pure celebration. But when it came time for Mr. Hernandez to accept his award as new artist of the year, he got drawn into politics, prefacing his remarks with a condemnation of the tough new immigration law that his home state of Arizona had just adopted.

title: Beethoven May Not Have Died of Lead Poisoning, After All
description: Scientists began speculating about what really killed Ludwig van Beethoven almost as soon as he was buried in 1827. He had complained of a wretched existence, with a long list of symptoms: abdominal pain, digestive trouble, colic, chronic bronchitis, foul body odors and extremely bad breath. And of course there was the hearing problem.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a church in Harlem, upstate hipsters, a long-time patron of Sardis, and college dorm rooms of the rich and famous.

title: A Veteran Goes House-Hunting on the G.I. Bill
description: THOUGH Willie Holmes had been traveling back and forth to New York for a few years, primarily for modeling jobs, he had little knowledge of the citys housing market  just vague impressions from his New York friends, most of whom lived in Harlem.

title: A Showcase for the Decorative Arts
description: THE four-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue in the 60s that is home to Barbara and Donald Tober isnt quite as grand as the Museum of Arts and Design, where Ms. Tober served as chairwoman of the board for 15 years.

title: One on One: Brian Lam of Gizmodo.com
description: It was just last month that Gizmodo.com, the gadget blog, published images of the next-generation iPhone that led to a chain of events that sound more like a soap opera than a gadget story. Since then, Gizmodo has been catapulted into the mainstream media, being discussed on Good Morning America and The Daily Show.

title: 40 Years In, a Couple Still Seek New Ideas
description: Performance retrospectives are all the rage right now, with museums and presenters trying to figure out just what it means for body-based art to receive a curatorial backward glance. Danspace Project and several partners jumped into the fray on Thursday night with Retrospective Project I: Regeneration, Part 1 of a three-year survey examining the nearly 40-year collaboration of Eiko & Koma.

title: American Idol Finalists Sign Record Deals
description: Its an annual tradition with American Idol: the finalists are named, a winner is chosen, the public expresses its outrage and questions the fidelity of the voting process, and then the top two performers are signed to record labels. Both Lee DeWyze, who won the shows ninth season on Wednesday night, and Crystal Bowersox, who came in second, are signed to 19 Recordings Limited, the label founded by the Idol creator, Simon Fuller. Billboard.com reported that Mr. DeWyze would release his first post-Idol album on RCA Records, while Ms. Bowersox will release hers on Jive Records. No release date was given for either album.

title: Dance Lifts Fox
description: Fox led the ratings race on Thursday as the seventh season of So You Think You Can Dance made its debut with 8.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Ratings for the Fox reality show were down from the 8.9 million who watched the opening episode last May, yet Fox still managed to average the most viewers on the night by a slim margin. CBS finished close behind, earning the nights largest audiences with reruns of CSI at 9 (8.3 million) and The Mentalist at 10 (9.9 million), but averaged only 4.3 million viewers during the 8 p.m. hour with sitcom repeats. ABC was third with a special at 9, Hollywood Salutes Matt Damon: An American Cinematheque Tribute (3.3 million), followed by a rerun of Greys Anatomy at 10 (3.1 million). NBC and its lineup of mostly reruns placed fourth. The premiere of NBCs new comedy 100 Questions drew 2.5 million viewers at 8:30.

title: Palin Fences Off Author Neighbor
description: If good fences make good neighbors, Sarah Palin and the author Joe McGinniss should get along beautifully. Ms. Palin has just had a 14-foot-high fence, above, erected between her property and the house next door, which Mr. McGinniss has rented for the summer while he researches a book about Ms. Palin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGinniss, the author of The Selling of the President and Fatal Vision, drew criticism from both the right and the left this week when Ms. Palin announced on her Facebook page that he had moved next door to her family on Lake Lucille in Wasilla, Alaska. Ms. Palin told Glenn Beck on his radio show that her husband, Todd, and his friends began working on a fence almost immediately after Mr. McGinniss moved in.

title: No Hair Replacements For London Production
description: The West End wont be keeping its Hair past September, but the London theater district may be getting some interesting hair in another musical. Producers for the West End revival of Hair, a transfer of the Tony-winning Broadway production that brought its American cast (including Darius Nichols, above, as Hud) to Britain, said the show would close after its Sept. 4 performance. The musical had received strong reviews at the Gielgud Theater but its producers, who include Cameron Mackintosh, said a confluence of factors had contributed to its closing. In a statement, they wrote: Cameron and the U.S. producers have decided not to recast Hair when the Broadway company finish their London engagement. The fall in tourism, the ash cloud and the election has caused a drop in audience figures, which has also affected shops, restaurants and hotels across London. Meanwhile, another of Mr. Mackintoshs West End productions may soon gain another familiar American face. The Daily Mail reported that Nick Jonas, the teenage heartthrob and member of the Jonas Brothers, would join the cast of Londons Les Misrables as Marius for three weeks starting June 21. Mr. Jonas played Gavroche in the musicals 2003 Broadway revival.

title: Flintstones Cereal Maker Rocked By Hulk Hogan
description: There is a lot that Hulk Hogan is willing to do in the name of comedy. He will allow himself to be bonked on the head with bowling balls or zapped with electricity, or dress up in a tutu and practice ballet moves with small children (and thats just in the trailer for Mr. Nanny). But what he will not allow is for an apparent cartoon version of himself to be defeated in a wrestling match by the son of a cereal-shilling caveman. Under his real name, Terry Bollea, the Hulkster has filed suit against Post Foods, saying the company used his likeness without permission for a Cocoa Pebbles commercial, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the ad for the Flintstones-themed cereal, Fred Flintstone and Barney Rubble are pitted in a wrestling match against a character called Hulk Boulder, who shares Mr. Bolleas blond hair and horseshoe mustache. When Boulder prevails and reaches for a bowl of cereal, he is grabbed by Barneys baby son, Bamm-Bamm, and thrown around the ring. Citing the complaint filed by Mr. Bollea in federal court in Florida, The Hollywood Reporter said, Hulk Boulder is shown humiliated and cracked into pieces with broken teeth, with the closing banner Little Pieces...BIG TASTE! There was no immediate comment from Post Foods.

title: Back in Arkansas, Clinton Backs Lincoln
description: On a day he was thrust back on center stage nationally, former President Bill Clinton also stumped for Senator Blanche Lincolns re-election, casting the Democratic incumbent as the choice of a calmer electorate at a rally on Friday.

title: Judge Urges Resolution in Use of Obama Photo
description: A federal judge on Friday encouraged the parties involved in a dispute over Shepard Faireys Hope poster of Barack Obama, which is based on an Associated Press photograph, to come to a resolution, suggesting that The A.P. was likely to prevail in court. Mr. Fairey filed suit against The A.P. last year seeking a judges declaration that his poster was protected from copyright infringement claims. The A.P. then filed an infringement suit against Mr. Fairey, who has acknowledged that the poster was based on a photograph of Mr. Obama taken in 2006 by Mannie Garcia, a freelance photographer. On Friday, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York said in a hearing that whether its sooner or later, The Associated Press is going to win the case. Though Mr. Garcia has said that he was not working for The A.P. when he took the photograph, lawyers for The A.P. presented evidence at the hearing, including human resources forms and other documents, that Mr. Garcia was employed by the news service at that time and that the photograph was a work for hire. Geoffrey S. Stewart, a lawyer for Mr. Fairey, said, Mr. Fairey would of course be happy to resolve his differences on an amicable basis with The A.P., but it does not appear The A.P. is interested in it. Dale Cendali, a lawyer for The A.P., said, The A.P. was very encouraged by the hearing today and remains committed to vindicating the rights of photojournalists everywhere. George Carpinello, a lawyer for Mr. Garcia, had asked at the hearing to be removed from representing the photographer, but said in an interview that he would stay on and hoped to meet with The A.P. next week.

title: Pulse
description: China Chow on her style, a flash of red heats up fall, vintage Chanel and more items.

title: Skate Enthusiasts Roll to the River
description: Local skaters, including devotees of the recently closed Brooklyn Banks, are flocking to a 15,000-square-foot, waterfront skate park at Pier 62 in the Hudson River Park in Chelsea.

title: Holiday on Monday Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: New Stadiums Name Could Venture Outside U.S.
description: The Jets and the Giants are talking to two or three international companies about acquiring the naming rights to the generic-sounding new Meadowlands Stadium, the Jets owner, Woody Johnson, said Friday.

title: Morgan Stanley Raises Macks Salary to $2 Million
description: After holding out its pay practices as a rejoinder to Wall Street excess, Morgan Stanley disclosed late Friday afternoon that it will more than double the salary of John J. Mack, the firms chairman, to $2 million a year.

title: Producer Is a Friend to Comic Animals
description: LOS ANGELES  Cinephiles will undoubtedly hold their noses in horror over Marmaduke, a forthcoming live-action adaptation of the newspaper comic. Middlebrow drivel! Cinematic sewage!

title: One Man Won the Battle; the Other Won Hearts
description: What chance did the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen ever have? Yes, he won the race to the South Pole in 1911, as an engrossing exhibition opening on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History reminds us, leaving his British rival, Robert Falcon Scott, far behind. Yes, he made his way over uncharted Antarctic territory to the pole, taking 57 days to do what Scott, beginning from previously mapped terrain, could only do in 81. And yes, Amundsen attained the glory offered every pioneer in that waning era of exploration, without having lost a single man and with 39 of his sled dogs still alive, while Scott and his party, well ...

title: Chic in Review | Venus in the Flesh
description: Ambrosio, AlessandraGoes high fashion. Rocks it.

title: Complexity and Its Discontents
description: As the oil continues to spread in the Gulf of Mexico, I encourage you to read David Brooks column on the bloody crossroads where complex technical systems meet human psychology, as well as the 1996 Malcolm Gladwell article on complexity and hazard that Brooks alludes to.

title: BPs Murky Management of Information
description: From Louisianas tarred beaches to the silty scenes on the seabed a mile beneath the Gulf of Mexico, there have been repeated instances in which BP has tried to limit or delay the flow of information to the public on what is clearly now the biggest oil spill in United States history. Every time BP delays releasing information on its oil gusher and slick, the companys credibility sinks a bit lower.

title: Living in Lighthouse Hill, Staten Island
description: A Staten Island neighborhood that is dense with tall trees that overhang narrow and winding streets.

title: Always the Quick-Change Artist, From Skits to Songs to Stand-Ups
description: Nearly two months into his gig as the opening act on Conan OBriens Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour, Reggie Watts has finally gotten over his disbelief that he was offered the job, and his fear that it would be taken away.

title: Larger Units for a Richard Meier Condo
description: EIGHTEEN units have disappeared from On Prospect Park, the condominium building in Brooklyn designed by Richard Meier. The developer, SDS Procida, has been reworking the buildings interiors, originally expected to contain 114 units, to include more family-sized apartments. Now there are 96 units.

title: Brooklyn Developer Builds Following on Blog
description: THE template for setting up a Web site for a new development goes something like this: start with a flashy animated graphic, add a catchy soundtrack and paste a somewhat vague slogan across the page. Then wait for prospective buyers to roll in.

title: Geranium Friendly
description: TO anyone who has witnessed the Hamptons-bound conga line of cars on the Long Island Expressway, or has headed to Sheep Meadow in Central Park for a weekend picnic only to find the sky almost obscured by flocks of Frisbees, it is clear that New Yorkers are sun-seekers.

title: Lighthouse Hill, Staten Island
description: CHARLES DeSTEFANOS childhood memories of a certain Staten Island neighborhood were of quiet and beauty. So when he decided to move there nearly 40 years later, he was glad, and a bit shocked, to find that nothing had changed.

description: WITH private mortgage insurance considerably tougher to get last year than at any point in decades, many borrowers flocked to loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

Two Dutch teams competed against Iceland and a combination Italy-United States foursome. Did you ever see an auction with 24 calls that ended in only two hearts, admittedly doubled?

description: Word Is Out

title: Staging 1970s TV for 1950s Memories
description: As a hit television show set in the 1950s and early 60s, Happy Days dished up nostalgia to audiences in the 70s and 80s. Its weekly forays into the world of Jefferson High and its students, evoking the era when Sputnik circled the globe and Elvis reigned as the king of rock n roll, proved an irresistible formula for 11 seasons.

title: Our Way of Saying Goodbye
description: TWELVE years ago, after 18 months of marriage, my husband left me unexpectedly, and when I could finally rouse myself to do anything, I booked a flight to Italy. Every time Id been there, Id felt happier, more alive, and I hoped that by speaking another language I would become another person for a while, one whose heart was whole.

title: Old Battle, New Play: Religion vs. Science
description: Joe DiPietro does crowd-pleasing for a living. Mr. DiPietro is the playwright who gave us I Love You, Youre Perfect, Now Change and, on Broadway this season, the musical Memphis. With Creating Claire, now in its world premiere at the George Street Playhouse, he seems to be trying to please both sides of a fierce debate: the one between religion and science, creationism versus evolution.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

description: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School. He also serves as a member of the board of the New York Racing Association.

title: A Night at the Apollo, Starring Teachers
description: JOHN MORO, a walkie-talkie-wielding dean, was patrolling the halls of the Celia Cruz Bronx High School of Music one recent afternoon, droning, Lets go! Ladies, walk and talk please. Lisa Gwasda was leading her choir class in lilting 16th-century madrigals, Paula Kadanoff was teaching a health class on safe sex, and Matthew Daley was coaxing ideas from his senior English class about the use of hubris in Beowulf, Macbeth, Oedipus Rex and Percy Bysshe Shelleys Ozymandias.

title: Taliban Leave Pakistan, but Afghans Repel Them
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After five days of fighting, the Afghan border police, supported by American helicopters, repelled a force of Pakistani Taliban who appeared to have crossed the border to try to carve out a new haven in Afghanistans Nuristan Province, according to Afghan officials.

title: Piers on the Hudson: A Carousel World
description: Five hundred fifty feet off the coast of Chelsea, the eel and the horseshoe crab were having a grand time of it, bobbing along in interspecies embrace. The Atlantic sturgeon was rising and falling on gentle currents. Butterflies were everywhere. And Miley Cyrus was singing.

title: South Korea Expands Aid for Internet Addiction
description: SUWON, South Korea  Neither had a job. They were shy and had never dated anyone until they met through an online chat site in 2008. They married, but they knew so little about childbearing that the 25-year-old woman did not know when her baby was due until her water broke.

title: Its Not Just Drug Dealers Who Buy Prepaid Phones
description: There are reporters in New York who carry a half-dozen prepaid cellphones, loaded with minutes purchased in cash. The numbers are not registered to a real person, nor do they have to be under current law. They are peace of mind for confidential sources who have something to say but dont want to make calls to a phone associated with a reporter or a news organization.

title: Granderson Welcome Sight as the Yankees Seek Depth
description: Before speaking with reporters Friday afternoon, Curtis Granderson tucked in his shirt, slipped two titanium-embedded necklaces around his neck, and reached into his locker to grab his glove and remove his bat from its bag. Stretching was about to begin, and he did not want anything holding him back.

title: And the Parrot Said, Bonjour
description: Aaron Edward (Hotch) Hotchner, 89 by most accounts, came to fame with Papa Hemingway, his 1966 biography of his friend Ernest Hemingway. He recently wrote Paul and Me: 53 Years of Adventures and Misadventures With My Pal Paul Newman. Mr. Hotchner and his wife, Virginia Kiser, live on the Upper East Side and in Westport, Conn., where he spends most weekends, along with an African gray parrot and a flock of peacocks and chickens. CARA BUCKLEY

title: Thai Fondue to Start the Night
description: There is a certain sort of New York evening  varied in its pleasures, meandering in its rhythms, open to spontaneous events  that is good to start with a communal meal. It gives one a base on which to build, and on Monday nights at the Asian bistro Kittichai, at 60 Thompson Street in SoHo, that base is Thai fondue, with diners cooking proteins and veggies in bubbling pots of broth and then bathing them in sauces. Among those at the outset of an excursion into the city you might find trumpeters or European tourists or an impromptu gathering of friends who would soon be parting ways. ALAN FEUER

title: Times Square Terror
description: WHEN a major event occurs with implications for one of the citys ethnic groups, the ethnic press responds  sometimes analytically, sometimes angrily, sometimes defensively. In recent weeks, three newspapers  two Pakistani and one Indian  reported or reflected on the attempt by a Pakistani-American, Faisal Shahzad, to detonate a car bomb in Times Square. Here are excerpts translated with help from the New York Community Media Alliance.

title: GoDaddy Grand Prize Ad
description: A grand prize-winning user generated Go Daddy ad eschewed the company's typical provocative formula.

title: Rare Glimpses of a Pioneer of Performance Art
description: If you are planning an excursion this weekend, you might consider a visit to the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art in New Paltz. It is no exaggeration to say that the Carolee Schneemann retrospective there is one of the best exhibitions in the Hudson Valley. I liked just about everything about it, from the choice of Ms. Schneemann, a veteran New Paltz-based artist, to the judicious selection of her works.

Or rather she was wearing headgear that made it look as if she did, a gag associated with the comedian Steve Martin back in the wild and crazy guys days of Saturday Night Live.

title: Pavin Finds Success on Course Designed to Fit His Game
description: FORT WORTH  When he is playing well, on a course that suits him, Corey Pavin can still make a golf ball do just about anything he wants it to do.

title: Artists Ask the Public to Peek In
description: WHEN the current series of Open Studios in Peekskill began, back in 1998, about a dozen artists invited the public into their work spaces, according to Larry DAmico, an artist who is the president of the Peekskill Arts Councils board of directors.

title: A User-Friendly Film Festival
description: With a 12-member jury whittling 372 entries to 39 this year, the New Jersey International Film Festival is undeniably ambitious. Yet the organizers want to keep it humble.

title: Shell Buying an Oil and Gas Firm for $4.7 Billion
description: Royal Dutch Shell, the British-Dutch oil and gas producer, said Friday that it had struck a deal to buy most of the assets of East Resources for $4.7 billion in cash, moving into the coveted sector of natural gas contained in shale deposits.

title: Harsh Words for BP, Helpful Words for Propane
description: When it comes to which products chefs choose to endorse, timing can be everything.

title: Nepal Avoids Crisis in Deal to Extend Parliament
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepal averted political chaos on Friday when the leading political parties reached a last-minute agreement that prevented the dissolution of Parliament and provided another year for the Himalayan nation to complete its peace process.

title: South Africa: Paper Apologizes for Cartoon of Muhammad
description: The Mail & Guardian said Friday that it had underestimated the depth of anger ignited by a cartoon it published last week that depicted the Prophet Muhammad lying on a psychiatrists couch with a thought bubble over his head that said, Other prophets have followers with a sense of humor! The weekly said it regretted the sense of injury it caused many Muslims. The cartoon was by Jonathan Shapiro, known as Zapiro, whose sharp satiric pen has gouged many a politician.

title: Haiti: Ex-Director of Prison Is Taken Into Custody
description: The former director of the prison in Les Cayes, where a dozen or more inmates were shot dead on Jan. 19, was taken into custody by the judicial police in Port-au-Prince on Thursday, according to a United Nations official. It did not appear that the former director, Sylvestre Larack, was under arrest as of Friday evening, but he remained in isolation at the judicial police headquarters and he was not free to leave, the official said. After the inmate deaths in Les Cayes, Mr. Larack had been promoted to run the countrys largest prison, the national penitentiary in Port-au-Prince. Last Sunday, The New York Times published a report on the killings at Les Cayes, indicating that the authorities had shot unarmed detainees and then sought to cover it up. This provoked the Haitian president, Ren Prval, to establish a joint Haitian-United Nations commission of inquiry, and Mr. Larack, who was found last month to have lied to police investigators about the killings, is being questioned once again.

title: Workers Squeezing Honda With Especially Costly Strike
description: FOSHAN, China  In going on strike at a transmission factory, workers here have Honda by the jugular, although it was not entirely clear at the employees dormitory on Friday that they realized this.

His compelling research resonates in another era of budget-cutting and data-driven decision-making.

title: N.C.A.A. Is Looking Into Former Kentucky Player
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Two years ago, Eric Bledsoe was a star point guard without the grades to meet the N.C.A.A.s minimum standards and needing to find a new high school. He solved both problems by moving to A. H. Parker High School and now, after one season at the University of Kentucky, he is awaiting a lucrative payday in next months N.B.A. draft.

title: An Enigma to the End, Artest Joins Lakers Lore
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Somewhere along the way, the villain became the eccentric. Ron Artest morphed from unpredictably dangerous to merely unpredictable. His soundtrack is no longer the Darth Vader theme, but Looney Tunes.

title: Sand, Surf and Quesadillas
description: Pops Garage, a colorful taquera on the Boardwalk in Asbury Park, has a funky, south-of-the-border vibe. Theres nothing fancy on the menu  tacos, burritos, quesadillas and the like  which takes its cue from the kind of casual food you might find at a Mexican beach resort.

title: Specialty of the House? Improvisation
description: FOR years, the residents of Ho-Ho-Kus, Glen Rock, Ridgewood and other nearby towns in Bergen County had Kevin Oppici and his eclectic American cuisine pretty much to themselves, if only for lunch, takeout or catered events. Then, in September 2008, he started serving dinner, and the secret began to get out.

title: The Moynihan Future
description: Providence, R.I.

title: When Afghans Seek Medical Aid, Tough Choice for U.S.
description: KHAN NESHIN, Afghanistan  Five-year-old Sadiq was not a casualty of war. He was simply unlucky. The boy had opened a sack of grain at his home early on Wednesday morning, and a pit viper coiled inside lashed up and bit him above the lip.

title: Emerging Centers Reach Premier Stage
description: Crosby versus Ovechkin has been the N.H.L.s marquee matchup for some time  in the regular season, in the playoffs, in the Olympics, in next years Winter Classic. But now the Stanley Cup finals are here, and two other young captains have taken hockeys center stage with their skill, fire and leadership.

title: Jamaica Accused of Brutality in Hunting Suspect
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  The search for her sons body brought Lynette Armstrong down a cemetery path in west Kingston on Friday, past bushes of Chinese honeysuckle and bloodstained clothes to a jumble of 24 wooden coffins, strewn this way and that.

title: As Dont Ask Fades, Military Faces Thorny Issues
description: For opponents of the ban against homosexuals serving openly in the military, the steps by Congress this week to repeal the policy, known as dont ask, dont tell, were a major victory. But now they are girding for what may be an equally difficult task: the transition to a force where straight and openly gay servicemen and women live, work and fight alongside one other.

title: Dealing With Pakistan
description: Nine years after the 9/11 attacks, the United States is still trying to figure out how to manage relations with Pakistan  and what mix of inducements and public and private pressures will persuade Islamabad to fully commit to the fight against extremists.

title: Food for Thought
description: Its been a long time since Ive eaten a meal that I could honestly call motivational. But after a mind-bending lunch of macrobiotic soup, ancient grains and agave-sweetened smoothies on the garden patio at the O2 Live Food Caf, I vowed to start eating more thoughtfully.

title: A Renovated Menu, With a Wealth of Choices
description: SOME might remember the Toska brothers, Rui and Aris, who in 1988 transformed the Hearth restaurant into LEurope, introducing a menu of fancy French-Continental dishes  still in their butter-and-cream heyday  to Vista, then a sleepy area of South Salem. Many years and several renovations later, Jeff Toska (Ariss son) took over the restaurant, renamed it One Twenty Three (the number of the route its on), and gave the menu a decidedly contemporary cast, with most sauces thin or sheer and salads galore.

title: Owners Bet on Raising the Rent, and Lost
description: The first signs of financial turmoil came at Riverton Houses in Harlem.

title: On Graduation Day, Seniors Take Time to Feel Like Kindergartners Again
description: When Nitya Rajendran started kindergarten, she didnt talk until November. Shed point and wave, said her teacher, Rick Parbst. This year she was the lead in Trinity Schools spring musical and decided to translate parts of The Iliad from ancient Greek. Shes headed to Georgetown University in September.

title: Unintelligent Design
description: There doesnt seem to be anything terribly unethical about the White House offer of an unpaid advisory position to Joe Sestak if he would bow out of the Pennsylvania Democratic primary, in which he later defeated Senator Arlen Specter. There does, however, seem to be something strikingly unintelligent about it.

description: IN THE GULF OF MEXICO  The ocean caught fire.

title: Brewers May Be Petersons Toughest Task Yet
description: MILWAUKEE  The Brewers pitchers began their workout Friday at 3 p.m., more than an hour before the team was due on the field for stretching. With the roof open at Miller Park, the pitchers did their tossing, running and core conditioning under the supervision of Rick Peterson, the former Mets pitching coach who joined Milwaukee last winter.

title: Judge Grants Injunction Against Paterson Furlough Plan
description: A federal judge granted a preliminary injunction on Friday blocking Gov. David A. Paterson from furloughing tens of thousands of state workers.

title: Will That Be Cash? Or Big Bank Fees?
description: Small retailers have complained for decades about the seemingly arbitrary fees that they are required to pay Visa and MasterCard for processing debit transactions. The Senate finally responded earlier this month when it added price controls on the controversial fees to its financial reform bill.

title: Endangered Parks
description: There are more than 13 million acres of state parks in the United States. The national park system is far bigger  some 84 million acres  but state parks are far more heavily used, if only because they are our neighborhood parks. As states look for ways to slash budgets during this recession, state parks are in serious trouble.

description: A group led by Centerbridge Partners on Friday won the bidding for Extended Stay, a hotel chain, capping a monthslong battle for control, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

It is June 6, not Sunday, and therefore the entry should not have been included among the Last Chance theater listings.

title: A Potential Obama Ally Becomes an Outspoken Foe on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Luis V. Gutierrez was all set to be a friend of the Obama administration, a point man for the White House among Latinos. A nine-term Democrat, he had cut his political teeth in the wards of Chicago, just as Barack Obama did, and the two knew each other from their parallel early careers in Illinois.

description: The House passed a bill on Friday that would end a tax break for executives of investment funds, leaving hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capitalists scrambling to ease the effects of the bill before it is taken up by the Senate next month.

title: The Politicking Behind an Offer to a Specter Foe
description: WASHINGTON  The White House lavished attention on Senator Arlen Specter when he switched parties last year, but Rahm Emanuel realized he had a problem. To secure the seat for the Republican-turned-Democrat, Mr. Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, wanted to clear the path for Mr. Specter to win his new partys nomination.

description: KENNER, La.  New details emerged Friday about the frantic final actions of the crew aboard the Deepwater Horizon oil rig after it exploded April 20, killing 11 workers and triggering the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: 200 Patients Whose Heart Tests Were Never Reviewed by Doctors Died
description: More than 200 heart patients at Harlem Hospital Center died after undergoing heart tests that were never read by doctors, according to a hospital employee briefed on Friday on an investigation into the handling of 4,000 tests in the past three years.

title: A Vipers Strike, a Dying Boy and a Choice for the Marines
description: Military efforts to evacuate wounded civilians are complicated in an impoverished, hazardous land.
