description: Charli Carpenter, left, of the University of Massachusetts-Amherst and Daniel Drezner of Tufts University debate assassinating Anwar Al-Awlaki.

title: No Terror Evidence Against Some Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  The 48 Guantnamo Bay detainees whom the Obama administration has decided to keep holding without trial include several for whom there is no evidence of involvement in any specific terrorist plot, according to a report disclosed Friday.

title: Another Blow to Guantnamo Plan
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee voted to bar the construction of a military detention center in Thomson, Ill., in a further blow to the Obama administrations fading hopes of shuttering the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The committee met behind closed doors on Thursday to vote on amendments to the 2011 national defense authorization bill. On Friday, it released a summary of the results, which included the prison issue. The Obama administration has proposed spending $350 million to renovate a prison in Thomson and transfer dozens of Guantnamo detainees there. The House version of the bill contains a similar restriction, so the Senate committees decision means the final package is virtually certain to include such a ban.

title: Islands Trout Rodeo Is Victim of Spill, and Thats Not the Least of It
description: GRAND ISLE, La.  The directors of the Grand Isle Speckled Trout Rodeo had sold 500 tickets to the Memorial Day weekend event when the oil washed up on the beach here last week. They had paid for the band and the food, the visors and the door prizes.

title: 189 Nations Reaffirm Goal of Ban on Nuclear Weapons
description: UNITED NATIONS  Hard-fought negotiations over the future of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty ended here on Friday with 189 nations reaffirming their commitment to eliminating all nuclear weapons and setting a new 2012 deadline for holding a regional conference to eliminate unconventional weapons from the Middle East.

title: Gaza Flotilla Organizers Protest Israeli Response to Their Mission
description: Organizers of a flotilla of up to nine vessels carrying hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists and thousands of tons of supplies for Gaza protested on Friday against what they called an Israeli disinformation campaign aimed at their mission. Israel has vowed to stop the boats from reaching Gaza, which is controlled by the Islamic militant group Hamas, and insists that there is no humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian coastal enclave. For over four years, the organizers said in a statement, Israel has subjected the civilian population of Gaza to an increasingly severe blockade, resulting in a man-made humanitarian catastrophe of epic proportions. The boats were expected to approach the coast sometime over the weekend. The aim, the organizers said, was to break through the illegal Israeli blockade in non-violent direct action.

title: A Perkins Technical Could Prove Costly
description: The Celtics Kendrick Perkins had better watch out  after his next technical foul, he will be forced to sit out a game. Having accumulated six technicals over the course of 16 games  with as many as nine left to play  he had better make sure his suit is pressed, as hell need something to wear while sitting on the sideline. It isnt hyperbole to say that a technical foul at a critical juncture can alter the course of this years playoffs.

title: Ex-Officers Conviction for Murder Is Reinstated
description: Just 20 months after the murder conviction of a former New York City police officer was overturned, an appeals court reinstated it this week and ordered him sent back to prison.

title: Yankees Find Stride, With a Few Adjustments
description: The Yankees favorable schedule, with 13 of 16 games against the three worst teams in baseball, gives them a chance to fatten their victory total and improve their standing in the American League East. That is one way to look at it. Here is another view, courtesy of General Manager Brian Cashman:

title: A New Pragmatism Behind the Catwalk
description: PARIS  A postrecession strategy likely to define luxury brand management for the early 21st century has emerged from a week packed with designer changes at European fashion houses.

title: England: Serial Killing Suspect Calls Himself Crossbow Cannibal
description: A 40-year-old man accused of murdering three prostitutes in the northern city of Bradford identified himself as the crossbow cannibal on Friday at his first court appearance. British newspapers have compared Stephen Griffiths, left, a Ph.D. student in criminology, with Peter Sutcliffe, the Bradford-based man known as the Yorkshire Ripper, who was convicted in 1981 of killing 13 women, including several prostitutes.

title: France: Tombs of German Soldiers From World Wars Are Vandalized
description: The tombs of nearly 100 German soldiers killed during the First and Second World Wars were desecrated on Thursday night at a cemetery on land in Eastern France that once belonged to Germany. Unidentified vandals smashed crosses on 95 of the 1,238 German graves at the Guebwiller cemetery, which holds the remains of about 2,500 French and German war veterans. An offensive slogan was also left on one grave. President Nicolas Sarkozy of France called the act revolting and cowardly in a letter to President Horst Khler of Germany.

title: France: Noriega Request Rejected
description: A Paris appellate court on Friday rejected a request by the former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to be freed from prison pending a late June trial, deeming him a flight risk. Mr. Noriega has been held here since his extradition last month from the United States. He is to be tried on charges that he laundered $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in 1988 and 1989; Mr. Noriega has said the money came from payments from the Central Intelligence Agency, which once considered him a valued asset; his brothers inheritance; and his wifes personal fortune. A French court convicted him in absentia on the same charges in 1999. A lawyer for Mr. Noriega said his client would appeal.

title: China: Sentencing in Mine Death
description: Three men and one woman have been sentenced in Yunnan Province for killing a mentally challenged man in a mine, making it look like an accident and pretending to be family members of the victim to get compensation from the mine owner, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The four killed Cai Qianwen in October 2009 by shoving him down a mine shaft, according to the court in Yunnan. They then approached the mine owner and asked for $42,500 in compensation, saying they were relatives of Mr. Cai. The owner called the police. Two assailants were given suspended death sentences, and two others were sentenced to 15 years in prison. It is unclear whether the case is related to the arrests in late 2009 of nine people in Sichuan Province who were accused of killing or helping kill mentally challenged people in mines to extort money. The crimes resemble the plot of Blind Shaft, a 2003 Chinese movie.

title: Saturdays Epic Battles
description: The most dramatic moments in sports often take place when the outcome cannot be determined in regulation. And in a tennis match, the pulse quickens (for both players and fans) in extended, no-tiebreaker final sets.

title: Radio Program About Faith Defies the Skeptics
description: ST. PAUL  Not yet 30 and a veteran of two lives already, Krista Tippett retreated in the summer of 1988 to a rented room on an island off Spain. There, perhaps, her next direction would make itself known.

title: Holiday on Monday  Memorial Day

Tucked among mansions in this affluent Boston suburb, Pine Manor College was long a finishing school, a place for well-heeled women to receive an education and for Ivy League men to find wives  earning it the pejorative nickname Pine Mattress. Photographs around campus show alumnae clad in white gloves, pearls and shirtwaist dresses.

description: LONDON  Britains new coalition government suffered its first major political reverse on Saturday when the cabinet minister responsible for finding deep budget cuts resigned over newspaper disclosures involving his personal parliamentary expenses.

description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Breaking Down Henin-Sharapova
description: Darkness halted the scintillating prizefight of a match between Justine Henin and Maria Sharapova, with the match knotted at a set all. On a cold, drizzly day, Henin began the match with authority, winning the first set 6-2 with superior court coverage and better control of her sweeping ground strokes. Sharapova could not string together enough points to quell Henins momentum.

title: Manuel Defends Choice, Regardless of Final Score
description: MILWAUKEE  Jerry Manuel played pieces of two seasons for the Montreal Expos, 1980 and 81, barely enough for anyone to remember.

title: With a Grittier Style, Petrova Advances
description: Tennis experts often describe Nadia Petrova as the best current player yet to win a major. She wallops the ball off both sides, using her height and leverage to dominate her opponents. Shes beaten every big name player, but has a reputation for wilting under the bright lights of a Grand Slam. Sadly, she is known more for her memorable meltdowns (the Melanie Oudin match at last years United States Open) than for her incredible playing.

title: Reaching Out
description: Female Marines in Helmand Province have the mission of winning over the Afghan women who are culturally off limits to American men.

title: The Importance of the Governor's Race

title: In Ohio, Gauge for Midterms, Economy Rules
description: NEW ALBANY, Ohio  Good economic news has been virtually extinct in Ohio for a few years now, but Gov. Ted Strickland suddenly finds himself overseeing small yet hopeful moments of recovery: ribbon-cutting ceremonies, groundbreaking events for business parks and televised announcements that jobs are slowly returning to the state.

title: A Review of Bledsoe in Alabama
description: The head of the Alabama High School Athletic Association said on Saturday that the association would analyze a report that a former high school coach paid the rent for a player who wound up at Kentucky.

title: Duke vs. Notre Dame: Result Will Be a Mens Lacrosse First
description: BALTIMORE  The N.C.A.A. mens lacrosse tournament has long been dominated by one of the most persistent monopolies in sports. Only four teams  Syracuse, Johns Hopkins, Princeton and Virginia  have won the title since 1992. Despite the games rapid growth, it has flourished in the same areas and been dominated by teams wearing familiar jerseys.

title: Co-Leaders Take Aim at Colonials Course Mark

description: Jennifer Bestor is a fifth-generation Republican, a stay-at-home mother from Menlo Park who was concerned about budget cuts at her sons school. So she started looking into the property taxes that underwrite the schools. What she found disturbed her.

title: A Finger on the Pulse in Daly City
description: Benito Vergara, a Philippine-born Web editor for a financial services company, is the author of Pinoy Capital: The Filipino Nation in Daly City." A former assistant professor of Asian-American Studies at San Francisco State University, Mr. Vergara, 39, lives in the East Bay. In the mid-1990s he lived in Daly City for a year and a half, working on his Ph.D. thesis in anthropology. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: This Time, Its Halladay Whos Perfect
description: In his second career start, for Toronto in 1998, Roy Halladay lost a no-hit bid with two outs in the ninth inning. He did not ascend steadily to greatness, falling back to Class A ball before rising to regain his dominance of the American League.

title: Embracing the Renaissance and YouTube, Too
description: A few days after Jay Leno had seen the all-male a cappella ensemble Chanticleer singing Christmas songs on the Today show last December, he poked fun at it during the monologue on his own show. After asking his audience if it had ever heard of the group (a voice offstage answered no), Mr. Leno showed a clip of group members singing, and then cut to a shot of himself in white tie, holding a score and singing in falsetto.

title: G.O.P. Senate Candidate From Illinois Acknowledges Incorrect Reference to Award
description: CHICAGO  Mark S. Kirk, the Republican candidate seeking the United States Senate seat once held by President Obama, has acknowledged that his official biography incorrectly listed a prestigious military award that he never received.

title: Spot Start on Road Is the Latest Pothole
description: MILWAUKEE  On the Milwaukee Brewers annual Negro leagues tribute night, the Mets showed they were perfectly capable of losing on the road in anybodys gray uniforms, not just their own.

description: CHICAGO  They played the opener of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night, and a game of river hockey broke out.

title: Bryant Leads Lakers to Another Finals
description: PHOENIX  His arms were stretched wide, like wings. Kobe Bryant was soaring, smiling, his gaze fixed firmly on the horizon. There was nothing left for the Phoenix Suns to do or say, except goodbye and good luck.

title: After Top Kill, Few Options to Cap Well
description: The top kill procedure for choking off the gushing seabed well in the Gulf of Mexico was not quite the last best chance, but close. Now that it has failed, BP, with authorization from the Obama administration, is moving to cut away the tangle of pipe from the well and install a small containment cap, called the lower marine riser package.

title: China Balks at Criticism of North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Resisting pressure from South Korean and Japanese leaders during two days of talks, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China gave no public hint on Sunday that his government was ready to join in reproaching North Korea over the sinking of a South Korean warship.

title: French Glamour Comes to Hong Kong
description: For much of the month of June, Hong Kongers will be able to get an up close and personal look at one of Frances most beautiful exports: their women. From June 3 to 23, 20 French films featuring some of the countrys most famous and luminous actresses, past and present, will be showing at two cinemas in Hong Kong, as a part of Le French May, the citys annual French culture festival.

title: Schott Op-Chart: Hook, Line and Signaler
description: Since the 1930s, construction workers called flaggers or signalers have used a private vocabulary of hand signals to communicate from the ground with crane operators. These hand signals ensure that loads are maneuvered, sometimes at dizzying heights, with all due regard for the safety of pedestrians, workers and cargo.This July, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is set to issue revised regulations for crane operations  which may include changes to the way signalers are trained and certified. Kevin McGuire, a master rigger who has worked for Con Edison for 38 years, offers a guide to what aspiring flaggers need to know.

title: Takahashis Spot Appears Secure

Her rise back to No. 2 in the world this spring, and her strong play in the opening rounds, turned Williams into an emerging tournament favorite. She had buzz.

description: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

title: Breaking Down Henin-Sharapova, Part II
description: Justine Henin pulled off a great escape to advance to the fourth round by defeating Maria Sharapova in a rollercoaster third set. Down, 0-2, and serving at 0-40, Henin had bleak prospects, as Sharapova was playing with assertiveness and confidence. She was fortunate on the first break point, as Sharapova netted a routine backhand, pulling up too soon to make a loose error.

title: A Time Capsule, Captured on a Bars Business Card
description: The strangest business cards I ever saw used to be in circulation at the Paris Blues Bar and Lounge, a drinking establishment at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 121st Street in Harlem. Printed in vivid royal blue, they listed not only the proprietors name  Samuel J. Hargress Jr.  but the names of every member of his staff.

description: ISTANBUL  With 17 laps left in the Turkish Grand Prix here on Sunday, and after spending most of the race in second place behind the leader, Sebastian Vettel made a brash attempt to pass him and the two cars collided, throwing Vettel out of the race.

title: NATO Has High Hopes for Afghan Peace Council
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Western leaders are banking on a national peace council set to begin here on Wednesday to start a new chapter in Afghanistans political life, bringing the country together and strengthening President Hamid Karzai, even as security deteriorated on Sunday in several areas of the country.

title: Day After Being Hit in Head, Huff Is Feeling Good
description: The first thought that popped into David Huffs mind as he lay facedown and motionless on the Yankee Stadium mound Saturday was to ask the training staff to call his brother, Tim. Huff recited the cellphone number, then stopped to correct himself.

title: Sidekick No More: Eubanks Starts Post-Leno Life
description: Kevin Eubanks ended his 15-year tenure as musical director of The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on Friday with a song, alone on acoustic guitar. It was Adoration, an original ballad flecked with classical filigree, and he gave it a warmly dignified calm. He seemed unhurried and introspective, already pulling away from the frenetic clamor of the show. The moment played out like a curtain call, when an actor leaves his character in the wings and you think, So this is who he really is. Not that you actually know him any better.

title: In the Wee, Steamy Hours, a Wash of Languorous Pop
description: Most concerts engage just two senses, hearing and sight. By the time Twin Sister took the stage early Saturday morning at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, smell and touch were also very much in play.

title: Looking for a New Narrative of Founding Fathers
description: Its one of the curiosities of American history that there is no definitive single-volume chronicle of the Revolutionary War, the kind of serious but approachable book that would grasp the conflict in the way that James M. McPhersons Battle Cry of Freedom grasps the Civil War. One good schoolmaster is of more use than a hundred priests, the founding father Thomas Paine thundered. This war still awaits its great popular educator.

title: 700-Hour Silent Opera Reaches Finale at MoMA
description: At 5 p.m. Monday one of the longest pieces of performance art on record, and certainly the one with the largest audience, comes to an end. Since her retrospective opened at the Museum of Modern Art on March 14, the artist Marina Abramovic has been sitting, six days a week, seven hours a day in a plain chair, under bright klieg lights, in MoMAs towering atrium. When she leaves that chair Monday for the last time, she will have clocked 700 hours of sitting.

title: A Crack in the Stoics Armor
description: In a remarkably prescient moment in September, 1965, James B. Stockdale, then a senior Navy pilot shot down over Vietnam, muttered to himself as he parachuted into enemy hands, Five years down there at least, Im leaving behind the world of technology and entering the world of Epictetus. As a departing graduate student at Stanford, Stockdale received a gift of Epictetuss famous Enchiridion, a 1st-century Stoic handbook. The text looked esoteric, but in his long nights aboard the U.S.S. Ticonderoga, he found himself memorizing its content. Little did he know then that Stoic tonics would become his salvation for seven and a half years as the senior prisoner of war, held under brutal conditions by the North Vietnamese at Hoa Lo prison, the Hanoi Hilton.

title: Glee in Concert Favors Passion Over Plotlines
description: Perky to the max, the television phenomenon Glee shed its plotlines and flaunted its young troupers gusto and its karaoke repertory for Glee Live! on Friday night, starting a sold-out three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall that completes a four-city tour.

title: The Wild and the Tamed
description: The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon has the trick of making New York City Ballets audience happy. He served as the companys resident choreographer for most of the last decade. On Saturday night, returning to choreograph for City Ballet for the first time in two years, he gave it a world premiere that brought many to their feet in a full-throated ovation.

title: Teixeiras Confidence Shows in Homer
description: Mark Teixeira would rather not tease the Yankees like this. Honest, he wouldnt.

title: A Tragic Day for a Faith Under Siege
description: TORONTO  Lets put our tears into our Sajda and pray that God may give the Taliban hearts, the leader at my local Toronto Ahmadiyya mosque said during Friday prayer. He was urging the congregation to shed their tears during the critical Sajda step of prayer, while kneeling down and touching their foreheads to the ground.

title: Architect Maya
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Is there anyone joining me here today? Or are you all otherwise engaged  barbecuing with friends and family, at a race or, more appropriately, honoring those who gave their lives in battle?

title: Djokovic Tries to Become Relevant Again
description: Its not easy to come up with a plausible Roland Garros final that ends with a player not named Rafael Nadal or Roger Federer holding up the mens final trophy. There is a sleeper in the draw, however, one who incredibly has a combined 12 victories over those two since 2007. Hes won a major, and tournaments on red clay in Europe. And he certainly isnt afraid of either the worlds best player or the four-time champion. So why is this player given little chance of winning the title? Because hes Novak Djokovic, and there is a gaping hole in his head-to-head record against Nadal and Federer.

title: Womens Works and a Tempest at Bargemusic
description: The neoLIT Ensemble, founded in 2008, is one of the newest additions to the parade of contemporary-music groups in New York. Like most such ensembles, this is a flexible bunch: the full roster includes mezzo-soprano, flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano, with the musicians playing in whatever combinations their programs demand. At Bargemusic on Wednesday, the group performed without its singer.

title: Resignation of Gay Minister Jolts New British Government
description: LONDON  In a political upheaval that shook Britains new coalition government and prompted fresh debate about the acceptance gays find in the countrys public life, a widely admired cabinet minister resigned on Saturday after newspaper disclosures about his taxpayer-refunded rental payments to a long-term gay partner.

title: Dickeys Knuckler Returns Just in Time

Dickey sat at the far end of the visiting dugout engrossed in a paperback version of Life of Pi, an adventure novel about an Indian teenager who forms an uneasy yet necessary alliance with a Bengal tiger.

description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  When the Dock Street Theater opened here in February 1736, it was ahead of the Colonial curve: the first purpose-built theater building in America, according to publicity materials of the Spoleto Festival USA (though some scholars see the history differently). But it was already playing catch-up in Charleston.

title: The Hunt for Liberia's Assets
description: The Liberian government is on the hunt for the millions, perhaps even billions, of dollars it believes was pilfered by Charles Taylor, the country's former president who is now on trial at The Hague.

description: SECAUCUS, N.J. title: Angry Over Okinawa Deal, Party Quits Coalition
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A small leftist party in Japan resigned from its governing coalition on Sunday, dealing an embarrassing blow to the increasingly unpopular prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, as a new poll showed half of Japanese want him to resign.

title: The Case for Soderling Over Federer
description: Is it time to go out on limb and predict the unthinkable? After twelve straight losses, is Robin Soderling ready to beat Roger Federer? Is Federers streak of Grand Slam semifinals about to end? Is Soderling ready for prime time? As an unabashed admirer of Federer I can answer yes to all of these questions. The big-hitting Soderling is ready to step up to greatness. After all, familiarity does breed contempt, and Soderling is far from an obeisant underling on the tour. I predict that he will take the reigning French Open champion down in four sets.

title: Ex-Defense Chief Leads in Colombia
description: BOGOT, Colombia  A scion of a powerful Colombian family comfortably won more votes than an eccentric former mayor of Bogot in presidential elections on Sunday, but narrowly failed to get the majority needed to prevent a runoff election in June between the two men.

title: Child Brides Escape Marriage, but Not Lashes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The two Afghan girls had every reason to expect the law would be on their side when a policeman at a checkpoint stopped the bus they were in. Disguised in boys clothes, the girls, ages 13 and 14, had been fleeing for two days along rutted roads and over mountain passes to escape their illegal, forced marriages to much older men, and now they had made it to relatively liberal Herat Province.

title: An Untapped Phone Call in Italy? Its Possible
description: ROME  In Italy, youre nobody if your phone isnt tapped. Or, as Beppe Grillo, Italys leading political provocateur and blogger, put it: This is a nation where if you cant be blackmailed, youll never get ahead.

title: This Promising Day
description: Memorial Day is a very short season  one day, if youre strict about it; three days, if youre not. It isnt spring, and it isnt quite summer. Its a season for noticing the transitions taking place around you, human and otherwise. Follow the Taconic north from New York City, and the grass is already ripe and taller than a standing woodchuck. title: Numberplay: A Fond Farewell to Martin Gardner

When I first encountered Martin Gardners columns in Scientific American as a schoolboy many years ago, my reaction was one of awe. Here was pure intelligence incarnate, I thought, coming up with puzzles of mind-bending difficulty month after month and explaining the ideas behind them with crystal clarity. I was convinced that Martin Gardner was the smartest man in the world. The profusion of his writings, their quality and the sheer length of time that he kept on producing them, month after month, were just mind-boggling. When he retired from Scientific American in 1981, I was convinced that no one could fill his shoes. Although I much admired Douglas Hofstadter, who replaced him, and was a great fan of Gdel, Escher, Bach I just knew that no one else could keep this up for as long as Martin Gardner had. And so it proved to be. It is a tribute to Martin Gardners oeuvre that the final considered impression that he left is not very different from the one seen through the eyes of a hero-worshiping adolescent.

title: Communing With a Master Choreographer in a Long Farewell
description: MONTREAL  To watch performances by a dance company that perfectly understands the behests of its living choreographer can seem a supreme and many-layered thrill. Very occasionally, however, the level actually rises when the choreographer dies. New York City Ballet often danced astoundingly in the five years after George Balanchines death; some of his works  Divertimento No. 15 and Symphony in Three Movements for example  looked better than before, and individual dancers gave stratospheric performances of particular roles. After Merce Cunningham died in July, it likewise seemed in every sense that there could be nothing better to do than to watch his company, which danced some Events in New York the next weekend.
